text: David Leatherbarrow
label: Title

text: What is modern architecture?’ Strange as it may seem to ask this question today,
label: Paragraph

text: after more than a century of answers by the movement's protagonists, apologists,
label: Paragraph

text: and historians, the need to rethink this body of work is no less pressing in our time
label: Paragraph

text: than it was in the past. No doubt there exists some consensus about which projects
label: Paragraph

text: were especially important and influential; this volume presents 50 that will, we
label: Paragraph

text: trust, seem sensible choices to most readers, more or less. But the basis for that
label: Paragraph

text: consensus, the reasons why some, and not other projects, have been judged to
label: Paragraph

text: be especially, if variously, modern are not self-evident. The date of construction
label: Paragraph

text: or of conception is not enough, for not everything that was built or designed in
label: Paragraph

text: the twentieth century expressed the modernity of the time. Nor were the buildings
label: Paragraph

text: that were said to be modern consistently so, for formal elements and kinds of artic-
label: Paragraph

text: ulation that appeared to observers as novel often concealed techniques of construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion that had been used for centuries. One should not say that adherence to pre-
label: Paragraph

text: modern ways of building occurred by accident, or that it was a result of a desire to
label: Paragraph

text: deceive on the part of designers or critics; some measure of continuity is inescap-
label: Paragraph

text: able in the sorts of historical change that affect the material and spatial domains o:
label: Paragraph

text: culture: cities, gardens, buildings, or rooms. Techniques, for example, accumulate in
label: Paragraph

text: the history of building construction, new methods cooperate with old. Factory-
label: Paragraph

text: made elements manufactured with the newest (today, digital) methods are stil
label: Paragraph

text: assembled on structural foundations built into sites according to long-standing
label: Paragraph

text: methods. Likewise, modern arrangements of inhabitable settings, in houses or
label: Paragraph

text: libraries, for example, do not erase; they transform, alter, or modify earlier pat-
label: Paragraph

text: terns. The history of cities shows something similar, for their cultural and historica.
label: Paragraph

text: richness gives them the capacity to absorb even the most unprecedented o
label: Paragraph

text: insertions — and be better for it. All of this is to say that even the most strident
label: Paragraph

text: proposals are never closed in on themselves. Modern architecture was not “spoken
label: Paragraph

text: into the void,” even if Adolf Loos, who published essays under this title, said things
label: Paragraph

text: and invented configurations that had not been said or seen before.” Only by
label: Paragraph

text: accepting the idea that modern projects adhered to inherited conditions as much
label: Paragraph

text: as they rejected them can we understand why Loos admitted, “I am a modern
label: Paragraph

text: architect because I build in the manner of the ancient Viennese.”
label: Paragraph

text: While many modernists would have rejected Loos’ statement, even a little his-
label: Paragraph

text: torical study shows that no surpassing is ever complete, or desired. Advances
label: Paragraph

text: always depend on “conversations” with predecessors. Rarely are they viva voce,
label: Paragraph

text: of course; they are instead asymmetrical, because the past, having passed, cannot
label: Paragraph

text: answer back. Yet silence does not prevent significance. For architects with non-
label: Paragraph

text: dogmatic minds it seems to have invited unending inquiry. Who, among the mod-
label: Paragraph

text: erns we still study, did not say both yes and no to work from the past? Because not
label: Paragraph

text: one of the conversations between modernists and their predecessors was limited by
label: Paragraph

text: or concluded in the twentieth century — not Tadao Ando’s with Louis I. Kahn,
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s with Le Corbusier, or Le Corbusier’s with the ancient Greeks and Romans —
label: Paragraph

text: we should not be surprised that still today we find it hard to “sum up” what modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was or is all about.
label: Paragraph

text: Modernity, and by implication modern architecture, has been famously
label: Paragraph

text: described as “an incomplete project.”* Rightly celebrated and often cited, this only
label: Paragraph

text: reverses the direction of the observation we have just made: twentieth century
label: Paragraph

text: modernism reaches forward into our present just as it extended itself backward into
label: Paragraph

text: its past.
label: Paragraph

text: Nor was there only one new architecture: first there was the modernism of the
label: Paragraph

text: “pioneers”; after this came the translations of formerly new vocabularies into local
label: Paragraph

text: dialects; next followed the modernism of those who built in different regions
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the world; and then still another modern tradition emerged as a result
label: Paragraph

text: of the critical assessments that called for a renewal of early impulses. The history of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture is less a line of development than a field of sequential begin-
label: Paragraph

text: nings and returnings, including false starts, real initiatives, and renewals, each ela-
label: Paragraph

text: borating new possibilities that appeared thanks to changed conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: There is, as a result, a history of the histories of modern architecture. Through-
label: Paragraph

text: out much of the twentieth century, reports on the new architecture insisted on the
label: Paragraph

text: novelty and progressive character of its exemplary projects. The Latin stem modo
label: Paragraph

text: can be translated as “just now.” For the early historians of the movement an acute
label: Paragraph

text: sense of the unprecedented character of conditions just now meant stopping the
label: Paragraph

text: clock of earlier ages and starting another one for the new time. According to this
label: Paragraph

text: premise, historical change is not transitional but successive, distinct ages precede
label: Paragraph

text: and follow one another; the Gothic, mannerist and baroque periods occurred in
label: Paragraph

text: blocks or chunks of time, hewn out of the landscape of the past by historical science
label: Paragraph

text: in order to be viewed independently, as separate and sequential architectural
label: Paragraph

text: approaches.
label: Paragraph

text: Two histories of the 1920s that were particularly emphatic about the epoch-
label: Paragraph

text: making advances of modern works were Adolf Behne’s The Modern Functional
label: Paragraph

text: Building (1923) and Walter-Curt Behrendt’s The Victory of the New Building Style
label: Paragraph

text: (1927). To some degree these books were both histories of the movement and pro-
label: Paragraph

text: posals for it, simultaneously retrospective, as Behrendt announced that a victory
label: Paragraph

text: had been won; and prospective, because his “history” set forth an agenda. No less
label: Paragraph

text: progressive were Henry-Russell Hitchcock’s Modern Architecture: Romanticism and
label: Paragraph

text: Reintegration (1929) and Alberto Sartoris’ Gli elementi dell’architettura (Elements of
label: Paragraph

text: Functionalism, 1932), even if they had sharply different interpretations of what
label: Paragraph

text: was essential about the movement. Two other texts, both published in 1936, like-
label: Paragraph

text: wise accented the unprecedented character of avant-garde architecture: Nikolaus
label: Paragraph

text: Pevsner’s Pioneers of the Modern Movement from William Morris to Walter Gropius
label: Title

text: and George Nelson’s Building a New Europe: Portraits of Modern Architects. But per-
label: Paragraph

text: haps the most influential and widely read account of this epochal type was Sigfried
label: Paragraph

text: Giedion’s Space, Time and Architecture: The Growth of a New Tradition (1941).
label: Caption

text: In the postwar decades, however, as the work of the modernists was coming
label: Paragraph

text: under the tough criticism of a younger generation of modernists, the progress
label: Paragraph

text: of the movement was reassessed. To some degree Giedion’s use of the term
label: Paragraph

text: “new tradition” suggested or anticipated this turn, by placing the modern period
label: Paragraph

text: among traditions that had come before. Without disavowing the linearity of devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opments, later historians offered what might be termed “regional” accounts, in
label: Paragraph

text: both the geographic and disciplinary senses of the term: the world-wide locations
label: Paragraph

text: of the new architecture were described and interpreted and the themes or topics of
label: Paragraph

text: modern innovations came under closer review — the expressive, technological,
label: Paragraph

text: political, or environmental characteristics of the new ways of building. Historical
label: Paragraph

text: works in this second group included Bruno Zevi’s Storia dell’architettura moderna
label: Paragraph

text: (1950), Reyner Banham’s Theory and Design in the First Machine Age (1960), Leo-
label: Paragraph

text: nardo Benevolo’s History of Modern Architecture (1960), Kenneth Frampton’s Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture: A Critical History (1980), Manfredo Tafuri’s The Sphere and the
label: Paragraph

text: Labyrinth: Avant-Gardes from Piranesi to the 1970s (1980), and William Curtis’ Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture since 1900 (1982). Two more recent histories show the full complexity
label: Paragraph

text: of the inheritance: Alan Colquhoun’s Modern Architecture (2002) reaffirms the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gressive character of modern architecture’s several movements in their nuanced
label: Paragraph

text: variation, and Jean-Louis Cohen’s The Future of Architecture since 1889 (2012) shows
label: Paragraph

text: the amplitude and richness of its geographical and cultural diffusion.
label: Paragraph

text: Additionally, in recent decades much historiographic work has focused on single
label: Paragraph

text: figures, limited time frames, and under-studied territories. The result is an abun-
label: Paragraph

text: dance of material that complicates the story of modernism. Partly because of this
label: Paragraph

text: richness, few today are willing to accept epic narratives of the whole period. Addi-
label: Paragraph

text: tionally, there is considerable doubt about the value and methodological assump-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of such accounts. The ambition seems to have run its course. But the difficulty
label: Paragraph

text: of the task and hesitations about method cannot free us from the basic task of all
label: Paragraph

text: history writing: to tell a story, about architecture and for it; and also about the
label: Paragraph

text: worlds it builds. For such a story to be told, selections must be made — for wholly
label: Paragraph

text: inclusive tabulations of events still want an explanation — meaning that choices must
label: Paragraph

text: be made. These must be guided by the double requirement for utmost plausibility
label: Paragraph

text: (approximating objectivity) and intelligibility.” For this second requirement to be
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilled, imagination is required, for historical traces are always incomplete, terms
label: Paragraph

text: are often used with ill-defined meanings, and the protagonists generally remain
label: Paragraph

text: silent on their primary motivations. The historian’s imagination, of course, limits
label: Paragraph

text: the account’s objectivity. One nevertheless attempts to reconstruct a sequence that
label: Paragraph

text: rectifies all available data, seeking a rendition that is inferior to none other in like-
label: Paragraph

text: lihood. An intelligible narrative also requires judgments about importance that in
label: Paragraph

text: turn invoke the historian’s sense of what indeed is architectural. None of this can be
label: Paragraph

text: avoided if the desire for both explanation and understanding is acknowledged. It is
label: Paragraph

text: not only the breadth and systematic unity of the report that is important, but also
label: Paragraph

text: the depth and singularity of the understanding the story creates.
label: Paragraph

text: Accordingly, the historian’s task today is to describe avenues of design practice
label: Paragraph

text: hat were opened, pursued, and then abandoned, ways of working and of thinking
label: Paragraph

text: hat initially built upon earlier achievements but later diverged, found their footing
label: Paragraph

text: in the particularity of a given historical moment, but then sought to recall topics
label: Paragraph

text: that have always defined the discipline. Concern for “classical,” “primitive,” and
label: Paragraph

text: “vernacular” traditions, for example, went hand in hand with the celebration of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary possibilities. To see the historical depth of progressive propositions,
label: Paragraph

text: we need to look beyond the claims of unprecedented novelty by the protagonists or
label: Paragraph

text: their apologists. Consider this example from Le Corbusier: “T wish it were possible
label: Paragraph

text: for the reader, by an effort of imagination, to conceive of what such a vertical city
label: Paragraph

text: [the Voisin City] would be like; imagine all this junk, which till now has lain spread
label: Paragraph

text: out over the soil like a dry crust, cleaned off and carted away and replaced by
label: Paragraph

text: immense clear crystals of glass...”° Despite what seems a rather thoroughgoing
label: Paragraph

text: erasure, the clearing recommended in this transformation allowed the city’s axes
label: Paragraph

text: to stay where they were, along with what Le Corbusier called the great creations of
label: Paragraph

text: the past: Invalides, Tuileries, Place de la Concorde, Camp de Mars, and the Etoile.
label: Paragraph

text: One does not have to accept his preference for monuments over fabric to see his
label: Paragraph

text: desire to assimilate the new into the old.
label: Paragraph

text: A clear rendering of this assimilation emerges when we take a close reading of
label: Paragraph

text: the full spectrum of architectural tasks: the work of intervening in a given site, of
label: Paragraph

text: interpreting a program of uses, of selecting materials (many of which were familiar
label: Paragraph

text: but used in unfamiliar ways), and of detailing construction. What might be called
label: Paragraph

text: the different times of architectural work — the prehistory, current expectations, and
label: Paragraph

text: future possibilities of the site, program, materials, and labor practices — were folded
label: Paragraph

text: in on themselves, as if the past had been nothing more than a recent present and the
label: Paragraph

text: future a present yet to come. It is precisely this interlapsing that is the subject matter
label: Paragraph

text: of histories that seek to catch the growth and continuity of the modern tradition at
label: Paragraph

text: its source: the actual practices of design and construction, which is to say project
label: Paragraph

text: making.
label: Paragraph

text: The basic premise of this book’s structure is that a particularly good way of
label: Paragraph

text: understanding the history of modern architecture (including the modern architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture of our time) is by looking again at the tradition’s key projects. We would like
label: Paragraph

text: this term to describe works that were not only built and persist to our time, even if
label: Paragraph

text: altered, but also those we can no longer see because they were destroyed or
label: Paragraph

text: intended to be temporary, or even only drawn or modeled. A history of projects
label: Paragraph

text: can address and explain the themes that persist through a work’s several stages and
label: Paragraph

text: t
label: Title

text: t
label: Title

text: alterations, as well as the concrete and limited conditions that allowed and
label: Paragraph

text: expressed those changes.
label: Paragraph

text: Given the weight of our historiographic tradition and of our naturalized sense of
label: Paragraph

text: distinct ages succeeding one another in time, coming to grips with the interlapsing
label: Paragraph

text: just mentioned means looking again at buildings and designs we thought we knew
label: Paragraph

text: perfectly well. Each of the 50 chapters of this volume is an exercise in that task. When
label: Paragraph

text: a built project is not the topic of study it is the idea of one, as represented in drawings
label: Paragraph

text: or models. In some cases works that were built decades ago remain standing today.
label: Paragraph

text: Other significant projects were destroyed or modified beyond recognition. Still
label: Paragraph

text: others were meant to be temporary. Another set of projects that have been impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant in this history were never built at all. Regardless of the current state of a partic-
label: Paragraph

text: ular work, its projective dimensions are the essential subject matter of the
label: Paragraph

text: 50 chapters that follow. Although different interpretative instruments and proce-
label: Paragraph

text: dures are required for the different embodiments of a project (built, altered, tempo-
label: Paragraph

text: rary, or unbuilt), there seems to be no good reason to rank one kind of
label: Paragraph

text: materialization over another. As shown in the chapters that follow, architectural pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects have the capacity to absorb and integrate ideas, material facts, cultural norms,
label: Paragraph

text: and possibilities, as well as questions internal to the discipline of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Because it refuses any categorical separation of fact and idea, of any discrete condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and recurring theme, there is perhaps no better medium of architectural history
label: Paragraph

text: than the project. A new story of the modern tradition unfolds as a result of this focus,
label: Paragraph

text: even though the characters who play leading roles have names we have heard before.
label: Paragraph

text: The projects presented in the book have been grouped into six chronologically
label: Paragraph

text: structured sections, the subtitles of which introduce the term world. Our basic
label: Paragraph

text: premise is that the modern architectural project is an instrument of world building.
label: Paragraph

text: The book’s sections show, however, that different understandings of the architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural project corresponded to different senses of the worlds that would result. We
label: Paragraph

text: distinguish the ways projects were alternately anticipatory, imaginative, construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tive, recursive, interrogative, and engaging. The story that results is thus an
label: Paragraph

text: account of the modern period as well as an elaboration of the different aspects
label: Paragraph

text: or dimensions of project making in these years. The ways of doing architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and of world building that emerge in this story are modern architecture’s gift to
label: Paragraph

text: the present, representing at once an inheritance and a set of tasks.

text: ANTICIPATING MODERN WORLDS
label: Title

text: Alexander Eisenschmidt
label: Title

text: The progressive movements from the turn of the nineteenth century to the dawn
label: Title

text: of World War I largely preconditioned the modern avant-gardes that followed. All
label: Paragraph

text: the buildings studied in the chapters of this section were designed by architects who
label: Paragraph

text: were born at the end of the nineteenth century and practiced at the beginning of the
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth century. They were part of a generation that witnessed unparalleled
label: Paragraph

text: modernization first hand, an experience that deeply influenced the way they
label: Paragraph

text: thought architecture had to engage the world. While the concept of the “modern”
label: Paragraph

text: had been long in the making — from the seventeenth century quarrel against the
label: Paragraph

text: supremacy of the ancients to the Enlightenment ideas of critical reason — industri-
label: Paragraph

text: alization brought about an unprecedented world, so radically transformed that its
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants struggled to recognize it. Modern life was catapulted into existence
label: Paragraph

text: through urban developments that took place at a record pace, changing the world
label: Paragraph

text: more rapidly and dramatically than ever before.
label: Paragraph

text: The industrial city witnessed an extreme urbanization, no longer composed of
label: Paragraph

text: familiar expressions of communal intimacy, torn by political turmoil, and increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: questioning established traditions and patterns of behavior. Modernization was inti-
label: Paragraph

text: mately linked to the modern city, where the industrial environment with its factories,
label: Paragraph

text: credit networks, new institutional systems, and communication and information tech-
label: Title

text: nologies drew an unmatched number of workers to urban areas. The flow of migra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion into cities between 1800 and 1900 was dramatic and drastically changed urban-
label: Paragraph

text: rural relationships. In Europe, London’s population increased from 1.2 to 4.5 million,
label: Paragraph

text: and Berlin’s from 172,000 to 1.9 million. Cities in the United States surpassed these
label: Paragraph

text: statistics, with New York growing from 60,000 to 3.5 million and Chicago developing
label: Paragraph

text: from a settler’s village around 1800 to a metropolis with 1.7 million inhabitants. This
label: Paragraph

text: rapid growth in population did not match the construction efforts, resulting in den-
label: Paragraph

text: sities that in many cities reached its all-time high by the end of the nineteenth century.
label: Paragraph

text: Observing an environment that sharply contrasted with the previously known
label: Paragraph

text: world, Friedrich Engels wrote: “[the modern city is an] urban mess ... and the
label: Paragraph

text: result of a gigantic accident.”’ The poor working, living, and urban conditions
label: Paragraph

text: of cities, were for Engels conditioned by modern industrial capitalism, giving

text: way to an “accidental” urban development, often at the expense of previous urban
label: Paragraph

text: orders. This notion of the city was passed on throughout the nineteenth century,
label: Paragraph

text: and found one of the most outspoken opponents of the metropolis in Friedrich
label: Paragraph

text: Nietzsche, who encouraged his Zarathustra to “spit on the great city.”* Driven
label: Paragraph

text: by economic demands and new urban forms of living, mobility, and work required
label: Paragraph

text: anew understanding of this recently transformed metropolitan space. The conver-
label: Paragraph

text: gence of the desire to order the urban ground, the increasing rationalization of the
label: Paragraph

text: city and of life, and the subsequent aesthetization of modern rational forms and life,
label: Paragraph

text: marked the birthplace of an era in its anticipation of a new world. An industrial
label: Paragraph

text: metropolis was born that was contingent on imperial models and colonial influ-
label: Paragraph

text: ences — a new kind of international scene with a more cosmopolitan understanding
label: Paragraph

text: motivated by far-reaching communication and news outlets, and disciplines such as
label: Paragraph

text: sociology and city planning determined to understand the urban world by relying
label: Paragraph

text: heavily on new methods of information mining, such as statistics.
label: Paragraph

text: These changes in the urban topography had a fundamental impact on architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In cities affected by the Industrial Revolution — and with it the implementation of
label: Paragraph

text: new policies — the erosion of traditional urban and architectural forms and norms
label: Title

text: not only transformed existing typologies, such as prisons and schools, but introduced
label: Paragraph

text: a multitude of new programs. Urbanization, economic development, and expansion
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously provoked and demanded a new make-up of the city. The exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: rise of the railroad for example — which in the United States largely conditioned
label: Paragraph

text: monopolistic capitalism and the exploitation of the frontier—not only shifted regional
label: Paragraph

text: time and space ratios by bringing territories closer together but also demanded new
label: Paragraph

text: building types in the form of the urban and suburban train station. Similarly, new
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing techniques and procedures required more and differently equipped
label: Paragraph

text: factories, while new product lines and an ever-enlarging consumer culture carved
label: Paragraph

text: new spaces of commerce into the city. The expansion of the latter proceeded during
label: Paragraph

text: the nineteenth century from single stores along sidewalks to a collection of stores
label: Paragraph

text: under colonnades, and the excavation of the urban block through arcades, only to
label: Paragraph

text: culminate toward the end of the century in the “house of goods” — the department
label: Paragraph

text: store — from the rue de Colonnes (1793) via the passage Delorme (1808) to Bon
label: Paragraph

text: Marché (1887). At a national and, increasingly, international scale, new communica-
label: Paragraph

text: tion networks enabled global trade and facilitated unprecedented organizational and
label: Paragraph

text: bureaucratic structures. Different companies would congregate in buildings
label: Paragraph

text: equipped with the newest technologies and devoted entirely to office space.
label: Paragraph

text: It is, therefore, no coincidence that Louis H. Sullivan’s famous — famously mis-
label: Paragraph

text: understood and notoriously overused — dictum “form ever follows function”
label: Paragraph

text: appears in his essay “The Tall Office Building Artistically Considered.”* As Joanna
label: Paragraph

text: Merwood-Salisbury shows in her chapter, the Carson Pirie Scott building by
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan quickly became a symbol of “the rational and universal expression of social
label: Paragraph

text: progress achieved through technology,” which Sullivan himself complicates
label: Paragraph

text: through his selective use of ornamentation. The buildings of the Chicago School
label: Paragraph

text: grew ever larger and taller by the end of the nineteenth century, effectively
label: Paragraph

text: superseding conventional brick masonry construction, rapidly introducing the steel
label: Paragraph

text: frame, and rethinking established methods, proportions, and materialities. Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects had to come to terms with a new lightness, structural exuberance, material
label: Paragraph

text: transparency, and prefabrication efficiency that engineers already utilized. Con-
label: Paragraph

text: structs such as the poignantly named Crystal Palace by Joseph Paxton (1851) in
label: Paragraph

text: London and the iron lattice tower by Gustave Eiffel (1889) in Paris are only two
label: Paragraph

text: of the legendary products of modern technology that challenged architectural
label: Paragraph

text: thinking and forever transformed the city. Not only were these new constructs
label: Paragraph

text: utterly different, even alien, to the neighborhoods they occupied but they also
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to transform their surroundings. Modernist painters such as Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Delaunay depicted the buildings adjacent to the Eiffel Tower fractured and
label: Paragraph

text: reflected into a cacophony of forms, and photographers were equally mesmerized
label: Paragraph

text: by the tower's lightweight member through which the city was newly seen. Both
label: Paragraph

text: works hinted at a new spatial condition that questioned the solidity of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and the opposition between interior and exterior. Sigfried Giedion, empowered by
label: Paragraph

text: hindsight, would later lobby that “in the air-flooded stairs of the Eiffel Tower,” one
label: Paragraph

text: experienced a new aesthetic, where “through the delicate iron net suspended in
label: Paragraph

text: midair stream things, ships, sea, houses, masts, landscape and harbor.”* Here, mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern forms not only conditioned the modern city but assembled a new world from
label: Paragraph

text: the fragments of the old.
label: Paragraph

text: The kaleidoscopic capacities of the glass and iron structures of the nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century were the precursors to the expressionist imagery of Paul Scheerbart, ulti-
label: Paragraph

text: mately culminating in the urban scenarios and architectural experiments of
label: Paragraph

text: Bruno Taut. Often, these explorations were supported by the use of materials
label: Paragraph

text: that only slowly found their way from engineering into architecture. Markus
label: Paragraph

text: Breitschmid’s chapter, for example, begins by pointing out that concrete was
label: Paragraph

text: the material that made Bruno Taut’s Glass House possible; a structure, as
label: Paragraph

text: Breitschmid later emphasizes, that simultaneously harvested “technological pos-
label: Paragraph

text: sibilities ... and a new and necessarily metaphysical foundation.” Viollet-le-Duc
label: Paragraph

text: had already argued for the power of new industrial materials; against the stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: assemblage of historicism, he advocated for architecture as a logical system born
label: Paragraph

text: from within contemporary functional and material rules: “if we would invent that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of our own times ... we must certainly seek it no longer by mingling all
label: Paragraph

text: the styles of the past, but by relying on novel principles of structure.”” For him,
label: Paragraph

text: the rational structuring of iron trusses was the logical outcome of industrial pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction and current technological advancements. Viollet-le-Duc induced archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture with the ambition toward a rational and “true” process of form-finding
label: Paragraph

text: within the present, a dramatic shift in architectural thinking that was echoed
label: Paragraph

text: by the coming generation and reinterpreted by associates in Art Nouveau,
label: Paragraph

text: Jugendstil, Stile Liberty, and Secession. Designers in these groups no longer
label: Paragraph

text: applied these new aesthetic principles to single elements alone but to interiors
label: Paragraph

text: as a whole (from furniture to the dress). Here, families of forms created a “thick-
label: Paragraph

text: ened interior” of a new parallel world of seeming fluidity and structural alliance,
label: Paragraph

text: or what Amy Kulper in her chapter on the House for an Art Lover by Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Rennie Mackintosh calls “a radicalized interior.”
label: Paragraph

text: Shortly after, however, these formal escalations were placed into perspective by
label: Paragraph

text: considerations relating to the city, often by the very same protagonists. August Endell,
label: Caption

text: an eccentric German architect who before 1900 deployed “free form” to provoke
label: Paragraph

text: emotional responses, by 1908 sought to find aesthetic potential in the visual effects
label: Paragraph

text: of the metropolis. Otto Wagner’s Postal Savings Bank constituted a new urban archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture, a vision that was followed by his proposal for a new metropolis of infinite
label: Paragraph

text: growth. Similarly, Peter Behrens called for simplified architectural uniformity that
label: Paragraph

text: responded to the increasing speed of the city.° In his chapter on the Postal Savings
label: Paragraph

text: Bank, Béla Kerékgyarté argues that one can identify the developments that Wagner
label: Paragraph

text: made toward a rational approach, while Gabriele H. Bryant’s chapter on the AEG
label: Paragraph

text: Turbine Factory points at Behrens’ intense search for an “architecture of our time.”
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens stipulated that architectural details had to be suppressed once the tempo of
label: Paragraph

text: vehicular traffic allowed one to see only silhouettes of buildings passing by. This was
label: Paragraph

text: only one year after Filippo Tommaso Marinetti had described in detail a car race that
label: Paragraph

text: prematurely ended in a disastrous crash while singing to the “multicolored and pol-
label: Paragraph

text: yphonic tides of revolution.”” By 1914, Umberto Boccioni, followed by Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’Elia, supplied Futurism with an architecture that spoke to the dynamism of
label: Paragraph

text: the industrial city and wholeheartedly committed to and even accelerated the infra-
label: Paragraph

text: structural and technologically saturated metropolis. Here, architectural form as enor-
label: Paragraph

text: mous machine had become a fully immersed urban construct, linking all aspects of
label: Paragraph

text: urban movement and vertically erupting at transportation nodes. Only after the tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nological and strategic mechanization of World War I caused an unprecedented num-
label: Paragraph

text: ber of casualties, including many Futurists, a reassessment of some of their
label: Paragraph

text: fundamentals took place. Michelangelo Sabatini’s chapter contrasts the fast-paced
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism of Sant’Elia’s Citta Nuova to what he calls a “slow Futurism” that developed
label: Paragraph

text: by the early 1920s, captivated by “the dramatic qualities of the rugged landscape” on
label: Paragraph

text: the island of Capri.
label: Paragraph

text: Just before and immediately after 1900, architecture had tested disciplinary
label: Paragraph

text: boundaries, deployed new materials (or utilized old ones in new dimensions),
label: Paragraph

text: and advanced techniques in its search for an expression of the historical moment.
label: Paragraph

text: This search can be read as an attempt to catch up to a world it no longer under-
label: Paragraph

text: stood, and much less had sway over. As a result, these two decades constitute
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most contested eras in architectural history. To give only three exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ples in a long list of books that struggled with the historical significance of this
label: Paragraph

text: period: Nikolaus Pevsner’s Pioneers of the Modern Movement (1936) aimed to dem-
label: Paragraph

text: onstrate how this timeframe was a “historical unit” that fully formed the “legit-
label: Paragraph

text: imate style of our century”; Reyner Banham, on the other hand, saw the first
label: Paragraph

text: machine age as erupting around 1912 and argued that “we are still the children
label: Paragraph

text: of that turbulent generation”; and Manfredo Tafuri and Franceso Dal Co
label: Paragraph

text: unhinged the master narratives of the time and understood the period as a “final
label: Paragraph

text: flare-up of romantic Sehnsucht.”* More recently, writings by historians such as
label: Paragraph

text: the late Detlef Mertins have expanded and opened up new insights in familiar
label: Paragraph

text: territories by, for example, relating theories of glass to a much wider realm
label: Paragraph

text: of influence.” As much as these interpretations differ, all concur on the period’s
label: Paragraph

text: transformative capacities from nineteenth century aspirations to twentieth cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury formulations.
label: Paragraph

text: Marshall Berman went so far as to identify a shift from an open-ended and
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic engagement with modernity during the late-nineteenth century toward
label: Paragraph

text: a more hermetic understanding of modernism in the following decades. He saw
label: Paragraph

text: a polarization at the beginning of the twentieth century, when “[ojpen visions
label: Paragraph

text: of modern life have been supplanted by close ones, Both/ And by Either/Or.”"°
label: Paragraph

text: For Berman, the struggle with modernity by the “first modernists,” as he calls
label: Paragraph

text: them, presented not only problems but also revelations, where “their self-ironies
label: Paragraph

text: and inner tensions were a primary source of their creative power.” As such, these
label: Paragraph

text: early projects of the late nineteenth and very early twentieth century hold a unique
label: Paragraph

text: place in the history of modernity — one of dualisms and twilights but, most of all,
label: Paragraph

text: animated by an openness toward the modern world, which the Futurists were
label: Paragraph

text: about to polarize between embrace and resistance. The few projects presented here
label: Paragraph

text: as part of a much larger catalogue of works are not only vital to an understanding of
label: Paragraph

text: the modernisms that followed but, to paraphrase Berman, may hold opportunities
label: Paragraph

text: to better understand the modernities of today. While seemingly far-fetched, taking
label: Paragraph

text: clues from the resourcefulness of these early modernists may just give us the right
label: Paragraph

text: dose of foresight to engage the city of today, to detect openings in the immediate
label: Paragraph

text: future, and to anticipate another world.
label: Paragraph

text: 1 SCHLESINGER
label: Caption

text: AND MAYER
label: Title

text: DEPARTMENT STORE/
label: Title

text: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT
label: Title

text: Louis Sullivan
label: Title

text: Joanna Merwood-Salisbury
label: Title

text: Louis Sullivan, Schlesinger and Mayer Department Store (Carson Pirie Scott),
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, 1903.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: In his 1892 essay, “Ornament in Architecture,” Louis Sullivan summarized the
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic implications of the steel frame: if the structure of a building and its exte-
label: Paragraph

text: rior walls are now separate systems, what is the relationship between the two?
label: Paragraph

text: The essay features his suggestion that “it would be greatly for our aesthetic good
label: Paragraph

text: if we would refrain entirely from the use of ornament for a period of years, in
label: Paragraph

text: order that our thought might concentrate acutely upon the perfection of build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings well formed and comely in the nude.”’ For much of the twentieth century,
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s Schlesinger and Mayer department store, later known as Carson Pirie
label: Paragraph

text: Scott (1899-1903), was regarded as the physical manifestation of that impulse, a
label: Paragraph

text: building in which ornament had been stripped away from all but the base and
label: Paragraph

text: attic, revealing the naked form of the frame underneath. In this way it seemed
label: Paragraph

text: to herald a new aesthetic in which the representation of technology replaced con-
label: Paragraph

text: ventional forms of ornament. Considered in the urban and social context of late
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century Chicago, the Schlesinger and Mayer building illustrates Sul-
label: Paragraph

text: livan’s belief in the ongoing viability of architectural ornament, in particular as a
label: Paragraph

text: representation of American democracy. This contextual reading suggests an
label: Paragraph

text: alternative narrative of architectural modernism, one in which the curtain wall,
label: Paragraph

text: so long understood as a form of structural expressionism, is also recognized for its
label: Paragraph

text: decorative function.
label: Paragraph

text: A State Street Department Store
label: Title

text: In 1891 the Schlesinger and Mayer Company consulted architects Adler and Sul-
label: Paragraph

text: livan about giving a unified architectural expression to their department store,
label: Paragraph

text: then located in a series of adjoining buildings in the block bounded by State, Mad-
label: Paragraph

text: ison, Wabash, and Monroe Streets in downtown Chicago. The partners had
label: Paragraph

text: achieved success with a series of projects combining technological innovation
label: Paragraph

text: with decorative creativity, including the Schiller Theater (1886-92) and the
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago Auditorium (1886-90). These projects dealt with complex functional
label: Paragraph

text: requirements, including the need for large, well-lit interior spaces, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: the desire for the expression of a civic and cultural identity suitable to a city
label: Paragraph

text: of recent immigrants, many newly wealthy. While the department store commis-
label: Paragraph

text: sion came to nothing, in 1898, after his partnership with Adler was dissolved, Sul-
label: Paragraph

text: livan was commissioned to design a new 12-story flagship building for the
label: Paragraph

text: company, replacing the existing one. The new building was constructed in
label: Paragraph

text: two stages: a nine-story, three-bay building facing Madison Street, completed
label: Caption

text: in 1899, and the main 12-story corner block with three bays on Madison and seven
label: Paragraph

text: on State, completed in 1903. In 1904, the rival Carson Pirie Scott Company took
label: Paragraph

text: control of the business and the building, gradually extending it southwards with a
label: Paragraph

text: five bay extension by D.H. Burnham and Co. in 1906, and a three-bay section by
label: Paragraph

text: Holabird and Roche in 1961. Both these additions mimicked the style of Sullivan’s
label: Paragraph

text: original building.
label: Caption

text: One of a series of department stores built along State Street, the Schlesinger and
label: Paragraph

text: Mayer Company sold mass-market luxury goods to middle-class customers, predom-
label: Paragraph

text: inantly women. State Street itself was the vision of dry goods magnate Potter Palmer
label: Paragraph

text: who had it widened and developed as the city’s premiere commercial boulevard in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1860s. Along with his early partners, Marshall Fields and Levi Leiter, Palmer was
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for the first commercial “palaces” built there, all influenced by the great
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian department stores: Blondel’s Grand Magasin du Louvre (1866); Laplanche
label: Paragraph

text: and Boileau’s Bon Marché (1869-76); and Paul Sedille’s Au Printemps (1883). Each
label: Paragraph

text: of these buildings exploited an iron structure to create huge, open shopping floors
label: Paragraph

text: illuminated with copious natural light. In Chicago the architect William Le Baron
label: Caption

text: Jenney, one of Sullivan’s early employers, established a new precedent for buildings
label: Paragraph

text: of this type with the second Leiter building and the Fair stores (both 1891). Though
label: Paragraph

text: these were considerably plainer than their French counterparts, they were unprec-
label: Paragraph

text: edented in their enormous size. With these buildings, eight and eleven stories high
label: Paragraph

text: respectively, Jenney inaugurated the hybrid skyscraper-department store type.
label: Paragraph

text: The skyscraper appeared in the early 1880s when, in the middle of a real estate
label: Paragraph

text: boom, property owners began using a method known locally as the “Chicago con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction” to build 12-, 16-, and even 20-story buildings. This method was made up
label: Paragraph

text: of a series of related technologies including an internal metal structure, elevators,
label: Paragraph

text: electric lighting, steam heating, and so-called curtain walls: lightweight assemblies
label: Paragraph

text: of brick, terracotta tile, and plate glass connected to the frame with anchors and
label: Paragraph

text: brackets. Faster to erect than masonry, this method allowed the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: tall buildings with large volumes that produced significantly increased rental
label: Paragraph

text: revenue for their owners. For architects, the method presented an accompanying
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic problem: what should the Chicago construction look like? In early experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ments, such as Holabird and Roche’s Tacoma building (1889), the inner frame was
label: Paragraph

text: expressed on the exterior via an undulating wall of unusually large windows. While
label: Paragraph

text: the Tacoma mimicked the brown color of masonry buildings, Daniel Burnham and
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Atwood offered a radical new aesthetic in their design for the Reliance
label: Paragraph

text: building (1895). The original home of the Carson Pirie Scott company, the Reliance
label: Caption

text: presented an obviously non-load-bearing curtain wall of cream-colored glazed ter-
label: Paragraph

text: racotta tile inset with unusually large panes of plate glass. This wall of windows was
label: Paragraph

text: folded into a series of bays projecting out over dark brown granite and bronze
label: Paragraph

text: framed display windows at the street level.
label: Caption

text: With its large windows and dramatic chromatic distinction between base and
label: Paragraph

text: upper stories, the Reliance was a precedent for the Schlesinger and Mayer building.
label: Paragraph

text: In its design Sullivan drew on the formula he had established for tall office buildings
label: Paragraph

text: in the early 1890s: a single block divided into three horizontal layers, with a two-
label: Paragraph

text: story “mercantile base” decorated in a “sumptuous” way in order to “attract the
label: Paragraph

text: eye”; above this, an indefinite number of office tiers; and finally a decorative attic
label: Paragraph

text: that signified the vertical termination of the building.” Adler and Sullivan’s Wain-
label: Paragraph

text: wright (1891) and Guaranty (1895) buildings exemplify this approach. In most
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of this type the dimensions of the individual office units dictated the
label: Paragraph

text: width of the structural bays. In the case of the skyscraper department store, how-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, the structural bays were wider, designed to maximize open floor area for the
label: Paragraph

text: display of merchandise and allow the large windows necessary to light it. The
label: Paragraph

text: wider spacing of the bays may explain why, in contrast to the Wainwright and
label: Paragraph

text: the Guaranty, Sullivan gave the windows of the Schlesinger and Mayer store a hor-
label: Paragraph

text: izontal orientation.
label: Paragraph

text: Even more significant than the wider bays, the “mercantile base” was given spe-
label: Paragraph

text: cial prominence. Unlike other commercial buildings, where the street level occu-
label: Paragraph

text: pants were tenants, here it was the owner of the building and the expression of
label: Paragraph

text: the Schlesinger and Mayer Company’s identity was of primary importance. Working
label: Paragraph

text: with his assistant, Grant Elmslie, Sullivan developed a distinctive dark green metallic
label: Paragraph

text: frame for the street-level display windows. The design of these windows was part of
label: Paragraph

text: a larger effort to brand the store with a specific visual identity. Beautiful and intri-
label: Paragraph

text: cate, the foliated decorative motif contained within the geometric frames was
label: Paragraph

text: repeated in the store’s interior in the form of sawn mahogany panels, ornamental
label: Paragraph

text: plasterwork capitals, and bronze-plated lighting fixtures. This motif even influenced
label: Paragraph

text: the graphic design of Schlesinger and Mayer’s newspaper advertising. With its sty-
label: Paragraph

text: lized natural forms, this ormamental scheme echoed the art nouveau style popular in
label: Paragraph

text: France, for example Frantz Jourdain’s Samaritaine department store (1905), which
label: Paragraph

text: included decorative ironwork and polychromatic terracotta tile with a floral motif.
label: Paragraph

text: The most obvious feature of the Schlesinger and Mayer building is the dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: contrast between the base and the facade above. Clad in a pale cream-colored
label: Paragraph

text: terracotta tile, this facade is unornamented except for the inset borders of the win-
label: Paragraph

text: dow frames. Above this an unbroken cornice appears to float above deeply
label: Paragraph

text: recessed windows at the attic level. Connecting these horizontal layers, a rounded
label: Paragraph

text: tower unites the State and Madison facades and acts as the main entrance to the
label: Paragraph

text: store. Though it echoed the grid, Sullivan’s design for the upper facade stood apart
label: Paragraph

text: from the bulk of the building behind it. He employed no rhythm of vertical
label: Paragraph

text: projecting bays, as in the Tacoma and Reliance, merely the simple repetition of
label: Paragraph

text: cell-like windows. He chose not to follow the convention by which the
label: Paragraph

text: interior structure was expressed on the exterior as a series of pronounced vertical
label: Paragraph

text: piers mimicking the classical orders. Instead the pale-colored screen appears to
label: Paragraph

text: stretch tightly across the surface from one edge of the building to the other like
label: Paragraph

text: a thin veil. This veiling effect is particularly pronounced because the horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: spandrels are deeper than the vertical mullions. Sullivan raised these mullions from
label: Paragraph

text: the surface of the wall only on the tower where they are grouped close together,
label: Paragraph

text: enhancing the appearance of a single surface wrapping around the corner, at which
label: Paragraph

text: point it is puckered, or folded. It was this aspect of the building that would
label: Paragraph

text: attract the attention of the architects and critics of the early twentieth-century
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde.
label: Paragraph

text: The Articulated Frame
label: Title

text: By the late 1920s, the construction of the Schlesinger and Mayer building, or
label: Paragraph

text: Carson Pirie Scott as it was now known, was considered a crucial moment in
label: Paragraph

text: the evolution of the modern style, the first overt expression of the curtain wall.
label: Paragraph

text: Now the building was thought of primarily as a skyscraper and its function as a
label: Paragraph

text: department store was given secondary importance. Attention was focused on
label: Paragraph

text: the upper levels of the facade, and the ornamented base and cornice were treated
label: Paragraph

text: as vestigial, a nineteenth-century relic. In 1924 the American critic Lewis Mumford
label: Paragraph

text: described such ornament as the “last gesture of traditional architecture,” clinging to
label: Paragraph

text: the highest and lowest stories of the “draped cube.”’ In 1939 the Museum of Mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern Art in New York claimed Carson Pirie Scott as a native precursor to the Inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national Style. Because of this “one great and prophetic building,” which “frankly
label: Paragraph

text: exhibits its cage-like steel skeleton, sheathed only in terracotta,” the Museum
label: Paragraph

text: declared, Sullivan “may claim his place with contemporary European pioneers
label: Paragraph

text: of the Modern Movement, [Adolf] Loos, [Otto] Wagner, [Hendrik] Berlage, and
label: Paragraph

text: [Henry] Van de Velde.”* In this way the International Style was understood as a
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneous movement arising not in the context of Europe alone, but also in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States. The Swiss critic and historian Sigfried Giedion cemented this
label: Paragraph

text: view in his canonical Space, Time and Architecture (1941), where Carson Pirie Scott
label: Paragraph

text: figures as a forebear to the steel and glass facades of Walter Gropius’ Fagus Factory
label: Caption

text: (1913) and Gropius’ entry to the Chicago Tribune Tower competition (1923).
label: Paragraph

text: In this historiographic framework, Carson Pirie Scott was one of a series of piv-
label: Paragraph

text: otal buildings that launched a global modern style, one in which the thick masonry
label: Paragraph

text: wall was transformed into an “articulated frame.” For high modernists, the internal
label: Paragraph

text: steel frame and the external curtain wall were conceptually interchangeable and
label: Paragraph

text: universally applicable. This idea was to find its highest expression in the work
label: Paragraph

text: of German émigré Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, who inaugurated the “Second
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago School of architecture” in the mid-twentieth century. Mies believed that
label: Paragraph

text: great architecture was the aesthetic fulfillment of technology: “Construction not
label: Paragraph

text: only determines form, but is form itself,” he wrote.’ In buildings such as the Lake
label: Paragraph

text: Shore Drive apartments (1948-51) and the Seagram building (1954-58), metal and
label: Paragraph

text: glass skins evoke the steel structure underneath. For Mies and other modernists,
label: Paragraph

text: technology was a metaphor for the rational and efficient organization of modern
label: Paragraph

text: society irrespective of national or cultural differences. In such a society, good archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture was the aesthetic expression of technology. “The revitalization of the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing art can only come from construction and not by means of arbitrarily assembled
label: Paragraph

text: motifs,” he claimed.®
label: Paragraph

text: The privileging of technological expression (which was thought to further the
label: Paragraph

text: progress of modern society) over the application of historicist ornament (which
label: Paragraph

text: was thought to retard it), dates to a turn-of-the-century discourse about the place
label: Paragraph

text: of ornament in architecture and design. At a time when traditional social bound-
label: Paragraph

text: aries were less and less meaningful, the florid ornament of the Victorian era was
label: Paragraph

text: damningly associated with the bourgeois, or middle class. No longer an expression
label: Paragraph

text: of social status, ornamented goods now signified a lack of taste. The Austrian archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect and critic Adolf Loos famously derided efforts to invent a modern form of orna-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, arguing that conventional decoration appealed only to the culturally
label: Paragraph

text: backward, to criminals and primitive peoples. The German sociologist Werner
label: Paragraph

text: Sombart linked the problem of contemporary design (its debasement through
label: Paragraph

text: the proliferation of cheap, industrially-produced goods) to the rise of capitalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Prompted by the need to increase both production and consumption, he argued,
label: Paragraph

text: the market preyed on the base urge of consumers, particularly women, for the lat-
label: Paragraph

text: est fashion. Around the same time, the Chicago economist Thorstein Veblen
label: Paragraph

text: coined the term “conspicuous consumption,” meaning lavish spending on clothing,
label: Paragraph

text: jewelry and extravagant houses in order to demonstrate one’s wealth. In this sense,
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetes believed, the system of ornament had been corrupted by consumerism:
label: Paragraph

text: the social status it once conferred could now be bought and sold. Veblen identified
label: Paragraph

text: department stores in particular as an essential part of the “propaganda of culture,”
label: Paragraph

text: inculcating the lower classes with a taste for fashionable rather than functional
label: Paragraph

text: goods. In these terms the highly decorated base of Carson Pirie Scott was doubly
label: Paragraph

text: problematic. Not only a throwback to an outmoded ornamental tradition, it was
label: Paragraph

text: also designed specifically to promote the consumption of cheaply made, mass-
label: Paragraph

text: produced goods.
label: Paragraph

text: Organic Architecture and the Textile Wall
label: Title

text: Since the 1960s, the rise of post-modernism has bought a renewed appreciation of
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan’s ornament. Historians have focused in particular on his drawing and writ-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in order to understand how and why he produced such complex decorative
label: Paragraph

text: facades, as well his intellectual influences and the social context in which he
label: Paragraph

text: worked. This scholarship has shown that while Sullivan utilized innovative archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural technologies, he also regarded ornament as a viable form of modern
label: Paragraph

text: expression, one that made manifest not universal social progress but the particular
label: Paragraph

text: benefits of American democracy. Like many of his contemporaries in Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, Sullivan rejected the thoughtless replication of historical prece-
label: Paragraph

text: dent in favor of a philosophy of “organic” architecture. The definition of organic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture varied greatly. Broadly speaking it meant architectural form derived
label: Paragraph

text: from the inner function of a building, whether structural or programmatic, and
label: Paragraph

text: not from the imitation of existing examples. Sullivan summarized this idea in
label: Paragraph

text: his famous and frequently misunderstood aphorism: “form ever follows function.””
label: Paragraph

text: The adoption of this principle implied no particular style: quite the opposite, the
label: Paragraph

text: outward appearance of a building depended entirely on its situation. Classical or
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic styles could be appropriate, depending on the manner in which they were
label: Paragraph

text: used. In Chicago, “organic” architecture came to mean the “evolution” of Euro-
label: Paragraph

text: pean styles into a new American one as they were transplanted into the American
label: Paragraph

text: “west” (as Illinois and the Midwestern states were then considered). Beginning in
label: Paragraph

text: the mid-nineteenth century, architects in Chicago adopted a simplified version of
label: Paragraph

text: the fashionable neo-Gothic style for their commercial structures. By the mid-1880s,
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the French architect Eugéne Emmanuel Viollet-le-Duc, they began
label: Paragraph

text: to think of the Gothic as a constructive system, one adaptable to modern functions
label: Paragraph

text: and materials.
label: Paragraph

text: In these terms the steel frame rendered conventional forms of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: expression derived from load-bearing tectonic systems (such as the classical orders)
label: Paragraph

text: obsolete. Architectural historian Mark Wigley has suggested that, in their efforts to
label: Paragraph

text: legitimate the curtain wall, Sullivan and his colleagues were influenced by the
label: Paragraph

text: German architect Gottfried Semper’s “principle of cladding”: the idea that the
label: Paragraph

text: origins of architecture lay not in post and beam construction but in the textile cov-
label: Paragraph

text: ering used to enclose space in early human societies.* Semper’s theory was derived
label: Paragraph

text: from the archetype of a “Caribbean hut” (a reproduction of which he saw at the
label: Paragraph

text: Great Exhibition in London in 1851) in which the lightweight wall was a separate
label: Paragraph

text: system from the masonry base and hearth. This idea was attractive to the Amer-
label: Paragraph

text: icans because it implied that the curtain wall might represent not a deviation from
label: Paragraph

text: architectural tradition, but a return to its origins: that to dress a steel-framed build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in a textile-like fagade, what Sullivan called the “product of loom and mine,”
label: Paragraph

text: might be entirely appropriate.” Certainly many of his designs evoked textiles,
label: Paragraph

text: especially his polychromatic Transportation Building at the World’s Columbian
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition (1893), which he compared to an oriental rug.
label: Paragraph

text: This leaves the question of what Sullivan was trying to express with his una-
label: Paragraph

text: shamedly draped surfaces. His method of dividing the facades of his tall buildings
label: Paragraph

text: into three horizontal zones followed the organic principle of “form follows
label: Paragraph

text: function,” at least in an abstract sense. But though he was well aware of what
label: Paragraph

text: he called the “social conditions” that produced the new building type — real estate
label: Paragraph

text: conventions, structural technology, interior program — he had no interest in expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sing them directly. Rather, he shared with the American transcendentalist move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment the belief that the role of art was to make visible the invisible spiritual world
label: Paragraph

text: behind the material one. In this sense ornament was the highest form of architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, the emotional expression of the inner “life” of a building. In the case of his
label: Paragraph

text: own practice this meant making manifest the energy he saw inherent in the urban
label: Paragraph

text: landscape of Chicago, a city he described as crude and raw but full of “big things to
label: Paragraph

text: be done.”?® Just as Jenney and Adler utilized the steel frame to construct buildings
label: Paragraph

text: suited to those big deeds, Sullivan experimented with cast-iron, plate glass and ter-
label: Paragraph

text: racotta tile to render them visible in decorative form. His ornamental plant motifs
label: Paragraph

text: were above all a metaphor for growth: the fertility of the natural landscape sym-
label: Paragraph

text: bolized for him the social and economic potential of the American Midwest. In this
label: Paragraph

text: sense he sought to naturalize the capitalist processes that produced the department
label: Paragraph

text: store and the skyscraper in two distinct ways, linking their invention to the biolog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical process of evolution and their appearance to organic forms found in the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: While the ornamented Carson Pirie Scott building undoubtedly had a com-
label: Paragraph

text: mercial function — to draw attention to the store and to establish an image for
label: Paragraph

text: the company as a purveyor of affordable luxury — Sullivan sublimated that prag-
label: Paragraph

text: matic function into a broader, social one. Together with his protégé Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright, he linked organic architecture to the concept of democracy,
label: Paragraph

text: which he understood not as a formal system of government but as a philosophy
label: Paragraph

text: of individual freedom and self-reliance particular to the United States. The tall
label: Paragraph

text: office building symbolized the power of the American businessman to achieve
label: Paragraph

text: great things via sheer will. Architectural historian Joseph Siry sees the
label: Paragraph

text: department store as a related, but different form of democratic institution.’
label: Paragraph

text: For department store owners, shopping was more than a leisure activity; it
label: Paragraph

text: was also an aid to assimilation, a means for personal self-improvement if not
label: Paragraph

text: reinvention. In an era of great social instability, it played an important role
label: Paragraph

text: in the fashioning of new Americans: here the immigrant from Ireland, Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: many, or Bohemia could learn how to dress, behave, and ultimately succeed.
label: Paragraph

text: In this context architectural ornament derived from the plant life of the Midwest
label: Paragraph

text: was not the expression of individual social status, either inherited or bought, but
label: Paragraph

text: of the new society being forged there.
label: Paragraph

text: Though Sullivan became increasingly pessimistic about the future of American
label: Paragraph

text: society in the later years of his life, his Prairie School followers carried his par-
label: Paragraph

text: ticular vision of American modernism into the twentieth century. For Wright, it
label: Paragraph

text: was the single family house rather than the tall commercial building that best
label: Paragraph

text: represented organic architecture. Opposing both the aesthetic and political bases
label: Paragraph

text: of European functionalism, he continued to experiment with abstracted natural
label: Paragraph

text: forms, not only as ornament, as in his turn-of-the-century Prairie Houses, but also
label: Paragraph

text: as the basis for planning in his idealized Broadacre City (1932-35) and later Uso-
label: Paragraph

text: nian Houses. In the same tradition, Sullivan’s friend, the Rochester architect
label: Paragraph

text: Claude Bragdon, created a system of “projective ornament”: geometric motifs
label: Paragraph

text: designed to replace traditional forms of decoration. He realized these most suc-
label: Paragraph

text: cessfully in a series of sound and light displays during the 1910s. Designed to
label: Paragraph

text: accompany community singing concerts, they were intended to foster both musi-
label: Paragraph

text: cal and political harmony.
label: Paragraph

text: The early twentieth-century critique of ornament in design was that it was
label: Paragraph

text: obsolete, no longer a meaningful form of aesthetic expression in modern soci-
label: Paragraph

text: ety. Corrupted by the rise of capitalism, it served only as an indicator of wealth,
label: Paragraph

text: not social position or even taste. In its place, modernist architects forged an aes-
label: Paragraph

text: thetic of technology, one in which decoration was supposedly abandoned in
label: Paragraph

text: favor of the sober representation of the “facts” of a building: its function and
label: Paragraph

text: method of construction. In this understanding, the curtain wall was the rational
label: Paragraph

text: and universal expression of social progress achieved through technology. Sulli-
label: Paragraph

text: van’s Schlesinger and Mayer/Carson Pirie Scott served as a symbol of the birth
label: Paragraph

text: of this idea, its plain upper stories presenting a stark contrast to the ornamented
label: Paragraph

text: display windows below. But Sullivan himself did not see architecture in these
label: Paragraph

text: terms. Part of a group of Chicago-based architects searching for the appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: expression of the steel-framed skyscraper, he argued that, judiciously applied,
label: Paragraph

text: ornament was necessary in order for a building to exceed the realization of mere
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic need. Ornament, he claimed, had an ongoing role as the expression
label: Paragraph

text: not of social status or technological progress, but of the potential of an entire
label: Paragraph

text: nation.
