text: REVERBERATING ECHOES
label: Title

text: Echoes are a genus of soundbite related to diminuendo, where some syllables fall
label: Paragraph

text: away and others assume a surpassing resilience. Echo-effects exaggerated the
label: Paragraph

text: temperamental timeliness of echoes, repeating and recombining end-syllables into
label: Paragraph

text: remonstrance, irony, or affirmation while prodding monologue into dialogue.'
label: Paragraph

text: ...resonating from self to self, in itself and for itself, at once the same and the other
label: Paragraph

text: than itself, one in the echo of the other, and this echo is like the very sound of its
label: Paragraph

text: sense.
label: Paragraph

text: Hermann Muthesius, a contemporary of Charles Rennie Mackintosh, once
label: Paragraph

text: observed about his domestic interiors that they evoked a “fairy-tale world” in
label: Paragraph

text: which “a book in an unsuitable binding would disturb the atmosphere simply
label: Paragraph

text: by lying on the table.”* Hermetic and tightly composed, detailed and aesthetically
label: Paragraph

text: complete, inward and palpably exclusive — how best to describe and interpret
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s domestic interiors that are paradoxically both stylistically singular,
label: Paragraph

text: yet sufficiently abstract and autonomous to be ubiquitous? This chapter will focus
label: Paragraph

text: on a single interior, the music room in the House for an Art Lover (1901). The
label: Paragraph

text: radicalized interiority of Mackintosh’s domestic architecture will find its corollary
label: Paragraph

text: in the emancipated reverberations of the acoustic echo, resonating through four
label: Paragraph

text: interpretive readings. This sonorous analogy will facilitate the articulation of four
label: Paragraph

text: claims about Mackintosh’s domestic architecture: it aspires to a dialogical relation-
label: Paragraph

text: ship with its situation; it conceptually eschews verbatim mimicry and exact copying
label: Paragraph

text: in favor of re-presenting domestic habits and practices; it has the capacity to express
label: Paragraph

text: meaning while subverting disciplinary categories from within; and it is atmos-
label: Paragraph

text: pheric, explicating architecture’s spatial and temporal roles in the preservation
label: Paragraph

text: of culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Echo Location: Between Seemliness and Seaminess
label: Title

text: In 1901, the Journal for Interior Decoration (Zeitschrift fiir Innendekoration) launched a
label: Paragraph

text: competition for the design of a House for an Art Lover (Haus eines Kunstfreundes).
label: Paragraph

text: Since none of the entries precisely followed the rules of the Darmstadt competi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, no first prize was awarded. While second prize went to Baillie Scott, it
label: Paragraph

text: was Mackintosh’s design (disqualified for its insufficient number of interior per-
label: Paragraph

text: spectives) that piqued the most international interest and generated heated disci-
label: Paragraph

text: plinary debate. One year later, Alexander Koch, a wallpaper manufacturer and
label: Paragraph

text: the organizer of the Darmstadt competition, published the three best proposals
label: Paragraph

text: in a portfolio provocatively titled Meister der Innenkunst (Masters of Interior Art.)
label: Paragraph

text: In the same year, 1902, Mackintosh delivered a lecture to an audience of fellow
label: Paragraph

text: artists and teachers, entitled “Seemliness.”* Mackintosh began his lecture with
label: Paragraph

text: the following admission: “I have chosen as my theme ‘Seemliness’ but the theme
label: Paragraph

text: will often be lost in my wanderings, will sometimes be only faintly heard in the
label: Paragraph

text: ”> Brom the beginning, the operations of the echo, only faintly heard
label: Paragraph

text: in the conceptual variations and faintly manifested in the architectural variations,
label: Paragraph

text: is apparent. In advocating for seemliness, Mackintosh searches for an ideal that
label: Paragraph

text: might guide all artists, and finds it in the situated variation:
label: Paragraph

text: variations.
label: Paragraph

text: What one misses in most of the work I refer to is — the large rhythm that undulates
label: Paragraph

text: through that of the great masters antient |sic] and modern — the sustained note of
label: Paragraph

text: informing purpose — the deep vibration of some unifying undertone /now rising to accent
label: Paragraph

text: and emphasis — now sounding faintly, beneath the multifariousness of accompanying
label: Paragraph

text: motives — but always visible to an attentive sense as — the basis if not the burden
label: Paragraph

text: of the theme with variations — the ensamble [sic] which every artists [sic] work —
label: Paragraph

text: no matter how trivial, should constitute. Reason informed by emotion — expressed
label: Paragraph

text: in beauty — and elevated by earnestness — lightened by humour — the is the ideal that
label: Paragraph

text: should guide all artists.°
label: Paragraph

text: In his search for architectural seemliness, for spatial decorum, for constructed
label: Paragraph

text: character, Mackintosh deploys the language of the echo, with its rhythm and undu-
label: Paragraph

text: lations, sustained notes, deep vibrations, and unifying undertone. In fact, the orig-
label: Paragraph

text: inal manuscript for the lecture utilizes gaps and dashes of various sizes, as if the
label: Paragraph

text: author is ascribing notations to a resonating and diminishing sound.’ If this paean
label: Paragraph

text: to seemliness is predicated upon the notion of appropriate beauty, and if for Mack-
label: Paragraph

text: intosh this is found in specific spatial situations in which both aesthetic and utili-
label: Paragraph

text: tarian concerns are met, then surely his use of auditory tropes and notational
label: Paragraph

text: language suggest an awareness that acoustic events must be experienced from
label: Paragraph

text: within. For as Peter Sloterdijk so poignantly observes in his essay, Wo sind wir,
label: Paragraph

text: wenn wir Musik héren? (Where Are We When We Listen to Music?), auditory
label: Paragraph

text: experiences are always situated events — the act of listening, deprived of the priv-
label: Paragraph

text: ilege of distance granted to vision, is immersed in the specifics of a spatial setting.*
label: Paragraph

text: How can we locate this architectural aspiration for seemliness in the actual
label: Paragraph

text: music room of the House for an Art Lover? In his lecture, Mackintosh emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: that the operations of seemliness reside in the clothing of invention — architects
label: Paragraph

text: must “attempt the task of clothing in grace and beauty the new forms and condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions that modern developments of life — social - commercial and religious insist
label: Paragraph

text: upon...”” Echoing this sentiment in his seminal Stilarchitektur und Baukunst (Style-
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture and Building-Art) published in the same year (1902 first edition,
label: Paragraph

text: 1903 second edition), Hermann Muthesius writes: “For the new cannot arise in
label: Paragraph

text: such outward appearances; architecture, like every other expression, presumes
label: Paragraph

text: a vital presence. We expect new ideas, not commonplaces clothed in new
label: Paragraph

text: words. Architecture ... must seek its essence in content to which the external
label: Paragraph

text: appearance must adapt.” These allusions to the clothing of new inventions are
label: Paragraph

text: not coincidental; rather they implicate architectural involvement in an emerging
label: Paragraph

text: culture of abstraction epitomized by the embrace of whiteness. Just as Mackintosh
label: Paragraph

text: embraced the abstractness of the white page of his lecture to disperse his words
label: Paragraph

text: across the page as a composer might disseminate musical notations, so too does
label: Paragraph

text: his architecture articulate an abstract language of spatial detailing predicated upon
label: Paragraph

text: the whiteness of his interiors. This pursuit of an abstract, linear language of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural interior allows for the subtle transition from the ethical pursuit of
label: Paragraph

text: seemliness in his writings to the architectural construction of seaminess in his
label: Paragraph

text: domestic projects.
label: Paragraph

text: In the music room of the House for an Art Lover such seaminess is evident in the
label: Paragraph

text: insistent and visually dominant wainscoating, mullioning, and columnating of the
label: Paragraph

text: space. Here, the clothing of invention echoes through the iterative details of the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture: beginning with the elaborately encased piano, the central focus of
label: Paragraph

text: the space, and reverberating outward through linear vertical motives that ulti-
label: Paragraph

text: mately give shape to two flanking muse-like murals. The room is south facing,
label: Paragraph

text: and architectural echoes also emanate from the 10 reed thin columns flanking
label: Paragraph

text: and separating six sets of French doors that open out onto the adjacent outdoor
label: Paragraph

text: terrace. On the terrace, Mackintosh positions five planters containing thin orna-
label: Paragraph

text: mental trees, recalling his earlier description of an echo “faintly heard in the varia-
label: Paragraph

text: tions.” As the sun tracks across this southern facade, long thin shadows are cast
label: Paragraph

text: back into the music room, their systematic spacing resonating in the decorative
label: Paragraph

text: engaged columns of the opposite wall. Similarly, the murals bordering the piano
label: Paragraph

text: on each side are echoed in the reverberations of Margaret Macdonald’s so-called
label: Paragraph

text: “linen ladies” — textiles representing elongated female forms — sentinels marking
label: Paragraph

text: the transition from interiority to exteriority. Finally, ensconced within the baldac-
label: Paragraph

text: chino-like structure that houses the piano are two highly stylized roses, resonating
label: Paragraph

text: from this musical source, and reappearing in two elongated floor vases across
label: Paragraph

text: the room.
label: Paragraph

text: How, then, can this dialogue between seemliness and seaminess in Mackin-
label: Paragraph

text: tosh’s domestic interiors be interpreted? The exchange is not unlike the conver-
label: Paragraph

text: sation between the mythological figures of Echo and Narcissus. Though the
label: Paragraph

text: many literary accounts and paintings that re-tell this story set the stage for a dia-
label: Paragraph

text: logue, the reality of the narrative is that Echo is condemned by Hera to only ever
label: Paragraph

text: repeat the words she hears, and Narcissus is too captivated by his own image to
label: Paragraph

text: participate in a genuine dialogue. Latent within the figure of Echo is “the prospect
label: Paragraph

text: of sound displaced — uprooted, multiple, abbreviated, translocated,” and yet,
label: Paragraph

text: anticipated in this displacement is the fact of this conversation’s original situa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion." In this sense, Echo is at once a withered “genius loci,” simultaneously “scat-
label: Paragraph

text: tered so widely that she expands into the spirit of every place, pure and
label: Paragraph

text: singing.”'* If the aspiration for the Darmstadt competition was for the design
label: Paragraph

text: of a house for an art lover that was itself work of art (as the subsequent portfolio
label: Paragraph

text: title, Masters of Interior Art, suggests), then this dialogue between seemliness and
label: Paragraph

text: seaminess is a manifestation of the tension between lived and aesthetic experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ence in this domestic interior. If the mythological figure of Echo is transformed
label: Paragraph

text: from the “old me of ancient Echo” described as a “nymph out-of-doors,” to the
label: Paragraph

text: “hold me of early modern Echo” who was a “figure of interiors,” then this displace-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of echoes from an exterior condition to the interior suggests the complicity
label: Paragraph

text: of the natural world rendered immanent in the transition from echoes that are
label: Paragraph

text: site-specific to echoes that are ubiquitous.'? In the threshold between park and
label: Paragraph

text: terrace, and then again between terrace and music room, the domestication,
label: Paragraph

text: interiorization, and abstraction of the natural world into the immanence of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural motives reverberates like a displaced echo. Echoes are, in a sense, inte-
label: Paragraph

text: gral to the construction of modern privacy, “heard not as a noise but as the
label: Paragraph

text: sounding of a proper distance, a distance that made for domestic and other har-
label: Paragraph

text: monies.”"* In this example of “echo location,” there is no genuine dialogue
label: Paragraph

text: between seemliness and seaminess in Mackintosh’s projects, rather, aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: experience supplants lived experience in a displacement of the domestic interior
label: Paragraph

text: from an ethical realm to a realm of abstraction and autonomy.
label: Paragraph

text: Asimilar gravitation toward the realms of abstraction and autonomy is evident
label: Paragraph

text: in the work of Mackintosh’s Belgian contemporary, Henry van de Velde, specif-
label: Paragraph

text: ically in his design for the Nietzsche Archive between 1901 and 1903. Ina paralle
label: Caption

text: demonstration of seaminess, van de Velde inserts what architectural historian Ole
label: Paragraph

text: W. Fischer describes as a “studiolo” into the existing Villa Silberblick to house the
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher’s archive.’’ Fischer argues that this addition epitomizes van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde’s aspiration for “ornamental transcription,” or program art. Originated
label: Paragraph

text: by composers Richard Wagner and Franz Liszt, program art provided music
label: Paragraph

text: and architecture with a vehicle to shuttle non-figurative content and meaning
label: Paragraph

text: into the highly abstract realms of music and architecture. Program music utilized
label: Paragraph

text: a title, a parallel theoretical or philosophic text, and the arrangement of music
label: Paragraph

text: into themes, or leitmotifs, and this appealed to van de Velde for its “rejection
label: Paragraph

text: of mimicry and imitation ... providing an abstract object with philosophica
label: Paragraph

text: meaning beyond the application of symbolic ornament or classical tectonic lan-
label: Paragraph

text: guage.”'® Quite literally, in van de Velde’s studiolo, the echoes of Wagner and
label: Paragraph

text: Liszt and their quest for the manifestation of philosophical meaning in the
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction of architecture and music are evident. The seaminess of van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde’s archive resides in vertical ribs that appear to be simultaneously structural,
label: Paragraph

text: spatial dividers, bookshelf armatures, and decorative support for the white pla-
label: Paragraph

text: fond above. If Mackintosh’s music room utilizes the title of a House for an Art
label: Paragraph

text: Lover, the theoretical text of his lecture on “Seemliness,’ and the thematic
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of interiorized and domesticated natural motives, then, van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde similarly deploys the title - Nietzsche-Archiv — engraved above the villa’s
label: Paragraph

text: main entrance, the theoretical work of Wagner and Liszt’s framing of program
label: Paragraph

text: music, and the leitmotif of Nietzsche’s reformulation of the natural into “an
label: Paragraph

text: organic unity of spirit and matter.”’” Here, Mackintosh’s music room and van
label: Paragraph

text: de Velde’s Nietzsche archive embody echoes of distant mythological figures and
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary musical figures. These architectural ensembles raise questions
label: Paragraph

text: about the possibility of importing content and meaning in the context of abstrac-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, where the desire for seemliness and spatial decorum yields to an expression
label: Paragraph

text: of seaminess or spatial synthesis through composition and detailing.
label: Paragraph

text: Echo Replications and Echo Re-Presentations
label: Title

text: In 1901, the same year in which he executed the design of the House for an Art
label: Paragraph

text: Lover, Mackintosh contributed to a Viennese book on artistic lettering, Beispiele
label: Paragraph

text: kunstlerischer Schrift, deploying a font of his own making to inscribe a quotation
label: Paragraph

text: by J.D. Sedding.’* Though he never designed an alphabet, the distinctive lettering
label: Paragraph

text: of Mackintosh’s drawings — attenuated, stylized, ornamental, and uniquely his
label: Paragraph

text: own — became reified in his contribution to this publication. Today, the CRM Font
label: Paragraph

text: Company sells nine variations of Mackintosh’s stylized typography, each modifica-
label: Paragraph

text: tion named after a specific place, as with the “Glasgow Font,” or a specific project,
label: Paragraph

text: as with the “Artlover Font.”’? Although these fonts preserve a residual reference to
label: Paragraph

text: the place of their invention, in philosopher of communication theory Marshall
label: Paragraph

text: McLuhan’s sense they are autoamputations — echoing technological extensions
label: Paragraph

text: of Mackintosh himself, creating a closed system of reference — a culture of copies
label: Paragraph

text: that induces narcosis.”” In fact, the terminology of typography preserves something
label: Paragraph

text: of this numbing effect in the word that describes a stereotype block intended to
label: Paragraph

text: perpetuate phrases without change, the cliché. Though this argument refers specif:
label: Paragraph

text: ically to Mackintosh’s practice of typography, a similar case can be made for his
label: Paragraph

text: repetitive use of ornamental motives — ubiquitous stylistic echoes more or less
label: Paragraph

text: indifferent to the architectural settings in which they are deployed.
label: Paragraph

text: If McLuhan’s reading of Narcissus proffers an interpretive framework through
label: Paragraph

text: which to understand the culture of replication and reproduction surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s oeuvre, then it is Athanasius Kircher’s conceptualization of the echo
label: Paragraph

text: in his seminal Musurgia Universalis (1650) that will contribute to an understanding
label: Paragraph

text: of the re-presentational capacities of the term.”” What Kircher so beautifully evokes
label: Paragraph

text: in this illustration of an echo is its nascent capacity for polysemy, the possibility that
label: Paragraph

text: each one of the iterations might somehow re-present the original linguistic utter-
label: Paragraph

text: ance. How does Mackintosh accommodate such polysemy in his domestic projects?
label: Paragraph

text: How is the spatial utterance transformed in his work into manifold architectural
label: Paragraph

text: expressions and meanings? To answer these questions it is critical to examine
label: Paragraph

text: the operations of whiteness in his work.
label: Paragraph

text: As an architect, Mackintosh’s style evolves between 1893 and 1904, but there is a
label: Paragraph

text: period of marked productivity and growth between 1900 and 1901, a juncture that
label: Paragraph

text: is often described as his white period. Mackintosh’s first white room was a bed-
label: Paragraph

text: room designed for the publisher Robert Maclehose at Westdel in Glasgow in
label: Caption

text: 1898. The insertion of this single white room into a domestic setting was followed
label: Paragraph

text: by a number of such discrete, white interventions: the director's room at the
label: Paragraph

text: Glasgow School of Art (1899); the six rooms of Mackintosh’s own flat at Mains
label: Paragraph

text: Street (1900-06); and a series of tearoom projects for Miss Cranston, culminating
label: Paragraph

text: in a complete white interior on Ingram Street (1900). Elements from these early
label: Caption

text: white projects were then combined into a showcase room for the Vienna Secession
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition in 1900.7
label: Caption

text: All of the white projects leading up to the House for an Art Lover can be char-
label: Paragraph

text: acterized as insertions: the insertion of a room (Westdel); the insertion of a
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of spaces in a pre-existing structure (Mains Street and Miss Cranston’s
label: Caption

text: Tearooms); the insertion of a room within a larger exhibition space (the Secession
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition and later, the Universal Exposition of Turin in 1902). The role of white-
label: Paragraph

text: ness within this strategic spatial insertion resides in the production of a harmonious
label: Paragraph

text: and atmospheric space that is both radically interiorized and conceptually whole.
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s use of whiteness connotes interiority by rendering the interior a rep-
label: Paragraph

text: resentational domain in which the materiality of the natural world is translated and
label: Paragraph

text: domesticated. By producing a spatial monochrome, Mackintosh achieves a visual
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis of the elements — a spatial ensemble merging architecture, furnishings,
label: Paragraph

text: fittings, and details into a novel stylistic whole. A simple comparison of
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s scheme for the House for an Art Lover with the second-place entry
label: Paragraph

text: by Baillie Scott, demonstrates the degree to which whiteness allowed Mackintosh
label: Paragraph

text: to eschew historical reference, and to some extent, materiality. And yet, in all of
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s white projects, even the Director’s Office at the Glasgow School and
label: Paragraph

text: the tearooms for Miss Cranston, the whiteness establishes a horizon of domesticity,
label: Paragraph

text: operating at the level of spatial manicure or refinement to produce a hermetic
label: Paragraph

text: domestic sanctuary. In an untitled paper on architecture dating back to 1892, Mack-
label: Paragraph

text: intosh associates the use of white paint with an aspiration for comfort: “Paint I say is
label: Paragraph

text: no deception, for in wood, iron, plaster & sometimes even stone it is necessary for
label: Paragraph

text: comfort....””? Here, white paint provides a context that allows echoes of Mackin-
label: Paragraph

text: tosh’s domestic projects and the comfort they invoke, to bleach dimensions of his
label: Paragraph

text: public projects, coating them in whiteness and infusing them with the coziness of
label: Paragraph

text: home. Paradoxically, the whiteness of Mackintosh’s domestic projects shares affi-
label: Paragraph

text: nities with the whiteness of the exhibition space, especially those of the Vienna
label: Paragraph

text: Secession in 1900, and the Universal Exposition held in Turin in 1902. In both,
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh exhibited white rooms, embraced for their purity, “so straightforward
label: Paragraph

text: that they look as innocent and serious as young girls about to receive Holy
label: Paragraph

text: Communion,” and yet critiqued for their blanched emptiness: “there was scarcely
label: Paragraph

text: anything in these rooms except two upright chairs, with backs as tall as man, which
label: Paragraph

text: stood on white carpet, looking at each other over a slender table, silently like
label: Paragraph

text: ghosts.”** By the time Mackintosh designs the House for an Art Lover, the white-
label: Paragraph

text: ness that was formerly a strategy for discrete spatial insertion has become ubiqui-
label: Paragraph

text: tous and pervasive, as evidenced by the subtle exterior massing of the white
label: Paragraph

text: volumes of the house. This is the whiteness of abstraction, the whiteness that facil-
label: Paragraph

text: itates the smooth importation of natural motives into the interior of the music
label: Paragraph

text: room, the whiteness that Mackintosh posits as a blank canvas for the expression
label: Paragraph

text: of cultural ideas. In his untitled paper on architecture of 1892, Mackintosh articu-
label: Paragraph

text: lates the primary role of the artist and architect as that of giving “expression to the
label: Paragraph

text: ideas of the general cultured mind,” and the role of architecture to offer “pleasure
label: Paragraph

text: to the mind” and “comfort and protection to the body.””’ Thus, across the white
label: Paragraph

text: gesso of the murals, the white linen of the wall hangings, the white paint of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural details, and the white fibers of the carpet, Mackintosh offers a blank
label: Paragraph

text: canvas, sending echoes and reverberations throughout the European architectural
label: Paragraph

text: community, promoting a novel white architecture that is interiorized, ahistorical,
label: Paragraph

text: domesticated, exhibitionist, and abstract.
label: Paragraph

text: Polysemous Echoes: Subverting
label: Title

text: Disciplinary Categories
label: Title

text: Though the mythological figure of Echo is often interpreted benignly as a figure
label: Paragraph

text: who can only reiterate, it would be misguided to interpret the echoes of
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s music room in the House for an Art Lover as pale imitations lacking
label: Paragraph

text: agency. In fact, it is possible to “retrieve the nymph Echo who shows that iter-
label: Paragraph

text: ation can explode a category from within, and that language’s parrotings some-
label: Paragraph

text: times do have salutary agency.”*° But how is this categorical dismantling
label: Paragraph

text: accomplished? In what way does the repetition of an utterance achieve salutary
label: Paragraph

text: agency? “Echo does re-present, literally so. But what she presents back is no
label: Paragraph

text: longer the original utterance. The word, now as thing, is wrenched into a novel
label: Paragraph

text: sense or a nonsense, made stranger by the brute fact of its re-presentation alone
label: Paragraph

text: or because its context has been lopped off.””” The echo emanates from a place,
label: Paragraph

text: but the more distance that is accrued between the echo and the initial utterance,
label: Paragraph

text: the greater the potential for de-contextualization. This capacity of the echo to de-
label: Paragraph

text: contextualize is readily apparent in Mackintosh’s work — the coat of whiteness he
label: Paragraph

text: utilizes in projects between 1900 and 1901 is just one manifestation of this ten-
label: Paragraph

text: dency. However, in order to identify echoes within his work that not only re-
label: Paragraph

text: present but also have the capacity to unmake disciplinary categories, we must
label: Paragraph

text: look to Mackintosh’s furniture design, and specifically to the so-called “high-
label: Paragraph

text: back.” Near the piano in the music room of the House for an Art Lover sits a
label: Paragraph

text: simple table surrounded by three high-backs; a fourth sits flush against the solid
label: Paragraph

text: wall, a tacit reminder of the spatial agency of these furnishings. For the high-back
label: Paragraph

text: is not simply a chair in its typical sense; rather it is charged with the difficult task
label: Paragraph

text: of producing an alternative interior that is at once more private and more exclu-
label: Paragraph

text: sive than its original context. Echoes of this strategy of territorializing space
label: Paragraph

text: through the deployment of room-like furniture also appear in the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of Frank Lloyd Wright, perhaps most notably in the dining-room chairs of his
label: Paragraph

text: Robie House (1908 to 1910). Why, then, does Mackintosh make the curious
label: Paragraph

text: choice of locating the fourth high-back against the wall, rather than fully enclos-
label: Paragraph

text: ing this nascent room within a room? This high-back’s language of slim repeti-
label: Paragraph

text: tious verticals resonates with the numerous iterations of thin vertical elements
label: Paragraph

text: in the room — mullions, columns, even the rhythm of slim wires suspending
label: Paragraph

text: the light fixtures from the ceiling. Here, in an interesting inversion of Robin
label: Paragraph

text: Evans’ argument about the developed surface of the eighteenth-century domestic
label: Paragraph

text: interior, rather than the interior elevation preserving all of the evidence of the
label: Paragraph

text: objects that will ultimately populate the room, Mackintosh’s high-backs function
label: Paragraph

text: as a sort of “lopped off” context, with the capacity to generate a domestic interior
label: Paragraph

text: in their next setting.”* The high-backs are complicit both in the completion of the
label: Paragraph

text: room within a room, and in the anticipation of possible future interiorities.
label: Paragraph

text: The earliest versions of the high-backs were designed by Mackintosh for the inte-
label: Paragraph

text: rior of Miss Cranston’s Argyle Street Tearoom in 1898, executed in dark stained
label: Caption

text: oak and topped with oval ornaments, likened by some observers to a “human head
label: Paragraph

text: atop an androgynous body.”” Within the context of the tearoom, the chairs were
label: Paragraph

text: designed to create a domestic intimacy within a public venue, but their capacity to
label: Paragraph

text: generate their own context is also noted: “When these chairs are placed at a table,
label: Paragraph

text: the anthropomorphic references intensify; even with no one sitting in them the
label: Paragraph

text: chairs appear peopled.”*° Once again, as an ensemble, the high-backs have the
label: Paragraph

text: capacity to recreate the context of intimate conversation, with or without occu-
label: Paragraph

text: pants. While this echo of Mackintosh’s work compellingly dismantles the category
label: Paragraph

text: “chair” by allowing the ensemble of high-backs to “lop off’ the context and gen-
label: Paragraph

text: erate some version of it in their subsequent settings, the status of the high-back
label: Paragraph

text: changed radically in 1973 when facsimiles were produced for the Triennale in
label: Paragraph

text: Milan by Cassina. At precisely the moment in which the facsimile is produced,
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s high-backs become reified as iconic objects, as authored chairs, as his-
label: Paragraph

text: torical reproductions, relinquishing their capacity to generate context, to sponsor
label: Paragraph

text: privacy, and to proffer alternative interiorities. Ironically, in a Sotheby’s auction
label: Paragraph

text: just two years later, a Mackintosh high-back from the drawing room of the Hill
label: Paragraph

text: House (1904) was sold for a record-breaking sum for twentieth-century decorative
label: Paragraph

text: art objects at auction. As one observer remarked: “Despite the efforts of scholars
label: Paragraph

text: and others seeking to establish Mackintosh’s place in history ... it was in fact the
label: Paragraph

text: sale of a single chair that, through the activities of the commercial world, made
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh a household name.”*’ At this moment of the turn of the century,
label: Paragraph

text: the role played by furniture in the definition or in-definition of space is critical. This
label: Paragraph

text: is a moment of equipoise that marks the transition from the raumplan and its com-
label: Paragraph

text: plicity with furnishings in the act of room making, and the free plan whose only
label: Paragraph

text: concession to furniture is to provide an open floor plate upon which emancipated
label: Paragraph

text: objects can be positioned. Equally, echoes of this moment can be found in the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund debates of 1914, in which Muthesius and van de Velde debated the vir-
label: Paragraph

text: tues of individually designed furnishings and objects (van de Velde) versus standar-
label: Paragraph

text: dized and industrially produced goods (Muthesius.)
label: Paragraph

text: Conclusion: Atmospheric Echoes Over Time
label: Title

text: There is an intangible that remains to be addressed in this account of the figurative
label: Paragraph

text: echoes of Charles Rennie Mackintosh’s music room, and we must return to
label: Paragraph

text: Hermann Muthesius’ characterization of Mackintosh’s domestic interiors to retrieve
label: Paragraph

text: it. What lies behind Muthesius’ observation that a book in an unsuitable binding
label: Paragraph

text: would disturb the atmosphere of one of Mackintosh’s domestic interiors? Harry Mal-
label: Paragraph

text: lgrave sheds light on this question, when he identifies a text written by Richard Strei-
label: Paragraph

text: ter in 1896 as a theoretical influence on Muthesius’ work. In the text, Streiter argues:
label: Paragraph

text: Just as realism in poetry views as one of its central tasks the delineation of character in
label: Paragraph

text: relation to its milieu, so the parallel program in architecture sees as its most desirable
label: Paragraph

text: goal of artistic truth the development of the character of a building not only out of the
label: Paragraph

text: determination of its needs but also from the milieu — from the qualities of local mate-
label: Paragraph

text: rials and from the environmentally and historically conditioned atmosphere of the
label: Paragraph

text: place [Stimmung der Ortlichkeit.
label: Paragraph

text: Somewhere between Mackintosh’s first white ensemble in the Westdel bed-
label: Paragraph

text: room and the production of facsimile chairs that made the architect a household
label: Paragraph

text: name, lurks this question of character, seemliness, or environmentally and histor-
label: Paragraph

text: ically conditioned atmosphere. For, as everyone knows, a critical component of any
label: Paragraph

text: echo is the atmosphere in which it is immersed, the milieu through which it reso-
label: Paragraph

text: nates. If an echo is the “sounding of a proper distance” that occasions domestic
label: Paragraph

text: harmony, then in the work of Charles Rennie Mackintosh one understands that
label: Paragraph

text: when this distance is not in the service of architectural character, or environmen-
label: Paragraph

text: tally and historically conditioned atmospheres, it can become the springboard for
label: Paragraph

text: architectural styles, motives and objects, reified and fully emancipated from their
label: Paragraph

text: respective contexts — displaced interiors, both literally and figuratively.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1960, Mackintosh’s home at 78 Southpark Avenue in Glasgow, where he lived
label: Paragraph

text: from 1906 to 1914, was demolished. In 1981, the Hunterian Art Gallery recon-
label: Paragraph

text: structed the hall, the dining room, the studio, the drawing room, and the principal
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom, within the museum, calling the exhibit “The Mackintosh House.” And
label: Paragraph

text: though the House for an Art Lover was a hypothetical proposal for an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: competition in 1901, the project was fully realized in Glasgow’s Bellahouston Parkin
label: Paragraph

text: 1996. The renovated structure boasts a Mackintosh exhibition, a heritage center, art
label: Caption

text: studios and classes, the Art Lover’s Shop selling countless Mackintosh facsimiles and
label: Paragraph

text: reproductions, and the Art Lover's Café; and it is one of the premier venues for wed-
label: Paragraph

text: dings in Glasgow. The same conditions that rendered the music room of
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s House for an Art Lover an environmentally and historically condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tioned atmosphere, imbued each of its ingredients with the dual capacities of
label: Paragraph

text: reification and emancipation. Beneath the seemliness of appropriate beauty resides
label: Paragraph

text: the seaminess of emancipated styles and motives; beneath the atmosphere of
label: Paragraph

text: whiteness that fosters a dialogue between constituent parts, resides a coat of white
label: Paragraph

text: paint — the sign for radical interiorization and absolute autonomy; and beneath the
label: Paragraph

text: capacity of the high-back to produce a room within a room, undermining shifting
label: Paragraph

text: disciplinary categories, resides the Mackintosh Chair, a facsimile that reifies the orig-
label: Paragraph

text: inal, pushing it squarely back into the well-worn category of “chair.” Many echoes
label: Paragraph

text: resonate from the source of Mackintosh’s music room: echoes in the practice of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural monochromy and in the aspirations of the Vienna Secession; echoes
label: Paragraph

text: of a movement away from period styles and toward the white abstraction of early
label: Paragraph

text: modernism; and echoes of the contemporary discourse on World Heritage Sites,
label: Paragraph

text: historic preservation, and curatorial practices with their attendant cultures of facsi-
label: Paragraph

text: miles and reproductions. Amidst these echoes, reverberations, and resonances,
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh’s aspiration for seemliness is displaced, both within the work itself
label: Paragraph

text: and within the history of architecture. The hollow drumming of museum interiors
label: Paragraph

text: and facile facsimiles supplants his desire for environmentally and historically condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tioned atmospheres. The competition for the House for an Art Lover is the ultimate
label: Paragraph

text: inducement for Mackintosh, an invitation to aestheticize experience through design,
label: Paragraph

text: to create a house that is a work of art. The ambition of the music room, then, is not to
label: Paragraph

text: function as a space for making music, but rather to show itselfas a room that is simul-
label: Paragraph

text: taneously a work of art. Beneath the detritus of preservation, restoration, and repro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction lurks the “large rhythm,” the “sustained note,” and the “deep vibration” of
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate beauty, awaiting a context through which it can once again echo.

label: Caption

text: TIMELESS MODERNITY
label: Title

text: But the task of art, and therefore also of modern art, has remained what it has been in
label: Paragraph

text: all times. Modern art must offer us modern forms that are created by us and that
label: Paragraph

text: express our abilities and actions.’
label: Paragraph

text: The Postal Savings Bank in Vienna was built in two phases from 1904 to 1906
label: Paragraph

text: and from 1910 to 1912. Its architect, Otto Wagner, was over 60 years old at the
label: Paragraph

text: time, and perhaps the most influential architect in Vienna. He was also a highly
label: Paragraph

text: controversial figure. Shortly after he was appointed professor at the Academy of
label: Paragraph

text: Fine Arts he published his lectures, which were both a summary of his professional
label: Paragraph

text: credo and a militant manifesto. This work, entitled Modern Architecture, demanded
label: Paragraph

text: that architecture would no longer imitate past forms but become an up-to-date
label: Paragraph

text: building art. Wagner's efforts were aided by a lucky coincidence of internal and
label: Paragraph

text: external factors. In the 1890s a fundamental change in art and culture had swept
label: Paragraph

text: through both Vienna and the rest of Europe. The break with historicism (referred
label: Paragraph

text: to as revivalism) came along with a turn toward the new instead of the old, toward
label: Paragraph

text: the creative rather than the receptive. These were widespread themes around 1890
label: Paragraph

text: and the revolutionary changes in art and architecture were only part of these pro-
label: Paragraph

text: cesses.” For Wagner this tendency was not without inner contradictions, as his ear-
label: Paragraph

text: lier works seemed to relate him to a “free renaissance style.” The turn toward an
label: Paragraph

text: ideological radicalism preceded visible changes in his practice.’ A paradoxical — or
label: Paragraph

text: according to his admirers tragic — aspect of his career was that although he took part
label: Paragraph

text: in many international and local competitions and developed, exhibited, and pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lished many progressive and inventive projects, he received hardly any public com-
label: Paragraph

text: missions until the mid-1890s. Most of his works were apartment buildings of mixed
label: Paragraph

text: function, among them several important and spectacular houses in downtown
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna. His big commission in the mid-1890s to design the station buildings
label: Paragraph

text: and other structures and amenities of the Stadtbahn (urban railway) was to shape
label: Paragraph

text: definitively the face of the modern metropolis. However, Wagner later complained
label: Paragraph

text: of not having received the type of monumental commissions with which he could
label: Paragraph

text: have demonstrated the superiority of the modern architectural principles he
label: Paragraph

text: espoused. He initiated conceptual plans for buildings such as a modern church
label: Paragraph

text: and a variety of museum types. His “agitation project” for the city museum
label: Paragraph

text: (1900) was an attempt to pre-empt the announcement of a public competition
label: Paragraph

text: in order to be awarded the commission directly. Although he did indeed win
label: Paragraph

text: the competition, which was announced shortly after his action, he was not able
label: Paragraph

text: to realize his plans even after a long and eventful battle. Nevertheless, he went
label: Paragraph

text: on to build two monumental buildings at the beginning of the twentieth century,
label: Paragraph

text: which were to be his major works: a church for the psychiatric hospital complex at
label: Paragraph

text: Steinhof on the outskirts of Vienna (1902-04) and the Postal Savings Bank
label: Paragraph

text: (1903-12). Both are manifestations of his mature approach while naturally differing
label: Paragraph

text: greatly in purpose and type. Whereas in the case of the church the aim was a mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern reformulation of a traditional type — he had referred to it as the most interesting
label: Paragraph

text: task for an architect — the Postal Savings Bank was a prototype of an institution
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of modern mass society.
label: Paragraph

text: Planning the Institution: “The Modern
label: Title

text: Building Method”
label: Title

text: Throughout Europe, Postal Savings Banks were new institutions based on the
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructural and communication possibilities of the network of post offices.
label: Paragraph

text: The Postal Savings Bank in Vienna was founded as a state institution in 1883.
label: Paragraph

text: Its aim was to encourage thrift in wider and poorer circles of society and, at the
label: Paragraph

text: same time, to collect and use these savings for the economic benefit of the state,
label: Paragraph

text: which was to compete with the monopoly of the big private banks. The Postal Sav-
label: Paragraph

text: ings Bank was a dynamic and extensive institution. The organization of work was
label: Paragraph

text: strict, resembling a factory more than an office, with a 14-hour work day and poor
label: Paragraph

text: conditions. The spaces in the Postal Savings Banks were very tight and considered
label: Paragraph

text: unhealthy (due to the lack of ventilation and proper sanitation). As a consequence
label: Paragraph

text: of these problems and the repeated protests of the employees about them, along
label: Paragraph

text: with further plans for development, the government decided to support the erec-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of a new building.“
label: Paragraph

text: An open competition was announced, which was unusual for state buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna in this period. The relatively rare state commissions were usually given
label: Paragraph

text: immediately to the officials of the government building departments. Architects
label: Paragraph

text: repeatedly protested against this practice and demanded open competitions. The
label: Paragraph

text: one for the Postal Savings Bank perhaps reflected the prestige of this new insti-
label: Paragraph

text: tution, as the competition brief meticulously described the practical demands for
label: Paragraph

text: light, healthy and hygienic workplaces, and sanitary equipment. As far as the
label: Paragraph

text: building was concerned, the brief stipulated “simple and dignified appointments”
label: Paragraph

text: and that “an emphasis should be laid on durability and low maintenance.”” Two
label: Paragraph

text: banking halls were to be developed: a larger, dignified one in a covered court-
label: Paragraph

text: yard for checking transactions, and a smaller one for savings transactions. Prio-
label: Paragraph

text: rities were given to pragmatic factors such as general appropriateness for
label: Paragraph

text: business, sufficient usable space, and a well-functioning system of communica-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, in addition to the feasibility of construction. Aesthetics were mentioned
label: Paragraph

text: only among the lower priorities. Of the 32 participating architects, the projects
label: Paragraph

text: varied from historicist to modern solutions but most stayed within the compe-
label: Paragraph

text: tition brief and planned a functional building with relatively simple facades and
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation. Five prizes were awarded, together with Wagner’s winning
label: Paragraph

text: commission.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner was already familiar with the problems of the Postal Savings Bank as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the conditions of the site. After winning a joint first prize with his city expan-
label: Paragraph

text: sion plan in 1893, he was commissioned to elaborate on a plan for regulating the
label: Paragraph

text: part of the Ringstrafe where the bank was to be located (the Stubenring). On the site
label: Caption

text: of the huge military barracks, which were to be demolished, Wagner proposed a
label: Paragraph

text: new central post office and the Postal Savings Bank nearby. Later, most of the plot
label: Paragraph

text: was bought for the erection of the new bank building. Although the irregular, trap-
label: Paragraph

text: ezoid plot was not directly a showpiece on the boulevard, it had immediate spatial
label: Paragraph

text: and visual contact with the Ringstrafe because one plot between the Ring and
label: Paragraph

text: the new bank building was left open for a small urban square and a forecourt
label: Paragraph

text: to the building. The huge bank and office building was constructed in two phases.
label: Paragraph

text: The first part, closer to the Ringstrafe, was erected between 1904 and 1906, and the
label: Paragraph

text: second part was built in simplified form between 1909 and 1912.
label: Paragraph

text: The building, which according to Wagner is an exemplary case of a modern
label: Paragraph

text: building type, namely the office building (Amtshaus), is horizontal in character with
label: Paragraph

text: a prominent middle part, long wings at the sides and a vast building mass. His
label: Paragraph

text: design efforts were directed to fulfill the functional needs of the building and at
label: Paragraph

text: the same time to express its overall character: “The equivalent office rooms of
label: Paragraph

text: the individual floors, the extension of the units for operative functions refer already
label: Paragraph

text: in outlook to a certain uniformity.”* The proportion of walls and windows, the
label: Paragraph

text: varying heights of floors and the functional ornament brought some diversity to
label: Paragraph

text: the uniformity of the huge building mass. As one of the main goals of the planning
label: Paragraph

text: was to create healthy and hygienic working conditions, Wagner planned “unusu-
label: Paragraph

text: ally” large windows in order to let more light in.” The demand for more available
label: Paragraph

text: space in the building required relatively low floor heights, which Wagner justified
label: Paragraph

text: by referring to practicalities.
label: Paragraph

text: He employed a hybrid construction with concrete floors and load-bearing walls
label: Paragraph

text: made of brick. The brick walls are covered by a facade, which Wagner had already
label: Paragraph

text: alluded to in his theory of a modern building method in the first edition of Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, where he sought to demonstrate the superiority of modern construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to the so-called Renaissance method. His example of the latter was Semper and
label: Paragraph

text: Hasenauer’s Burgtheater (1871-88) with its heavy and expensive materials and
label: Paragraph

text: labor-intensive construction. In contrast, modern construction was cheaper and fas-
label: Paragraph

text: ter: “For the exterior cladding of a building ... a panel system will be used on the
label: Paragraph

text: planar surfaces. Since these panels can be assumed to have significantly less cubic
label: Paragraph

text: volume, they can be designed for a nobler material. ... They are to be fastened with
label: Paragraph

text: bronze bolts (rosettes).”*
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner made use of a sophisticated stone cladding system for the facade. In ear-
label: Paragraph

text: lier versions, he chose majolica and even the type of ornamentation recalled in its
label: Paragraph

text: motifs the Secession, with its quasi-organic forms. In the final version, one can dis-
label: Paragraph

text: cern different versions of the veneered patterns. The rusticated base is “curved at
label: Paragraph

text: the bottom to create a shadow line and increase the visual height,”” but reveals at
label: Paragraph

text: the corners and through the fixing bolts that it is not solid masonry. In the middle
label: Paragraph

text: part, Wagner combined bonded and gridded configurations. The former was char-
label: Paragraph

text: acteristic of the traditional building method; the latter emphasized the veneered
label: Paragraph

text: nature of masonry. This duality expresses the difference between heavy and light
label: Paragraph

text: structure, which recalls the classical order, where “this facade becomes a columned
label: Paragraph

text: portico between two towers.”’° The ornamentation reinforces this reading as the
label: Paragraph

text: ornaments at the bottom and upper part of the facade can be understood as the base
label: Paragraph

text: and capital of columns.'?
label: Paragraph

text: The different versions of the plan trace the evolution of Wagner’s stylistic devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opment from the use of explicitly historicist elements through the influences of the
label: Paragraph

text: Secession to a rational, functionalist approach. At the same time, Wagner distanced
label: Paragraph

text: himself more and more from tradition or the idea of continuity. He stated that art
label: Paragraph

text: and architecture should always express their own time. Given the new materials,
label: Paragraph

text: methods of construction, demands, and lifestyle, these should become the starting
label: Paragraph

text: point for artistic creation. In the final phase of this evolution, Wagner arrived at a
label: Paragraph

text: severe form of economic expression, where, as Otto Antonia Graf outlines, “all the
label: Paragraph

text: concepts and realized constructions result from the character and purpose of the
label: Paragraph

text: building.”’* This did not entail a ban on tradition, which is present in a clear
label: Paragraph

text: but more indirect, allusive way.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner emphasized two main functions on the facade: first, the position of the
label: Paragraph

text: directorate on the piano nobile, expressing hierarchy and distinction; and second, the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance with five doors and a canopy above them, which underscored the bustling
label: Paragraph

text: public circulation. This construction is kept apart from the main body of the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. It has a roof of glass on a metal frame supported by thin aluminum columns.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner, thus, created a number of transitions from the outer to the inner public
label: Paragraph

text: space. First, the urban square functions as an anteroom to the stairs with the can-
label: Paragraph

text: opy. In the building itself we enter an imposing, elegant vestibule with a broad,
label: Paragraph

text: marble staircase, which leads up to a connecting passage that opens onto the hall.
label: Paragraph

text: This ceremonial introduction heightens the effect of the main hall in the heart of
label: Paragraph

text: the building.
label: Paragraph

text: The Heart of the Building: The Counter Hall
label: Title

text: Counter halls with a public function have always formed the central part of modern
label: Paragraph

text: bank buildings, beginning with Soane’s spectacular Bank of England (1788-1834).
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner's counter hall is a building within a building, a light iron and glass structure
label: Paragraph

text: that contrasts with the stone clad exterior. From the very beginning Wagner placed
label: Paragraph

text: the vestibule and the main hall in the center of a symmetric composition. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: the explicit demand of the competition brief to allocate the counters for checking
label: Paragraph

text: and savings activities in different rooms, he concentrated all of them in the main
label: Paragraph

text: hall and situated the processing administration vertically in the floors on both sides
label: Paragraph

text: of the courtyard. The individual floors were arranged flexibly. The safes and safety
label: Paragraph

text: deposit boxes were placed below the courtyard along with a large mail room,
label: Paragraph

text: which was connected by lifts to the counters and the administrative offices for
label: Paragraph

text: checking and savings, in order to provide an effective network of communication.
label: Paragraph

text: However, compositional considerations were of equal importance to practical ones
label: Paragraph

text: for Wagner. He divided the almost regular quadrilateral courtyard into three parts
label: Paragraph

text: in order to achieve the desirable elongated form of the hall. This resulted in a basil-
label: Paragraph

text: ica-like space with three naves, a higher one in the middle section and two lower
label: Paragraph

text: aisles on each side.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the most effective and influential feature of the counter hall is the
label: Paragraph

text: juxtaposition of a sacral type of space with industrial materials and structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Iron glass constructions had been a novelty yielding great acclaim in public
label: Paragraph

text: buildings since the middle of the nineteenth century. Examples of such anon-
label: Paragraph

text: ymous, transitory spaces of the modern metropolis can be found in exhibition,
label: Paragraph

text: trade, and commercial halls, as well as in department stores. However, the vis-
label: Paragraph

text: ible use of iron structures and their aesthetic value sparked fierce debates in
label: Paragraph

text: architectural theory and criticism. Until the last decade of the nineteenth cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury, the majority of architects and critics were rather skeptical about their
label: Paragraph

text: artistic merits. Wagner expressed great interest in new materials and technol-
label: Paragraph

text: ogies: he considered iron, and later also concrete, to be the most promising of
label: Paragraph

text: the new materials and hoped to make fitting use of them as modern architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture advanced.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner had already used an iron-glass roof in his Landerbank 20 years earlier,
label: Paragraph

text: but had combined it with traditional or conventional historicist architectural ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments. The same can be observed in the designs for the Stadtbahn stations. In
label: Paragraph

text: the Postal Savings Bank, however, Wagner avoided any direct allusion to historical
label: Paragraph

text: forms, and consciously used industrial structures without any traditional ornamen-
label: Paragraph

text: tation. At the same time, he wanted to avoid the “ignoble” appearance of the iron
label: Paragraph

text: trusses caused by the usual industrial green paint and, therefore, devised a method
label: Paragraph

text: to ennoble the iron structure, as he described it: “The naturally very precisely exe-
label: Paragraph

text: cuted work will be transposed and then repeatedly painted white and the paint
label: Paragraph

text: itself polished.”’* Next, he combined the iron with different cladding materials:
label: Paragraph

text: “After all the construction workers have finished their works and left the site,
label: Paragraph

text: the greatest part of the iron surfaces thus treated would be embellished with adorn-
label: Paragraph

text: ments in aluminum and golden bronze screwed onto the columns as diverse smal-
label: Paragraph

text: ler parts. ...white as primary color remains partly visible and together with the
label: Paragraph

text: similarly white toned decor of the room, it surely elicits a very noble impression.
label: Paragraph

text: It is proper to maintain that the result is an effect not yet achieved elsewhere.
label: Paragraph

text: A decor like this will, I hope, make the iron acceptable with the further highly val-
label: Paragraph

text: uable advantage of easy cleaning.”"*
label: Paragraph

text: Besides the de-materialized iron, glass is the ultimate material of the hall. The
label: Paragraph

text: covering uses translucent industrial glass, which lets light in and allows the support-
label: Paragraph

text: ing structure to glitter through the roof. Wagner wanted to build a second protec-
label: Paragraph

text: tive glass roof at the top of the building but due to the wishes of the client had to
label: Paragraph

text: lower it immediately above the visible membrane roof of the hall. Wagner was
label: Paragraph

text: afraid of the unpleasant effects of these changes, in consequence of which he had
label: Paragraph

text: “to lower and simplify the profiles of the side aisles, to thicken the iron trusses in
label: Paragraph

text: order to be able to carry the second roof which will take away the ... lightness and
label: Paragraph

text: daintiness of the banking hall.”’* On both sides of the central nave, five columns
label: Caption

text: bear the double-skin structure, running through the lower membrane of the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Not only the roof but also the floor is made of glass, which is surprising at first sight.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps because of the unusual application of glass bricks, this is the only point
label: Paragraph

text: where Wagner refers to spectacular examples from abroad. It is no accident that
label: Paragraph

text: these examples are from Paris, which was for Wagner the center of modern life.'®
label: Paragraph

text: The pragmatic argument for the use of the glass bricks was their translucency,
label: Paragraph

text: which allowed the workplaces below the hall to receive natural light. Nevertheless,
label: Paragraph

text: the compositional role and aesthetic effects were at least as important, or even
label: Paragraph

text: more so. The field of glass bricks is ordered in a raster of a thin solid framework
label: Paragraph

text: made of white granite with black frames and stripes indicating the main direction.
label: Paragraph

text: The conception seems to be similar to the description of carpets in Modern Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. Within an elongated, bigger field, the bricks are always ordered in units of
label: Paragraph

text: four pieces, with two different prismatic patterns. The thick translucent material
label: Paragraph

text: refracts light and produces spectacular effects.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner also used glass for cladding the walls. Together with the marble panels
label: Paragraph

text: below and the artificial marble plaster above, the glass panels create a sleek com-
label: Paragraph

text: posite surface. The rationale is again functional: the cladding served to protect the
label: Paragraph

text: walls from the doodles of the public or clerks who might be tempted to scribble
label: Paragraph

text: their calculations on them. However, the intentions of the composition seem to go
label: Paragraph

text: beyond these practicalities as the combined effect of the different kinds and uses of
label: Paragraph

text: glass and their harmony with other materials and structures result in complex aes-
label: Paragraph

text: thetic effects.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner was even keen on the newest, rarely used materials such as aluminum,
label: Paragraph

text: which he sought to use abundantly for both functional and aesthetic purposes. Its
label: Paragraph

text: silver-like, glittering appearance, together with its ease of cleaning and non-fading
label: Paragraph

text: nature, made it suitable for noble and elegant features both outside and inside the
label: Paragraph

text: building. Aluminum columns by the entrance support the canopy, which acts as a
label: Caption

text: kind of prelude to the banking hall, signaling the difference between the building’s
label: Paragraph

text: solid structure and the modern iron-glass construction inside. The iron columns of
label: Paragraph

text: the hall are clad in aluminum with geometric ornamentation. Wagner also used
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum for the design of the ventilation and heating pipes, which number among
label: Paragraph

text: the most original and inventive elements of the interior. Another new material was
label: Paragraph

text: linoleum, invented in the middle of the nineteenth century, an inexpensive material
label: Paragraph

text: for high use areas. He carefully focused on the protection of the heavily used parts of
label: Paragraph

text: the floor. To avoid buckling and the danger of stumbling, the linoleum is inverted
label: Paragraph

text: into the floor and, with the other materials, creates an even surface. Each material
label: Paragraph

text: and form is repeated, transformed, connected, and contrasted with others.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner consciously avoided the use of vivid colors in his design. The colors in
label: Paragraph

text: both public counter hall and work places is a combination of white, gray, silver,
label: Paragraph

text: and black, expressing the economic, hygienic, and impersonal character of the
label: Paragraph

text: institution and the Grofstadt. Nevertheless, in the central hall the palate is nobler,
label: Paragraph

text: while in the workplaces it is much simpler — an assembly of a kind of “colorless
label: Paragraph

text: colors.”’” The glass floor and roof, the combination of glittering marble and glass
label: Paragraph

text: panels on the walls, as well as the added marble plaster above them — all add to
label: Paragraph

text: the effects of light. In addition, the exterior walls in the courtyard above the hall
label: Paragraph

text: are plastered in white majolica, the brightness of which further amplifies the
label: Paragraph

text: reflections and demonstrates the conscious manner in which Wagner made
label: Paragraph

text: his choice of materials and effects. Whereas from a functional point of view
label: Paragraph

text: cleanness and clearness are the keywords, the harmony of materials and effects,
label: Paragraph

text: of transparency and reflections and the rich modulations of light result in a sort
label: Paragraph

text: of “industrial sublime” and monumentality. The banking hall seems to be float-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in light, strengthened and contrasted even by the artificial light of the pure
label: Paragraph

text: electric bulbs.
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner designed the Postal Savings Bank as a Gesamtkunstwerk, an integral work
label: Paragraph

text: of art encompassing both the building and its furniture from the smallest detail to the
label: Paragraph

text: whole. The functional aspects, the employment of objects and rooms and their ease
label: Paragraph

text: of care and durability were expressed by Wagner in the different forms of covering,
label: Paragraph

text: cladding and fixings. Not only the marble plates but also the glass panels are fixed to
label: Paragraph

text: the walls with bolts. The feet and other heavily used parts of the furniture are cov-
label: Paragraph

text: ered with aluminum. The use of fixed bolts and heads as structural ornaments can be
label: Paragraph

text: observed in various forms and at different scales, from the furniture and the inner
label: Paragraph

text: walls to the facade. There is a certain duality or even ambiguity in this use of “bolts”
label: Paragraph

text: or rivets, which partly act as real structural joints and partly as ornaments.
label: Paragraph

text: The Synthesis
label: Title

text: Wagner's original intention was that a final integration of the solid and the ethereal,
label: Paragraph

text: the outer and inner construction, would be achieved with an iron and glass dome
label: Paragraph

text: on the top of the building above the courtyard. While this was rejected by the direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tor because of economic and practical reasons, Wagner insisted on the “absolutely
label: Paragraph

text: necessary crowning” element and formulated a new version as a pierced structure
label: Paragraph

text: at the attic. It is set back from the facade line in a way that can be seen only froma
label: Caption

text: certain distance.’* Wagner called this solution “Scheinarchitektur” (illusionary archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture) because it lost the immediate connection with the inner iron and glass
label: Paragraph

text: structure and, therefore, the chance to clearly stress the modem, integrative char-
label: Paragraph

text: acter of the building; that is, the structural and compositional unity of the exterior
label: Paragraph

text: and interior. However, it can be argued that the final version is in line with
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner's efforts to use “high expressions of artistic feeling and monumental exal-
label: Paragraph

text: 19 and with the deletion of
label: Title

text: almost any explicit historical or Secessionist elements during the planning process.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead of a group of figures a la baroque and Secession, there is only a pair of
label: Paragraph

text: tation ... only with absolute justification and sparingly
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine angels holding up symbolic wreaths, which are then repeated on the
label: Paragraph

text: piers and at the corners of the building. In its universality and conventionality,
label: Paragraph

text: the Semperian wreath as the “ultimate textile object” and “the archetypical work
label: Paragraph

text: of art
label: Title

text: 29 can be interpreted as a sign of the victory of art and the success of human
label: Paragraph

text: efforts, which instead of static monumentality and power refer back to the process
label: Paragraph

text: of the building’s production and express the ultimate principles of modern urban
label: Paragraph

text: culture: rationality, anonymity, and thrift.
