text: AEG TURBINE
label: Title

text: FACTORY
label: Title

text: Peter Behrens
label: Title

text: Gabriele H. Bryant
label: Title

text: Peter Behrens, AEG Turbine Factory, Berlin, 1909.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: It lies in the hands of industry to create culture by bringing together art and
label: Paragraph

text: technology.’
label: Paragraph

text: The AEG Turbine Factory in Berlin, designed by the architect Peter Behrens
label: Caption

text: (1868-1940) in collaboration with the building engineer Karl Bernhard
label: Paragraph

text: (1859-1937), represents a milestone in the development of modern industrial archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. Built in just a few months in 1909 in glass, iron,’ and concrete as an enor-
label: Paragraph

text: mous modern industrial production space — the largest iron construction in Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: at the time, with an enclosed volume of around 150,000 cubic meters uninterrupted
label: Paragraph

text: by internal supports — today, more than a hundred years later, it still fulfills its orig-
label: Paragraph

text: inal function, the assembly of large industrial turbines.’ The Turbine Factory has
label: Paragraph

text: long been hailed as representing the integration of industrial building types and
label: Paragraph

text: modern construction methods and materials into the tradition of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: and an artistic elevation of the modern workplace and the world of industry into
label: Paragraph

text: the realm of culture. The Turbine Factory constitutes an attempt at reconciling the
label: Paragraph

text: modern disciplines of architecture and engineering — or, as Behrens would put it,
label: Paragraph

text: creating a new unity between art and technology — and one of its historical achieve-
label: Paragraph

text: ments is that it marks a new beginning in artists’ and architects’ engagement with
label: Paragraph

text: the sites and products of modern industry in the early twentieth century.“
label: Paragraph

text: The iconic status of the AEG Turbine Factory in the history of modern architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture is based to a large extent on the combined effect ofa seemingly open display of
label: Paragraph

text: modern constructive principles in the 127 meter street front along Berlichingenstrafe,
label: Paragraph

text: and the image ofits unadorned yet monumental main facade toward Huttenstrage. It
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously provides the public face ofa giant modern factory and represents the
label: Paragraph

text: power of modern industry. Its earliest commentators recognized in this facade a
label: Paragraph

text: fusion of the motifs of an upright hammer standing on its handle’ anda stylized tem-
label: Paragraph

text: ple-front, soon earning the Turbine Factory the critical epithet of a “temple of
label: Paragraph

text: work.”® And indeed, the historical reinterpretation of architectural prototypes
label: Paragraph

text: and their symbolic transference to modern functional buildings, or, to put it differ-
label: Paragraph

text: ently, the integration of new building types and industrial products into the time-
label: Paragraph

text: honored tradition of art, is a recurring theme in the oeuvre of Peter Behrens. The
label: Paragraph

text: design of modern monuments that go beyond being purely functional buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: but which contribute to the symbolic expression as well as the very creation of cul-
label: Paragraph

text: tural values, remained a lasting concern for this seminal early twentieth-century
label: Paragraph

text: architect, who also became a kind of artistic father figure for some of the most impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant proponents of the modern movement in architecture. Behrens’ quest to give
label: Paragraph

text: artistic form to the driving forces of his own time without uncritically embracing
label: Paragraph

text: technological progress as an end in itself, and to engage with architectural tradition
label: Paragraph

text: without succumbing to formal historicism — that is, his ambition to achieve a balance
label: Paragraph

text: between the demands of modern “civilization” and the desire for its artistic elevation
label: Paragraph

text: to the level of “culture”” — informs the design of the AEG Turbine Factory and
label: Paragraph

text: accounts for its key role in the history of (not just industrial) modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The Architect Peter Behrens
label: Caption

text: The artistic development of the painter, architect, and designer Peter Behrens is
label: Paragraph

text: representative of many of the paramount concerns of artists and architects at
label: Paragraph

text: the beginning of the twentieth century. His career reflects the move of many artists
label: Paragraph

text: at the turn of the century away from a concern with “high art” to an engagement
label: Paragraph

text: with Lebensreform (life reform)* and the idea of a reconciliation of Life and Art via a
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis of the arts, an all-encompassing new design on the basis of architecture, to
label: Paragraph

text: eventually transfer these concerns into the realm of industry. Further, his artistic
label: Paragraph

text: activity was accompanied by theoretical reflection, in which the complex relation-
label: Paragraph

text: ship between art and technology, as well as the role of architecture as the founda-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of a modern Gesamtkunstwerk (total work of art) was debated. Behrens
label: Paragraph

text: embraced the Romantic-idealist quest for a total work of art as an agent of
label: Paragraph

text: socio-cultural change, an ideal force in the creation of a new culture.° A great
label: Paragraph

text: admirer of the philosophy of Friedrich Nietzsche since the early stages of his career,
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens adhered throughout his life to a strong faith in the artist’s role— and power
label: Paragraph

text: — to embody the spiritual forces of his time and to create new values, as “the ref-
label: Paragraph

text: ormation of the world, in order to be able to bear living in it, is the driving force.”'®
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Behrens started his career as a painter before turning to the “applied arts,”
label: Paragraph

text: became a major influence in the theatre as well as the garden reform movement,
label: Paragraph

text: and, though never formally trained, would eventually be one of the most promi-
label: Paragraph

text: nent architects of his time in Germany. The different phases of Peter Behrens’ work
label: Paragraph

text: have variously been characterized as belonging to Jugendstil (art nouveau), geomet-
label: Paragraph

text: ric abstraction, Sachlichkeit (objectivity), neoclassicism, and expressionism, but
label: Paragraph

text: while there has been an overemphasis on the changes in Behrens’ work on such
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic grounds, it is the conceptual continuities that run through the seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: disparate periods of Behrens’ oeuvre over four decades that need to be stressed.""
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’ artistic creed in the creation of a unity of art and life, the fusion of the
label: Paragraph

text: world of spirit and matter by means of artistic form creation, is apparent from
label: Paragraph

text: his early experiments in creating a spiritually uplifting environment as a member
label: Paragraph

text: of the Darmstadt artists’ colony of 1901, where he designed his first house, ” to his
label: Paragraph

text: engagement with geometric abstraction as head of the Diisseldorf Kunstgewer-
label: Paragraph

text: beschule (Academy of Arts and Crafts) from 1903 to 1907,'? and, most prominently,
label: Paragraph

text: his later work for industry, both before and after the First World War."*
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens received some of the most prestigious architectural commissions of his
label: Paragraph

text: time, from private villas and an embassy building to major factory complexes and
label: Paragraph

text: modern company headquarters, but he is still most widely known for his work as
label: Paragraph

text: artistic consultant for the Allgemeine Elektricitéts-Gesellschaft (AEG) in Berlin from
label: Paragraph

text: 1907 to 1914, described by art historian Tilmann Buddensieg as “probably the wid-
label: Paragraph

text: est-ranging commission of modern times.”’* Behrens’ artistic task was gradually
label: Paragraph

text: extended to designing everything from letterheads and advertising posters to
label: Paragraph

text: electrical appliances, factory buildings and workers’ housing. In “symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: objectivity,” '6 considered the new classicism of the twentieth century, Behrens rede-
label: Paragraph

text: signed the insignia of the corporation, suggestive of technological progress and
label: Paragraph

text: smooth efficiency. In his work for the AEG, Behrens created a total new corporate
label: Paragraph

text: image for this general electrical concern, which was one of the most powerful indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trial corporations in Germany at the beginning of the twentieth century. Andithas to
label: Paragraph

text: be emphasized that the role of artistic design in the creation of a corporate identity,
label: Paragraph

text: the function of a building like the Turbine Factory beyond its practical purpose to
label: Paragraph

text: serve as a piece of advertising architecture, with the much-reproduced image of the
label: Paragraph

text: Turbine Factory facade itself advancing to the level of a new logo for the AEG
label: Paragraph

text: company, was to be expressive not just of economic superiority, but of the role
label: Paragraph

text: of industry as a national force and driver of socio-political change. As Schwartz notes
label: Paragraph

text: in this context: “In the years before World War I, the trademark arose in Germany as
label: Paragraph

text: a symbol of redemption.”’” Soon Behrens’ work for the AEG was recognized as an
label: Paragraph

text: embodiment of the ideals of the German Werkbund, which was founded in the same
label: Paragraph

text: year, and whose agenda is summarized in the famous slogan to design everything
label: Paragraph

text: “from sofa cushions to town planning””* to such an extent that the architectural his-
label: Paragraph

text: torian Julius Posener even referred to Behrens as “Mister Werkbund.”'”
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture and Industry in the Early
label: Title

text: Twentieth Century
label: Title

text: The question of how to negotiate the demands of art and industry was at the fore-
label: Paragraph

text: front of architectural debates in the early twentieth century. While the English Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts Movement was regarded as largely negative in its attitude toward mod-
label: Paragraph

text: em machine-production and technology, in Germany, the critical discussions
label: Paragraph

text: before World War I turned toward the integration of modern technology into
label: Paragraph

text: the realm of artistic activity. Concerned not so much with the work’s actual mode
label: Paragraph

text: of production, but rather questions of “good form,” the German debates centered
label: Paragraph

text: on the problem of how to arrive at a new style that was expressive of its time,”°
label: Paragraph

text: while satisfying the demands of the artist and the industrialist — and their respective
label: Paragraph

text: clients. Behrens’ AEG Turbine Factory is regularly presented as the epitome of
label: Paragraph

text: such a successful union as well as an “icon of modernism.” However, the AEG
label: Paragraph

text: Turbine Factory can also serve as an illustration of some of the inherent ambigu-
label: Paragraph

text: ities that characterize Behrens’ approach.
label: Paragraph

text: The first building Behrens designed for the AEG was a small octagonal pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: for the first German Shipbuilding Exhibition in Berlin (1908). This was an austere,
label: Paragraph

text: two-story construction of 20 meters height and 18 meters diameter, in which mod-
label: Paragraph

text: erm machines were displayed like religious artifacts or beautiful sculptures, thus
label: Paragraph

text: forming part of an aesthetic advertising strategy that famously requested that
label: Paragraph

text: “an engine must look like a birthday present.”’ The temporary nature of the exhi-
label: Paragraph

text: bition pavilion makes considerations of structural durability of secondary impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tance here, and it can serve instead as a model in which an architectural idea is
label: Paragraph

text: given form, with the building itself becoming an exhibit, a piece of advertising art
label: Paragraph

text: that combines aesthetic and economic interests, as well as providing an artistic
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto that can throw some light on Behrens’ larger ambitions as an architect
label: Paragraph

text: for industry. Housing some of the most modern and technologically advanced pro-
label: Paragraph

text: ducts of its time, the design of Behrens’ AEG pavilion, the iconographic program of
label: Paragraph

text: the architecture, and its interior, hardly suggests a “prosaic” presentation of these
label: Paragraph

text: emblems of a new spirit of “objectivity.” If the transference of religious prototypes
label: Paragraph

text: for the exhibition of art had become culturally acceptable in the nineteenth cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury, Behrens now uses one of the great European prototypes of religious architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, aform reminiscent of, for example, the Baptistery in Florence, for the purpose
label: Paragraph

text: of displaying industrial goods. In the Berlin exhibition, the octagon — the eight refer-
label: Paragraph

text: ring symbolically to the beginning of a new cycle, resurrection, a new life, unity,
label: Paragraph

text: and eternity — was oriented westward toward the main exhibition halls, which at
label: Paragraph

text: night were illuminated by an arcade of thousands of electrical light bulbs. Behrens
label: Paragraph

text: defined the combination of art and industry as the source of a new culture.”” In the
label: Paragraph

text: “AEG baptistery,” water as the traditional symbol of a new life is replaced by the
label: Paragraph

text: new power of electricity, and a large, octagonal, electrical chandelier surmounts
label: Caption

text: the space in which the products are laid out, with the memorial address to the
label: Paragraph

text: firm’s 25th anniversary designed and exhibited like a medieval illuminated manu-
label: Paragraph

text: script. On the exterior, the pavilion bears the new logo that Behrens designed for
label: Paragraph

text: the company: the hexagonal pattern with the trinity of the letters A E G in a hon-
label: Paragraph

text: eycomb arrangement, which later also features prominently in the gable on the
label: Paragraph

text: facade of the Turbine Factory. A contemporary critic wrote: “One calls for the Art-
label: Paragraph

text: ist, so that out of the noise of work he can extract the great rhythms, so that he can
label: Paragraph

text: seize the hidden organ tones and amplify them toward hymns, toward the conse-
label: Paragraph

text: cration of the house,””’ and this hymn to the house, to the AEG, became the eulogy
label: Paragraph

text: of industrial culture in the monumental Turbine Factory.
label: Paragraph

text: The AEG Turbine Factory is situated at the south-east corner of the old AEG
label: Paragraph

text: factory site in the Moabit district of Berlin, at the corner of Huttenstrafe and
label: Paragraph

text: Berlichingenstrage. Its monumental ochre-yellow facade with green iron bands
label: Paragraph

text: accentuating the corners and a large central iron-glass window construction
label: Paragraph

text: underneath a massive gable or pediment — with the inscription “Turbinenhalle”
label: Caption

text: and the hexagonal AEG logo in the tympanon — still dominates the street-view.”*
label: Paragraph

text: The enormous dimensions required for this modern factory hall and the specific
label: Paragraph

text: technical requirements for a light and spacious, efficient, and highly durable mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern production space, which had to accommodate a complex arrangement of
label: Paragraph

text: large movable cranes with a lifting capacity of 100 tons, led to a collaboration
label: Paragraph

text: of Behrens with the experienced engineer Karl Bernhard.”” While Bernhard’s
label: Paragraph

text: expertise was to make up for Behrens’ lack of technical and engineering training
label: Paragraph

text: and experience, it was Behrens who clearly dominated in decisions concerning
label: Paragraph

text: the overall design and its symbolic program.*° The Turbine Factory consists
label: Paragraph

text: of the main hall with a projected length of 207 meters (127 meters were realized
label: Paragraph

text: in the first stage in 1909),”” approximately 25 meters high and 25.60 meters wide,
label: Paragraph

text: with a long pitched skylight for light and ventilation on the roof, and a smaller
label: Paragraph

text: flanking two-story side-hall with a basement to accommodate storage and sec-
label: Caption

text: ondary manufacturing operations, which is also slightly set back from
label: Paragraph

text: Huttenstrafe to give maximum impact to the main facade.
label: Caption

text: Karl Bernhard’s structural design for the main hall was based ona series of asym-
label: Paragraph

text: metrical three-hinged arches with tie-rods,’* and the way the structural elements
label: Paragraph

text: are given artistic form on the outside of the building reveals the creative differences
label: Paragraph

text: between the artist and the engineer: the constructive rationality of the side of the
label: Title

text: lower hall toward the factory yard — which has also been linked to Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe, who worked in Behrens’ office at this time?’ — stands in marked contrast
label: Paragraph

text: to the street-front toward Berlichingenstrafe with its symbolic emphasis of the hall’s
label: Paragraph

text: constructive principles. The tectonic display of structural elements is intensified
label: Paragraph

text: here by an aesthetic enhancement of the vertical metal members on the outside,
label: Paragraph

text: lending them a greater visual solidity and mass, to create a dynamic “image” of a
label: Paragraph

text: modern load-carrying structure. This effect is further enhanced by the 14.40 meter-
label: Paragraph

text: high tinted glass walls, which alternate with the green iron trusses and incline
label: Paragraph

text: toward the top so that the “roof” overhangs them by nearly two meters, resulting
label: Paragraph

text: in a strong relief-like effect with the beam at the cornice suggestive of a classical
label: Paragraph

text: entablature. The vertical iron members thus appear in a rhythmic sequence at
label: Paragraph

text: 9.22-meter intervals as abstract, inverted classical columns or pillars which narrow
label: Caption

text: toward the base and “resolve” in the striking detail of the lower hinges just above
label: Paragraph

text: the concrete pedestal. The total visual impact of these features creates for Behrens
label: Paragraph

text: the desired effect of a new, de-historicized classicism that is expressive of the
label: Paragraph

text: essence of the modern machine-age.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Poetry and Truth in Modern Architecture
label: Title

text: As a straightforward formal exposure of a modern factory construction in glass and
label: Paragraph

text: iron was out of the question for Behrens, because he aspired to an elevation of
label: Paragraph

text: these materials and new forms into the tradition of architecture, he repeatedly
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the aesthetic need to achieve a sense of corporeality for the building,
label: Paragraph

text: which is to act as a spatial enclosure, not its unveiling.”’ This ambition comes most
label: Paragraph

text: fully to the fore in the design of the main facade, with its 14.40 meter-high vertical
label: Paragraph

text: plane of the iron-glass window in the center and the giant polygonal gable, but
label: Paragraph

text: particularly its most strongly debated aspect: the visually massive rounded corners
label: Paragraph

text: or pylons, which are executed in a thin layer of concrete and accentuated with hor-
label: Paragraph

text: izontal iron bands. This corner treatment does not just lend a much-debated heavy
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality and association with Egyptian temples to the building’s public face,
label: Paragraph

text: it has also given rise to fierce controversy over the “aesthetic honesty” of a design
label: Paragraph

text: that has the appearance of a load-bearing masonry construction when in fact it is
label: Paragraph

text: mere concrete infill.** It was not just the engineer Bernhard who voiced his dis-
label: Paragraph

text: pleasure with this artistic solution;®* the tenor of the critique can be summed
label: Paragraph

text: up in Mies van der Rohe’s later notebook entry that “people who build factories
label: Paragraph

text: like temples lie.”** The question of what constitutes artistic honesty is, of course, as
label: Paragraph

text: central to the architectural debates of the time as it is complex. Behrens’ artistic
label: Paragraph

text: maxim from his early involvement with the artists’ colony in Darmstadt had been
label: Paragraph

text: that “we want to be elevated, not deceived,””’ that is, he proposed a view of art as
label: Paragraph

text: providing a beautiful illusion that contains its own (higher) truth. For Behrens, an
label: Paragraph

text: “aesthetic lie” might thus have consisted in not attempting to give the building a
label: Paragraph

text: representative form that takes it beyond the display of constructive rationality,
label: Paragraph

text: which would instead be seen as an all too literal and narrow, if not to say naive
label: Paragraph

text: or even primitive notion of truth.
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens explicitly rejected as a “pseudo-aesthetic” the idea of a beautiful form
label: Paragraph

text: that arises directly from the laws of mechanical construction, for “just as nature is
label: Paragraph

text: not culture, the mere fulfillment of purpose and material intentions cannot create it
label: Paragraph

text: either,” and he repeatedly emphasized that genuine artistic form can only be
label: Paragraph

text: derived from an orientation toward psychological or spiritual, not just material pur-
label: Paragraph

text: poses and functions.”° If even the Berlichingenstrafe front of the AEG Turbine Fac-
label: Paragraph

text: tory has to be understood as a direct display of both constructive principles and
label: Paragraph

text: their aesthetic elevation, then its temple-like main facade most clearly
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrates the primacy of artistic form over the logic of construction. Far from
label: Paragraph

text: exhibiting a modernist will to “functional directness” or espousing a narrow
label: Paragraph

text: echnical — and in any case highly mythical — functionalist ethos, it was precisely
label: Paragraph

text: he desire to negotiate the technical demands of a modern industrial production
label: Paragraph

text: space with the representative function of the factory building as a monument of
label: Paragraph

text: its time that proved to be Behrens’ guiding concern. While it is clearly true that
label: Paragraph

text: a formal allusion to classical temple fronts is intended, Behrens can hardly be
label: Paragraph

text: accused of mere historicist disguise in this facade. Comparing the reduced formal-
label: Paragraph

text: ism of Behrens’ Turbine Factory with most older factory buildings makes it clear
label: Paragraph

text: that he goes beyond both the historicist facade treatments of earlier architect-
label: Paragraph

text: designed examples, as well as the engineer-designed solutions to industrial produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion sites that aim to follow only the dictates of technical functionality.
label: Paragraph

text: The artist whose work became more closely identified with the creation ofa new
label: Paragraph

text: Industriekultur (industrial culture) than any other in his time, whose work was iden-
label: Paragraph

text: tified with the AEG to such an extent that Behrens’ style and the AEG’s style
label: Paragraph

text: became synonymous, fervently rejected any mere Verkunstung (artistic surface dec-
label: Paragraph

text: oration) of the products of industry. At the same time, he never dispensed with the
label: Paragraph

text: idealist agenda of an architecture as Denkmal (monument). Behrens is an architect
label: Paragraph

text: who frequently appears to subordinate function, material, and technique in his
label: Paragraph

text: buildings for the sake of the expression of what he sees as a higher historical truth.
label: Paragraph

text: In the famous Turbine Factory facade, ideas concerning form and symbolism over-
label: Paragraph

text: whelmingly dictate the physical solution. Behrens’ inversion of classical form for
label: Paragraph

text: this show-front of the AEG factory complex marks a new — though perhaps not
label: Paragraph

text: altogether whole-hearted — endorsement of the power of modern industrial civili-
label: Paragraph

text: zation. “The evolution of monumental art has always been an expression of the
label: Paragraph

text: t
label: Title

text: t
label: Title

text: concentration of power: if one can speak of the art of the Church in the Middle
label: Paragraph

text: Ages; in the Baroque era of the art of the kings; of bourgeois art in the styles around
label: Paragraph

text: 1800; then I believe that today our flourishing industry again forms a concentration
label: Paragraph

text: of power which cannot remain without influence on the development of culture,”
label: Paragraph

text: states the most sought-after German architect of his time.”” It is Behrens’ determi-
label: Paragraph

text: nation to go beyond utility in his will to monumentalize his culture’s driving forces
label: Paragraph

text: that subsequent generations have come to regard as both the strength and weak-
label: Paragraph

text: ness of this building and its design ethos. Behrens’ solution can be seen as an
label: Paragraph

text: attempt at mediation — to lend dignity and meaning to the products of our material
label: Paragraph

text: culture in an age of rapidly changing technological and socio-political conditions,
label: Paragraph

text: without succumbing either to cultural pessimism or the uncritical embrace of tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nological progress — and the facade of the AEG Turbine Factory remains a mon-
label: Paragraph

text: ument to such an attempt at “historical synthesis,” an enlightened vision that
label: Paragraph

text: occupies a splendid and sometimes slippery middle ground between formal and
label: Paragraph

text: ideological extremes.
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens has been lauded as one of the earliest exponents of industrial design and
label: Paragraph

text: one of the first artists to engage in creating what is now called “corporate identity”
label: Paragraph

text: by means of a unified design program. However, Behrens also holds the curious
label: Paragraph

text: position of being “the first artist to devote special care to the beauty of form of
label: Paragraph

text: peculiarly modern industrial products in terms of some larger cultural conception
label: Paragraph

text: external to the immediate processes of production and use.”** Even during his AEG
label: Paragraph

text: period, it has been argued, Behrens’ call for a unity of art and technology never
label: Paragraph

text: meant identification or equality, but always a spiritual elevation of technology
label: Paragraph

text: (the factory) to the level of art (the temple).”” Behrens takes the idea of the Gesamt-
label: Paragraph

text: kunstwerk from the nineteenth-century theater to the turn-of-the-century villa and
label: Paragraph

text: then to the modern factory as cult building. The program for a spiritual elevation of
label: Paragraph

text: man through the contemplation of ideal form is transferred from the idealist “thea-
label: Paragraph

text: tre as moral institution” (Friedrich Schiller), which had already informed the aes-
label: Paragraph

text: thetic program of Behrens’ much-admired artistic forbear, the great nineteenth-
label: Paragraph

text: century Prussian architect Karl Friedrich Schinkel (1781-1841) and his artistic pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gram for a transformation of the modern city into a Kulturlandschaft, to the show
label: Paragraph

text: front of the new power of industry. The facade of the Turbine Factory, proudly
label: Caption

text: orientated toward the south-east, the center of Berlin, elevates the industrial eve-
label: Paragraph

text: ryday into a meaningful manifestation of the “spirit of the age,” an expression of the
label: Paragraph

text: Kunstwollen®® of the modern era, while expanding the notion of culture into the
label: Paragraph

text: realm of modern production.
label: Paragraph

text: But there is an even greater subtlety in the design of Behrens’ monumental
label: Paragraph

text: Turbine Factory facade than it has yet been given credit for, and what is usually
label: Paragraph

text: read as a straightforward elevation of the factory to the level of the temple is
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps still more ambiguous than it seems. Friedrich Nietzsche had described
label: Paragraph

text: his own philosophy as “inverted Platonism, the appearance, the illusion, is the
label: Paragraph

text: aim,”“* and we might also recognize this sentiment in the AEG Turbine Factory
label: Paragraph

text: facade. The ambivalence here lies in Behrens putting forward a design that does
label: Paragraph

text: not so much imitate a temple front but instead inverts its very principles: the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: truding gable is supported by the central window opening, while the seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: load-bearing elements, the gently inclined concrete pylons at the corner, serve a
label: Paragraph

text: purely aesthetic purpose.” The Nietzsche-inspired architect Behrens, it seems,
label: Paragraph

text: had absorbed and applied the lessons of the master’s observations concerning
label: Paragraph

text: “Truth and lie in the extra-moral sense: [that all] truths are illusions that have
label: Paragraph

text: been forgotten as suc ”° A Nietzschean contention that all truth is created, that
label: Paragraph

text: there is no one truth but only a multitude of different perspectives, can also be
label: Paragraph

text: observed in the artistic treatment of the different sides of the Turbine Factory,
label: Paragraph

text: culminating in its famous main facade, which presents an architecture of the
label: Paragraph

text: “asif.”** Instead of either celebrating the Turbine Factory as a “temple of
label: Paragraph

text: work,” or condemning the design by perpetuating a moralistic reading of it as
label: Paragraph

text: a structurally dishonest and/or ideologically questionable attermpt to make a fac-
label: Paragraph

text: tory look like a sacred building, perhaps we should interpret Behrens’ AEG Tur-
label: Paragraph

text: bine Factory design as an expression of a new and altogether different historical
label: Paragraph

text: truth: that “the truth” is not what it seems; that a “revaluation of all values,” a
label: Paragraph

text: Copernican turn has taken place; and that the modern world and industrial reality
label: Paragraph

text: are turning classical culture on its head.
label: Paragraph

text: The influence of Behrens and his oeuvre on the younger generation of architects
label: Paragraph

text: we associate with the modern movement is unquestionable. Even where they con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceived of their creations as antidotes to the precedents set by Behrens - whom they
label: Paragraph

text: credited with having brought the industrial building into the realm of art, but cri-
label: Paragraph

text: ticized for not having gone far enough in exploring the creative potential of the new
label: Paragraph

text: materials and constructive principles — a building like the AEG Turbine Factory set
label: Paragraph

text: the standard and became the critical reference-point for subsequent architect-
label: Paragraph

text: designed industrial buildings. This is clearly the case with the famous Fagus
label: Paragraph

text: shoe-last factory of 1911 by Walter Gropius and Adolf Meyer in Alfeld, another
label: Paragraph

text: seminal modern industrial building of the pre-war period in Germany. It has been
label: Paragraph

text: convincingly argued by Posener that the main building of the Fagus factory can be
label: Paragraph

text: read as an architectural counter-demonstration or revision of Behrens’ AEG Tur-
label: Paragraph

text: bine Factory, with Gropius and Meyer, who had both worked in the office of Beh-
label: Paragraph

text: rens at the time of the Turbine Factory design, taking an “antithetically dependent”
label: Paragraph

text: stand here against Behrens.” Gropius and Meyer, suggests Posener, “corrected”
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’ design by inversion: where Behrens had created solid and accentuated
label: Paragraph

text: corner sections, to give but one example, Gropius and Meyer designed fully glazed
label: Paragraph

text: corners without visible supports, although they were, it has to be emphasized, no
label: Paragraph

text: more “structurally true” than Behrens’ solution.** However, where Behrens was
label: Paragraph

text: seen by critics as putting too much emphasis on weight, mass, pathos, and mon-
label: Paragraph

text: umentality, the main Fagus building was characterized by a visual lightness that
label: Paragraph

text: avoided overtly symbolic gestures, making it one of the key buildings of the Inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national Style.
label: Paragraph

text: Anderson’s critical assessment that with the “interestingly problematic” Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens, “architecture answered to “The Time’, not the people,”*” remains a
label: Paragraph

text: challenging contention. But it is also the deep seriousness of his very attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: negotiate between the demands of “the time” and “the people” that made
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’ work both an inspiration and challenge for successive generations of
label: Paragraph

text: architects. Where Mies van der Rohe later credited Behrens with having taught
label: Paragraph

text: him “the great form,” he also carried on his quest for a gestaltend engagement
label: Paragraph

text: with the essence of his time.** The continuity of the idealist tradition in the mod-
label: Paragraph

text: erm notion of Formgestaltung for the protagonists of the Neues Bauen is further
label: Paragraph

text: attested in, for example, Walter Curt Behrendt’s The Victory of the New Building
label: Paragraph

text: Style (1927). In the early twentieth century, Formgestaltung assumes the status of
label: Paragraph

text: a quasi-metaphysical activity, and whether they embrace or reject the idealist
label: Paragraph

text: notions of “art” and “style,” the quest for the right Form and Gestaltung becomes
label: Paragraph

text: the driving force even for those modernists who criticized the particular formal
label: Paragraph

text: solutions in Behrens’ work. And while we have rightly become wary of the Hege-
label: Paragraph

text: lian teleological conception of history and its notion of Zeitgeist, suspicious of
label: Paragraph

text: promises — or even offers — of cultural redemption through art and/or technol-
label: Paragraph

text: ogy, the legacy of the artistic struggles and achievements of early twentieth-
label: Paragraph

text: century architecture, of which the AEG Turbine Factory by Peter Behrens is a
label: Paragraph

text: prime example, continues to inform the debate and serve as a point of departure
label: Paragraph

text: in the search for an “architecture of our time.”*°

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: COLOGNE

text: Bruno Taut
label: Title

text: Markus Breitschmid
label: Title

text: Bruno Taut, Glass House at Cologne, 1914.
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.

label: Caption

text: Das Glashaus hat keinen anderen Zweck, als schén zu sein.’
label: Paragraph

text: Part of the prestige of the Glass House rests upon the renown of the man who
label: Paragraph

text: designed it, Bruno Taut (1880-1938), an architect with a particularly ambitious
label: Paragraph

text: vision for the future of architecture. Yet Taut’s reputation derives in no small
label: Paragraph

text: degree from the Glass House itself — an early work of his career — and the high
label: Paragraph

text: place it continues to hold in the history of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The most obvious and exceptional fact about the Glass House is implied in its
label: Paragraph

text: seemingly lapidary name. The Glass House is the first among the many buildings
label: Paragraph

text: known simply by the material with which it was built, an attribute also given, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, to houses by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Philip Johnson. This is even
label: Paragraph

text: more noteworthy as considerable parts of what made Taut’s Glass House buildable
label: Paragraph

text: were not actually made of glass, a fact keenly emphasized by the architect himself,
label: Paragraph

text: who called it “my ‘Glass House,’ the lightest possible concrete structure.”” While
label: Paragraph

text: the building’s reinforced concrete construction, particularly its highly complex
label: Paragraph

text: polyhedral lamellar dome structure, was a technical masterpiece in and of itself,
label: Paragraph

text: and in respect to its engineering ingenuity more than equal to the application of
label: Paragraph

text: the various kinds of glass,’ it is nonetheless the use of glass that led to this building
label: Paragraph

text: becoming one of the most iconic structures of twentieth-century modernism. Self-
label: Paragraph

text: aware of its importance, one of the mottoes Taut incised into the concrete of the
label: Paragraph

text: Glass House was “Das Glas bringt uns die neue Zeit - Backsteinkultur tut uns nur
label: Paragraph

text: leid.” He had invited the poet Paul Scheerbart to provide aphorisms to be incor-
label: Paragraph

text: porated into the building and Scheerbart supplied Taut with 16, of which six were
label: Paragraph

text: eventually used.*
label: Paragraph

text: A Strange Building at the Werkbund Exhibition
label: Title

text: The Glass House was part of the first Deutsche Werkbund-Ausstellung held in
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne in 1914. The Deutscher Werkbund, a German association of artists, archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects, designers, and industrialists, organized the exhibition in Cologne with the
label: Paragraph

text: initial purpose of establishing a partnership between product manufacturers and
label: Paragraph

text: design professionals that would improve the competitiveness of German compa-
label: Paragraph

text: nies on the global market. As Frederic Schwartz explains in his work on the Werk-
label: Paragraph

text: bund, the organization was formed around 1907 to facilitate cooperation between
label: Paragraph

text: producers, tradesmen, and art professionals. Schwarz writes: “It drew support from
label: Paragraph

text: groups within and outside of government who saw the artistic reform of German
label: Paragraph

text: production and trade as a source of national prestige and economic prosperity; and
label: Paragraph

text: it spoke also to the many groups, so characteristic of Wilhelmine Germany, who
label: Paragraph

text: furthered cultural reform of all kinds.”* Thus, the Werkbund was as much an art
label: Paragraph

text: and manufacturing collaborative as a state-sponsored program intended to inte-
label: Paragraph

text: grate traditional crafts and industrial mass-production techniques, in order to
label: Paragraph

text: put Germany on a competitive footing with Great Britain and the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition was held at the Rheinpark, a large open green area opposite
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne’s city center. The Hohenzollernbriicke, crossing the Rhine, essentially
label: Paragraph

text: connected the famed Gothic Cathedral located in the old town with the entrance
label: Paragraph

text: to the exhibition situated on the other side of the river. The exhibition had come to
label: Paragraph

text: the city mainly due to the initiative of Konrad Adenauer, later the German Chan-
label: Paragraph

text: cellor, but by 1914 a 36-year-old aspiring inventor, Werkbund member, and local
label: Paragraph

text: politician. The luxurious sum of five million Goldmarks was spent on the event.°
label: Paragraph

text: Planning began in earnest in 1912, but construction work started only in early 1914.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition was opened to the public on May 15, 1914, with the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: the Glass House still incomplete. Scheduled to last until the end of October, the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition was prematurely shut down on August 5, in reaction to the outbreak
label: Paragraph

text: of World War I a day earlier.’
label: Paragraph

text: The encounter with the Glass House must have been strange for visitors to the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition grounds. It was as if the earth had miraculously opened, releasing a
label: Paragraph

text: building’s base made of concrete that arched upward with a soft curvature in a
label: Paragraph

text: shape not unlike the utopian and enormous mega-structure rising out of the Alps
label: Paragraph

text: that Taut later drew in Alpine Architecture.” Obviously the Cologne site was not
label: Paragraph

text: Alpine, yet a row of large mirrored glass spheres suggested that these spheres,
label: Paragraph

text: too, were brought up from the underworld to the light; that an eruption had come
label: Paragraph

text: to an inadvertent stop where the globes found their ultimate position — all of this
label: Paragraph

text: the result of mighty geological forces at play.
label: Paragraph

text: Rising immediately from the bulge-like concrete ring was a tambour frame, sup-
label: Paragraph

text: ported by slim concrete pillars, with partial glass insets in the configuration of a 14-
label: Paragraph

text: sided prism. A gently curved and slightly pinnacled rhomboid cupola was built on
label: Paragraph

text: top of the tambour. The glass facets of the cupola, with their mirroring surface,
label: Paragraph

text: took on a greenish-yellowish coloration in bad weather. Somewhat unhappily, this
label: Paragraph

text: appearance gave rise to one of the building’s nicknames, Spargelkopf, meaning
label: Paragraph

text: asparagus tip. In clear weather, though, the glass facets mirrored the crystalline
label: Paragraph

text: transparency of ether, as well as the lively movements of clouds, the play of the
label: Paragraph

text: wind with the leaves of the adjacent trees, and, sometimes, the fleeting reflection
label: Paragraph

text: ofan airplane. At night-time, the body of the building — illuminated with thousands
label: Paragraph

text: of watts from the interior — was transformed into a sparkling and radiating jewel —a
label: Paragraph

text: designation one assumes Taut would have preferred.”
label: Paragraph

text: The circumstances of how the Glass House became a part of the Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition are unclear. It was not part of the original building program for the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition. As a consequence, Taut did not receive an actual building commission
label: Paragraph

text: from the exhibition’s board of directors but was assigned a specific location on the
label: Paragraph

text: terrain of the exhibition area, not unlike other manufacturer-sponsored pavilions.
label: Paragraph

text: This meant also that the office of the exhibition organizers did not carry the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing cost. Rather, what became the Glass House was given a small financial allow-
label: Paragraph

text: ance that covered only a fraction of the expenses. Despite the meager support,
label: Paragraph

text: Taut valued these concessions because they afforded him a venue for his Glass
label: Paragraph

text: House, a building he had drawn up previously, long before he hoped for
label: Paragraph

text: participation in the exhibition. While Taut did not yet have the renommée to be
label: Paragraph

text: awarded an outright commission for one of the major exhibition buildings, he did
label: Paragraph

text: receive support from Karl Ernst Osthaus, a vehement but isolated advocate of the
label: Paragraph

text: most recent artistic avant-garde movements among the board of directors of the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition. Taut also received backing from his former professor, Theodor
label: Paragraph

text: Fischer, the architect of the main hall of the exhibition. Taut’s reputation among
label: Paragraph

text: leading architects had grown on the basis of two noted exhibition pavilions he had
label: Paragraph

text: built: the Trager-Verkaufskontor in Berlin (1910) and his Monument des Eisens in
label: Caption

text: Leipzig (1913)."°
label: Paragraph

text: The Glass House was not, however, a typical fit in the ensemble of
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturer-sponsored pavilions. There was no single company or industrial
label: Paragraph

text: association — for example, the association for glass manufacturers — that
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned the building as its exhibition pavilion. Rather, Taut himself acted
label: Paragraph

text: as owner, with all the associated risks and obligations that came with ownership.
label: Paragraph

text: The requisition for in-kind donations for materials and other services, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: partial financial support for the Glass House, was Taut’s responsibility. Because
label: Paragraph

text: he was only modestly successful on these fronts, Taut faced the painful conse-
label: Paragraph

text: quences of being the work’s main sponsor: 20,000 Goldmarks out of his own
label: Paragraph

text: pocket. Therefore, the Glass House was partly a Werkbund building, partly an
label: Paragraph

text: advertisement pavilion for the glass manufacturing industry, and, largely, Taut’s
label: Paragraph

text: very own house in glass.'' Ownership — and all that it cost — was the price to
label: Paragraph

text: be paid for the absolute artistic liberty that Taut enjoyed. However, paying for
label: Paragraph

text: his own building would not be the last insult that Taut had to endure for his archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural vision. In July of 1916, in the middle of World War I, he received a letter
label: Paragraph

text: from the Cologne City Administration demanding that he, the building’s owner,
label: Paragraph

text: take responsibility for the demolition of the remaining concrete skeleton, now a
label: Paragraph

text: relic of the former jewel of the exhibition, at an estimated cost of a further
label: Paragraph

text: 5,000 Reichsmark. Osthaus’ unconventional proposal to use the Glass House as
label: Caption

text: a training object for test blasting techniques by the engineering battalion that
label: Paragraph

text: now occupied the former exhibition area was denied by the commanding officer
label: Paragraph

text: and Taut was stuck with the financial obligations for the demolition of his own
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece.’
label: Paragraph

text: While the architectural merit of Taut’s building was recognized even before the
label: Paragraph

text: construction was finished, the ownership status and the subsequent financial diffi-
label: Paragraph

text: culties caused the Glass House to be incorporated into the planning of the exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion at a very late date. Approval for the project was secured only four months
label: Paragraph

text: before the planned opening of the exhibition. Construction began around mid-Feb-
label: Paragraph

text: ruary. According to Taut’s own report, the complex concrete structure was erected
label: Paragraph

text: in a mere five weeks in March. Despite the swift speed of construction, the Glass
label: Paragraph

text: House was not on course to be completed for the official exhibition opening.’ Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Westheim reported in a preview published in the Kélner Tagblatt four weeks before
label: Paragraph

text: the opening date of the exhibition that one of the “artistically very interesting”
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, referring to Taut’s Glass House, was unfortunately not completed
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the “early stages.”'* It was only during the first week of July, for the event
label: Paragraph

text: of the 7 Annual Convention of the Werkbund held in Cologne, that the Glass
label: Paragraph

text: House was fully realized.’” As the war began on August 4 and the exhibition closed
label: Paragraph

text: prematurely the next day, we can surmise that the Glass House was on display for
label: Paragraph

text: no more than one month.
label: Paragraph

text: Given the project’s late entry into the exhibition planning process, it is no sur-
label: Paragraph

text: prise that the site on which the building came to stand was also peculiar. The core
label: Paragraph

text: area of the exhibition, which included the Haupthalle by Theodor Fischer, the Fest-
label: Paragraph

text: halle by Peter Behrens, the so-called Osterreichisches Haus by Josef Hoffmann, the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund theater by Henry van de Velde, the model factory and office building by
label: Caption

text: Walter Gropius and Adolf Meyer, and an exhibition building devoted to paint by
label: Paragraph

text: Hermann Muthesius, was about 600 meters or more than a third of a mile away
label: Paragraph

text: from the site of the Glass House.
label: Caption

text: While it stood far away from the main buildings, Taut’s pavilion did, however,
label: Paragraph

text: receive a constant flow of pedestrians and visitors because it was situated imme-
label: Paragraph

text: diately behind the entrance gate and main ticket stand. The visitors arrived either
label: Paragraph

text: by the public light rail lines, for which a station was built at the entrance gate of the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition, or by other vehicular means. Once there, they would pass the entrance
label: Paragraph

text: gate and see the Glass House as the exhibition’s very first building. It stood at the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of a slightly bent, elongated approach of about 300 meters, which led
label: Paragraph

text: toward the portal building that served as the ceremonial entrance to the core of
label: Paragraph

text: the exhibition. The result of the building’s position was that visitors were able
label: Paragraph

text: to see, and most likely visit, what became one of the main attractions of the
label: Paragraph

text: entire exhibition, the Glass House, long before they approached the central build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings. While the Glass House was one of the earliest impressions of any visitor to
label: Paragraph

text: the exhibition, it also stood at the margins of the exhibition, which was
label: Paragraph

text: further emphasized by the fact that the ground on which the visitors would have
label: Paragraph

text: walked toward and around the Glass House was muddy on rainy days and dusty on
label: Paragraph

text: sunny days."
label: Paragraph

text: Another ultimately telling peculiarity of the site was the fact that the Glass
label: Paragraph

text: House stood close to the new amusement park. The Werkbund was forced to
label: Paragraph

text: accept the presence of an amusement park on the grounds of its exhibition because
label: Paragraph

text: of the financial benefits it would bring to the entire endeavor.’” Its proximity to the
label: Paragraph

text: Glass House is noteworthy, for Taut’s pavilion was the only one in the exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: that seemed to embrace themes of movement and dynamism, topics that were viv-
label: Paragraph

text: idly on display in the amusement park. These themes had, of course, already pene-
label: Paragraph

text: trated the discourse of modern architecture, particularly the artistic and
label: Paragraph

text: architectural circles of the Italian Futurists, for whom movement, and its engine,
label: Paragraph

text: modern technology, were keys to the modern world. It was not only Filippo Tom-
label: Paragraph

text: maso Marinetti, however, who pointed to the increasing mechanization of modern
label: Paragraph

text: life. In fact, the electrification and automation of daily life was well underway by
label: Paragraph

text: this time. Venues such as the world’s fairs in Paris (1900) and St. Louis (1904) had
label: Paragraph

text: made ample use of these new possibilities. Yet, little of this existed on the Cologne
label: Paragraph

text: site. One sharp-tongued critic described the Werkbund exhibition as “nearly offi-
label: Paragraph

text: ciated boredom” and “well-mannered yawning caused by these ephemeral crea-
label: Paragraph

text: tions.”'* Such criticism would have been understood as an evaluation of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural quality of most of the buildings. Yet, it could have been equally appli-
label: Paragraph

text: cable to the exhibition’s apparent indifference to technological innovation, as there
label: Paragraph

text: was no manifestation of the sought-after Qualitétsarbeit, no elevators, escalators,
label: Paragraph

text: electric conveyer belts, or other mechanized innovations to be seen there. One
label: Paragraph

text: would not have guessed that the organizers were members of an association of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial manufacturers. Even the machines in Gropius’ model factory were never
label: Paragraph

text: in motion because the architect objected to the noise such practical demonstrations
label: Paragraph

text: would cause. While the amusement park did not contain anything that could not
label: Paragraph

text: be enjoyed at the Berlin Lunapark or at Coney Island in New York, there was an
label: Paragraph

text: electrical escalator, from which visitors could appreciate the new potentials for
label: Paragraph

text: movement and dynamism.’” The Glass House embraced these technological pos-
label: Paragraph

text: sibilities, but in its own way. The peculiar location on the exhibition grounds was,
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps, not that unsuitable after all.
label: Paragraph

text: An “Overwhelmingly Beautiful” House
label: Title

text: Despite the fact that the Glass House was accessible to the public for a mere month,
label: Paragraph

text: the building is well documented and allows for detailed descriptions.” Given its
label: Paragraph

text: pivotal position in architecture history, many historians have weighed in. Ian Boyd
label: Paragraph

text: Whyte described the interior of the pavilion as follows:
label: Caption

text: The lower floor housed a water cascade while the upper level depended for its effect
label: Paragraph

text: on the “Luxfer” prisms and coloured glass which made up the inner layer of the glaz-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. The natural effects of light on glass were heightened by the inclusion of a
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical kaleidoscope, built in to the back of the pavilion.7!
label: Caption

text: Dennis Sharp describes it thus:
label: Paragraph

text: The total effect was by all accounts startling both from the outside, which shone at
label: Paragraph

text: night like a jewel, and from the inside where the effect was heightened by the play
label: Paragraph

text: of coloured light from the mechanical kaleidoscope. In a sense Taut’s Glass House
label: Paragraph

text: was an early prototype of the multi-media — or psychedelic — pavilions that are now
label: Paragraph

text: commonly found at international exhibitions. ... The main space of the exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion rose through two floors and the lower part, in which the water basin was
label: Paragraph

text: situated, contained a number of glass mosaics and cartoons let into the glass wall
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces.””
label: Paragraph

text: In comparison to these elaborate accounts, the architect's own assessment is use-
label: Paragraph

text: ful, and even surprising. In his influential Modern Architecture of 1929, Taut aimed
label: Paragraph

text: not so much for a detailed description but to present it as a key building in the
label: Paragraph

text: development and possibilities of modern architecture:
label: Title

text: Two other protagonists of the next generation gave proof of the new art of architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture at this [the Cologne] exhibition. One was the “Industry” building by Walter Gro-
label: Paragraph

text: pius and Adolf Meyer ... The other was perhaps my “Glass House,” the lightest
label: Paragraph

text: possible concrete structure, destined to demonstrate the use of glass in all its varied
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic charm, the variegated shining glass prisms ofits glass envelopments, its glass
label: Paragraph

text: ceilings, glass floors, glass tiles, and the cascade, lit up from beneath, and a giant kalei-
label: Paragraph

text: doscope, which was intended to illustrate by its illumination at night all that glass
label: Paragraph

text: might achieve towards the heightening of intensity in our lives. The dome was of
label: Paragraph

text: network construction without draw-beams — a forerunner of the post-war wood,
label: Paragraph

text: and the recent steel and concrete — further improved upon “Lamellen” construction.”
label: Paragraph

text: The dramaturgy of the spatial sequences is equally revealing. As Angelika
label: Paragraph

text: Thiekétter suggests: “Alles flieBt, alles bewegt sich” “(Everything flows, everything
label: Paragraph

text: is in motion),” and there was more than one way that fluid movements brought the
label: Paragraph

text: building to life and, ultimately, characterized it.7* Taut’s architectural choreogra-
label: Paragraph

text: phy did not allow for a visitor to freely ramble through the building’s several set-
label: Paragraph

text: tings; instead, movement was precisely directed with regard to what visitors were
label: Paragraph

text: able to see, hear, and touch at any given moment. The influence of late-baroque
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, particularly of Balthasar Neumann's magnificent stairs in the corps de
label: Paragraph

text: logis at the castle in Bruchsal, has been noted as a possible point of reference.”* Buta
label: Paragraph

text: walk through the Glass House could also be compared to a ride on one of the then-
label: Paragraph

text: popular ghost trains, with the important difference that the sequence of rooms was
label: Paragraph

text: to evoke more elevated thoughts and feelings.
label: Paragraph

text: The three-sided concrete entrance staircase welcomed its visitors with seven
label: Paragraph

text: steps before the stair narrowed to one flight of 12 more steps, buttressed by
label: Caption

text: two sturdy concrete half walls on each side that led visitors to the entrance plat-
label: Paragraph

text: form, where tickets were sold. On that platform, the entry forked. To the right
label: Paragraph

text: and left were narrow curved flights of stairs that led up one more level to the
label: Paragraph

text: cupola room. These stairs were pressed between the slim concrete pillars of the
label: Paragraph

text: outer 14-sided prism and a second concentric inner cylinder. The staircase, follow-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the curvature of the tambour, remained open toward the outside, as the infill
label: Paragraph

text: between the pillars was left open above the steps, exposed to the hustling and bus-
label: Paragraph

text: tling panorama outside.
label: Paragraph

text: Gradually the view closed and the visitor entered into a glassy and otherworldly
label: Paragraph

text: cupola room — rather like plunging into a body of water. Contemporary reports
label: Paragraph

text: described the view that emerged as “overwhelmingly beautiful.”** The domed
label: Paragraph

text: and double-layered glazed cupola did not allow for a view to the outside but trans-
label: Paragraph

text: formed the entering daylight into a soft and hazy transparency, devoid of shadows.
label: Paragraph

text: Seven large spherical lamps made of milky glass were suspended in a concentric
label: Paragraph

text: configuration. In the center, suspended lower than the other seven lamps, hung
label: Paragraph

text: another large and vertically elongated light fixture that conveyed colored light and
label: Paragraph

text: filled the cupola room with a warm and fairytale-like Stimmung, a spatial mood as
label: Paragraph

text: far removed from the everyday world as possible.
label: Paragraph

text: Taut’s dramaturgic principle moved from the exterior to the interior, from the
label: Paragraph

text: noisy and busy locomotion of everyday life to a dreamlike seclusion of the interior
label: Paragraph

text: spaces. This turn toward a physical and mental interiority was heightened by the
label: Paragraph

text: room’s inaccessible and empty center, a round opening in the floor beneath the
label: Paragraph

text: cupola. Through that opening the reflecting water surface of the fountain on
label: Paragraph

text: the lower floor became visible, including the glittering play of what seemed to
label: Paragraph

text: be colorful glass beads lying on the ground of the fountain, all illuminated by
label: Paragraph

text: the suspended central light fixture. Thus, the cupola room assumed a temple-like
label: Paragraph

text: character.
label: Paragraph

text: Next, two narrow, curved, and light-penetrated staircases, fully encased with
label: Paragraph

text: glass stone blocks — having been imbued with a strange sense of weightlessness —
label: Paragraph

text: led the visitors downstairs to the cascade room. Here, once again, the atmospheric
label: Paragraph

text: disposition changed dramatically. The soft, ether-like light of the cupola room gave
label: Paragraph

text: way to the colorful shine of glass and ceramic ornaments on ceilings, walls, and
label: Paragraph

text: floors. Further, the concentric disposition of the cupola room upstairs was transfig-
label: Paragraph

text: ured into an axial spatial organization. Moreover, a sense of solemnity was meta-
label: Paragraph

text: morphosed into experiences of sound and movement. The round opening of the
label: Paragraph

text: floor of the cupola room appeared above, as an eye in the shallow dome — Pan-
label: Paragraph

text: theon-like — pointing upward to the pinnacle of the rhomboid cupola. The basin that
label: Paragraph

text: had appeared as an enclosed circle now turned out to be the spring of a new kind of
label: Paragraph

text: movement: waters streamed downward on the shimmering seven-step cascade into
label: Paragraph

text: a lower basin, flanked by shallow staircases on each side that allowed visitors to fol-
label: Paragraph

text: low the flow of the water. The cascade’s glowing waters gave the room a rich spec-
label: Paragraph

text: trum of light, sound, and motion, which infused the visitor’s senses.
label: Paragraph

text: One more spectacle was to come: extending the length of the cascade’s axis was a
label: Paragraph

text: dark recessed alcove into which the variegated patterns of a mechanical kaleido-
label: Paragraph

text: scope were projected. The endless, rhythmic change of abstract images was the
label: Paragraph

text: final bewitching act before visitors exited the building through one of the two side
label: Paragraph

text: doors and faced the everyday world again.””
label: Paragraph

text: Matter-of-Fact Objectivity and Quixotic Utopianism
label: Title

text: Despite the brevity of its public existence, the Glass House made an indelible
label: Paragraph

text: impression on the world of architecture. Today it still serves as a masterly attempt
label: Paragraph

text: at the total dissolution of the existing foundations of architecture with respect to
label: Paragraph

text: the ways it occupies its location, acknowledges its programmatic functions, articu-
label: Paragraph

text: lates its expressions, and deploys its materials and construction techniques. The
label: Paragraph

text: Glass House also largely defined the perception of its architect as perhaps the most
label: Paragraph

text: important exponent of architectural expressionism. However, Bruno Taut’s
label: Paragraph

text: influence reaches well beyond his pivotal role for expressionism. He sought noth-
label: Paragraph

text: ing less than the “cosmic character of architecture.””*
label: Paragraph

text: The Glass House embodied a distinct duality that is the hallmark of Taut’s entire
label: Paragraph

text: body of work. Its aesthetic characteristics consisted of both a matter-of-fact objec-
label: Paragraph

text: tivity (the embrace of the newest and most advanced technical possibilities) and a
label: Paragraph

text: quixotic utopianism (the projection of an otherworldly and fantastic spatial temper-
label: Paragraph

text: ament). It embraced all that modernity promised to offer — a potential for objec-
label: Paragraph

text: tivity, efficient organization, rationalized ordering systems, clarity, and honesty —
label: Paragraph

text: but also embodied the side of the modern world that presented the coalescing
label: Paragraph

text: power necessary for the realization of the sought-after new world — the mystery
label: Paragraph

text: and almost demonic allure of the intangible.” Taut’s cosmology, his vision of a
label: Paragraph

text: unified totality, provided the entire modernist project with not only a harvest of
label: Paragraph

text: technological possibilities but also a new and necessarily metaphysical founda-
label: Paragraph

text: tion.’° Although these two seemingly opposed potentials of the time were apparent
label: Paragraph

text: to Taut early on in his life, his Glass House was a first masterful expression of his
label: Paragraph

text: vision of a new, and newly unified modern world.
label: Paragraph

text: Notes
label: Title

text: 1. Bruno Taut, Glashaus — Bauprospekt (Cologne: 1914). The translation reads: “The Glass
label: Caption

text: House has no other purpose than to be beautiful.” Taut repeated this statement in his
label: Paragraph

text: text “Haus des Himmels” (House of Heaven), published in the pamphlet Frihlicht, ed.
label: Caption

text: Bruno Taut (1920). The first four sentences of the text read: “A house should be nothing
label: Paragraph

text: other than beautiful. It should fulfill no other purpose than to be empty, as Meister
label: Paragraph

text: Eckhart put it: ‘I never want to ask God to be with me. I want to ask him that he makes
label: Paragraph

text: me empty and pure; because if I were to be empty and pure, God would come to me, as
label: Paragraph

text: it is his nature to be with me and in me.’ The visitor will be filled with the joy of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture, which will cleanse all human elements from his soul and make it a receptacle for
label: Paragraph

text: the divine.”
label: Paragraph
