text: CITTA NUOVA
label: Caption

text: Antonio Sant'Elia
label: Title

text: Michelangelo Sabatino
label: Title

text: Antonio Sant’Elia, La Citta Nuova: Stazione d’aeroplani e treni, circa 1914.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: FAST AND SLOW FUTURISM
label: Title

text: Airplanes and trains have a key role in setting the tumultuous pace of Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’Elia’s Cittd Nuova (circa 1914). His one-point perspective drawing, entitled
label: Paragraph

text: “Stazione d’aeroplani e treni ferroviari” (Station for Airplanes and Trains), executed
label: Caption

text: on the eve of the First World War, puts the viewer in the air, with a bird’s-eye view
label: Paragraph

text: of a hybrid railroad station and airport of some imagined city of the future.’
label: Paragraph

text: Although commercial air travel was still in the process of becoming reality at
label: Paragraph

text: the time, rail travel had already collapsed the distance between countryside and
label: Paragraph

text: city with the introduction of transportation networks that facilitated the exchange
label: Paragraph

text: of ideas, people, and products. Automobiles, too, were gradually replacing horse-
label: Paragraph

text: drawn carriages and streetcars. The phenomenon of speed and movement were as
label: Paragraph

text: essential to futurist painters such as Umberto Boccioni as they were “constructive
label: Paragraph

text: elements” for Sant’Elia’s vision of the world to come.
label: Paragraph

text: Writing in his Manifesto dell’architettura futurista (1914), Sant’Elia states: “We
label: Paragraph

text: must invent and rebuild the Futurist city: it must be like an immense and tumul-
label: Paragraph

text: tuous shipyard, agile, mobile and dynamic in every detail; and the Futurist house
label: Paragraph

text: must be like a gigantic machine.”” The exhilarated and combative tone of the man-
label: Paragraph

text: ifesto owes as much to the new style of “telegraphic” communication as it does to
label: Paragraph

text: the context in which Sant’Elia was writing. During the first decades of the twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century, Italy was still primarily an agrarian nation that had only begun to awaken
label: Paragraph

text: to the stimuli of the industrial revolution. Throughout its countryside and cities,
label: Paragraph

text: Italy had been shaped over the centuries by layers of historical architectures that
label: Paragraph

text: were a cumulative presence to be reckoned with. Sant’Elia was well aware of this
label: Paragraph

text: challenge, and his bold schemes paralleled Filippo Tommaso Marinetti’s threat to
label: Paragraph

text: “free this land [Italy] from its smelly gangrene of professors, archaeologists, ciceroni,
label: Paragraph

text: and antiquarians.”*
label: Paragraph

text: It is not a coincidence that the Station for Airplanes and Trains drawing (and the
label: Paragraph

text: rest of the Citté Nuova drawing portfolio for that matter) provides little or no indi-
label: Paragraph

text: cation of a “real” city in which Sant’Elia might have been planning to realize his
label: Paragraph

text: monumental transportation nodes and housing towers. Buildings adjacent to the
label: Caption

text: airplane and railroad station are mere outlines, “projections” of a city in fieri.
label: Paragraph

text: The fact that Sant’Elia provides only perspectival drawings, not plans, in the port-
label: Paragraph

text: folio for the Citta Nuova is an indication of the “utopian” nature of his endeavor.
label: Paragraph

text: Whether he conceived the project as a transformative addition to a real city or asa
label: Paragraph

text: catalyst for the founding of a new city is of little importance. It is the speculative
label: Paragraph

text: quality of Sant’Elia’s drawings that excited the imagination of successive genera-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of architects and city planners from the 1920s well into the 1960s, from Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s Contemporary City (Ville contemporaine) (1922) and Norman Bel Geddes
label: Paragraph

text: Futurama (1939), to Yona Friedman's Spatial City (Ville spatiale) (circa 1962) and
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram’s (Peter Cook) Plug-in-City (circa 1963) — all of these urban projections
label: Paragraph

text: owe some debt to Sant’Elia’s “expressionist” visions in which he conflated art, engi-
label: Paragraph

text: neering, architecture, and urbanism. Even today, his drawings remain at the center
label: Paragraph

text: of discussions about the future of the city.“
label: Paragraph

text: Capri as Epicentre of “Slow” Futurism
label: Title

text: Although the natural and built landscape of the island of Capri off the coast of
label: Paragraph

text: taly, south of Naples, shares little with the soaring verticality of Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’ Elia’s Citta Nuova, or the dynamism of Virgilio Marchi’s Citta fantastica (circa
label: Paragraph

text: 1919-20), its remoteness from the industrialized urban realm paradoxically fueled
label: Paragraph

text: the creative impulses of a new generation of Futurists.” To be sure, theirs was a
label: Paragraph

text: Futurism at odds with the contemporary obsession with velocity, invoked, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, in one of the last images of Le Corbusier’s Vers une architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (1923), in which automobiles were seen driving around the rooftop of the Fiat
label: Paragraph

text: Lingotto Factory in Turin, a building designed by the engineer Giacomo
label: Paragraph

text: Matté-Trucco (1915-26). Nonetheless, by the early 1920s, Capri and southern
label: Paragraph

text: taly, where industrialization had been least felt, became an epicenter and pilgrim-
label: Paragraph

text: age site for Italian Futurists who were strongly attracted to the strikingly simple
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular structures typical of this part of the country, as well as the dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: qualities of the rugged landscape and the slow pace of life and artisanal industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Capri’s insularity, far removed as it was from the metropolis celebrated by first-
label: Paragraph

text: generation Futurists working in Milan, coupled with the conspicuous absence of
label: Paragraph

text: any trace of modernity’s fascination with speed (the automobile, the train, the
label: Paragraph

text: airplane), appealed to these Futurists as much as it did the pleasure-seeking bour-
label: Paragraph

text: geoisie who frequented the island.°
label: Paragraph

text: After the First World War, due to the efforts of charismatic mayor Edwin Cerio,
label: Paragraph

text: himself an engineer-turned-politician, the island evolved into a haven for interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional artists, architects, intellectuals, and preservationists. First and second gener-
label: Paragraph

text: ation Futurists such as Fortunato Depero, Virgilio Marchi, Marinetti, and Enrico
label: Paragraph

text: Prampolini visited Capri on a regular basis during those years.” In an address deliv-
label: Paragraph

text: ered to the 1922 Convegno del Paesaggio (Symposium on Landscape) staged on the
label: Paragraph

text: island, Marinetti praised its vernacular buildings because of their rational and non-
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque qualities:
label: Title

text: I believe that this is a Futuristic island; I feel that it is full of infinite originality as if
label: Paragraph

text: it had been sculpted by Futurist architects like Sant’Elia, Virgilio Marchi, painted
label: Paragraph

text: by Balla, Depero, Russolo, Prampolini, and sung and made musical by Francesco
label: Caption

text: Cangiullo and Casella!*
label: Title

text: More than a decade after Marinetti’s attack on Italy’s cult of the past in his leg-
label: Paragraph

text: endary Founding and Manifesto of Futurism (1909), he exonerated vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, sparing them his anti-historicist wrath and proclaiming them exempt
label: Paragraph

text: from the flux of academic styles conjured up by art historians. Marinetti saw
label: Paragraph

text: beauty and freedom in the dramatic and unpredictably varied landscape of Capri
label: Paragraph

text: because it rejected, as he put it, “any kind of order reminiscent of classicism.”®
label: Paragraph

text: Although the interest in primitivism that surfaced in the 1920s among Futurists
label: Paragraph

text: shared something with the pursuit of the archaic that was typical of the Valori
label: Paragraph

text: Plastici milieu, it remained a fundamentally anti-classical impulse. The rediscov-
label: Paragraph

text: ery and appropriation of the vernacular did not imply an end to the avant-garde,
label: Paragraph

text: but rather reframed its objectives in the context of fascist Italy, in which artists
label: Paragraph

text: and architects began to engage simultaneously with issues of national identity
label: Paragraph

text: and modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1922, the year that Benito Mussolini led the March on Rome to illegally seize
label: Paragraph

text: political power, Virgilio Marchi (1895-1960), Futurist architect and set designer,
label: Paragraph

text: praised the vernacular buildings of Capri and the Amalfi coast as a source of formal
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration for contemporary designers. He published his “Primitivismi capresi,” a
label: Paragraph

text: short illustrated essay, in Anton Giulio Bragaglia’s Rome-based avant-garde jour-
label: Paragraph

text: nal, Cronache d’attualita.’° Two years later, in his Architettura futurista (1924),
label: Paragraph

text: Marchi valorized the “innate virtue of primitive builders,” and elaborated on the
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between the vernacular tradition and contemporary design. On the
label: Paragraph

text: book’s cover he reproduced one of his drawings for a hydroelectric plant, one
label: Paragraph

text: of the most modern of twentieth-century architectural types. This project echoed
label: Paragraph

text: the sculptural, stereotomic qualities of the vernacular building types of Capri, and
label: Paragraph

text: more broadly, the Amalfi coast, which he had recorded a few years earlier in a
label: Paragraph

text: drawing of the Hotel Luna in Amalfi and published in Cronache d’attualita. In this
label: Caption

text: book, as well as in his successive book entitled Italia nuova architettura nuova of
label: Paragraph

text: 1931, Marchi expressed admiration for the “ingenious spontaneity” of the architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture of Capri. With Architettura futurista (1924) and Italia nuova architettura nuova
label: Caption

text: (1931), he tried to position himself as the heir to Sant’Elia, and as the champion
label: Paragraph

text: of Futurist architecture after the latter’s death in 1916. Yet Marchi’s drawings
label: Paragraph

text: for Citta fantastica (circa 1919-20) reject the linearity of Sant’Elia’s Citta Nuova (circa
label: Paragraph

text: 1914) in favor of an expressionist quality akin to Bruno Taut’s visionary drawings
label: Paragraph

text: for Alpine Architektur (1919). Most of all, Marchi’s spiraling fantasy city of the future
label: Paragraph

text: recalls the dramatic topography of Capri.
label: Paragraph

text: As a prefiguration of Marchi’s interest in primitivism and the vernacular, it is
label: Paragraph

text: worth recalling the debate between Giulio Ulisse Arata, one of the founding mem-
label: Paragraph

text: bers of the Nuove Tendenze group established in Milan in 1914, shortly before the
label: Paragraph

text: outbreak of the First World War, and Marinetti. Arata was initially supportive of
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’ Elia, whom he described as a “young artist of great genius,” encouraging him
label: Paragraph

text: to participate in the group’s first exhibition and to write a preface for the catalogue.
label: Paragraph

text: But Arata later condemned Sant’Elia’s manifesto on Futurist Architecture (his orig-
label: Paragraph

text: inal Messaggio touched-up and radicalized by Marinetti), which was published in
label: Paragraph

text: the August 1914 issue of Lacerba. He argued that architecture was intimately
label: Paragraph

text: related to ethnography and geology, and therefore could not break completely
label: Paragraph

text: with tradition for a “fresh start” as Sant’Elia advocated: “Architecture now makes a
label: Paragraph

text: break with tradition. It must perforce make a fresh start.”"”
label: Paragraph

text: The 1911 Mostra di Etnografia Italiana (Italian Ethnography Exhibition) gave new
label: Paragraph

text: visibility to “primitive” vernacular architecture and the arts of Italy’s different
label: Paragraph

text: regions, which emerged as an alternative to more traditional expressions of Italian
label: Paragraph

text: identity based on classicism. The divisionist artist, Giacomo Balla (who would later
label: Paragraph

text: become a Futurist), displayed his relief painting Contadina davanti a due capanne
label: Paragraph

text: (Peasant woman in front of two huts, 1910) with others of a series of 12 in Duilio
label: Caption

text: Cambellotti’s monumental reed hut where the Mostra dell’Agro Romano (Exhibition
label: Caption

text: of the Roman Territory) was installed.'? This exhibition promoted the efforts of
label: Paragraph

text: reform-minded intellectuals such as Giovanni Cena and Alessandro Marcucci,
label: Paragraph

text: who befriended many socially-minded artists. They were seeking to improve
label: Paragraph

text: the squalid living conditions (and high illiteracy rate) of the Italian peasantry by
label: Paragraph

text: supporting education and building schools in the countryside. Along with advan-
label: Paragraph

text: cing this socio-political agenda, the organizers of the exhibition sought to draw
label: Paragraph

text: attention to the “dark beauty” of peasant dwellings and arts.
label: Paragraph

text: Balla’s emphasis on the grace and humility of a female peasant against the back-
label: Paragraph

text: drop of coarse reed huts (he had added coarse sand to the oil paint to enhance
label: Paragraph

text: through granularity their tactile quality) suggests his solidarity with the peasantry
label: Paragraph

text: who lived outside the cities and towns.'? Among the 12 works in the series was
label: Paragraph

text: Balla’s portrait of Leo Tolstoy, whose seminal What is Art? (1897) had been trans-
label: Paragraph

text: lated into Italian in 1902. Cambellotti’s socialist-minded circle in Rome, frequented
label: Paragraph

text: by Balla and many others, sought to broaden the traditional boundaries of art.'*
label: Paragraph

text: With much less emphasis on the political dimension of the vernacular tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: the artist, artisan, and stage-set designer, Fortunato Depero, also took inspiration
label: Paragraph

text: from Capri and Italy’s Mezzogiorno in paintings of the peasantry and their built envi-
label: Paragraph

text: rons in his Portatrice caprese (1917), Tarantella (1918-20), and Paese di tarantelle
label: Paragraph

text: (1918), which challenged modern Italian artists to engage simultaneously with fig-
label: Paragraph

text: uration and abstraction. Depero’s enthusiasm for “primordial machines” and peas-
label: Paragraph

text: ant vitality extended to such folk customs as the tarantella, a lively dance typical of
label: Paragraph

text: southern Italian villages and towns. Describing his travels to the “paradise of Capri”
label: Paragraph

text: and the Amalfi coast in 1917, Depero wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: After four hours of sailing from Capri we landed in Positano on the Amalfi Coast. ...
label: Paragraph

text: On one side of this small port we noticed a simple windmill that was inactive for
label: Paragraph

text: many years and that was transformed into a home. ... It looked like a primordial
label: Paragraph

text: machine made of wood built with peasant ingenuity.’”
label: Paragraph

text: When he set up his professional practice in Rovereto in the Alto Adige region,
label: Paragraph

text: Depero brought to his playful Cubo-Futurist reading of the northern Italian ver-
label: Paragraph

text: nacular landscape the bold colors and visual excitement he had experienced in
label: Paragraph

text: Capri. Depero’s depictions of mountain towns to the east of Rovereto, including
label: Caption

text: Serrada (1920) and Lizzana (1923), show his interest in the organic relationship
label: Paragraph

text: between vernacular architecture and the natural landscape. This dialectical rela-
label: Paragraph

text: tionship is manifested in his faceted one-story Bestetti Treves Tuminelli book pavil-
label: Paragraph

text: ion, built for the third Monza Biennale (1927)."° In many ways, its stereotomic mass
label: Paragraph

text: recalls the sculptural qualities of the layered, interlocking stone masonry of the
label: Paragraph

text: southern Italian vernacular buildings anchored to the earth from which they rise.
label: Paragraph

text: Like Marchi’s visionary drawings for the Citta fantastica (circa 1919-20), this build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing evokes solid masses in contradistinction to the pursuit of transparency and
label: Paragraph

text: dematerialization that had come to characterize much of the avant-garde glass
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the same period in Germany and Holland.
label: Paragraph

text: Depero was an artist who visualized the future without ignoring the past. His
label: Paragraph

text: modernism extended beyond painting to the applied arts. His so-called Casa del
label: Paragraph

text: Mago (House of the Magician) in Rovereto was a workshop in which local artisans,
label: Paragraph

text: mainly women, produced handicrafts of vernacular inspiration such as tapestries,
label: Paragraph

text: ceramics, and furniture, often manufactured with basic materials and technologies.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead of working in such new materials as glass and steel, Depero employed pre-
label: Paragraph

text: industrial materials and techniques such as wood, ceramics, and weaving to forge a
label: Paragraph

text: novel synthesis of modernism and primitivism.
label: Paragraph

text: Depero’s Cubo-Futurist portrayals of Italy’s rural landscapes and peasant life are
label: Paragraph

text: indebted to the figurative tradition and single-point perspective. He was captivated
label: Paragraph

text: by pre-industrial farm equipment like the boldly painted horse-drawn carts typical
label: Paragraph

text: of rural communities of southern Italy. Depero’s framing and use of color paral-
label: Paragraph

text: leled the brilliantly hued geometric ornament typical of Sicilian and Neapolitan
label: Paragraph

text: carts and fishermen’s vessels. His painting Carretto napoletano (1918), contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: with Paese delle tarantelle, celebrates the peasant cart as an ancient ancestor of mod-
label: Paragraph

text: erm machines.
label: Paragraph

text: Another prominent Futurist painter and aspiring architect, Enrico Prampolini’s
label: Paragraph

text: painting Architettura cromatica di Capri (1921) offers a synthetic Cubo-Futurist read-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in which he depicts the intrinsic relationship between vernacular buildings and
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape of Capri. Throughout his life, Prampolini looked to the landscape,
label: Paragraph

text: light, and water of Capri as a source of artistic inspiration, and in 1935 he went
label: Paragraph

text: so far as to design a villa (never built) for Marinetti. His multi-story, multi-faceted
label: Paragraph

text: Futurist “pavilion as landscape” in Turin (1927) draws on the sculptural and laby-
label: Paragraph

text: rinthine landscape of Capri, echoing the paintings and prints produced during those
label: Paragraph

text: years by the Danish artist Maurits Cornelis Escher, who also drew attention to sites
label: Paragraph

text: in the Campania such as the Amalfi coast. Between 1922 and 1935, M. C. Escher
label: Paragraph

text: combed central and southern Italy, and made drawings of the architecture he dis-
label: Paragraph

text: covered in towns and villages along the coast of the Tyrhennian Sea, like Atrani and
label: Paragraph

text: Amalfi. The extraordinary degree to which these vernacular buildings were coher-
label: Paragraph

text: ent with the landscape in which they were sited would continue to inform his idi-
label: Paragraph

text: osyncratic interpretations of space throughout his life.
label: Paragraph

text: The pre-industrial and remote character of Capri, both associated with the pre-
label: Paragraph

text: industrial world of southern Italy, posed a challenge to Futurist artists and archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects like Depero, Marchi, and Prampolini, who were in thrall to an identity
label: Paragraph

text: politics tainted by nationalism under fascism. Insofar as it was devoid of the
label: Paragraph

text: mechanized symbols of progress (the car, the train, the airplane), the island forced
label: Paragraph

text: artists and architects to think in terms of a modernity of the spirit. It is not by
label: Paragraph

text: coincidence that the most celebrated example of Futurist and rationalist Italian
label: Paragraph

text: architectural modernism, the Casa Malaparte (1938-42), designed for himself by
label: Paragraph

text: the writer Kurt Erich Sukert (aka Curzio Malaparte) in collaboration with the
label: Paragraph

text: architect Adalberto Libera and the mason-builder Adolfo Amitrano, was com-
label: Paragraph

text: pleted after Futurism had been marginalized by the fascist regime. Given its dra-
label: Paragraph

text: matic site on a remote outcropping on the rocky coast of Capri, its stone
label: Paragraph

text: construction, flat roof, and Pompeian red stucco cladding, the Casa Malaparte
label: Caption

text: recalls the primitive vernacular buildings celebrated by Marchi and the likes of
label: Paragraph

text: Depero more than two decades earlier. In effect, it rejects facile allusions to
label: Paragraph

text: mechanized modernism typical of banal Futurism, instead celebrating the power
label: Paragraph

text: of cultural and physical rootedness.
label: Paragraph

text: PART Il
label: Title

text: The Modern Project
label: Title

text: INnNtroauction
label: Title

text: IMAGINING NEW WORLDS
label: Title

text: David Leatherbarrow
label: Title

text: The ideas of modernity and project making that were developed in early twentieth-
label: Paragraph

text: century architecture reinforced one another. Proponents of the new architecture
label: Paragraph

text: had no doubt that the new century was a time of profound historical change. They
label: Paragraph

text: were also confident about the role to be played by their designs: the new epoch
label: Paragraph

text: would result from the work of imaginations attuned to the new age. This was espe-
label: Paragraph

text: cially true in the first few decades of the century, when the projects studied in the
label: Paragraph

text: chapters that follow were imagined, proposed, and sometimes built.
label: Paragraph

text: Although today, nearly a century later, little of this seems surprising, defining an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural project in this way — a freely imagined instrument of radical cultural
label: Paragraph

text: change — was relatively new to architecture. The same is true of the associated idea
label: Paragraph

text: of “the modern,” the notion that ages, like styles, succeed one another. Difference
label: Paragraph

text: more than distance was stressed, hence the common use of words that indicated
label: Paragraph

text: overturning or turning against to describe the modernization process: revolt, not
label: Paragraph

text: reform, not even renewal, exactly the opposite of restoration. Le Corbusier's his-
label: Paragraph

text: torical assessment was as follows: “We do not appreciate sufficiently the deep
label: Paragraph

text: chasm between our own epoch and earlier periods.” Others felt similarly. At
label: Paragraph

text: the First International Dada Fair in Berlin George Grosz and John Heartfield pro-
label: Paragraph

text: claimed: “Art is dead; long live Tatlin’s machine-art.”
label: Paragraph

text: But as I have already observed, the expectations for difference expressed by
label: Paragraph

text: these conceptions of the modern are historically specific. Generally speaking,
label: Paragraph

text: before the early twentieth century, project making and historical change allowed
label: Paragraph

text: adaptation and continuity — together with difference. Because these alternative con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceptions have resurfaced in contemporary historiography we can no longer simply
label: Paragraph

text: accept the self-proclaimed progressivism of the early moderns, nor its reappearance
label: Paragraph

text: in subsequent avant-gardes, particularly those of our time.
label: Paragraph

text: Leaving aside for a moment the ideas of history and project making that were
label: Paragraph

text: advanced in 1920s and early 1930s, one can observe that project making had been
label: Paragraph

text: seen previously as a prefiguration of a possible outcome, less certain of its results than
label: Paragraph

text: a modernist design, making no promises about its effects on society and culture.’
label: Paragraph

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: It was not that the project’s anticipatory character was denied, rather that its
label: Paragraph

text: contingency was accepted. The difference between a proposal and promise was
label: Paragraph

text: apparent every time a design was transformed into a built work, when an idea
label: Paragraph

text: was subjected to the availability or scarcity of materials, the skills and mistakes
label: Paragraph

text: of builders, the opportunities and constraints of an actual site, the interests and
label: Paragraph

text: complaints of a client, legal conditions, and so on.
label: Paragraph

text: If one accepts at face value what they wrote, the architects studied in the chapters
label: Paragraph

text: that follow — Poelzig, Tatlin, Mies van der Rohe, van Doesburg, Asplund, and Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier — would seem to have overlooked limitations of this kind when making
label: Paragraph

text: promises or predictions about the societal outcomes of their designs. They seem to have
label: Paragraph

text: assumed that the future could be drawn back into the present, that project making was
label: Paragraph

text: same as production, that it could advance locomotively toward a destination known in
label: Paragraph

text: advance.
label: Paragraph

text: But surely this conception abbreviates the architectural project’s historical real-
label: Paragraph

text: ity. Before it can anticipate anything final, let alone achieve it, a proposal must
label: Paragraph

text: define its relationships to what exists, partly tearing itself away from the present,
label: Paragraph

text: because its provisions no longer suit current needs, partly remaining there, for that
label: Paragraph

text: is where changes must be made and where their effect will be seen. A complete
label: Paragraph

text: break is refused and adhesions are required, notwithstanding the opportunities
label: Paragraph

text: of the historical moment and the need for change.
label: Paragraph

text: Contrary to some of the claims of this story’s protagonists, modernity’s forward
label: Paragraph

text: march was similar, similarly contingent and similarly incomplete, as Jiirgen
label: Paragraph

text: Habermas famously observed.’ I say “some of the claims” because these architects
label: Paragraph

text: also argued for continuity. The contradiction cannot be denied. With frequency
label: Paragraph

text: that is often surprising, they identified themselves and explained their works with
label: Paragraph

text: direct reference to historical examples, arguing for linkages with the past, despite
label: Paragraph

text: their professed need for a radical break with the historical inheritance. Admittedly,
label: Paragraph

text: models from the recent past were rarely cited, though Le Corbusier did republish
label: Paragraph

text: drawings from Auguste Choisy’s Histoire de Varchitecture (1899) in his Vers une
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, and built his early vision of the modern city out of arguments formu-
label: Paragraph

text: lated by Camillo Sitte in Der Stddtebau nach seinen kiinstlerischen Grundsdtzen (1889).
label: Caption

text: In most cases the historical turn was toward rather more distant times: ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Greece and Rome for Le Corbusier; Gothic Germany for Mies; the medieval
label: Paragraph

text: (not the Gothic) period for Poelzig; and ancient Scandinavia for Asplund.
label: Paragraph

text: If we are to grasp the particularity of their work, especially their built work, we
label: Paragraph

text: need to consider their modernity within the traditions they tried to renew, even
label: Paragraph

text: though they also argued against tradition. A common mistake of older histories
label: Paragraph

text: of the modern movement is that they accepted the self-identification of the moder-
label: Paragraph

text: nists as modernists at face value, neglecting clear evidences of historical continuity
label: Paragraph

text: in their built work and the historical dimension the discipline they sought to renew.
label: Paragraph

text: The choice suggested by the last chapter of Vers une architecture — architecture or
label: Paragraph

text: revolution — posed an alternative between the time of the discipline and of that
label: Paragraph

text: of the historical moment. With the whole of the book in mind, to say nothing of
label: Paragraph

text: his projects, and those of the 1920s and 1930s more generally, could not be seen as
label: Paragraph

text: works of architecture; which is to say, entitled to their own standing among the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings and cities of the Greeks and Romans, Bramante and Michelangelo, and so on.
label: Paragraph

text: Of course, these architects had no doubt that the world could be remade, and
label: Paragraph

text: that their instructions would guide the hands that poured the concrete and welded
label: Paragraph

text: the steel. Nineteenth-century transformations in both rural and urban regions had
label: Paragraph

text: made the possibility of “world-making” exceedingly plain. The rail lines that reor-
label: Paragraph

text: ganized the countryside offered clear evidence of the power of modern industry, as
label: Paragraph

text: did the growth and increased density of cities. Change was not only given a prec-
label: Paragraph

text: edent but warranted. Accordingly, projects were to disclose entirely new possibi-
label: Paragraph

text: lities, even possible realities. World making — the unmaking and remaking of
label: Paragraph

text: cities, neighborhoods, buildings, and interiors — was understood to be the archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect’s proper remit. The visions described in the chapters that follow elaborate a
label: Paragraph

text: number of these “possible realities.”
label: Paragraph

text: Despite their shared sense of a new epoch, the architects and artists of these
label: Paragraph

text: years generally saw themselves as members of movements that were distinct from
label: Paragraph

text: one another, as if each circle had its own insight into the spirit of the times. The
label: Paragraph

text: number of influential groups in these years is not great, but their importance can-
label: Paragraph

text: not be denied, for they provided a context for the debates, disagreements, and dis-
label: Paragraph

text: coveries that allowed the progressive ideas to develop. Each architect was, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, an individual, but not in our contemporary sense, not a “star architect” pro-
label: Paragraph

text: moting a unique brand. Consider Mies van der Rohe. He relied on Friihlich, the
label: Paragraph

text: short-lived journal of Bruno Taut’s circle, for the publication of his glass skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: designs. In his chapter on the Friedrichstraffe project, Ufuk Ersoy explains that Mies
label: Paragraph

text: used the journal even though he did not share the utopian dimensions of Taut’s
label: Paragraph

text: “glass culture,” nor the ideas that were widely shared among the “crystal chain”
label: Paragraph

text: artists and architects. It was not only publications that served the dissemination
label: Paragraph

text: of ideas; exhibitions did so too, as did less formal meetings in cafés, clubs, and pri-
label: Paragraph

text: vate houses. Although the movements of the 1920s and 1920s — expressionism, con-
label: Paragraph

text: structivism, Futurism, De Stijl, Poetism, and Purism — were generally country- or
label: Paragraph

text: language-based (Germany, Russia, Italy, Holland, Czech Republic, or France, for
label: Paragraph

text: those just listed), these differences did not prevent single individuals from circulat-
label: Paragraph

text: ing from one group to another. Theo van Doesburg, for example, migrated
label: Paragraph

text: between different circles, as did Karel Tiege. Why did groups of this kind provide
label: Paragraph

text: fertile soil for the development of projects that proposed radically new possibilities?
label: Paragraph

text: It seems that thought and works that were free from the constraints of actual sites,
label: Paragraph

text: ways of building, and budgets were particularly free for the formulation of new
label: Paragraph

text: worlds. What is most striking about the projects of this time is that the designers
label: Paragraph

text: convinced themselves that the architecture that emerged from their discussions
label: Paragraph

text: would be richer than the world in which it was to find its place.
label: Paragraph

text: The projective thinking of these years also shared ground with concurrent art prac-
label: Paragraph

text: tices. In one sense this is obvious because a number of the protagonists were both
label: Paragraph

text: artists and architects. Vladimir Tatlin, for example, was mainly a painter. Richard
label: Paragraph

text: anarchitectural project, was envisaged asa synthesis of the arts. Le Corbusier admitted
label: Paragraph

text: that his painting studio was a laboratory for the discovery of architectural ideas. While
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe was no painter, his dedication to the art of building did not prevent
label: Paragraph

text: him from adopting new art techniques, such as montage, for the representation and
label: Paragraph

text: dissemination of his ideas. Moreover, as George Dodds shows, the relatively high
label: Paragraph

text: degree of abstraction of Mies’ Brick Country House drawings allowed — encouraged?
label: Paragraph

text: — comparisons with contemporary painting, particularly when Mies’ plan was viewed
label: Paragraph

text: without its perspective rendering, rotated 90° on the page, and placed alongside Theo
label: Paragraph

text: van Doesburg’s Rhythms of Russian Dance. Van Doesburg, for his part, was as much a
label: Paragraph

text: painter as an architect. His Café de Aubette in Strasbourg can be seen as a three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional translation of one of his Contra-Compositions, as described in Hilary
label: Paragraph

text: Bryon. Van Doesburg described it as the realization of “unbridled imagination.”
label: Paragraph

text: As with Tatlin’s experimental work, in this case the alliance between artistic and archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural practices proposed a “total work of art.” For the progressive artist-architects of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1920s and 1930s, actual buildings did not reveal new possibilities as vividly as draw-
label: Paragraph

text: ings, photographs, models, installations, temporary constructions, and writings.
label: Paragraph

text: Of course many radical proposals named a location for the projects. Yet, the
label: Paragraph

text: exact site of Tatlin’s Monument, for example, is very difficult if not impossible
label: Paragraph

text: to determine. In most of Mies’ renditions of his skyscraper projects, the identifying
label: Paragraph

text: attributes of the location have been suppressed, giving the project greater prom-
label: Paragraph

text: inence. Dodds describes the Brick Country House project as a Landhaus without
label: Paragraph

text: Land because all that can be said about a (possible) site must be inferred, as no top-
label: Paragraph

text: ographical details were added to the lines, angles, thicknesses, and distances shown
label: Paragraph

text: on the plan. Michael Andersen, in his chapter on the Stockholm Public Library,
label: Paragraph

text: explains that Asplund backed away from reshaping the building’s immediate vicin-
label: Paragraph

text: ity — the transformation of which he had sketched out in an early version of the
label: Paragraph

text: project — in order to achieve greater complementarity between its rawness and
label: Paragraph

text: the building’s simplicity. Flora Samuel shows that Le Corbusier’s Voisin Plan
label: Paragraph

text: was clearly sited in the center of Paris. But, while some remnants of pre-existing
label: Paragraph

text: conditions were meant to survive the insertion, the relationships between the
label: Paragraph

text: orders of the new and old were never articulated and are hard to imagine.
label: Paragraph

text: Construction materials also played important roles in these proposals for the new
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Much has been written about the forward-looking character of glass
label: Paragraph

text: and steel (ferro-vitreous) construction. These materials were often described as
label: Paragraph

text: “modern.” They are still seen in this way today. But two facts make the claim uncon-
label: Paragraph

text: vincing: materials like steel and glass were used before this period; and other mate-
label: Paragraph

text: rials, such as brick, were also used in forward-looking designs. Yes, Mies did design a
label: Paragraph

text: concrete version of his country house; but his sense of “the modern” did not prevent
label: Paragraph

text: him from developing a brick variant too. The conclusion this example suggests is
label: Paragraph

text: that materials themselves are neither modern nor traditional; what makes them
label: Paragraph

text: indicative of new thinking is the way they are used, the dimensions of the steel col-
label: Paragraph

text: ummns, the expanse of glass panes, the ways pieces are joined together (to give the
label: Paragraph

text: impression of uninterrupted planarity), their positions with respect to one another,
label: Paragraph

text: these buildings is that new uses — modern uses — were key, and that new applications
label: Paragraph

text: were made possible by what today is often called “research” on materials.
label: Paragraph

text: A common way research of this kind was undertaken in the architecture of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s and 1930s was by utilizing — as much as possible — a single material for the
label: Paragraph

text: whole of the building. Bruno Taut’s Glass Pavilion at the Cologne Exhibition is an
label: Paragraph

text: obvious case in point. The projects by Mies already mentioned also isolate and
label: Paragraph

text: explore the possibilities of one or two materials: glass and steel in the skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: projects, concrete and brick in the country houses. Ersoy argues that Mies (re)dis-
label: Paragraph

text: covered the “liquid” character of glass in the FriedrichstraBe project. Similarly, the
label: Paragraph

text: first real building undertaken by Bauhaus teachers and students was a study in tim-
label: Paragraph

text: ber construction, the Sommerfeld House (1920-21): timber cladding, structure, fur-
label: Caption

text: nishings, and ornament. Tatlin’s Monument to the Third International was a study
label: Paragraph

text: in the frank (unpainted and unclad) use of steel. In many early modern projects
label: Paragraph

text: (constructivist, expressionist, and De Stijl designs) materials were not specified.
label: Paragraph

text: But this did not mean the topic was neglected. The forms and geometries of
label: Paragraph

text: van Doesburg’s Contra Compositions were expected to “react dialectically” with
label: Paragraph

text: the materials of construction once the labors of building commenced. This, too,
label: Paragraph

text: would be a time when unforeseen possibilities could be discovered. But again,
label: Paragraph

text: the use, not the material itself was modern. Unprecedented applications disclosed
label: Paragraph

text: new possibilities, sometimes for their own sake, sometimes to represent new ways
label: Paragraph

text: of inhabiting rooms, buildings, or urban settings.
label: Paragraph

text: In the chapters that follow, a basic question arises in different forms: what is the
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between the “possible realities” imagined in early modern projects and
label: Paragraph

text: the “real possibilities” of the modern world? Flora Samuel’s account of Le Corbu-
label: Paragraph

text: sier’s Voisin Plan shows that the design not only proposed the reorganization of a
label: Paragraph

text: large section of the city but also allowed for new architecture, furniture, art works,
label: Paragraph

text: emotions, and therefore new ways of living. Modern forms were meant to be
label: Paragraph

text: “orthopedic,” Le Corbusier said, which is to say corrective.° Ufuk Ersoy explains
label: Paragraph

text: that Mies van der Rohe imagined not only a new architecture but also anew human
label: Paragraph

text: subject. Life was the target of this re-ordering as much as architecture. The same
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen in the writings and designs of Poelzig, Tatlin, van Doesburg, and
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund. The fact that the various realizations of this ambition — the creation of
label: Paragraph

text: a new type of person — were challenged by cultural and historical conditions out-
label: Paragraph

text: side the scope of the projects does not diminish their potency and continued rel-
label: Paragraph

text: evance; all it means is that better understanding their historical reality requires that
label: Paragraph

text: we insist on the difference between a proposal and a promise.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Conceived in 1919, Vladimir Tatlin’s Monument to the Third International
label: Paragraph

text: remains a powerful and enigmatic icon of the artistic and architectural innova-
label: Paragraph

text: tions that followed the October Revolution. The project was at once central
label: Paragraph

text: to architecture’s development in the post-revolutionary period, but Tatlin oper-
label: Paragraph

text: ated only on the periphery of the productive experiments undertaken by the
label: Paragraph

text: Soviet architectural vanguard during the 1920s and early 1930s. His Monument
label: Paragraph

text: to the Third International was widely recognized as having initiated a new
label: Paragraph

text: approach both to the monument as a building type and to architecture as such.
label: Paragraph

text: To some, this project for a towering skeleton of steel appeared as a logical con-
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of Tatlin’s exploration of material properties; to others it was a design
label: Paragraph

text: overburdened with symbolism.
label: Paragraph

text: Origins of the Monument
label: Title

text: The Monument was Tatlin’s first work on an architectural scale. He started his
label: Paragraph

text: career as a painter; having studied at both the Moscow School of Painting, Sculp-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, and Architecture and the Penza Art School, he established himself as a leading
label: Paragraph

text: figure in the art worlds of Moscow and St. Petersburg before the Revolution of
label: Paragraph

text: 1917. His works on canvas demonstrated his sensitivity to the formal and material
label: Paragraph

text: traditions of Russian icon painting. Equally important to Tatlin’s development was
label: Paragraph

text: his engagement with advanced artistic practices in Russia and Western Europe. He
label: Paragraph

text: viewed the work of Picasso in both the Shchukin and Morozov collections in Mos-
label: Paragraph

text: cow and during a trip to Paris in 1914. At the time, Picasso was exploring the pos-
label: Paragraph

text: sibilities of work in three dimensions and producing sculptures such as his Guitar of
label: Paragraph

text: early 1913. Tatlin saw this work during a visit to Picasso’s Paris studio, and this
label: Paragraph

text: experience, together with Tatlin’s interest in the tactile qualities of materials,
label: Paragraph

text: led him to produce a series of “painterly reliefs” and “counter-reliefs” in 1914
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin exhibited his “counter-reliefs” at the legendary 0.10 exhibition in Petro-
label: Paragraph

text: grad in late 1915, where they formed a materialist counterpoint to Kazimir Male-
label: Paragraph

text: vich’s ethereal Suprematist paintings. With his “counter-reliefs,” Tatlin introduced
label: Paragraph

text: several interests that would inform his conception of the Monument: the frank use
label: Paragraph

text: of materials, the interpenetration of spaces, suspension as structural device, and the
label: Paragraph

text: appearance of dynamic movement. The Corner Counter-Reliefs he installed in the
label: Caption

text: galleries of the 0.10 exhibition were composed of a variety of hitherto “non-artistic”
label: Paragraph

text: materials such as rope, sheet metal, scrap wood, and wire. Installation photographs
label: Paragraph

text: show Tatlin’s works in taut suspension, pulling away from the gallery walls and
label: Paragraph

text: occupying three-dimensional space.
label: Paragraph

text: Late in life, Tatlin wrote that “to accept or not to accept the October Revolution,
label: Paragraph

text: that wasn’t a question for me.”’ His assumption of several positions within the
label: Paragraph

text: growing cultural bureaucracy of the young Soviet state attests to the truth of
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s statement. His most important role was in the Department of Fine Arts
label: Paragraph

text: (IZO) of the People’s Commissariat of Enlightenment (Narkompros), which was
label: Paragraph

text: directed by the Marxist philosopher and critic Anatoly Lunacharsky. IZO organized
label: Paragraph

text: decorations for mass demonstrations and public festivals, and it facilitated the exe-
label: Paragraph

text: cution of the “Plan for Monumental Propaganda,” a campaign initiated by Lenin for
label: Paragraph

text: the construction of monuments to revolutionary philosophers and activists. The
label: Paragraph

text: plan removed many existing monuments from Moscow’s landscape, but the realist
label: Paragraph

text: mode of the works intended to replace the monuments of the Tsars disheartened
label: Paragraph

text: advanced artists like Tatlin. Exploiting his position as president of the IZO Colle-
label: Paragraph

text: gium, Tatlin issued a memorandum on the plan in which he wrote that “the state as
label: Paragraph

text: it now is cannot and must not be the initiator of bad taste.””
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin responded to the “Plan for Monumental Propaganda” through his friend
label: Paragraph

text: and interpreter Nikolai Punin, an art critic and historian. Punin’s essay, “On
label: Paragraph

text: Monuments,” which was published in March 1919, outlined Tatlin’s concept for
label: Paragraph

text: a monument that would both synthesize the arts of painting, sculpture, and archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture and serve as a center for the dissemination of information through radio,
label: Paragraph

text: film, and other media.’ Tatlin’s interest in artistic synthesis was shared by other
label: Paragraph

text: representatives of the Soviet vanguard, most importantly the circle gathered
label: Paragraph

text: around the sculptor Boris Korolev and the architect Nikolai Ladovskii and their
label: Paragraph

text: group SINSKUL’PTARKh (Synthesis of Sculpture and Architecture).4 When
label: Caption

text: Punin’s article was published, Tatlin’s Monument was still dedicated to the “Great
label: Paragraph

text: Russian Revolution” and the structure’s form was only roughly defined. It was to
label: Paragraph

text: be composed of cubes, cylinders, cones, semi-circles, and their combinations; the
label: Paragraph

text: ascending double-spiral of the Monument’s final form was not yet developed. At
label: Paragraph

text: this early stage Tatlin envisioned large geometrical volumes as habitable, dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: spaces. They were to house auditoria, halls for gymnastics, and halls for meetings.
label: Paragraph

text: He rejected the idea of including a museum or library in the Monument and
label: Paragraph

text: insisted on the necessity of an agitation center, which could produce pamphlets
label: Paragraph

text: and brochures, present cultural news on a giant screen, host a radio station with
label: Paragraph

text: a global reach, project slogans and headlines on the clouds, and accommodate a
label: Paragraph

text: fleet of motorcycles that would serve as a mobile extension of the Monument’s
label: Paragraph

text: functions. The program of Tatlin’s Monument, as initially conceived, combined
label: Paragraph

text: the facilities found in a workers’ club with a garage and broadcast center. At its
label: Paragraph

text: inception, Tatlin’s Monument represented a flexible and innovative building type;
label: Paragraph

text: only later, during its development, was it assigned the functions of a government
label: Paragraph

text: ministry.
label: Paragraph

text: In September 1919 Tatlin moved to Petrograd, where he took up a teaching posi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion at the Petrograd Free Art Studios (SVOMAS) and further developed his con-
label: Paragraph

text: cept for a monument. When Tatlin arrived in the city, it was still suffering from the
label: Paragraph

text: aftermath of the Revolution and the ensuing civil war. As buildings were torn
label: Paragraph

text: down for firewood, Viktor Shklovskii, the literary critic, wrote that “the city slowly
label: Paragraph

text: began to transform itself into an engraving by Piranesi.”’ But as Tatlin arrived,
label: Paragraph

text: municipal authorities were staging the reconstruction of the city through several
label: Paragraph

text: high-profile architectural competitions, most notably the competition for a new
label: Paragraph

text: crematorium. Ivan Fomin, the best-known architect to participate in the competi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, submitted a project characterized by a multi-tiered tower that rises from a
label: Paragraph

text: compact base. A crematorium project by one of Fomin’s students, Aleksandr
label: Paragraph

text: Gegello, also adopted a vertical composition, but he articulated his principal vol-
label: Paragraph

text: ume as an ascending spiral staircase. These projects were important elements of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural context in which Tatlin found himself in Petrograd, and they would
label: Paragraph

text: have been very much in the public eye as he joined SVOMAS in the building of the
label: Paragraph

text: former Academy of Fine Arts — the building where Fomin and his colleagues
label: Paragraph

text: worked and the place where Tatlin and his assistants would later build and exhibit
label: Paragraph

text: the model of the Monument.
label: Paragraph

text: By December 1919, Tatlin had a version of his Monument that was refined
label: Paragraph

text: enough for him to seek technical expertise.° He had indicated that the structure
label: Paragraph

text: was to be 400 m tall, and had prepared several drawings of the project.” Presumably
label: Paragraph

text: the documentation Tatlin submitted for examination consisted of the two elevation
label: Paragraph

text: drawings that Punin published in his pamphlet on the Monument and perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: other drawings as well.* The elevation drawings depict a structure composed of
label: Paragraph

text: two nested, ascending spirals that are supported by an inclined girder. Four
label: Caption

text: volumes are suspended from this skeletal system: a cube, a pyramid, a cylinder,
label: Paragraph

text: and a hemisphere. Arranged in diminishing scale from bottom to top, the volumes
label: Paragraph

text: do not share a central axis; instead, they appear to hover in tense juxtaposition. The
label: Paragraph

text: scale and site of the proposed building is difficult to discern from the surviving
label: Paragraph

text: drawings. In one, the Monument appears to rise above a crudely drawn, uniden-
label: Paragraph

text: tifiable cityscape. In the other, the building appears as a solitary figure against an
label: Paragraph

text: undifferentiated background. Anatolii Strigalev has pointed out that these two
label: Paragraph

text: drawings do not meet the standards of rigorous architectural delineation: they offer
label: Paragraph

text: not two projections of the same form, but rather two slightly different variations on
label: Paragraph

text: the form of the monument.” Nevertheless, when Tatlin submitted his project for
label: Paragraph

text: expert review, the panel, which was composed of an architect and an engineer,
label: Paragraph

text: both unnamed, wrote that “contemporary technology fully permits the possibility
label: Paragraph

text: of constructing such a building.”’°
label: Paragraph

text: Over the course of eight months, from March to November 1920, Tatlin con-
label: Paragraph

text: structed a model of his Monument in the former mosaics workshop of the Academy
label: Caption

text: of Fine Arts. He was assisted by the artist Sofia Dymshits-Tolstaia and the students
label: Paragraph

text: Joseph Meerzon, Tevel Shapiro, and Pavel Vinogradov.’ The model was con-
label: Paragraph

text: structed from materials similar to those Tatlin had used in his “counter-reliefs”:
label: Paragraph

text: wood, cardboard, paper, wire, and metal. Although estimations of the height of
label: Paragraph

text: the model have varied widely — some observers have said it rose 25 m — the super-
label: Paragraph

text: structure was only about 5 m tall, while its base, which was intended to accommo-
label: Paragraph

text: date mechanisms for the rotating bodies, was about 1-1%m tall.’” Shapiro, who
label: Paragraph

text: supplied several statements about the model in the 1960s and 1970s, reported that
label: Paragraph

text: the project was completed without the use of detailed working drawings.
label: Paragraph

text: Shapiro also noted that because metal was so scarce, Tatlin and his assistants carved
label: Paragraph

text: nearly two thousand wooden pegs by hand in order to hold the structure together’?
label: Paragraph

text: The principal elements of the model were “L’-shaped legs, which were arranged
label: Paragraph

text: as radii around a central point and stacked in tiers. Tatlin and his team were unable
label: Paragraph

text: to motorize the rotation of the internal volumes in their original model;
label: Paragraph

text: Shapiro claimed that a young boy turned the volumes while it was on display in
label: Paragraph

text: Moscow.'*
label: Paragraph

text: During the construction of the model, the Monument was rededicated to the
label: Paragraph

text: Third International, or Comintern, on the occasion of the organization’s second
label: Paragraph

text: congress, which took place in July and August 1920 in Moscow and Petrograd.”
label: Paragraph

text: At this time Tatlin proposed the staging of a mass spectacle in Petrograd devoted to
label: Paragraph

text: the construction of the Monument, but this concept proved to be short-lived. The
label: Paragraph

text: period of the model’s construction also saw the publication of Punin’s pamphlet on
label: Paragraph

text: the Monument, which contains the most detailed description of the project.'®
label: Paragraph

text: Punin claimed that the project was commissioned by IZO Narkompros. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin had been president of the Moscow IZO Collegium and had worked on the
label: Paragraph

text: plan for monumental propaganda, this was an exaggeration of the degree of gov-
label: Paragraph

text: ernmental approval for Tatlin’s project. Punin’s pamphlet recalls his earlier essay,
label: Paragraph

text: “On Monuments,” but his later text offers a more concrete description of Tatlin’s
label: Paragraph

text: project. Its origins lay in the desire to combine “a purely artistic form with a util-
label: Paragraph

text: itarian one.” This rationale was already present in Tatlin’s earlier statement on
label: Paragraph

text: monuments, but he now assigned a more definite program to the structure: the
label: Paragraph

text: volumes suspended from its spiral-shaped armature were to house the legislative,
label: Paragraph

text: executive, and propaganda arms of the Comintern. Inexplicably, Punin’s text dis-
label: Paragraph

text: cusses only three volumes (the cube, pyramid, and cylinder), neglecting the hem-
label: Paragraph

text: isphere that is clearly visible in the uppermost section of the model and elevation
label: Paragraph

text: drawings. The cube, the lowest volume, was designed for conferences of the Com-
label: Paragraph

text: intern and was to revolve around its axis once per year. The pyramid was for the
label: Paragraph

text: executive committee and secretariat and was to revolve once per month. The cyl-
label: Paragraph

text: inder was to be an international information center that would rotate once per day.
label: Paragraph

text: Film projectors were to be mounted on the uppermost diaphragm of the spiral
label: Paragraph

text: structure. Radio antennas crown the monument, enabling it to disseminate “infor-
label: Paragraph

text: mation to the world proletariat.” Punin described how the Monument was to
label: Paragraph

text: “share in the social and public life of the city,” but he did not indicate a proposed
label: Paragraph

text: site for the structure — a telling and perhaps strategic omission.
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s model was first exhibited in the studio where he and his assistants had
label: Paragraph

text: constructed it. Photographs of this exhibition, which ran from November 8 to
label: Paragraph

text: December 1, 1920, provide the most detailed records of the model. In one image,
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin stands in front of his model, while a banner with the slogan “Long Live the
label: Paragraph

text: Third International!” hangs above. After this event, Tatlin’s model was disas-
label: Paragraph

text: sembled and shipped to Moscow, where it would be displayed at two separate
label: Paragraph

text: events in the House of Trade Unions, which stands in the center of Moscow.’”
label: Paragraph

text: The first event was a trade fair that was organized to accompany the Eighth
label: Paragraph

text: Congress of Soviets. Here, Tatlin’s model was exhibited in the section of the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: press agency, underlining the importance of information to the program of Tatlin’s
label: Paragraph

text: Monument. In the Berlin-based journal, Veshch’, El Lissitzky described how Tatlin
label: Paragraph

text: and his assistants “explained the purpose and meaning of the tower-like monument
label: Paragraph

text: to delegates from Siberia, Turkestan, Crimea, and the Ukraine.”’* The exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: also provided an opportunity for Tatlin and his assistants to issue a statement on the
label: Paragraph

text: value of the Monument in their well-known text, “The Work Ahead of Us.” In this
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto they linked the work at “laboratory scale” that Tatlin had undertaken
label: Paragraph

text: before the October Revolution to the work on the Monument, calling the latter
label: Paragraph

text: a model that stimulates “us to inventions in our work of creating a new world,
label: Paragraph

text: and which call[s] upon the producers to exercise control over the forms encoun-
label: Paragraph

text: tered in our new everyday life.”?? As Maria Gough has recently shown, Tatlin’s
label: Paragraph

text: model was displayed a second time in the House of Trade Unions in summer
label: Paragraph

text: 1921, this time at a trade fair held in conjunction with a meeting of the international
label: Paragraph

text: delegates of the Third Congress of the Comintern. At this event the model was
label: Paragraph

text: presented along with a multilingual selection of books and a radio transmitter.
label: Paragraph

text: The model seems to have stood in the House of Trade Unions through early
label: Paragraph

text: 1922, when Lunacharsky criticized it in a statement on the relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: art and the Soviet state.*° After this date, the fate of the original model is difficult
label: Paragraph

text: to trace, though Tatlin did exhibit at least one elevation drawing of the Monument
label: Paragraph

text: in 1923, at the “Exhibition of Artists of All Directions” in Petrograd.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Reception of the Monument
label: Title

text: Tatlin’s project for the Monument found immediate resonance both within Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Russia and abroad. In January 1921 Shklovskii praised the project, writing that “the
label: Paragraph

text: Monument is made of glass, iron, and Revolution.””* In 1923 the poet Vladimir
label: Paragraph

text: Mayakovsky counted Tatlin’s Monument among the “first art objects of the
label: Paragraph

text: post-October epoch.””’ Tatlin’s work also attracted the attention of the Soviet lead-
label: Paragraph

text: ership, notably Leon Trotsky. In his Literature and Revolution, which was first pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lished in 1923, Trotsky wrote that Tatlin was “undoubtedly right” in discarding
label: Paragraph

text: historical styles in his Monument and in “attempting to subordinate the entire
label: Paragraph

text: design to a correct constructive use of material.””“ He nevertheless expressed skep-
label: Paragraph

text: ticism at the proposal to hold meetings of the Comintern in rotating glass volumes.
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s Monument had a broad impact on the international scene. Reports on
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s concept for a new type of monument spread to Germany through the writ-
label: Paragraph

text: ing of Konstantin Umanskii. His essays in the arts periodical Der Ararat, which were
label: Paragraph

text: published before Tatlin had completed his model, inspired the memorable slogan
label: Paragraph

text: that George Grosz and John Heartfield presented in Berlin at the First International
label: Paragraph

text: Dada Fair: “Art is dead; long live Tatlin’s machine-art.””” The writer Il’ia Ehren-
label: Paragraph

text: burg further popularized Tatlin’s work in his book, A vse-taki ona vertitsia (Eppur
label: Paragraph

text: si muove), as well as in articles in the journals L’Esprit Nouveau and Frihlicht.”* Lajos
label: Paragraph

text: Kassak and Laszl6 Moholy-Nagy published a photograph of Tatlin’s model in their
label: Paragraph

text: Buch neuer Kiinstler (Book of New Artists), and E] Lissitzky published an elevation
label: Paragraph

text: drawing of the Monument in the Basel-based publication ABC.”” Louis Lozowick’s
label: Caption

text: essay in Broom of 1922 was perhaps the first English-language publication on the
label: Paragraph

text: project.”* Tatlin’s Monument also circulated in sculptural form: two distinct sim-
label: Paragraph

text: plified models of the tower were exhibited in 1925: one in a workers’ parade in
label: Paragraph

text: Leningrad; the other at the International Exposition of Decorative Arts in Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: While Tatlin’s Monument circulated through the vectors of an emerging inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national art world, Soviet architects responded to the complex spatial and program-
label: Paragraph

text: matic propositions Tatlin had put forward. Lissitzky captured the paradoxical role
label: Paragraph

text: of Tatlin’s Monument in the development of Soviet architecture with great clarity.
label: Paragraph

text: nhis lecture “On New Russian Art” of 1922, Lissitzky noted that “within the sphere
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture proper, the most important work was accomplished only on theo-
label: Paragraph

text: retical territory, in consequence of the absolute paralysis of building.” He counted
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s Monument as one of the few “architectural manifestations of recent years.”
label: Paragraph

text: But, as Lissitzky never tired of pointing out, Tatlin’s Monument was not the
label: Paragraph

text: achievement of an architect but the work of a painter. Tatlin, unlike Lissitzky,
label: Paragraph

text: had no architectural training. Lissitzky nevertheless described the Monument as
label: Paragraph

text: “the first work of the new generation, which is demanding of itself invention, ele-
label: Paragraph

text: mentary design, clear construction and mastery of material.””° Eight years later, in
label: Paragraph

text: his book Russland (1930), Lissitzky modified his interpretation of Tatlin’s tower.
label: Paragraph

text: With a hint of disdain, Lissitzky recalled how Tatlin “assumed ... that the intuitive
label: Paragraph

text: and artistic mastery of materials would lead to inventions on the basis of which
label: Paragraph

text: objects could be constructed.”*° Lissitzky identified Tatlin’s work as a landmark
label: Paragraph

text: in architectural constructivism, but he nevertheless offered the disparaging sugges-
label: Paragraph

text: tion that Tatlin’s Monument revived spatial concepts found in the pyramid of Sar-
label: Paragraph

text: gon II at Khorsabad.
label: Caption

text: Tatlin’s relationship to architectural constructivism was complex. With few
label: Paragraph

text: exceptions, constructivist architects rarely claimed Tatlin’s legacy as their own.
label: Paragraph

text: Moisei Ginzburg hardly mentioned Tatlin in his 1924 book Stil i epokha (Style
label: Paragraph

text: and Epoch). This text was a first attempt to identify the sources of what Ginzburg
label: Paragraph

text: called Gn purely Wolfflinian fashion) “the characteristic aspects of the new style.”
label: Paragraph

text: Ginzburg illustrated Tatlin’s Monument in the book’s crucial chapter on construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tivism in architecture, but he did not discuss it in his text.’’ Six years later, Ginzburg
label: Paragraph

text: would level a harsh critique at Tatlin in the pages of Sovremennaia arkhitektura
label: Paragraph

text: (Contemporary Architecture). Here, in 1928, Ginzburg described Tatlin’s “engi-
label: Paragraph

text: neering compositions” as demonstrations that he was fully alienated from both
label: Paragraph

text: social and technical reality.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Despite Ginzburg’s reservations about Tatlin’s relationship to architectural
label: Paragraph

text: constructivism, there was a direct and strong link between Tatlin and Aleksandr
label: Paragraph

text: Vesnin. Perhaps more than anyone else, Vesnin was responsible for bringing
label: Paragraph

text: the principles of constructivism to architecture. He was present during the crucial
label: Paragraph

text: debates of 1921 at Moscow’s Institute of Artistic Culture where constructivism was
label: Paragraph

text: first defined, and he worked very closely with Liubov’ Popova on a number of pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects in the early 1920s. Vesnin also claimed to have worked with Tatlin.
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s influence is evident in a project Vesnin and Popova produced for the
label: Paragraph

text: meeting of the delegates of the Third International in 1921. Vesnin and Popova
label: Caption

text: devised a mass spectacle that was to take place during the event in Moscow. It
label: Paragraph

text: was to be a theatrical contest between the “citadel of Capital” and the Socialist city
label: Paragraph

text: of the future. The socialist city is made up of lattice-like trusses, and the entire scene
label: Paragraph

text: appears to be bound together by high-tension cables. There is certainly a formal
label: Paragraph

text: resemblance to the open-work structure that Tatlin devised for his Monument,
label: Paragraph

text: but the very concept of the event is more significant, for it recalls Tatlin’s interest
label: Paragraph

text: in staging a spectacle on the construction of the Monument in Petrograd.
label: Paragraph

text: Vesnin and Popova’s project resembles a stage design, and it was on the stage
label: Paragraph

text: that constructivist architecture found its first realizations. Vesnin’s set for Alek-
label: Paragraph

text: sandr Tairov’s production of G. K. Chesterton’s The Man who was Thursday, which
label: Paragraph

text: ran in the 1922-23 season at the Kammernyi Theater in Moscow, was a major
label: Paragraph

text: achievement. The overall conception develops the openwork forms employed
label: Paragraph

text: in his project with Popova. He also made use of curved ramps, and the set incor-
label: Paragraph

text: porated moving platforms and crane-like arms. Lissitzky recognized the novelty of
label: Paragraph

text: Vesnin’s work. In his lecture “On New Russian Art” of 1922, he noted that the
label: Paragraph

text: set allows one to “trace how the principles of the Tatlin tower have been applied
label: Paragraph

text: to the theater.”*’ Lissitzky’s remark is especially significant, for it is only a short
label: Paragraph

text: move from Vesnin’s stage set to the project for the Palace of Labor (1923) that
label: Paragraph

text: he completed with his brothers — the project that represents the first mature state-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of architectural constructivism. Their Palace of Labor emphasizes the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing’s reinforced concrete frame through the rhythmic articulation of austere
label: Paragraph

text: structural members — a quality that links it to Tatlin’s interest in the culture of
label: Paragraph

text: materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Konstantin Melnikov translated Tatlin’s dynamism into concrete architectural
label: Paragraph

text: projects. His entry to the competition of 1924 for the Moscow headquarters of
label: Paragraph

text: the newspaper Leningradskaia Pravda made dynamism a basic operating principle.
label: Paragraph

text: His building’s four upper floors were to be anchored to a central, cylindrical core,
label: Paragraph

text: which would act as the pivot around which each floor could rotate freely. The
label: Paragraph

text: movement of the floors would not only alter the building in plan; it would also
label: Paragraph

text: lend the building a constantly changing silhouette. Melnikov’s project represents
label: Paragraph

text: a reinterpretation and extroversion of the internal, rotating forms of Tatlin’s tower.
label: Paragraph

text: The dynamism of Tatlin’s tower would also find its detractors; Lissitzky would
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately be among them. While he noted the innovative qualities of Tatlin’s
label: Paragraph

text: work in his lecture on Russian art of 1922, Lissitzky also wrote that “this group
label: Paragraph

text: reached a kind of material-fetishism and forgot the necessity of creating a new plan.
label: Paragraph

text: At times this reminds one of building a concrete railway-station from a Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: design.”** In place of this alleged material fetishism and overt dynamism, Lissitzky
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the importance of what he called spatial equilibrium. To establish this
label: Paragraph

text: condition was one of the fundamental aims of his Wolkenbiigel project (1923-25).
label: Paragraph

text: Here vertical pillars counteract horizontal floors, producing an asymmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: balance. In contrast to the revolving shapes of Tatlin’s tower, Lissitzky ensured that
label: Paragraph

text: his series of skyscrapers for Moscow would become stable points of orientation
label: Paragraph

text: within the city’s expanding urban scale.
label: Paragraph

text: A fourth vector of Tatlin’s architectural legacy concerns electromagnetic waves.
label: Paragraph

text: A radio station, telegraph cabins, telephone centers, and great projectors that could
label: Paragraph

text: display movies and messages on the clouds were all integral parts of Tatlin’s
label: Paragraph

text: Monument. As Punin wrote, “radio, screen, and cables are elements of the Mon-
label: Paragraph

text: ument, and they can also be elements of form.”?” Tatlin’s interest in these media
label: Paragraph

text: technologies had a strong spatial dimension: the radio station was to be equipped
label: Paragraph

text: with an antenna capable of reaching the entire world, thus suggesting that he con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceived the scope of the Monument on a global scale.
label: Paragraph

text: In a series of understudied projects, Ivan Leonidov explored the relationship
label: Paragraph

text: between architecture and broadcast media that Tatlin outlined. This is evident
label: Paragraph

text: in Leonidov’s project for a monument to Christopher Columbus (1929), which
label: Paragraph

text: was to be located in Santiago, Chile. The aim of Leonidov’s Monument was the
label: Paragraph

text: “condensation of all the achievements of world progress.”*° The center of the Mon-
label: Paragraph

text: ument was a “radio-port” composed of two 300 m-tall pylons. He imagined that on
label: Paragraph

text: the open squares of cities around the world, screens would be installed that would
label: Paragraph

text: receive “radio-images” of the story of Christopher Columbus and other accounts of
label: Paragraph

text: social and technological progress. In Leonidov’s remarkable Monument we find a
label: Paragraph

text: direct response to the most expansive, if least visible, ambitions of Tatlin’s Mon-
label: Paragraph

text: ument to the Third International.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 1930s, the reception of Tatlin’s Monument in the Soviet Union
label: Paragraph

text: adopted a new character. In his book, Puti arkhitekturnoi mysli, 1917-1932 (Paths
label: Paragraph

text: of Architectural Thought, 1917-1932), Roman Khiger described Tatlin’s project
label: Paragraph

text: as a “typical product of the chaotic aesthetic reflexes of revolution” and noted that
label: Paragraph

text: it represented a “primitive desire to embody the dynamism of revolution” in archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural form.*” Tatlin’s Monument received little attention from Soviet critics
label: Paragraph

text: during the following decades. In his book, Vyvoj sovetské architektury (The Devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opment of Soviet Architecture) of 1936, the Czech critic Karel Teige drew a parallel
label: Paragraph

text: between Tatlin’s tower and the project for the Palace of the Soviets by Boris lofan,
label: Paragraph

text: Vladimir Shchuko, and Vladimir Gel’freikh. While noting that Tatlin’s tower was
label: Paragraph

text: an early attempt to apply constructivist principles, Teige nevertheless dismissed the
label: Paragraph

text: project as “purely formalist, metaphysical, and idealistic” because it had allegedly
label: Paragraph

text: been conceived as a symbol, not designed according to functional methods.** After
label: Paragraph

text: World War II, in the final years of Stalin’s reign, Mikhail Tsapenko described
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s tower as an “absurd formalist exercise” in a doctrinaire book on the “realist
label: Paragraph

text: foundations” of Soviet architecture.”
label: Paragraph

text: Only in the 1960s would architects and historians revive serious interest in
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s Monument and its conceptual underpinning.” The first review of Tatlin’s
label: Paragraph

text: work to appear in the Soviet Union following his death in 1953, was published in
label: Paragraph

text: Dekorativnoe iskusstvo in 1966, on what would have been the artist’s 80th birthday.”
label: Paragraph

text: In Western Europe Tatlin’s legacy was celebrated slightly earlier. Two important
label: Paragraph

text: publications that addressed Tatin’s Monument appeared in 1962: Camilla Gray’s
label: Paragraph

text: The Great Experiment: Russian Art, 1863-1922 and an extraordinary issue of Casabella
label: Title

text: Continuita devoted to the USSR. Vittorio De Feo’s landmark URSS architettura,
label: Caption

text: 1917-1936 followed in 1963; Anatole Kopp discussed Tatlin’s Monument at length
label: Paragraph

text: in Ville et révolution of 1967; and Troels Andersen organized the first major retro-
label: Paragraph

text: spective of Tatlin’s work at the Moderna Museet in Stockholm in 1968.7 These
label: Caption

text: publications and events marked the beginning of several decades of detailed schol-
label: Paragraph

text: arly study of Tatlin’s contribution to art and architecture. The editorial that Ernesto
label: Paragraph

text: Rogers contributed to the Soviet issue of Casabella Continuita conveyed the impetus
label: Paragraph

text: behind the revival of interest in Tatlin’s work since the 1960s. Rogers counted
label: Paragraph

text: Tatlin’s Monument to the Third International among the documents of construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tivism that “aside from their historical interest, arouse great excitement in art
label: Paragraph

text: circles,’ and concluded that “there is still something to be learned from those
label: Paragraph

text: projects.”

text: Water intrinsically belongs to glass architecture because of its capacity to reflect;
