label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe’s entry for the FriedrichstraBe Skyscraper Competition
label: Title

text: of 1921, a project he named the “Wabe” (Honeycomb) construction, not only
label: Paragraph

text: epitomized the polemics then current about the renovation of Berlin as a
label: Paragraph

text: modern metropolis, but also represented a radical shift in the architect’s own
label: Paragraph

text: viewpoint — his views of modern life, modern construction, and modern mate-
label: Paragraph

text: rials, particularly glass.
label: Paragraph

text: The year before the competition the 34-year-old architect, then called Ludwig
label: Paragraph

text: Mies, decided to distance himself from his family. He moved to his atelier at
label: Paragraph

text: Am Karlsbad 24, where he would fully commit himself to his search for the truth
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture. Having practiced for more than a decade in the offices of two well-
label: Paragraph

text: known Berlin architects, Bruno Paul and Peter Behrens, Mies was ready to reorient
label: Paragraph

text: his thinking and practice. Although the residences he had built on his own at the
label: Paragraph

text: outskirts of the city allowed him to implement and experiment with what he had
label: Paragraph

text: learned, he had convinced himself that the time had come to discover the real pos-
label: Paragraph

text: sibilities for architecture embedded in the period’s specific — and specifically
label: Paragraph

text: modern — conditions. The glass skyscraper project, which seems to have received
label: Paragraph

text: its impetus from his observations on contemporary technology, vividly expressed
label: Paragraph

text: the architecture he sought. And the project heralded new beginnings in another
label: Paragraph

text: sense: by combining his mother’s and father’s names, he gave himself a new name:
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe.
label: Paragraph

text: In the monograph accompanying the Mies van der Rohe exhibition at the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Modern Art in 1947, Philip Johnson described the Friedrichstrabe
label: Paragraph

text: Skyscraper project as the point of departure for the architect’s “visionary /experimen-
label: Paragraph

text: tal” projects; that is, designs in which he explored the “genuine” elements of building
label: Paragraph

text: art.” Through careful observation of Mies’ works, however, it is possible to see that
label: Paragraph

text: the skyscraper project extended earlier developments. If there were heralds of the
label: Paragraph

text: principles and elements that would give shape to his later buildings, including
label: Paragraph

text: the Barcelona Pavilion (1929-30) and the Tugendhat House (1928-30), they
label: Paragraph

text: were his early country villas and houses. Nevertheless, the glass skyscraper did
label: Paragraph

text: signal a transition in the history of Mies’ formal expression. In the 1920s, making
label: Paragraph

text: use of modern building techniques and materials, Mies successfully paraphrased
label: Paragraph

text: what he had expressed in his earlier works but with more mature, “artless”
label: Paragraph

text: words.’
label: Paragraph

text: The questions this chapter* will address are: how did modern materials, pattic-
label: Paragraph

text: ularly glass, contribute to Mies’ search for expressive silence; and, more directly,
label: Paragraph

text: how did glass act on his architectural imagination and alter his understanding and
label: Paragraph

text: practice of architectural expression? While the competition entry will be my point
label: Paragraph

text: of focus, I will also consider the work of a few of his contemporaries, in order to
label: Paragraph

text: indicate what is unique and significant about this design.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’ revolutionary proposal for the FriedrichstraBbe Skyscraper failed to receive
label: Paragraph

text: an award. Even worse, it was even excluded from the pamphlet of the competition
label: Paragraph

text: results. The evaluation was harsh: the judges thought it was a fantasy that could
label: Paragraph

text: never be built. Even so, Mies continued working on his drawings and developed a
label: Paragraph

text: second glass skyscraper project, Hochhaus (High Rise), intended to give visual man-
label: Paragraph

text: ifestation to ideas he developed in a text on glazed high-rise buildings. That short
label: Paragraph

text: article, which broke his reticence in architectural media, appeared in the fourth and
label: Paragraph

text: last issue of Friihlicht, the journal edited by Bruno Taut.”
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’ preference for Taut’s journal was hardly coincidental. After designing the
label: Paragraph

text: Glass Pavilion for the Werkbund Exhibition at Cologne (1914), in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: the poet Paul Scheerbart, Taut took on the mission of encouraging architects to
label: Paragraph

text: make use of glass as often and in as many ways as possible. During the turmoil
label: Paragraph

text: following the First World War, Taut’s utopian vision appealed to the young gen-
label: Paragraph

text: eration of artists and architects, and brought many of them together in the Arbeits-
label: Paragraph

text: vat fiir Kunst Workers’ Council for Art) and Gléserne Kette (Crystal Chain) circles he
label: Paragraph

text: led. Friihlicht served as the forum of radical thought, where the limits of possible
label: Paragraph

text: reality were questioned. Although Mies did not share the utopian vision of all of the
label: Paragraph

text: journal’s contributors, and never joined the art and architecture circles around
label: Paragraph

text: Taut, he knew very well that Friihlicht was the only professional publication that
label: Paragraph

text: would publicize his glass skyscraper projects.° And the two shared basic ideas: both
label: Paragraph

text: Taut and Mies believed that technology was the formative agent of modern cul-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, and identified glass as the prospective element of modern architecture, with
label: Paragraph

text: which architects had to experiment.
label: Paragraph

text: In the architectural discourse of the second half of the twentieth century and up
label: Paragraph

text: until today, glass architecture has been widely seen in technical terms, obvious in
label: Paragraph

text: its properties, selfevidently useful, and plainly modern. From this vantage point,
label: Paragraph

text: the approaches taken by Taut and Mies may well seem surprising, as if they sought
label: Paragraph

text: not to use but to fetishize an industrial product and the techniques of its use. From
label: Paragraph

text: their vantage point, however, glass was neither an icon of industrialization nor an
label: Paragraph

text: obsession of bourgeois culture. Nor were its properties obvious. Even if it had not
label: Paragraph

text: yet been architectonically mastered, it was a material that could redefine the nature
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural space. As Arthur Korn wrote in Glas im Bau und als Gebrauchsgegen-
label: Paragraph

text: stand (1929): “[glass] can enclose and open up spaces in more than one direction. Its
label: Paragraph

text: peculiar advantage is in the diversity of the impressions it creates.””
label: Paragraph

text: When these two architects are viewed together, Korn seems to have been
label: Paragraph

text: correct, for both Taut and Mies used glass to open interior space in multiple
label: Paragraph

text: directions. Yet, their approaches also differed, at least in Korn’s view. Believing
label: Paragraph

text: that the order of modern architecture and of modern culture more generally
label: Paragraph

text: was based on the rational and objective laws of building art, Korn presented
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’ perspective as the opening page of his book. Taut’s Glashaus, by contrast,
label: Paragraph

text: was ignored. The term objectivity (Sachlichkeit) referred to a norm used to
label: Paragraph

text: measure the appropriateness of architecture to contemporary life conditions
label: Paragraph

text: and was generally used to invoke “a straightforward attention to needs” miss-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in the world of daily life.* Yet, the range of needs that architecture
label: Paragraph

text: addressed were phenomena open to interpretations that could be poles apart,
label: Paragraph

text: as will be clear in what follows.
label: Paragraph

text: Glass Architecture
label: Title

text: At the dawn of the twentieth century, glass was a material that had not yet been
label: Paragraph

text: architectonically mastered, especially when it was used in sheets of large dimen-
label: Paragraph

text: sions. This lack of mastery did not prevent it from performing splendidly in the
label: Paragraph

text: literature of the time, however. Paul Scheerbart’s sense of the possibilities of
label: Paragraph

text: glass emerged in criticism of its use in the late nineteenth century. He had
label: Paragraph

text: observed that the misuse of industrial materials had mechanized the interiors
label: Paragraph

text: both of buildings and of the individuals who inhabited them.® In reaction, he
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to redefine their use, to imagine expressions and meanings that were
label: Paragraph

text: radically alternative. Scheerbart’s most significant and typical literary tactic was
label: Paragraph

text: “fictional estrangement.”'° Through a series of metaphorical utterances, he cre-
label: Paragraph

text: ated semantic ambiguities that destabilized postulations that had mostly been
label: Paragraph

text: taken for granted by the general population. The aim was not destabilization
label: Paragraph

text: for its own sake, but to stimulate his readers’ imaginations. One of the most
label: Paragraph

text: effective ways by which Scheerbart attempted to loosen the link between words
label: Paragraph

text: and world was with the use of glass. For the poet, glass, specifically colored glass,
label: Paragraph

text: could serve as a metaphoric tool to deform what one perceived. His aim was to
label: Paragraph

text: free the mind from habitual images in memory. To this end glass became an
label: Paragraph

text: instrument of imaginative freedom, capable of engendering possible, if unknown
label: Paragraph

text: environments.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1914, after learning about Taut’s engagement in the Glass House project,
label: Paragraph

text: and in the hope of extending the imaginative abilities of architects, Scheerbart
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to translate his ideas into architecture. The result was his widely
label: Paragraph

text: known manifesto, Glasarchitektur.'! In the first and strongest chapter of the
label: Paragraph

text: text he invited architects to break open the closed character of the rooms in
label: Paragraph

text: which modern men had been constrained to live. He intentionally juxtaposed
label: Paragraph

text: architecture with glass to separate buildings from their ordinary, pragmatic
label: Paragraph

text: definition.
label: Paragraph

text: Taut’s Glashaus was designed with a similar intent, exploiting glass’s fictional and
label: Paragraph

text: estranging potential. In Taut’s view, what distinguished glass from other materials
label: Paragraph

text: was its fictive character. Although it “emanated” from the earth, it could act as if it
label: Paragraph

text: were intangible. By virtue of its changeable nature, submissive one might say to
label: Paragraph

text: external or ambient influences, it could mimic “air, water, fire,” and overcome
label: Paragraph

text: the heaviness of the earth.'* This meant that glass could help the architect elevate
label: Paragraph

text: the materials of construction toward the immaterial. Furthermore, glass was not
label: Paragraph

text: only to chronicle substantial transformations of the earth surface, but also to carry
label: Paragraph

text: “subtle” values and feelings that would stimulate the human psyche. Through col-
label: Paragraph

text: orful luminous surfaces in constant flux, Taut created perceptual ambiguity, which
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged the impression of an architecture without earthly limitations, agitating
label: Paragraph

text: the visitors’ sense of horizon. After visitors entered the glass hall their contact with
label: Paragraph

text: mundane reality was suspended.
label: Paragraph

text: From a distance the Glashaus looked like a gemstone, one that crystalized sub-
label: Paragraph

text: surface potentials. Coming closer, one would notice a substantial transformation
label: Paragraph

text: from the bottom upward. Emerging from a sculpted, organically shaped concrete
label: Paragraph

text: base, the building ended in the crystalline geometry of the polyhedral cupola,
label: Paragraph

text: which was composed of rhomboids.
label: Paragraph

text: The art critic Adolf Behne, who hoped that the renewal of arts would generate
label: Paragraph

text: a spiritual revolution and change the modern individual, appreciated the Glashaus
label: Paragraph

text: for having given shape to nothing other than its “inner-artistic” purpose.’ Taut’s
label: Paragraph

text: building was a purpose-free — zweckfrei — work that freed technology from its
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic concerns. Taut had accomplished this by returning to “the primal ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments of building.” The wall and the opening exposed the “reality of arts.” The
label: Paragraph

text: primal elements were enlivened through “pure” artistic means of color, line, and
label: Paragraph

text: light. Leaving aside all derivative elements, Taut invented his own modern orna-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, which was stripped of all excess and was purely expressive. In Behne’s
label: Paragraph

text: view, Taut subdued construction techniques to artistic expression and converted
label: Paragraph

text: the art of building (Baukunst) into a primitive, cosmic ur-force, capable of trans-
label: Paragraph

text: forming the world. For Behne, the Glashaus stood as a prototype that allowed him
label: Paragraph

text: to reconcile artistic creativity with matter-of-factness and construe the principle of
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit as a synthesis of reason and vision — sachliche Kunst. It provided the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete model of a new kind of architecture closer to crystalline, abstract,
label: Paragraph

text: non-historical forms, distinct from what he judged to be the pseudo-symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of technology, such as Peter Behrens’ well-known AEG Turbine Fac-
label: Paragraph

text: Reflections
label: Title

text: The rejection Mies received in his entry in the 1919 Ausstellung fiir unbekannte Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tekten (Exhibition of Unknown Architects) provoked him to reconsider his design
label: Paragraph

text: strategies."* He became increasingly engaged in theoretical discussions, question-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the fundamentals of artistic form-giving (Gestaltung), with the hope of more
label: Paragraph

text: fully understanding what constituted architecture as a work of art. The same year,
label: Paragraph

text: after the exhibition closed its doors and Taut’s Alpine Architecture was already in the
label: Paragraph

text: hands of its readers,”* Ludwig Hilberseimer warned his colleagues against the sort
label: Paragraph

text: of misapplications of Scheerbart’s glass architecture that had already become com-
label: Paragraph

text: mon. According to Hilberseimer, Taut and his circle misread Scheerbart by closing
label: Paragraph

text: their eyes to existing conditions. They sacrificed the essential “constructive prem-
label: Paragraph

text: ises” of architecture for the sake of their fantasies.'* Taut’s over-exaggerated spec-
label: Paragraph

text: ulations about achieving a faultless world and society by simply adorning the Alps
label: Paragraph

text: with crystalline glass buildings denoted an escapist attitude that gave in to the dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ficulty of offering concrete alternatives to the present conditions. Years later, Taut
label: Paragraph

text: admitted with regret that the freedom of work on paper led him to easily overlook
label: Paragraph

text: the given reality of the material world in which he lived, and ended in an unachiev-
label: Paragraph

text: able abstraction.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Hilberseimer’s criticism was an open call for a glass architecture based on amore
label: Paragraph

text: realist and practical understanding of Sachlichkeit. Mies would seem to have
label: Paragraph

text: responded to this call in the Friedrichstrake competition. For him, the demand
label: Paragraph

text: for Sachlichkeit meant the end of art in architecture. Nevertheless, pure expression
label: Paragraph

text: was a goal common to both Mies and Taut. To attain an elementary but more real-
label: Paragraph

text: ist language, Mies focused on building technology. Explicitly industrial materials
label: Paragraph

text: and construction techniques came before purely artistic means, as a precondition
label: Paragraph

text: for architectural design. The basic concern was to conceive the primitive and eter-
label: Paragraph

text: nal urform immanent in modern technology, even if it had been intentionally
label: Paragraph

text: ignored or masked by the previous generation. In the first paragraph of his man-
label: Paragraph

text: ifesto in Friihlicht, Mies clarified that “the bold constructive thoughts” that give
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers their strong impression were only visible on buildings “under construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion.””* Traditional walls concealing steel skeletons completely killed this impres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion. Technology was important, but no more so than the impression it was
label: Paragraph

text: capable of creating.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies had no doubt that the non-load-bearing glass walls would best represent the
label: Paragraph

text: constructive principle he saw as the possibility and sign of the times. Even so, he did
label: Paragraph

text: not forget that glass itself required a unique formal approach, pertinent to its par-
label: Paragraph

text: ticular characteristics. Otherwise, large glass panes hung on steel frames would kill
label: Paragraph

text: the facade. “To avoid the danger of lifelessness,” Mies imagined a stereometric
label: Paragraph

text: mass composed of three polygonal towers. None of the “facade fronts” of the
label: Paragraph

text: polygonal structure was parallel to the outlines of its triangular site. He pro-
label: Paragraph

text: posed angled glazed facades not for the effect of light and shadow but for “a
label: Paragraph

text: rich interplay of light reflections.”’? Because he said little more, the precise dis-
label: Paragraph

text: tinction between his sense of “interplay” and Taut’s dematerialization remains
label: Paragraph

text: unclear — yet they may have been more like one another than either of their
label: Paragraph

text: designers cared to admit.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the large-format image rendered in charcoal initially brings to mind
label: Paragraph

text: the technique of chiaroscuro, it derived from a series of photomontages.”° Mies
label: Paragraph

text: consciously drew on the technique of montage to determine how his glass
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper would look in its urban context. At the outset, he inserted a rough out-
label: Paragraph

text: line of his building into the enlarged eye-level photograph looking north along the
label: Paragraph

text: Friedrichstrafe. Then, he cleaned the scene from all distractions of metropolitan life
label: Paragraph

text: by darkening the surroundings. Finally, to expose the skyscraper, he cropped the
label: Paragraph

text: frame and meticulously articulated the reflections on its glazed surface. Later in his
label: Paragraph

text: career, he frequently used the same technique to control and manipulate the set-
label: Paragraph

text: tings and optic qualities of his buildings in ways that denied their palpable reality.”
label: Paragraph

text: In the FriedrichstraBe project, however, his intention was not to create a photo-
label: Paragraph

text: realistic simulation. By superimposing, dissolving, and cropping he abstracted
label: Paragraph

text: the existing conditions and located his building on the FriedrichstraBe that he ima-
label: Paragraph

text: gined. He made use of these techniques, as the filmmaker Lev Kuleshov has sug-
label: Paragraph

text: gested, “to create a new earthly terrain that did not exist anywhere.””” Obviously,
label: Paragraph

text: in the drawing the skyscraper stands out as the most active figure while the city is
label: Paragraph

text: largely suppressed into a mute background. It is only the building — not the urban
label: Paragraph

text: context — that communicates an architectural intention. Its glazed surfaces both
label: Paragraph

text: reflect the sunlight and pick up on the shadows of surrounding buildings, together
label: Paragraph

text: with those of the interior. Though dark shadows on the surface give clues about
label: Paragraph

text: vertical volumetric recesses and the slabs behind the glass, the luminous reflections
label: Paragraph

text: that Mies highlighted obscure any real sense of what exists beneath the surface
label: Paragraph

text: within the interiors.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to the edges that sharply define the skyscraper’s geometry, the
label: Paragraph

text: depth of the glazed surface remains elusive. This perceptual instability imbues
label: Paragraph

text: the glass and the building with a sense of mystery. As his term “reflection” implies,
label: Paragraph

text: Mies used glass to liquefy the surface. He exploited the technique of chiaroscuro
label: Paragraph

text: to emphasize its receptive character, as if it were similar to water. The liquid sur-
label: Paragraph

text: face was offered as a cure for modern eyes, tired of looking at congested opaque
label: Paragraph

text: walls. It was to give depth to pure vision by approaching the limits of sensual
label: Paragraph

text: experience.
label: Paragraph

text: The polygonal shape of Mies’ 20-floor glass building made critics like Carl
label: Paragraph

text: Gottfried think ofa “tower-like gothic force,” and compare it with Hans Scharoun’s
label: Paragraph

text: crystalline towers in watercolor.” The idea that the glass skyscraper aimed to
label: Paragraph

text: embody the crown of the city (Stadtkrone) that Taut advocated has merit, yet only
label: Paragraph

text: with some qualifications, for Mies was interested neither in colored light nor in any
label: Paragraph

text: formal distortions that challenged the perspective. Glass, for Mies, was cold and
label: Paragraph

text: colorless. Nevertheless, the glazed facades of the skyscraper, like the walls of
label: Paragraph

text: the Glashaus, presented themselves as if in flux. What set the facades in motion,
label: Paragraph

text: however, was not the colored prismatic structure of glass that transformed sunlight
label: Paragraph

text: into a shadow-less colored light, but the reflective patina that liquefied the surface.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’ scrutiny of reflective, watery surfaces reached its peak in his Barcelona Pavil-
label: Paragraph

text: ion, which marked the end of the period of experimentation that had started with
label: Paragraph

text: the FriedrichstraBe project.
label: Paragraph

text: Similar to the glazed surfaces of the skyscraper, the reflective walls in the
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona Pavilion rendered prospects unclear in both profile and position. Along
label: Paragraph

text: with the labyrinthine layout of the building, polished glass and marble surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: transmuted the rational structure into a perceptually ambiguous space. In Glass
label: Paragraph

text: in Architecture and Decoration (1936), Raymond McGrath maintained that Mies
label: Paragraph

text: polished glass was a “modern counterpart, on a larger scale, to the Claude Lorraine
label: Paragraph

text: glasses,” in order to create a stereoscopic effect.”* Similar to the eighteenth-century
label: Paragraph

text: glasses that transformed landscapes into picturesque images, the optics of the
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion visually dislocated surfaces and figures. Superimposed reflections on
label: Paragraph

text: the marble and glass relocated elements in a fictive landscape. Robin Evans
label: Caption

text: described his experience in the reconstructed pavilion as a “dreamy disorienta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion.””* By virtue of their anamorphic quality, reflective surfaces simultaneously
label: Paragraph

text: created an aesthetic distance between the pavilion and its observers and intensified
label: Paragraph

text: the sense of the wider horizon by visually extending the platforms and walls that
label: Paragraph

text: ostensibly defined the building. The polished, reflective surface was a dream device
label: Paragraph

text: that opened Mies’ building to imagination. But, unlike the hermetic microcosm
label: Paragraph

text: of Taut, the self-discovery it promoted was not only from within but also in relation
label: Paragraph

text: to the milieu.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Material Cause
label: Title

text: As a substance on the threshold between materiality and immateriality, glass
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to signify for both Taut and Mies a repository of profound expressions —
label: Paragraph

text: even if it was also a material of building construction. Under Scheerbart’s influence,
label: Paragraph

text: both saw glass as a contemplative substance, one that would give rise to psychic aspira-
label: Paragraph

text: tions by engaging the imagination. Read through the philosopher Gaston Bachelard’s
label: Paragraph

text: outlook, they were after a poetry of materials that science had destroyed and, corre-
label: Paragraph

text: spondingly, engineers could not read. The imaginary aura of glass made it exceptional
label: Paragraph

text: among other materials and keptit outside the cognitive order. The potential of glass to
label: Paragraph

text: actin the subjunctive mode of “as if” and to suspend material reality invited both archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects to use it as a metaphor that opened the doors of the poetic reality. This common
label: Paragraph

text: attribute of the Glashaus and the Barcelona Pavilion makes it possible to set up affi-
label: Paragraph

text: nities between these two buildings and Symbolist, expressionist, Dadaist, surrealist,
label: Paragraph

text: or even existentialist approaches.
label: Paragraph

text: For both Mies and Taut, buildings ought to signify more than a simple technical
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon (to which they were and still are typically reduced). Their search for
label: Paragraph

text: pure expression did not intend to purify space of content and context, nor of mean-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. They were interested in an iconoclasm that would initiate a search for the
label: Paragraph

text: images hidden behind or within visible phenomena. To this end they replaced tra-
label: Paragraph

text: ditional stone with glass. But again, they explored different ways of engaging the
label: Paragraph

text: world. Taut was interested in the vertical axis. He employed glass to elevate his
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, as if they embodied an inexhaustible force. His aim was to cause a psychic
label: Paragraph

text: excitement of airiness that would evoke the dreams of flight or fall. Mies, on the
label: Paragraph

text: other hand, sought the liquidity of glass, allowing or imagining a later spread of
label: Paragraph

text: effects, reflections, or mirrorings. He used glass to give depth to walls — even ifit was
label: Paragraph

text: an exceedingly shallow depth — and to make them, thereby, unfathomable, like a
label: Paragraph

text: mystery. The eyes that dived into Mies’ walls were to look for pale and vague images
label: Paragraph

text: of the selfon a far horizon. Mies’ portrait as the rational architect has been built upon
label: Paragraph

text: his apparent apathy toward emotional content. But, using glass he disclosed the
label: Paragraph

text: material cause to be one that arose from feelings. Hidden behind the veil of reason,
label: Paragraph

text: glass was the perfect vehicle that allowed Mies, as Evans has explained, to force sen-
label: Paragraph

text: sation into the foreground and to push consciousness into apperception.””
label: Paragraph

text: To conclude, it is worth noting that Scheerbart’s aim in writing Glasarchitektur
label: Paragraph

text: was to create a Traumkunst, not a Raumkunst. He believed that in the twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century neither reason nor faith would break the eternal silence of infinite space,
label: Paragraph

text: only dream. With a similarly optimist view, Bachelard suggested a return to the
label: Paragraph

text: cosmology of dreams, covert in the primitive zone of “material reveries that pre-
label: Paragraph

text: cede contemplation.””* This seems to recall an observation of ancient Empedocles:
label: Paragraph

text: “Tt is through the earth that is in us that we know the earth, water through water,
label: Paragraph

text: through our air the air divine, and through our fire devouring fire.”??
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: At times, the image of a building attains a status above and beyond the physical
label: Paragraph

text: artifact represented, wherein the depiction of what could have been is given equa
label: Paragraph

text: status to or privileged over what was built. Ludwig Mies van der Rohe’s oeuvre is
label: Paragraph

text: chockablock with such instances — both intentional and not. The canonical Berliner
label: Paragraph

text: Bild-Bericht photographs of his German Pavilion for the Barcelona Internationa
label: Caption

text: Exposition (1928-29) are the most celebrated of these, while the drawings of his
label: Paragraph

text: “Project for a Brick Country House” are arguably the most influential of his early
label: Paragraph

text: Weimar experiments (1921-25).' Yet, typical of the uncertainty that surrounds
label: Paragraph

text: much of Mies’ avant-garde work of the 1920s, little is known with certainty o
label: Paragraph

text: the genesis of the brick villa project: not its client, if there was one; not its site,
label: Paragraph

text: if there was one; not even the year in which the drawings were made. Moreover,
label: Paragraph

text: while they have influenced generations of architects, their resonance in Mies’ own
label: Paragraph

text: architectural production is relatively limited, and short-lived.
label: Paragraph

text: Only two drawings attributable to Mies’ Berlin office describe the project: a
label: Paragraph

text: spare plan, largely absent annotations, and a perspective. Neither existed for very
label: Paragraph

text: long; no one seems to know what became of them. It is equally unclear how many
label: Paragraph

text: of those who have written about them since the 1920s have done so from first-hand
label: Paragraph

text: inspection. No one living today has laid eyes on them. Further complicating the
label: Paragraph

text: matter, the perspective (which does not appear to have been drawn by Mies) seems
label: Paragraph

text: to have been generated from a different plan. Once there may have been a pair of
label: Paragraph

text: drawings that aligned better; we will never know. Wolf Tegethoff has carefully
label: Paragraph

text: parsed this lack of internal coherence, one that has troubled far fewer authors than
label: Paragraph

text: it ought.” Yet, even the exacting Tegethoff wanders into the tall grass on more than
label: Paragraph

text: one occasion as he attempts to will these drawings into the coherent form of a proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect with both a site and client.’ In a more recent commentary, Dietrich Neumann
label: Paragraph

text: includes a description of the second floor, down to the number of bedrooms.* As
label: Paragraph

text: there has apparently never been a plan of an upper level, or a section, and as the
label: Paragraph

text: outside depicted in the perspective does not align with the inside delineated in the
label: Paragraph

text: plan, this ought to make one wonder.* Describing an interior, which is immeasur-
label: Paragraph

text: able, based on the relation of a plan to a perspective, which do not agree in ways
label: Paragraph

text: that are clearly measurable, is a dicey proposition. Yet, this is simply one of the
label: Paragraph

text: several “phantasies and unconscious logic” projected onto these relatively mute
label: Paragraph

text: and absent documents.®
label: Paragraph

text: There are, however, a few critical moments in the history of the Berlin drawings
label: Paragraph

text: of the Brick Country House Project that one can point to with varying degrees of
label: Paragraph

text: certainty. It seems more than likely that Mies created the drawings specifically for
label: Paragraph

text: The Great Berlin Art Exhibition of 1924. It is certain that they were hung in the
label: Paragraph

text: show well after the exhibit opened. The timing of the late entry has led to specu-
label: Paragraph

text: lation that Mies made the drawings partly in response to what was already on dis-
label: Paragraph

text: play.” Adding to the historical uncertainty, two additional versions of the plan were
label: Paragraph

text: produced in Mies’ Chicago office in the mid-1960s, ostensibly with his imprimatur,
label: Paragraph

text: and specifically for Werner Blaser’s Mies van der Rohe: The Art of Structure (1965),
label: Paragraph

text: wherein each brick of every wythe is visible.* Blaser’s crisp and clear “reconstruc-
label: Paragraph

text: tions” (1964 and 1965) only confound the matter; although they were created from
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’ photograph of the drawings exhibited in the Berlin exhibition, they differ
label: Paragraph

text: from “the original” in terms of enclosure and construction.”
label: Paragraph

text: That the status of the missing drawings has troubled few who have written
label: Paragraph

text: about them is illustrative of a cultural phenomenon that is commonplace.'” This
label: Paragraph

text: gap between what was and what may have been, however, is a telling characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural discourse on Mies van der Rohe’s oeuvre in particular. At the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Modern Art’s (MoMA) Mies in Berlin exhibition une 21 — September
label: Caption

text: 11, 2001), for example, the large format photographic print of the drawings were
label: Paragraph

text: hung alongside Mies’ original architectural drawings, montages, and photographs
label: Paragraph

text: of his built works — on equal terms, as if they were all originals. The aura of an
label: Paragraph

text: authentic work notwithstanding, there is simply far more to be learned from an
label: Paragraph

text: original drawing than there is from the finest reproduction: the substrate and
label: Paragraph

text: graphic medium, traces of the drawing’s construction, the maker’s pentimenti,
label: Paragraph

text: marginal notes, not to mention the obverse side on which one may find revealing
label: Paragraph

text: graphic and textual notations.'' None of these are available in the case of Mies’
label: Paragraph

text: Brick Country House drawings; that path is closed.
label: Caption

text: The open path is limited to photographic reproductions of varying quality. And
label: Paragraph

text: while we can learn nothing from the original drawings, there is much to be learned
label: Paragraph

text: from the manner in which they have been reproduced. Hans Soeder’s 1924 article
label: Paragraph

text: published in Der Neubau seems to be the first publication of the two brick villa draw-
label: Paragraph

text: ings exhibited at the Great Berlin Art Exhibition.’” The following year Hans Rich-
label: Paragraph

text: ter and Paul Westheim each published the Der Neubau drawings in articles.'? The
label: Paragraph

text: caption in the Westheim article, published in Das Kunstblatt, refers to the project as
label: Paragraph

text: “a house for the architect.”'* The combined effect of Westheim’s caption, an anno-
label: Paragraph

text: tation of “Neubabelsberg” on the plan, and a brief comment by Mies in a contem-
label: Paragraph

text: poraneous letter in which he evinced an interest in a parcel of land, prompted
label: Paragraph

text: Tegethoff to conclude that the drawings were originally made for a client with
label: Paragraph

text: a site in mind, suggesting that only later did Mies decide to develop the project
label: Paragraph

text: for himself.’*
label: Paragraph

text: But the most important publication of Mies’ brick villa may have been in Alfred
label: Paragraph

text: Barr's pioneering Cubism and Abstract Art (1936). Barr, the founding director of
label: Paragraph

text: MoMA in New York, included the Der Neubau plan, oriented vertically, alongside
label: Paragraph

text: a reproduction of Theo van Doesburg’s Rhythms of Russian Dance (1918). Barr asserts:
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe’s plan for a country house...done in 1922 [sic], a year after
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg’s arrival in Berlin, may be compared with Doesburg’s painting Russian
label: Paragraph

text: dance |sic|...of 1918. The resemblance is obvious and by no means superficial.
label: Paragraph

text: The broken, asymmetrical, orthogonal character of the plan was a direct result of
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg’s sojourn in Berlin in 1921 and ’22, at which time he publicized not merely
label: Paragraph

text: the paintings of the Stijl but the work of its architects as well.’®
label: Paragraph

text: Barr concludes: “In the history of art there are few more entertaining sequences
label: Paragraph

text: than the influence by way of Holland of the painting of a Spaniard [Picasso] living in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris upon the plans of a German architect in Berlin — and all within twelve
label: Paragraph

text: years.”’” The pairing of these two figures, Mies and van Doesburg (and connecting
label: Paragraph

text: Mies with Picasso), establishes the legitimacy of Mies as an avant-garde artist of
label: Paragraph

text: international renown far beyond what he was able to achieve, up to that point,
label: Paragraph

text: from his short-lived association with the G Group, his directorship of the Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: during its declining years in Dessau and Berlin, or his selfpromotion.'* More
label: Paragraph

text: importantly, the pairing of these two graphic works, each emerging from funda-
label: Paragraph

text: mentally different programs, relegitimizes for a new generation the old model
label: Paragraph

text: of the spatial, figural, and emotive qualities of two-dimensional artwork as the
label: Paragraph

text: experimental basis for new directions in architectural production: specifically,
label: Paragraph

text: the lawfulness of equating the qualities of the two-dimensional canvas art of ana-
label: Paragraph

text: lytical and synthetic cubism onto the architect’s productive task. Perhaps most
label: Paragraph

text: influential of all, largely through the strategic use of black-and-white photographic
label: Paragraph

text: reproduction with the intimation of a scientific method through comparative anal-
label: Paragraph

text: ysis, Barr directs the reader to apprehend a painting and an architectural plan on
label: Paragraph

text: equal terms; they are different only in degree, not in kind.
label: Paragraph

text: Two years after Barr's MoMA exhibition and publication, Siegfried Giedion
label: Paragraph

text: delivered his Norton Lectures at Harvard, published as Space, Time, and Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (1941), in which he leaned heavily on Barr to bolster his characterization of analyt-
label: Paragraph

text: ical cubism and its relation to architectural production.'” No doubt emboldened by
label: Paragraph

text: Barr’s comparative technique, Giedion constructed several now-famous graphic
label: Paragraph

text: juxtapositions in Space, Time, and Architecture, among them the comparison of
label: Paragraph

text: the Piazza del Popolo in Rome (as seen from the Pincio) to van Doesburg’s Relation
label: Paragraph

text: of Horizontal and Vertical Planes (1920), and of Picasso’s L’Arlésienne (1911) to a pho-
label: Paragraph

text: tograph of a corner of Gropius’ Dessau Bauhaus building (1926).”°
label: Caption

text: By the time Giedion was delivering the bulk of his lectures and preparing his text
label: Paragraph

text: for publication, Mies had immigrated to the United States, relocated his practice to
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, and was installed as the director of the architecture program at the newly
label: Paragraph

text: formed Armour Institute of Technology, soon to be IIT. Nonetheless, Mies’ entire
label: Paragraph

text: career is largely absent from Giedion’s epoch-defining book; the Brick Country
label: Paragraph

text: House Project appears as a fragmented footnote.”’ By the third edition (1954), how-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, no longer able to elide Mies’ growing oeuvre and reputation, Giedion created
label: Paragraph

text: a new section for the book, “Mies van der Rohe and the Integrity of Form,” which
label: Paragraph

text: included several richly illustrated pages devoted to the brick and concrete villa pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects; these he valorized as “of inestimable importance for the development of mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern architecture.” For the Giedion of the third edition, these projects are not
label: Paragraph

text: grounded in the analytic cubism of L’Arlésienne, but rather in the synthetic cubism
label: Paragraph

text: of postwar Europe: “cubism’s happiest [period].””” Advancing the book’s subtitle,
label: Paragraph

text: “The Growth of a New Tradition,” Giedion posits: “Cubism originated among
label: Paragraph

text: artists belonging to the oldest cultures of the western world.”” Listing the key
label: Paragraph

text: figures — Le Corbusier and Ozenfant, Malewitsch [Malevich], Moholy-Nagy,
label: Caption

text: Mondrian, and van Doesburg — Giedion asserts: “More and more clearly it appears
label: Paragraph

text: that this new conception of space was nourished by the elements of bygone per-
label: Paragraph

text: iods.”**
label: Paragraph

text: these architects and artists were exploring ways to make cubism, and its several
label: Paragraph

text: derivations, operational. “The analytical spirit of Theo van Doesburg had enabled
label: Paragraph

text: Mies] to show by means of his transparent architectural drawings that the concep-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the house as a self-contained cube had lost its meaning. In [the concrete and
label: Paragraph

text: brick country villa] studies, Mies van der Rohe gives this conception a clear and
label: Paragraph

text: concentrated artistic expression.””?
label: Paragraph

text: projects are perhaps the clearest demonstrations of the avant-garde operationa-
label: Paragraph

text: ized, albeit unrealized.
label: Paragraph

text: Another overlooked yet potent aspect of Barr’s reproduction of the Der Neubau
label: Paragraph

text: plan in Cubism and Abstract Art relates back to its cardinal orientation. By rotating
label: Paragraph

text: the plan 90°, Barr not only underscores the visual correspondence between Mies’
label: Paragraph

text: Having established its place in an unbroken lineage, Giedion explains how
label: Paragraph

text: For Giedion, Mies’ experimental country house
label: Caption

text: plan and the van Doesburg painting, but no less importantly, by redacting the per-
label: Paragraph

text: spective, he frees the plan from the literalness of a projected architectural form.
label: Paragraph

text: What once signified the architect’s intension to extend the horizontal plane of
label: Paragraph

text: the dwelling out beyond the normative boundaries of an intimated interior to
label: Paragraph

text: an as yet undefined exterior world, is reduced to a graphic diagram of dark and
label: Paragraph

text: light marks, absent scale or any suggestion of dwelling. Abstraction is, after all,
label: Paragraph

text: Barr’s main concern. The architectural plan of neo-plastic origin, reoriented much
label: Paragraph

text: like Marcel Duchamp’s “Fountain,” or Meret Opperheim’s “Fur Lined Tea Cup,” is
label: Paragraph

text: de-familiarized and reinvented into a highly plastic icon, readily reproduced in any
label: Paragraph

text: number of contexts, ready to accrete new meanings and associations.
label: Paragraph

text: Barr’s rhetorical and graphic technique immediately resonated with a wide
label: Paragraph

text: range of artists and designers, including a small but influential core of young land-
label: Paragraph

text: scape architects. The year Giedion delivered his Norton Lectures, James C. Rose re-
label: Paragraph

text: published the van Doesburg painting alongside the Der Neubau plan (again rotated
label: Paragraph

text: 90°) in his groundbreaking article, “Freedom in the Garden,””° only this time it was
label: Paragraph

text: the van Doesburg painting that was laid on its side, to render a more “landscape”
label: Paragraph

text: orientation, while the Der Neubau plan was reproduced according to its original
label: Paragraph

text: datum, albeit with the perspective once again deleted. Rose made no reference
label: Paragraph

text: to the plan in his text, however, citing instead Brancusi’s sculpture as the model
label: Paragraph

text: for his newly found freedom. Expelled from Harvard the previous year, the
label: Paragraph

text: recently freed Rose argued that to be unfettered by outdated Beaux Arts practices
label: Paragraph

text: (read Harvard's landscape program), contemporary landscape architecture must be
label: Paragraph

text: reconceived as “outdoor sculpture, not to be looked at as an object, but designed to
label: Paragraph

text: surround us in a pleasant sense of space relations.””” Rose was not unique, but he
label: Paragraph

text: was one of the first to build upon the order of things according to Barr; most of the
label: Paragraph

text: illustrations in the Rose article were lifted from Bart’s book.”* By the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: next half-century, when museums and historians were celebrating Mies van der
label: Paragraph

text: Rohe’s centenary, the number of similarly artful provocations, ingenious associa-
label: Paragraph

text: tions, and erroneous attributions, became legion.
label: Paragraph

text: As we cannot study the Brick Country House directly, and as virtually all we
label: Paragraph

text: know about the project is limited to its p’
label: Paragraph

text: texts, it seems fitting to register the magi

text: Alan Colquhoun, in Modern Architecture (2002), adds a new term (and period) to
label: Paragraph

text: the already crowded Mies lexicon: for Colquhoun, the brick and concrete villas are
label: Paragraph

text: part of Mies’ “Constructivist projects.”*? Colquhoun illustrates his argument with a
label: Paragraph

text: redrawn and diagrammatic Der Neubau plan, which is now part of a tripartite com-
label: Paragraph

text: parison of two other simplified plans of unbuilt projects: Mies’ Concrete Country
label: Paragraph

text: House (1923), and the Lessing House (1923). In a relatively brief passage, Colqu-
label: Paragraph

text: houn conflates a diagram of an unrealized plan with an actual building, while dis-
label: Paragraph

text: closing that in order to equate an architectural experience with a two-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: representation, one must first reduce the architecture to little more than a graphic
label: Paragraph

text: “pattern.”*”
label: Paragraph

text: In The Future of Architecture since 1889 (2012), Jean-Louis Cohen groups the coun-
label: Paragraph

text: try house projects alongside Mies’ other important works of the early 1920s, several
label: Paragraph

text: of which were actually built, under the heading, “Mies van der Rohe’s Theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: Projects.””* Following Barr, Cohen illustrates his text with the Der Neubau plan
label: Paragraph

text: alone, absent the perspective. For Cohen, the import of the brick villa, which
label: Paragraph

text: he considers “more provocative” than its earlier concrete counterpart, is the role
label: Paragraph

text: it played in Mies’ much later design for the German Pavilion in Barcelona: “The
label: Paragraph

text: latent fluidity of his Brick Country House began to be palpable in [the German
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion’s] sequence of open rooms.” Yet, neither the Barcelona Pavilion, nor
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’ brick villa, are known for their “rooms.”
label: Paragraph

text: The varied re-presentations of the Brick Country House story and its drawings
label: Paragraph

text: notwithstanding, these graphic documents — photographically copied, rotated, edi-
label: Paragraph

text: ted, and redrawn — continue to incite the imaginations of scholars and practitioners
label: Paragraph

text: alike, most recently evinced in Shigeru Ban’s realized country house in Sagaponac,
label: Paragraph

text: Long Island (2006), consciously based on Mies’ brick villa drawings. While the role
label: Paragraph

text: the brick villa project played in Mies’ later projects for Barcelona and Brno remains
label: Paragraph

text: unclear, that of its photographic reproduction, variously registered in twentieth-
label: Paragraph

text: century modernism, does not.
label: Paragraph

text: The brick villa project occupied the center of five years of fundamental exper-
label: Paragraph

text: imentation in Mies’ career, beginning in 1921, a watershed year for the architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Substantial changes in his private life — not least of which was his separation from
label: Paragraph

text: his wife Ada and his two children — set the stage for him to reinvent his public
label: Paragraph

text: image and private practice (or at least part of it). An important part of this reinven-
label: Paragraph

text: tion (one of several in a long and varied life) was signified by the addition of “van
label: Paragraph

text: der Rohe,” in 1921, to his family name.’ Well-equipped to live a highly compart-
label: Paragraph

text: mentalized life, in relatively short order he emerged as one of the leaders of the
label: Paragraph

text: European avant-garde, as he maintained a practice producing relatively conven-
label: Paragraph

text: tional domestic designs for his upper-middle class clients. Following his project
label: Paragraph

text: for the Friedrichstrahe competition (1921), he became the director of exhibitions
label: Paragraph

text: for the Novembergruppe. During this relatively narrow window of opportunity,
label: Paragraph

text: in addition to the Friedrichstrabe project and the two country house studies, he
label: Paragraph

text: produced an extraordinary group of projects: the curvaceous Glass Skyscraper Proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect (1922); a Concrete Office Building (1923); the Lessing House (1923); and a Traf-
label: Paragraph

text: fic Tower (1924) — all unbuilt. Among his more adventurous realized works from
label: Paragraph

text: this period were his Monument to the November Revolution (1925-26) and the
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable Wolf House (1925-27), both built in brick but neither of which sur-
label: Paragraph

text: vived the war. Apparently, neither did the Der Neubau drawings of the brick villa.
label: Paragraph

text: The question remains: what do the Der Neubau reproductions of the brick villa
label: Paragraph

text: drawings represent and what can we learn from them? What do they document,
label: Paragraph

text: and what do they depict? For Barry Bergdoll, they document how thoroughly Mies
label: Paragraph

text: had engaged the Wohnreform, or “Residential Reform” movement in Germany.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Simultaneously with the Wohnreform, Hermann Muthesius mounted his campaign
label: Paragraph

text: through the publication of Stilarchitektur und Baukunst (1902), in which he opened a
label: Paragraph

text: window onto a new culture — its arts, crafts, and architecture — one that embraced
label: Paragraph

text: mechanization as the gateway to anew and modern Germany, a new way of living
label: Paragraph

text: inanew century.” In contrast to Ruskin and Morris in England, Muthesius argued
label: Paragraph

text: in Stilarchitektur und Baukunst that machines could be extensions of the hand. They
label: Paragraph

text: were not the end of hand craft; they empowered it. Mechanization posed no threat
label: Paragraph

text: to the cozy tranquility upon which German domestic life was founded. Part of
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius’ brilliance resided in his recognition that this quest must begin, not
label: Paragraph

text: in city plans, office towers, department stores, or cafés, but in the home. As Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Collins outlined in Changing Ideals in Modern Architecture (1750-1950):
label: Paragraph

text: |The] villa...once it was adopted as the favourite type of dwelling for the newly
label: Paragraph

text: enriched merchants and industrialists...became a medium for expressing architectur-
label: Paragraph

text: ally many of the most powerful aspiration of the age.... Not only at the beginning of
label: Paragraph

text: the modern era, but throughout the whole period from 1750-1950, architectural the-
label: Paragraph

text: ory was dominated by factors more strictly appropriate only to domestic architecture;
label: Paragraph

text: and it is by no means coincidental that the most influential architectural pioneers of
label: Paragraph

text: the present century, such as Wright, Gropius, Mies van der Rohe, and Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: originally gave expression to their theories by building either villas for wealthy connois-
label: Paragraph

text: seurs or, after the 1918 war, modest dwellings for artisans and impecunious artists. The
label: Paragraph

text: romantic suburban villa was not so much a minor building-type characteristic of the early
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth century, as a paradigm for the architecture of a whole age.”
label: Paragraph

text: Once mechanized craft is welcomed into the home, other doors soon open. In
label: Paragraph

text: Landhaus und Garten (1907/1910), Muthesius envisioned a new German domestic
label: Paragraph

text: life in which discrete interior life directly extended into corresponding exterior
label: Paragraph

text: spaces: “If the house belongs to architecture, the garden must also.”*” The walls
label: Paragraph

text: of the home did not dictate the limits of domesticity. Rather, they facilitated the
label: Paragraph

text: extension of the private and precisely coded interior living space into the garden.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’ Riehl house ostensibly demonstrated this so well that Muthesius included it
label: Paragraph

text: in the second edition of Landhaus und Garten.*° But, in the Der Neubau plan of the
label: Paragraph

text: brick villa, discrete reciprocity between explicitly coded interiors and geometri-
label: Paragraph

text: cized exterior spaces is effaced. For Peter Behrens, the garden of the Landhaus,
label: Paragraph

text: defined by hedgerows and pergolas that enclosed room-like terraces, “is as an
label: Paragraph

text: essential part of a dwelling as a bathroom is.” This “spiritually purifying union with
label: Paragraph

text: nature ... has been given form by our desires ... that leads to inner harmony.”*" In
label: Paragraph

text: the Der Neubau plan, this “union with nature” is moot. For Behrens and Muthesius,
label: Paragraph

text: the relation of the domestic interior and exterior garden was essential, but inside
label: Paragraph

text: and outside remained different in kind. In the brick villa drawings, the difference is
label: Paragraph

text: one of degree: a carefully crafted ambiguity. The disposition of spaces in the brick
label: Paragraph

text: villa is generic, even vague, absent any semblance of the “coziness” Muthesius
label: Paragraph

text: recognized as central to the German domestic culture. One is left to imagine
label: Paragraph

text: how, and even where, one would dwell. Mies’ response to the need for craft
label: Paragraph

text: and the comfort of home was limited to his choice of materials. The concrete villa
label: Paragraph

text: was cold and empty; the brick villa is empty but warm, or at least warmer. Part of
label: Paragraph

text: the genius of the brick villa is that it was imagined in brick: a retardataire material
label: Paragraph

text: (for the avant-garde) put to work to advance a radically new vision of domesticity.
label: Paragraph

text: The precise relation of interior to exterior is anyone’s guess. The drawings for
label: Paragraph

text: the brick villa represent an inside with no outside. Nonetheless, Bergdoll observes
label: Paragraph

text: of the villa project: “famous for its abolition of roomlike enclosures ... [t]his vocab-
label: Paragraph

text: ulary continues outside the house to create a series of outdoor ‘rooms’ of unprec-
label: Paragraph

text: edented grandeur and openness to the landscape.”*” Later in the same essay: “The
label: Paragraph

text: line of the garden wall in the foreground of the perspective view of the Brick Coun-
label: Caption

text: try House severs any continuity between our space and the representational space
label: Paragraph

text: of the image, even as it draws a boundary between the garden and the broader
label: Paragraph

text: landscape.”** In addition to descriptions of non-existent terraces and gardens,
label: Paragraph

text: and their relation to an unknowable “landscape,” Bergdoll describes how the villa’s
label: Paragraph

text: glazed openings, from the interior, “selectively frame the landscape, not creating a
label: Paragraph

text: seamless relation to the outdoors but pictorializing key views.”** Yet, this Landhaus
label: Paragraph

text: is absent a specific site, cardinal orientation, or any specificity of the ground plane
label: Paragraph

text: with a material surface (interior or exterior), not to mention “key views.” In short,
label: Paragraph

text: this Landhaus has no land. In both plan and perspective, the exterior is effaced.
label: Paragraph

text: The scholarship on Mies amassed during the last two decades reverberates with
label: Paragraph

text: the Giedion-like premise that for Mies to have envisioned a new architecture, it
label: Paragraph

text: must have been a “New Tradition,” — an outgrowth of long-held values from
label: Paragraph

text: the “oldest cultures of the western world,” and “bygone periods.””” There is com-
label: Paragraph

text: fort in the idea of Mies’ work being an extension of a nineteenth-century agenda,
label: Paragraph

text: one that begins with Schinkel, is reconfigured by, among others, Muthesius and
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens, and is subsequently reimagined in Mies’ avant-garde work. Mies offers
label: Paragraph

text: us no comfort, however in his new domestic visions, projected or constructed.
label: Paragraph

text: In stark contrast to Muthesius and Behrens, and Schinkel before them, Mies’ image
label: Paragraph

text: of domesticity does not accommodate the exigencies of dwelling; it offers no pro-
label: Paragraph

text: tection. It does not quarter: it challenges.
label: Paragraph

text: As an inside with no outside, the brick villa is one of many Mies projects and
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that have a dubious relationship with their site, imagined or physical.
label: Paragraph

text: It has been argued of late that the “received view” of Mies’ architecture as largely
label: Paragraph

text: autonomous of its site can be traced to misguided or ideologically driven agitprop
label: Paragraph

text: in which the garden exteriors (or context) of his projects were purposely deleted.*°
label: Paragraph

text: In these recent revisions, such iconic works as the New National Gallery in Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: (1962-68) is argued to be not only highly site-specific, but also unjustly character-
label: Paragraph

text: ized as inhospitable to the display of art.*” That successful exhibitions have been
label: Paragraph

text: mounted in the gallery, however, is hardly a cogent argument that the gallery
label: Paragraph

text: is particularly well suited to display art.
label: Paragraph

text: The same site-specific argument has been made for Mies’ German Pavilion for
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona. In the end, however, it was not the building that appeared to fuse with
label: Paragraph

text: its site, as Wolf Tegethoff argued, but the black-and-white abstract tonal patterns of
label: Paragraph

text: the pavilion’s marble perimeter wall and the coniferous trees beyond, depicted in
label: Paragraph

text: the canonical Berliner Bild-Bericht prints.**
label: Paragraph

text: In most of the scholarship on Mies’ brick villa project, since his centenary, there
label: Paragraph

text: is a clear tendency to site it on a parcel of land in Potsdam, to make it into a “real”
label: Paragraph

text: rather than a hypothetical project. This desire speaks volumes about the traditions
label: Paragraph

text: upon which much of the recent literature on Mies is based. Just as many who inter-
label: Paragraph

text: pret Mies’ later work seem compelled to imbue it with a conceptual richness often
label: Paragraph

text: difficult to find in the built artifact, these same interlocutors seem compelled to
label: Paragraph

text: retroactively transform scant drawings, photographs, and models, through com-
label: Paragraph

text: pound and complex hypotheticals, as if to elevate “merely” provocative specula-
label: Paragraph

text: tions into intended realizations. In part, this desire is fueled by a certain view of
label: Paragraph

text: Mies as master builder — even the Mies of the early 1920s who had built relatively
label: Paragraph

text: little and nothing approaching the exhilarating country house cousins. That Mies’
label: Paragraph

text: most influential works are arguably those produced during his G Group years,
label: Paragraph

text: along with unbuilt projects or realized works that no longer survive, does little
label: Paragraph

text: to deter an argument that remains central to much of the Mies literature.
label: Paragraph

text: What then is to be learned from the remaining photo-fragments of Mies’ brick
label: Paragraph

text: villa, saturated as they are “with meaning, along with their phantasies and uncon-
label: Paragraph

text: scious logic”? Since Alfred Barr redacted, reconfigured, and represented the Brick
label: Paragraph

text: Country House project to an American audience in 1936, it has become part of
label: Paragraph

text: “an anthropological dream ... existing ... above and beyond ... symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: exchange.” A kind of “hyperreality,” to borrow another of Baudrillard’s concepts,
label: Paragraph

text: has long permeated the literature on Mies van der Rohe, particularly since his cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tenary. The Der Neubau drawings for the Brick Country House, saturated as they
label: Caption

text: have been with ever-altering meanings, help us better understand the nature of
label: Paragraph

text: the anthropological dream they represent. Akin to the photographic space depicted
label: Paragraph

text: in the Berliner Bild-Bericht prints of the Barcelona Pavilion, the Der Neubau drawings
label: Paragraph

text: are the most curious kind of simulacrum — one for which there is no original. As
label: Paragraph

text: Shigeru Ban demonstrates in his country house in Sagaponac, there seems no limit
label: Paragraph

text: to where they can take one, or what one can attribute to them. Their continued
label: Paragraph

text: power to incite “phantasies and unconscious logic” resides less in what they docu-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, than in what they depict. The photographs of Mies’ drawings for a Brick Coun-
label: Paragraph

text: try House tell us more about what we want them to be, than what they were to have
label: Paragraph

text: been. They tell us less about the world made than they do about the world we would
label: Paragraph

text: make.
