text: THEO VAN DOESBURG'S OBLIQUE VIEW OF
label: Paragraph

text: MODERN ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: Theo van Doesburg’s Contra-Construction is one of modern architecture’s iconic
label: Paragraph

text: pictorial representations. Embedded in its traces are early modernism’s regard for
label: Paragraph

text: universality and infinite space, and by extension spatial simultaneity and formal
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction. The drawing’s convention itself, parallel projection, is inherently based
label: Paragraph

text: on the concept of infinity. Unlike perspective, pictorial depth is indicated objectively
label: Paragraph

text: via parallel projectors extending infinitely. As well, the Contra-Construction is an
label: Paragraph

text: oblique parallel projection drawing and thus has coexisting two-dimensional and
label: Paragraph

text: three-dimensional spatial aspects. Of course, parallel projection techniques had been
label: Paragraph

text: representational tools with varied ends for engineers, architects, and artists for cen-
label: Paragraph

text: turies, but van Doesburg’s drawing immerses the representation in its projective
label: Paragraph

text: essence. For perhaps the first time, the visual expression of a conceptual proposition
label: Paragraph

text: exactly coincided with this means of architectural representation.
label: Paragraph

text: De Stijl
label: Title

text: In 1917, near the end of the tumultuous First World War, a collective of Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: artists and architects formed the De Stijl, or the Style, group to promote painting,
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture, and architecture as cooperative artistic endeavors with a common aim of
label: Paragraph

text: advancing a new, unified order to be shared by the arts, life, and culture. In varied
label: Paragraph

text: ways, the artistic movement coalesced as a response to cubism and perhaps to
label: Paragraph

text: counter other contemporaneous movements, such as (Italian) Futurism,
label: Paragraph

text: (German) expressionism, and (Russian) suprematism. In 1918, in the newly
label: Paragraph

text: launched journal De Stijl, primary protagonist, editor, and painter Theo van Does-
label: Paragraph

text: burg, along with painters Piet Mondrian and Vilmos Huszar, sculptor Georges
label: Paragraph

text: Vantongerloo, and architects Robert Van’t Hoff and Jan Wils, signed their first
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto, positioning their ideas as particularly reflective of and appropriate to
label: Paragraph

text: a “new consciousness of time,” and its universal values.’ The publication remained
label: Paragraph

text: akey outlet for advancing theoretical deliberations and debates through 1932; how-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, it was through art, be it painting or architecture, that the group probed new,
label: Paragraph

text: plastic modes of expression, or in other words, the non-mimetic embodiment of
label: Paragraph

text: nature’s underlying laws or principles particular to each art form.
label: Paragraph

text: Theory of Neoplasticism in Painting
label: Title

text: Mondrian’s early ideas and work featured largely in De Stijl’s initial neoplastic
label: Paragraph

text: tenets. From about 1918 onward, Mondrian tested not only abstraction in
label: Paragraph

text: painting but also its transcendence by engaging how one could use the universa.
label: Paragraph

text: means of painting itself to convey directly, or plastically, the absolute relations o
label: Paragraph

text: the world.” This approach, and indeed many of De Stijl’s formal principles, ema-
label: Paragraph

text: nated in part from the theories of Mondrian’s friend and philosopher, Mathieu H.
label: Paragraph

text: J. Schoenmaekers.* Schoenmaekers, a theosophist and Neoplatonist, advanced
label: Paragraph

text: that plastic mathematics, or positive mysticism, was a means of contemplation
label: Paragraph

text: on the eternal laws of cosmic creation because it “penetrate[s] nature in such
label: Paragraph

text: a way that the inner construction of reality is revealed to us.”* Schoenmaekers’
label: Paragraph

text: writings ruminated directly on what would become De Stijl’s geometric and
label: Paragraph

text: color principles. Within his theory of contraries, or mystical dialectics, Schoen-
label: Paragraph

text: maekers laid out the fundamental, qualitative differences, yet necessary balance,
label: Paragraph

text: between the vertical and the horizontal.’ He explained, “the two fundamental,
label: Paragraph

text: complete contraries which shape our earth and all that is of the earth, are: the
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal line of power, that is the course of the earth around the sun and
label: Paragraph

text: the vertical, profoundly spatial movement of rays that originates in the center
label: Paragraph

text: of the sun.”® Following this line of reasoning, the horizontal line, the vertical
label: Paragraph

text: ray, their perpendicular intersection, and thus a principle of the right angle were
label: Paragraph

text: established as the absolute fundamentals of natural construction that must be put
label: Paragraph

text: into equilibrium.’ Color was similarly configured: “The three principal colors are
label: Paragraph

text: essentially yellow, blue, and red. They are the only colors existing ... Yellow is the
label: Paragraph

text: movement of the ray ... Blue is the contrasting color to yellow ... Asa color, blue
label: Paragraph

text: is the firmament, it is line, horizontality. Red is the mating of yellow and blue ...
label: Paragraph

text: red ‘floats.””* Mondrian subsequently synthesized these ideas for painting, writ-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in De Stijl: “Neoplastic painting remains pure painting: the plastic means
label: Paragraph

text: remain form and color-interiorized to the extreme; straight line and plane color
label: Paragraph

text: remain the pure pictorial means.””
label: Paragraph

text: Architectonic Plasticism
label: Title

text: Architecture’s neoplastic means were also discussed in the pages of De Stijl.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1917 and 1920, the De Stijl architects reviewed the plastic approaches
label: Paragraph

text: of others as well as presenting their own designs.'° Later, Van Doesburg used their
label: Paragraph

text: plastic forms to identify the principles of architectonic plasticism.’’ He noted a
label: Paragraph

text: house by Van’t Hoff, observing that its external features result from its internal
label: Paragraph

text: features, every spatial unit can be perceived from the outside, and its ideal form
label: Paragraph

text: transcends nature.” Also, note the reinforced concrete house had a flat roof and
label: Paragraph

text: large areas of glass enclosed voids defined by smooth orthogonal volumes and
label: Paragraph

text: articulated with cantilevered overhangs. A hotel by Wils was referenced for its
label: Paragraph

text: vertical, planar chimney that operates as the axis to an asymmetrical whole and
label: Paragraph

text: with varied cubic masses that give rhythm to space.’* Both buildings reflect ideas
label: Paragraph

text: and some latent formal properties evidenced in Frank Lloyd Wright’s Prairie
label: Paragraph

text: Houses from the 1910s and adopted by his early Dutch admirer, Hendrik Petrus
label: Paragraph

text: Berlage (1856-1934), such as cornices and banding emphasizing the horizontal and
label: Paragraph

text: an exterior form of aggregated volumes extending from an interior core element or
label: Paragraph

text: volume.'* Van Doesburg applauded the early plastic works of the De Stijl architects
label: Paragraph

text: and conceded that architecture’s “plasticism will evolve from the functional needs
label: Paragraph

text: which determine the division of space,” but he added that in order to achieve a
label: Paragraph

text: truly monumental art, the problem of “color and space is the most important.”1*
label: Title

text: Painting and Architecture
label: Title

text: The fundamental association of architecture and color had been laid out in De Stijl’s
label: Paragraph

text: first issue by the painter Bart van der Leck. In his essay, “The Place of Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Painting in Architecture,” Van der Leck explained that because architecture is con-
label: Paragraph

text: structional, closed, and colorless, with planar surfaces and space-restricting flatness,
label: Paragraph

text: it must be contrasted and harmonized through modern painting’s destructional
label: Paragraph

text: character due to its direct plastic expression of light via color and its multiplicity
label: Paragraph

text: of spatial relationships via direct relationship.'® Van Doesburg reiterated this dia-
label: Paragraph

text: lectical argument a year later, writing, “Architecture produces construction, that is
label: Paragraph

text: closed, relief. In this respect it is neutral in relation to painting, which gives open
label: Paragraph

text: relief by means of flat color plasticism. Architecture joins together, binds. Painting
label: Paragraph

text: loosens, unbinds. The very fact that they have to fulfill essentially different func-
label: Paragraph

text: tions makes possible a harmonious combination. The latter arises, not from similar
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics, but precisely from opposite characteristics. In this opposition, in this
label: Paragraph

text: complementary relationship of architecture and painting, plastic form and flat
label: Paragraph

text: color, pure monumental art finds its basis.”’”
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas Mondrian focused primarily on developing neoplastic ideas in his
label: Paragraph

text: paintings, the other affiliates of De Stijl endeavored to manifest the theory in artistic
label: Paragraph

text: expression both from within and between the arts. Van Doesburg was particularly
label: Paragraph

text: active and vocal with this mission. Throughout his short life, he remained commit-
label: Paragraph

text: ted to evolving a plastic approach in painting, but equally and directly, to sculpture,
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, typography, and text, as well. While not signing the first manifesto,
label: Paragraph

text: the architects J. J. P. Oud and Gerrit Rietveld were also part of the group and, with
label: Paragraph

text: Wils, Van’t Hoff, and C. R. de Boer, early collaborators with the painter. But, even
label: Paragraph

text: though most members of De Stijl supported the unity of painting and architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as unified collaborations between painters and architects, Van Doesburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: contributions were typically limited to adding decorative treatments, such as brick
label: Paragraph

text: mosaics, stained-glass, tiled floors, harmonized paint-colored surfaces, and pat-
label: Paragraph

text: terned borders, to an already established architectural schema. Furthermore, let-
label: Paragraph

text: ters from Van Doesburg to Oud during construction of the De Vonk holiday
label: Paragraph

text: home in 1918 reveal the latent friction in collaboration. One reads, “It’s a shame
label: Paragraph

text: that so little unanimity appears possible,”"* and another, “I just want to remind you
label: Paragraph

text: that the hall doors (upstairs and downstairs) should either be executed precisely accord-
label: Paragraph

text: ing to my designs or not at all.”"? Van Doesburg sought a more substantive
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration in the development of an architectural project to fully test De Stijl’s
label: Paragraph

text: premises, yet the secondary nature of his engagement continued in the same vein
label: Paragraph

text: for the next few years. In May 1922, while living in Weimar with the aim of influ-
label: Paragraph

text: encing the Bauhaus with De Stijl’s agenda, Van Doesburg met and persuaded a
label: Paragraph

text: young Dutch student architect, Cornelis van Eesteren, to collaborate. Their future
label: Paragraph

text: alliance on four projects for the 1923 De Stijl Exhibition in Paris would display inci-
label: Paragraph

text: dences of mutual contribution and at least one unified work of art in which paint-
label: Paragraph

text: erly and architectural means were plastically synthesized.
label: Paragraph

text: Paris, 1923: The Architecture of the De Stijl Group
label: Title

text: At the invitation of art historian and collector Léonce Rosenberg, members of the
label: Paragraph

text: De Stijl Group exhibited architectural work at his Galerie de l’Effort Moderne in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris from October to November 1923. There were no paintings or sculptures, only
label: Paragraph

text: architectural projects as a “total art.” Exhibitors included Van Eesteren and Van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg, J. J. P. Oud, Vilmos Huszar, Jan Wils, Gerrit Rietveld, and Mies van
label: Caption

text: der Rohe. Moreover, a fifth De Stijl manifesto, Vers une Construction Collective,
label: Paragraph

text: signed by Van Eesteren, Rietveld, and Van Doesburg, was distributed at the expo-
label: Paragraph

text: sition.”° Its eight points laid out the critical relationships for the (new) style of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. It stated that to achieve a collective unification of all the arts, architecture
label: Paragraph

text: must challenge the articulation of and the relationships between space, color, time,
label: Paragraph

text: dimension, proportion, materials, and inside and outside.”’ It is through a synthesis
label: Paragraph

text: of these concerns that Van Doesburg’s “Contra-Construction” drawing was gener-
label: Paragraph

text: ated for the exhibition.
label: Paragraph

text: The development of the drawing identified here as the “Contra-Construction”
label: Paragraph

text: emanates from one of Van Doesburg’s, and De Stijl’s, primary beliefs — the neces-
label: Paragraph

text: sary opposition and reconciliation of painting and architecture. For the exhibition,
label: Caption

text: Van Doesburg collaborated with the De Stijl novitiate Cornelis van Eesteren on
label: Paragraph

text: four architectural projects: the University Hall, a country house for Rosenberg
label: Caption

text: (Hétel Particulier), a private house (Maison Particuliére), and a house for an artist
label: Paragraph

text: (Maison d’ Artiste). From June to October 1923, they worked together in Van Does-
label: Paragraph

text: burg’s Paris studio to develop projects for exhibition. The nature and significance
label: Paragraph

text: of the individual contributions to the exhibited works and subsequent publications
label: Paragraph

text: were contested by the authors themselves and consequently has been debated by
label: Paragraph

text: others. Undoubtedly, the University Hall originated in Van Eesteren’s 1921 win-
label: Paragraph

text: ning Prix de Rome entry for a Royal Institute of Sciences, Literature, and Fine Arts;
label: Paragraph

text: however, he made spatial, tectonic, and organizational adjustments to the scheme
label: Paragraph

text: in response to Van Doesburg’s interior color design. It appears as well that the main
label: Paragraph

text: responsibility of the Hétel Particulier was conveyed to Van Eesteren after Oud
label: Paragraph

text: pulled out “sometime during 1922” and its model was constructed by Rietveld.”*
label: Paragraph

text: However, there is little question that the two Maisons were undertaken collabora-
label: Paragraph

text: tively and concurrently in the Paris studio and the resultant complexity in their
label: Paragraph

text: designs and their representations reveal an achievement attained through the more
label: Paragraph

text: intimately collective effort of the generative design process. The Private House was
label: Paragraph

text: the most comprehensively demonstrated of the four projects and the works
label: Paragraph

text: devoted to its development alone filled one room of the gallery. As might be
label: Paragraph

text: expected, the exhibited representations of the Maison Particuliére span and blur
label: Paragraph

text: the boundaries of architectural convention and painterly abstraction.
label: Paragraph

text: Oscillations between Architecture and Painting:
label: Title

text: Maison Particuliére
label: Title

text: Room two of the Rosenberg Gallery was exclusively devoted to the Maison
label: Paragraph

text: Particuliére and didactically labeled: “Development of an Architecture demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: by a Private House.””’ The house centers itself around two vertical rectangular vol-
label: Paragraph

text: umetric masses that extend from ground to roof and are set at 90° to each other so as
label: Paragraph

text: to articulate a generally square central core volume. The plan is loosely cross-shaped
label: Paragraph

text: as defined by cubic room volumes that centrifugally but orthogonally extend and
label: Paragraph

text: slightly overlap floor to floor. Thus, while the smaller volumes are generally cubic,
label: Paragraph

text: the overall building volume is broken up, which is especially noticeable at the cor-
label: Paragraph

text: ners. The expression of aggregated volumes and voids is further enhanced by hor-
label: Paragraph

text: izontal, cantilevered planes that often operate as terraces and window overhangs.
label: Paragraph

text: The horizontal and vertical shifting of the building leads to volumes in space that
label: Paragraph

text: appear to defy gravity. Furthermore, the plastic form of the architecture is disrupted
label: Paragraph

text: through the painted application of colored planes. This architectural assembly was
label: Paragraph

text: portrayed through an array of drawings and a model, each enumerated.
label: Paragraph

text: It is likely that the line drawings of the plans, elevations, and parallel projections
label: Paragraph

text: were from Van Eesteren’s hand, while the model, Analysis of Architecture, the
label: Paragraph

text: Construction(s) of Color, and all applied color were by Van Doesburg.”* While
label: Paragraph

text: individual attributions remain debatable, the work reflects the providential out-
label: Paragraph

text: come of collaboration between the unique contributions of discipline specific
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge. A harmonically balanced union of architectural demonstration and
label: Paragraph

text: painterly expression is evident in the scale model of different materials and color
label: Paragraph

text: (no. 28: “maquette”), a set of colored orthographic views of the four elevations (no.
label: Paragraph

text: 24: “Détermination des différents plans de Varchitecture par la couleur’), and three poly-
label: Caption

text: chromed, oblique parallel projections of the architecture: one, as seen from a bird’s-
label: Paragraph

text: eye view and two, from a worm’s-eye view (nos. 25-27: “architecture”). In these
label: Paragraph

text: blended representations, it is possible to perceive the complementary approach
label: Paragraph

text: as described by Van Doesburg: “I myself endeavored to use color as a reinforcing
label: Paragraph

text: element in the plastic treatment of architectural space. There was no question of
label: Paragraph

text: any ‘artistic compositional tendency’ in my approach. Each of the space-defining
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces was accentuated by color according to its place in that space. Height,
label: Paragraph

text: depth, and width were accentuated by red, blue, and yellow, the volumes being
label: Paragraph

text: painted gray, black, or white. This enlivened the effect of the room’s dimensions.
label: Paragraph

text: In this manner it was possible to use color as an architectural element without sug-
label: Paragraph

text: gesting an aesthetic effect.”** The combinatory plastic effects of the architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and painting are clearly balanced in these representations; however, other repre-
label: Paragraph

text: sentations in the exhibit are adjusted for more architectural or more painterly
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction.
label: Paragraph

text: Specialized architectural knowledge and its drawing conventions not only reg-
label: Paragraph

text: ulate the scaled plans of the Private House’s three floors (nos. 13-15), but also a
label: Paragraph

text: series of four bird’s-eye view oblique parallel projection drawings of the architec-
label: Caption

text: ture’s exterior form (nos. 16-19: “Schema de V’architecture”).”® The series of drawings
label: Paragraph

text: are plan oblique, equally oriented at 45° to horizontal, and the view rotates to each
label: Paragraph

text: corner in four 90° intervals. All the parallel projection drawings in the exhibit were
label: Paragraph

text: similar plan-based oblique projections. In this type of drawing, the horizontal face
label: Paragraph

text: of the building is parallel to the picture plane and the projectors are oblique to the
label: Paragraph

text: plane of projection. In the Western world, parallel projection drawings were devel-
label: Paragraph

text: oped for their functional capacity, concurrently conveying a pictorial view and
label: Paragraph

text: maintaining measured precision.” Up to the eighteenth century, oblique projec-
label: Paragraph

text: tion drawings delineated most practical and technical views, when in the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century the technique of parallel projection was differentiated and
label: Paragraph

text: divided into oblique projection and orthographic axonometric projection. Since
label: Paragraph

text: then, all such parallel views, and the Contra-Construction itself, are often impre-
label: Paragraph

text: cisely identified as axonometric, but the fundamental trait that overtly delineates
label: Paragraph

text: the oblique from the axonometric is critical in the ideas of De Stijl.” Oblique par-
label: Paragraph

text: allel projection drawings have concurrent two-dimensional and three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: space attributes. Two-dimensional geometric purity resides in the plane parallel to
label: Paragraph

text: the picture plane, thus rectangles look like rectangles and squares look like squares.
label: Paragraph

text: The inherent spatial multi-dimensionality in Van Eesteren’s plan oblique parallel
label: Paragraph

text: projections of the Maison Particuliére clearly became a compelling device for the
label: Paragraph

text: artist Van Doesburg. Thus, we find that the four rotated, bird’s-eye view oblique
label: Paragraph

text: parallel projection drawings of the Private House’s architectural scheme (nos.
label: Paragraph

text: 16-19) are balanced in the exhibit with corresponding abstractions achieved
label: Paragraph

text: through literally tracing them (nos. 20-23, respectively). In Van Doesburg’s traces,
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural facts of the originating, objective representation are eliminated in
label: Paragraph

text: order to distill other aspects, such as colored plasticity, volumetric simultaneity,
label: Paragraph

text: material ambiguity, and multi-dimensional spatiality. The drawing identified here
label: Paragraph

text: as the “Contra-Construction” is one of these drawings (no. 21); however, during
label: Paragraph

text: the time of its generation it was not regarded under this nomenclature.
label: Paragraph

text: Contra-Construction: From Construction of Color to
label: Title

text: Construction of Space-Time
label: Title

text: Three of the four abstractions traced from the series of oblique projection
label: Paragraph

text: drawings of the architectural scheme have now achieved iconic status as the
label: Paragraph

text: Contra-Construction drawings. However, these drawings were initially identified
label: Paragraph

text: as Construction of Color (nos. 21-23: “construction de la couleur’).”? This descrip-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, as well as the drawing convention itself, indicates that the three drawings were
label: Paragraph

text: intended to not only validate the plastic nature of color, but establish it as equal to
label: Paragraph

text: the constructed nature of architecture. The Construction of Color drawings, as
label: Paragraph

text: seen in Figure 1 on p 133, reduce the external surface boundaries of the correspond-
label: Paragraph

text: ing projection drawing to vertical and horizontal planar volumes of varying dimen-
label: Paragraph

text: sions and thicknesses with color (red, yellow, blue, black, white, or gray) which is
label: Paragraph

text: variously applied to each rectangular prism’s three visible surface planes.*° The col-
label: Paragraph

text: ored planes and volumes are aligned and held aloft by the x,y,z axes of parallel
label: Paragraph

text: projection’s infinite space, and thus take on the appearance of a three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: assembly despite the fact that they are limited to the architecture’s perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: boundaries. Concurrently, the spatially synthetic nature of the plan oblique allows
label: Paragraph

text: its undistorted orthographic plane to demonstrate the pure plastic relations of
label: Paragraph

text: painting alone — geometrically pure, flat rectangles of color orthogonally set into
label: Paragraph

text: relation with one another. In essence, this horizontal plane parallels Mondrian and
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg’s painted compositions. It was soon after the exhibition that the
label: Paragraph

text: identification of these drawings transitioned to “Contra-Construction,” but during
label: Paragraph

text: the exhibition that designation was applied to the fourth of Van Doesburg’s dia-
label: Paragraph

text: grammatic abstractions paired to the oblique projection drawing series. This dia-
label: Paragraph

text: grammatic trace is labeled an Analysis of Architecture (Contra-Construction)
label: Paragraph

text: (no. 20: “Analyse de Varchitecture (contre-construction)’).
label: Paragraph

text: The Analysis of Architecture delineation is similar to, but distinct from, the Con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction of Color diagrams. The external boundaries of the architecture’s form are
label: Paragraph

text: outlined and reduced to transparent, overlapping vertical and horizontal planes of
label: Paragraph

text: varying dimensions and thicknesses. The planar depths of some of the rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: prisms are filled, giving a pronounced and concurrent presence of line to plane.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the architectural premise, the “analytic” diagram does not contain the
label: Paragraph

text: architectonic elements essential to the formation of this work of architecture, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the two central, rectangular, vertical cores or the ground floor columns; nor does
label: Paragraph

text: it convey spatial order, such as the centrifugal grouping of functional spaces extend-
label: Paragraph

text: ing from the core. Rather, the architecture is abstracted to a collection of its orthog-
label: Paragraph

text: onally oriented planar boundaries, and their horizontal and vertical edge lines,
label: Paragraph

text: floating in anti-gravity space. This drawing captures Van Doesburg’s general con-
label: Paragraph

text: ception of plastic architecture: “The subdivision of the functional spaces is strictly
label: Paragraph

text: determined by rectangular planes, which possess no individual forms in themselves
label: Paragraph

text: since, although they are limited (the one plane by the other), they can be imagined
label: Paragraph

text: as extended into infinity, thereby forming a system of coordinates, the different
label: Paragraph

text: points of which would correspond to an equal number of points in universal, open
label: Paragraph

text: space.”*’ Undoubtedly, Van Doesburg’s regard of the means to architecture led
label: Paragraph

text: both to its appropriate representation in parallel projection and to its parenthetical
label: Paragraph

text: identification as counter to construction, or Contra-Construction. Moreover, the
label: Paragraph

text: transfer of this term to the Construction of Color drawings is a logical shift because
label: Paragraph

text: it more fully reflects Van Doesburg’s, and De Stijl’s, stated relation of painting to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture — that is, plastic color is the primary means by which to provoke the
label: Paragraph

text: normative facts of architecture’s construction, thus the construction of its color
label: Paragraph

text: must be the counter to its construction, or Contra-Construction.
label: Paragraph

text: It should be noted that the Contra-Construction typology undergoes two more
label: Paragraph

text: transitions between the 1923 exhibit and 1925.*” In this period, Van Doesburg
label: Paragraph

text: returned to and redrew the Contra-Construction drawings — twice. Both circum-
label: Paragraph

text: stances involve minimal adjustments but nevertheless disclose critical questions as
label: Paragraph

text: to how the iconic Contra-Construction might be understood.
label: Paragraph

text: The first adjustment to the notion of Contra-Construction straddles 1923-24.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg literally copied the three exhibition drawings formerly called
label: Paragraph

text: Constructions of Color. The first copy (of no. 21) is without title; however, the
label: Paragraph

text: other two (of nos. 22-23) take on a new persona, Construction of Space-Time
label: Paragraph

text: (II and Ill, respectively).’’ There is no significant difference between either repro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction and its original manifestation; however, the change in taxonomy coincides
label: Paragraph

text: with and reflects Van Doesburg’s concurrent reconsideration of space, relative to
label: Paragraph

text: time. Like other artists in the early twentieth century, Van Doesburg’s thoughts
label: Paragraph

text: had been provoked by hyperspace philosophy and its speculation on fourth-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional space, or n-dimensional geometry that emerged at the turn of the
label: Paragraph

text: century.** In 1912, Cubist painter Albert Gleizes explained their Synthetic
label: Paragraph

text: approach: “Beyond the three dimensions of Euclid we have added another, the
label: Paragraph

text: fourth dimension, which is to say, the figuration of space, the measure of the infi-
label: Paragraph

text: nite.”?’ During the course of the 1910s, the idea of a fourth dimension in the arts
label: Paragraph

text: evolved as a compelling spatio-geometric question, but this was challenged in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1920s when the Theory of Relativity posited time as the fourth dimension in
label: Paragraph

text: the space-time continuum. In 1922, Van Doesburg recognized the issue, writing in
label: Paragraph

text: De Stijl, “a new and important problem has arisen in painting and sculpture beside
label: Paragraph

text: the problem of space, and that is the problem of time.”**
label: Paragraph

text: By 1923, Van Doesburg related both space and time to the exhibited architecture;
label: Paragraph

text: the accompanying Manifesto noted: “We have studied the relationship between space
label: Paragraph

text: and time and have found that the plastic expression of these two elements through
label: Paragraph

text: color gives a new dimension.”*” One infers here that the fourth dimension is engaged
label: Paragraph

text: through color. Yet, it was not until 1928 that Van Doesburg explained how space and
label: Paragraph

text: time were purposely and plastically expressed through color in architecture.** His
label: Paragraph

text: argument sets out that neoplastic, two-dimensional paintings not only established a
label: Paragraph

text: new relationship to space, but by consequence to man, the static viewer. In this case,
label: Paragraph

text: man is metaphorically moved by color’s plastic space and from “this relationship of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘dynamic man’ to space, a new notion was established to architecture, the notion
label: Paragraph

text: of time.” In architecture, man’s actual movement in space would allow man not only
label: Paragraph

text: to engage color as in the painting, but also to engage color in time. Thus, color’s role
label: Paragraph

text: expands in architecture as “space-time painting.”’” Put simply, color engaged dynam-
label: Paragraph

text: ically is a fourth dimensional “space-time” effect. With this understanding, Van Does-
label: Paragraph

text: burg’s last variation on the Contra-Construction drawing can be clearly conveyed.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1925, Van Doesburg followed the Construction of Space-Time iterations with
label: Paragraph

text: one last set.“° Only one of these drawings was given an inscription: Construction of
label: Paragraph

text: Color in the Fourth Dimension of Space-Time.”’ As before, the drawings are literal
label: Paragraph

text: copies of the originals, but this time they are placed on a square field that is rotated
label: Paragraph

text: obliquely by 45°. It appears that Van Doesburg introduces the new oblique field in
label: Paragraph

text: order to bring dynamic movement and thus “space-time” into the representation.
label: Paragraph

text: Given Van Doesburg’s ongoing reconsideration of what the Contra-Construction
label: Paragraph

text: meant to architecture, it should come as no surprise that his discoveries would
label: Paragraph

text: inform his paintings. Subsequent to 1925, Van Doesburg brought obliquity to
label: Paragraph

text: his painted Compositions. The 45° diagonal compositions were soon entitled,
label: Paragraph

text: Contra-Compositions.
label: Paragraph

text: Contra-Construction and its Space in
label: Title

text: Architectural Representation
label: Title

text: In the hundred years between axonometry’s origination as isometry in the 1820s and
label: Paragraph

text: the De Stijl exhibition in 1923, parallel projection drawings were most often employed
label: Paragraph

text: for the measured transmission of architecture’s objective nature and tectonic forma-
label: Paragraph

text: tion. Over the second half of the nineteenth century, engineers Robert Willis (1800-75)
label: Paragraph

text: and Auguste Choisy (1841-1909) documented the history of architecture’s construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion through compelling oblique and axonometric parallel projections.** Choisy’s
label: Paragraph

text: graphic experiments with the spatial capacity of this pictorial form of architectural rep-
label: Paragraph

text: resentation brought about the worm’s-eye view, in which each individual image,
label: Paragraph

text: working from the inside out, simultaneously builds in three dimensions, montaging
label: Paragraph

text: the plan, the section, and the elevation. Often, the building’s plan is highly differen-
label: Paragraph

text: tiated to ensure a reading of solid and void, order and rhythm, element and structure,
label: Paragraph

text: mass and space. Choisy himself noted that “in this system, one sole image, moving and
label: Paragraph

text: animated like the building itself, takes the place of abstract figuration.”
label: Paragraph

text: In 1920, three years before the De Stijl exhibition, Choisy’s parallel projections
label: Paragraph

text: were adopted by Le Corbusier for the pages of the L’esprit nouveau. The drawings
label: Paragraph

text: were used to remind architects that “volume and surface are determined by the
label: Paragraph

text: plan.”**
label: Paragraph

text: a clear rhythm of the parts, render just proportions to both masses and spaces,
label: Paragraph

text: and thus transmit a coordinated sensation and spirit, thereby making architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier asserts that plans should formally fix the volumes, express
label: Paragraph

text: In this spirit, the infinite space of parallel projection conveys the space and the
label: Paragraph

text: structure of architecture as necessary reciprocal constructs and so analogues to
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture. During the twentieth century, parallel projections continue
label: Paragraph

text: to be used for such syntactic simultaneity.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg’s Contra-Construction functions in a very different way. It does
label: Paragraph

text: not model architecture and its space; rather it is a conceptualized symbol of
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic, modern space itself. In fact, when Van Doesburg reflected directly on
label: Paragraph

text: parallel projection as an explicit form of architectural representation, he presented
label: Paragraph

text: that echoes Choisy. Van Doesburg counseled that when architecture is conceptua-
label: Paragraph

text: lized as a spatial-functional construct, “axonometries” properly correspond to the
label: Paragraph

text: construction. The representation aligns “better to the requirement of perceiving
label: Paragraph

text: the house spatially from all sides, even from above and from below, in its true
label: Paragraph

text: proportions, that is to say without perspective vanishing points. The structure
label: Paragraph

text: is immediately surveyed in its cubic content, instead of in its surface ... Clearly
label: Paragraph

text: ‘axonometries’ will need to be detailed, from the foundation to the roof.”””
label: Paragraph

text: The Architecture of Contra-Construction
label: Title

text: Ultimately, the impact of De Stijl was not achieved through the production of the
label: Paragraph

text: “monumental work of art.” As is often observed, Gerrit Rietveld’s 1924 Schroeder
label: Paragraph

text: house stands alone as a total manifestation of neoplastic principles in a complete work.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead, De Stijl’s contribution to architecture lies in its provocations through publi-
label: Paragraph

text: cation and exhibition. Through these modes of communication — word, model, pho-
label: Paragraph

text: tograph, and drawing — De Stijl played a more noteworthy role in architecture’s
label: Paragraph

text: modern development. The Contra-Construction stands as an embodiment of both
label: Paragraph

text: its influence and its ideals.

text: THE FUNCTIONAL CITY
label: Title

text: The city plans of the Franco-Swiss architect Le Corbusier changed the face of town
label: Paragraph

text: planning in the postwar era. The three best known are the Ville contemporaine
label: Paragraph

text: (1922, also known as the City of Three Million), the Plan Voisin (1925), the focus
label: Paragraph

text: of this chapter, and the Radiant City (1933). The Plan Voisin, developed together
label: Paragraph

text: with his cousin Pierre Jeanneret, was particularly controversial as it was here, for
label: Paragraph

text: the first time, that Le Corbusier translated the brittle assertions of his canonical
label: Paragraph

text: books, Toward an Architecture (1923), The City of Tomorrow (1924) and The Decorative
label: Paragraph

text: Art of Today (1925) to a real site — Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: At the core of this discussion is the definition of the “functional city,” in Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's terms, a city that provided the body with emotional as well as physical
label: Paragraph

text: sustenance: “A form of town planning which ... attempted to create happiness and
label: Paragraph

text: expel misery would be a noble service in this age of confusion.”’ I will draw on Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's fondness for dualistic thinking to differentiate bodily needs in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: the poetic (emotional) and the utilitarian (the ingress and egress of provisions and
label: Paragraph

text: waste).” Having illustrated how these two needs were to be addressed by the Plan
label: Paragraph

text: Voisin and one of its “cells,” the Esprit Nouveau Pavilion, I will discuss the reasons
label: Paragraph

text: for what I believe to be a distortion of his ideas toward the utilitarian, leading to the
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent neglect of the poetic body in many of the “Le Corbusier inspired” city
label: Paragraph

text: plans of the 1950s and 1960s.
label: Paragraph

text: It is my intention to focus on the motivations and methodology beneath the Plan
label: Paragraph

text: Voisin in order to tease out its importance for the development of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: culture. To do this I will need to set Le Corbusier's work within its cultural con-
label: Paragraph

text: text.’ Close examination of Le Corbusier’s work often reveals that it was not so
label: Paragraph

text: * “Thus does architecture become a mirror
label: Title

text: of the times,” he wrote.” Specifically, it was Tony Garnier’s extraordinarily revo-
label: Paragraph

text: tionary but Arcadian Cité industrielle scheme published in 1917 that paved the way
label: Paragraph

text: for the Voisin plan,” part of a long tradition of urbanism in France and a vision that,
label: Paragraph

text: original as we might at first suppose:
label: Paragraph

text: ike Le Corbusier's, was strongly influenced by the socialist utopianism of Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Fourier.”
label: Paragraph

text: No other architect has received as much attention as Le Corbusier. His upbring-
label: Paragraph

text: ing (as Charles Edouard Jeanneret) and self-education through books and travel
label: Paragraph

text: have been studied in minute detail by scholars from a variety of angles, though
label: Paragraph

text: much still remains obscure.* Le Corbusier was a connoisseur, a collector of objects
label: Paragraph

text: and ideas. His work, both at large and small scale, was an exercise in curatorship
label: Paragraph

text: and ordering. Deeply troubled by what he saw as the chaos of the world around
label: Paragraph

text: him, he sought “a new age of discipline, wisdom and unanimity.” Spirituality
label: Paragraph

text: played a vexed role in all this. Having been quick to depart from the religion within
label: Paragraph

text: which he was raised, he spent much of his life looking for a system of belief that
label: Paragraph

text: made sense of the world around him, a journey that led him to nature,'° to science,
label: Paragraph

text: and eventually to an Orphic vision of the world as a system of mathematical rela-
label: Paragraph

text: tionships charged with energy and indeed love. His more arcane ideas are couched
label: Paragraph

text: cryptically within his writings, left obscure for fear of ridicule in an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: milieu that increasingly favored the rational, a key factor in the misinterpretation
label: Paragraph

text: of his work."*
label: Paragraph

text: As a young man Le Corbusier described his city plans as “technical,” apparently
label: Paragraph

text: because he wanted to get away from accusations of political bias.'” Politics are,
label: Paragraph

text: however, central to the making of a city. The source of the word politics is ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Greek. Aristotle’s Politics focused on the political life of the city, the polis. Although
label: Paragraph

text: well versed in Aristotle, Le Corbusier was very careful to side-step such issues,
label: Paragraph

text: which are nevertheless absolutely integral to an accurate understanding of his moti-
label: Paragraph

text: vations. His refusal to take a political stance added to the uncertainty of what he
label: Paragraph

text: really meant by his city schemes, which, at first glance, appear to favor the
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian.
label: Paragraph

text: Whatever his protestations to the contrary, the Plan Voisin was deeply political.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1920s Le Corbusier spent a great deal of effort trying to persuade capi-
label: Paragraph

text: talists, car manufacturing magnates such as Citroen, Peugeot, and Voisin, to sup-
label: Paragraph

text: port his grandiose schemes, at this stage in his career believing them capable of
label: Paragraph

text: realizing his audacious vision of cheap, factory-built, standardized homes for the
label: Paragraph

text: masses.'* Clearly he felt that car manufacturers had much to gain from his car-
label: Paragraph

text: friendly plans, his avant garde reputation — the inhabitant of the “light, flexible
label: Paragraph

text: and strong” Maison Voisin would be animated by the “new spirit’’* — and his
label: Paragraph

text: increasing ability to attract publicity.'* Gabriel Voisin, who had started life as an
label: Paragraph

text: aviator and plane manufacturer before moving to automobile production in
label: Paragraph

text: 1919, helped to finance not only the Plan but also the Esprit Nouveau Pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: within which it was displayed.’* Tag Gronberg notes that Voisin’s cars were known
label: Paragraph

text: for “their luxury and artisanal manufacture,” rendering it slightly ironic that his
label: Paragraph

text: name was given to a plan that was such a celebration of standardization.’” It is
label: Paragraph

text: my suggestion, however, that, for Le Corbusier, standardization and pleasure were
label: Paragraph

text: not mutually exclusive. The Plan Voisin and the Esprit Nouveau Pavilion were
label: Paragraph

text: designed to open the mind of the public to the possibilities of the future city, min-
label: Paragraph

text: imalist pleasures set in opposition to the decorative excesses of the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition.’*
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s interest in the persuasive power of rhetoric and advertising is
label: Paragraph

text: now well documented." The origins of the promenades of “cultural propaganda”
label: Paragraph

text: that were to characterize Le Corbusier’s exhibition designs can clearly be seen in
label: Paragraph

text: the Esprit Nouveau Pavilion in the 1925 International Exposition of Modern
label: Caption

text: Decorative and Industrial Arts in Paris where the Voisin plan was first exhibited.”°
label: Paragraph

text: In Le Corbusier’s words, 1925 was “a time pregnant with grandiose and dangerous
label: Paragraph

text: activities.” “MM Loucheur and Bonnevay” had recently asked “the chamber for a
label: Paragraph

text: law decreeing the building of 500,000 low-cost housing units,” providing what Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier saw as an exceptional opportunity for the construction industry.” It is
label: Paragraph

text: always instructive to turn to the pages of Le Corbusier’s Oeuvre complete, the seven
label: Paragraph

text: self-curated volumes that chart his career, to see how he wanted the projects to be
label: Paragraph

text: presented. Here, in the 1919-29 volume, a discussion of Le Corbusier, Amédée
label: Paragraph

text: Ozenfant and Paul Dermée’s journal L’Esprit nouveau,”’ moves on to the Ville con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporaine, the Plan Voisin and thence to the Esprit Nouveau Pavilion itself. They
label: Paragraph

text: are intimately connected.
label: Paragraph

text: L'Esprit nouveau took its title from Guillaume Apollinaire’s lecture, “L’Esprit
label: Paragraph

text: nouveau et les poétes” of 1917.74 Le Corbusier, like many other architects of his time,
label: Paragraph

text: adhered to the idea that it was the task of the enlightened artist/poet to unite both
label: Paragraph

text: art and science, in other words the poetic and utilitarian body, to bring about
label: Paragraph

text: the eponymous spirit.” The subject matter of the journal was extremely
label: Paragraph

text: diverse, ranging from biology, astronomy, physics, medicine, and engineering
label: Paragraph

text: to psychoanalysis, sexuality, history, literature, art, and town planning. It was
label: Paragraph

text: clearly an attempt to find commonality across a range of fields, some certitude
label: Paragraph

text: in an extraordinarily diverse world. Contemporary with the Pavilion, Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: planned issue 29 to be devoted to the subject of architecture.”* Purism, the art
label: Paragraph

text: movement instigated by Le Corbusier and Ozenfant around “the organisation of
label: Paragraph

text: raw sensations,””” was conceived through its pages. “PURISM DOES NOT AIM
label: Paragraph

text: TO BE A SCIENTIFIC ART, WHICH WOULD HAVE NO MEANING” they
label: Paragraph

text: stated with categorical finality." It was conceived with the poetic body firmly
label: Paragraph

text: in mind.
label: Paragraph

text: The Esprit Nouveau Pavil
label: Title

text: reinforced concrete, was a ful
label: Paragraph

text: On display within the Pavilion was a radical new way of life played out through
label: Paragraph

text: its fittings, the latest in “equipment,” Le Corbusier’s new term for furniture.” By
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: age that he so desired.*’ At the Esprit Nouveau Pavilion, seating was organized for
label: Paragraph

text: practicality, not etiquette, a subject of which Le Corbusier was not overly fond.”*
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: made in the factories that used to manufacture office-furnishing.”*° Le Corbusier
label: Caption

text: himself wrote of the limitations of wood as a material for chairs, believing that
label: Paragraph

text: metal construction lent itself to new ways of sitting.*' With both utilitarian and
label: Paragraph

text: functional bodies firmly in mind, Le Corbusier, together with Charlotte Perriand,
label: Paragraph

text: conceived four different modes of emancipated sitting, each leading to a particular
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The hanging garden or terrace space of the Pavilion was built around an existing
label: Paragraph

text: tree. Its leaves gave a dappled light to the space so evocatively captured in an illus-
label: Paragraph

text: tration in the Oeuvre complete, encouraging a state of reverie.** The lifestyle on offer
label: Paragraph

text: was relaxed, yet orderly, and at one with nature.
label: Paragraph

text: In a rotunda attached to the “cell unit” was an exhibition containing two dior-
label: Paragraph

text: amas facing one another, one of the Ville contemporaine (originally exhibited at the
label: Paragraph

text: Salon d’automne in 1922) and one of the Plan Voisin, displayed as though seen
label: Paragraph

text: through a window of one of the blocks, the aim being “to objectify for the eyes
label: Paragraph

text: that innovation for which our spirit is not prepared.”*’ Here, carefully framed
label: Paragraph

text: views were set against walls covered in “methodically worked out plans for cruci-
label: Paragraph

text: form skyscrapers, housing colonies with staggered layouts, and a whole range of
label: Paragraph

text: types new to architecture that were the fruit of a mind preoccupied with the
label: Paragraph

text: The Plan Voisin
label: Title

text: The diorama of the Plan Voisin revealed 18 cruciform towers of the business dis-
label: Paragraph

text: trict, bisected by an enormous raised superhighway, that were essentially the
label: Paragraph

text: same as that of the Ville contemporaine ordered on a large geometric grid.*”
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier did not just choose any site; he chose one of the most charged sites
label: Paragraph

text: possible, believing that the congested Right Bank business district opposite the
label: Paragraph

text: Cité of Paris, an area roughly two miles square, was ripe for demolition. Only
label: Paragraph

text: a few fragments of the city would be left behind like follies in an “English
label: Paragraph

text: Garden,”** the character of which was demonstrated by Le Corbusier in The City
label: Paragraph

text: of Tomorrow and its Planning in the form of a postcard of the Parc Monceau.*” An
label: Paragraph

text: illustration in L’Esprit nouveau shows “Nature” as a naked woman strumming a
label: Paragraph

text: lute against a background of greenery: peaceful, delightful, gendered, and
label: Paragraph

text: ordered. Le Corbusier’s city vision would exclude “antagonistic natural phenom-
label: Paragraph

text: ena, giving us, we men, our human milieu.””°
label: Paragraph

text: In this section I will explore the assumptions that lay behind Le Corbusier’s uto-
label: Paragraph

text: pian vision for the Plan Voisin, asserted so authoritatively through plans, diagrams,
label: Paragraph

text: and numbers in the Esprit Nouveau Pavilion, and their relationship with bodily
label: Paragraph

text: need. Despite Le Corbusier’s assertion that the principles behind his city plans
label: Paragraph

text: remained the same throughout his career’! they are quite fragmentary and incon-
label: Paragraph

text: sistent, with certain “elements” being prioritized and then shrinking into the back-
label: Paragraph

text: ground in the next book or project.
label: Paragraph

text: An assumption fundamental to Le Corbusier’s work is the need for classifica-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and order, hence his fascination with filing cabinets so amply illustrated in
label: Paragraph

text: The Decorative Art of Today.”” It has been seen that one of the central aims of the
label: Paragraph

text: journal L’Esprit nouveau was to make sense of the disparate advances that Le Cor-
label: Paragraph

text: busier saw around him, to bring them into some kind of family. This preoccu-
label: Paragraph

text: pation, so central to architectural culture, translated itself to the city in terms
label: Paragraph

text: of the zoning of particular activities. Le Corbusier was so obsessed with this sub-
label: Paragraph

text: ject that he named Chapters V and VI of The City of Tomorrow and its Planning:
label: Paragraph

text: “Classification and Choice (A Survey)” and “Classification and Choice (Timely
label: Title

text: Decisions)”:** “A city is a whirlpool; let us classify the impression it gives rise
label: Paragraph

text: to, inquire into our sensations arising therefore and choose among the methods
label: Paragraph

text: which may relieve or effect a cure.” His method was to “deal first with the eye”
label: Paragraph

text: and then “afterwards we can consider the ear, the lungs, and our legs,” the order
label: Paragraph

text: of proceedings foregrounding the aesthetic experience of space.”* He placed great
label: Paragraph

text: importance on the realm of “feelings ... emotions ... and sensibilities,”** “the soul
label: Paragraph

text: of the city” being for Le Corbusier, “more important than the mechanism of the
label: Paragraph

text: city.”°6
label: Paragraph

text: Feelings, Emotions and Sensibilities - Addressing the
label: Paragraph

text: Needs of the Poetic Body
label: Title

text: Le Corbusier saw a need to create “a common human measure and a proportional
label: Paragraph

text: ‘mean’ between the fact ‘man’ and the fact ‘nature.’”"” He reminisced that before
label: Paragraph

text: the advent of the train, motorcar, and airplane, “the speed of life was 3% miles per
label: Paragraph

text: hour: the pace of man, of his ox, his horse or his ass. An authentic harmony lived
label: Paragraph

text: enshrined in those settlements, maintained in such intimacy as the human body
label: Paragraph

text: and mind.”** The layout of the house, the road and the city was proportioned
label: Paragraph

text: to the heartbeat pace of the human foot. Further, “in the same way as the palate
label: Paragraph

text: enjoys the variety of a well-arranged meal, so our eyes are ready for ordered
label: Paragraph

text: delights.”*” The text of The City of Tomorrow and its Planning is illustrated amply
label: Paragraph

text: with historical examples from Le Corbusier’s travel sketchbooks: “In old cities
label: Paragraph

text: famous for their beauty we walk among shapes which are coordinated, designed
label: Paragraph

text: around a center or along an axis.”°° Yet the axes of the Plan Voisin bear little rela-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to those of his favorite cities or the Parthenon, so celebrated in the pages of
label: Paragraph

text: Toward an Architecture.”
label: Paragraph

text: The geometry of space experienced on foot was vital: “These rhythms are at the
label: Paragraph

text: root of human activity. They resound in man through an organic inevitability, the
label: Paragraph

text: same inevitability that inscribes the golden section in children, in the elderly, in
label: Paragraph

text: savages, in the educated.” These ideas were based on an unquestioning belief
label: Paragraph

text: in the innate bodily appeal of Platonic solids such as the cone or the cube. “The
label: Paragraph

text: forms we are discussing are the eternal forms of pure geometry and these will
label: Paragraph

text: enshrine in a rhythm which will in the end be our own.” This idea was aug-
label: Paragraph

text: mented with a theory Le Corbusier based on air resistance of particular forms from
label: Paragraph

text: nature to suggest a way in which a route might be crafted using forms of little resist-
label: Paragraph

text: ance.’ The message is that the Platonic forms of an ordered city appeal to an inner
label: Paragraph

text: order innate within each of us. Such an order could be achieved through the use of
label: Paragraph

text: a system of “regulating lines” giving geometric order to space and form. Such ideas
label: Paragraph

text: would eventually evolve into his theory of the Modulor.°’ Underpinning all this is
label: Paragraph

text: the belief, again inspired by Plato, that if it is possible to change the way people feel
label: Paragraph

text: it is possible to change the way they think.
label: Paragraph

text: “Unity in detail; a magnificent ‘tumult’ in the whole” would be achieved through
label: Paragraph

text: the use of an underpinning geometry common to both the order of the city and the
label: Paragraph

text: wilderness of the park.®° Le Corbusier believed it was necessary to bring in “a pro-
label: Paragraph

text: portional mean” that would prevent too great a disparity between the scale of man
label: Paragraph

text: and his environment — the blocks of the Plan Voisin.” This would take the form of
label: Paragraph

text: trees, “a common architectural measure” that would “in any case” help “our phys-
label: Paragraph

text: ical and spiritual wellbeing.
label: Paragraph

text: The idea of the unified grouping is one that goes back to Le Corbusier’s days as
label: Paragraph

text: an interior designer and the evolution of what he called his “technique of group-
label: Paragraph

text: ing.”” This at first seems to have focused on geometry, color and material before
label: Paragraph

text: becoming increasingly symbolic in scope.”” “Town planning demands uniformity
label: Paragraph

text: in detail and a sense of movement in the general layout,” he wrote.’’ He enthused
label: Paragraph

text: about “groupings of a rare quality,” such as the rue de Rivoli, place des Vosges and
label: Paragraph

text: the place Vendéme in Paris,” where “the methods of construction were
label: Paragraph

text: uniform,”’” the result being that “every house was of the same tribe.” Once there
label: Paragraph

text: was more unity in material, “ideas of planning on a noble scale can then make
label: Paragraph

text: themselves heard”; in other words, geometry and rhythm innately appealing to
label: Paragraph

text: the poetic body.”* The “new weapon” in this battle was, for Le Corbusier, rein-
label: Paragraph

text: forced concrete and the potential of factory-built mass-produced houses.”
label: Paragraph

text: Mass production was the vital next step in Le Corbusier’s vision. The industri-
label: Paragraph

text: alization of the builder’s yard would bring about the uniformity and quality he so
label: Paragraph

text: desired. In the chapter “Mass Production Houses” in Toward an Architecture he
label: Paragraph

text: drew connections between the production of cars and the production of houses.
label: Paragraph

text: The airplane, the automobile, and the Parthenon were all examples of the potential
label: Paragraph

text: of evolutionary endeavor. The house should become “a machine for living,” the
label: Paragraph

text: best it could possibly be, not just in terms of function but also in terms of emotion.
label: Paragraph

text: It should be an extension of the body, a prosthetic limb, like the furnishings of the
label: Paragraph

text: Esprit Nouveau show home.
label: Paragraph

text: If we wrest from our hearts and minds static conceptions of the house and
label: Paragraph

text: consider the question from a critical and objective point of view, we will come
label: Paragraph

text: to the house-tool, the mass-production house that is healthy (morally too) and
label: Paragraph

text: beautiful from the aesthetic of the work tools that accompany our existence. Beau-
label: Paragraph

text: tiful too from all the life that the artistic sense can bring to these strict and pure
label: Paragraph

text: organs.”
label: Paragraph

text: In emphasizing the “house tool,” Le Corbusier addressed the needs of the
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian body. In emphasizing beauty, the emotions of the poetic body
label: Paragraph

text: come to the fore. This balance could only be achieved by the most delicate
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis.
label: Paragraph

text: Addressing the Needs of the Utilitarian Body
label: Title

text: There are moments in Le Corbusier's narrative when the needs of the poetic
label: Paragraph

text: body recede into the background, bringing function to the fore. These moments,
label: Paragraph

text: which are few, seem to have been those with the greatest impact as they discuss
label: Paragraph

text: tangible things, incitements to action that can be measured. “The city is a whirl-
label: Paragraph

text: pool, yet it is none the less a body with definitely placed organs, and it has a shape
label: Paragraph

text: ... the analysis of a city belongs to the realm of scientific investigation.”””
label: Paragraph

text: “Cancer” had set in and “surgery” was needed to make it healthy once more.”
label: Paragraph

text: The urban body becomes at once one of function, illustrated with images of the
label: Paragraph

text: heart and lungs, input and output. “The condition of the whole city lies in the con-
label: Paragraph

text: dition of each of its cells...”””
label: Paragraph

text: In line with this quasi-scientific view, a picture of the city could be developed
label: Paragraph

text: through the power of information. “By its geographical and topographical situa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, from the political, economic, and social part, played by it, the line of its
label: Paragraph

text: evolution can be followed ... Statistics, graphs, are the a, b, c, and so on of an equa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion whose x and y can be calculated in advance with a certain approximation.”*°
label: Paragraph

text: How such measurements, well known for flattening out the subjective, tally with
label: Paragraph

text: his poetic world view is a moot point.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s fascination with order led him inevitably to the concept of
label: Paragraph

text: zoning. All his city plans are zoned with areas devoted to industry, housing,
label: Paragraph

text: and so on. The passage of people, cars, and other forms of transport would be
label: Paragraph

text: similarly segregated. “The motor has killed the great city. The motor must save the
label: Paragraph

text: great city,” wrote Le Corbusier.*” In his opinion, “the ‘corridor-street’ between its
label: Paragraph

text: two pavements, stifled between tall houses, must disappear.”** It was chaotic, dark
label: Paragraph

text: and unhealthy. Inspired, in part, by the Garden City ideal of Raymond Unwin, he
label: Paragraph

text: proposed instead a series of aerial arteries devoted to vehicular traffic, leaving the
label: Paragraph

text: verdant ground plane free for pedestrians who would move through the city on a
label: Paragraph

text: series of platforms and what have come to be known as “streets in the sky,” perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: his most infamous legacy.
label: Paragraph

text: Legacy of Voisin
label: Title

text: Although he continued to search for a higher authority with the vision of Colbert or
label: Paragraph

text: Louis XIV, Le Corbusier was soon to be disabused of his delusion that capitalism
label: Paragraph

text: would bring about the city that he so desired. The assumptions behind the Plan
label: Paragraph

text: Voisin were that that zoning was desirable, that the use of geometry could be used
label: Paragraph

text: to make a link between the city and the poetic body (with quasi-scientific results),
label: Paragraph

text: and that mass production would provide the key to creating the unity in detail nec-
label: Paragraph

text: essary for a visually ordered city. The garden that formed its backdrop would be a
label: Paragraph

text: pleasant place affirming the links between nature and mankind, again addressing
label: Paragraph

text: poetic needs; and further, and most importantly, that the needs of the poetic and
label: Paragraph

text: utilitarian body must be addressed in tandem. For Le Corbusier the term “func-
label: Paragraph

text: tional” encompassed emotional and sensory needs, a fact that escaped the majority
label: Paragraph

text: of commentators, notably the eminent historian Nikolaus Pevsner, who wrote the
label: Paragraph

text: history of modernism for generations of architects with the utilitarian body very
label: Paragraph

text: much in mind.*?
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier himself came to detest the word functional, which in the hands of
label: Paragraph

text: Hannes Meyer and others became increasingly bogus in its pursuit of objectivity,
label: Paragraph

text: denying the “magical” qualities of architecture that he felt to be so important. Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier raged at the misrepresentation of his ideas, but in leaving his work so
label: Paragraph

text: ambiguous and open for interpretation, he was often his own worst enemy.**
label: Paragraph

text: The primary organ for spreading “the functional city’ were the meetings of
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM, the Congrés internationaux d’architecture moderne founded in Switzerland
label: Paragraph

text: in 1928.7 After World War II, local authorities all over Europe, tasked with the
label: Paragraph

text: swift reconstruction of their cities, were quick to understand the cost-saving poten-
label: Paragraph

text: tial of Le Corbusier's urban vision. Architects, such as those of London County
label: Paragraph

text: Council, were happy to deliver homes to people who did not always accept the
label: Paragraph

text: complete vision (a requisite of its success), with few communal facilities and min-
label: Paragraph

text: imal maintenance budgets. Many architects adopted Le Corbusier’s geometric
label: Paragraph

text: principles but ignored their philosophical grounding. The utilitarian body might
label: Paragraph

text: just have shelter, but the non-fungible needs of the poetic body lost out in the bar-
label: Paragraph

text: gain. Industry is only now, nearly 100 years later, gearing up to the reality of fac-
label: Paragraph

text: tory-built, mass-production homes. Zoning was quickly discredited by Jane Jacobs’
label: Paragraph

text: 1961 book, The Death and Life of Great American Cities as it gave rise to empty, un-
label: Paragraph

text: policed, and frightening city space of indeterminate ownership. The rejection of
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM functionalism was finally completed with the Commission of European
label: Paragraph

text: Communities’ 1990 Green Paper on the Urban Environment, which stressed the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of a “mixing of urban uses” taking “the old traditional life of the Euro-
label: Paragraph

text: pean city” as its model.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Writing in the early 1990s Robert Fishman stated, “the Plan Voisin still arouses
label: Paragraph

text: the same horror as it did at its original showing,” I suspect because of its seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: wanton destruction of a large swathe of Paris.°” Many would say it is just as well
label: Paragraph

text: that the Plan Voisin has never been tested in its entirety, the postwar experiments
label: Paragraph

text: in city planning being too far from Le Corbusier’s original conception to count in
label: Paragraph

text: my opinion. Ultimately the potential benefit of Le Corbusier's city vision for a will-
label: Paragraph

text: ing populace, under the right political conditions, has yet to be properly tested —
label: Paragraph

text: only his Unité d’habitation in Marseille (started 1947) giving some sense of what
label: Paragraph

text: might be possible.**
label: Paragraph

text: Conclusion
label: Title

text: Much of the blame for the misinterpretation of Le Corbusier’s theories must lie
label: Paragraph

text: with Le Corbusier himself. The Plan Voisin was an attempt to create a universal
label: Paragraph

text: city for an individual place while addressing a generalized vision of bodily need. His
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge of history had taught Le Corbusier that such a solution needed to be
label: Paragraph

text: slippery in its semantics offering multiple possible interpretations if it was to stand
label: Paragraph

text: any chance of success over time. It is for this reason that Charles Jencks was partly
label: Paragraph

text: correct to identify Le Corbusier as the first Post Modern architect.
label: Paragraph

text: That Le Corbusier came to understand that there are no universal solutions can be
label: Paragraph

text: seen from a sketch that he made of himself as Don Quixote tilting at the windmills of
label: Paragraph

text: his own ideals (dated 6 October 1953), a drawing that offers much to the profession
label: Paragraph

text: even today. Le Corbusier's early career was spent constructing a vision of world
label: Paragraph

text: order, but it was filled with contradiction and empty assertions. He was not immune
label: Paragraph

text: to the pressures caused by finance, politics, and fashion. During his late career he
label: Paragraph

text: came to understand the futility of pursuing his early vision, but the importance of
label: Paragraph

text: pursuing it anyway. The decisive clash of real and ideal that is the Plan Voisin exem-
label: Paragraph

text: plifies this conundrum perhaps more than any other Le Corbusier scheme.
label: Paragraph
