text: Gently take hold of the legs and pull them toward you in a long, sweeping motion,
label: Paragraph

text: then step inside and ascend into the large, encircling interior. That is roughly how a
label: Paragraph

text: first encounter with Stockholm Public Library would have been — a sensual expe-
label: Paragraph

text: rience leading from the busy urban space into the quiet world of books. As for the
label: Paragraph

text: legs, they belonged to sculptures of Eve and Adam that once served as door handles
label: Paragraph

text: on the entrances.
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm Public Library, which opened on March 31, 1928, was in many ways
label: Paragraph

text: an innovation in the Nordic countries. Most striking was the fact that lenders could
label: Paragraph

text: now take books off the shelves themselves, but the central placement of the lending
label: Paragraph

text: room and the secondary placement of the reading rooms also indicated a new way
label: Paragraph

text: to organize libraries. The thoughts embodied in the building became a model for
label: Paragraph

text: many later libraries.
label: Paragraph

text: The building is not only testimony to an important period of Nordic architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural history and a recognized masterpiece by the Swedish architect Erik Gunnar
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund (1885-1940), it is also part of the history of the Nordic social model that
label: Paragraph

text: was taking shape in the interwar years. Because of its function as a public institution
label: Paragraph

text: and its unique architectural qualities, Stockholm Public Library today stands as an
label: Paragraph

text: early manifestation of Nordic welfare building.
label: Paragraph

text: Building in the City
label: Title

text: Like many other European cities, Stockholm underwent great changes in the early
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth century and Asplund, a writer, editor, and practicing architect, took an
label: Paragraph

text: active part in that development. In a lecture, published in the journal Arkitektur, he
label: Paragraph

text: discussed the city’s monumentality and voiced his skepticism about the expressive
label: Paragraph

text: design of housing facades at the time, which, to his mind, attracted way too much
label: Paragraph

text: attention in the cityscape:
label: Paragraph

text: A city gets its charm from the rhythmic alternation between simple, modest apart-
label: Paragraph

text: ment buildings and monumental public buildings. As in the other arts, where, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, a decorative or sculptural ornament requires a calm, neutral background
label: Paragraph

text: to be displayed to its best advantage, this simple and familiar rule also applies to
label: Paragraph

text: the art of city building |... the effect of a cityscape with a monumental building will
label: Paragraph

text: depend on both its placement in the city plan and its architectural design.’
label: Paragraph

text: In the years around 1920 Asplund’s interest in the city’s development was embo-
label: Paragraph

text: died in his design of the Sédermalm housing development and his competition
label: Paragraph

text: entries for Gétaplatsen, Gustav Adolf Square, and the Royal Chancellery (with
label: Caption

text: Ture Ryberg). In fall 1918, Asplund was appointed to a committee, made possible
label: Paragraph

text: by a grant from the Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation, that would develop
label: Paragraph

text: the groundwork for a public library in Stockholm. Later that year, he wrote
label: Paragraph

text: another polemical article arguing for more thoughtfulness and more comprehen-
label: Paragraph

text: sive solutions in Swedish urban planning. As a positive example, he held up Swe-
label: Paragraph

text: den’s second largest city, Gothenburg, which had organized several competitions
label: Paragraph

text: involving the city’s most important streets, squares, and neighborhoods. Criticizing
label: Paragraph

text: the lack of planning in Stockholm, he mentioned the eastern part of Observator-
label: Paragraph

text: ielunden as one of several sites that were important to the city’s future develop-
label: Paragraph

text: ment.” This was where the library would eventually be located.
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund’s work on the project over the next decade not only shows the great
label: Paragraph

text: care with which he made the building, but also indicates the changes and new direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tions in his architecture in the period. The hill, with its observatory, towers over
label: Paragraph

text: the roofs of the city. It is cut offby two busy thoroughfares, Sveavagen to the north-
label: Paragraph

text: east and Odengatan to the northwest. In his early sketches, Asplund was working
label: Paragraph

text: with a site plan in which a continuous volume along Sveavagen would contain a
label: Paragraph

text: number of different institutions. These did not correspond to the municipal land-
label: Paragraph

text: use plan, which accentuated the corner of the site with a monumental square
label: Paragraph

text: framed by buildings. This plan was published in the journal Byggmdstaren, together
label: Paragraph

text: with three of Asplund’s subsequent proposals, in which the library is a separate
label: Paragraph

text: building with a circle-in-a-square floor plan.’ The site plan for the three proposals
label: Paragraph

text: shows how he first located the building on Sveavagen and then moved it to the
label: Paragraph

text: street corner, before finally placing it on Odengatan with a new orientation of
label: Paragraph

text: the main entrance.
label: Paragraph

text: In the studies of the library’s placement and orientation, the surrounding obser-
label: Paragraph

text: vation hill is likewise shaped in different ways. In the first of the three site plans, the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape is subordinated to an idealized geometry, in which the irregular hill
label: Paragraph

text: would be straightened out into a terraced, rectilinear park with regularly spaced
label: Paragraph

text: vegetation and large staircases. The landscape was made an object of the will to
label: Paragraph

text: organize and rule. In the last of the site plans (and partially in the second), the hill’s
label: Paragraph

text: steep cliffs were left in their natural state, while the north-south axis of the observ-
label: Paragraph

text: atory still contrasted with the symmetrical and rectangular geometry of a park,
label: Paragraph

text: corresponding to the street grid. The areas along the roads on both sides of the
label: Paragraph

text: library would be turned into parkland, and Asplund later won the competition
label: Paragraph

text: to design them, though only the reflecting pond alongside Sveavagen was ever rea-
label: Paragraph

text: lized. Leaving the cliffs as they are creates a unity that equates landscape and build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings in a mutual relationship and to this day contributes to the impression of
label: Paragraph

text: Stockholm as a green city.
label: Paragraph

text: In the subsequent adjustment of the site plan, the building’s square volume,
label: Paragraph

text: which on some schemes was U-shaped in plan, was slightly rotated in relation
label: Paragraph

text: to the orthogonal street grid and thus was geometrically emancipated from the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding residential and commercial buildings. It was also moved forward
label: Paragraph

text: toward Sveavagen, locating the center of the cylindrical volume, which rises over
label: Paragraph

text: the rest of the building and can be seen from a greater distance, on the observa-
label: Paragraph

text: tory’s north-south axis. This volume is the same all the way around and thus is
label: Paragraph

text: perceived as frontal no matter from where it is viewed, giving it the character of a
label: Paragraph

text: fulcrum in the urban structure.
label: Paragraph

text: With historical counterparts in the Rotonde de la Villette by Claude-Nicolas
label: Paragraph

text: Ledoux, the Villa Rotonda by Andrea Palladio, the Castel Sant’Angelo in Rome,
label: Caption

text: and the Lanterna del Faro in Messina, among others, the basic geometric shapes
label: Paragraph

text: of the library lend a forceful impression that, despite their modest size, is capable
label: Paragraph

text: of holding its own against the weight of the hill and the mass of the neighboring
label: Paragraph

text: building blocks. In its urban context, the advanced position and the rotation, as
label: Paragraph

text: Johan Martelius has argued, can be seen as an attempt to establish an extended axis,
label: Paragraph

text: through Adolf Fredrik’s church and Strémgatan’s square, to the Royal Palace.* The
label: Paragraph

text: library’s square and cylindrical volumes sit behind a platform on which shops with
label: Paragraph

text: large glass sections to the street contribute to an inviting and well-defined
label: Paragraph

text: streetscape.
label: Paragraph

text: The ability to design a building based on a multifaceted and complex under-
label: Paragraph

text: standing of the city is manifested in many other projects as well. As Colin St. John
label: Paragraph

text: Wilson explains, “the spirit that informed Asplund’s approach was grounded in a
label: Paragraph

text: rigorous and sensitive interpretation of context. The way in which the strands ofa
label: Paragraph

text: formidable orchestrated order are woven from the grain of the surrounding fabric
label: Paragraph

text: is truly remarkable.”* For Asplund, the act of designing was an extended and
label: Paragraph

text: exploratory process in which the different scales and levels of meaning of the con-
label: Paragraph

text: text were analyzed and gradually worked in, so that the projects were integrated
label: Paragraph

text: into, while simultaneously changing, the context.
label: Paragraph

text: In Collage City, Colin Rowe and Fred Koetter compare Asplund’s competition
label: Paragraph

text: entry for the Royal Chancellery to Le Corbusier’s Plan Voisin. In their view, the
label: Paragraph

text: Chancellery expresses a profound understanding of the city’s historical continu-
label: Paragraph

text: ity and a remarkable sense of its specific details. This is manifested in many of
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund’s works, which Rowe and Koetter consider as having “the most elabo-
label: Paragraph

text: rate use of multiple design strategies.”® These strategies are put into play not
label: Paragraph

text: only in the design of the city, which is their primary interest, but also in how
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund’s projects relate to a great number of other architectural and societal
label: Paragraph

text: conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: The Library’s Gestalt
label: Title

text: Stockholm Public Library came into being out of a desire to create a democratic
label: Paragraph

text: place where anyone could come, regardless of background. It was intended not just
label: Paragraph

text: to inspire and invite those who were already well versed in literature, but also, in
label: Paragraph

text: the words of chief librarian Fredrik Hjelmqvist, to “awaken an interest in those
label: Paragraph

text: who are still slumbering, and it will ease the way into the world of books for
label: Paragraph

text: all of those for whom that road presents difficulties.”” Among its most important
label: Paragraph

text: innovations, Hjelmqvist emphasized the library’s open shelves and card catalogue,
label: Paragraph

text: its openness to users, its separate children’s and youth departments, and the clear
label: Paragraph

text: The axial progression of spaces is familiar from many other building cultures.
label: Paragraph

text: Working from Oswald Spengler’s Untergang des Abendlandes, Asplund discussed this
label: Paragraph

text: in his professorial inaugural lecture at the KTH Royal Institute of Technology in
label: Paragraph

text: 1931: “In Egyptian culture space was seen as a direction, a path, best illustrated,
label: Paragraph

text: according to Spengler, by the temples with their unending narrowing, majestic
label: Paragraph

text: routes between rows of sphinxes, through pillared champers, courtyards and pas-
label: Paragraph

text: sages towards the goal.”’* The desire to allude to Egyptian architecture is not lim-
label: Paragraph

text: ited to this. It is also, more literally, expressed in the exterior frieze and in the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance portals of the three almost identical facades.
label: Paragraph

text: The progression of spaces at the Public Library is characterized not only by an
label: Paragraph

text: axial composition, but also by contrasts between the size and proportions of the
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, the colors and textures of materials, and the direction and intensity of
label: Paragraph

text: the lighting. Contrasts of big and small, hard and soft, and light and dark create
label: Paragraph

text: a forceful transition from the spectacle of the street to the calmness of the interior,
label: Paragraph

text: presenting a wealth of varied and content-rich experiences. The artistic ornamen-
label: Paragraph

text: tation is an integrated part of the spatial progression, from the exterior frieze with
label: Paragraph

text: its subjects from different cultures, to the door handles with Old Testament figures,
label: Paragraph

text: and the interior reliefs, with stories from Homer's Hiad. The aforementioned proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect entry similarly proposed to feature the Greek inscription FNWOI LAYTON
label: Paragraph

text: (Know thyself) on the floor of the lobby. Asplund had observed the statement
label: Paragraph

text: in a building in Rome on his grand tour of France and Italy in 1913-14."*
label: Paragraph

text: In his analysis of Asplund’s architecture, Robert Venturi zeroes in on the
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation: “Much of the early work of Gunnar Asplund and some other early
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth-century architects espoused a non-literal historicism that was expressed
label: Paragraph

text: through representational ornament.”’” It is a telling statement of how Asplund’s
label: Paragraph

text: work was viewed by many in the 1970s and 1980s, who considered it a precursor
label: Paragraph

text: to the stylistic escapades of postmodernism. The myriad narratives of the ornamen-
label: Paragraph

text: tation have fostered many and highly varied interpretations of their meaning. Aside
label: Paragraph

text: from this, they tell parts of the stories that can be borrowed as books in the library,
label: Paragraph

text: potentially arousing curiosity and a desire to learn.
label: Paragraph

text: The exterior of the library is as simple and moderate as its interior is rich in
label: Paragraph

text: texture and detail. The large, serene, plastered volumes with their simple window
label: Paragraph

text: openings tone down the middle scale, and the building assumes the character of an
label: Paragraph

text: abstract, almost alienated object. The Danish architect Steen Eiler Rasmussen
label: Caption

text: described how the simple look induces a figure-ground reading emphasizing the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s lines over its forms.'® The abstract and alienated are counterbalanced
label: Paragraph

text: not only by the building’s integrated placement on the site but also by the colored
label: Paragraph

text: plastering of the facade, which is common in Stockholm and thus, in a very uncom-
label: Paragraph

text: plicated way, ties in to the surroundings, including the observatory.
label: Paragraph

text: The ornamentation on Asplund’s buildings was in part influenced by a way of
label: Paragraph

text: thinking that came from the Romantic period, when artistic motifs from different
label: Paragraph

text: epochs were rather freely used and combined. Though it can justifiably be
label: Paragraph

text: regarded as a potpourri of styles, it also serves spatial and organizing purposes
label: Paragraph

text: in the Public Library. The ornamentation helps to differentiate the importance of
label: Paragraph

text: the spaces and underscore the lines of the building. Asplund had earlier proclaimed
label: Paragraph

text: that “now, more than anything, it seems to be about employing the currently mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern type of architecture, regardless of environment and tradition, and above all not
label: Paragraph

text: falling behind in the ‘architectural race.’ People forget that it is more important to
label: Paragraph

text: follow the style of the site rather than of the times.”'” In other words, he was arguing
label: Paragraph

text: in favor of anchoring architecture in its context. He also distanced himself from the
label: Paragraph

text: tendency to hopelessly pursue the whims of fashion and blindly follow the styles of
label: Paragraph

text: the changing times, not least historicism.
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund was very aware of the relationship between the different scales of a
label: Paragraph

text: building and their contextual cohesion. In his review of the Gothenburg Tercen-
label: Paragraph

text: tennial Jubilee Exposition, he formulated this in an architectural ideal: “Today’s
label: Paragraph

text: architectural desire, at its best, inclines toward a subordination of detail, a coordi-
label: Paragraph

text: nation of all heterogeneous needs and requirements and dimensions under a strong
label: Paragraph

text: architectural idea. Around a central concept. It strives for order and character.”"*
label: Paragraph

text: The notion of having a simple and strong architectural idea for a building was not
label: Paragraph

text: only essential in Asplund’s work; it was also an indispensable principle for many
label: Paragraph

text: other Nordic architects of the twentieth century.
label: Paragraph

text: The above two quotations about the style of the site and architectural desire
label: Paragraph

text: indicate the artistic tensions and paradoxes that marked Asplund and his times. Like
label: Paragraph

text: the rest of Europe, the Nordic countries had contrasting cultural currents and sig-
label: Paragraph

text: nificant social challenges. The downgrading of styles and the subordination of
label: Paragraph

text: detail likewise signaled the impending breakthrough of modernism, which would
label: Paragraph

text: catch up with the library before it had even been completed. Eva Eriksson has aptly
label: Paragraph

text: described how “Nordic 1920s-Classicism can be seen as an heroic attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: employ the knowledge and experience of history, without directly borrowing its
label: Paragraph

text: finished dress, to design the modern city.”??
label: Paragraph

text: Eriksson pinpoints the start of Nordic 1920s classicism to a 1911 Copenhagen exhi-
label: Paragraph

text: bition of works by C.F. Hansen, and she considers Carl Petersen’s Faborg Museum
label: Paragraph

text: from 1915 to be the breakthrough work of the period.”” Henrik O. Andersson and
label: Paragraph

text: Kenneth Frampton argue in a catalogue for a retrospective exhibition in 1982 that the
label: Paragraph

text: currents in architecture and other arts in the rest of Europe and the United States
label: Paragraph

text: helped to lay a foundation for the significant blossoming of classicism in Nordic archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture.”" Moreover, there was considerable exchange in the field of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: among the Nordic countries in the period, not least due to their closely related lan-
label: Paragraph

text: guages, geographical proximity, and shared cultural heritage. For example, Danish
label: Paragraph

text: architect Kay Fisker wrote about new Swedish architecture in the Danish journal
label: Paragraph

text: Arkitekten, after working for Asplund and Lewerentz for a time.” Conversely,
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund reviewed a Danish book about the old manor house of Liselund that
label: Paragraph

text: had served as an important source of inspiration for his Woodland chapel. The book
label: Paragraph

text: included measured drawings by Kay Fisker, Aage Refn, and others, and was
label: Paragraph

text: reviewed in the Swedish journal Arkitektur.”* These are just some of the countless
label: Paragraph

text: examples of the exchanges between architects in the Nordic countries.
label: Paragraph

text: In the exhibition catalogue, Frampton further describes how this period of Nor-
label: Paragraph

text: dic architecture was characterized by a Doric sensibility that “intended a return to
label: Paragraph

text: an accessible culture of building; to an expression which, despite its modesty,
label: Paragraph

text: aspired to a certain restrained monumentality and generally employed a sparse
label: Paragraph

text: but nonetheless direct iconography.” In this sensibility, Frampton says, classical
label: Paragraph

text: and vernacular architecture could be combined into new architectural expressions.
label: Paragraph

text: Relating the architecture to a sensibility, rather than a stylistic preference, allows
label: Paragraph

text: the identification of common traits across its highly varied buildings. The exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion catalogue features works by the most important architects, including, in addi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to Asplund, Carl G. Bergsten, Sigurd Lewerentz, and Ivar Tengbom of
label: Paragraph

text: Sweden; Gudolf Blakstad, Herman Munthe-Kaas, and Lorentz Ree of Norway;
label: Paragraph

text: Alvar Aalto, Erik Bryggman, and Johan Sigfrid Sirén of Finland; and Hack Kamp-
label: Paragraph

text: mann, Carl Petersen, and Edvard Thomsen of Denmark, along with many others
label: Paragraph

text: from each of the Nordic countries.
label: Paragraph

text: Swedish architecture of the first half of the interwar years received some inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national attention, among other ways with Bergsten’s pavilion at the 1925 Paris
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition Internationale des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes. The exposition
label: Caption

text: also introduced Nordic architects to the burgeoning European modernism embo-
label: Paragraph

text: died in Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret’s Esprit Nouveau pavilion. Architects
label: Caption

text: who were unable to see the pavilion for themselves could read about it and the
label: Paragraph

text: most recent trends in architecture later that year in Uno Ahrén’s seminal article,
label: Paragraph

text: “Taming Points.””’ Swedish architecture of the 1920s also became known by
label: Paragraph

text: the term “Swedish Grace,” coined by Morton Shand in a discussion of
label: Paragraph

text: European architecture and decorative arts.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning a New Era
label: Title

text: “The Public Library now stands as the termination and peak of a period, as the City
label: Paragraph

text: Hall does of the preceding. Neo-Classicism is over,””” Ahrén wrote in his 1928
label: Paragraph

text: review of Asplund’s building. Continuing his critique of the library and other build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings of the 1920s, Ahrén argued, “Swedish architecture of this period was driven by
label: Paragraph

text: a longing to find clear expressions for the architectural functions, but this striving
label: Paragraph

text: was hard to reconcile with, and thus was counteracted by, an oddly powerful a
label: Paragraph

text: priori view of how architecture should look.” In his review, he focused on the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s style more than its functions — despite an aim for “a radical functional
label: Paragraph

text: outlook” — and found the ornamentation particularly problematic.”* As on previous
label: Paragraph

text: occasions, he made himself a spokesman for modernism, and in that regard he
label: Paragraph

text: considered the library hopelessly outdated.
label: Paragraph

text: Eva Eriksson has argued that Stockholm Public Library, in terms of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: history, can be read in three different ways: as a masterpiece of the period before
label: Paragraph

text: the breakthrough of modernism, as a heterogeneous work balancing between
label: Paragraph

text: tradition and modernity, or as an unresolved and conflicting work stretched
label: Paragraph

text: between two radically different world views. The latter is grounded in Ahrén’s
label: Paragraph

text: criticism, which concluded with this verdict: “This building does not stand on
label: Paragraph

text: the boundary between two minor fashion trends in Swedish architecture, as
label: Paragraph

text: some may contend, but between two phases of profound differences in
label: Paragraph

text: mentality.””?
label: Paragraph

text: Two drawings of the library, which were used to illustrate Hjelmqvist’s article in
label: Paragraph

text: Ord och Bild and Ahrén’s article in Byggmdstaren, respectively, show the change that
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund’s architecture was going through when the building opened. Drawn from
label: Paragraph

text: approximately the same angle, the first drawing represents the building in a wealth
label: Paragraph

text: of details and with surrounding vegetation, while the second is highly simplified,
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizing the building’s horizontal lines. The latter, in other words, shows a
label: Paragraph

text: quasi-modernist building. The platform, which was not built until after the library
label: Paragraph

text: had opened, in its transparency, light color, and absence of ornament, expresses the
label: Paragraph

text: change that was underway, and as such is closer to the stylistic ideal that would
label: Paragraph

text: dominate in the years to follow.
label: Paragraph

text: Only two years after the completion of the Public Library, the Stockholm Exhi-
label: Paragraph

text: bition opened in 1930, with Asplund as chief architect. Though hardly the first
label: Paragraph

text: modernist work, the exhibition came to stand as the introduction of modernism
label: Paragraph

text: in the Nordic countries. More than anything, the exhibition was a popular and pro-
label: Paragraph

text: fessional success that helped modernist buildings become widely accepted among
label: Paragraph

text: the populace. Employing a vocabulary of large glass sections, steel beams and gir-
label: Paragraph

text: ders, white-plastered surfaces, and colorful banners, the architecture heralded a
label: Paragraph

text: new age to visitors. It was supplemented by an abundance of exhibited applied-
label: Paragraph

text: art objects and industrial products. The new vocabulary notwithstanding, Asplund
label: Paragraph

text: and many of the other exhibition’s architects showcased a unique sense of propor-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, form, and composition, based on their experiences from the 1910s and 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: As in other periods of major transition, Nordic architecture was characterized by
label: Paragraph

text: continuity rather than distinct breaks.
label: Paragraph

text: Next to the Public Library, the Stockholm Exhibition represents an uncom-
label: Paragraph

text: monly quick and quite significant change of architectural expression for
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund. Most obvious are the rejection of traditional decorative elements
label: Paragraph

text: and the use of glass, steel, and concrete instead, which were considered the most
label: Paragraph

text: important materials of the day. More striking, however, is the change from a
label: Paragraph

text: predominantly stereometric to an explicitly tectonic approach. This change of
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary for Asplund not only expressed an authentic interest in the new pos-
label: Paragraph

text: sibilities but also a persistent striving to explore the recurring challenges of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural gestalt.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition attracted a lot of attention beyond Sweden. In the Danish journal
label: Paragraph

text: Arkitekten, Aage Refn, who co-designed the Copenhagen Police Headquarters, dis-
label: Paragraph

text: cussed the exhibition in relation to Asplund’s other works and described it as “fes-
label: Paragraph

text: tive, light, and elegant.”*° Like Morton Shand in Architectural Review, the editors of
label: Paragraph

text: the Norwegian journal Byggekunst were far less positive in their review,”’ while in
label: Paragraph

text: Finland, Alvar Aalto, who had been strongly inspired by Asplund in the previous
label: Paragraph

text: decade and had closely followed the genesis of the exhibition, related his experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ence as follows:
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition speaks out for joyful and spontaneous everyday life. It consistently
label: Paragraph

text: propagates a healthy and unpretentious lifestyle based on economical realities.
label: Paragraph

text: [...] The Stockholm Exhibition proclaims the contemporary artist's determination
label: Paragraph

text: to create objects for present-day needs and acceptable values, making use of the
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of Swedish society.””
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto goes on to say that Sigfried Giedion, comparing the Stockholm Exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: to Mies van der Rohe’s Weissenhof Exhibition in Stuttgart, reportedly described it
label: Paragraph

text: “as a concerted effort, no other exhibition can compete with this.”’’ It was one of
label: Paragraph

text: the few Nordic projects that made it into Henry-Russell Hitchcock and Philip John-
label: Paragraph

text: son’s exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: book The International Style. The other Nordic buildings were Aalto’s Turun Sano-
label: Paragraph

text: mat, Ahrén’s Flamman Theatre and Students’ Clubhouse (with Sven Markelius),
label: Paragraph

text: and Eskil Sundahl’s Cooperative Society Siedlung.**
label: Paragraph

text: The following year, it was also Asplund, Ahrén, Markelius, and Sundahl who,
label: Paragraph

text: with chief curator of the Stockholm Exhibition, Gregor Paulsson, and the architect,
label: Paragraph

text: Wolter Gahn, published acceptera, which is considered Sweden’s most important
label: Paragraph

text: architectural manifesto. The book opens with the words: “accept the reality that
label: Paragraph

text: exists — only in that way have we any prospect of mastering it, taking it in hand,
label: Paragraph

text: and altering it to create culture that offers an adaptable tool for life.”*” The six wri-
label: Paragraph

text: ters contend that architecture should play a central role in that development, as had
label: Paragraph

text: also been expressed in the exhibition. In chapters on culture, society, homes, stand-
label: Paragraph

text: ardization, and so on, they discuss a long list of contemporaneous issues. Although
label: Paragraph

text: the book points in many directions, they share a common goal:
label: Paragraph

text: The organization of the world’s resources and the improvement and stabilization of
label: Title

text: the living conditions of individuals are what we are working toward. But these are
label: Paragraph

text: merely means to enable richer lives to be led. If that end is distant, we have to make
label: Paragraph

text: even greater endeavors to perfect the means.”
label: Paragraph

text: The development toward modernism was not without conflict and was far from
label: Paragraph

text: desirable for all Nordic architects. Apart from Ahrén’s 1925 article, the Norwegian
label: Paragraph

text: architect Johan Ellefsen, in his essay, “What is Contemporary Architecture?” and
label: Paragraph

text: the Danish architect Poul Henningsen, in his essay, “Tradition and Modernism,” both
label: Paragraph

text: from 1927, contributed to the debate in their respective homelands on the side of the
label: Paragraph

text: new architecture.’’ In Sweden, part of the debate came to be fought between so-called
label: Paragraph

text: traditionalists and functionalists. The latter designation, shortened to “Funkis,” was
label: Paragraph

text: later applied to Nordic modernism of the second half of the interwar years.
label: Paragraph

text: Rather than just seeing Stockholm Public Library as a masterpiece preceding the
label: Paragraph

text: breakthrough of modernism, a work straddling tradition and modernity, or one
label: Paragraph

text: falling between two different world views, the building should be seen as the begin-
label: Paragraph

text: ning of a new era of Nordic architecture. From the 1920s onward, a new social
label: Paragraph

text: structure was emerging. Known as the Nordic model, it became extremely impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant to the development of architecture and the built environment. A significant
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of this development was the role played by the governments of the Nordic
label: Paragraph

text: countries as initiators and clients of public institutions in the making of a welfare
label: Paragraph

text: system. Through large investments in buildings for these institutions, the govern-
label: Paragraph

text: ments managed to serve as a model for the rest of society, or as Aalto put it, “one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most important functions of public architecture is to set an example.”** In the
label: Paragraph

text: Nordic countries it was broadly accepted that investments in buildings for the wel-
label: Paragraph

text: fare system was for the common good.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from public libraries, the welfare system included a number of other pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lic institutions, such as hospitals, senior and childcare facilities, schools and univer-
label: Paragraph

text: sities, and houses of art and culture. While in other Western countries it had been
label: Paragraph

text: left to private initiative to build and operate some of these institutions, in the Nor-
label: Paragraph

text: dic countries this was considered a job for the government. There has been a high
label: Paragraph

text: degree of societal consensus on this issue, which has aided the political and eco-
label: Paragraph

text: nomical continuity in the Nordic countries.
label: Paragraph

text: With the exception of Bredenberg department store, a project raised on pillars
label: Paragraph

text: and featuring horizontal bands of windows, Asplund himself did not dwell long
label: Paragraph

text: upon the new architectural vocabulary he had so powerfully showcased with
label: Paragraph

text: the Stockholm Exhibition. In the following decade he was mainly occupied with
label: Paragraph

text: his projects for the Gothenburg Courthouse, which he had won in 1913, and
label: Paragraph

text: the Woodland Crematorium at the Woodland Cemetery, which he had won (with
label: Paragraph

text: Lewerentz) in 1915. The working process and final form of these two lifelong pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects show how he continued to explore new paths. In 1940, Asplund put the fin-
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Revising the
label: Title

text: Modern Project

text: INnNtroauction
label: Title

text: CONSTRUCTING NEW WORLDS
label: Title

text: David Leatherbarrow
label: Title

text: The optimism and ambition that defined the project(s) of early modern architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture were not abandoned in the late 1920s and 1930s, only revised. New worlds
label: Paragraph

text: resulting from projects attuned to modern realities were still envisaged, but they
label: Paragraph

text: were no longer imagined to be wholly new, or the responsibility of single
label: Paragraph

text: designers. Adhesions to pre-existing conditions came to be seen as inevitable when
label: Paragraph

text: actual sites, programs, materials, and builders were used as instruments of project
label: Paragraph

text: realization. Furthermore, just as projects could not free themselves from inherited
label: Paragraph

text: culture, they were rarely, if ever, realized in full. Non-finality came to be seen as the
label: Paragraph

text: norm rather than the exception. Acceptance of this double contingency — of histor-
label: Paragraph

text: ical continuity and shared authority — marked a significant shift in the understand-
label: Paragraph

text: ing of an architectural project; the work of design and construction came to be seen
label: Paragraph

text: as less emancipated, more engaged. Was the new attitude defeatist? From a stri-
label: Paragraph

text: dently avant-garde stance, acceptance of a project’s “practical” conditions might
label: Paragraph

text: seem so. But given the beauty, intelligence, and cultural richness of these buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: such an assessment makes little sense. We need to ask how a project’s circum-
label: Paragraph

text: stances not only conditioned but enriched its development.
label: Paragraph

text: Decades ago interpreters of modern architecture observed a “turn toward the
label: Paragraph

text: organic” in the buildings of the late 1920s and 1930s, and also a “return to order.”
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, more recent studies, including those in earlier chapters in this book, have
label: Paragraph

text: shown that architectures of the preceding two decades were also concerned with
label: Paragraph

text: the “organic” or natural world — less its appearance, however, than its processes and
label: Paragraph

text: structure — and that there was no absence of thinking about architectural order
label: Paragraph

text: before the “heroic” period, even if conceptions of order were often reduced to tech-
label: Paragraph

text: niques of ordering. The “organic” and the “mechanic” aspects of early modern
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were not seen as categorically distinct,’ and there was hardly a return
label: Paragraph

text: to order when many architects sought nothing so intently. How, then, did the
label: Paragraph

text: designs of the next decades differ? In short, the building’s place, program, materials,
label: Paragraph

text: and modes of production came to be seen as conditions that would strengthen its
label: Paragraph

text: development, despite the fact that they also complicated its idea. The key point is
label: Paragraph

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: that order was discovered in the world, not only in the project. The passage from
label: Paragraph

text: imagining to constructing also meant revising the architect’s sense of the project’s
label: Paragraph

text: autonomy. What had been independent became involved. Insofar as projects were co-
label: Paragraph

text: determined by conditions the architect could not control the results were hybrid,
label: Paragraph

text: jointly-authored, and often unfinished; if less pure they were also often more rel-
label: Paragraph

text: evant; if compromised technically, they expressed great ingenuity, and they were
label: Paragraph

text: good to look at, move through, and think about.
label: Paragraph

text: To introduce the productive role of the project’s place, program, and construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion let me outline some of the ways this period’s key buildings benefited from
label: Paragraph

text: their encounter with conditions outside their designers’ control.
label: Paragraph

text: The coordination between a project and its location took a number of forms in
label: Paragraph

text: the built work of these years. The most obvious sort of connection was visual: the
label: Paragraph

text: site presented itself through a series of views, around the building and from within
label: Paragraph

text: it. The heated debates about the “pros and cons” of the horizontal window, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, took for granted the importance of the landscape or urban prospect.”
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier argued for the first sort of view, Auguste Perret the second. Similarly,
label: Paragraph

text: a chief function of a ribbon, sash, or “French” window was to frame a view. Perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: the most famous instance of the aperture’s framing function is the “window” that
label: Paragraph

text: concludes the Villa Savoye’s promenade architecturale. Window walls, by contrast,
label: Paragraph

text: opened entire panoramas. No less common than discussions of framing were the
label: Paragraph

text: many accounts of “merging” or “connecting” interiors to their surroundings for the
label: Paragraph

text: sake of views. In all of these examples the wider context was understood as a pic-
label: Paragraph

text: ture. But that was not the only sense of the site at this time.
label: Paragraph

text: The project’s location was also understood dynamically, which is to say as a play
label: Paragraph

text: of environmental forces; particularly, light, wind, and temperature. Design and
label: Paragraph

text: construction now entered into this play, into its sequences, transformations, and
label: Paragraph

text: variations. Patterns could be discerned — days and seasons, for example — but
label: Paragraph

text: the key principle was alteration, the outcome of which was development or dete-
label: Paragraph

text: rioration. Let me explain this more fully by citing a few examples that are studied in
label: Paragraph

text: the chapters that follow.
label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller is known to have viewed the natural and built worlds very
label: Paragraph

text: widely — unusually so, one could say. Distances and dimensions were taken to be
label: Paragraph

text: significant, but also the movements and energies at play in the great expanse. Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: characterized the ambient landscape as a “field of forces” or animated context that
label: Paragraph

text: not only posed the problem but also determined the success of any built work. He
label: Paragraph

text: focused on the selection and sizing of construction materials, particularly new and
label: Paragraph

text: lightweight materials, as AnnMarie Brennan shows. Even the term he used for his
label: Paragraph

text: best known inventions, dymaxion, points in this direction: it couples maximum
label: Paragraph

text: yield with the dynamism of elements. The energies of the work were to harmonize
label: Paragraph

text: with those of the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Something less than a planetary horizon could also allow the building site to be
label: Paragraph

text: understood as an interaction of natural forces. Approaching the topic more locally —
label: Paragraph

text: and with both industrial and vernacular construction materials — Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: in his study of Fallingwater. There is no question that the views from the house
label: Paragraph

text: were breathtaking, as was the prospect of it from the lower level of the falls.
label: Paragraph

text: But the process-character of the place was equally important. Levine shows that
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s concern for the site’s temporality led him to synchronize the times of
label: Paragraph

text: occupation with those of the daily cycles, adjusting the geometry of the plan to
label: Paragraph

text: the path of the sun, lines on the ground with those in the sky. Wright had, of course,
label: Paragraph

text: been working with diagonal composition for years; it was one of the outcomes of
label: Paragraph

text: “breaking the box” (of enclosed orthogonality). But in this and other projects of the
label: Paragraph

text: time, ideas for spatial layout developed in dialogue with conditions he had not
label: Paragraph

text: designed but was compelled to work with — natural conditions. Later he described
label: Paragraph

text: the principle that regulated this cooperative effort as the “organic ground motive.”
label: Paragraph

text: Once the project’s location was understood as both a set of views and play of
label: Paragraph

text: forces a number of basic tasks presented themselves, the first of which was orien-
label: Paragraph

text: tation. Randall Ott explains that the buildings sited near the Goetheneum were
label: Paragraph

text: carefully positioned with respect to one another, each in its own spot, but also fac-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the “gravitational center” of the constellation. Because the main building occu-
label: Paragraph

text: pied the hilltop, the ensemble’s overall layout was thus co-determined by pre-
label: Paragraph

text: existing topography, institutional requirements being the other determining factor.
label: Paragraph

text: The role of topography in the configuration and detailed articulation of a single
label: Paragraph

text: building can be seen clearly in Eileen Gray’s layout of E.1027, as described by
label: Paragraph

text: Caroline Constant. She explains that while Gray conceived the house from inside
label: Paragraph

text: to outside, opportunities of the location were used as counterparts to interior spe-
label: Paragraph

text: cifications and qualification — the seaside site partly determined qualities of light,
label: Paragraph

text: temperature, and air in the house’s several settings, as well as their degrees of inti-
label: Paragraph

text: macy or openness. The living room, for example, enjoyed southern exposure; the
label: Paragraph

text: bedrooms, on the other hand, were greeted by the morning sun. Views of the
label: Paragraph

text: ocean were also important, of course. But while the apertures were designed to
label: Paragraph

text: respond to opportunities of prospect, they also had to protect the interiors against
label: Paragraph

text: glare and winds, allowing some and resisting others.
label: Paragraph

text: In his account of Villa Savoye, Richard Wesley explains that the building’s dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferent framing instruments variously targeted the wide panorama and axes of view,
label: Paragraph

text: even if the terminal point (a historic monument) framed by the famous solarium
label: Paragraph

text: window could rarely, if ever, be seen. But the screen wall performed environmen-
label: Paragraph

text: tally, too; it sheltered plants and people against the wind, while it partially enclosed
label: Paragraph

text: open-air rooms. A viewing frame also opened the wall that enclosed the roof deck
label: Paragraph

text: of Adolf Loos’ Miiller Villa. Christopher Long explains that it framed a prospect of
label: Paragraph

text: Hradéany that included Prague Castle. The enclosing wall opposite this one sup-
label: Paragraph

text: ported an open-air shower, presumably for use after sunbathing. The attractions of
label: Paragraph

text: a closer vista, however, help explain why Loos reversed the typical orientation of
label: Paragraph

text: the house, shifting the main salon from the entry front to the opposite side, where
label: Paragraph

text: its windows and balcony could open onto the descending terraces of the villa’s gar-
label: Paragraph

text: den in the foreground, a thoroughfare in the lower, middle distance, and a land-
label: Paragraph

text: scape garden beyond. In fact, each of the four facades was distinct, precisely
label: Paragraph

text: rr: sb : es es Ce Ce a ee © i oe
label: Title

text: ae
label: Title

text: relative privacy, and so on. Nothing could be further from the truth than the
label: Paragraph

text: old idea that this building was disengaged from its location. Care for ambient
label: Paragraph

text: views was coupled with attention to patterns of use and environmental change.
label: Paragraph

text: In the buildings of Le Corbusier, Gray, Loos, and Wright, “rituals of living” were
label: Paragraph

text: coordinated with the cycles of daily and seasonal change in the natural
label: Paragraph

text: environment.
label: Paragraph

text: Engagement such as this did not restrict invention. Reversals of typical patterns
label: Paragraph

text: of site development discovered unforeseen possibilities in the project’s location.
label: Paragraph

text: A case in point is Richard Neutra’s siting of the VDL house. Edward Ford explains
label: Paragraph

text: that Neutra broke from the habit of placing the house in the middle of its lot, where
label: Paragraph

text: front, side, and rear yards had similar dimensions and character. By pushing the
label: Paragraph

text: plan close to two of the boundaries he was able to develop an elaborate layout
label: Paragraph

text: of courts and gardens that extended interiors into complimentary outdoor settings.
label: Paragraph

text: Insofar as the “flow of space” from inside to outside was virtually uninterrupted,
label: Paragraph

text: the interiors were largely qualified by site conditions (of light, air, plantings, and so
label: Paragraph

text: on). The same sort of thing happened in urban settings in the work of other archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects. Grace Ong explains that the street front of the PSFS building enclosed public
label: Paragraph

text: spaces at several levels -subway, sidewalk, and mezzanine — all public and all inter-
label: Paragraph

text: connected. Although there was no precedent for stratification such as this in
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia, the discovery of these new possibilities made the proposal attractive
label: Paragraph

text: to clients, who saw its commercial advantages. But with respect to the history of
label: Paragraph

text: urban architecture, this manner of engaging and developing the vicinity also
label: Paragraph

text: allowed the solution to serve as a model for later projects in this and other
label: Paragraph

text: American cities. And the innovations at the lower levels were complemented by
label: Paragraph

text: new solutions above, for the large sign was designed by Howe and Lescaze to
label: Paragraph

text: be seen from blocks away (along a cross-city avenue on one side and from a bridge
label: Paragraph

text: on the other). Here, as before, the actual site provided architects with “un-
label: Paragraph

text: designed” conditions that served as the grounds for project development. Projects
label: Paragraph

text: in these years, one can say, developed eccentrically; a work’s source of order was
label: Paragraph

text: outside its proper limits, the margins shaped and qualified the center.
label: Paragraph

text: The more we learn about the actual construction of the buildings of the “heroic”
label: Paragraph

text: period of modern architecture the more we see that later historians have been
label: Paragraph

text: more dogmatic about materials and methods of construction than the architects
label: Paragraph

text: themselves. No doubt the architects initiated the familiar — if now discredited —
label: Paragraph

text: story about “modern” materials (steel, concrete, and glass) and “modern” means
label: Paragraph

text: of construction (standardization, prefabrication, and dry assembly) determining
label: Paragraph

text: the “evolution” of modernism. Yet, the apologists went much further than the
label: Paragraph

text: designers, in some cases to the point of obscuring the subject matter of their
label: Paragraph

text: descriptions — the buildings themselves. Richard Wesley explains how Sigfried
label: Paragraph

text: Giedion, for example, rewrote and reduced Le Corbusier’s Five (or Six) Points
label: Paragraph

text: for a New Architecture so that they would express more forcefully his
label: Paragraph

text: notion of building technology as the engine that powered the modern movement.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier was far less dogmatic. The “points,” such as they were, only
label: Paragraph

text: and its outer surface was stucco. No less hybrid was the most representative work of
label: Paragraph

text: his former teacher, Adolf Loos’ Villa Miiller in Prague. Loos did not share Neutra’s
label: Paragraph

text: dedication to the newest products, but he was equally willing to integrate ways of
label: Paragraph

text: building we tend to see as categorically distinct. The structure of the Miller Villa
label: Paragraph

text: combined perimeter brickwork with cast-in-place concrete columns toward the cen-
label: Paragraph

text: ter, a so-called “half-box” system with outside load-bearing walls and two longitu-
label: Paragraph

text: dinal frames inside the plan (the Hennebique system). A spatial idea — the
label: Paragraph

text: Raumplan, which allowed varying floor and ceiling heights — required the insertion
label: Paragraph

text: of the different means of support where level changes were desired. Loos feltnoneed
label: Paragraph

text: to “reveal” or “express” the structure; more important was the accommodation and
label: Paragraph

text: representation of the building’s use program. A mixture of building materials and
label: Paragraph

text: techniques was the result, nevertheless. A simple, pure, or self-evidently modern
label: Paragraph

text: way of building was far less important than careful attunement to ways of living —
label: Paragraph

text: patterns that were, of course, of their time.
label: Paragraph

text: The buildings studied in the chapters that follow were designed to accommodate
label: Paragraph

text: and express ways of living that were partly modern and partly traditional. Possibi-
label: Paragraph

text: lities were projected, of course, patterns of life that might be present and may have
label: Paragraph

text: occurred in the past; but ways of living nonetheless. One cannot overlook the
label: Paragraph

text: impracticality of many of these buildings, even those that are most well known.
label: Paragraph

text: If the Villa Savoye is to be seen as a machine for living, the term should be under-
label: Paragraph

text: stood theatrically not mechanistically. Richard Wesley describes it as a “contriv-
label: Paragraph

text: ance for producing the effect of dwelling.” But the tension between expression
label: Paragraph

text: and accommodation is one of degree. Caroline Constant describes Eileen Gray’s
label: Paragraph

text: focus on quotidian comfort and sensuality. This concentration resulted from her
label: Paragraph

text: desire to overcome the dehumanizing qualities of architecture based on abstrac-
label: Paragraph

text: tion. The alternative represented by E.1027 was care for human needs and the exi-
label: Paragraph

text: gencies of life, a concern for intimacy that did not prevent enjoyment of the natural
label: Paragraph

text: world. For Loos, the concern with inhabitation led to specific structural solutions
label: Paragraph

text: that allowed for great differentiation of settings. The floors of the Miiller Villa can
label: Paragraph

text: best be seen, Christopher Long argues, as stacked, rotating platforms; props to be
label: Paragraph

text: elaborated and qualified by materials, dimensions, and furnishings that would suit
label: Paragraph

text: intended purposes. His idea of each setting having its own character or mood is
label: Paragraph

text: close to the argument put forth by Alvar and Aino Aalto at Villa Mairea, for there
label: Paragraph

text: the modern way of building was not an exercise in standardized construction per se
label: Paragraph

text: but in the formation of “character, identity, and milieu.” Scott Poole shows that the
label: Paragraph

text: Villa was, indeed, innovative; not in the sense of earlier experiments with form and
label: Paragraph

text: geometry but rather in its ever more precise attunements to the habits of the
label: Paragraph

text: human body, resting and moving within the building’s several settings.
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Neutra took a different approach to the task of accommodating prac-
label: Paragraph

text: tical purposes. Edward Ford shows that the plans and sections of the VDL House
label: Paragraph

text: did not specify the functions of rooms. Neutra thought of purposes and settings
label: Paragraph

text: rather more “elastically.” But corresponding to this sense of spatial generality was
label: Paragraph

text: a highly analytical — Neutra once criticized himself for being overly fond of
label: Paragraph

text: “systematic consistency”* — sense of bodily movements, postures, perceptions,
label: Paragraph

text: and emotions. One can certainly identify typical forms and geometries in his
label: Paragraph

text: work, but he maintained that his chief goal was responsiveness to sensory motor
label: Paragraph

text: conditions. A similarly generalized sense of rooms can be seen in Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: work, particularly Villa Savoye. Richard Wesley alludes to this in his comments
label: Paragraph

text: on that building’s “free plan,” which could be described as a configuration that
label: Paragraph

text: was free-from fully defined enclosures so that it would be free-for rather more
label: Paragraph

text: idealized patterns, those of an artistic type of person, for whom creativity and
label: Paragraph

text: modernity would be realized though mediated, conditioned, and engaged ways
label: Paragraph

text: of making and living.
label: Paragraph

text: The fact that these buildings acknowledged the continuity of ways of living, the
label: Paragraph

text: hybridity of building practices, and the dependence of interior on site conditions
label: Paragraph

text: suggests that another sense of the architectural project had force in these years:
label: Paragraph

text: inventive because involved.

text: GOETHEANUM
label: Title

text: Rudolf Steiner
label: Title

text: Randall Ott
label: Title

text: Rudolph Steiner, Second Goetheanum, Dornach, Switzerland, 1928.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: A first glimpse of Rudolf Steiner’s existing concrete Goetheanum near Basel still
label: Paragraph

text: causes awe nearly a century after its inception. Resting with imposing bulk upon
label: Paragraph

text: its hilltop, this organically sculptural monolith seems not so much dormant as
label: Paragraph

text: quietly brooding. Nature itself here appears to ripple its musculature and consider
label: Paragraph

text: rising up, yet instead settles back into a foreboding posture of watching and wait-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. We sense a cryptic messenger of profound yet still untimely import — a gray
label: Paragraph

text: gargoyle lodged in its aerie, holding a societal key for which the day-to-day world
label: Paragraph

text: remains unready.
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner was a philosopher who also produced — like Ludwig Wittgenstein — a
label: Paragraph

text: salient architectural act. Understanding such a building first necessitates that the
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual stage be set. Today the Goetheanum serves as an active cultural center
label: Paragraph

text: for, and the eminent physical expression of, Steiner’s guiding creed — anthroposo-
label: Paragraph

text: phy. A knowledge of this underlying movement is essential in order to grasp what
label: Paragraph

text: is effectively a cult building manifesting Steiner’s desire to remake society in his
label: Paragraph

text: own compelling image.
label: Paragraph

text: As well as being a philosopher, Steiner was a scientist, spiritualist, Goethe scholar,
label: Paragraph

text: and one of the twentieth century’s most controversial and passionate reformers.
label: Paragraph

text: Few aspects of human endeavor escaped this consummate polymath’s active study,
label: Paragraph

text: mastery, and reconceptualization. A modern Uomo Universale, he examined medi-
label: Paragraph

text: cine, organic farming, education, physical and mental therapy, banking, and social
label: Title

text: activism.’ Often he loosely attached the word “scientific” to his theories; he chal-
label: Paragraph

text: lenged his listeners to verify empirically his suggestions.” Many of his progressive
label: Paragraph

text: projects remain active today, particularly in schooling and in homes for children
label: Paragraph

text: and adults with developmental disabilities.* His missionary zeal to improve human-
label: Paragraph

text: ity led to the founding of anthroposophy, an early twentieth-century offshoot of the
label: Paragraph

text: wider late nineteenth-century esoteric movement of theosophy.
label: Paragraph

text: A phenomenally prolific author and speaker, Steiner’s collected writings run to
label: Paragraph

text: several hundred volumes and his known lectures into the thousands. Eventually he
label: Paragraph

text: expanded his horizons far beyond bookish or technical pursuits and directly
label: Paragraph

text: embraced the arts, which were necessary to any totalizing, humanistic system
label: Paragraph

text: and could help attract converts. Dramas of his own creation — mystery plays —
label: Paragraph

text: became crucial to the early anthroposophical rite. Over time, he began working
label: Paragraph

text: directly in other performance and visual modes: music, dance, verse, sculpture,
label: Paragraph

text: and painting. While lecturing, he often created astonishing blackboard drawings
label: Paragraph

text: of colored chalk; many were preserved and now are considered worthy of exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and monographic treatment in their own right.*
label: Paragraph

text: Of all the visual arts, architecture rose to become central; while not a profession-
label: Paragraph

text: ally trained architect, Steiner developed considerable skill in design and awarded
label: Paragraph

text: architecture pride of place in his aesthetics.” The Goetheanum enshrines his belief
label: Paragraph

text: that buildings can heal and morally benefit humans.° Yet the world is perhaps even
label: Paragraph

text: less ready for Steiner’s proposed transformation today than it was in his time. So,
label: Paragraph

text: the weighty Goetheanum continues to sit above us in silent witness, a prophetic
label: Paragraph

text: work now rendered a tourist destination yet still vaguely worrisome — rather like
label: Paragraph

text: Paolo Soleri’s “Arcosanti” in the Arizona desert half a century later.”
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner's Path toward Anthroposophy
label: Title

text: Born in 1861, in Kraljevic, Austria (now Croatia), Steiner was an early intellectual
label: Paragraph

text: prodigy. At the Vienna Institute of Technology, he studied mathematics, physics,
label: Paragraph

text: chemistry, botany, and biology, but also showed interest in the more humanistic
label: Paragraph

text: realms of literature and philosophy. At the tender age of 21, on the recommenda-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of a professor, Steiner was named natural sciences editor of a new edition of
label: Paragraph

text: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe’s collected works in 1882. Goethe thus gave Steiner’s
label: Paragraph

text: journey first focus. In 1888, Steiner was invited to Weimar’s Goethe archive,
label: Paragraph

text: remaining there until 1896. While in residence, Steiner produced additional com-
label: Paragraph

text: mentaries about Goethe’s scientific ideas and began writing books about Goethe’s
label: Paragraph

text: wider philosophy. One of these, Steiner’s The Theory of Knowledge Implicit in Goethe’s
label: Paragraph

text: World-Conception (1886), set out the epistemological foundation of Steiner’s mature
label: Paragraph

text: thinking.
label: Paragraph

text: Goethe’s seminal study, The Metamorphosis of Plants (1790), had a particularly
label: Paragraph

text: strong impact on Steiner. Here, Goethe searched for biological archetypes — core
label: Paragraph

text: forms (Urpflanze) that metamorphose into the diversity of organic life. Goethe
label: Paragraph

text: described how homologous plant organs evolve from cotyledon, to photosynthetic
label: Paragraph

text: leaf, to a flower’s petals. Sequential growth became a key concept for Steiner, pro-
label: Paragraph

text: voking a lifelong interest in movement, sculptural form, and metamorphosis.*
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner came to see buildings as analogous to living organisms.” Such ideas were then
label: Paragraph

text: in currency, as shown by “empathy theory” (Einfiihlungstheorie), which suggested that
label: Paragraph

text: a building’s spatial movement can mimic and also directly affect people’s physical and
label: Paragraph

text: psychic states and perceptions.’” Goethe had other diverse impacts on Steiner, his
label: Paragraph

text: theory of color, for instance. Steiner, like Goethe, felt that color imparts inherent
label: Paragraph

text: movement to static forms, causing them to approach or recede.’ But perhaps most
label: Paragraph

text: importantly, Steiner came to share Goethe’s beliefin the physical and spiritual duality
label: Paragraph

text: of nature; gradually he began to develop a holistic “cosmology” based on this prem-
label: Paragraph

text: ise.'* Steiner began to perceive a grand synthesis of science and mysticism, which
label: Paragraph

text: eventually he would term “spiritual science.” Through this he sought to provide
label: Paragraph

text: a connection between the cognitive path of Western philosophical sciences and
label: Paragraph

text: the inner, spiritual needs of the individual human being. While Steiner was still at
label: Paragraph

text: the Goethe archive, the core tenets of what would become anthroposophy came for-
label: Paragraph

text: ward in his book, The Philosophy of Freedom (1894), which focused upon paths toward
label: Paragraph

text: achieving complete ethical and spiritual independence. The Goetheanum would
label: Paragraph

text: eventually become that vision’s architectural manifestation.
label: Paragraph

text: Goethe was not a lone influence. Steiner edited a 12-volume edition of Arthur
label: Paragraph

text: Schopenhauer. Contemporaneously he engaged in philosophical disputes over
label: Paragraph

text: monism with the eminent biologist Ernst Haeckel.’? Steiner encountered
label: Paragraph

text: Nietzsche while that philosopher was still living (though essentially catatonic)
label: Paragraph

text: and published a penetrating book about Nietzsche’s struggles against his own
label: Paragraph

text: times and on the concept of the Ubermensch.'* In 1897, Steiner moved to Berlin.
label: Paragraph

text: The rapidly growing Theosophical Society there invited him to lecture on
label: Paragraph

text: Nietzsche in 1900. This was a fortuitous interaction; Steiner encountered another
label: Paragraph

text: influence as large as these German philosophers and scientists, though now from
label: Paragraph

text: a religious perspective.
label: Paragraph

text: Late nineteenth-century theosophy as conceived by Madame Blavatsky attracted
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner, with its emphasis on individuals and on how hidden knowledge or wisdom
label: Paragraph

text: offers enlightenment and salvation. The theosophists’ esoteric belief in “corre-
label: Paragraph

text: spondence” (that everything in nature is a sign that can be read), their stress upon
label: Paragraph

text: the interplay of microcosm and macrocosm, their holding of all nature as alive, and
label: Paragraph

text: their surety that nature best reveals the divine, all inspired him. By 1902, Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: had become affiliated and taken up the post of General Secretary of the Society’s
label: Paragraph

text: “German Section.”
label: Paragraph

text: From the outset, Steiner rather freely interpreted theosophy’s creed, inserting
label: Paragraph

text: his own terminology for Blavatsky’s. Ever restive, by 1907 he began to pull subtly
label: Paragraph

text: away and in 1909 his first lectures on overtly anthroposophical subjects com-
label: Paragraph

text: menced. Steiner’s perception that the official theosophists were making a turn
label: Paragraph

text: more toward Eastern spirituality generated the 1912 definitive break, for Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: himself favored the “Christian-Rosicrucian” path within theosophy that drew from
label: Paragraph

text: occidental esotericism more than eastern mysticism.’’ In 1913, the Anthroposoph-
label: Paragraph

text: ical Society was founded in Berlin. Still an occult sect, it leaned more upon non-
label: Paragraph

text: denominational Christian teachings.
label: Paragraph

text: Anthroposophy’s name derives literally from joining the Greek words for man —
label: Paragraph

text: Anthyopos — and wisdom — Sophos.'® Within it, humankind and its perceptions are
label: Paragraph

text: the center of all purpose. Humanity gives to nature self-consciousness. This reflects
label: Paragraph

text: Goethe’s thoughts that by making humanity, God created the means to experience
label: Paragraph

text: Himself in the beauty, fullness, and perfection of His own creation. Humanity
label: Paragraph

text: becomes “the alpha and omega of existence.” Anthroposophy’s core goal is to dem-
label: Paragraph

text: onstrate that human knowledge has no essential limits. Emphasis is given to per-
label: Paragraph

text: sonal meditation, sentiments, and emotions. Humans must become spiritually free
label: Paragraph

text: beings in order to develop their individuality. Steiner had long advocated a form of
label: Paragraph

text: ethical individualism, but after his exposure to theosophy this now became explic-
label: Paragraph

text: itly spiritual. He had little regard for established hierarchies of power. As one
label: Paragraph

text: scholar notes: “In general terms, anthroposophy can be said to regard the history
label: Paragraph

text: of the human race as the history of its liberation from spiritual and religious autho-
label: Paragraph

text: rities on the one hand and from secular and political ones on the other,” adding,
label: Paragraph

text: “The aim of development is liberation or freedom, so that each individual’s creative
label: Paragraph

text: resources, individuality, autonomy and relationship to the cosmos can evolve.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner’s diverse mental journey over these decades offered him glimmers of
label: Paragraph

text: what the touchstones for an anthroposophical architecture might be:
label: Paragraph

text: metamorphosis, organicism, empathy, sequential development, a fusion of all
label: Paragraph

text: human skills, and a drive always toward individuality. It is no surprise that Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: “railed against the degeneracy of most nineteenth-century architecture, with its
label: Paragraph

text: eclectic plagiarism of former styles.”’* Upon turning toward housing his own
label: Paragraph

text: movement, he sought a modern, synthetic statement as unique as his philosophy.
label: Paragraph

text: Germany was restive in the decade both before and after World War I and
label: Paragraph

text: possessed a wealth of competing architectural trends; Steiner’s embracing of indi-
label: Paragraph

text: viduality actually made him rather typical. Extreme diversity of aesthetic experi-
label: Paragraph

text: mentation was heralded in a context full of conflict and visionary
label: Paragraph

text: pronouncements. Closest to Steiner’s taste was German expressionism. Evolving
label: Paragraph

text: out of National Romanticism and the Jugendstil (German art nouveau), expression-
label: Paragraph

text: ism’s vocabulary affected architecture like all the arts. Peter Behrens’ own 1901
label: Paragraph

text: flowing house in Darmstadt, Hans Poelzig’s 1911 crystalline Water Tower and
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition Building in Posen, and Max Berg’s 1912-13 curvaceous and swelling
label: Paragraph

text: concrete Centenary Hall in Breslau show the multiplicity of gestural attitudes in
label: Paragraph

text: play. Utopian fantasies, like Bruno Taut’s Crystal Chain correspondences, were
label: Paragraph

text: common and suddenly entered reality — as Taut’s faceted, organically-evolving
label: Paragraph

text: 1914 Glass Pavilion in Cologne shows. Steiner’s desire to remake an “expressive”
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was far from unique.
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner travelled in these artistic circles. His interests and interactions across
label: Paragraph

text: Europe were broad; he had, for example, substantive links with Mondrian and neo-
label: Paragraph

text: plasticism.'? He enjoyed many direct ties with German expressionism, such as with
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Scheerbart, for whom he expressed great affection.*° A number of Steiner's
label: Paragraph

text: thoughts directly paralleled Wassily Kandinsky’s — particularly the need to sense
label: Paragraph

text: the spiritual in the material and the abstract.”’ Like expressionism, anthroposophy
label: Paragraph

text: became inculcated with the drive toward creating a total aesthetic and social envi-
label: Paragraph

text: ronment, following upon the nineteenth-century Romantics’ desire for architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture to lead the way toward a Gesamtkunstwerk.’? The Dornach realization
label: Paragraph

text: programmatically resembled other early twentieth-century German examples like
label: Paragraph

text: Joseph Olbrich’s 1899-1905 Mathildenhshe colony at Darmstadt.
