text: The current, wholly concrete Goetheanum is the second to occupy the site.”’ It
label: Paragraph

text: succeeds one of wood, which itself was derived from a prior headquarters scheme
label: Paragraph

text: intended for elsewhere. Steiner began to design architecturally while still affiliated
label: Paragraph

text: with theosophy, redecorating the interior of a Munich hall for a 1907 federation
label: Caption

text: meeting. A faux painted “serial metamorphosis of seven column capitals” appeared
label: Paragraph

text: there, a motif that would recur.”* Also, prior to splitting with theosophy, Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: oversaw the realization of several ellipsoidal, inward-focusing shrines — a 1908 min-
label: Paragraph

text: iature interior by E. A. Karl Stockmeyer in Malsch, Germany and a larger 1911-12
label: Caption

text: crypt-like meeting hall in a Stuttgart cellar (ow destroyed) by Carl
label: Caption

text: Schmid-Curtius.”’ Both illustrate how, throughout his career, Steiner worked col-
label: Paragraph

text: laboratively using a cadré of trained architects.*° A columnar ambulatory sur-
label: Caption

text: rounded a dome in each. A substantial program of drawn astral symbols
label: Paragraph

text: decorated the Stuttgart dome — an early glimpse of the later drive at Dornach
label: Caption

text: toward artistic fusion. Following these modest early constructions, the German
label: Paragraph

text: theosophists realized that building numerous regional bases could delay the crea-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of a true headquarters for the German Section.
label: Paragraph

text: Plans first emerged for just such a structure in central Munich in 1911, signed by
label: Paragraph

text: Schmid-Curtius. Following the break and anthroposophy’s founding, efforts to
label: Paragraph

text: build the proposed headquarters on behalf of the new creed commenced instead.
label: Paragraph

text: Projected to occupy nearly an entire block, the complex had a central, double-
label: Paragraph

text: domed hall surrounded on many sides by street-fronting wings containing support-
label: Paragraph

text: ing functions. Steiner’s mystery plays required a raked auditorium and raised stage
label: Paragraph

text: (the initial scheme was named the Johannesbau after a character in one of Steiner’s
label: Paragraph

text: dramas).”” The hall was “scarab shaped,” composed by slicing off and interpene-
label: Paragraph

text: trating two equal, half-spherical cupolas, one for seating and the other for perfor-
label: Paragraph

text: mance.” The seam served as proscenium. Seven columns undergoing
label: Paragraph

text: transformation again provided an ambulatory on each side around the auditorium
label: Paragraph

text: portion and expanded its base. The mass’s axial character followed the trend of
label: Paragraph

text: blending centralized and longitudinal aspects seen in the prior elliptical interiors.
label: Paragraph

text: The surrounding rectangular structures gave urban privacy to the more sacral, cur-
label: Paragraph

text: vaceous form, both protecting it from the uninitiated’s eyes and hoping to defuse a
label: Paragraph

text: nearby Catholic congregation’s objections to the “potentially offensive” space.””
label: Paragraph

text: Widespread community opposition eventually prevented construction in Munich
label: Paragraph

text: anyway.
label: Paragraph

text: An alternate site was quickly offered by a supporter in German-speaking
label: Paragraph

text: Switzerland, at Dornach in the Birs Valley of the Jura Mountain foothills. Steiner
label: Caption

text: accepted the Swiss offer and transferred the scheme’s core there. The rural hilltop
label: Paragraph

text: location meant the urban wrapper could be peeled away and the ancillary services
label: Paragraph

text: placed in a wide podium, lifting the hall even higher. In line with expressionist fash-
label: Paragraph

text: ion, the central cult building became the looming, central Stadtkrone of a utopian
label: Paragraph

text: garden colony. The hall now stood fully visible as an axial, creature-like mass on a
label: Paragraph

text: modest acropolis overlooking the rolling landscape. Steiner felt such a visible axis,
label: Paragraph

text: or spine, was the method of growth shown in all higher organisms, as opposed to
label: Paragraph

text: expansion from a single center as with lower organisms.*° Construction began in
label: Paragraph

text: September of 1913, with substantial exterior completion achieved a year later.
label: Paragraph

text: Volunteers’ handcrafted, artisanal efforts were crucial. World War I greatly
label: Paragraph

text: delayed the interior, but by 1920 the hall had opened and anthroposophical perfor-
label: Paragraph

text: mances and rites had begun.
label: Paragraph

text: This first Dornach version relied on monolithic heavy timber for its main, lofty,
label: Paragraph

text: double-domed hall and concrete for the low podium. The podium provided an
label: Paragraph

text: entrance, with internal stairs leading upward. Despite the differences of
label: Paragraph

text: constructional technique, Steiner integrated the levels by using similar, expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sively flowing forms ultimately of art nouveau derivation (strong formal, ornamen-
label: Paragraph

text: tal, and functional resemblances exist, for example, with Henry van de Velde’s
label: Paragraph

text: realized theater at Cologne’s Werkbund Exhibition of 1914, the design of which
label: Paragraph

text: was proceeding contemporaneously in 1913).’) Steiner envisioned architecture
label: Paragraph

text: through direct sculpting: huge, hollow, papier maché-like models were constructed
label: Paragraph

text: that allowed him great freedom plastically. Since anthroposophy was growing, the
label: Paragraph

text: seating expanded and the two domes diverged in size.’* The larger swelled to
label: Paragraph

text: 110 feet — four feet wider than St. Peter’s (the overall podium was 272 x 243 feet).
label: Paragraph

text: For Steiner, the larger dome now represented the physical world, the smaller the
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual — joint expressions of the “lower” versus “higher” self.”’
label: Paragraph

text: By now, Steiner was achieving quasi-mythical status within anthroposophy and,
label: Paragraph

text: while still supported by Schmid-Curtius and others, began assuming wide latitude
label: Paragraph

text: as an architect, artist, and client/patron.** He orchestrated all artistic aspects per-
label: Paragraph

text: sonally; through sheer will, he forged a “total” environment. Steiner wed sinuously
label: Paragraph

text: carved details, colored glass windows, diaphanous ceiling murals, lava-like flows of
label: Caption

text: stairs, helmet-shaped drooping eaves, and sculpted wood column capitals expres-
label: Caption

text: sing serial metamorphosis, which all came together into a startling unity of met-
label: Paragraph

text: aphysical symbolism.” A 30-foot high wood figural group sculpted by Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: himself and expressing the rite’s core tenets culminated the axis at the end of
label: Paragraph

text: the stage’s circle. The rich interior truly became an anthroposophical temple of
label: Paragraph

text: learning. Various harmonic ratios and geometrical systems (pentagrams and so
label: Paragraph

text: forth) offered an underlying level of more abstract, formal control.** The building’s
label: Paragraph

text: complex exterior form — varying domes, transept-like side wings, and podium —
label: Paragraph

text: directly expressed the differing functions within, yet achieved an overall sense
label: Paragraph

text: of an organized, bilaterally symmetrical, organic whole. Forms not only fulfilled
label: Paragraph

text: function but imaged function — an “organic functionalism” in one scholar’s terms.”
label: Paragraph

text: Such visible, coordinated functionalism was intended to overcome any sense of
label: Paragraph

text: alienation between user and environment. In line with this premise, after the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing’s completion Steiner suggested replacing the name Johannesbau with
label: Paragraph

text: “Goetheanum,” honoring Goethe’s theory of how a coordinated metamorphosis
label: Paragraph

text: of forms underlies natural creation.
label: Paragraph

text: The Second, Existing Goetheanum
label: Paragraph

text: After only several years of use, tragedy struck: a fire (likely arson) on New Year's
label: Paragraph

text: Eve 1922 consumed everything but the concrete podium. Devastated, Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: announced immediate reconstruction, but this time in concrete throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: After initial plans to reuse the first Goetheanum’s scorched but surviving base,
label: Paragraph

text: this was demolished and an entirely new beginning made. Steiner explained,
label: Paragraph

text: “you cannot build in 1924 as you did in 1913 or 1914.”** Anthroposophy had
label: Paragraph

text: evolved in the intervening years and so would its architecture. In line with
label: Paragraph

text: Goethe, Steiner aimed not for repetition but for continual transformation and
label: Paragraph

text: progression.””
label: Paragraph

text: Clues toward a new architectural conception came from several surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: colony structures erected in the interim under Steiner’s influence.*” More than
label: Paragraph

text: a dozen subsidiary buildings had appeared, clustering about the first Goetheanum
label: Paragraph

text: and oriented toward it, rather like minor mosques magnetically focusing their axes
label: Paragraph

text: toward a nearby Mecca. An approach avenue led out axially several hundred feet
label: Paragraph

text: from the first Goetheanum’s entrance, but this remained largely an honorific path
label: Paragraph

text: and ended simply in a view station. Access actually looped up from one side.*! The
label: Paragraph

text: colony evolved in a loose ring in relation to the terrain sloping down from the first
label: Paragraph

text: Goetheanum. Steiner exerted considerable architectural control over these second-
label: Paragraph

text: ary buildings, wishing the colony to expressively form a “connected whole.”*” Most
label: Paragraph

text: significant about them was the predominant use of exposed concrete. Steiner had
label: Paragraph

text: taken to sculpting formal suggestions for these structures in plasticine, generating
label: Paragraph

text: ever more aggressively expressionistic masses. The colony’s 1913-15 “Boiler
label: Paragraph

text: House” was itself revolutionary; this was Steiner’s first purely concrete construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion.*? A pair of round domes in front formed coal-bunkers, while a tall stack
label: Paragraph

text: erupted sculpturally between them with protuberances suggesting billowing
label: Paragraph

text: smoke. Profoundly organic, it resembled “a resting stag with antlers.”*4 Numerous
label: Caption

text: houses followed. Of these, the 1915-16 Haus Duldek most vividly anticipates
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner’s second Goetheanum. Also of concrete, this “viscous mass” assumed a
label: Paragraph

text: crouching, expressive power, with its angularly folded roof surfaces tensely sug-
label: Paragraph

text: gesting imminent motion.””” Influence from Antoni Guadi’s 1906-10 ashlar Casa
label: Paragraph

text: Mila in Barcelona is often suggested, though unproved. Links to Josef Chochol’s
label: Paragraph

text: 1912-13 cubist, stucco-rendered Villa Kovarovic in Prague are likelier, as Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: was well aware of Czech Cubism. *° Closest in affect is Erich Mendelsohn’s slightly
label: Paragraph

text: later 1917-21 Einstein Tower near Potsdam, which shares Haus Duldek’s literally
label: Paragraph

text: animalian curves, ground hugging posture and pronounced bilateral axis.*” Such
label: Paragraph

text: resemblances suggest at least Steiner's cognizance of and responsiveness to works
label: Paragraph

text: of his times.
label: Paragraph

text: The second, existing Goetheanum was begun in 1924 and daringly fused such
label: Paragraph

text: ideas into one of modernism’s most evocatively personal and photogenic perfor-
label: Paragraph

text: mances. If the initial building’s uniqueness relied on interior exoticism, the second
label: Paragraph

text: was energized through its exterior muscularity.** Concrete’s greater plasticity over
label: Paragraph

text: wood let Steiner sculpt a turbulent yet still symmetrical massing, which projected
label: Paragraph

text: organic references, but also in its stark axiality generated more eerie readings such
label: Paragraph

text: as a “grey sphinx” or “bald death’s head.”*? A remarkable changeability of profile
label: Paragraph

text: and mien suffused its rigid posturing.”° Steiner stressed how such dynamic tensions
label: Paragraph

text: or atectonic effects resulted not from any literal borrowings from nature but rather
label: Paragraph

text: — again in concert with Goethe — from a deeper understanding of nature’s abiding
label: Paragraph

text: theme of metamorphosis and growth.”? Steiner did, however, acknowledge direct
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration from the mountainous countryside.’ For the second Goetheanum
label: Caption

text: Steiner consciously sought greater harmony with the site, quite literally reflecting
label: Paragraph

text: the Gempen Ridge of the Jura Mountains in the immediate background.” Locally
label: Paragraph

text: the structure has become known as the rock face (“Fluh”).”*
label: Paragraph

text: A gigantic, exterior, plasticine model became the definitive statement of
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner’s intentions.” Illness gradually weakened and overtook him; his involve-
label: Paragraph

text: ment grew sporadic and ended with his untimely death in 1925, in the construction
label: Paragraph

text: shed adjacent to the Dornach worksite. Perhaps had he lived longer the existing
label: Paragraph

text: Goetheanum’s interiors may have equaled the first’s elaboration. Instead he left
label: Paragraph

text: behind an awesome shell, which finally opened in 1928 (others fitted it out exten-
label: Paragraph

text: sively over subsequent decades and transformed it, a process that continues to this
label: Paragraph

text: day).*° Contemporaneous reactions were mixed. Coming a decade after expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sionism’s apogee, this heavily earthbound, elephant-toned, atavistic mass con-
label: Paragraph

text: trasted with canonical functionalism’s newly emerging trends toward lightness,
label: Paragraph

text: whiteness, abstraction, mechanical repetition, and industry. By the time it was fin-
label: Paragraph

text: ished, it spoke more of the “other” within modernism, something quite different
label: Paragraph

text: from what would become the prevailing International Style.””
label: Paragraph

text: If anything, in moving toward greater plastic unity the new massing conceals
label: Paragraph

text: functionality.** Steiner’s main auditorium and stage are subsumed within a 50%
label: Paragraph

text: larger bulk that houses enhanced ancillary spaces. The side wings rise higher, fus-
label: Paragraph

text: ing with the upper eaves. A continuously folding and bulging roof covers all, itself
label: Paragraph

text: coated with diminutive slate tiles resembling a faintly granulated layer of protective
label: Paragraph

text: dust that some temperamental pachyderm has thrown up upon its back to defend
label: Paragraph

text: against the sun’s rays. Gestural motion is greatest toward the front entrance, with
label: Paragraph

text: its protruding “jaw,” and gradually lessens toward the rear administrative and sup-
label: Paragraph

text: port zones.”

text: Reflecting Steiner's increasing emphasis on larger-scale theatrics, an expressively
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: plemented with the development of “eurythmy” — an expressive dance having
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Visitors now had to climb several sets of stairs to reach the auditorium. Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: sculpted this into a Piranesian interior flow worthy of Garnier’s Paris Opéra.”
label: Paragraph

text: Overall, the second Goetheanum’s effect is much less directly cabalistic about
label: Paragraph

text: the symbols of anthroposophy’s core rites than the earlier version and more expres-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: that the basic forms both in section and plan are still geometrically derived from a
label: Paragraph

text: circle, yet the perceptual results now seem far removed from such coolly abstract
label: Paragraph

text: intents.°°

text: beyond the aesthetic rewards.”° In essence, a wood construction of equal complex-
label: Paragraph

text: ity to the original Goetheanum had to be erected once more, only then to be shorn
label: Paragraph

text: away. The first building was realized from the inside out, the second from the out-
label: Paragraph

text: side in. The second’s elaborate wood cocoon was the work of master carpentry
label: Paragraph

text: foreman Heinrich Liedvogel, who also was skilled from his participation in the con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction of the first building.”’ The lack of regularity anywhere was revolutionary.
label: Paragraph

text: Submerged within, discrete concrete trusses do span the wide hall and land on
label: Paragraph

text: major pillars, but the reading is of a radically continuous, undulating mass. The
label: Paragraph

text: progressiveness of the attempt (and the faulty mixing of some concrete) still results
label: Paragraph

text: in the need for constant patches and repairs today.” A monumentally cohesive if
label: Paragraph

text: differentiated entity replaces any sense of an assembled construction.
label: Paragraph

text: This drive toward the monolithic reflected Steiner’s desire now to go beyond
label: Paragraph

text: mere functional accommodation in architectural expression and achieve a deeper
label: Paragraph

text: resonance with the very processes of life itself. The second Goetheanum became an
label: Paragraph

text: obsessive portrayal of his notion of the “living wall.””’ Walls were not to be mere
label: Paragraph

text: barriers or acts of enclosure. One scholar notes how when seen from the inside,
label: Paragraph

text: “The [Goetheanum’s] doubly curved surface embodied for Steiner both the con-
label: Paragraph

text: vexity produced by peripheral, ‘cosmic’ formative forces of nature working inward
label: Paragraph

text: and the concavity resulting from the polar centrifugal forces working outward.””*
label: Paragraph

text: This represented the basic, foundational Urphdnomen of life, as detailed by Goethe.
label: Paragraph

text: The molding of one form from another fascinated Steiner. He spoke of “eversion”
label: Paragraph

text: (Umstiilpung), the turning inside out of a form as a cosmic principle; the relation ofa
label: Paragraph

text: concrete construction’s cavity-like formwork to the eventual poured mass reflected
label: Paragraph

text: such dialectics. Hints of continual metamorphosis infused all the Goetheanum’s
label: Paragraph

text: elements; Steiner felt the designer must cajole discrete architectural forms into a
label: Paragraph

text: flux of gradual transformation, as in music. Architecturally, load and loaded fused.
label: Paragraph

text: Discrete members did emerge (such as in the two colossal, free-standing columns
label: Paragraph

text: flanking the front of the entrance) but then melted back into the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: matrix.”” This expressed the drama of our own muscular struggle with gravity.
label: Paragraph

text: Windows (some, here again, with colored glass) were never allowed to stand in
label: Paragraph

text: repetitive arrays, but instead became groupings of irregularly shaped openings
label: Paragraph

text: involving rather gratuitous slants and tucks — Steiner’s way of instilling life and
label: Paragraph

text: movement through “the inclining gesture.””°
label: Paragraph

text: Impacts and Progeny
label: Title

text: Much contentiousness attends any attempt to ascribe the second Goetheanum to
label: Paragraph

text: German Expressionism.” Steiner’s most committed followers react negatively to
label: Paragraph

text: suggestions that outside formal influences or conceptual constellations affected
label: Paragraph

text: him at all, and prefer to discuss his work in isolation as purely reverential hagiog-
label: Paragraph

text: raphy.”* Even independent architectural historians who place the second version
label: Paragraph

text: firmly within expressionism maintain that it had no sources or progeny.” Yet
label: Paragraph

text: any belief that Steiner achieved his architecture autonomously simply detracts
label: Paragraph

text: from his real achievement: his fusion of diverse influences into a personal and, ulti-
label: Paragraph

text: mately, seminal statement. These influences far transcended the formal. It is a les-
label: Paragraph

text: son to all architects to see how the comprehensiveness of his intellectual inquiries
label: Paragraph

text: did not divert but rather fed his aesthetics. What really separated Steiner from
label: Paragraph

text: other German expressionist architects was the systematic depth and breadth of
label: Paragraph

text: his learning and societal vision, and how this attracted a broad enough range of
label: Paragraph

text: fervent supporters to allow his design actual realization and testing.
label: Paragraph

text: Eventual progeny were numerous, though this had to wait several decades for
label: Paragraph

text: mid-twentieth-century International Style Modernism’s force to wind down. Hugo
label: Paragraph

text: Haring held theoretical positions that seem indebted to Steiner, and the two were
label: Paragraph

text: linked through common anthroposoph friends.” Walter Gropius’ 1927 Total The-
label: Paragraph

text: ater project approximates aspects of the first Goetheanum’s plan. A young Le Cor-
label: Paragraph

text: busier visited the second Goetheanum in 1926, and was said to be impressed.*' The
label: Paragraph

text: much later expressive plasticity and béton brut of Corbusier's nearby 1954 Notre
label: Paragraph

text: Dame du Haut at Ronchamp likely has some root there. Hans Sharoun once
label: Paragraph

text: described the second Goetheanum as the most significant building of the first half
label: Paragraph

text: of the twentieth century, and its influences upon his own masterwork, the
label: Paragraph

text: 1956-63 Berlin Philharmonie, seem compelling.*” Further relations could be argued
label: Paragraph

text: regarding Dominikus Béhm’s more crystalline 1963-73 Pilgrimage Church of Mary,
label: Paragraph

text: Queen of Peace, in Neviges Velbert. Distant comparisons have even been made to
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Gehry. Some who acknowledge such links nonetheless dismiss them as merely
label: Paragraph

text: “formal,” without stating how that undermines these relations’ importance.”
label: Paragraph

text: An interesting distinction from many such examples is the direct, expressed axi-
label: Paragraph

text: ality of Steiner's work.** The Philharmonie’s ground plan, in comparison, has a
label: Paragraph

text: carefully cloaked axis: Scharoun’s performance hall for acoustic reasons is rigor-
label: Paragraph

text: ously symmetrical within, yet smaller, appended masses of fire stairs and other ser-
label: Paragraph

text: vices are used consciously to mask this fact from the exterior.*’ Scharoun goes to
label: Paragraph

text: great effort to maintain a studied asymmetry of external impact. The same could be
label: Paragraph

text: said of Alvar Aalto’s many auditoria, where the sensibility toward an overall asym-
label: Paragraph

text: metry of form dominates, despite the occasional sculptural resemblances to Stei-
label: Paragraph

text: ner’s work. Steiner, different from these later modernists, wanted to express
label: Paragraph

text: literally an axial spine within the creatures he created. A closer resemblance to
label: Paragraph

text: his attitude is shown perhaps in the symmetrical, animal-like character of Eero
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s 1962 TWA Terminal in New York City.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Within the contemporary anthroposophical movement, Steiner's architecture
label: Paragraph

text: remains a force. The Swede Erik Asmussen with great sensitivity translates aspects
label: Paragraph

text: of Steiner’s work into the Swedish wood building tradition.*” An entire anthropo-
label: Paragraph

text: sophical colony by this architect’s hand has sprung up in Jarna, near Stockholm.*
label: Paragraph

text: Many related cases exist elsewhere across the globe.*” Outside the anthroposoph-
label: Paragraph

text: ical movement, other architects today also still acknowledge direct inspiration from
label: Paragraph

text: Steiner, such as Hungary’s Imre Makovecz.””

text: “THE ART OF A MASTER”
label: Title

text: It was a late spring or early summer day in 1926 when the architect Erich
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn, almost certainly with the music of Johann Sebastian Bach playing
label: Paragraph

text: in the background, made this series of sketches for the facade of a department store
label: Paragraph

text: in the southern German city of Stuttgart." Mendelsohn, who shared a birthday with
label: Paragraph

text: Bach and was married to a talented cellist, made at least one sketch for the store on
label: Paragraph

text: the back of a program for a concert of Bach’s music in which his wife performed.”
label: Paragraph

text: He often sketched while listening to music on the gramophone, and preferred the
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance and baroque technique of counterpoint to Romantic harmony.’ Show-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the building from four different points of view, and also including locations for
label: Paragraph

text: two flights of stairs within one corner tower, the sheet illustrates the degree to
label: Paragraph

text: which the architect conceived of it in the round. He drew three of the perspectives
label: Paragraph

text: in black charcoal; the fourth and largest one, however, is executed largely in red,
label: Paragraph

text: with black used only to underline the bands of the stair tower. This corresponded
label: Paragraph

text: more closely with the color of the brick, out of which the steel-framed building,
label: Paragraph

text: which was completed in 1928, was eventually faced.
label: Paragraph

text: Quickly and skillfully drawn, the sheet stands at the center of interconnected
label: Paragraph

text: stories about the Neues Bauen (New Building), as the commercial and residential
label: Paragraph

text: architecture erected in a bold and inexpensive new style was termed in Germany
label: Paragraph

text: during the 1920s and early 1930s; about Erich Mendelsohn, who was one of its most
label: Paragraph

text: famous and fashionable practitioners; and about the impact that industrialization
label: Paragraph

text: has had on consumerism and thus in turn upon architectural and urban space.‘
label: Paragraph

text: Because both Mendelsohn and his client, Salman Schocken, were politically pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gressive Zionists who would emigrate to Jerusalem and the United States, this
label: Paragraph

text: is also a story about the role that German Jews played in the creation of both
label: Paragraph

text: modernity and modernism.’
label: Paragraph

text: The physical evidence offered here also complicates received wisdom about the
label: Paragraph

text: modern movement in architecture in crucial ways. It demonstrates the importance
label: Paragraph

text: of individual creativity within an approach toward architecture that has often been
label: Paragraph

text: understood to be objective and functional. Furthermore, although the urban con-
label: Paragraph

text: text is implied rather than shown, it proves how seriously Mendelsohn took a very
label: Paragraph

text: specific site in a very specific city. This is a welcome reminder of how attuned to the
label: Paragraph

text: existing urban fabric Neues Bauen almost always was.
label: Paragraph

text: The Drawing
label: Title

text: In this drawing the balance of pragmatism and imagination, which Mendelsohn
label: Paragraph

text: would have phrased in terms of functionalism and dynamism, that characterized
label: Paragraph

text: Neues Bauen during the brief German economic boom of 1924 to 1929 as well as its
label: Paragraph

text: immediate aftermath, are both clearly on display. The tension between the
label: Paragraph

text: volumes is indicative of this larger tension, as well as of the contrapuntal compo-
label: Paragraph

text: sition techniques Mendelsohn admired in both baroque music and contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: art and architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: What exactly are we looking at? The top sketch shows the Eberhardt- and
label: Paragraph

text: Steinstrafe facades of the building. Lined by streetcar tracks, the Eberhardtstrape
label: Caption

text: front was the most important. Furthermore the curves of the street and the
label: Paragraph

text: intersections that framed the full block site ensured that the two most prominent
label: Paragraph

text: corners, each of which could be glimpsed at a considerable distance, were located at
label: Paragraph

text: either end of this facade. In this sketch Mendelsohn contrasts the curved stair tower
label: Caption

text: anchoring the far facade with the sharp corner with Steinstrafle and the second,
label: Paragraph

text: taller, and more enclosed rectangular tower that punctuated the transition from
label: Paragraph

text: the high front and lower rear stories of the block. In the next, much smaller sketch,
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn envisions the building from the corner of Stein- and Breitestrafe. Par-
label: Paragraph

text: adoxically Breite or “Broad” street was in fact the much narrower rear facade of the
label: Paragraph

text: building. Only at its far end does the height of the building begin once again to step
label: Paragraph

text: up. By the third, also relatively small sketch, Mendelsohn’s design strategy is appar-
label: Paragraph

text: ent. He is wrapping a single facade treatment around each corner, in this case of
label: Paragraph

text: Breite- and Hirschstrafe. This one, however, is the least developed of the four; it
label: Paragraph

text: remains the single aspect of the building least documented in the surviving photo-
label: Paragraph

text: graphs. In the fourth drawing he returns to the key Eberhardtstrafe facade, now
label: Paragraph

text: viewed from the crucial corner with Hirschstrafe. Befitting its key role in the design,
label: Paragraph

text: this is the largest sketch; the red color of most of the drawing adds additional visual
label: Paragraph

text: prominence.
label: Paragraph

text: The following year Mendelsohn wrote of the importance of such sketches to his
label: Paragraph

text: design process:
label: Title

text: I see the site, the surface area, the space above it. Generally, the architectural idea
label: Paragraph

text: already appears spontaneously at this moment. | fix it in the form of a sketch. This
label: Paragraph

text: means that the knowledge, the exact information about the actual requirements
label: Paragraph

text: enters one’s subconscious; the surface area comes to life as a ground plan, the empty
label: Paragraph

text: space as a spatial shape, a two- and three-dimensional experience at the same time.
label: Paragraph

text: keep this first sketch. For, as an experience, as a vision, it has concentrated reality,
label: Paragraph

text: plan, and structure into one architectonic organism. An inspiration, an action of
label: Paragraph

text: creation.®
label: Paragraph

text: Although the subject of the drawing is immediately identifiable to anyone famil-
label: Paragraph

text: iar with photographs of the realized building, the two smaller sketches of the plan
label: Paragraph

text: of the curvilinear stair tower remind us that Mendelsohn had not yet in fact fina-
label: Paragraph

text: lized all the details of his design. In the end he nestled the flights of stairs within the
label: Paragraph

text: curve of the tower, rather than back from it as shown here. In fact, this is not the
label: Paragraph

text: only way in which these sketches differ from the final result. The sense of certainty
label: Paragraph

text: conveyed through the rapid movement of the charcoal over the paper is in this
label: Paragraph

text: sense an illusion. Published plans reveal that the corner on Breite- and Hirschstrape
label: Paragraph

text: never projected forward in the way shown here; the half-dozen bands of windows
label: Paragraph

text: in the cylindrical stair tower grew to 16 in the final scheme, where, except on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground level, they no longer corresponded in any way to the number of stories
label: Paragraph

text: behind them. Nor are the sketches detailed enough to show the considerable atten-
label: Paragraph

text: tion Mendelsohn eventually paid the glazing of each corner treatment, the alternat-
label: Paragraph

text: ing stripes of brick and local stone that tied the two stair towers together, or the
label: Paragraph

text: way in which he punctuated the Eberhardtstrafe facade with bold letters spelling out
label: Paragraph

text: the Schocken name. These were illuminated from within in the dematerialized
label: Paragraph

text: night view that was as central to the building’s impact as its more sedate daytime
label: Paragraph

text: appearance. Finally, the sketches give no sense of the way in which Mendelsohn
label: Paragraph

text: sensitively addressed the slope of the site, which fell a full story along the length
label: Paragraph

text: of the Hirschstrafe facade. As was characteristic for him, Mendelsohn resolved
label: Paragraph

text: many of these details through the less glamorous means of a model, although even
label: Paragraph

text: after this was built he and his client battled over whether to add a single recessed
label: Paragraph

text: story, as Mendelsohn favored, or further bulk, as Schocken desired.
label: Paragraph

text: The Building
label: Title

text: The pair of speeches that architect and client gave in October 1926 at the opening
label: Paragraph

text: of an earlier Schocken store in Nuremberg demonstrated the degree to which each
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless understood the goals of the other. Schocken declared in words that
label: Paragraph

text: were undoubtedly inspired by his appreciation of Mendelsohn’s sketches, “The
label: Paragraph

text: art of a matter shows itself in the ability for selection and reduction, in the ability
label: Paragraph

text: to refrain from the inessential, to restrict material, to recognize the supporting col-
label: Paragraph

text: umns, to shape what is needed with a few strong lines.”” Mendelsohn in turn
label: Paragraph

text: defined the spirit of the age in terms of “Bare knees and a sporty ‘do/Radio
label: Paragraph

text: and film/Automobile and aeroplane, specialty shops and department stores.” It
label: Paragraph

text: demanded, he concluded, buildings designed in the same spirit. “You do demand
label: Paragraph

text: sincerity? From your friends, from everyone? But you want to be tricked by the
label: Paragraph

text: things around you, by your house, your builders? Are those somehow things that
label: Paragraph

text: do not belong to you — your electric stove and razor? So efficient, so simple, so
label: Paragraph

text: obvious ... Only one who has no rhythm in the body — do not think of jazz,
label: Paragraph

text: be serious — does not understand the metallic swing of the machine, the humming
label: Paragraph

text: of propellers, the enormous new vitality that stimulates, blesses, and makes us
label: Paragraph

text: creative.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn achieved this rhythm in Stuttgart through the skillful way in which
label: Paragraph

text: he exploited the dynamic potential of the functional steel frame. In addition to
label: Paragraph

text: allowing the complete glazing of the corner stair tower, this also permitted him
label: Paragraph

text: to cantilever the shop windows along Eberhardtstrafe forward of the supporting col-
label: Paragraph

text: umns. This in turn created a band of shop windows interrupted only by an
label: Paragraph

text: entrance, to connect the two stair towers at ground level. The effect was especially
label: Paragraph

text: impressive at night, when the carefully conceived figure ground relationship of the
label: Paragraph

text: day view was reversed and the building appears to sit atop an illuminated void.
label: Paragraph

text: Little of this architectural excitement permeated the straightforward display of
label: Paragraph

text: goods on the building’s interior, however. Most earlier department stores were
label: Paragraph

text: arranged around atria, which announced the existence of multiple floors of goods
label: Paragraph

text: and helped illuminate deep spaces. Mendelsohn eliminated this feature, tucking
label: Paragraph

text: only a small light court — insisted upon by the building authorities — into the rear
label: Paragraph

text: of the building. Instead he relied heavily upon electric light. He canted the column
label: Paragraph

text: grid, which featured four rows parallel to Eberhardtstrage and a further three parallel
label: Paragraph

text: to Breitestrafe. The existence of this grid, around which he wrapped many of the
label: Paragraph

text: sales counters, was later given as an excuse to replace the building with a more up-
label: Paragraph

text: to-date one featuring clear spans. At the time, however, the quasi-industrial char-
label: Paragraph

text: acter of the interiors contributed to the chain’s image of no-frills goods and prices.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, the fittings for Stuttgart were the most detailed Mendelsohn designed
label: Paragraph

text: for Schocken. They included a prow-like mezzanine from which managers could
label: Paragraph

text: observe the sales force, an element that he accentuated by ringing the ceiling above
label: Paragraph

text: it with exposed light bulbs.
label: Paragraph

text: The Architect
label: Title

text: The Stuttgart design emerged from a process that was characteristic of Mendel-
label: Paragraph

text: sohn. More than any of his contemporaries allied with either Neues Bauen or the
label: Paragraph

text: broader Modern Movement of which it was a part, despite having lost on eye
label: Paragraph

text: to cancer in 1921 Mendelsohn relied on the perspective sketch as the crucial stage
label: Paragraph

text: in his design process. Beginning in 1914 the architect, who was born in Allenstein in
label: Paragraph

text: 1887 and had been educated in Berlin and Munich, began to draw visions of a new
label: Paragraph

text: industrial architecture, whose boldly sculptured forms were inspired in part by his
label: Paragraph

text: admiration of the increasingly abstract paintings of Wassily Kandinsky and other
label: Paragraph

text: painters associated with the Blue Rider group.’ Although he did not contribute
label: Paragraph

text: to the Arbeitsrat fir Kunst’s exhibition of unknown architects, held in Berlin in
label: Paragraph

text: 1919, and did not join the Crystal Chain, initiated the same year, Mendelsohn
label: Paragraph

text: shared with many expressionist contemporaries a predilection for curves that could
label: Paragraph

text: be labeled organic.’ Mendelsohn’s drawings also fostered the sense of drama that,
label: Paragraph

text: while based in part upon his interest in experimental theater, was extremely effec-
label: Paragraph

text: tive commercially. No one realized this better than Schocken, who proved to be
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s most sage, if also his most consistently demanding client, and who
label: Paragraph

text: saw the sketches when they were first put on public display in Berlin in 1919. By
label: Paragraph

text: this time Mendelsohn had already received the commission for what became his
label: Paragraph

text: breakthrough building, the Einstein Tower in Potsd am."
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s only attempt to build in the highly expressionist style of drawings
label: Paragraph

text: that originally had no relationship to function and little to structure, the Einstein
label: Paragraph

text: Tower was largely complete by the late summer of 1921, although the economic
label: Paragraph

text: crisis delayed the installation of its interior furnishings and scientific equipment.
label: Paragraph

text: The building, whose eccentric shape was intended to be a monument to the con-
label: Paragraph

text: troversial new theory of relativity, and to express the possible conversion of mass
label: Paragraph

text: into energy postulated by it, also housed a highly pragmatic observatory and lab-
label: Paragraph

text: oratory for relativity-related research. Erected in part out of brick covered with
label: Caption

text: stucco, rather than entirely out of reinforced concrete as its architect had originally
label: Paragraph

text: intended, its eccentric forms were also inspired by art nouveau and Futurist
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture.
label: Paragraph

text: The publication of the Einstein Tower in the popular press made Mendelsohn
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most famous, if not infamous, of the new generation of German archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects, which also included Walter Gropius, Ernst May, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe,
label: Paragraph

text: and Bruno Taut. Especially after the Bauhaus exhibition of 1923 and the stabiliza-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the German economy the following year, thanks to the implementation of
label: Paragraph

text: the Dawes Plan, these architects abandoned their earlier, often utopian experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ments, in favor of a more sober or objective approach, which featured low-cost
label: Paragraph

text: construction infused with industrial imagery and inspired as well by De Stijl and
label: Paragraph

text: constructivism. Where most adherents of Neues Bauen focused on the design of
label: Paragraph

text: housing estates on the suburban fringes of Berlin and Frankfurt in particular,
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s early fame generated a slew of commercial commissions. These
label: Paragraph

text: came almost exclusively from Jewish businessmen like Schocken and the publisher
label: Paragraph

text: and real-estate developer Hans Lachmann-Mosse, the father of the renowned his-
label: Paragraph

text: torian George Mosse.’* Such men recognized the advertising merits of
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s architectural flair and were also proud of his association with Ein-
label: Paragraph

text: stein, the most celebrated member of their community.
label: Paragraph

text: They also appreciated the first-hand familiarity with the latest international
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that informed Mendelsohn’s designs. He found that the composition
label: Paragraph

text: of baroque music, one of Germany’s most venerated cultural traditions, correlated
label: Paragraph

text: almost exactly with the art and architecture he had seen in the Netherlands in 1921
label: Paragraph

text: and again in 1923, and in the Soviet Union in 1925 and twice in 1926. Here he made
label: Paragraph

text: contact with architects, who excelled at juxtaposing abstract rectangular forms.
label: Paragraph

text: These included J. J. P. Oud, already a proponent of De Stijl geometries, and the
label: Paragraph

text: constructivists, E] Lissitzky, Konstantin Melnikov, and the Vesnin brothers.'? This
label: Paragraph

text: was not the only fruit of these trips. Somewhat paradoxically, Mendelsohn’s cap-
label: Paragraph

text: italist graphics were undoubtedly inspired in part by Soviet political propaganda,
label: Paragraph

text: especially as integrated by the Vesnin brothers into their 1924 project for the Len-
label: Paragraph

text: ingrad headquarters of the Soviet newspaper, Pravda.
label: Paragraph

text: Even more crucial to the respect accorded to the architect by his commercial
label: Paragraph

text: clients was the trip he made to the United States in 1924 and the book he published
label: Paragraph

text: about it two years later, Amerika: Bilderbuch eines Architekten (America: Picturebook
label: Paragraph

text: of an Architect). Mendelsohn’s itinerary, which took him from Manhattan to four
label: Paragraph

text: Mid-Western cities, adhered to that of the German businessmen who sailed across
label: Paragraph

text: the Atlantic to observe first-hand the factories, department stores, and office
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, which were bigger and bolder than their European counterparts.’* He
label: Paragraph

text: made a pilgrimage to Taliesin to meet Frank Lloyd Wright. Mendelsohn was
label: Paragraph

text: scarcely the only German cultural figure of the day to advance his standing at
label: Paragraph

text: home this way; he sailed over with Fritz Lang, the director of Metropolis. Mendel-
label: Paragraph

text: sohn was awed by the speed of American traffic, the brightness of the night light-
label: Paragraph

text: ing, the height of the skyscrapers, and the bare volumes of the industrial
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular. He was appalled, however, by the historicist veneers that fronted
label: Paragraph

text: the towers he photographed, and dreamed of a more straightforward expression
label: Paragraph

text: of their most modern qualities.
label: Paragraph

text: The commercial function and downtown location of the Schocken store, and
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s other department stores, office buildings, and single cinema set them
label: Paragraph

text: slightly apart from the other most celebrated examples of Neues Bauen, even as they
label: Paragraph

text: established new prototypes for these building types that would be influential for
label: Paragraph

text: decades around the world. The Stuttgart store bears comparison with the Weissen-
label: Paragraph

text: hof Housing Estate erected in 1927 on a suburban hillside only a few miles away by
label: Paragraph

text: an international who’s who of avant-garde architects led by Mies van der Rohe,
label: Paragraph

text: with whom Mendelsohn had had a falling out and whose invitation to participate
label: Paragraph

text: he consequently refused.’* As befits its suburban setting, the Weissenhof buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: which were open to the public as an exhibition before the civil servants they were
label: Paragraph

text: built to house moved in, are arrayed in a manner influenced by the garden city
label: Paragraph

text: movement, with considerably more space between them than was available to
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn. Another significant difference was the choice of exterior materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Although some of the contributions to the Weissenhof were also steel-framed, they
label: Paragraph

text: were all clad in stucco, whereas Mendelsohn chose more durable brick and stone,
label: Paragraph

text: just as he eschewed the fashionable tubular metal furnishing on view throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the Weissenhof. Only Hans Scharoun’s contribution to the Weissenhof shared
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn’s dynamism. The composition of the contributions to the housing
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition were either more subtle or, in some cases, simply more banal.
label: Paragraph

text: The Client
label: Title

text: The balance of pragmatism and panache that made the Schocken store such a com-
label: Paragraph

text: pelling addition to the Stuttgart cityscape was greatly appreciated by the building’s
label: Paragraph

text: client. A decade older than his architect, Schocken and his brother Simon owned a
label: Paragraph

text: chain of department stores that during the second half of the 1920s expanded from
label: Paragraph

text: its original base in Saxony across southern Germany.’® Acutely aware of the role
label: Paragraph

text: played by publicity, Schocken employed Mendelsohn for only the most visible of
label: Paragraph

text: the new stores: an expansion of an existing building in Nuremberg, which opened
label: Paragraph

text: in 1926; the building in Stuttgart; and another in Chemnitz, which was completed
label: Paragraph

text: in 1930. Smaller stores in cities like Cottbus featured novel architecture but were
label: Paragraph

text: consigned to local architects, whose work was less likely to be featured in trade
label: Paragraph

text: journals and architecture magazines.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Few building types were more modern than the department stores that, begin-
label: Paragraph

text: ning in the middle of the nineteenth century, anchored new entirely commercial
label: Paragraph

text: districts, first in New York and Paris, and eventually in cities around the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Here for the first time the fruits of the industrial revolution, as well as of countless
label: Paragraph

text: sweatshops and seamstresses working at home, were made available at fixed prices
label: Paragraph

text: to an anonymous public, who did not need to avail of a long standing relationship
label: Paragraph

text: with the shopkeeper to see what was on offer or find themselves a bargain. More
label: Paragraph

text: than the factories in which many of their wares were made, department stores were
label: Paragraph

text: the place where middle-class consumers were introduced to new technology,
label: Paragraph

text: whether that of elevators and escalators, or new goods, such as radios and gramo-
label: Paragraph

text: phones, not to mention the latest fashions.’*
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most modern aspects of department stores was the degree to
label: Paragraph

text: which they were run, staffed, and frequented by women. For a decade after
label: Paragraph

text: the death in 1877 of her husband Aristide, Marguerite Boucicaut ran Bon Marché
label: Paragraph

text: in Paris.'? Although the leading administrative positions were more often
label: Paragraph

text: reserved for men, many staff were women, not least because it was presumed
label: Paragraph

text: that their attentiveness to fashion would help win sales from female customers.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Sales girls, like stenographers and telephone operators, numbered prominently
label: Paragraph

text: among the New Women of the Weimar Republic, who challenged established
label: Paragraph

text: social norms, most famously by bobbing their hair and shortening their skirts,
label: Paragraph

text: but also by earning independent incomes, taking unprecedented control over
label: Paragraph

text: their romantic lives, and constituting a large part of the audience for a novel
label: Paragraph

text: new form of entertainment, the cinema.”? Many department stores catered to
label: Paragraph

text: women by offering them respectable places to lunch and take tea, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: clean public toilets.
label: Paragraph

text: Department stores arrived relatively late in Germany; the big chains such as Kar-
label: Paragraph

text: stadt, Tietze, and Wertheim began to flourish only at the end of the nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century. With the exception of Karstadt, most German department stores were
label: Paragraph

text: founded by Jewish families. From the beginning they attracted opposition — much
label: Paragraph

text: of it frankly anti-Semitic — for the way in which they undercut smaller, established
label: Paragraph

text: businesses.” In part to demonstrate their respectability, in part because fashion was
label: Paragraph

text: a crucial part of their business, by the 1890s German departments store owners
label: Paragraph

text: were paying careful attention to architecture. Bernhard Sehring’s Hermann Tietz
label: Paragraph

text: store in Berlin of 1899-1900, which featured the city’s first curtain wall facade,
label: Paragraph

text: Alfred Messel’s Wertheim store on the same city’s Leipzigerplatz, erected in stages
label: Caption

text: between 1896 and 1906, and Joseph Maria Olbrich’s Leonard Tietz store in Dus-
label: Paragraph

text: seldorf, completed in 1909, were among the most innovative and admired build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings of their day.
label: Paragraph

text: Schocken’s business model was to keep prices low and quality high, and to focus
label: Paragraph

text: on supplying staples to the broadest possible array of consumers. He paid rigorous
label: Paragraph

text: attention to the bottom line, turning to Mendelsohn and Neues Bauen because he
label: Paragraph

text: realized how much less expensive this industrially-oriented architecture would be
label: Paragraph

text: than its overtly palatial predecessors. No one would have more appreciated the
label: Paragraph

text: degree to which Mendelsohn based the Eberhardtstraffe facade on the reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: concrete framed factories by Albert Kahn in which Model T Fords were being pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced with celebrated efficiency, which he had visited in 1924. At the dedication of
label: Paragraph

text: the Stuttgart store Schocken declared in words that showed his appreciation of the
label: Paragraph

text: latest art and architecture, “We are building from the point of view of the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit [new objectivity or sobriety, a term often used to describe contempo-
label: Paragraph

text: rary German painting]. Architecture is a purely economic affair; all technical per-
label: Paragraph

text: fections are exploited in the examination of the beauty of the whole, which results
label: Paragraph

text: technically from the new means [of production].””?
label: Paragraph

text: The Schocken chain was “Arianized” in 1938; only in 1949 was it returned to
label: Paragraph

text: Schocken. Like his architect, he had lived in exile in Jerusalem, where Mendelsohn
label: Paragraph

text: built him a house and library, and in the United States. Both Mendelsohn and
label: Paragraph

text: Schocken renounced the creation of the commercial spectacle at which they had
label: Paragraph

text: so excelled and turned much of their attention to sustaining the endangered com-
label: Paragraph

text: munity to which they so proudly belonged. For Schocken, the department store
label: Paragraph

text: business proved only a way-station to a career of even greater importance. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1930, he founded the Schocken Press, which published the complete works of
label: Paragraph

text: Kafka, and bought the Israeli newspaper Haaretz seven years later. He supported
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish writers, including the poet Else Lasker-Schiiler, the Nobel prizewinner
label: Paragraph

text: Shmuel Yosef Agnon, and the philosopher Gerschom Scholem, and hired Hannah
label: Paragraph

text: Arendt as an editor.* Mendelsohn specialized in the last years of his life in the
label: Paragraph

text: design of modernist synagogues, establishing the prototypes for the plethora of
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish houses of worship doubling as community centers that were erected in sub-
label: Paragraph

text: urbs across the United States in the first decades after World War I.”’ The store on
label: Paragraph

text: which they had collaborated so successfully was demolished in 1960. Labeled as
label: Paragraph

text: outmoded by the new owners who had purchased the business from Schocken
label: Paragraph

text: in 1953, four years after it was returned to him, it was immediately replaced with
label: Paragraph

text: a building designed by Egon Eiermann.”°
