text: THE ART OF DIALOGUE
label: Title

text: During the 1920s, Anglo-Irish designer Eileen Gray and Romanian architect Jean
label: Paragraph

text: Badovici, editor of the French avant-garde periodical L’Architecture Vivante, wrote
label: Paragraph

text: a series of essays in dialogue form.’ These constitute an alternative to the mani-
label: Paragraph

text: festo, the principle literary means by which Modern Movement architects
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to argue for the “universal” validity of their approach. The most signif-
label: Paragraph

text: icant of Gray’s architectural collaborations with Badovici, the house E.1027 in
label: Caption

text: Roquebrune-Cap Martin, France (1926-29), operates in dialogue with Le Corbu-
label: Paragraph

text: sier’s “Five Points of a New Architecture,” an early version of which Badovici
label: Paragraph

text: published in L’Architecture Vivante.’
label: Paragraph

text: Working in Dialogue
label: Title

text: Whereas Eileen Gray’s early lacquer work and interiors were motivated by the
label: Paragraph

text: sensual luxury associated with the French decorative arts, she derived the non-
label: Paragraph

text: heroic aspects of her subsequent architectural production from a critical engage-
label: Paragraph

text: ment with the work of her avant-garde contemporaries. While challenging
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of Le Corbusier’s theoretical approach to the modern dwelling, she simul-
label: Paragraph

text: taneously distilled ideas from Adolf Loos and the advocates of De Stijl, among
label: Paragraph

text: others. Rather than reflecting the limitations of Gray’s a-theoretical stance, this
label: Paragraph

text: reliance on certain leaders of the architectural avant-garde was a necessary corol-
label: Paragraph

text: lary to her own creative act. By working within the framework of particular Mod-
label: Paragraph

text: erm Movement spatial devices in her early buildings and projects, Gray sought to
label: Paragraph

text: overcome the dehumanizing qualities associated with abstraction by prioritizing
label: Paragraph

text: the subjective qualities of experience. Rather than begin her designs from a set of
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical precepts declared in a manifesto — the approach favored by her heroic
label: Paragraph

text: counterparts — Gray challenged the totalizing aims of such examples of contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary theorizing by working within and expanding upon selective aspects
label: Paragraph

text: of Modern Movement spatial principles to engage issues of quotidian comfort
label: Paragraph

text: and sensuality.
label: Paragraph

text: Dialogue differs from manifesto, the unequivocal statement of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: principles that was the preferred form of written exposition for the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde. Manifestos are written, not to interpret the world, but to change it.
label: Paragraph

text: In the architectural manifesto the form of the built environment is interpreted
label: Paragraph

text: anew. Although written to shock —to endorse change — manifestos ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: encourage conformity and orthodoxy through their exhortative tone.
label: Paragraph

text: A prominent example is Le Corbusier’s Vers une architecture (1923), structured
label: Paragraph

text: around a dialectic between the engineer’s aesthetic and architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Gray and Badovici were inspired to engage in dialogue by Paul Valéry’s
label: Paragraph

text: “Epautinos ou UVarchitecte” of 1921.° Unlike the dialectic method instituted by the
label: Paragraph

text: ancient Greeks, which involved a debate between two opposing points of view
label: Paragraph

text: to attain a superior form of knowledge, Valéry’s twentieth-century dialogue is a
label: Paragraph

text: mode of exchange that is infinite in tone, scope, and number of variables. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: the aim of dialectic reasoning is a higher truth achieved via a synthesis of opposing
label: Paragraph

text: concepts, a dialogue elaborates the ever-shifting relationship between ideas, a gen-
label: Paragraph

text: erative exchange that is never resolved but perpetually in flux. Gray and Badovici
label: Paragraph

text: used this literary genre to voice alternate points of view, one more rational and
label: Paragraph

text: scientific and the other motivated primarily by human sensibility, reflecting differ-
label: Paragraph

text: ences between the assertive terms of avant-garde rhetoric and the more subtle
label: Paragraph

text: arguments espoused by Gray. Their dialogues transcend the singularity of polem-
label: Paragraph

text: ical assertions about the Modern Movement to elaborate their nuances and internal
label: Paragraph

text: contradictions, thus revealing the movement’s complex character.
label: Paragraph

text: Gray represents the most substantive voice in these dialogues. While Badovici
label: Paragraph

text: introduced themes associated with avant-garde theory, such as geometry, abstrac-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, hygiene, mechanization, functionalism, and the avant-garde, Gray opened
label: Paragraph

text: them up to a relational logic that contrasts the manifesto’s assertive tone. She
label: Paragraph

text: exploited dialogue for its capacity to expand upon certain dichotomies prevalent
label: Paragraph

text: in Modern Movement discourse: body and spirit; reason and intuition; order
label: Paragraph

text: and flux; science and art; individual and collective; particular and universal. Rather
label: Paragraph

text: than view such categorical distinctions as mutually exclusive, she sought their
label: Paragraph

text: points of convergence and overlap.
label: Paragraph

text: Gray occasionally wrote in prose, using that form to engage Le Corbusier’s writ-
label: Paragraph

text: ings in dialogue. Ina description of E.1027, the house that she built both for and with
label: Paragraph

text: Badovici on a remote site overlooking the Mediterranean in 1927-29, she qualified
label: Paragraph

text: certain statements from Vers une architecture. Responding to Le Corbusier's asser-
label: Paragraph

text: tion: “Architecture is the masterly, correct and magnificent play of masses brought
label: Paragraph

text: together in light,” Gray focused on generating architecture from the life of the inte-
label: Paragraph

text: rior: “Iflyricism can be dedicated to the play of masses brought together in daylight,
label: Paragraph

text: the interior should respond to human needs and the exigencies of individual life, and
label: Paragraph

text: it should ensure calm and intimacy.” She countered his often-repeated assertion,
label: Paragraph

text: “The plan is the generator,” by declaring her priority for human values: “The thing
label: Paragraph

text: constructed is more important than the way it is constructed, and the process is sub-
label: Paragraph

text: ordinate to the plan, not the plan to the process. It is not only a matter of construct-
label: Paragraph

text: ing beautiful arrangements of lines, but above all, dwellings for people.”*
label: Paragraph

text: To Gray, a house was not an object to be apprehended through intellectual
label: Paragraph

text: detachment, but a flexible structure whose occupants would invest it with life,
label: Paragraph

text: as she argued: “External architecture seems to have absorbed avant-garde archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects at the expense of the interior, as if a house should be conceived for the pleas-
label: Paragraph

text: ure of the eye more than for the well-being of its inhabitants.” Linking her critique
label: Paragraph

text: of the building as object with her a-theoretical stance, she concluded: “Theory is
label: Paragraph

text: insufficient for life and does not respond to all its requirements.”* While resisting
label: Paragraph

text: the lure of architectural theory, she recognized the need to transcend the intuitive
label: Paragraph

text: limits of her work and ground it in the intellect — in a fertile combination of the
label: Paragraph

text: sensual and the commonsensical. The title of the dialogue published in the issue
label: Paragraph

text: of L’Architecture vivante devoted to E.1027, “From Eclecticism to Doubt,” is itself
label: Paragraph

text: dialogic; it reflects the uncertainty that accompanied the early twentieth-century
label: Paragraph

text: rejection of historic styles and the resulting quest for rigorous and logical bases
label: Paragraph

text: for architectural form, often grounded in issues of use.
label: Paragraph

text: The design of E.1027 makes explicit reference to Le Corbusier's “
label: Paragraph

text: New Architecture.” Such reliance on Corbusian formulas served as a corollary to
label: Paragraph

text: Five Points of a
label: Title

text: Gray’s own creative act. By challenging and/or working within the framework of
label: Paragraph

text: such Modern Movement spatial devices, she sought to overcome the supposedly
label: Paragraph

text: cold and inhuman qualities associated with abstract forms by engaging the subjec-
label: Paragraph

text: tive qualities of experience. Opposing the formulaic aspects of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto, she argued: “Formulas are nothing, life is everything. And life is simul-
label: Paragraph

text: taneously mind and heart.” Rather than reject such formulas outright, however,
label: Paragraph

text: Gray sought to challenge their limits and “push them to the point where they rees-
label: Paragraph

text: tablish contact with life, to incorporate reality within their abstraction.”° She con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceived of E.1027 from the interior outward, from a reconsideration of the modern
label: Caption

text: individual’s need for an interior life and a place of retreat. “The interior plan should
label: Paragraph

text: not be the incidental result of the facade,” she argued in reaction to certain of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's built works; “It should live a complete, harmonious and logical life.”
label: Paragraph

text: She sought a more integrated conception, an interior that “as in Gothic times [was]
label: Paragraph

text: a homogenous whole built for man, to the human scale and balanced in all its
label: Paragraph

text: parts.””
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture as Dialogue: E.1027
label: Title

text: On an exhibition placard associated with E.1027, Gray articulated her objectives:
label: Paragraph

text: “House envisaged from a social point of view: minimum of space, maximum of
label: Paragraph

text: comfort.” Toward this end she adopted certain ordering principles that she fol-
label: Paragraph

text: owed throughout her career: orienting the main living space to the southern expo-
label: Paragraph

text: sure and view, and bedrooms to the rising sun; segregating private areas from the
label: Paragraph

text: more public zones; isolating service spaces. The spatial hierarchy of E.1027 reflects
label: Paragraph

text: Badovici’s penchant for entertaining: an open living/dining room capable of
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating extra guests and a discrete zone for sleeping, dressing, and work
label: Paragraph

text: on the main level; an independent kitchen adjoining an outdoor cooking space near
label: Paragraph

text: the main entry; a guest room and minimal housekeeper’s quarters on the
label: Paragraph

text: ower level.
label: Paragraph

text: By integrating furniture and architecture, Gray facilitated multiple uses in each
label: Paragraph

text: space. She conceived of the living room opening onto a narrow balcony as a loggia,
label: Paragraph

text: equipped with screen-like vertical windows capable of opening fully to admit sun-
label: Paragraph

text: ight and view. A sleeping alcove and adjoining shower/ dressing area off the far
label: Paragraph

text: corner of the room and a dining alcove near the stair contribute to the room’s plu-
label: Paragraph

text: rality of use. To invoke a more remote locale, Gray incorporated a nautical chart of
label: Paragraph

text: the Caribbean in her design. Overlaid with the inscriptions “invitation au voyage,”
label: Paragraph

text: *Beaux temps,” and “vas-y-totor” (the name she gave her automobile), the collage
label: Paragraph

text: is an inducement to travel farther afield, both luring the imagination and under-
label: Paragraph

text: scoring the limited temporality of modern conditions of dwelling. Affixed to the
label: Paragraph

text: wall by a tubular light fixture and folding shelves, this collage exemplified an
label: Paragraph

text: important principle for Gray: the inseparability of art and architecture — a view
label: Title

text: she shared with the early adherents of De Stijl. She treated the floors in a manner
label: Paragraph

text: consistent with the interrelationship of furniture and walls, overlapping rugs on
label: Paragraph

text: a carpetlike pattern of black-and-white floor tiles. The adaptable furnishings
label: Paragraph

text: and fittings enable the house to accommodate shifting individual requirements
label: Paragraph

text: while enhancing its function as a sanctuary from the vicissitudes of contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: urban life.
label: Paragraph

text: In Le Corbusier's related reinterpretation of the bourgeois dwelling — the Pavil-
label: Paragraph

text: lon de VEsprit Nouveau (1925) — he included conventional gendered spaces: a study
label: Paragraph

text: adjoining the dining space and a boudoir off the master bedroom. To eliminate
label: Paragraph

text: gender associations from comparable spaces at E.1027, Gray inverted their relative
label: Paragraph

text: positions, placing a bed alcove off the living room and her own workspace off the
label: Paragraph

text: principal bedroom. She termed her workroom a “boudoir-studio,” merging the
label: Paragraph

text: historically gendered spaces of boudoir and study into a single entity.
label: Paragraph

text: While treating E.1027 as a site of selective liberation for its occupants, Gray pro-
label: Paragraph

text: vided them with a concomitant sense of anchorage by drawing on their physical
label: Paragraph

text: presence. Her elaboration of the strip window manifests the potential for these
label: Paragraph

text: apparently divergent qualities to coexist. The strip window was a primary element
label: Paragraph

text: in Le Corbusier's domestic ensemble; he termed it “the primordial element or
label: Paragraph

text: agent of the house.”* In contrast to Le Corbusier’s sharp delineation of the strip
label: Paragraph

text: window, Gray articulated hers as a layered membrane. Its outer zone of sliding
label: Paragraph

text: shutters with segments that pivot vertically contributes to interior comfort and pri-
label: Paragraph

text: vacy by limiting solar penetration and views from the outside while admitting ven-
label: Paragraph

text: tilation. She based her pivoting shutters on a traditional Mediterranean form, which
label: Paragraph

text: she adapted to a horizontal format, arguing: “a window without shutters is an eye
label: Paragraph

text: without eyelids.”” By equipping the windows with vertical panes of glass that are
label: Paragraph

text: proportioned to the human body, she suggested the possibility of embracing Mod-
label: Paragraph

text: erm Movement principles without suffering the loss of anthropomorphic reference
label: Title

text: inherent to traditional windows. These panes and the doors opening onto the ter-
label: Paragraph

text: race pivot and slide, much like draperies, to facilitate an uninterrupted expanse; the
label: Paragraph

text: interior can thus open directly to garden and sea. In these terms Gray’s strip win-
label: Paragraph

text: dow merges two seemingly disparate objectives: opening the private recesses of the
label: Paragraph

text: interior to the outer world, and affording the body a sense of protection. In making
label: Paragraph

text: exposure to the outer world a matter of choice, she fulfilled the premise of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern dwelling as a volume reaching for light, while maintaining privacy in
label: Paragraph

text: the interior.
label: Paragraph

text: Gray extended her critique of Corbusian principles to the building’s exterior. The
label: Paragraph

text: terraced site posed a challenge to Le Corbusier’s twin postulates of pilotis and roof
label: Paragraph

text: garden, with their hypothetical reliance on a flat ground plane. In response to the
label: Paragraph

text: existing fieldstone walls and layered ground, Gray made the relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: building and site physical and tangible rather than abstract and theoretical. Counter-
label: Paragraph

text: ing Le Corbusier’s use of pilotis to isolate dwelling from ground, she developed the
label: Paragraph

text: space within the pilotis as an outdoor living room, engaging the fieldstone walls to give
label: Paragraph

text: it privacy. She subtly depressed this external volume into the earth to affirm the dwell-
label: Paragraph

text: ing’s grounded essence. Such co-optation of the ground plane made the roof terrace
label: Paragraph

text: functionally redundant, a quality Gray reinforced by omitting rooftop parapets.
label: Paragraph

text: Both the interior and exterior of E.1027 are characterized by a new interdepend-
label: Paragraph

text: ence of parts. Architectural components and furnishings are rarely perceived as
label: Paragraph

text: bounded or distinct; rather, their value is understood in relation to adjoining ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments. Gray’s fascination with opacity and indecipherability led her to focus on the
label: Paragraph

text: surface of elements, their colors, textures, and reflective qualities, rather than on
label: Paragraph

text: their profile, modeling, or position in a legible space. She never isolated the indi-
label: Paragraph

text: vidual element or made it represent the ensemble as a whole. The boundaries of
label: Paragraph

text: elements are no longer frontiers, but extend into the lines of the adjoining walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Badovici described the resulting visual mélange as “a richly realized totality of
label: Paragraph

text: space.”?°
label: Paragraph

text: By emphasizing bodily experience, with its meaning-laden immersion of the
label: Paragraph

text: viewer in the flesh of the world, Gray challenged Le Corbusier’s Cartesian privile-
label: Paragraph

text: ging of cerebral understanding at the cost of the actual senses. She invoked the
label: Paragraph

text: senses directly and indirectly in both architecture and furnishings: in the tile floor-
label: Paragraph

text: ing underfoot that radiates heat from the sun or the cork-covered tea and dining
label: Paragraph

text: tables that muffle sound. Where Le Corbusier used curved forms to represent the
label: Paragraph

text: body, Gray relied on materials to engage qualities of bodily contact, from chro-
label: Paragraph

text: mium handrails to fur bed-throws. Furthermore, her furniture invokes analogies
label: Paragraph

text: with the mechanics of the body: in the flexible table that extends to meet the occu-
label: Paragraph

text: pant of the bed, the drawers that pivot horizontally, or the hinged mirror that
label: Paragraph

text: affords oblique views of the head.
label: Paragraph

text: In those areas of the house where contact with the body is most intimate — the
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom and bathroom — Gray strove to heighten bodily awareness. The profu-
label: Paragraph

text: sion of shimmering materials in the bathroom, for example, includes tiled walls,
label: Paragraph

text: a folding mirror, a porcelain sink, and a polished aluminum tub enclosure. Their
label: Paragraph

text: cool surfaces provide a soothing respite from the relentless Mediterranean sun.
label: Paragraph

text: Such material palpability invokes a sense of the erotic; the house is marked by
label: Paragraph

text: the experience of a sensual being. “The poverty of modern architecture,” Gray
label: Paragraph

text: wrote during the 1940s in an explicit challenge to Le Corbusier, “stems from
label: Paragraph

text: the atrophy of sensuality. Everything is dominated by reason in order to create
label: Paragraph

text: amazement without proper research. The art of the engineer is not enough if it
label: Paragraph

text: is not guided by the primitive needs of men. Reason without instinct. We must
label: Paragraph

text: mistrust merely pictorial elements if they are not assimilated by instinct.””?
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas Le Corbusier used a mechanistic logic in asserting that, “a house is a
label: Paragraph

text: machine for living in,” Gray privileged qualitative aspects of habitation over
label: Paragraph

text: quantitative criteria, arguing: “The art of the engineer is not sufficient, unless
label: Paragraph

text: it is guided by human needs.” Responding to Le Corbusier’s well-known maxim,
label: Paragraph

text: she concluded: “A house is not a machine to live in. It is the shell of man, his
label: Paragraph

text: extension, his release, his spiritual emanation. Not only its visual harmony but
label: Paragraph

text: its entire organization, all the terms of the work, combine to render it human
label: Paragraph

text: in the most profound sense.”'? Much like the imaginary country that Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Baudelaire conjured up in his prose poem, “L’invitation au voyage” (1869), an
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration for the mural in the E.1027 salon, one could say of Gray’s architecture:
label: Paragraph

text: “It is there we must go to breathe, to dream, and to prolong the hours in an infin-
label: Paragraph

text: ity of sensations.” ””
label: Paragraph

text: Although Gray remained a silent partner in Badovici’s early writings, the art of
label: Paragraph

text: dialogue informed her architecture on several levels. Rather than begin her designs
label: Paragraph

text: from a set of theoretical precepts declared in a manifesto, Gray challenged the all-
label: Paragraph

text: encompassing claims of such examples of contemporary theorizing by questioning,
label: Paragraph

text: adapting, and/or expanding upon them, thereby engaging them in dialogue.
label: Paragraph

text: Through this critical process she sought to enhance the human potential of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, overcoming its supposed alienating qualities by reinstating fundamen-
label: Paragraph

text: tal physical, psychological, and spiritual needs as primary. A dialogue is open
label: Paragraph

text: ended; it does not seek to prove a point, but leads its readers to draw their own
label: Paragraph

text: conclusions. This approach led Gray to design buildings that have the same effect —
label: Paragraph

text: with respect to both the experiences of their occupants and the designs of her
label: Paragraph

text: “heroic” counterparts.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier: In Response
label: Title

text: Gray’s architectural dialogue with Le Corbusier took on new dimensions in 1938/
label: Paragraph

text: 39, when the Swiss architect painted a series of murals on the walls of E.1027. In
label: Paragraph

text: light of Badovici’s complicity in the production of these pictorial interventions, the
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances surrounding their creation merit scrutiny. In 1935 Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: painted his first mural in the living room of Badovici’s house in Vézelay, a pair
label: Paragraph

text: of small stone structures that Badovici renovated in 1927-31 according to plans
label: Paragraph

text: drawn up by Gray. To the rear of the house was a small garden court, set into
label: Paragraph

text: the steep hillside. As both its shallow depth and the height of its rear wall reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: the dwelling’s limited volume, Badovici invited Fernand Léger to paint a mural on
label: Paragraph

text: the courtyard wall in 1934. Prose poet Jean Follain remarked on the result:
label: Paragraph

text: I met Léger in Vézelay, at the house of the architect Badovici, who asked him to
label: Paragraph

text: come paint a wall, a wall without life, which blocked all views and closed off a small
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard. Léger came and he destroyed the wall, pulverizing it under a burst of red
label: Paragraph

text: color, and, in the play of tonal values, several simple and graceful objects remained in
label: Paragraph

text: place, expressing all the power of their magical volume, their belonging to the uni-
label: Paragraph

text: verse and, at the same time, their magnificent isolation.’*
label: Paragraph

text: Inspired by Léger’s example, Le Corbusier painted his first mural on an upper
label: Paragraph

text: surface of Badovici’s Vézelay living room. On the basis of these interventions,
label: Paragraph

text: Badovici claimed that he, Léger and Le Corbusier rediscovered the great pictorial
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of spatial painting, as “assembled before the courtyard wall ... an idea
label: Paragraph

text: occurred to us all: THAT OF THE DESTRUCTION OF WALLS BY PAINTING,
label: Paragraph

text: ”} ‘This statement opposes Gray's
label: Paragraph

text: position on painting and architecture expressed in one of Badovici’s early dialo-
label: Paragraph

text: gues: “Painting must not ... oppose itself to the construction, but on the contrary
label: Paragraph

text: it must emphasize its character, accentuate its rhythms.”’° His eagerness to comply
label: Paragraph

text: with Corbusian polemics apparently led Badovici to ignore any incongruities
label: Paragraph

text: between this pictorial dissolution of the wall and Gray’s more constructive integra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of architecture and the decorative arts.
label: Paragraph

text: As with the Vézelay murals, Badovici not only sanctioned, but encouraged Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's pictorial interventions at E.1027. However, contrary to Gray’s architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural intentions, these murals brought Badovici considerable pleasure, as he
label: Paragraph

text: recounted to Le Corbusier after surveying the damage they sustained under the Ital-
label: Paragraph

text: ian bombardment during World War II: “Your frescoes more luminous and beau-
label: Paragraph

text: tiful than ever.”’” Yet even Léger found the Roquebrune murals too intrusive, as he
label: Paragraph

text: commented to Le Corbusier, “don’t you think that you have gone too far with color
label: Paragraph

text: for an interior?”’*
label: Title

text: Whereas the words that Gray inscribed on the walls of E.1027 using Corbusian
label: Paragraph

text: stencils — “overcoats and umbrellas,” “pillows,” “shoes,” “little things,” “teeth,”
label: Paragraph

text: “no laughing” (on a partition in the entry hall) — comprise a wry commentary
label: Paragraph

text: on functionalist logic, those upon which Le Corbusier superimposed his mural
label: Paragraph

text: ” “enter slowly” — constitute a more overt provoca-
label: Paragraph

text: crowning, above all, the architecture to come.
label: Paragraph

text: by the front door — “one way,
label: Paragraph

text: tion. His suggestion that Badovici remove the hallway partition, which inhibited
label: Paragraph

text: views into the living room, is a revealing indicator of their differences. Gray sought
label: Paragraph

text: to transcend the reductive nature of the total view. Affording limited glimpses of
label: Paragraph

text: the salon between the partition’s coat closet and its stand for depositing umbrellas,
label: Paragraph

text: she called upon the imagination to draw one into the experience while kinesthe-
label: Paragraph

text: tically engaging the body in rituals of entry.
label: Paragraph

text: While Gray may have considered Le Corbusier's pictorial interventions at
label: Paragraph

text: E.1027 “an act of vandalism,” she deemed his published remarks about the murals’
label: Paragraph

text: role in the architecture a more problematic provocation:
label: Paragraph

text: The walls chosen to receive nine large paintings were the most colorless and insig-
label: Paragraph

text: nificant. In this way the beautiful walls have remained and the indifferent ones have
label: Paragraph

text: become very interesting... One must recognize above all that the proprietor and
label: Paragraph

text: I had witnessed the nourishment and development of a spatial phenomenon — as,
label: Paragraph

text: little by little, the paintings emerged under the brush. An immense transformation.
label: Paragraph

text: A spiritual value introduced throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: Apparently aware of the controversy his paintings aroused, Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: concluded:
label: Title

text: It is not for me to decide whether this value is, here, pleasing or the contrary. When
label: Paragraph

text: one opens one’s doors to an artist, one gives him speech. When he speaks, one lis-
label: Paragraph

text: tens... Hence the great risk one runs in having his walls painted.’”
label: Paragraph

text: In a letter that Gray encouraged him to write, Badovici issued a sharp rebuttal to
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s published comments:
label: Paragraph

text: What a narrow prison you have built for me over a number of years, particularly this
label: Paragraph

text: year through your vanity... My hut served |you] as a testing ground by sacrificing the
label: Paragraph

text: profound direction of an attitude that formally banished painting. As purely func-
label: Paragraph

text: tional architecture, that was its strength for such a long time: 1925. And you have
label: Paragraph

text: denied its absolute character with such harshness in your writings, disseminating
label: Paragraph

text: them through your worldwide authority. You lack any generosity toward me.
label: Paragraph

text: A correction from you seems necessary; if not, | will be forced to do it myself, thus
label: Paragraph

text: to reestablish the original spirit of the house by the sea.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the acerbic tone of this exchange, Gray’s admiration for Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was undiminished. She continued to take active interest in his work
label: Paragraph

text: and use it in counterpoint to her own ideas. She took pride in the note that Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier sent her from E.1027 in 1938, in which he expressed his admiration
label: Paragraph

text: for the “rare spirit” of the house:
label: Paragraph

text: genuinely regret having arrived here too late to have been able to spend some time
label: Paragraph

text: with you ... | hope that you will give us the pleasure of paying us a visit in Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: would be delighted to relate how much those few days spent in your house have
label: Paragraph

text: made me appreciate the rare spirit that dictates all of its organization, both inside and
label: Paragraph

text: outside, and has given the modern furniture and equipment a form that is so digni-
label: Paragraph

text: fied, so charming and full of wit.?!
label: Paragraph

text: On visiting Le Corbusier’s exhibition at the Musée d’Art Moderne in Paris in
label: Paragraph

text: 1953, which included numerous examples of his paintings, Gray noted: “I was
label: Paragraph

text: much impressed, this man has a genius for presentation or whatever you call it;
label: Paragraph

text: the whole place, so banal generally, was changed.””” In response to Colin Rowe’s
label: Paragraph

text: commentary on Le Corbusier’s monastery of La Tourette in The Architectural
label: Caption

text: Review, she proclaimed:
label: Paragraph

text: Was fascinated by the Photos and account of Corbu’s monastery, the first photos
label: Paragraph

text: I have seen. No one has seen it as yet in Paris. What a vitality in that man and
label: Paragraph

text: how much he has learnt from working in India.”
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier reciprocated this appreciation in the holiday cabin that he built for
label: Paragraph

text: himself next to the property adjoining E.1027 in 1952. Although Gray professed
label: Paragraph

text: that she did not understand how Le Corbusier could have built himself “just a
label: Paragraph

text: wooden shack,” several aspects of his design reflect her concern for the nuances
label: Paragraph

text: of vision and visibility.** A narrow corridor at the entry blocks views of the modest
label: Paragraph

text: room from visitors’ prying eyes, despite both his repudiation of that idea at E.1027
label: Paragraph

text: and the cabin’s diminutive size. He used the walls of this narrow passage to con-
label: Paragraph

text: tinue his experiments into the pictorial dissolution of the wall. By limiting mural
label: Paragraph

text: painting to this entry passage, he ensured that such images would not intrude on
label: Paragraph

text: the domestic milieu within, where bi-fold wooden shutters attached to the inside of
label: Paragraph

text: the windows include both painted and mirrored segments. The mirrors enabled
label: Paragraph

text: him to manipulate views of mountains and sea and to achieve certain visual effects
label: Paragraph

text: of the strip window from square apertures. This recalls Gray’s account of her win-
label: Paragraph

text: dows at E.1027:
label: Caption

text: When the seas are rough and the horizon gloomy, it suffices to close the large south-
label: Paragraph

text: ern windows, draw the curtains and open the small northern window that overlooks
label: Paragraph

text: the garden of lemon trees and the old village to seek a new and different horizon,
label: Paragraph

text: where the masses of greenery replace the expanses of blue and gray.””
label: Paragraph

text: In addition, Le Corbusier’s custom-made built-ins and hidden storage compart-
label: Paragraph

text: ments accommodate multiple functions in the restricted volume. Such details attest
label: Paragraph

text: to his open attitude toward architectural form and his willingness to engage her
label: Paragraph

text: work in dialogue, as well as his enduring esteem for Gray’s accomplishment.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret
label: Title

text: Richard Wesley
label: Title

text: Le Corbusier, Villa Savoye, view from the south-west, Poissy, France, 1929.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.

text: BUILDING ON A CLEAR HORIZON
label: Title

text: al
label: Title

text: “The horizons must be re-disclosed.
label: Paragraph

text: The Villa Savoye was designed by the artist-architect, Le Corbusier, in collabo-
label: Paragraph

text: ration with another architect, his cousin Pierre Jeanneret. In this case the artist-
label: Paragraph

text: architect was a painter educated to observe and admire nature by another artist,
label: Paragraph

text: Charles L’Eplattenier, who painted vibrant landscapes.” Not surprisingly the house
label: Paragraph

text: frames a number of views of the surrounding landscape, sometimes between col-
label: Paragraph

text: umns, sometimes through openings in walls, and sometimes through windows. In
label: Paragraph

text: one instance on the second level a view is framed from a roof-garden into the living
label: Paragraph

text: room through a mur de verre coulissant — a floor-to-ceiling sliding glass wall — and
label: Paragraph

text: then out again on the opposite wall through a long, horizontal window — a fenétre en
label: Paragraph

text: longueur. In most instances one is allowed to move freely through the house posi-
label: Paragraph

text: tioning oneself in various relationships to these framed views; but this is not the
label: Paragraph

text: case moving up the central ramp to the third level where the orientation and direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of movement are predetermined and the ultimate view is framed on an axis
label: Paragraph

text: with the ramp and in a frontal relationship to the line of travel. Surprisingly, the
label: Paragraph

text: view offered at the destination of the ramp is framed by a relatively small, window-
label: Paragraph

text: less opening in a windscreen wall. This opening limits the prospect of the horizon
label: Paragraph

text: more than any other view-frame in the house. Perhaps this is what the designers of
label: Paragraph

text: the villa meant when they described the house as “a veritable architectural prom-
label: Paragraph

text: enade, offering constantly varied aspects, unexpected, sometimes surprising.”
label: Paragraph

text: That a house by two architects, one of whom was also a painter, was conceived
label: Paragraph

text: as sequential tableaux should not be surprising; but it is a surprise to find the degree
label: Paragraph

text: to which the automobile was incorporated into the view sequence. Driving onto
label: Paragraph

text: the property from the rue de Villiers formerly the chemin des Migneaux) past the
label: Paragraph

text: gardener’s lodge on the right, one turns left onto a lane pre-existing the villa (visible
label: Paragraph

text: in the photograph on p. 233) that runs at an angle neither parallel to the road nor
label: Paragraph

text: perpendicular to the house. Turning right from this lane onto the driveway the
label: Paragraph

text: automobile is shifted into a frontal relationship to the house — not centered on
label: Paragraph

text: the facade, but aligned with the bay of covered space on the right defined by
label: Paragraph

text: the recessed walls of the house on the left and free standing posts or stilts, pilotis,
label: Paragraph

text: on the right. Much like the destination at the top of the ramp, the orientation and
label: Paragraph

text: direction at the beginning of the movement sequence are precisely determined.
label: Paragraph

text: The driveway penetrates the house beneath the second level, circles around the
label: Paragraph

text: supposed back of the house, where the main entry is located, and returns to the
label: Paragraph

text: lane at the apparent front of the house. This U-shaped space carved out of three
label: Paragraph

text: sides of the first level of the house (visible in the photograph on p. 233) is a hybrid
label: Paragraph

text: form of an ancient loggia and a contemporary porte-cochére. On one set of drawings
label: Caption

text: this hybridized space is labeled “abri,” implying a naturally sheltered space typically
label: Paragraph

text: found on the side of a hill beneath overhanging rock. Such a label by the architects
label: Paragraph

text: might express an aspiration that both an ancient and a modern space type have
label: Paragraph

text: connections to a spatial archetype found in nature. In the Villa Savoye the abri
label: Paragraph

text: is defined beneath the second level of the house between the walls on its inner edge
label: Paragraph

text: and a line of pilotis along its outer edge. These pilotis act to frame views of the
label: Paragraph

text: immediate landscape from the abri in the direction of travel and along the periphery
label: Paragraph

text: on the right. With its wide-open horizontal views the roofed and compressed space
label: Paragraph

text: of the abri on the first level appears as an inverted prefiguration of the roofless solar-
label: Paragraph

text: ium on the third level with its relatively small opening punched through the wind-
label: Paragraph

text: screen wall. The sill of this opening extends inward providing a built-in table. Here,
label: Paragraph

text: the table top, an important image in Purist painting, extends from the opening in
label: Paragraph

text: the windscreen wall as both a locus of domestic dwelling and a definitive plane
label: Paragraph

text: along which the view to the distant horizon of nature is progressively redisclosed
label: Paragraph

text: as one moves up the ramp.
label: Paragraph

text: Orienting and Structuring the Villa
label: Title

text: The Villa Savoye is located in Poissy, a commune in the suburbs of Paris approx-
label: Paragraph

text: imately 24 kilometers north-west of the city center. At the time it was constructed
label: Paragraph

text: the villa was located south-east of the village center. The village has since expanded
label: Paragraph

text: and now encroaches on the original site of the house. An axial line projected
label: Paragraph

text: through the center of the house — through the center of the U-shaped abri and
label: Paragraph

text: entry — intersects the far bank of the Seine River approximately 825 meters, or half
label: Paragraph

text: a mile, away where, surprisingly, an axial line projected through the center of the
label: Paragraph

text: nearby Chateau de Villiers, built in the mid-nineteenth century, also converges. So
label: Paragraph

text: important to the architects of the villa was the precise angle of the view that the
label: Paragraph

text: living room on the second level of the house is oriented toward the north-west, a
label: Paragraph

text: less than ideal orientation with regard to the sun since it provides little or no sun-
label: Paragraph

text: light during most times of the day and year and brutal late-afternoon sunlight dur-
label: Paragraph

text: ing others. The villa is oriented neither with respect to the angles of the existing
label: Paragraph

text: road and lane, nor with respect to optimum sunlight conditions. Instead, the house
label: Paragraph

text: is oriented on the ordinal directions on an axis running from the south-east to the
label: Paragraph

text: north-west toward a distant location along the Seine River. It isn’t surprising that
label: Paragraph

text: the designers of the villa chose not to orient the house in relation to an existing road
label: Paragraph

text: or lane, but instead toward a view, even though the view may have been more
label: Paragraph

text: generalized and ideal than specific and real; but it is surprising that the north-west
label: Paragraph

text: orientation of the house is in direct opposition to the principles of orientation
label: Paragraph

text: according to an axe heliothermique — a heliothermic axis, a term made renowned
label: Paragraph

text: in an exhibition at the 1930 International Congresses of Modern Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (CIAM) by one of the villa’s architects, Charles-Edouard Jeanneret-Gris, also
label: Paragraph

text: known as Le Corbusier.* A floor-to-ceiling and wall-to-wall mur de verre coulissant
label: Paragraph

text: (sliding glass wall) on the south-east side of the living room facing the roof-garden
label: Caption

text: compensates for the lack of sunlight through the living room’s north-west view
label: Paragraph

text: window, the architects’ solution to a situation where “Vorientation du soleil est oppo-
label: Paragraph

text: sée a celle de vue.”*
label: Paragraph

text: The programmatic requirements for the villa were simple: a weekend house for
label: Paragraph

text: a married couple with one child, where the family could enjoy the rustic surround-
label: Paragraph

text: ings of Poissy, a rural village in the late 1920s.° Although the open land surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: the house is approximately one acre today, the original property consisted of 7 hec-
label: Paragraph

text: tares, or about 17 acres. As constructed the villa included a main house, a garden-
label: Paragraph

text: er’s lodge, and an orchard. The house contained a three-car garage, an entrance
label: Paragraph

text: hall, a laundry, two maid’s rooms, and a chauffeur’s apartment on the first level.
label: Paragraph

text: The main living areas of the house were located on the second level and included a
label: Paragraph

text: roof-garden, a combined living-dining room, a kitchen, a master bedroom suite
label: Paragraph

text: with a boudoir and bathroom, a child’s bedroom with bathroom, and a guest room
label: Paragraph

text: with bathroom.’ Although in an earlier design a solarium and boudoir were located
label: Paragraph

text: on the third level, the boudoir was moved to the second level and connected to the
label: Paragraph

text: master bedroom suite when the design was revised for budgetary reasons.* The
label: Paragraph

text: house also included a partial basement. With the exception of the columns, ramp,
label: Paragraph

text: and stair, the interior partitions on the second level of the house are “free” from the
label: Paragraph

text: levels above or below. An interior ramp in the center of the house connects the first
label: Paragraph

text: level to a second level free plan, le plan libre, with access to living room, bedrooms,
label: Paragraph

text: baths, and kitchen, as well as to the roof-garden. An exterior ramp (visible in the
label: Caption

text: photograph on p. 233) connects the roof-garden on the second level to the solarium
label: Caption

text: on the third level. An internal spiral stair connects all levels of the house from the
label: Caption

text: solarium down to the basement. The shape and form of these vertical elements, the
label: Paragraph

text: ramp and the stair, are given figural significance and, at least in the case of the ramp,
label: Paragraph

text: compositional importance. Neither the ramp nor the stair seems to be “free” of the
label: Paragraph

text: structure. The stair is connected to one of the columns and the ramp fits precisely
label: Paragraph

text: within the space defined by six columns. As for the rooms on the first and second
label: Paragraph

text: levels, other than certain functional relationships with regard to proximity, privacy
label: Paragraph

text: gradient, and access to windows for light and air, the architects appear to have been
label: Paragraph

text: indifferent to their form or configuration. On the second level, the main living level
label: Paragraph

text: of the house, the rooms are rectangular in shape and dense-packed next to each
label: Paragraph

text: other with respect to the windows and column location along traditional hallways
label: Paragraph

text: for circulation. None of these rooms for day-to-day activities, including the living-
label: Paragraph

text: dining room, seems to have any connection to the promenade as it passes up the
label: Paragraph

text: ramp from the entry hall to the opening in the windscreen wall. One travels from
label: Paragraph

text: the first level to the third without going through any of the rooms on the second
label: Paragraph

text: level, with the exception of a small corner of the hall. The promenade does incor-
label: Paragraph

text: porate the roof-garden on the second level at the point of transition from the inte-
label: Paragraph

text: rior ramp to the exterior ramp. The true spatial sequence of the Villa Savoye (abri—
label: Paragraph

text: entry hall — ramp — roof-garden — solarium) bypasses all of the rooms on the second
label: Paragraph

text: level, which, along with the configuration and lack of composition of the rooms,
label: Paragraph

text: suggests that the house was intentionally designed with two orders: a ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: one for the promenade and a mundane one for everything else.
label: Paragraph

text: The roof and floors of the house are constructed with a “lost tile” system of
label: Paragraph

text: poured-in-place concrete. The minor reinforced concrete beams formed between
label: Paragraph

text: the hollow tiles are supported by girders below the slabs running from the front to
label: Paragraph

text: the back of the house.” Although Le Corbusier wrote that “the simple columns of
label: Paragraph

text: the ground floor, by their suitable plan, frame the landscape with a regularity that
label: Paragraph

text: suppresses all notions of ‘front’ or ‘back’ or ‘side’ of the house,”’® the cantilevered
label: Paragraph

text: second level differentiates the south-east and north-west front and back from the
label: Paragraph

text: sides and gives the house a definite front-back orientation, even if there is ambigu-
label: Paragraph

text: ity as to which is front and which is back. This uncertainty is caused by the location
label: Paragraph

text: of the main entrance door on the apparent back of the house, the north-west facade
label: Caption

text: opposite the road frontage; but the slots of space defined between the pilotis and the
label: Paragraph

text: edges of the overhangs create thick implied thresholds and clearly delineate the
label: Paragraph

text: front and back of the house from the sides. The girders run front-to-back and
label: Paragraph

text: are supported on cast-in-place reinforced concrete columns arrayed on a four-
label: Paragraph

text: by-four grid of 4.75-meter bays. The selection of an even number of structural bays
label: Paragraph

text: rather than an odd number places a line of columns through the center of house
label: Paragraph

text: running from front to back. This decision by the architects has the effect of denying
label: Paragraph

text: any possibility of an axis of entry or vision through the center of the front of the
label: Paragraph

text: house and reinforces through negation the significance of the peripheral penetra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the front of the house. From the apparent back of the house, however, entry
label: Paragraph

text: is through the center on an axis with the ramp.
label: Paragraph

text: A Contrivance for the Effect of Dwelling
label: Title

text: To accommodate the ramp an additional half-bay is inserted into the central struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural line of girders, creating an A-A-B-A-A rhythm of five bays from side to side of
label: Paragraph

text: the house. Perhaps the insertion of the ramp at such an obviously difficult and illog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical location relative to the structural bays was done to reinforce the primary idea of
label: Paragraph

text: the house as a vertical journey. That one winds back and forth four times on the
label: Paragraph

text: ramp, going around and around the centerline of the house, reinforces through
label: Paragraph

text: repetition the concept of the ramp as the most significant figural element in the
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye. The stair was seen by the architects as being another kind of spiraling
label: Paragraph

text: vertical figure penetrating the horizontal floor levels. “This spiral, a pure vertical
label: Paragraph

text: organ,” wrote Le Corbusier, “is inserted freely into the horizontal composition.”"*
label: Paragraph

text: Evident in Le Corbusier’s description of the Villa Savoye in Precisions is the sig-
label: Paragraph

text: nificance of the vertical movement through the horizontal layers of the house, as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the hierarchical differentiation between the use of the ramp for ascent and
label: Paragraph

text: the spiral stair for descent. “From inside the entrance, a ramp leads easily, hardly
label: Paragraph

text: noticed, up to the first floor (second level}, where the life of the inhabitants goes on
label: Paragraph

text: ... Receiving views and light from around the periphery of the box, the different
label: Paragraph

text: rooms center on a hanging garden ... From the hanging garden, the ramp, now on
label: Paragraph

text: the outside, leads to the solarium on the roof ... This is connected by a spiral stair-
label: Paragraph

text: case three stories high down to the cellar dug in the earth under the pilotis.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Much like an ancient Pompeian house structured around a hierarchical and
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic sequence of fauces-atrium-tablinium-peristylum-hortus, the Villa Savoye is
label: Paragraph

text: structured around a similar dynamic sequence beginning with an aediculalike
label: Paragraph

text: entry hall on the first level marked with four columns; a deep and narrow fau-
label: Paragraph

text: ces-like ramp leads from the entry hall to a roof-garden open to the sky, much like
label: Paragraph

text: asky-lit central atrium; and a salle, or living room, with its front opening to the roof-
label: Paragraph

text: garden and its back overlooking a hortus, in this case an orchard.” In the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Savoye the final destination is the solarium on the third level above the living-
label: Paragraph

text: dining room. Perhaps this is what Le Corbusier meant by a machine a habiter, less
label: Paragraph

text: an “appliance for environmental control” and more a “contrivance for the produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of effects of dwelling,” much like a Pompeian house. Such an interpretation
label: Paragraph

text: would rely on the less common meaning of the French word machine as a “theat-
label: Paragraph

text: rical-like device”; but despite similarities between the Pompeian house and the
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye, there is an undisputable and significant difference: while the ritualized
label: Paragraph

text: salutatio in the first is absolutely horizontal, the promenade in the second inclines
label: Paragraph

text: vertically.
label: Paragraph

text: The exterior walls of the Villa Savoye were constructed of two layers of hollow
label: Paragraph

text: concrete masonry with an air space between them. The concrete masonry was cov-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: stone was used.'* Although the original exterior colors are yet to be verified,
label: Paragraph

text: sufficient evidence exists to assume that the walls on the first level were dark green,
label: Paragraph

text: to reinforce the sense of a recess in shadow beneath the floating white rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: solid of the second level.’* The walls of the solarium on the third level were light
label: Paragraph

text: pastel colors, described in The International Style as a “white second story ... weight-
label: Paragraph

text: less on its round posts. Its severe symmetry is a foil to the brilliant study of abstract
label: Paragraph

text: form, unrestricted by structure, of the blue and rose windshelter above.”'!* The
label: Paragraph

text: interior walls throughout the house were constructed of hollow clay masonry
label: Paragraph

text: of various thicknesses depending on location, covered with plaster, and painted.
label: Paragraph

text: The treatment of the color of material surfaces in the house follows the hierarchical
label: Paragraph

text: goals of a “work of art” established by Le Corbusier and the painter Amedée Ozen-
label: Paragraph

text: fant in “Le Purisme,” published in the fourth issue of L’Esprit Nouveau, 1920.' “The
label: Paragraph

text: work of art is an artificial object which permits the creator to place the spectator in
label: Paragraph

text: the state he wishes.”’* In the case of Purism, the goal of art was “to put the spec-
label: Paragraph

text: tator in a state of a mathematical quality, that is a state of an elevated order”
label: Paragraph

text: through the compositional means of “choice of surface, division of surface, co-mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ulation, relationships of density, color scheme.””° Color is not only the last and least
label: Paragraph

text: significant of the five compositional devices, but Ozenfant and Le Corbusier warn
label: Paragraph

text: of its potential to destroy other primary compositional means since “color has prop-
label: Paragraph

text: erties of shock (sensory order) which strike the eye before form (which is a creation
label: Paragraph

text: already cerebral in part).” Throughout “Le Purisme” the authors, one an artist and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ture and painting. This is especially evident in their description of “surface,” the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: sition; space means three dimensions. Therefore we think of the painting not as
label: Paragraph

text: surface, but as a space.
