label: Paragraph

text: Although the Villa Savoye is often referenced as the ultimate manifestation of
label: Paragraph

text: the “five points of a new architecture,” a theoretical conclusion of successive
label: Paragraph

text: experiments first drafted by Le Corbusier and Jeanneret in the late 1920s, a com-
label: Paragraph

text: parison of the house with the much earlier theoretical model of the 1914 “maison
label: Paragraph

text: dom-ino” may be more productive in an attempt to understand the true formative
label: Paragraph

text: principles of the house.”* The obvious understanding of the word “dom-ino” refers
label: Paragraph

text: to the similarity in the pattern of freestanding columns — called “poteaux,” “posts,”
label: Paragraph

text: not pilotis, by Le Corbusier — in the plan of a prototypical house with a domino.
label: Paragraph

text: While the term “dom-ino” refers to the possibility of a game-like combination
label: Paragraph

text: and recombination of a modern prototypical house structure, its hyphen suggests
label: Paragraph

text: associations with other meanings. The hyphenated word “dom-ino” has possible
label: Paragraph

text: connections to other ancient Latin terms derived from dom such as in domus, a
label: Paragraph

text: household or home, and domi, to be at home. In this sense maison dom-ino might be
label: Paragraph

text: understood as a “maison domus,” a “house-home,” or “maison-domi,” a “house to be
label: Paragraph

text: at home in.” In either case a modern French word for “house” is being combined
label: Paragraph

text: with an ancient Latin term for “home.” The maison dom-ino is a theoretical model of
label: Paragraph

text: a “house-home” without walls, windows or doors, and like the Villa Savoye it also
label: Paragraph

text: implies thresholds of space along its front and back faces. These slots of space are
label: Paragraph

text: formed between the columns and the edges of the horizontal floor and roof slabs
label: Paragraph

text: and act as thickened thresholds. Like the Villa Savoye there is no center depicted in
label: Paragraph

text: the maison dom-ino. Similar to the Villa Savoye, the maison dom-ino has an even num-
label: Paragraph

text: ber of structural bays blocking any possibility of a central spatial axis without mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ification to the structural grid. In the maison dom-ino the stair is positioned outside of
label: Paragraph

text: the enclosed space as a figural projection of the rectangular form. The intention of
label: Paragraph

text: the maison dom-ino is obvious: one is meant to enter off-center through an implied
label: Paragraph

text: threshold and climb the stair to the roof. As such, the maison dom-ino is the theo-
label: Paragraph

text: retical model for the idea of a machine a habiter, a vertical journey in a “contrivance
label: Paragraph

text: for the effect of dwelling.” The first house designed by Le Corbusier and Jeanneret
label: Paragraph

text: to fully embody the maison dom-ino was not the Villa Savoye but the Hatel Parti-
label: Paragraph

text: culier A Boulogne-sur-Seine, also known as the Maison Cook, constructed in 1926.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier was well aware of the revolutionary nature of the reversal of the
label: Paragraph

text: sequential journey from an ancient horizontal one to a modern vertical one.
label: Paragraph

text: “The classic pattern is reversed,” he wrote of the Maison Cook, “The reception
label: Paragraph

text: is at the top of the house. We come directly to a roof-garden dominated by the
label: Paragraph

text: vast forests of the Bois du Boulogne; we are no longer in Paris, we are in the
label: Paragraph

text: countryside.””’
label: Paragraph

text: A Few Points about the “Five Points”
label: Title

text: Between the completion of construction of the Maison Cook in 1926 and the begin-
label: Paragraph

text: ning of the design of the Villa Savoye in 1928, Le Corbusier had engaged in an
label: Paragraph

text: active campaign to formulate and defend the principles of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The rejection in 1927 of a modern building for the League of Nations headquarters
label: Paragraph

text: in Geneva, designed by Le Corbusier and Jeanneret, in favor of a traditional Beaux-
label: Paragraph

text: Arts design, sparked the establishment of the International Congresses of Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture (CIAM). Although there was no unanimity among the international
label: Paragraph

text: attendees of the first CIAM meeting held at La Sarraz, Switzerland, on June 28,
label: Paragraph

text: 1928, a common platform emerged for a new architecture based on the logic of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary construction. Promoted at the CIAM meeting by two fellow Swiss,
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier and Sigfried Giedion, an architectural historian and the first secretary-
label: Paragraph

text: general of CIAM, the platform proposed the functional independence of the struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural skeleton from the exterior wall. Made possible by contemporary techniques
label: Caption

text: of steel and reinforced concrete construction, the independence of skeleton and
label: Paragraph

text: wall found expression in Le Corbusier’s “five points for a new architecture.”
label: Paragraph

text: According to Werner Oechslin, Les cing points d’une architecture nouvelle had first
label: Paragraph

text: been articulated in writing by Le Corbusier and Jeanneret in a letter to Alfred Roth
label: Paragraph

text: dated July 24, 1927 for translation into German by Roth and publication in Zwei
label: Caption

text: Wohnhduser von Le Corbusier und Pierre feanneret: Fiinf Punkte zu einer neuen Architek-
label: Caption

text: tur.”° In the 1927 letter, the five points were listed in the following order: les pilotis
label: Paragraph

text: (stilts or posts); les toits jardins (roof-gardens); le plan libre (free plan); la fenétre en
label: Paragraph

text: longueur (ong or horizontal window); and la facade libre (free facade). Le Corbusier
label: Caption

text: did discuss these same five terms in “Ou en est Varchitecture?” published in L’Arch-
label: Paragraph

text: itecture vivante in 1927, but placed them in a different order and added a sixth term
label: Paragraph

text: as follows: theorie du toit-jardin; la masion sur pilotis; la fenétre en longeur; le plan libre;
label: Paragraph

text: la facade libre; and the sixth, la suppression de la corniche.”’ The article in L’Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: vivante ends with plans, sections, and elevations of the Maison Cook. The
label: Paragraph

text: five points, not six, were published again in the Oeuvre compléte, 1929-34,
label: Paragraph

text: using the same terms and in the same order as in the letter to Roth, followed
label: Paragraph

text: by six pages of photographs and drawings of the Maison Cook.”* Drawings of
label: Paragraph

text: the pre-final design of the Villa Savoye appear in the same volume, followed by
label: Paragraph

text: sketches of the “four house-types” first published in “The Plan of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: House,” a lecture delivered by Le Corbusier in Buenos Aires in 1929, the same year
label: Paragraph

text: that construction began on the Villa Savoye. The house was described in the lecture
label: Paragraph

text: as the fourth of “four house types,” attaining “on the outside, the pure form of the
label: Paragraph

text: second type,” the Villa at Garches, “which shows the compression of organs within
label: Paragraph

text: a rigid envelope, absolutely pure.” On the inside the Villa Savoye house type had
label: Paragraph

text: “the advantages, the characteristics of the first type,” Maison La Roche, with “each
label: Paragraph

text: organ rising up next to its neighbor in accordance with an organic reasoning,” as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the characteristics of the third type, the Villa at Carthage, with its “visible
label: Paragraph

text: framework (skeleton structure), a simple envelope, clear, transparent as a
label: Paragraph

text: network,” allowing “useful volumes of rooms different on each floor in form
label: Paragraph

text: and quantity.””?
label: Paragraph

text: There is no specific reference to the five — or six — points in the text describing
label: Paragraph

text: the Villa Savoye in the Oeuvre complete, 1929-34. The piloitis and the roof-garden,
label: Caption

text: described as a jardin suspendu (hanging garden), and labeled on the plans as a
label: Paragraph

text: jardin terrasse, are included in the written description of the house. Perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: the indifference of Le Corbusier and Jeanneret to the number of points and their
label: Paragraph

text: ranking in the various publications of the five points suggests that they were less
label: Paragraph

text: a manifesto of modern architecture and more a result of logical thinking about
label: Paragraph

text: the results of a process over time, much like their analysis leading to the four
label: Paragraph

text: house types. As Le Corbusier had written in 1929, “we, Pierre Jeanneret and
label: Paragraph

text: I, have built quite a lot of houses. Studying our production I manage to discern
label: Paragraph

text: the general intention that determined the tendency of our work ... up to now we
label: Paragraph

text: have worked on four distinct types of plans, each expressing characteristic intel-
label: Paragraph

text: lectual preoccupations.”*’ In both lists of points produced by Le Corbusier and
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret, pilotis and roof-garden are ranked at the top suggesting the essential
label: Paragraph

text: role played by an abri on the ground level and its inverted counterpart, a roof-
label: Paragraph

text: garden, in the new architecture. If this is true, then the form of the Villa Savoye
label: Paragraph

text: has less to do with the manifesto of the static five points or the classification of
label: Paragraph

text: the four house types, and more to do with the concept of the machine 4 habiter as
label: Paragraph

text: a “contrivance for the effect of dwelling,” and its dynamic theoretical model, the
label: Paragraph

text: maison dom-ino.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1928 Giedion had published some of Le Corbusier’s work in Building in France,
label: Paragraph

text: Building in Iron, Building in Ferroconcrete,”’ an early history of modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: that Reyner Banham claimed “had a wide and curious influence on the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement’s view of its own history.” According to Banham the book “helped
label: Paragraph

text: to give the International Style a sense of international ancestry but it did so in a
label: Paragraph

text: biased manner.””” Giedion’s biased view of modern architecture as an outgrowth
label: Paragraph

text: of nineteenth-century engineering construction advanced into the early twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century is no more evident than in his reinterpretation of Le Corbusier and
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret’s original five points and in his promotion of the Villa Savoye as the epit-
label: Paragraph

text: ome of the embodiment of these principles in modern architecture. Giedion
label: Paragraph

text: gradually transformed the “five points” from a logical conclusion made by Le Cor-
label: Paragraph

text: busier and Jeanneret resulting from the observation of the design of a sequence of
label: Paragraph

text: houses into a manifesto-like set of design principles based on contemporary con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction techniques. In the preface to the second volume of the Oeuvre complete,
label: Paragraph

text: 1929-34, Giedion edited the original five points, deleting the original point four —
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal window — and adding a new point, “functional independence of struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural skeleton and wall.” He rearranged the order of the points, keeping pilotis in
label: Paragraph

text: the first position but adding the new point, “functional independence of structural
label: Paragraph

text: skeleton and wall,” in the second position. Following the new second point he
label: Paragraph

text: wrote the phrase, “This results in:” after which he listed the remaining points: free
label: Paragraph

text: plan, free facade, and in the last position, roof-garden, designating them as subser-
label: Paragraph

text: vient results of the “functional independence of structural skeleton and wall.”
label: Paragraph

text: Finally, he renamed the “five points of a new architecture” as the “five points of
label: Paragraph

text: liaison between modern architecture and technological progress.” Having deleted,
label: Paragraph

text: added, rearranged, and renamed the five points, Giedion declared the Villa Savoye
label: Paragraph

text: as “the purest and clearest example” of these principles.’’ Seven years later in 1941,
label: Paragraph

text: in a chapter on “Le Corbusier and the Means of Architectonic Expression,” in Space,
label: Paragraph

text: Time and Architecture: The Growth of a New Tradition, Giedion published the five
label: Paragraph

text: points with additional revisions along with extracts from his essay on the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Savoye originally published in Cahiers d’art in 1930, written just as construction
label: Paragraph

text: on the house was nearing completion.”* In the 1941 version of the five points, Gie-
label: Paragraph

text: dion kept the same reordering of the points from his 1934 preface in the Oeuvre
label: Paragraph

text: complete, but changed the first point, “les pilotis,” to “the pillar,” which he declared
label: Paragraph

text: “leads directly to Le Corbusier’s second principle ... the functional independence of
label: Paragraph

text: skeleton and wall.” He then explained the “free plan’ and “free facade” as conse-
label: Paragraph

text: quences of skeleton construction, and described the roof-garden as a surface that
label: Paragraph

text: “can be looked at from above,” and “used for many different intentions.” Finally, he
label: Paragraph

text: renamed the five points for a second time as the “five points of liaison between
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary architecture and contemporary construction.””’ Giedion’s revisions
label: Paragraph

text: of the five points, both in 1934 and 1941, demonstrated a determined intention to
label: Paragraph

text: transform them from a loose list of ambiguous terms into an organized manifesto
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture based on technological principles.
label: Paragraph

text: Houses can Die as well as Men
label: Title

text: At about the same time that Giedion was championing the Villa Savoye as “the purest
label: Paragraph

text: and clearest example” of the principles of the five points, the house was being pro-
label: Paragraph

text: moted by Henry-Russell Hitchcock and Philip Johnson as an example of the Inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national Style in the first exhibition of architecture at the Museum of Modern Art in
label: Paragraph

text: 1932, as well as in the concurrent publication of The International Style: Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Since 1922. Even today the Villa Savoye is cited in many academic and professional
label: Paragraph

text: circles as the pre-eminent example of both an expression of the International Style
label: Paragraph

text: and a manifestation of the five points. It is ironic, however, that concurrent with the
label: Paragraph

text: rise of the Villa Savoye to a canonical status in modern architecture, the house was
label: Paragraph

text: being declared to be uninhabitable by its owners. According to Kevin D. Murphy, “as
label: Paragraph

text: early as 1930 Emilie Savoye began a correspondence with Le Corbusier that contin-
label: Paragraph

text: ued through 1937 and in which she documented the many defects of her house.”**
label: Paragraph

text: These defects, including coldness and dampness due to an insufficient heating system
label: Paragraph

text: and extensive roof leaks, caused the owners to stop living in the house in 1938. Emilie
label: Paragraph

text: Savoye wrote to Le Corbusier in 1937, “After innumerable demands you have finally
label: Paragraph

text: accepted that this house which you built in 1929 is uninhabitable. Your ten-year
label: Paragraph

text: responsibility is at stake and I have no need to foot the bill. Please render it inhab-
label: Paragraph

text: itable immediately. I sincerely hope that I will not have to take recourse to legal
label: Paragraph

text: action.”*” Looking back in 1960, Reyner Banham juxtaposed photographs of the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Savoye, which he labeled “the summation of the Latin stream in the International
label: Paragraph

text: style — a post-Futurist villa,’ with Buckminster Fuller’s Dymaxion House,
label: Paragraph

text: 1927-30, “conceived at the time that the International style was crystallizing into
label: Paragraph

text: a set of forms symbolizing the Machine Age,” a project for a house that “established
label: Paragraph

text: a radical technological criticism of the International style as mechanically inade-
label: Paragraph

text: quate.”** The Villa Savoye was indefinitely abandoned by the Savoye family in
label: Paragraph

text: 1940 and subsequently occupied by German and American troops during the
label: Paragraph

text: war. The house was used as a barn during the period when Emilie Savoye farmed
label: Paragraph

text: the surrounding land. In 1959 Time reported “the machine for living became a
label: Paragraph

text: machine for farming,” and Historic Preservation magazine verified the need for the
label: Paragraph

text: restoration of the building following damage by troops and neglect by the owner.
label: Caption

text: That same year the town of Poissy began the process to appropriate the 7 hectares
label: Paragraph

text: of the Villa Savoye for the construction of a new school, and even before the legal
label: Paragraph

text: transaction was finalized the house had been altered for use as a youth center.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite its original technical problems and its poor condition due to disuse and
label: Paragraph

text: neglect, Emilie Savoye took an active interest in the preservation of the house and
label: Paragraph

text: conveyed to Le Corbusier the news of the appropriation of the villa. On the same
label: Caption

text: day that he received the news from her, Le Corbusier sent a series of telegrams,
label: Paragraph

text: including one to Giedion and José Luis Sert: “URGENCY. SEND FINANCIAL
label: Paragraph

text: PROPOSITIONS. SAVOYE HOUSE.” Giedion, who had a major interest in a
label: Paragraph

text: house that had become a well-known monument of modern architecture in part
label: Paragraph

text: through his historical writing, joined with Sert to launch a rigorous campaign to
label: Paragraph

text: “save Savoye.” Through the efforts of André Malraux, the French Minister of Cul-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, and the support of others around the world, the building was named a bdti-
label: Paragraph

text: ment civil in 1963; but this had little real effect on the restoration of the house. For
label: Paragraph

text: restoration to be fully supported by the French government, the house would need
label: Paragraph

text: to have been designated as a “historic monument,” and under French law this was
label: Paragraph

text: only possible for buildings whose architects were deceased. “Houses can die as well
label: Paragraph

text: as men,” said Le Corbusier in a 1959 Time magazine article, “but if there’s a way of
label: Paragraph

text: saving them, so much the better.””? But Le Corbusier couldn’t be saved. He died
label: Paragraph

text: on August 27, 1965 at Roquebrune-Cap Martin, France, near his summer home
label: Paragraph

text: while swimming in the Mediterranean Sea. His death allowed the Villa Savoye
label: Paragraph

text: to be saved. The building was officially declared an “historic monument” on
label: Paragraph

text: December 16, 1965 and two years later, when the French Ministry of Cultural
label: Paragraph

text: Affairs officially took control of the house, restoration work began and continued
label: Paragraph

text: into the late 1990s.
label: Paragraph

text: Much has been written since 1930 about the Villa Savoye, a house designed by
label: Paragraph

text: a painter-architect in association with another architect. Perhaps only Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Slutzsky, another painter, got it right: “This house is a machine for viewing.
label: Paragraph

text: The curved forms on the roof further evoke the metaphor, suggesting a roll
label: Paragraph

text: of film stretched around two spools, with the center portion cut out like a cam-
label: Paragraph

text: era aperture, framing first the sky and then the arcadian landscape as one pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gresses up the internal circulation ramp.”*° Despite a biased interpretation of the
label: Paragraph

text: “five points” as technical achievements, Giedion, too, had also once gotten the
label: Paragraph

text: essence of the new architecture “right.” In his 1928 description of the housing at
label: Paragraph

text: Pessac in Building in France, Building in Iron, Building in Ferroconcrete, Giedion
label: Caption

text: wrote: “The flat contours of Pessac merge with the sky: the suspended canopies
label: Paragraph

text: over the roof gardens form the transition. The color scheme is taken from Jean-
label: Paragraph

text: neret’s (Le Corbuiser’s) paintings: ethereal sky blue and light green, a more
label: Paragraph

text: intense brown. The interplay of the units can be judged neither spatially nor plas-
label: Paragraph

text: tically. Only relations count ... Still photography does not capture them clearly.
label: Paragraph

text: One would have to accompany the eye as it moves: only film can make the new
label: Paragraph

text: architecture intelligible!”*? But Giedion also got it right in the still photograph
label: Paragraph

text: from the south-west (see p. 233 above), published in his 1930 essay in Cahiers
label: Paragraph

text: dart. Conceived in the years of 1928-29, between the end and beginning of
label: Paragraph

text: two cataclysmic wars — the second one a global, machine-based blitzkrieg marking
label: Paragraph

text: the end of the “machine aesthetic’ and the beginning of post-war empiricism and
label: Paragraph

text: brutalism — the house appears as an architectural culmination of Purism, a move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment born in reaction to the decorative patterns of cubist paintings and the chaos
label: Paragraph

text: of the earlier Great War. Pure and clear, this “machine for viewing” stands as an
label: Paragraph

text: objectification of horizons re-disclosed, connecting the flat horizon of the fore-
label: Paragraph

text: ground of approaching earth to the figural horizon of the treetops against the
label: Paragraph

text: background of a receding sky. Seemingly timeless within the ever-changing qua-
label: Paragraph

text: lities of these surfaces of nature, the Villa Savoye appears as a still image, one
label: Paragraph

text: frame of a film capturing for the imagination of a new epoch, if only for a brief
label: Paragraph

text: moment of time, les heures claires.
label: Paragraph

text: Adolf Loos, Villa Miiller, view from the living room toward the dining area and stair,
label: Caption

label: Caption

text: BUILDING PHILOSOPHY
label: Title

text: The Villa Miller, completed in Prague in 1930, is among Adolf Loos’ signature
label: Paragraph

text: works and one of the epochal buildings of the modern movement. With its tight,
label: Paragraph

text: interlocking volumes positioned on multiple levels, the house remains perhaps the
label: Paragraph

text: best illustration of Loos’ Raumplan, or space-plan, conception. It is a tour de force of
label: Paragraph

text: modern space-making, an essay on how to foster complex volumes and how to
label: Paragraph

text: connect them. It is the key building of Loos’ later years, a summation of all he
label: Paragraph

text: sought to achieve as an architect and a précis of his idiosyncratic ideas of form
label: Paragraph

text: and living. It has become one of the most oft-studied and discussed buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: those years, an object lesson in three-dimensional design.
label: Paragraph

text: The Making of the Villa Muller
label: Title

text: Loos received the commission in late October 1928. The clients, Frantisek Miiller
label: Paragraph

text: and his wife, Milada Miillerova, were acquaintances of Loos’ from Pilsen, in west-
label: Paragraph

text: ern Bohemia, where Loos had numerous clients. Miiller and another Pilsen native,
label: Paragraph

text: Lumir Kapsa, were partners in a large construction company, Miiller & Kapsa,
label: Paragraph

text: which their fathers had founded in Pilsen before the turn of the century. The
label: Paragraph

text: Miillers had moved to Prague only a short time before, and in September they
label: Paragraph

text: purchased a large, hilly lot in the StfeSovice district (at Nad Hradnim vodojemem
label: Paragraph

text: 642/14) above Prague Castle and the central city.”
label: Paragraph

text: The genesis of the commission, however, remains unclear. Franti8ek Miiller evi-
label: Paragraph

text: dently first approached Czech architect Karel Lhota, a professor of architecture at
label: Paragraph

text: the building trades school in Pilsen, and Loos’ local partner there. Lhota, in turn,
label: Paragraph

text: asked Loos to participate in the project — an arrangement that Miiller seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: intended from the outset.” Both architects signed a contract with FrantiSek Miiller
label: Paragraph

text: on October 30, 1928.
label: Paragraph

text: Lhota, it seems, made the initial drawings for the house, probably with Loos’
label: Paragraph

text: input, though it is possible that Miller intended for Loos to design only the inter-
label: Paragraph

text: iors. But Loos soon became fully involved in the project, apparently modifying the
label: Paragraph

text: structural system and spatial plan that Lhota had made, which, in turn, necessitated
label: Paragraph

text: numerous changes to the facade.’ The first extensive drawings date to November
label: Caption

text: 1928. Loos and Lhota worked swiftly, and by late December the basic set of plans
label: Paragraph

text: was complete and submitted to the Prague 6 municipal offices for a building per-
label: Paragraph

text: mit.* The city authorities, however, rejected the design because both its footprint
label: Paragraph

text: and its height exceeded what was permitted for the area. Many of the neighbors
label: Paragraph

text: also complained that the large, flat-roofed house was decidedly out of character
label: Paragraph

text: for the area, which was made up of mostly smaller, conventional, pitched-roof
label: Paragraph

text: structures. Miiller was forced to resubmit the project twice more, each time with
label: Paragraph

text: slightly altered plans. The final design was not approved until late June, after the
label: Paragraph

text: Provincial President had issued an override of the authorities’ decision.
label: Paragraph

text: By then, construction on the house, which was carried out by the Kapsa &
label: Paragraph

text: Miiller Company, was well underway. Although Miiller had not received permis-
label: Paragraph

text: sion from the municipal building office to begin work, he fast-tracked the construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion process. The walls and roof were completed by mid-July 1929, and the
label: Paragraph

text: electrical work and exterior stuccowork were finished by the end of September.
label: Caption

text: Work on the interiors began in October, and the Miillers and their four-year-
label: Paragraph

text: old daughter Eva moved into the house in the spring of 1930, although the final
label: Paragraph

text: occupancy permit was not issued until July of that year.”
label: Paragraph

text: The relatively quick progress of the construction, however, belied numerous pro-
label: Paragraph

text: blems during the design process. Local architect Willy Hofmann wrote in the Prager
label: Paragraph

text: Tagblatt not long after the house’s completion that the authorities had rejected the
label: Paragraph

text: house “on ten occasions” for “aesthetic reasons.”® In truth, records show that there
label: Paragraph

text: were far fewer rejections, probably no more than five in all, and most of the objec-
label: Paragraph

text: tions had to do with the building’s siting and scale (although one of the position
label: Paragraph

text: papers from the zoning office closed with the remark, “besides, the proposed facade
label: Paragraph

text: is tasteless”).” Miiller, who was intimately familiar with the permitting process in
label: Paragraph

text: Prague, used his knowledge and connections to push the project through, even
label: Paragraph

text: though it manifestly did not comply with local ordinances.
label: Paragraph

text: The larger problems had to do with a lack of coordination between Loos, who
label: Paragraph

text: was the building’s actual designer, Lhota, who was to prepare the final plans, and
label: Paragraph

text: Pilsen contractor Bofivoj Kriegerbeck, who served as the site manager. Loos and
label: Paragraph

text: Lhota split the 50,000 crown commission, but Lhota’s construction drawings, based
label: Paragraph

text: on Loos’ verbal instructions and incomplete sketches, were so riddled with errors
label: Paragraph

text: that, as Kriegerbeck later described, Loos was forced to step in and oversee the
label: Paragraph

text: process, working closely with Kriegerbeck to ensure its completion.* Heinrich
label: Paragraph

text: Kulka, one of Loos’ former pupils who served as Loos’ assistant in Vienna, was
label: Paragraph

text: so employed, starting in December 1929, to aid in the completion of final details,
label: Paragraph

text: while the immediate supervision for the Miiller & Kapsa Company was left to yet
label: Paragraph

text: another assistant, Rudolf Volesky.
label: Paragraph

text: The work went far from smoothly. Loos, who was nearly deaf by that time and in
label: Paragraph

text: health, was often absent during the weeks the final decisions were being made
label: Paragraph

text: about the house’s disposition and detailing. Loos also had an unusual working
label: Paragraph

text: method, typically relying to a large extent on his associates. Lhota recalled afterward:
label: Paragraph

text: “[Loos] maintains that he is not an architect but a building philosopher. Of course,
label: Paragraph

text: this attitude also stems from his aversion to drawing: he positively hates architectural
label: Paragraph

text: draftsmanship. His projects consist of a sequence of logically fluent ideas, he practices
label: Paragraph

text: written — not drafted — architecture; if there is no one at hand capable of understand-
label: Paragraph

text: ing Loos, no blueprints are produced. Yet ‘this someone’ is always found.”
label: Paragraph

text: In the case of the Villa Miiller it was Lhota and Kriegerbeck who mostly per-
label: Paragraph

text: formed the work of “translating” Loos’ ideas. But as Kriegerbeck remembered
label: Paragraph

text: ry
label: Title

text: years afterward, Loos could be highly unreliable: “At first, Loos worked with gusto
label: Paragraph

text: but pretty soon his verve waned, he could not persevere. No wonder: he was a
label: Paragraph

text: delicate little wisp, his illness had progressed, he did not take good care of himself,
label: Paragraph

text: and he loved parties. Never before did he have so much work to do at one time.””°
label: Paragraph

text: At one point, Loos, flush with money from the Miller commission, went off to
label: Paragraph

text: Paris for a month without informing his co-workers and, characteristically, having
label: Paragraph

text: spent all of his available funds there, wired Miiller asking for money to return.
label: Paragraph

text: Miiller refused but eventually sent money to Loos’ office in Vienna to pay the fare
label: Paragraph

text: of one of his assistants to go to Paris and bring Loos back with him. Many of the
label: Paragraph

text: final decisions and much of the detailing in this period thus were left to Kriegerbeck
label: Paragraph

text: and Kulka.'' Miiller also intervened in the design process, altering some of the
label: Paragraph

text: details, especially on the facades. Despite his considerable wealth, he vetoed some
label: Paragraph

text: of Loos’ suggestions for more expensive detailing and for the preparation of a more
label: Paragraph

text: detailed set of plans.’* Loos also refined the plans a number of times during the
label: Paragraph

text: course of construction or, in a few instances, changed them entirely.
label: Paragraph

text: Because Loos was only infrequently on site while construction was ongoing,
label: Paragraph

text: some of the work was executed contrary to his instructions, and this created further
label: Paragraph

text: problems. Claire Beck Loos, Loos’ wife at the time, later remembered one incident:
label: Paragraph

text: “Loos orders an overhang of half a centimeter on the house. He drives away. When
label: Paragraph

text: he returns, the overhang measures an entire centimeter instead of only a half. Loos
label: Paragraph

text: is beside himself and has the extra half a centimeter taken off all the way around the
label: Paragraph

text: house.””?
label: Paragraph

text: The House and its Interiors
label: Title

text: Despite the myriad issues, the house that emerged over the early months of 1930 is
label: Paragraph

text: one of the extraordinary modernist works of that era. The massive white cubic
label: Paragraph

text: structure is set near the edge of the upper portion of the steeply sloping lot, imme-
label: Paragraph

text: diately adjacent to Nad Hradnim vodojemem Street. The north facade, which is set
label: Caption

text: back some distance from StieSovicka Street (the principal thoroughfare in the area)
label: Paragraph

text: and featuring a large balcony and windows, has the appearance of the building’s
label: Paragraph

text: main or front facade. But the entry is, in fact, on the other, or south, side, which
label: Paragraph

text: has much smaller windows and is largely unarticulated. The east and west facades
label: Caption

text: are also differentiated, the west facade only with smaller and unaligned windows,
label: Paragraph

text: the east sporting a large oriel. All of the facades, despite their differences, share the
label: Paragraph

text: same understated look. Loos explained to Kriegerbeck why he had placed so little
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on them: “I do not play with the facade, I do not live there. Take a chair,
label: Paragraph

text: sit in the rain in the middle of the street and look at the facade. If1 do a facade in the
label: Paragraph

text: street, I doa nice ground floor, sometimes cladding the first floor in marble. Above
label: Paragraph

text: the first floor I leave it uncovered, I can’t see that far.”"*
label: Paragraph

text: The matter-of-factness of the building’s exterior cloaks the richness and com-
label: Paragraph

text: plexity of its interior spaces. The south entry, which is set in a shallow recess below
label: Caption

text: street level, leads past a travertine door surround and bench (a late addition to the
label: Paragraph

text: design) and into a narrow, emerald-green corridor. Just beyond is a vestibule, orig-
label: Paragraph

text: inally painted white, with a dark blue ceiling and yellow curtains. From there a
label: Paragraph

text: right-angled stair leads to the double-height living room. This space is unusually
label: Paragraph

text: large, measuring 11 x 5.6 meters (36 x 18 feet), and 4.3 meters (14 feet) high.
label: Paragraph

text: On one side of the hall are massive windows and a door to the north balcony;
label: Paragraph

text: on the other is a long, green-gray Cippolino marble wall, which conceals two stair-
label: Paragraph

text: ways, one to the boudoir and library (or gentleman’s study), the other to the dining
label: Paragraph

text: room and the upper floors. The dining room is situated just above the hall, in a
label: Paragraph

text: lower, more intimate space, overlooking the hall. On the other side of the same
label: Paragraph

text: intermediate floor, or entresol, are the split-level boudoir, the study, and, con-
label: Paragraph

text: cealed from public view, the kitchen and pantry. Above, on the next floor, are
label: Caption

text: the bedrooms, bathrooms, and a children’s playroom; and on the topmost floor
label: Caption

text: are a storage space and a summer breakfast or tearoom, which gives out onto
label: Paragraph

text: another terrace.
label: Paragraph

text: Heinrich Kulka, in his monograph on Loos published a year after the villa’s com-
label: Paragraph

text: pletion, described the experience of walking into and through it:
label: Paragraph

text: Through a weather-covered entrance, a wind porch, and a small vestibule, by climb-
label: Paragraph

text: ing several winding stairs, we enter the hall, which surprises us by its beauty... The
label: Paragraph

text: hall, the dining room, and the staircase produce an all-embracing spatial effect of
label: Paragraph

text: unparalleled harmony. The columns and the stepped bannisters of the staircase
label: Paragraph

text: ascending to the dining room are lined with sublime greenish marble (Cippolino
label: Caption

text: de Salon, Valley of the Rhéne), displaying reddish blue and yellow veins. The dining
label: Paragraph

text: room and study are made from mahogany, the lady’s boudoir is from lemon wood."”
label: Paragraph

text: This description, however, hardly does justice to the richness and complexity of
label: Paragraph

text: the interiors. They are made up of a succession of highly varied spaces, with het-
label: Paragraph

text: erogeneous forms of cladding or surfaces. The house is effectively divided into
label: Paragraph

text: three zones. One, a service zone, includes the garage and laundry on the lowermost
label: Paragraph

text: floor, the kitchen and pantry on the main floor, a rear service stair, and a maid’s
label: Caption

text: room on the upper level. The second zone is made up of the principal living and
label: Paragraph

text: entertaining spaces on the lower floors. And the third includes the more private
label: Paragraph

text: realm: the bedrooms and children’s playroom on what is essentially the third floor
label: Paragraph

text: and the breakfast or tearoom on the fourth. The house is also subdivided into two
label: Paragraph

text: spatial spheres: the upper portion, the top two levels, which preserve the conven-
label: Paragraph

text: tional horizontal layering of floors, and the lower floors in which the Raumplan
label: Paragraph

text: idea is fully developed.
label: Paragraph

text: The functional and spatial partitioning is possible because of the house’s unusual
label: Paragraph

text: structural system. The exterior walls are conventional load-bearing block construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, but the interior supports consist of four reinforced concrete columns that
label: Paragraph

text: carry the horizontal beams. By moving the beams, which extend from the walls
label: Paragraph

text: to the columns, up or down in relation to each other, Loos was able to vary
label: Paragraph

text: the heights of the different rooms. The four columns, which form a rectangle in the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s center, also support the upper stairway, which wraps around their edges,
label: Paragraph

text: leaving an open well and, in conjunction with a rooftop skylight, permit light to
label: Paragraph

text: enter into the interior. The effect, then, in the lower part of the house is a series
label: Paragraph

text: of stacked and rotating platforms, which resolve in the upper stories into a sort of
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter plan with an open stair at the center.
label: Caption

text: Space and Meaning
label: Title

text: It is this spatial play, the product of the Raumplan, to which the Villa Miiller owes
label: Paragraph

text: its notoriety. But while Loos is now justly famous for his idea, he had curiously
label: Paragraph

text: little to say about it during his lifetime. He had begun to experiment with the
label: Paragraph

text: Raumplan concept early on, first in his Goldman & Salatsch Building on Michae-
label: Paragraph

text: lerplatz in Vienna (1909-11), and later, during and after World War I, in a series of
label: Paragraph

text: commissions for single-family houses. Throughout the last decade and a half of his
label: Paragraph

text: career, he investigated and reinvestigated strategies of spatial manipulation, experi-
label: Paragraph

text: menting with various means to foster pleasing, affective, and functional volumes.
label: Paragraph

text: His few specific spoken or written references to the Raumplan came late, starting
label: Paragraph

text: only in 1929, at the time he was already at work on the Villa Miiller. In a footnote to
label: Paragraph

text: an essay penned after the death of his favorite cabinetmaker, Joseph Veillich, Loos
label: Paragraph

text: exclaimed that his new approach was the “greatest revolution in architecture”:
label: Paragraph

text: Before Immanuel Kant humanity could not yet think in space and architects were
label: Paragraph

text: compelled to make the toilet as high as the hall. Only by dividing everything in
label: Paragraph

text: two could they obtain lower rooms. As man will one day succeed in playing chess
label: Paragraph

text: on a three-dimensional board, so, too, other architects will find spatial solutions for
label: Paragraph

text: the ground plan.’°
label: Paragraph

text: Kulka, writing two years later, employed the term Raumplan for the first time in
label: Paragraph

text: print (Loos never used it in any of his writings), arguing that Loos had “introduced
label: Paragraph

text: a fundamentally new and higher spatial concept: thinking in space, the planning of
label: Paragraph

text: rooms of differing heights, composing these with interlocking volumes to create a
label: Paragraph

text: harmonious, inseparable unit that formed a single spatially economical whole.”’”
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’ most complete statement, however, can be found in Lhota’s transcript of a
label: Paragraph

text: conversation he had with Loos in Pilsen in 1930; “My architecture,” he quotes Loos
label: Paragraph

text: as saying:
label: Paragraph

text: is not conceived in plans, but in spaces (cubes). I do not design floor plans, facades,
label: Paragraph

text: sections. I design spaces. For me, there is no ground floor, first floor, etc...For me,
label: Paragraph

text: there are only contiguous, continual spaces, rooms, anterooms, terraces, ete. Stories
label: Paragraph

text: merge and spaces relate to each other. Every space requires a different height: the
label: Paragraph

text: dining room is surely higher than the pantry — thus the ceilings are set at different
label: Paragraph

text: levels. To join these spaces in such a way that the rise and fall are not only unobserv-
label: Paragraph

text: able but also practical, in this I see what is for others the great secret, although it is for
label: Paragraph

text: me a great matter of course...It is just this spatial interaction and spatial austerity that
label: Paragraph

text: thus far I have best been able to realize in Dr. Miiller’s house.”®
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’ allusion to austerity here highlights one of his rationales for introducing
label: Paragraph

text: the Raumplan — to utilize space more economically. Space taken away from less
label: Paragraph

text: important rooms, he claimed, could be added to other, more significant areas.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet Loos also had other motives. Chief among them was to use the ideas of spatial
label: Paragraph

text: play to enhance — to vitalize — the rituals of daily life. To move through the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Miiller is to engage the architecture both physically (through the act of climbing or
label: Paragraph

text: walking or touching) and psychologically (by experiencing the dramatic alterations
label: Paragraph

text: in space, texture, color, and light). Everywhere in the house one is confronted with
label: Paragraph

text: different architectural effects and architectural realities; living in and moving
label: Paragraph

text: through it necessitates a high level of mental and physical activity.
label: Paragraph

text: The Millers lived in the villa during the 1930s, and they continued to inhabit it
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the German occupation and the early postwar years. But after the
label: Paragraph

text: Communist seizure of power in Czechoslovakia in 1948, the house was converted
label: Paragraph

text: into an “apartment villa,” and the Miillers were forced to move into a few rooms.
label: Paragraph

text: FrantiSek Miiller died in 1951, and the house was “nationalized” in 1955. Milada
label: Paragraph

text: Miillerova occupied the several rooms that had been allotted to the couple — after
label: Paragraph

text: 1962, it was only the former servants’ quarters — until her death in 1968. In 1972, the
label: Paragraph

text: villa was put at the disposal of the Institute of Marxism-Leninism of the Central
label: Paragraph

text: Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist Party, and it was not until 1989, after
label: Paragraph

text: the Velvet Revolution, that it was returned to Eva Miillerova. In 1995, the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Prague purchased the house and assigned it to the City Museum of Prague. From
label: Paragraph

text: 1998 to 2000, it underwent extensive restoration and is now accessible to the
label: Paragraph

text: public.”
label: Paragraph

text: In architectural circles, the Villa Miiller almost immediately became a revered
label: Paragraph

text: object. Loos himself believed it to be one of his most important works. On the
label: Paragraph

text: occasion of his 60th birthday party, held at the house on December 10, 1930, Loos
label: Paragraph

text: wrote in the Miiller’s guest book that it was his “most beautiful house!” (He
label: Paragraph

text: added that Frantisek Miller was “the most intelligent client I have ever had,”
label: Paragraph

text: and “This is the entire secret of architecture.””°) Shortly after the house’s com-
label: Paragraph

text: pletion, Robert Scheu, a protégé of Loos, wrote fawningly: “Now we know the
label: Paragraph

text: beauty of reason. The glory of the modern age incarnated in the splendor of
label: Paragraph

text: space. Modern humankind has its home.””’ And Kulka, also hardly an objective
label: Paragraph

text: observer, described the villa as the most complete expression of Loos’ conception
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture.”
label: Paragraph

text: But the verdict from others was equally glowing. The Czech art historian
label: Paragraph

text: Antonin Matéjéek, for example, gushed (though not entirely accurately): “Having
label: Paragraph

text: found an ideal investor in Dr. F. Miller, A. Loos was able to incorporate his artistic
label: Paragraph

text: creed in this house to a hitherto unattained perfection. In all previous cases, he had
label: Paragraph

text: to fight obstacles interfering with the purity of his idea; anywhere else, he had to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate the wishes of the client beyond the acceptable measure.””’
label: Paragraph

text: The more thoughtful discussions of the house that appeared in later years
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized its remarkably plain exterior and the sophisticated spatial play of
label: Paragraph

text: the interior. Gustav Kiinstler, who along with Ludwig Miinz produced the first
label: Paragraph

text: complete monograph on Loos’ works in 1964, rendered a typical assessment:
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing on the |house’s] exterior...betrays the truly novel conception, the product of
label: Paragraph

text: a genial design ability, of a complete and wholly unordinary idea of available living
label: Paragraph

text: space and its organization. The usual scheme of the single-family house — living
label: Paragraph

text: rooms on the ground floor, bedrooms on the second floor, connected by a stair,
label: Caption

text: which is to say two wholly independent spatial groupings, on different levels and
label: Paragraph

text: independent of each other — has been rearranged to form a convincing...and harmo-
label: Paragraph

text: nious sequencing of rooms of different sizes and heights, which through the course of
label: Paragraph

text: a gradual climb from the entry to the main living floor...fuse the house into an
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary whole.”
label: Paragraph

text: Some later commentators, however, had difficultly reconciling Loos’ plain
label: Paragraph

text: facades (which seemingly offer evidence of his anti-ornament pronouncements)
label: Paragraph

text: and his remarkably prescient spatial ideas with the villa’s sumptuous, and in many
label: Paragraph

text: respects traditional, furnishings and finishes. Nikolaus Pevsner, Vincent Scully, and
label: Paragraph

text: Kenneth Frampton, among others, all dealt with this issue effectively by pointing to
label: Paragraph

text: what was modern and ignoring what seemed not to be. But other historians and
label: Paragraph

text: critics were able to bring together the varied faces of the villa. Yehuda Safran and
label: Paragraph

text: Wilftied Wang, writing in 1985, argued that Loos’ design had “preserved a ‘desire
label: Paragraph

text: for habitability,’ in terms not of function but of the shape of the interior space.” The
label: Paragraph

text: colors, surfaces, and textures all operated to normalize the spaces, making them
label: Paragraph

text: livable:
label: Title

text: Against such conceptual rigor, the green Cipollino marble mounted in panels creates
label: Paragraph

text: with its pattern of veining a ready-made design over the entire wall of the staircase.
label: Paragraph

text: The block of stone stands out against the white walls, allowing one to perceive the
label: Paragraph

text: interior at a glance. The extreme variety of colour — yellow curtains and red brick
label: Paragraph

text: fireplace, green curtains and granite slab used as a dining room table — intensify
label: Paragraph

text: the links effected by contrasts and similarities.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Italian historian Benedetto Gravagnuolo similarly maintained that Loos’
label: Paragraph

text: stress on color and comfort were evidence of his intention to heighten the livability
label: Paragraph

text: of the house — something that had been at the center of Loos’ ambitions from the
label: Paragraph

text: start of his career — and that the villa “synthesizes many of the ideas of design that
label: Paragraph

text: had emerged in [Loos’] previous works.””° Giovanni Denti, professor at the Poli-
label: Paragraph

text: tecnico in Milan, echoed the assessment: “The silence of the exterior protects the
label: Paragraph

text: interior, which is an ensemble of places offering hospitality to different moments
label: Paragraph

text: of family life ... In the Miiller house every place has its own character, its own
label: Paragraph

text: aspect, determined by materials and Raumplan.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Leslie van Duzer and Kent Kleinman, who wrote one of the best books on the
label: Paragraph

text: house, Villa Muller: A Work of Adolf Loos, also underscored the importance of the
label: Paragraph

text: interior finishes:
label: Caption

text: Each room. ..is not only distinctively formed, but also uniquely clad. Despite the den-
label: Paragraph

text: sity and opacity of the construction, one experiences the interior of the building as a
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of linings. Like slipping in and out of fine dinner jackets, lining succeeds
label: Paragraph

text: lining. The entry sequence, for example, is composed of four discrete spaces and four
label: Paragraph

text: discrete wrappers.”
label: Paragraph

text: Van Duzer and Kleinman have suggested, however, that a person’s experience
label: Paragraph

text: of the house can differ greatly, depending on whether he or she is actively moving —
label: Paragraph

text: “roving” — through the house or passively seated. The “roving subject ... is further
label: Paragraph

text: privileged by the freedom to gaze and peer across boundaries,” permitted even
label: Paragraph

text: “visual access to the landscape beyond the shell of the building,” whereas anyone
label: Paragraph

text: stationary within has a far more limited experience because the rooms are often
label: Paragraph

text: bounded in ways that reduce or eliminate such visual connectivity.”
label: Paragraph

text: Beatriz Colomina has drawn a related comparison, emphasizing the tension
label: Paragraph

text: between elements of theatricality and intimacy in the house:
label: Paragraph

text: In the Miiller House...the sequence of spaces, articulated around the staircase, fol-
label: Paragraph

text: lows an increasing sense of privacy from the drawing room to the dining room and
label: Paragraph

text: study to the “lady’s room” (Zimmer der Dame) with its raised sitting area, which occu-
label: Paragraph

text: pies the center or “heart” of the house. But the window of this space looks onto the
label: Paragraph

text: living space...|TJhe most intimate room is like a theater box, placed just over the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance to the social spaces in this house, so that any intruder could easily be seen.
label: Paragraph

text: Likewise, the view of the exterior, toward the city, from this “theater box” is con-
label: Paragraph

text: tained within a view of the interior. Suspended in the middle of the house, this space
label: Paragraph

text: assumes the character both of a “sacred” space and a point of control. Comfort is
label: Paragraph

text: produced by two seemingly opposing conditions, intimacy and control.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Precisely how much of any of this Loos intended, we have no way of knowing.
label: Paragraph

text: He left few clues to his objectives in designing the spaces and even fewer about
label: Paragraph

text: how he thought his clients should live there. The little remaining evidence suggests
label: Paragraph

text: that he thought simply about providing his inhabitants a full and rich environment,
label: Paragraph

text: one that was intimate, secure, and comfortable, one that allowed a certain flexibil-
label: Paragraph

text: ity for conducting the rituals of daily life. If the paths through the house describe a
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive journey and a very specific set of spatial experiences (from closed to
label: Paragraph

text: open, from darker to lighter, etc.), they are also part of a narrative of dwelling.
label: Paragraph

text: One enters, one removes one’s outer clothing in the cloakroom and then ascends
label: Paragraph

text: to the living room. There one might relax or entertain. The room is both public and
label: Paragraph

text: private. The dining room, poised just above, is about an even more intimate form
label: Paragraph

text: of interaction. Whether the Millers were dining alone or with guests, the space,
label: Paragraph

text: with its lower ceiling and cozy scale, offered a field for close conversation.
label: Paragraph

text: Like almost all grand Central European houses of the time, the villa is also metic-
label: Paragraph

text: ulously segmented: there are the servants’ spaces, always concealed, and spaces for
label: Paragraph

text: the Miillers and their guests. The divisions between public and private are similarly
label: Paragraph

text: fully drawn. The public spaces — and the public portion of the promenade through
label: Paragraph

text: the house — end at the dining room. What lies beyond, the boudoir, Frantisek
label: Paragraph

text: Miiller’s study, and the bedrooms and breakfast room above, are all screened away.
label: Paragraph

text: To enter this zone is to be admitted to a different and far more personal realm.
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond that, Loos appears to have given his clients the latitude — literally and
label: Paragraph

text: figuratively, the space — to shape their own lives. The furnishings and finishes,
label: Paragraph

text: which meld the traditional and the modern, are about expressing the Miiller’s life-
label: Paragraph

text: style, much less about assembling it. Because the interiors are not stylistically con-
label: Paragraph

text: sistent, they can admit new pieces and new forms. Loos’ only stipulations here — as
label: Paragraph

text: in all of his interiors — is that they should be of high quality (and therefore durable)
label: Paragraph

text: and that they stand outside the cycles of fashion, which would prevent their rapid
label: Paragraph

text: obsolescence. But since the house was not conceived with the purifying rigor that
label: Paragraph

text: characterized much of modernism, it falls into another category, a deeply personal
label: Paragraph

text: one. Lhota’s comment, that Loos was “not an architect but a building philosopher,”
label: Paragraph

text: rings true here. The Villa Miller is perhaps less a modernist architectural object
label: Paragraph

text: than a specific statement about the experience of modernity and modern living.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: R. Buckminster Fuller
label: Title

text: AnnMarie Brennan
label: Title

text: Buckminster Fuller, Photograph of Dymaxion Dwelling Machine Wichita House with steel
label: Caption

text: tube “packaging” overlaid with drawing submitted to the U.S. Patent Office, filed March
label: Paragraph
