text: SHIP SHAPE
label: Title

text: In January 1975, the American designer and inventor R. Buckminster Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: (1895-1983) gave a series of 12 continuous lectures lasting 42 hours. In the lectures,
label: Paragraph

text: simply titled “Everything I Know,” Fuller spoke on a broad range of topics that
label: Paragraph

text: included his personal history, inventions, and the seemingly esoteric vignettes that
label: Paragraph

text: illuminated his thinking. At one point he spoke admiringly of the indigenous
label: Paragraph

text: Polynesian people of New Zealand, the Maori. Initially classified as “ignorant”
label: Paragraph

text: by European settlers because they could only count to two, Fuller claimed that
label: Paragraph

text: the Maori were in fact quite advanced since they had already discovered the
label: Paragraph

text: advantages of binary systems, anticipating the emerging world of computers.
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller continued to note that these “water people” who ruled the South Pacific
label: Paragraph

text: seas, despite not having literature or written language, did not possess charts or
label: Paragraph

text: maps for navigation. They lived their lives without very much need for clothing,
label: Paragraph

text: and therefore the Maori seamen did not have pockets in which to carry devices
label: Paragraph

text: such as compasses. However, they did have very long ear lobes embedded with
label: Paragraph

text: large discs fashioned out of bone or ivory, which, according to Fuller, signaled
label: Paragraph

text: the cardinal points of a type of corporal compass. Fuller admired the Maori and
label: Paragraph

text: considered their novel method of navigation as “a very mature, very economic,
label: Paragraph

text: very efficient kind of information controlling device.”! Not only could the Maori
label: Paragraph

text: navigate the open seas of the South Pacific with their “information controlling
label: Paragraph

text: devices,” but the constantly changing forces of weather, tides, and currents
label: Paragraph

text: necessitated that their rings merge within the extraneous skin, thereby transform-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the surface of the body into a site of performance. This small passage demon-
label: Paragraph

text: strates Fuller’s appreciation for other skilled “water people,” but more
label: Paragraph

text: importantly it illustrates his approach to design centered upon the very same
label: Paragraph

text: appreciation of performance, and underlines his understanding of the built envi-
label: Paragraph

text: ronment as being formed by undulating flows, forces, and turbulences of a non-
label: Paragraph

text: Cartesian, smooth space reminiscent of the sea.
label: Paragraph

text: The concept of dynamic forces shaping form in order to increase
label: Paragraph

text: performance was the foundation of Fuller’s most noted project, the
label: Paragraph

text: Dymaxion House. While Fuller is best known for his dome structures,
label: Paragraph

text: the Dymaxion House is perhaps the most important failed architecture project
label: Paragraph

text: of the twentieth century. It can be considered a failure because the project
label: Paragraph

text: never achieved its primary goal of being a mass-produced house that would
label: Paragraph

text: be transported directly to its customers across the United States at an affordable
label: Paragraph

text: price. The house’s significance, however, lies in the fact that Fuller reimagined
label: Paragraph

text: the way people would live in the future, and introduced to the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: profession new criteria by which to judge and assess housing design, which
label: Paragraph

text: was according to a standard of improved performance, not unlike the
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing and performance benchmarks of industrially-designed objects
label: Title

text: such as boats, cars, and airplanes. His insight into this advanced approach
label: Paragraph

text: was derived through his ability to transfer knowledge from his experience in
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing and the U.S. military to the field of design.
label: Paragraph

text: The design and redesign of the house spanned the entirety of Fuller’s early
label: Paragraph

text: career from 1927 to 1946, undergoing many name changes; from the initial 4D
label: Paragraph

text: Lightful Houses of 1927, to the Fuller or Dymaxion House, to the Dymaxion
label: Paragraph

text: Dwelling Unit or Machine, to the last version, the 1946 Wichita House. It served
label: Paragraph

text: as the catalyst for many auxiliary projects that were guided by Fuller’s principle of
label: Paragraph

text: the Dymaxion creed, which included the Dymaxion bathroom unit, the Dymaxion
label: Paragraph

text: car, and Dymaxion deployment units.
label: Paragraph

text: The house design developed through many iterations over a period of almost
label: Paragraph

text: 20 years; therefore, when speaking of the Dymaxion House, it is a reference to
label: Paragraph

text: a specific design vision that proposed the application of scientific methods of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial assembly to construction processes, rather than simply the design
label: Paragraph

text: of one type of futuristic-looking house. A constant theme defining all of Fuller’s
label: Paragraph

text: projects during this time was the concept of the Dymaxion creed. The term
label: Paragraph

text: “Dymaxion” is the combination of the words “dynamic” and “maximum,”
label: Paragraph

text: where the “maximum gain of advantage [is derived from] the minimal energy
label: Paragraph

text: input.”?
label: Paragraph

text: Industry: Housing Design Based on Performance
label: Title

text: As a young adult, Fuller was twice dismissed from Harvard University, and each
label: Paragraph

text: time this happened his mother would send him to work in factories. His first job
label: Paragraph

text: was an apprenticeship to a machine installer at a cotton mill in Quebec, his second
label: Paragraph

text: was with the Armour Meat Company where he was fascinated by the rapid, com-
label: Paragraph

text: plex, and semi-automated methods of the meatpacking process. Although his time
label: Paragraph

text: on the factory floor was brief, Fuller was able to observe and comprehend the
label: Paragraph

text: important principles that determined success in industry. He too witnessed first-
label: Paragraph

text: hand how a factory operated and the manner in which the machine tools func-
label: Paragraph

text: tioned, and most importantly he gained insight into the ways in which value
label: Paragraph

text: was created. He would later claim that a significant corollary of mass production
label: Paragraph

text: was that it was premised upon a process of “constantly improving performance,”
label: Paragraph

text: dependent upon perpetually improving the technology for manufacturing pro-
label: Paragraph

text: ducts of “increasingly improved and measurable performance.”’ This crucial aspect
label: Paragraph

text: of successful industry was one that Fuller did not see happening within the con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction of American housing.
label: Paragraph

text: Therefore it was through the design and production of the Dymaxion House
label: Paragraph

text: that Fuller sought to establish a new housing industry by treating houses like indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trially-designed products engineered to be mass produced within a factory using
label: Paragraph

text: the latest in material technology and adhering to advanced performance standards.
label: Paragraph

text: He conceded that engineered building products, such as elevators, lighting, and
label: Paragraph

text: heating systems were products of industry; however, the house, in its entirety,
label: Paragraph

text: was not conceived with the same drive toward constantly improved innovation
label: Paragraph

text: and increased performance.
label: Paragraph

text: Adhering to his Dymaxion creed, Fuller’s house was to be produced mostly from
label: Paragraph

text: the lightweight material of aluminum, manufactured in a factory, and then shipped
label: Paragraph

text: in a reusable stainless steel tube to any location within the United States along with
label: Paragraph

text: trained service crews who would immediately set upon the task of assembling the
label: Paragraph

text: house. A large crane would suspend a central aluminum mast, the house’s main
label: Paragraph

text: structure, while other parts, such as the main ground floor platform, and interior
label: Paragraph

text: and exterior walls, were to be constructed by connecting them to the central mast
label: Paragraph

text: by a universal joint. This central column, or mast, would also perform as the
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical core, containing all of the plumbing, electrical, and ventilation systems.
label: Paragraph

text: Once the assembly was completed, and state-of-the-art appliances and pre-
label: Paragraph

text: fabricated bathrooms installed, the house would be lowered onto the ground
label: Paragraph

text: and “anchored.”*
label: Paragraph

text: U.S. Navy: Dealing with Dynamic Forces
label: Title

text: Fuller was introduced to sailing and navigation as a young boy growing up ona
label: Paragraph

text: small island in Penobscot Bay, Maine. After his university misadventures, he
label: Paragraph

text: enlisted in the U.S. Navy, a move that fostered his childhood interests of sailing,
label: Paragraph

text: navigation, and boats. Fuller thrived in the disciplined environment of the Navy
label: Paragraph

text: where he was exposed to the logistics of Atlantic transport operations and the
label: Paragraph

text: organized movement of supplies moved over large expanses of geographical ter-
label: Paragraph

text: ritory. His responsibilities as U.S naval officer required the ability to understand
label: Paragraph

text: statistical methods (and early versions of operations research), map projection,
label: Paragraph

text: and chart making.
label: Paragraph

text: John McHale noted that the atmosphere of the Navy exposed Fuller to “precise
label: Paragraph

text: mathematical reckoning, advanced communications and the technical know-how
label: Title

text: involved in the logistics of mass tonnage movements, ballistics and navigation;”
label: Paragraph

text: influences that ultimately led to his concept of comprehensive total environmental
label: Paragraph

text: design and pre-planning.’ His exposure to the inner workings of manufacturing
label: Paragraph

text: coupled with the logistical prowess of the Navy provided Fuller with the conclu-
label: Paragraph

text: sion that the key element to success in industry was to understand it as a constantly
label: Paragraph

text: mobile entity of fluid systems. Fuller explained that by 1927, he understood that
label: Paragraph

text: innovation for house manufacturing was not to be found in the automobile indus-
label: Paragraph

text: try, but in shipbuilding and the aeronautical world, which was based on the prin-
label: Paragraph

text: cipal of measuring performance per pound of weight.
label: Paragraph

text: In order to illustrate the amount of advanced engineering and technology that
label: Paragraph

text: went into shipbuilding compared to architecture, Fuller often made the
label: Paragraph

text: comparison between the Mauretania ocean liner and the Hotel Belmont in New
label: Paragraph

text: York City.° The hotel, Fuller noted, received its electricity from the city infrastruc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and received its food twice a day from local suppliers, since its refrigeration
label: Paragraph

text: storage capacity was very small. However the ocean liner was required to carry its
label: Paragraph

text: own power and provisions for 1,500 people for a total of 30 days. Based on a per
label: Paragraph

text: guest basis, the Mauretania weighed one-fifteenth of the Belmont, proving that
label: Paragraph

text: weight does not equal stability. The Mauretania could withstand the motion of
label: Paragraph

text: open sea, whereas the Hotel Belmont would collapse under the same conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller concluded by pointing out the fact that if the Mauretania weighed as much as
label: Paragraph

text: the Belmont Hotel per unit of performance the boat would quickly sink.
label: Paragraph

text: 4D Lightful Houses
label: Caption

text: Fuller’s first iteration of the Dymaxion House, called the 4D Lightful House, was
label: Paragraph

text: based on a hexagonal plan created through the geometry of triangles. The primary
label: Paragraph

text: problem with existing housing stock for Fuller was the heavy, load-bearing walls of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional construction. To alleviate this issue, Fuller set out to design a house
label: Paragraph

text: made of lightweight yet strong modern materials that made up most ship and air-
label: Paragraph

text: plane construction.
label: Paragraph

text: The Dymaxion House was designed according to its performance in fuel con-
label: Paragraph

text: sumption, water requirements, actual production of individual parts, wind and
label: Paragraph

text: other weather conditions, and the ease of construction and delivery of materials
label: Paragraph

text: to the site. Unlike the existing housing stock in the United States at this time, Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: imagined a new type of house as well as a novel means of constructing it. In addi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, he proposed a method of distributing the houses as rentable, exchangeable,
label: Paragraph

text: and replaceable units, just as the telephone company would rent or lease a phone to
label: Paragraph

text: its customers, and then provide the necessary logistics and infrastructure for the
label: Paragraph

text: distribution of telephone services.
label: Paragraph

text: The 4D Houses, soon to be renamed Dymaxion Houses, would remain as a
label: Paragraph

text: scaled model, nevertheless the project was essential in establishing Fuller's theory
label: Paragraph

text: of “ephemeralization.” In Nine Chains to the Moon, Fuller defined ephemeralization
label: Paragraph

text: as advanced technology’s innate ability to do more with less material, and thereby
label: Paragraph

text: continually improve the quality of life while using less energy and natural
label: Paragraph

text: resources.”
label: Paragraph

text: Dymaxion Bathroom
label: Title

text: The 4D House included a prefabricated bathroom unit installed much like a corner
label: Paragraph

text: cabinet. The first prototype, consisting of a continuous surface of welded copper,
label: Paragraph

text: was commissioned by the American Standard Heating and Plumbing Company in
label: Paragraph

text: 1930. An additional 12 prototypes were developed in 1936 for the Phelps Dodge
label: Paragraph

text: Copper Company. The innovative aspect of this bathroom design was that it
label: Paragraph

text: was a compact, self-contained, structural unit that included a shower, bathtub, soap
label: Paragraph

text: holder, toilet, walls, floor, and washbasin shaped from one continuous surface. At
label: Paragraph

text: first the material was die-cut from a sheet of copper; this proved to be too heavy,
label: Paragraph

text: however, and subsequently stainless steel was specified, and later fiberglass. The
label: Paragraph

text: design was the culmination of considerations regarding performance, supported
label: Paragraph

text: by the inherent properties of the material selected, using the most advanced indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trial methods of manufacture.
label: Paragraph

text: Sigfried Giedion, in his concluding chapter on the mechanized bathroom in
label: Paragraph

text: Mechanization Takes Command, was the first historian to take serious note of
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller’s Dymaxion bathroom unit, and claimed that the central mechanical core
label: Paragraph

text: of the Dymaxion House was a harbinger of postwar housing design. He glow-
label: Paragraph

text: ingly described how the Dymaxion bathroom was easily and efficiently
label: Paragraph

text: manufactured:
label: Title

text: All the components are pressed simultaneously with the metal skin, their hollows
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes helping to give the system additional rigidity. |EJvery square inch was
label: Paragraph

text: worked out, so that the dies would have the highest industrial efficiency, and the
label: Paragraph

text: bathrooms could be stamped out by the million at minimal cost.*
label: Paragraph

text: Despite his initial praise, Giedion would conclude that the bathroom unit fell
label: Paragraph

text: short in terms of comfort; its dimensions were not unlike those found on a boat
label: Paragraph

text: or submarine and therefore too small and rigid for any house design with a flexible
label: Paragraph

text: ground plan.”
label: Paragraph

text: Dymaxion Car
label: Title

text: Since the Dymaxion Dwelling Machine was conceived as a house that could be
label: Paragraph

text: built in any location without roads or other infrastructure, Fuller devised a mode
label: Paragraph

text: of transport as an accessory to the Dymaxion House: “I decided to try to develop an
label: Paragraph

text: omni-medium transport vehicle to function in the sky, on negotiable terrain, or on
label: Paragraph

text: water — to be securely landable anywhere, like an eagle.” *° The Dymaxion Trans-
label: Paragraph

text: port Unit was initially designed as a “hoverable-type jet stilt ‘flying bedstead.’
label: Paragraph

text: However, these plans were modified to create a state-of-the-art, streamlined car,
label: Paragraph

text: engineered with the assistance of famed yacht designer Starling Burgess.
label: Paragraph

text: Burgess assisted in translating Fuller’s concept into an aerodynamic automobile.
label: Paragraph

text: He was best known for his design of the Enterprise, the 1930 America’s Cup winner.
label: Paragraph

text: Not unlike the duralumin mast of Fuller’s Dymaxion House, Burgess’ innovative
label: Paragraph

text: yacht design was the first to use duralumin masts and winches, reducing the work
label: Paragraph

text: required of 20 sailors down to four. A 1933 article in Fortune magazine claimed that
label: Paragraph

text: Burgess, a “fine mathematician,” was known to rise at 4 am to complete a series of
label: Paragraph

text: calculus problems, and noted that his experience in designing streamlined yachts
label: Paragraph

text: was “tremendously helpful in designing the [Dymaxion] car.”’?
label: Paragraph

text: Shaped into the streamlined form of a teardrop, the 11-passenger, three-wheeled
label: Paragraph

text: car was easily maneuverable since its rear wheel acted as a boat rudder steering the
label: Paragraph

text: direction of the vehicle. The front wheels, providing traction, were powered by an
label: Paragraph

text: eight-cylinder Ford motor concealed within a custom built chassis and bodywork
label: Paragraph

text: made of duralumin, weighing about 1,700 pounds compared to the Ford Sedan at
label: Paragraph

text: 2,700 pounds.’’ Despite the advanced technology and streamlined, futuristic aes-
label: Paragraph

text: thetic, the Dymaxion car would be yet another shelved project, as an unfortunate
label: Paragraph

text: accident involving the car at the 1933 World Fair killed the driver and injured two
label: Paragraph

text: other passengers. The cause of the accident was not entirely known; however, it
label: Paragraph

text: was rumored to be a problem with the steering, prompting investors to abandon
label: Paragraph

text: the project.
label: Paragraph

text: Dymaxion Dwelling Machine, or Wichita House
label: Paragraph

text: By 1944, Fuller was re-enlisted in the military and serving as an officer in the Eco-
label: Paragraph

text: nomic Warfare Division when union leaders in Washington, D.C., who remem-
label: Paragraph

text: bered the 1927 mass-produced Dymaxion House, contacted him. As the end of
label: Paragraph

text: World War II approached, the U.S. Department of Labor, along with the Aeronau-
label: Paragraph

text: tical Production Division of the War Production Board, were trying to find a solu-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to a series of anticipated problems that would plague the country at war’s end;
label: Paragraph

text: a shortage of laborers wanting to work in Mid-Western armament and airplane
label: Paragraph

text: factories, a surplus of materials, specifically aluminum, and a shortage of appropri-
label: Paragraph

text: ate housing for the general civilian population. It appeared that the production of a
label: Paragraph

text: redesigned Dymaxion House could resolve all of these problems, while achieving
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller’s goal of transforming house construction from a craft-based trade to an
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized system.
label: Paragraph

text: The major difference between the 1927 version of the Dymaxion House and the
label: Paragraph

text: 1946 Wichita model was that Fuller re-engineered the exterior skin according to the
label: Paragraph

text: improved tensile strength of aluminum and incorporated the most-advanced
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge of aircraft construction since it was to be produced at the B-29 bomber
label: Paragraph

text: Beech Aircraft plant in Wichita, Kansas. The original hexagon shape changed to a
label: Paragraph

text: streamlined circular plan, and the roof was a smooth, curved surface compared to
label: Paragraph

text: the previous angular form. The aluminum monocoque roof was self-supporting,
label: Paragraph

text: and the curved exterior walls were tied back to the central mast through tension
label: Paragraph

text: members enveloped within the roof. With the mast in compression and the roof
label: Paragraph

text: and walls in tension due to the double curvature shape, the structure, modeled
label: Paragraph

text: upon the idea of a Chinese lantern, was substantially rigid and did not require addi-
label: Paragraph

text: tional bracing, columns, or trusses for support. The increased performance in struc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture can be found in what Fuller described as shape factors. When Fuller placed the
label: Paragraph

text: Dymaxion prototype in a wind tunnel, he discovered that heat loss occurred in
label: Paragraph

text: direct proportion to drag, revealing that heat loss could be reduced if the house
label: Paragraph

text: shape took on an aerodynamic form.’* The air quality and comfort was further
label: Paragraph

text: assured through a ventilator located on the roof, which would change the air in
label: Paragraph

text: the house up to ten times per hour.
label: Paragraph

text: The redesign enabled Fuller to realize an actual prototype that manifested his
label: Paragraph

text: theory of ephemeralization with a house encompassing 800 square feet of floor
label: Paragraph

text: space and weighing a total of 4 tons; demonstrating a 98% reduction in weight from
label: Paragraph

text: a traditionally built home. Despite these technological innovations and a willing
label: Paragraph

text: pool of 3,000 customers placing orders, the Wichita House would not be mass pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced. Investors were unwilling to contribute the required $10 million to re-tool
label: Paragraph

text: the aircraft plant since the project did not have any marketing, distribution, and
label: Paragraph

text: installation strategies.
label: Paragraph

text: Dymaxion Legacy
label: Title

text: The greatest legacy of the Dymaxion House was the manner in which Fuller’s
label: Paragraph

text: design approach influenced generations of future architects and historians. Interest-
label: Paragraph

text: ingly enough, it seems that Fuller received more acknowledgment and apprecia-
label: Paragraph

text: tion for his work by British architects, historians, and designers than American
label: Paragraph

text: ones. Alison and Peter Smithson were inspired by the continuous structural surface
label: Paragraph

text: of the Dymaxion bathroom unit for their 1956 House of the Future. Within the
label: Paragraph

text: same U.K. design circles, the Dymaxion House served as a demonstration of port-
label: Paragraph

text: ability for the architecture group Archigram.’? While these young designers
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to imitate the technical and mechanical imagery of Fuller’s designs,
label: Paragraph

text: and the kit-of-parts aspect of the Dymaxion House appealed to the new postwar
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility for mobility, Archigram was not interested in the performative nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the house. As Hadas Steiner noted, Archigram wanted to create a type of mobile
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that “violated the principle of firmitas” and the Dymaxion House
label: Paragraph

text: served as an applicable precedent.’® Fuller's house actualized this new postwar
label: Paragraph

text: urge for freedom and the ability to roam, and it was this secondary dynamic aspect
label: Paragraph

text: — the house’s ability to be located anywhere without the reliance of infrastructure —
label: Paragraph

text: that inspired Archigram.
label: Paragraph

text: The next generation influenced by Fuller’s concepts includes the group of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects characterized as High-Tech, such as Norman Foster, Nicholas Grimshaw, and
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Rogers. The Dymaxion House demonstrated a new set of design values
label: Paragraph

text: that placed research, the development of technology regarding energy, perfor-
label: Paragraph

text: mance, and the transfer of knowledge from other industries above any outmoded
label: Paragraph

text: notion of (postmodern) style. Foster claimed that Fuller had a “profound influence
label: Paragraph

text: on my own work and thinking. Inevitably, I also gained an insight into his philos-
label: Paragraph

text: ophy and achievements.”’” During the last decade of Fuller's life, Foster established
label: Paragraph

text: a relationship with the inventor /architect, and his admiration for his work included
label: Paragraph

text: financing a built replication of Fuller’s Dymaxion car.
label: Paragraph

text: Although not acknowledged as an important influence, the work of contempo-
label: Paragraph

text: rary American architect Greg Lynn seems to revisit problems similar to the ones
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller addressed almost 80 years ago. Not unlike the “dynamic” in Fuller’s Dymax-
label: Paragraph

text: ion creed, Lynn’s design strategy is one based on the concept of “animation.” In his
label: Paragraph

text: 1999 book, Animate Form, Lynn proposed a new architecture that was not animate
label: Paragraph

text: itself, but was in fact formed by moving, fluid forces acting upon it. By adopting this
label: Paragraph

text: approach to architecture, traditional notions of statics and structure were replaced
label: Paragraph

text: by a “more advanced system of dynamic organizations.” !*
label: Paragraph

text: To illustrate his concept, Lynn often cites the designing of a boat hull, where
label: Paragraph

text: naval architects are required to factor in mobile forces such as flow, wind, turbu-
label: Paragraph

text: lence, and viscosity, in both upwind and downwind performance. However, the
label: Paragraph

text: actual boat hull is static in its final form; “While physical form can be defined in
label: Paragraph

text: terms of static coordinates, the virtual force of the environment in which it is
label: Paragraph

text: designed contributes to its shape.”"® The design of the boat hull negotiates these
label: Paragraph

text: shaping forces by engineering curves and inflection to modulate and respond, but
label: Paragraph

text: the actual surface of the hull does not move.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the publication of Animate Form, Lynn has in fact entered into a new design
label: Paragraph

text: realm that includes both moving and non-moving parts called “projectiles.” Like
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller, one of Lynn’s first projects was to design a factory-produced house called
label: Paragraph

text: the Embryological House (2000). Using an iterative process of digital animation pro-
label: Paragraph

text: grams borrowed from film and aerospace industries, Lynn set up a series of control
label: Paragraph

text: curves and shape grammars within a matrix that determined the way each form
label: Paragraph

text: would interact with others, and then established a set of expressions dictating
label: Paragraph

text: how the geometry defined structure, cladding, and apertures.”° This process, an early
label: Paragraph

text: attempt at mass customization, created a series of 50,000 varied house designs which
label: Paragraph

text: did not require adding or subtracting structure or cladding to create this formal
label: Paragraph

text: difference.
label: Paragraph

text: Paralleling Fuller’s interest in everything related to boats and sailing, Lynn estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lished a company with a naval architect, and now designs seafaring vessels such as
label: Paragraph

text: the GF42 Trimaran. The process of designing these boats includes the application
label: Paragraph

text: of fluid dynamics, which calculates both the force of wind and the dynamics of
label: Paragraph

text: water within a single model. A basic, instinctual geometry of the hull, rig, and sails
label: Paragraph

text: is created, and then these shapes are sent to a computer with massive processing
label: Paragraph

text: power, to calculate all of the data. It is through this iterative process — the analysis of
label: Paragraph

text: the flow and motion across surfaces, together with a graphical response — that the
label: Paragraph

text: final design is selected.
label: Paragraph

text: For Lynn, the most innovative aspect in the boating construction industry is the
label: Paragraph

text: simple fabrication of materials for the hull and sails consisting solely of layers of
label: Paragraph

text: fibers and resin rather than a frame structure with cladding fastened to it; a con-
label: Paragraph

text: figuration that occurs in most traditionally conceived architectural works. Consid-
label: Paragraph

text: erably less expensive than Fuller’s process of constructing with panels of die-cut
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum panels for the Dymaxion House, these vessels are made from 100% car-
label: Paragraph

text: bon fibers strategically placed along load paths and then molded together with glue
label: Paragraph

text: and heated into a strong composite material.”! Fuller and Lynn discovered the per-
label: Paragraph

text: formative advantages of shape factors and the collapsing of both envelope and
label: Paragraph

text: structure into one smooth continuous surface.
label: Paragraph

text: Conclusion
label: Title

text: In his 1969 book, Architecture of the Well-tempered Environment, the British architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural historian Reyner Banham, in reference to Fuller’s Dymaxion approach of
label: Paragraph

text: “ephemeralization,” recalled Paul Valery’s book Eupalinos, the Architect. He
label: Paragraph

text: explained how Eupalinos was primarily concerned with applying accepted meth-
label: Paragraph

text: ods to complete specific tasks, and, according to the tradition of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: profession, discovered a theoretical problem embedded within every pragmatic
label: Paragraph

text: decision. However, Tridon, the shipbuilder, attempted to resolve the problem
label: Paragraph

text: at hand in the most direct and efficient manner, whether it was part of the ship-
label: Paragraph

text: building tradition or not, and considered philosophical theories as additional guid-
label: Paragraph

text: ance toward achieving the most direct solution. Banham continued the analogy by
label: Paragraph

text: pointing out that contemporary architectural education was comparable to a
label: Paragraph

text: “sophisticated yacht with glass-fiber hull and aluminum mast” and other advanced
label: Paragraph

text: materials. However, in terms of performance, the architecture produced by these
label: Paragraph

text: elite institutions still required “an onboard motor to be used (under conditions of
label: Paragraph

text: great embarrassment) in emergencies.””” He concluded by noting that arguments
label: Paragraph

text: that defend the use of traditional methods in architecture often ignore the fact that
label: Paragraph

text: outside the “protected circle” of academia and the staged discourse of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: media, “there has been for almost a century a tide of innovation in environmental
label: Paragraph

text: management fully comparable with that in nautical design.””?
label: Paragraph

text: These insights begin to explain the unsuccessful acceptance of Fuller’s Dymaxion
label: Paragraph

text: House. A 1947 Fortune article referred to prefabricated housing as “the industry that
label: Paragraph

text: capitalism forgot,” noting that an entire generation of architects dismissed the possibil-
label: Paragraph

text: ity of prefabricated housing because they could not foresee how it could work within
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary political and financial structures, as is still the case today.’* Nevertheless,
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller’s concept of performance transferred from the sphere of industrial design and
label: Paragraph

text: manufacture to architecture is a noble goal with continuing resonance in contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architectural practices that currently explore the increased possibilities ofnew advances
label: Paragraph

text: in digital software and custom fabrication technologies. It becomes clear that the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: fession now needs to find a solution to overcome the same political and economic bar-
label: Paragraph

text: riers that thwarted Fuller’s best efforts.
label: Paragraph

text: VDL RESEARCH
label: Title

text: HOUSE
label: Title

text: Richard Neutra
label: Title

text: Edward R. Ford
label: Title

text: Richard Neutra, VDL Research House II, Los Angeles, California, 1966 [1933, 39, 44] rebuilt
label: Caption

text: after 1963 fire.*
label: Paragraph

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.

label: Caption

text: The genesis of the VDL Research house was a meeting in Basel in 1930 between
label: Paragraph

text: its architect, Richard Neutra, and the man for whom it is named, C. H. van der
label: Paragraph

text: Leeuw. It was a critical moment in the lives of both men. Neutra was on an
label: Paragraph

text: around-the-world promotional tour following the completion of the Lovell house
label: Paragraph

text: in Los Angeles in 1929, an event that had quickly established his international
label: Paragraph

text: reputation. For Neutra, then 38, it was the end of a long apprenticeship, educa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion in his native Vienna and office work in Germany and America, which
label: Paragraph

text: included short stays with Erich Mendelsohn and Frank Lloyd Wright. In 1926
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra moved to Los Angeles at the urging of his former classmate, Rudolph
label: Paragraph

text: Schindler, and the Lovell commission followed soon after. Van der Leeuw,
label: Paragraph

text: the director of the van Nelle coffee, tea, and tobacco company, had recently com-
label: Paragraph

text: missioned two pivotal International Style buildings — his own house and the Van
label: Paragraph

text: Nelle factory — both in Rotterdam, both the work of Brinkman é& Van der Vlugt.
label: Paragraph

text: One year later, soon after Neutra visited Rotterdam, van der Leeuw visited Neu-
label: Paragraph

text: tra in Los Angeles. Neutra relates that when van der Leeuw asked him why he
label: Paragraph

text: had not built his own house, he replied that he lacked sufficient capital. Van der
label: Paragraph

text: Leeuw asked how much he needed and gave him a check on the spot. Through-
label: Paragraph

text: out his life Neutra always referred to it as the VDL research house, even after its
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding, and always insisted that the house was not merely an architect’s home
label: Paragraph

text: but a scientific experiment, that van der Leeuw’s gift made possible a radical
label: Paragraph

text: rethinking of the American house, revolutionizing the form of building, the proc-
label: Paragraph

text: ess of construction and the science of design.
label: Paragraph

text: The True Importance of the House
label: Title

text: This is the canonical history of the VDL house and, like many canonical histories, it
label: Paragraph

text: contains some hyperbole and some inaccuracies. As a result the house and its
label: Paragraph

text: importance have often been misunderstood, most importantly the degree, or more
label: Paragraph

text: accurately the way, in which it was constructionally experimental. While it
label: Paragraph

text: employed a variety of new materials and processes, it did not represent a radical
label: Paragraph

text: break with the past in its basic construction; it was more evolutionary than revo-
label: Paragraph

text: lutionary in its innovations. It is more of a prototypical system than a prototypical
label: Paragraph

text: form, as there is much about the house that is particular to its program and its site.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless the VDL house remains a canonical work. Neutra’s intent was to
label: Paragraph

text: redefine three aspects of American building culture — to transform the typical site
label: Paragraph

text: plan of the single family house, to transform the process of single family house
label: Paragraph

text: construction into an industrialized system, and to establish a scientific methodol-
label: Paragraph

text: ogy for determining a sympathetic relationship between an architectural space and
label: Paragraph

text: its occupants, using the newly acquired tools of psychology. All three ideas were
label: Paragraph

text: central to much of 1930s modernism, but Neutra’s take on all, particularly the last
label: Paragraph

text: two, was his own.
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s first assault on the status quo was the site plan. He wished to rein-
label: Paragraph

text: vent the typical American model of the isolated house sandwiched between a
label: Paragraph

text: front lawn and back yard. The result would be a cell that could multiply itself
label: Paragraph

text: into a high-density settlement pattern. The result, he predicted, would be a Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles 40% the size with half the traffic. His task, as he described it, was to
label: Paragraph

text: make density beguiling or, more specifically, to place three families on a 60 x 70
label: Paragraph

text: foot lot.' Neutra’s solution to the problems high density created was both
label: Paragraph

text: real and psychological. Space would be both physically and psychologically
label: Paragraph

text: expanded.
label: Paragraph

text: This translated into a plan of buildings that were pushed to the property bound-
label: Paragraph

text: aries with courtyards between and accessed by multiple entries. This plan took
label: Paragraph

text: some time to achieve realization. The first phase was a 24x 70 foot block built
label: Paragraph

text: in 1933, a large, two-story building along Silver Lake Boulevard facing the Silver
label: Paragraph

text: Lake reservoir, containing the major living space on the second floor, with a view
label: Paragraph

text: of the lake, and Neutra’s office below. The office was accessed off the major street,
label: Paragraph

text: the residence from the rear by an elevated stairway. In 1939 the second phase was
label: Paragraph

text: added to the rear, a T-shaped wing that created an H-shaped complex with two
label: Paragraph

text: courtyards. It included a garage and two rental apartments, one for a bachelor
label: Paragraph

text: and one for a couple, to help with the financing. A smaller rooftop addition was
label: Paragraph

text: made to the older wing in 1944.
label: Paragraph

text: Making Houses like Cars
label: Title

text: The second of Neutra’s revolutions was to be constructional; in short, to make
label: Paragraph

text: houses like cars. Neutra said it was the very idea of industrialization that brought
label: Paragraph

text: him to America. Harwell Hamilton Harris, who worked for Neutra from 1928 to
label: Paragraph

text: 1932, said, more specifically, that it was the ideas of Henry Ford.” Ford saw rigid
label: Paragraph

text: standardization as the key to the economies of mass production and Neutra, along
label: Paragraph

text: with Le Corbusier and Gropius, agreed. But an equally important influence on
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s constructional conceptions was his work for Holabird & Roche on
label: Paragraph

text: the documentation and construction of the Palmer House Hotel in Chicago.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the many European architects who admired American construction, as
label: Paragraph

text: opposed to American architecture, Neutra was one of the few to experience
label: Paragraph

text: the former under construction first-hand. In terms of formal and constructional
label: Paragraph

text: consequences these experiences were manifested in two ways. The first, derived
label: Paragraph

text: from Ford, was the idea of standardized components but of a relatively small
label: Paragraph

text: scale. These consisted of a minimum number of components that were to be
label: Paragraph

text: applied in a maximum number of functional conditions. The second construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tional principal, growing out of his Chicago experience, was that modern con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction, regardless of program or scale, “consist[s] of skeleton construction
label: Paragraph

text: clad with lightweight materials.” The Palmer House Hotel was to Neutra a
label: Paragraph

text: strange hybrid, a heavy masonry envelope hung on a light steel frame. He wished
label: Paragraph

text: to hang a light envelope on a light frame.
label: Paragraph

text: The ideas of the rigidly standardized part and a skin and frame construction had
label: Paragraph

text: achieved their most doctrinaire expression in Neutra’s Lovell house of 1929. Its
label: Paragraph

text: standardized module consisted of a series of 4-inch steel H columns spaced at a
label: Paragraph

text: ittle over 5 feet with standardized steel units of out-swinging casement windows
label: Paragraph

text: between. The opaque portions of the wall were gunite (sprayed-on concrete).
label: Paragraph

text: oints were bolted or welded, not nailed; the structure was steel, not wood, and
label: Paragraph

text: there was, in theory, minimal on-site labor. This facade pattern was nearly univer-
label: Paragraph

text: sally applied. The same structural bay and the same window unit enclose library,
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom, and bathroom, and, with variations in the height of the windows, are
label: Paragraph

text: placed on the north, south, east, and west elevations. There were of course open-
label: Paragraph

text: ings, erosions, and protrusions in this envelope, but the idea of the rigid module,
label: Paragraph

text: made of rigidly standardized units, and hung on a rigidly standardized industria-
label: Paragraph

text: ized frame, was pervasive. There was an absolute clarity of what was structural
label: Paragraph

text: frame and what was not.
label: Paragraph

text: If Neutra was to adopt the Lovell house system or another one like it to the VDL
label: Paragraph

text: house he had to face some economic realities. The Lovell house is twice the size of
label: Paragraph

text: VDL and cost $12 a square foot. The 2000-square foot VDL house was eventually
label: Paragraph

text: built for $4 a square foot. If the VDL house was to be a prototype on the order of
label: Paragraph

text: the Lovell, Neutra would have to do so at one-third of the cost. Van der Leeuw’s
label: Paragraph

text: check was for $3000; the eventual cost of the house was $10,000 and the check was
label: Paragraph

text: an interest free loan, not a gift. Neutra never used the gunite-sprayed, steel-framed
label: Paragraph

text: assembly of the Lovell house again, probably because subsequent commissions had
label: Paragraph

text: less generous budgets. The VDL house, built three years after Lovell, is far less
label: Paragraph

text: dogmatic in its application of the ideas of standards and industrialized systems
label: Paragraph

text: and is perhaps the richer for it.
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s solution, at least in theory, was simple. If he could not afford a steel
label: Paragraph

text: frame he would build a wooden frame that looked like steel. From a distance
label: Paragraph

text: the facades of the VDL house seem similar to those of the Lovell. Columns tightly
label: Paragraph

text: spaced at four feet are infilled with standardized window units of two steel case-
label: Paragraph

text: ment windows. Closer inspection reveals far more crucial differences. The first
label: Paragraph

text: floor level is supported by precast concrete beams, but the house above is wood
label: Caption

text: columns and wood joists. The walls are stucco, not gunite. The VDL structure is
label: Paragraph

text: best understood as a modification of the traditional balloon frame. The members of
label: Paragraph

text: the typical balloon frame are 2 x 4 wood studs spaced at 16 inches supporting floors
label: Paragraph

text: of joists, usually 2 x 8s or 2 x 10s, also spaced at 16 inches. In the VDL system the
label: Paragraph

text: studs are larger and more widely spaced, 4 x 4s at 4 feet, while the floor and roof
label: Paragraph

text: joist sizes and spacing remains the same. The long ribbons of standardized steel
label: Paragraph

text: casement windows used at Lovell remain, and with them the large number of wall
label: Caption

text: openings required. This degree of openness is less easily accommodated in wood
label: Paragraph

text: than in steel. A balloon frame is structurally dependent on the wood sheathing of its
label: Paragraph

text: exterior wall for lateral stability. Despite its name, it is far more of a wall system
label: Paragraph

text: than a frame. In the VDL house diagonal bracing is added at every bay to provide
label: Paragraph

text: additional lateral stability, making the whole system far more ofa structural hybrid,
label: Paragraph

text: not purely a frame but not really a wall diaphragm. Neutra argued that the wood
label: Paragraph

text: frame provided greater elasticity in earthquakes. He was careful not to say greater
label: Paragraph

text: than what. So from a technological standpoint the VDL house is a much less a pure
label: Paragraph

text: industrial product, much less like a car, than its predecessor. Despite the long list of
label: Paragraph

text: innovative products the house contains, it is far more a hybrid of old and new
label: Paragraph

text: technology.
label: Paragraph

text: In a 1935 article Neutra wrote that his office had “endeavored to give many indi-
label: Paragraph

text: vidual jobs entrusted to us a character which would easily lend itself to series pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction.”* Later he called his early buildings “templates ... for the imaginative
label: Paragraph

text: appropriation of our advancing industrial methods.”* What is implied by this is
label: Paragraph

text: obvious: that there is little real prefabrication in the VDL house except for the steel
label: Paragraph

text: windows. The rigid module probably accomplished little in terms of real economy.
label: Paragraph

text: Harris wrote that Neutra saw himself as preparing the public — “education” he
label: Paragraph

text: called it — so that when industrialization finally came the public would be ready.
label: Paragraph

text: A dubious aspect of this “education” was painting all the exterior wood with alu-
label: Paragraph

text: minum paint, implying that it was metal, but again, Neutra argued that he was
label: Paragraph

text: preparing the public for the technical revolution that was to follow.®
label: Paragraph

text: Rooms with No Names
label: Title

text: This standardized wall system is applied on all facades and all types of space. Neu-
label: Paragraph

text: tra, writing in 1947, described the modern dwelling as consisting of spaces that,
label: Paragraph

text: while by no means universal, could accommodate a variety of functions. He said,
label: Paragraph

text: “In our house rooms have no names such as living room, dining room, bedroom ...
label: Paragraph

text: Rooms are portions of our great living space and pragmatically elastic.”” This was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly true of the VDL house, and helps to explain some of the odd moments
label: Paragraph

text: in the plan — small rooms for major functions such as the dining room and kitchen,
label: Paragraph

text: odd juxtapositions of space such as the intersection where the corridor connecting
label: Paragraph

text: the kitchen and dining crosses the public entry to the main living space.
label: Caption

text: The idea ofa standardized module consisting ofa structural bay and window was
label: Paragraph

text: not new in 1933 or even 1927. Le Corbusier's villa at Garches used repetitive struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural bays of 2.5 and 5 meters with standardized 2.5-meter-wide windows between
label: Paragraph

text: them; and the villas at Carthage, the Weisenhofsiedlung, and the original plan for the
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye do the same. The Corbusian facades of the 1920s also appear, at times,
label: Paragraph

text: indifferent to program. The front of Garches has one row of standard window units
label: Paragraph

text: and the rear has two, both enclosing a complex interior spatial layout. In this regard it
label: Paragraph

text: has much in common with the first phase of the VDL house, which had one row of
label: Paragraph

text: standard windows on the east side and two on the west, also only loosely related to
label: Paragraph

text: the interior disposition of space, and both houses have a living space on the second
label: Paragraph

text: floor with a external stair access. But while the VDL house owes a formal debt to Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier it also owes a technical debt to Frank Lloyd Wright. In 1911-17 Wright
label: Paragraph

text: had developed the Ready-Cut prefabricated housing system. It used widely spaced
label: Paragraph

text: 4 x 4 wood columns along with ribbons of casement windows in an arrangement
label: Caption

text: identical to the VDL but about half the width.
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra convinced material suppliers to donate products to the house with the
label: Paragraph

text: promise of publicity — glass and aluminum sandwich panels, Masonite walls, cork
label: Caption

text: flooring, precast concrete floor joists, and blue enameled metal wall panels. Few if
label: Paragraph

text: any were used for the first time here, but many were new on the market. Yet,
label: Paragraph

text: excepting the precast joists used for the ground floor, most of the new products
label: Paragraph

text: were finish materials, not structural, and created the appearance of a building gen-
label: Paragraph

text: erated by new building products rather than the essence of one. Neutra’s intentions
label: Paragraph

text: here, however, went well beyond simple economics. He frequently acknowledged
label: Paragraph

text: the influence and mentorship of Adolf Loos, who planted in Neutra a fascination
label: Paragraph

text: with the simple products of American industrial culture. To Loos, the true
label: Paragraph

text: American art was the vernacular products of American industry that remained
label: Paragraph

text: uncorrupted by “designers” (the oak toilet seat was a particular Loos favorite.) This
label: Paragraph

text: suggested a second model of the industrialized house, one that Neutra was partic-
label: Paragraph

text: ularly fond of, not the house made from prototypical custom components but the
label: Paragraph

text: house made from ready-made available objects, the house bought from the cata-
label: Paragraph

text: logue and ordered over the phone. Harris said that Neutra saw Sweets Catalogue, the
label: Paragraph

text: necessary instrument for such an activity, as his bible.®
label: Paragraph

text: The Question of Light
label: Title

text: There are a variety of exceptions to this rigid system of standards, most conspic-
label: Paragraph

text: uously the second floor living room, which became the focus of Neutra’s second
label: Paragraph

text: obsession — light, reflection, transparency, and permeability. The structure and
label: Paragraph

text: facade follow the same basic module of the remainder of the house but there
label: Paragraph

text: are crucial additions and deletions. The casement windows of the typical module
label: Paragraph

text: are gone, replaced by large, single sheets of polished plate glass. On its most simple
label: Paragraph

text: level Neutra wished to expand the space both in fact and in perception, and to
label: Paragraph

text: establish a connection to the “natural” environment beyond, particularly the lake.
label: Paragraph

text: In its most literal form this expression included folding glazed steel doors that erase
label: Paragraph

text: the boundary between living room and terrace. Other effects are more subtle and
label: Paragraph

text: virtual. The roof projects beyond the exterior wall and contains a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: recessed lighting strip so that at night more light comes in than goes out. This
label: Paragraph

text: reverses the typical condition where, after sunset, glass walls become black mirrors
label: Paragraph

text: to the interior space, and thus maintains the transparency of the interior/exterior
label: Paragraph

text: connection. From the exterior this is reversed. The light makes the glass reflective
label: Paragraph

text: at night, increasing privacy. Thus the living room is more connected to the outside
label: Paragraph

text: by greater transparency but at the same time more removed because of the absence
label: Paragraph

text: of direct, operable openings to the landscape. The living/family room of the
label: Paragraph

text: ground floor apartment has a similar connection to nature, with sliding doors that
label: Paragraph

text: open along more than half of the long wall surface to the adjacent courtyard, allow-
label: Paragraph

text: ing for direct access and connection to the constructed, but natural landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: While the living room was about light it was about a great deal more. Neutra
label: Paragraph

text: said of the room in 1962, “Providing light for reading the newspaper was not the
label: Paragraph

text: primary purpose of this illumination. Rather I saw in it an emotive stimulant, chan-
label: Paragraph

text: ging endocrinal discharges and biochemistry.”” Neutra believed for most of his life
label: Paragraph

text: that the human response to architecture could be scientifically understood. Biore-
label: Paragraph

text: alism was his own term for this study, and its underlying principle was that our
label: Paragraph

text: response to the physical environment is based on genetic impulses, but overlaid
label: Paragraph

text: with a kind of prenatal conditioning. Neutra agreed with Freud that the house
label: Paragraph

text: is the successor to the womb. Neutra had known Freud in Vienna, but the primary
label: Paragraph

text: influence on Neutra’s thinking seems to have been Wilhelm Wundt, one of the
label: Paragraph

text: founders of experimental psychology.’ To Neutra the crucial stimuli of a response
label: Paragraph

text: to architecture included sound, touch, even taste, and the crucial necessities were
label: Paragraph

text: the connection to nature, the need for privacy within density, and the need for nat-
label: Paragraph

text: ural light, and with it radiation. Neutra’s client, Philip Lovell, was a medical jour-
label: Paragraph

text: nalist and an advocate of massive exposure to natural sunlight, and his focus on the
label: Paragraph

text: physiology of architecture certainly contributed to Neutra’s own ideas. Some of
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s design decisions that appear largely aesthetic were to him the product
label: Paragraph

text: of scientific analysis. The large, transparent, operable surfaces established a connec-
label: Paragraph

text: tion between the body and nature — the lake and garden. The reflective surfaces of
label: Paragraph

text: the glass, mirrors, and water altered perception, expanding small rooms in a dense
label: Paragraph

text: urban environment; and the exterior soffit lighting, through reflection, rendered all
label: Paragraph

text: these transparent spaces private.
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s interest in light extended beyond the visible spectrum. The reflective
label: Paragraph

text: qualities of one of the donated materials, a sandwich panel of plate glass and alu-
label: Paragraph

text: minum, was used to form reflective spandrels and retain the heat generated by the
label: Paragraph

text: shower in the bathroom. At a time when the walls of a number of modernist build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings were built of uninsulated solid masonry, Neutra was experimenting with
label: Paragraph

text: reflective insulation within the hollow walls of the VDL house. The active material
label: Paragraph

text: here was reflective foil. Since reflective surfaces greatly reduce heat transfer by
label: Paragraph

text: radiation, a wall cavity lined on one face with a reflective surface will retard heat
label: Paragraph

text: transfer, and thus heat loss, through radiation. Obviously at different times of the
label: Paragraph

text: year the heat may be moving in or out of the building. Neutra experimented with
label: Paragraph

text: various locations for the foil; on the north wall it is placed on the inside face of the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior plaster, on the south wall on the inside face of the wall cavity, and in
label: Caption

text: another portion of the south wall it is placed on the inside face of the exterior layer
label: Caption

text: but the cavity is filled with Rockwool insulation.
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s concern with natural light and the transparency of the space may have
label: Paragraph

text: led to some ill-advised decisions. Both the Lovell house and the VDL house have the
label: Paragraph

text: facades with maximum glazing facing west. In both houses this was the best view,
label: Paragraph

text: and in both houses the living room is located on the second floor to accommodate it,
label: Paragraph

text: but Neutra did little to ameliorate the large quantities of afternoon sun, which
label: Paragraph

text: caused serious problems at Lovell. Gregory Ain, who worked for Neutra from
label: Paragraph

text: 1930 to 1935, said that the living room of the Lovell house was often uninhabitable
label: Paragraph

text: for this reason. At the VDL house the overhanging roof gave some relief, but as the
label: Paragraph

text: western sun is low, the roof’s helpfulness as a sunshade recedes in late summer after-
label: Paragraph

text: noons. Neutra argued that this problem was solved by “fast growing trees.”
label: Paragraph

text: Rebuilding from the Ashes
label: Title

text: In 1963, while Neutra was away, most of the VDL house burned down to its foun-
label: Paragraph

text: dations. The concrete substructure, basement, subfloor, and part of the guest wing
label: Caption

text: survived, and the decision was made to rebuild it to the extents of the previous
label: Paragraph

text: envelope, employing the previous layout. Most of the day-to-day documentation
label: Paragraph

text: and implementation was handled by Neutra’s son, Dion. Neutra provided instruc-
label: Paragraph

text: tions in the form of annotated tracing paper overlays to photographs of the original,
label: Paragraph

text: but some design decisions were made by Dion, not all of them to Neutra’s liking.”!
label: Paragraph

text: While the spatial layout is roughly the same as the old, its character was trans-
label: Paragraph

text: formed, incorporating a number of changes that reflected the evolution of Neutra’s
label: Paragraph

text: thought. Those aspects of the house that were the manifestation of its “industria-
label: Paragraph

text: lized” character — prefabrication and standardization — are eliminated or subdued.
label: Paragraph

text: Those that were the product of Neutra’s interest in biorealism — light, heat and the
label: Paragraph

text: physiology of architecture — are heightened or expanded.
label: Paragraph

text: The most dramatic changes were to the most public facade, the west. The new
label: Paragraph

text: design is decidedly less modular and more varied in its divisions and composition. Its
label: Paragraph

text: “industrialized” structure became a faint background pattern. The rigid module of
label: Paragraph

text: 4-foot column and casement window unit is simplified. Here the double casement
label: Paragraph

text: window modules were replaced by single panes of fixed glass. Neutra said this was
label: Paragraph

text: because of increased noise on Silver Lake Boulevard, which it faced. Problems of
label: Paragraph

text: excess solar radiation were ameliorated with the addition of two-story louvers.
label: Caption

text: More substantially, the nature and quantity of transparency, translucency, mutabil-
label: Paragraph

text: ity, and reflective surfaces were greatly increased. Mirrors were added. Solid walls
label: Paragraph

text: were glazed. Shallow pools of water were placed on the all of the roofs. Reflective
label: Paragraph

text: glass appeared in certain locations. While all these elements created a highly dra-
label: Paragraph

text: matic and photogenic imagery of transparent and reflective surfaces, Neutra again
label: Paragraph

text: described these changes in scientific terms. The water on the roof, he explained,
label: Paragraph

text: acted to cool the house through evaporation and reestablish the connection to
label: Paragraph

text: the lake beyond, the water’s edge having receded over the years. At least one author
label: Paragraph

text: has argued that the rebuilding transformed a highly original work of the 1930s into
label: Paragraph

text: an accumulation of 1950s clichés — structural outriggers, suspended stairs, and
label: Paragraph

text: reflective pools.” This is a bit unfair, as many of these elements, clichés or not, were
label: Paragraph

text: pioneered by Neutra in previous work. Reyner Banham thought the new house bet-
label: Paragraph

text: ter, writing that it was “much closer to [Neutra’s] own dreams and heart's desires.
label: Paragraph

text: As to the legacy of Neutra’s triad of intentions for the VDL house and the ques-
label: Paragraph

text: tions they raised, one might say they are still unanswered. Neutra used high-
label: Paragraph

text: density site plans in other projects, but the bulk of Los Angeles, which includes
label: Paragraph

text: a great many Neutra houses, is obviously characterized by freestanding houses
label: Paragraph

text: in the middle of suburban lots. Between 1948 and 1961 he designed a small,
label: Paragraph

text: nine-house community in Silver Lake, the “Silver Lake Colony,” but at a lower
label: Paragraph

text: density than the VDL prototype implied. In the end he was absorbed by the system
label: Paragraph

text: he wanted to change.
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s Legacy
label: Title

text: Neutra’s legacy as a technical innovator, like that of many modernists, falls outside
label: Paragraph

text: the mainstream of the evolution of the construction industry. It is perhaps because
label: Paragraph

text: of its impurity that the VDL construction system was far more often replicated than
label: Paragraph

text: his steel prototypes, certainly in Neutra’s own work. While he experimented with
label: Paragraph

text: more radically alternative building systems — all-steel construction in real projects
label: Paragraph

text: like the Beard and Von Sternberg houses, diatomaceous earth panels in theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: projects like the Diatom house — the VDL system became the standard Neutra res-
label: Paragraph

text: idential building system, used in the Strathmore and Kelton apartments, the
label: Paragraph

text: Brown, Kun, Barsha, and Hofmann houses, and even in portions of buildings like
label: Paragraph

text: the Moore house of 1950, whose aesthetic seems far away from its 1933 predeces-
label: Paragraph

text: sor. It is replicated in spirit in some 1950s work by others. It is hard to imagine that
label: Paragraph

text: Craig Ellwood’s Broughton or Hale houses would have been built the way they
label: Paragraph

text: were if the VDL house had not come first. The “house ordered from a catalogue”
label: Paragraph

text: saw its ultimate realization, at least in theory, in the Eames house. Writing late in
label: Paragraph

text: his career, Neutra said that the industrialization of the housing industry had not
label: Paragraph

text: failed; it had never been tried.“
label: Paragraph

text: The industrialization of building remains a topical issue, but the conventional
label: Paragraph

text: wisdom as to its nature has precisely reversed itself since 1933, proclaiming that
label: Paragraph

text: the nature of digital fabrication and production is the absence of a need for rigid
label: Paragraph

text: standardization. Contemporary industrialization, in theory, is rather about infinite
label: Paragraph

text: variety.
label: Paragraph

text: Neutra’s fascination with biorealism and the psychology of architecture would
label: Paragraph

text: seem to anticipate current trends such as biophilia, particularly in its emphasis on
label: Paragraph

text: the need for our connection to nature, but the basic premises differ. Biophilia empha-
label: Paragraph

text: sizes its origins in genetics. Neutra felt that those impulses acquired prenatally were of
label: Paragraph

text: equal importance. In any case it cannot be said that Neutra left behind a methodology
label: Paragraph

text: for responding to psychological factors, but rather a style that was to its author a man-
label: Paragraph

text: ifestation of that study, and it is that style, rather than the ideology that produced it,
label: Paragraph

text: that has become his enduring legacy. There is an image common to many of Neutra’s
label: Paragraph

text: later houses, including the rebuilt VDL house; that of elemental planes of water inter-
label: Paragraph

text: secting planes of transparent or translucent glass and opaque surfaces of wood or
label: Paragraph

text: plaster. Allinterpenetrate, overlap, and slide by one another, and a projecting piece of
label: Caption

text: structure usually confirms the absence of a visible barrier between interior and exte-
label: Paragraph

text: rior, or at least confuses us as to its location. It was the photographer Julius Shulman
label: Paragraph

text: who codified this image and it is no accident that Neutra’s career as an architect is so
label: Paragraph

text: closely associated with Shulman’s career as an architectural photographer. The typical
label: Paragraph

text: Shulman photograph of the typical Neutra space has become a trademark for both.
label: Paragraph

text: The legacy of the science of biorealism, strangely, is a set of aesthetic devices —
label: Paragraph

text: extended structure, glass and water, reflection and transparency.
label: Paragraph

text: Critical opinion of the historical importance of VDL house has risen and fallen
label: Paragraph

text: over time with Neutra’s own reputation. In 1946 Edgar Kaufmann, who had
label: Paragraph

text: selected Frank Lloyd Wright to design Fallingwater, selected Neutra to design
label: Paragraph

text: his house in Palm Springs. In 1949, Neutra was on the cover of Time magazine.
label: Paragraph

text: But by the time Reyner Banham wrote Los Angeles: The Architecture of Four Ecologies
label: Paragraph

text: in 1971, the year after Neutra’s death, his reputation had declined considerably.
label: Paragraph

text: Banham described much of Neutra’s work, particularly the larger buildings, as
label: Paragraph

text: “good-average” and made it clear that he preferred the work of Neutra’s one time
label: Paragraph

text: partner, Schindler.'” The absoluteness and clarity of Neutra’s ideas on industrial-
label: Paragraph

text: ization that had made him the man of the hour in the 1930s seemed a liability in
label: Paragraph

text: Banham’s relativist, post-International Style, modernist world. But Neutra’s repu-
label: Paragraph

text: tation slowly rebounded, and when in 1980 Neutra’s widow donated the VDL
label: Paragraph

text: house to California State Polytechnic University at Pomona, the house began its
label: Paragraph

text: slow rise to international prominence.
