text: MODERN ARCHITECTURE FOR
label: Title

text: THE CORPORATE CLIENT
label: Title

text: By the late 1950s, modern architecture had become the expected vocabulary for
label: Paragraph

text: American corporate headquarters. Decades earlier, this had not been the case.
label: Paragraph

text: Corporations were considered unreliable patrons for modern architecture by
label: Paragraph

text: tastemakers like the curators of the Museum of Modern Art in New York. In
label: Paragraph

text: the book, The International Style: Architecture Since 1922, published following the
label: Paragraph

text: famous “Modern Architecture” exhibition of 1932, Alfred Barr, Jr. expostulated,
label: Paragraph

text: “we are asked to take seriously the architectural tastes of real estate speculators,
label: Paragraph

text: renting agents, and mortgage brokers!”’ “It is, then, from the commercially
label: Paragraph

text: successful modernistic architects,” he continued, “that we may expect the strongest
label: Paragraph

text: opposition to the Style.”* Yet the PSES Building stands as one of the most significant
label: Paragraph

text: modern American buildings, precisely because of the commercial influences of its
label: Paragraph

text: business client. The context from which it emerged was not the imported Interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional Style, but instead a modernism that developed in parallel, out of commercial
label: Paragraph

text: interests in the urban environment. In fact, the business-minded clients had a depth
label: Paragraph

text: of influence over the building’s design, the most important of which was a concern
label: Paragraph

text: with advertising the company through its architecture and its red neon sign.
label: Paragraph

text: The building is an asymmetrical composition of two vertically oriented rectilin-
label: Paragraph

text: ear volumes that were notched at their bottoms into a horizontal curved volume
label: Paragraph

text: that floated above the street level. At the top of building stood four, 27 foot-high
label: Paragraph

text: white letters: P $ F S. Two sets of the initials, one facing directly west and another
label: Caption

text: facing north-east, advertised the client’s business to the city. From dusk to dawn,
label: Paragraph

text: the letters glowed red from neon-tube lighting. Though “PSFS” would not be used
label: Paragraph

text: regularly in the savings fund’s advertising until almost two decades later, the acro-
label: Paragraph

text: nym ’s association with the institution began with the building sign.
label: Paragraph

text: The Philadelphia Saving Fund Society (PSFS) building was conceived as the new
label: Paragraph

text: face of the oldest savings fund in America as it reinvented itself in the complex cir-
label: Paragraph

text: cumstances of the twentieth century.” As such, the PSFS Building alloyed architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and business. The design and construction of the PSFS Building, which
label: Paragraph

text: occurred between 1929 and 1932, emerged out of many struggles: the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Depression; the conflicts between the architects George Howe and William Les-
label: Paragraph

text: caze, and the client, the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society Building Committee,
label: Paragraph

text: led by its president, John M. Willcox; and the struggle to define the building’s
label: Paragraph

text: own modernism in relation to the constant undercurrent of commercialism. While
label: Paragraph

text: the building has attributes commonly associated with the International Style, and
label: Paragraph

text: has even been described as the first International Style skyscraper in America,” its
label: Paragraph

text: varied and expressive hybrid forms complicate this straightforward interpretation
label: Paragraph

text: and point toward a more nuanced reading.
label: Paragraph

text: Function
label: Title

text: The world of the 1920s and 1930s, which defined the personalities of George Howe
label: Paragraph

text: and William Lescaze, was turbulent, marked by the heights of economic prosperity
label: Paragraph

text: and depths of worldwide depression that followed. Yet the times were also enli-
label: Paragraph

text: vened by an American idealism that could be witnessed in commercial and tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nological vitality. The careers of Howe and Lescaze embodied the grand
label: Paragraph

text: transformations occurring during this tumultuous era. Architect William Lescaze
label: Paragraph

text: had been influenced by the rational expressionist strain of European modernism,
label: Paragraph

text: which he demonstrated in his designs for commercial interiors in New York imme-
label: Paragraph

text: diately prior to his work on PSFS. Howe had nurtured a late-blooming passion for
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture. He had become interested in German modernism while
label: Paragraph

text: studying a classical approach to architecture at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts from
label: Paragraph

text: 1907 to 1912. In addition to bringing his enthusiasm for modern architecture to
label: Paragraph

text: the project, Howe also provided the client. During his prior partnership with
label: Paragraph

text: Arthur Mellor and Walter Meigs, in the firm Mellor, Meigs, and Howe, he designed
label: Paragraph

text: four branch banks in the early 1920s for the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society,
label: Paragraph

text: whose president was James M. Willcox. When he terminated his partnership with
label: Paragraph

text: Mellor and Meigs, Howe started his own practice and took with him one of the
label: Paragraph

text: firm’s most substantial clients, the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society. His prior part-
label: Paragraph

text: nership and professional connections, in addition to his refined American upbring-
label: Paragraph

text: ing, made him perfectly suited to successfully deal with a wealthy and conservative
label: Paragraph

text: clientele.
label: Paragraph

text: When they came together as partners in 1929, both architects were struggling to
label: Paragraph

text: define a “functional” modern architecture, informed by their individual experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ences variously studying and practicing classicism, art deco, and expressionism.
label: Paragraph

text: As partners, they believed that functionalism, a highly debated term from its incep-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, was the basis of their common understanding of modern architecture. They
label: Paragraph

text: would describe the PSFS Building’s “functional”’ forms as “growing out of the
label: Paragraph

text: requirements of our civilization and the modern technique of building...”* Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the process the client had described the 33-story skyscraper as a collec-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of distinct building programs, “Office, Bank & Store,” a description that even-
label: Paragraph

text: tually would become a reality as the tall, rectilinear volume was devoted to rental
label: Paragraph

text: offices and mechanical services, while the curved volume held the banking hall and
label: Paragraph

text: the store. The contrast between straight and curved forms was highlighted through
label: Paragraph

text: different materials that sheathed the building’s forms and, in turn, its functions.
label: Paragraph

text: The service core was clad in black brick, the bank and store — both commercial
label: Paragraph

text: spaces — in polished granite, and the office tower in an envelope of brick spandrels
label: Paragraph

text: and piers clad in limestone and marble. The play of reflective and matte surfaces on
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior massing echoed that inside the banking hall. The material claddings did
label: Paragraph

text: not simply express interior function, however, but instead added to the dynamism
label: Paragraph

text: of the volumes through surface effects.
label: Paragraph

text: The PSFS Building further demonstrated “functional” principles by creating
label: Paragraph

text: important links to the surrounding urban site. While the building’s modern expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion was strikingly unlike Philadelphia’s classically derived architecture, there were
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of the building design that accommodated the neighborhood. The ground
label: Paragraph

text: and underground levels of the PSFS Building allowed the city’s infrastructure to
label: Paragraph

text: integrate with the architecture, as shopping and public transportation became part
label: Paragraph

text: of the building. The neighborhood was a lively area, full of moderately priced retail
label: Paragraph

text: outlets, with the Reading Railroad terminal across the street. As the building
label: Paragraph

text: owner, Philadelphia Saving Fund Society leased store space located at the corner
label: Caption

text: street level to its very first tenant, a women’s clothier called Lerner Shops, and this
label: Paragraph

text: blended easily into the retail street environment. An A & P grocery market was
label: Paragraph

text: another retail tenant in the building. Two underground levels accommodated a
label: Paragraph

text: connection to the Market Street subway stop and a stair to the subway concourse
label: Caption

text: was located on the street level between the banking hall and store entrance.
label: Paragraph

text: Expressive of its functions, the PSFS Building was conspicuously modern, an
label: Paragraph

text: example of which that was rarely seen in America at the time. Certainly, modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of a different evolution was prominent in Philadelphia’s buildings. In
label: Paragraph

text: the first decades of the twentieth century, Philadelphia’s modern architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified by the pared-down classicism of the Philadelphia Art Museum and the
label: Paragraph

text: City Beautiful movement, out of which the Benjamin Franklin Parkway had been
label: Paragraph

text: created. The modern architecture of the PSFS Building, however, was based on
label: Paragraph

text: entirely different sources.
label: Paragraph

text: In the pre-World War I period, both Howe and Lescaze were earnest students
label: Paragraph

text: of new developments in architecture. Repercussions of these early influences can
label: Paragraph

text: be witnessed in Lescaze’s sketches for the base of the PSFS Building, which dis-
label: Paragraph

text: played the dynamism and exuberance that had only been seen in works by J.J. P.
label: Paragraph

text: Oud, such as Hoek van Holland (1924-27) and Erich Mendelsohn’s buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: the Tageblatt Headquarters, known as Mossehaus, in Berlin (1921-23) and the
label: Paragraph

text: Schocken department store in Stuttgart (1926-28). Oud’s poetic and Mendel-
label: Paragraph

text: sohn’s dynamic functionalism can both be read in the PSFS Building.” Lescaze
label: Paragraph

text: had studied J. J. P. Oud’s building, as one of the projects included in his proposed
label: Paragraph

text: book comparing European and American modern architecture suggests. He
label: Paragraph

text: believed that Oud’s Hoek van Holland housing for workers was a model for
label: Paragraph

text: European modern architecture. Like the PSFS Building, Oud’s scheme was
label: Paragraph

text: designed for multiple uses. It contained 41 dwellings, four shops, four ware-
label: Paragraph

text: houses, and a public library. Both buildings were designed as self-contained com-
label: Paragraph

text: positions in which the individual functions were transformed into a single
label: Paragraph

text: building by the use of repetition. Oud situated four curved storefronts at the ends
label: Caption

text: of linear rows of houses and his curved plate glass facades undoubtedly influ-
label: Paragraph

text: enced Lescaze’s curved ground floor storefront, which prominently displayed
label: Paragraph

text: retail merchandise through a large, continuous glass window at the PSFS Build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. For Oud as well as for Lescaze, the curved element was seen as a symbol of
label: Paragraph

text: the modern machine, emulating its circular movements.
label: Paragraph

text: Lescaze had also visited Berlin, at least twice in the 1920s, once in 1922-23 and
label: Paragraph

text: again in 1926. Though not documented in Lescaze’s archive, it is highly likely that
label: Paragraph

text: he saw first-hand the strikingly modern renovation of the Mossehaus, the most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent feature in Berlin during those particular years. The emphasis on
label: Paragraph

text: curved horizontality in Mossehaus’ corner facade is unmistakably similar to
label: Paragraph

text: Lescaze’s sketch and the subsequent design of PSFS’s corner banking hall
label: Paragraph

text: facade. Mendelsohn believed that horizontality best expressed the modern con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction of reinforced concrete, as well as the velocity of modern urban street
label: Paragraph

text: life. Furthermore, for Mendelsohn horizontality would provide a much-needed
label: Paragraph

text: stabilizing force that would alleviate the stress of modern life. And on an expe-
label: Paragraph

text: riential level, the blurring of verticals and the extension of horizontals reflected
label: Paragraph

text: the way automobile passengers traveling at high speeds perceived buildings as
label: Paragraph

text: they drove past.*
label: Paragraph

text: Echoing Mendelsohn’s Mossehaus, the bold 1929 rendering by Lescaze showed
label: Paragraph

text: a similar horizontally curving facade and windows. The sketch dramatizes the play
label: Paragraph

text: of receding surfaces, one recessed at the street level and another implied by a dark
label: Paragraph

text: shadow at the second story banking hall level. In addition, Mossehaus’ appearance,
label: Paragraph

text: prominent location, and publicity-minded patron also made it similar to the PSFS
label: Paragraph

text: Building. Like the individualistic modernism of Oud and Mendelsohn, the
label: Paragraph

text: PSFS Building design would take shape from the dynamic sketches of one of its
label: Paragraph

text: designers.
label: Paragraph

text: Business
label: Title

text: It was just this kind of architectural individualism that translated well into the
label: Paragraph

text: business culture of PSFS’s clients. Throughout the design process, James Willcox
label: Paragraph

text: and the PSFS Building Committee judged its architecture by how it would dis-
label: Paragraph

text: tinguish itself through its functional characteristics and its aesthetic appearance
label: Paragraph

text: and, specifically, how these attributes would affect their business. While the
label: Paragraph

text: Building Committee did not have a particular aesthetic in mind, its criterion
label: Paragraph

text: for the architecture was that it be a sound business investment. Upon seeing
label: Paragraph

text: Howe and Lescaze’s proposed modern design, one consulting rental agent stated,
label: Paragraph

text: “the architecture, while novel, is striking and mod ern,”” while another one noted:
label: Paragraph

text: “Opinions will undoubtedly vary regarding its architecture, but the building is
label: Paragraph

text: sure to be talked about.”!° J. M. Willcox was ultimately concerned with how
label: Paragraph

text: his new building would bolster the saving fund’s larger business strategy to create
label: Paragraph

text: a competitive advantage. Originality, or the quality of being remarkable, served
label: Paragraph

text: as an advertising strategy and was ultimately one of the aspects that convinced
label: Paragraph

text: Willcox to accept the modern design.
label: Paragraph

text: But even in 1930, during the design process, the Building Committee was still
label: Paragraph

text: not convinced of the modern design. It also had been presented with a more tra-
label: Paragraph

text: ditional, Beaux-Arts scheme, in 1926, designed by Howe’s former practice, Mellor,
label: Paragraph

text: Meigs, and Howe. This caused Howe to write a letter on July 30, 1930 to his client,
label: Paragraph

text: Willcox, in which he argued for his modern design in bankers’ language. In pecu-
label: Paragraph

text: niary terms, Howe compared the modern and traditional schemes by their cost
label: Paragraph

text: effectiveness. He presented a graph that showed the gross area and cost saving that
label: Paragraph

text: the society would gain by building the modern scheme instead of the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: one. While the modern scheme would cost more, the society would get more
label: Paragraph

text: for its money. “In other words, for $930,000 or about 20% more than the cost
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1926 building, your institution obtains more than 200,000 square feet or over
label: Paragraph

text: 60% additional floor area. Furthermore, the 1930 building is more completely
label: Paragraph

text: equipped mechanically than the 1926 building.”'’ Here, Howe used business
label: Paragraph

text: criteria (price per square foot) to cast modern architecture as a good business
label: Paragraph

text: investment.
label: Paragraph

text: The discussion over the design’s “modernism” also continued as the client
label: Paragraph

text: worried that it might not appeal to potential tenants. Because modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: was predominately linked to industrial rather than commercial buildings, Willcox
label: Paragraph

text: informed Howe that, “We must recognize the fact that there is something in your
label: Paragraph

text: design which requires explanation. The first impulse of everyone I have shown it to
label: Paragraph

text: is [to turn] away from it.”’? Yet Willcox was open-minded about modern design, as
label: Paragraph

text: long as it would help his profits. “I don’t think that there is anything in your design
label: Paragraph

text: which would decide a prospective tenant against taking space in the building if the
label: Paragraph

text: matter were properly presented. It is impossible to take the architect along every
label: Paragraph

text: time a prospect is to be interviewed.”'* Willcox thought through the myriad of
label: Paragraph

text: possibilities and conclusions that would color his decision-making and finally con-
label: Paragraph

text: cluded, “On the other hand, its uniqueness — at least in Philadelphia — gives it an
label: Paragraph

text: advertising value that is worth something.”"4 Here, architecture served as adver-
label: Paragraph

text: tisement, giving the city a brand identity and an architectural image of the Phila-
label: Paragraph

text: delphia Saving Fund Society. Willcox’s assessment would come true: there was no
label: Paragraph

text: other comparable architecture in height, size, or expression. Strikingly unlike its
label: Paragraph

text: urban context of commercial buildings in the early 1930s, the PSFS Building would
label: Paragraph

text: define modern architecture in Philadelphia.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Advertising
label: Title

text: The modernity of an electric sign for the PSFS Building was foundational for the
label: Paragraph

text: design. The idea for such a sign was raised by the client himself, and in a letter to
label: Paragraph

text: Willcox on May 26, 1930, Howe noted, “You are aware that ever since you first
label: Paragraph

text: asked me to design a branch bank around an electric sign I have been looking
label: Paragraph

text: for a means of architectural expression which would not be in conflict with any
label: Paragraph

text: form of modern activity outside the field of architecture.”’* If the idea for the elec-
label: Paragraph

text: tric sign originated with Willcox, Howe viewed the suggestion as an opportunity to
label: Paragraph

text: design a modern building. The awkwardness of the electric sign designs on the
label: Paragraph

text: 1926 branch banks showed that a modern direction for placing advertising on
label: Paragraph

text: the PSFS bank was needed. Here, lettering was permissible as modern ornament
label: Paragraph

text: because it possessed “functional purpose in advertising and in indicating the use o:
label: Paragraph

text: different parts of a building.”’” In fact, in The International Style: Architecture Since
label: Paragraph

text: 1922, Hitchcock and Johnson stated, “Lettering is the nearest approach to arbitrary
label: Paragraph

text: ornament used by the architects of the international style.”!* The development o
label: Paragraph

text: the red neon P § F S$ sign has been largely overlooked, with the exception of David
label: Paragraph

text: Leatherbarrow’s insightful discussion of the urban implications of the sign.’*
label: Paragraph

text: The sign had many variations between July 1930 and the summer of 1932, when
label: Paragraph

text: it was finally constructed. The architects and clients grappled with three aspects o
label: Paragraph

text: the sign design. First, whether the Society’s whole name or its abbreviation should
label: Paragraph

text: be used. Second, whether the sign would be mounted on the side of the building
label: Paragraph

text: or on top. Third, whether the sign’s orientation would be north, south or east.
label: Paragraph

text: These details occupied the architects and clients throughout the design process
label: Paragraph

text: and were not mere minutiae; for these decisions signaled modernity on many
label: Paragraph

text: levels.
label: Paragraph

text: Legibility became an important deciding factor as the architects and clients chose
label: Paragraph

text: between displaying the whole name versus the initials. The discussion highlighted
label: Paragraph

text: the sign’s function as a medium for mass advertising. Publicity was at the forefront
label: Paragraph

text: in the minds of the clients and the use of initials was not only a matter of legibility; it
label: Paragraph

text: also signaled the modernization of the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society as a com-
label: Paragraph

text: pany, recasting its image and establishing a visual standard. The wish to modernize
label: Paragraph

text: was contested by the Society’s hesitation to fully to embrace a modern image, as
label: Paragraph

text: the oldest savings fund in America was just starting to grow into a modern business
label: Paragraph

text: through the diversification of real-estate ventures and expansion through branch
label: Paragraph

text: banks. These difficulties to wholeheartedly accepting modernity was not surprising
label: Paragraph

text: at a time when modern life in America was itself still in transition.
label: Paragraph

text: Advertising value figured largely in the decision to use initials for the sign and to
label: Paragraph

text: orient it toward the north-east transportation corridor. Earle Bolton, staff architect
label: Caption

text: for Howe and Lescaze, who attended most of the design meetings, reported the
label: Paragraph

text: clients’ desire for advertising value as the reason they eventually approved the initi-
label: Paragraph

text: als for the sign.”° One of the vice-presidents of the construction company, Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: and Company, asked Willcox if he had ever seen a large electric sign reading
label: Paragraph

text: “PON” visible from the Pennsylvania Railroad as one came into Newark. Willcox
label: Paragraph

text: had noticed the sign, which led him to inquire for what the initials stood for. The
label: Paragraph

text: Fuller and Company vice-president voiced his enthusiasm for using initials: “Let’s
label: Paragraph

text: make everyone curious about PSFS.””"
label: Paragraph

text: At a special roof sign meeting in late April 1932, full-scaled letter samples were
label: Paragraph

text: viewed: one at the size of the PSFS initial design and another at the size for the full-
label: Paragraph

text: name version. A hotel room at a high floor was rented several miles away to judge
label: Paragraph

text: visibility of the letters atop the actual, nearly finished PSFS Building. A single letter
label: Paragraph

text: S was first hoisted into place. Its simple sans serif typeface with an 18-inch stroke,
label: Paragraph

text: proved extremely legible. However, the full name size was constructed at a dimen-
label: Paragraph

text: sioned stroke that was considered illegible. The legible initials version was clearly
label: Paragraph

text: preferable: “great size ... takes less concentration to assimilate.””” By late spring of
label: Paragraph

text: 1932, the final sign design would show the PSES initials.
label: Paragraph

text: While the architect’s first sign design depicted it on top of the building, it was
label: Paragraph

text: followed by a number of studies that took advantage of the blank south facade that
label: Paragraph

text: covered the elevators and service equipment. PSFS’s sign design on the facade
label: Caption

text: reflected commercial signage practices of the time. By the 1910s and 1920s in Amer-
label: Paragraph

text: ica, billposting on building facades had become a prevalent way of advertising. At
label: Paragraph

text: the same time, there was also influence from a more rarified source. Both George
label: Paragraph

text: Howe and William Lescaze visited the 1925 Exposition des arts décoratifs in Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: and had seen Le Corbusier's Pavilion de Esprit Nouveau.’ The abbreviated letters
label: Paragraph

text: “E N” composed an emblazoned sign on the entrance facade. Le Corbusier's sign
label: Caption

text: not only reinforced the custom of billposting but also the use of abbreviation.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite these illuminating studies, the sign was finally positioned, not on the side
label: Paragraph

text: of the building, but on top of it— an example of skyline lettering. One precedent for
label: Paragraph

text: the PSFS sign position was the Van Nelle Factory in Rotterdam by J. A. Brinkman
label: Paragraph

text: and L. C. van der Vlugt, built between 1925 and 1931, which also used sans serif
label: Paragraph

text: lettering. The two buildings shared many similarities as modern architecture for
label: Paragraph

text: business clients, including angling of the sign toward key sight lines, and function-
label: Paragraph

text: alist design principles of clear legibility and use of electric lighting.
label: Paragraph

text: The sign atop the building also coincided with a decision to provide air condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tioning to the whole building. The Building Committee had originally decided to
label: Paragraph

text: air-condition only the banking floors but a particularly stifling summer convinced
label: Paragraph

text: the business savvy client that office space would be infinitely more desirable if
label: Paragraph

text: “manufactured air” (air conditioning) were installed throughout the entire office
label: Paragraph

text: tower. Now, the PSFS Building was the second in the nation to have this luxury
label: Paragraph

text: and the sign would hide the gigantic cooling towers of the air conditioning. This
label: Paragraph

text: necessitated a wall-like barrier to hide the service equipment, upon which the let-
label: Paragraph

text: ters would be mounted — essentially a billboard. As such, the sign would be under-
label: Paragraph

text: stood not simply as a display for a name, but as more conventional outdoor
label: Paragraph

text: advertising with automobile travel figuring largely in the final decisions.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early design schemes, the sign was oriented to the north and south, which
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to align with what was considered the front door on Market Street. How-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, in a variation of seven schemes presented on November 1930, the architects
label: Paragraph

text: included one version that showed an east-facing sign. This particular sign foresha-
label: Paragraph

text: dowed the final orientation and hinted at its urban impact, where the eastern face
label: Paragraph

text: addressed the Delaware River Bridge (named the Benjamin Franklin Bridge since
label: Paragraph

text: 1956), which linked Philadelphia to a network of urban centers connected by high-
label: Paragraph

text: ways.” After abandoning the idea of a sign on the south facade, the architects
label: Paragraph

text: designed a dual-faced sign directed toward the east and west. Finally, in 1932, after
label: Paragraph

text: the long debate, the PSFS sign was constructed on top of the 32nd floor of the sky-
label: Paragraph

text: scraper. Each letter was 27 feet tall, 18 feet wide, and 9 inches deep, constructed of
label: Paragraph

text: steel and painted white. Supported by steel brackets in front of a solid steel bill-
label: Caption

text: board of deep cobalt blue, the sign measured 28 feet tall and 120 feet long. The
label: Paragraph

text: framework was riveted and cross-braced to the building’s steel structure and could
label: Paragraph

text: withstand a 200-mile wind.”’ Between the two billboard sign surfaces was a resid-
label: Paragraph

text: ual space to house the air conditioning compressors.
label: Paragraph

text: The sign would now greet automobile commuters, who utilized a mode of
label: Paragraph

text: transportation that was quickly becoming dominant in the late 1920s. Eventually,
label: Paragraph

text: to the clients, the rooftop sign’s legibility from the Delaware River Bridge, where
label: Paragraph

text: tens of thousands of New Jersey commuters entered into Philadelphia, was one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most important factors of the building design. The large number of travelers
label: Paragraph

text: became public in a 1931 study by the Delaware River Joint Commission of Penn-
label: Paragraph

text: sylvania and New Jersey, which counted 62,126 people crossing the Delaware
label: Paragraph

text: River Bridge daily.“° These were 70% of the total commuters by various means
label: Paragraph

text: of travel, including ferries, from Camden to Philadelphia — commuters who could
label: Paragraph

text: not miss the four large letters on the building’s rooftop as they approached the city.
label: Paragraph

text: The PSFS sign had much in common with outdoor billboards. Instead of compli-
label: Paragraph

text: cated designs that would take too long to read, billboard designs were deliberately
label: Paragraph

text: abstract and simplified. Their design spoke concisely yet read loudly to meet the
label: Paragraph

text: modern tempo of life created by highway travel. As part of this new aesthetic, twen-
label: Paragraph

text: tieth-century advertisers refined their use of trademarks, logos, and slogans to create
label: Paragraph

text: massed images that gave a quick impression. An aesthetics of speed was required,
label: Paragraph

text: which could deliver messages in a state of unblinking recognition. A logo was the
label: Paragraph

text: ideal form of communication for mobile audiences. The rooftop letters, “PSFS,”
label: Paragraph

text: while not officially registered until the 1970s, were ostensibly such a trademark.
label: Paragraph

text: Economics
label: Title

text: In the decades after its opening, the PSFS Building enjoyed steady occupancy, per-
label: Paragraph

text: severing through the Great Depression. While modern architecture was not the
label: Paragraph

text: explicit choice of the client, it turned out to serve the institution well. The Architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural Forum promoted business patronage of modern architecture in an article from
label: Paragraph

text: September 1943, entitled, “Does Modern Architecture Pay?” The inquiry of
label: Paragraph

text: whether modern architecture was profitable for business clients tapped into a con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary concern. The editors asserted, “It should at the very least bring into ques-
label: Paragraph

text: tion the notion that investment return and resale value are answered only when a
label: Paragraph

text: building turns its face to the past.” The journal had sent a questionnaire to business
label: Paragraph

text: clients of modern architecture (including PSFS), and then printed a selection of the
label: Paragraph

text: responses together with 25 important modern buildings and their clients’ com-
label: Paragraph

text: ments. The article observed that while modern architecture in America predomi-
label: Paragraph

text: nated in the commercial and industrial fields, in others — including banks,
label: Paragraph

text: insurance companies, and government agencies — modern architecture was hardly
label: Paragraph

text: represented. The editors believed this was due to the unwillingness of investors to
label: Paragraph

text: put funds into something that may not pay off and, in turn, argued that “[iJn com-
label: Paragraph

text: mercial buildings, design is as much a competitive element as merchandising itself.
label: Paragraph

text: There is no better indication of the soundness of the modern approach than its rapid
label: Paragraph

text: »?8 Here, modern
label: Caption

text: architecture became a form of merchandise, which would promote a business’s
label: Paragraph

text: goods. The Philadelphia Saving Fund Society’s modern design stood as a bold exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ple against the status quo of other banks that did not patronize modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: In the reply to the Architectural Forum’s questionnaire, Willcox offered enthusi-
label: Paragraph

text: astic support for the PSES Building design.”” “The type of architecture adopted has
label: Paragraph

text: proved most successful, and has resulted in a building better adapted for the pur-
label: Paragraph

text: pose than would have been possible had the style been conventional.”*° But while
label: Paragraph

text: Willcox was satisfied with the design of PSFS, he did not embrace it as modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture per se, but instead called the design “ultra-practical.” On his first
label: Paragraph

text: and only patronage of modern architecture, Willcox wrote: “I am tempted to haz-
label: Paragraph

text: ard a forecast and say that there will be but few large office buildings erected in the
label: Paragraph

text: future designed along conventional lines.”*' He supported his statement with his
label: Paragraph

text: acceptance by the people who have to examine it most critically.
label: Paragraph

text: building’s excellent renting record, which despite the Depression was 92.8% occu-
label: Paragraph

text: pied, as well as the quick occupation of the ground floor store and restaurant space.
label: Paragraph

text: He attributed these positive results to “the orderliness and clean-cut arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: of space, typical of this type of architecture, we believe is in large part responsible
label: Paragraph

text: for our satisfactory rental experience.”*” When the Society examined the balance
label: Paragraph

text: sheet of their revenue-generating building, they estimated the total cost to have
label: Paragraph

text: been $12,360,942.37, which showed that the construction cost had actually come
label: Paragraph

text: in under its initial estimation of $12,500,000.”
label: Paragraph

text: According to the PSFS, modern architecture provided business advantage
label: Paragraph

text: against their competitors. However, it did so not through conforming to the
label: Paragraph

text: orthodoxy of the International Style, but instead through a combination of
label: Paragraph

text: poetic and dynamic functionalism in alignment with modern architecture’s
label: Paragraph

text: advertising and branding potential, including not least of all, its iconic rooftop
label: Paragraph

text: sign. The design was largely the result of a fruitful collaboration between client
label: Paragraph

text: and architect, exemplifying the larger cooperation between business and archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture in the twentieth century. The PSFS Building stands as a testament to
label: Paragraph

text: American modernism with the rise of corporations, the growth of media,
label: Paragraph

text: and a burgeoning consumer culture.

text: FALLINGWATER
label: Title

text: Frank Lloyd Wright
label: Title

text: Neil Levine
label: Title

text: Frank Lloyd Wright, Fallingwater, 1934-37.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: Fallingwater is the name Frank Lloyd Wright gave to the country house he
label: Paragraph

text: designed for Edgar Kaufmann and his wife, Liliane, in 1934-35, and built over a
label: Paragraph

text: waterfall in 1936-37 in the foothills of the Allegheny Mountains, about 65 miles
label: Paragraph

text: south of Pittsburgh. It is one of the most extraordinary and celebrated works of
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth-century architecture. Recognized as such even before it was inhabited,
label: Paragraph

text: Fallingwater stands out as a singular expression of integrating architecture with its
label: Paragraph

text: natural environment and creating out of that interrelationship a synergy that has
label: Paragraph

text: become definitive of the modern concept of site-specificity. The experience of it in
label: Paragraph

text: space and time is a multisensory one involving the kinesthetic and the aural in addi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to the more usual visual mode of perception of buildings.’
label: Paragraph

text: As its name implies, Fallingwater is about movement and change and the con-
label: Paragraph

text: tinuous effects and action of time. It incorporates and represents these phenomena
label: Paragraph

text: in its forms. There is no one point of view, no privileged spot for the gaze to alight
label: Paragraph

text: upon —no single moment in time that becomes the representative, pregnant one. In
label: Paragraph

text: part, this is a function of the medium of architecture, which generally presents itself
label: Paragraph

text: as a three-dimensional sequence of spaces to be traversed and experienced in time.
label: Paragraph

text: Philip Johnson called this the “processional element in architecture.”” But there is
label: Paragraph

text: more to it than that, for Fallingwater exploits this normal characteristic of the
label: Paragraph

text: medium to produce an architectural condition where time is understood not
label: Paragraph

text: merely in the literal terms of one’s movement through space in real time but also
label: Paragraph

text: as a more profound sensation of the virtual time of duration.
label: Paragraph

text: That dual experience of time in Fallingwater was recognized and highlighted as
label: Paragraph

text: soon as the building was completed in the exhibition devoted to it by the Museum
label: Paragraph

text: of Modern Art in New York in early 1938. For the museum’s first major one-
label: Paragraph

text: building exhibition, John McAndrew, the curator of Architecture and Industrial
label: Caption

text: Art, produced a catalogue including plans, an explanatory text by the architect,
label: Paragraph

text: and photographs of the structure taken mainly by Bill Hedrich, of the well-known
label: Caption

text: Chicago firm of Hedrich-Blessing, and Luke Swank, a family friend of the Kauf-
label: Paragraph

text: manns.’ The arrangement and layout of the photographs stressed the temporal
label: Paragraph

text: experience of the visitor in the perception of the house.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning with the title page, the sequence of views starts at the bridge leading to
label: Paragraph

text: the structure. Following the text by Wright and a double-page spread of plans, an
label: Paragraph

text: extended series of two-page spreads takes the visitor around and through the
label: Paragraph

text: building, focusing on its multiple aspects.* To illustrate the course of movement
label: Paragraph

text: and allow the reader to follow it in his or her mind’s eye, there is a diagrarmmatic
label: Paragraph

text: plan beneath each photograph with a small eye drawn to indicate the physical point
label: Paragraph

text: of view. These spreads are interrupted once, in the middle, with a pair of dramatically
label: Paragraph

text: opposing views of the house, both by Luke Swank and both lacking the situational
label: Paragraph

text: ocular index.
label: Paragraph

text: More significantly, and much more unusually, the processional sequence culmi-
label: Paragraph

text: nates on the final page of the catalogue in a collage of two photographs, one above
label: Paragraph

text: the other, both taken by Hedrich and both showing the house from precisely the
label: Paragraph

text: same point of view. The only difference is that the upper photograph was shot in
label: Paragraph

text: the daytime and the lower one at night.’ The final two images go beyond an
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledgment of the literal time it takes to see the house and reveal a sense
label: Paragraph

text: of the building’s durational aspect. The highly unusual juxtaposition of two views
label: Paragraph

text: of the same building at different moments in the diurnal cycle leads one to contem-
label: Paragraph

text: plate the fact that Fallingwater is not only about one’s passage through time but,
label: Paragraph

text: even more importantly, about the expression of the passage of time itself, a virtual
label: Paragraph

text: time made manifest in the building’s interaction with its ever-changing landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, accompanied by a cover story in
label: Paragraph

text: Time magazine and a multipage section of the January 1938 issue of Architectural
label: Paragraph

text: Forum, devoted to Wright, made Fallingwater instantaneously famous.* In 1963,
label: Paragraph

text: less than ten years after Edgar Kaufmann died (Liliane died in 1952), their only
label: Paragraph

text: son, Edgar Jr., donated the house to the Western Pennsylvania Conservancy to
label: Paragraph

text: become one of the first and most visited modern house museums. Indeed, despite
label: Paragraph

text: its remote location in rural Pennsylvania, close to the West Virginia line, and the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that it was until recently only open part of the year, it has attracted more than
label: Paragraph

text: five million visitors since 1964 and now averages more than 150,000 a year. Along
label: Paragraph

text: with Le Corbusier's Villa Savoye (1928-31) and Mies van der Rohe’s Tugendhat
label: Paragraph

text: (1928-30) and Farnsworth (1945-51) houses, Fallingwater is one of the first half
label: Paragraph

text: of the twentieth century’s iconic modern houses.
label: Paragraph

text: Client, Site, Materials, and Design
label: Title

text: When he commissioned the house, Edgar Kaufmann was the owner and president
label: Paragraph

text: of Pittsburgh’s largest department store as well as a leading citizen of a city made
label: Paragraph

text: famous for its industrial might and engagement in the arts and culture by such fig-
label: Paragraph

text: ures as Henry Frick, Andrew Carnegie, H. J. Heinz, and the Mellons. Kaufmann
label: Caption

text: was active in civic affairs at the highest levels and took a special interest in archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture and city planning. In the fall of 1934 he contacted Wright regarding the
label: Paragraph

text: design of a planetarium and parking facility for a vacant lot next to his downtown
label: Caption

text: department store, as well as a job as adviser to the recently established Allegheny
label: Paragraph

text: County Authority, which was in charge of overseeing the construction of certain
label: Paragraph

text: major, federally-funded Public Works Administration projects, including several
label: Paragraph

text: bridges, highways, a tunnel, and riverfront improvements. Nothing came of either
label: Paragraph

text: of these initiatives, but it was on Wright’s visit to the city to discuss the urban pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects that Kaufmann commissioned the country house.
label: Paragraph

text: The extensive property the Kaufmanns owned in the southwestern corner of
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania follows the winding and precipitous course ofa mountain stream, Bear
label: Paragraph

text: Run, which works its way down through the sandstone cliffs of an old glacial ravine,
label: Paragraph

text: falling nearly 1,500 feet in four miles before emptying into the Youghiogheny River.
label: Paragraph

text: About halfa mile before it reaches the river, it drops in a series of dramatic falls over
label: Paragraph

text: large boulders strewn in its bed. This is the place Edgar Kaufmann had in mind for
label: Paragraph

text: the house, and it is where he took his architect near the end of 1934. According to
label: Paragraph

text: reports, he had thought Wright would site the structure on the flat, lower bank of the
label: Paragraph

text: stream, facing the waterfalls. To his client’s surprise, and later consternation, Wright
label: Paragraph

text: decided to locate the house over the water by cantilevering it from the opposite cliff
label: Paragraph

text: and balancing the structure on the existing boulders in the streambed. Wright wrote
label: Paragraph

text: to Kaufmann in late December, immediately after returning home, that “the visit to
label: Paragraph

text: the waterfall in the woods stays with me and a domicile has taken vague shape in my
label: Paragraph

text: mind to the music of the stream.”” He later described his idea for the design as “an
label: Paragraph

text: extension of the cliff beside a mountain stream.” More importantly, he explained
label: Paragraph

text: that the house was conceived for someone “who liked to listen to the waterfall”
label: Paragraph

text: and for this reason was designed as a “living space over and above the stream.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Fallingwater’s design combines a seemingly accidental naturalness with a subtle
label: Paragraph

text: though no less powerful geometric order and structural logic, all characteristic of
label: Paragraph

text: the architect’s work since the 1911 design of his own country estate of Taliesin in
label: Paragraph

text: Wyoming Township, Wisconsin, but never before resolved in such a dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: way. A binary opposition of stone and concrete expresses the conjunction on a
label: Paragraph

text: basic, material level. The stone, quarried less than 500 feet from the actual site,
label: Paragraph

text: was reserved for all vertical, load-bearing piers and walls; reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: was used to create the stack of horizontal balconies, or trays, cantilevered from
label: Paragraph

text: the rock ledge over the bed of the stream.” Bounded by curved parapets, the trays
label: Paragraph

text: weave through the vertical stone structure to provide the house’s living spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: These are continuous inside and out. Where one tray overlaps another, doors
label: Paragraph

text: and windows of plate glass in steel sash are inserted to mark the distinction
label: Paragraph

text: between interior room and outdoor terrace. The lowest tray forms the main floor
label: Caption

text: of the house and contains a single open space combining the functions of living,
label: Paragraph

text: dining, reception, and library. The middle tray, with its main terrace forming
label: Paragraph

text: the roof of the living room, contains the two master bedrooms plus a smaller guest
label: Paragraph

text: room, each with its adjacent terrace. The top tray, roofing over the second-floor
label: Paragraph

text: bedrooms and forming an aerie within the overarching branches of the tall oak
label: Paragraph

text: trees, became the bedroom suite of Edgar jr?
label: Paragraph

text: The site on the north bank of Bear Run is a narrow shelf making an almost
label: Paragraph

text: perfect 30°/60° triangle defined by a group of large boulders that follow the line
label: Paragraph

text: of the ledge determining the upper of the two falls. The nearly 15-foot cantilever
label: Paragraph

text: of the living-room floor is partly supported by three “bolsters,” as Wright called
label: Paragraph

text: them, that angle up from the rock ledge. The even greater cantilever of the sec-
label: Paragraph

text: ond-floor terrace is partly supported by the two free-standing piers in the living
label: Caption

text: room; the weight of the enclosed section of the second floor, along with that of
label: Paragraph

text: the entire upper story (all of which is contained within the angle of the chimney
label: Paragraph

text: mass and the north wall of the house), serves to counterbalance the effect of the
label: Paragraph

text: cantilever. Visually, the composition is stabilized by the trellis of reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete beams that continues the slab of the second-floor tray through the rear
label: Paragraph

text: wall of the house and ties the floating layers of living space into the face of the
label: Paragraph

text: cliff. As a result, the tunnel-like driveway beneath becomes a fully integrated part
label: Paragraph

text: of the design.
label: Paragraph

text: The orthogonal geometry adopted for the plan contrasts with the triangular
label: Paragraph

text: shape of the shelf on which the house is superposed. The interaction of the two
label: Paragraph

text: geometries is reflected in the pivoting of the plan and the resulting diagonal axes
label: Paragraph

text: that govern its spatial form. The east-west path of the existing road, which was
label: Paragraph

text: reused as the driveway, served as the datum line from which Wright angled the
label: Paragraph

text: house in a southeasterly direction so that the leading edge of the cantilevered trays
label: Paragraph

text: would parallel the course of the stream beneath them and the diagonal axis defined
label: Paragraph

text: by that line would become the axis of the house’s main space. As “an extension of
label: Paragraph

text: the cliffbeside a mountain stream,” the house swings with the glen to align with the
label: Paragraph

text: stream, thus incorporating within its space the direction and sense of motion of the
label: Paragraph

text: body of water it overhangs. Within the space of the house, the dynamic quality of
label: Paragraph

text: this representation is perceived kinesthetically as an experience of virtual
label: Paragraph

text: movement.
label: Paragraph

text: The spatial definition of the interior of Fallingwater depends on lines generated
label: Paragraph

text: by implied diagonal axes. The main floor, entered at ground level, is approximately
label: Paragraph

text: 48 feet deep by 38 feet wide. Its flexible, open plan is loosely organized around a
label: Paragraph

text: central atrium-like space, illuminated from above by a large, nearly square,
label: Paragraph

text: recessed ceiling panel, which is supported at its four corners by stone piers. The
label: Caption

text: various functions are zoned into pockets of space that pinwheel around this open
label: Paragraph

text: core, sometimes overlapping and sometimes projecting from it. Just to the left of
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance is a seat with a built-in phonograph next to it. Beyond that is the sky-lit
label: Caption

text: area of the study, or library. Projecting between the two piers at the far side of the
label: Caption

text: room is a family sitting area that opens to the left and right onto outdoor terraces
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the stream. And just to the left of the fireplace is another built-in seat,
label: Paragraph

text: under the window, forming a more cozy sitting area next to the fire. To the right of
label: Paragraph

text: the fireplace and set back into the rear stone wall of the house is the dining area. On
label: Paragraph

text: one side it opens to the kitchen, and on the other to the stairway leading to the
label: Paragraph

text: upper-floor bedrooms.
label: Paragraph

text: The materials used inside are the same as those outside, an identity that is rein-
label: Paragraph

text: forced in two key places by the actual intrusion of an element from outside. The
label: Paragraph

text: walls and piers are stone; the ceiling, forming the underside of the upper slab, is
label: Paragraph

text: plastered and painted the same color as the parapets. The main, living-room floor is
label: Paragraph

text: covered in flagstones, similar in color and texture to the stones in the bed of the
label: Paragraph

text: stream. They are waxed, except for a single boulder that projects above floor level
label: Paragraph

text: to become the hearth of the fireplace. The visible surface is actually part of the
label: Paragraph

text: living rock of the streambed, the top of the easternmost boulder used in the foun-
label: Paragraph

text: dations of the house. As it emerges in its raw, natural state to form the base of the
label: Paragraph

text: living-room fireplace, its role in anchoring the composition is transformed from a
label: Paragraph

text: literal to a figurative one.
label: Paragraph

text: Diagonally opposite the fireplace, behind the library pier, is a second element
label: Paragraph

text: that works with the fireplace to determine the spatial shape and meaning of the
label: Paragraph

text: room by relating it directly to the natural world outside. This is a glass hatch, con-
label: Paragraph

text: tained by an external semicircular parapet under a trellis-skylight, that opens
label: Paragraph

text: through the floor and connects to a suspended stairway leading directly down
label: Paragraph

text: to the stream. Wright had thought that he could “deepen the stream for a swim-
label: Paragraph

text: ming pool” at this point. When that proved impossible, and a separate plunge pool
label: Paragraph

text: was created nearer to the road, the architect insisted on retaining the hatch and
label: Paragraph

text: stairs, admitting the originally intended use was perhaps only a pretext: “We
label: Paragraph

text: got down into the glen to associate directly with the stream and planned the house
label: Paragraph

text: for that association. Hence the steps from living room to stream.” “This feature,”
label: Paragraph

text: he told Kaufmann, was absolutely “necessary from every standpoint” and had to be
label: Paragraph

text: preserved no matter how or even if it was actually to be used."! Fireplace and hatch
label: Paragraph

text: each reveals, within the space of the living room, the direct association of the house
label: Paragraph

text: with its site. Taken together, as they were meant to be, they describe a cross-axial
label: Paragraph

text: diagonal line that traces the underlying geometric relation between building
label: Paragraph

text: and site.
label: Paragraph

text: The most dramatic, memorable, and well-known image of Fallingwater is the
label: Paragraph

text: view from the southwest, just below the first falls, where the house seems to rise
label: Paragraph

text: from the stream and float effortlessly over it. It is the view Wright chose for the
label: Paragraph

text: perspective he drew for Kaufmann as most fully representing the total effect of the
label: Paragraph

text: house in its site, as well as the one most often reproduced in photographs.” But, as
label: Paragraph

text: a representative image, it can be very deceptive, because this view does not actually
label: Paragraph

text: reveal itself until after one has seen the house, experienced its interior space, and
label: Paragraph

text: gone outside to look back at it. Like an inverted, baroque vol d’oiseau, the perspec-
label: Paragraph

text: tive is ideal and recapitulative, collapsing the disparate perceptions of experience
label: Paragraph

text: into one. To understand the house, then, one should not start with it, but end with
label: Paragraph

text: it, building toward it step by step.
label: Paragraph

text: Fallingwater as an Experience in Time and of Time
label: Title

text: Fallingwater is approached from a bridge that crosses the stream just above the two
label: Paragraph

text: falls. From it one can hear the sound of the falls but cannot see them. One senses a
label: Paragraph

text: drop-off beyond the house, but only the height of the trees and the depth of the sky
label: Paragraph

text: suggest this. The bridge abutments, which are constructed of the same thin ledges
label: Paragraph

text: of quarried stone as the house, blend into the stratified, natural stone walls of the
label: Paragraph

text: stream. Joining the house’s lower walls on the downstream side, they form a seam-
label: Paragraph

text: less transition between architecture and nature. The concrete span of the bridge, on
label: Paragraph

text: the other hand, is like the cantilevered trays of the house. Its softly rounded para-
label: Paragraph

text: pets effect a fluid connection between the stone piers of the banks, suggesting an
label: Paragraph

text: allusion to moving water. This dual reference was pointed out by the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: critic Lewis Mumford shortly after the house was completed. “The stones repre-
label: Paragraph

text: sent, as it were, the earth theme,” he wrote, “the concrete slabs are the water
label: Paragraph

text: theme.”
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond the bridge, the drive bends around the rear of the house and cuts
label: Paragraph

text: between it and the cliff, The horizontal lines of the building’s stone walls, which
label: Paragraph

text: are extended left and right into space by concrete beams and slabs, echo the strata
label: Paragraph

text: of stone ledges in the walls of the glen, while the rippling effect of the cliff is picked
label: Paragraph

text: up by the staggered vertical slots in the house’s rear wall. The passageway under-
label: Paragraph

text: neath the transverse beams that tie the house back into the cliff gives the impres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion of a natural cut shaded by an arbor-like trellis. Water can be seen seeping out
label: Paragraph

text: of the cliff face on the right. It also streams from a spout, in the pier next to the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance, into a small basin that functioned as a footbath. As you pass between
label: Paragraph

text: the stone walls of the loggia into the deep recess of the entry area, you hear the
label: Paragraph

text: water and feel its moisture. The transition from outside to inside is so orchestrated
label: Paragraph

text: as to seem like a gradual change in atmosphere rather than a change of place.
label: Paragraph

text: The gray-blue flagstone paving of the bridge and loggia continues into the house
label: Paragraph

text: to become the living-room floor. The only difference is that the flagstones inside
label: Paragraph

text: are waxed and polished to give them a shiny, reflective appearance. This causes the
label: Paragraph

text: eye to skim the surface quickly, following the line of the diagonal axis across the
label: Paragraph

text: room toward the light at the far side, which comes through the band of windows
label: Paragraph

text: and doors opening onto a terrace projecting over the ravine. The shiny surface of
label: Paragraph

text: the flagstone floor has a slippery look and feel that suggest the instability of the
label: Paragraph

text: moving water underfoot.'*
label: Paragraph

text: The reference to the stream below the floor is not merely metaphorical. It is
label: Paragraph

text: made real by the living rock of the boulder projecting through the floor as the fire-
label: Paragraph

text: place hearth and by the hatch that opens to reveal not only a view of the stream but
label: Paragraph

text: also the sound, smell, and moisture of the water rushing over the stream’s stone
label: Paragraph

text: bed. The visible water’s reflective surface reads as continuous in color, texture, and
label: Paragraph

text: substance with the waxed flagstone floor. The cool, damp air coming off the stream
label: Paragraph

text: is funneled through the hatch, while the steady burble resonates in the external
label: Paragraph

text: concrete wall of the chamber, which echoes, in its curve, the semi-cylindrical hol-
label: Paragraph

text: low of the fireplace.
label: Paragraph

text: The stream is brought into direct apposition with the living-room floor along the
label: Paragraph

text: room’s main diagonal axis, which, as already noted, parallels the ledge of the falls.
label: Paragraph

text: The polished flagstones reconstitute its rocky bed. Their uneven surface reflects the
label: Paragraph

text: constantly changing light that filters into the room through the trees. The irregular
label: Paragraph

text: outline of their raised joints recreates the stream’s swirling movement as it rounds
label: Paragraph

text: the bend before meeting the ledge. The connection to the stream is not a disem-
label: Paragraph

text: bodied, optical one. It is felt underfoot, through the body, and through all the
label: Paragraph

text: senses. The waxed floor imparts a sense of fluid motion to the body and suggests
label: Paragraph

text: the suspended animation of the drop of the waterfall from one level to the next.
label: Paragraph

text: Walking across the imaginary line connecting the projecting stone of the hearth to
label: Paragraph

text: the opening of the hatch, one is made aware of the changes in level that determine
label: Paragraph

text: the direction and flow of the water, and is thus subliminally induced to project
label: Paragraph

text: one’s thoughts beyond the space of the room. As the floor continues through
label: Paragraph

text: the plate-glass doors onto the southwest terrace, the dark flagstone plane turns
label: Paragraph

text: up into a rounded concrete parapet. In its light, airborne mass, this shape echoes
label: Paragraph

text: the color, texture, and trajectory of the cascade of white foam spilling over the rock
label: Paragraph

text: ledge just below it. One is left to imagine that the virtual pressure of water welling
label: Paragraph

text: up in the terrace is released in the overflow of the cantilever.
label: Paragraph

text: This returns us to Mumford’s perception of the concrete slabs and parapets as
label: Paragraph

text: representing the “water theme,” a perception that should be taken all the more
label: Paragraph

text: seriously given the critic’s acute understanding of Wright’s work and close per-
label: Paragraph

text: sonal relationship with him at the time. All the stone in the house, except for
label: Paragraph

text: the thin, waxed flagstones of the living-room floor, is treated as an inert, static
label: Paragraph

text: material, acting in compression — the “earth theme,” as Mumford noted. In vivid
label: Paragraph

text: contrast, the concrete is treated as fluid and dynamic, acting in tension. While the
label: Paragraph

text: deeply raked and randomly laid stone literally reproduces the eroded appearance of
label: Paragraph

text: the rear cliff face, the two terraces cantilevered over the falls, being broader in scale
label: Paragraph

text: and smoother in treatment than the stone walls, at first appear to echo the large
label: Paragraph

text: boulders in the streambed. But that is only an initial and partial impression. Their
label: Paragraph

text: rounded, fluid contours and light, insubstantial surfaces relate more to water than
label: Paragraph

text: to stone — not to a thin film of water as in the waxed flagstones, but to water aerated
label: Paragraph

text: and transformed into foam. The different directions in which these two main can-
label: Paragraph

text: tilevered terraces point correspond almost exactly with the relative disposition of
label: Paragraph

text: the two falls beneath them. Appearing to spill out from the stone masses to either
label: Paragraph

text: side of them like the falls between the banks of the stream, the two seemingly air-
label: Paragraph

text: borne trays effect changes in level that echo those in the stream. In its representa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the falling water, the house itself thus becomes a natural step in the descent
label: Paragraph

text: of Bear Run to the river.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright intended Fallingwater to represent nature in flux, to suggest the
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon of change over time. The architect’s decision to site the house
label: Paragraph

text: over the waterfall rather than facing it was critical and determined everything
label: Paragraph

text: about the perception and meaning of the house. It meant that the house, “designed
label: Paragraph

text: to the music of the stream” for “one who liked to listen to the waterfall,” would
label: Paragraph

text: offer an aural rather than a primarily visual experience of the falling water, an expe-
label: Paragraph

text: rience that, by its very nature, would be more time-consuming than instantaneous.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright privileged the aural over the visual and thereby gave precedence to the
label: Paragraph

text: continual over the momentary. Hearing takes time and gives to time a depth that
label: Paragraph

text: vision lacks. Where looking focuses on that which is present to the eye, listening
label: Paragraph

text: relies on expectation and is amplified through deferral. Hearing also blurs bound-
label: Paragraph

text: aries and distinctions and renders them fluid in contrast to vision, which specifies,
label: Paragraph

text: clarifies, and reduces the flux of nature to discrete, controllable, knowable entities.
label: Paragraph

text: It is thus not by chance but rather by design that the visitor to Fallingwater readily
label: Paragraph

text: conflates the concrete with water and the living-room floor with the streambed
label: Paragraph

text: beneath, just as it is by design that the view of the waterfalls is deferred until
label: Paragraph

text: one leaves the house to reflect back on it.
label: Paragraph

text: In the end it is the prolonged timeframe of listening and hearing that is the most
label: Paragraph

text: unusual and meaningful aspect of one’s experience of Fallingwater. The sound of
label: Paragraph

text: the rushing water and falls becomes perceptible as soon as one reaches the bridge
label: Paragraph

text: leading to the house. It does not stop when one enters the house. It underscores the
label: Paragraph

text: waxed flagstones of the floor to cause the element of moving water to pervade the
label: Paragraph

text: space of the living room. The echo chamber-like semicircular backing of the hatch
label: Paragraph

text: amplifies the sound as it makes it literally part of the room.’’ Hearing the water
label: Paragraph

text: constantly rushing underneath extends the kinesthetic experience of the con-
label: Paragraph

text: structed interior space into a temporal dimension that includes the entire physical
label: Paragraph

text: environment of which that space is a part. Through hearing, one imagines what
label: Paragraph

text: one might see, and it is this that gives Fallingwater a valence beyond the momen-
label: Paragraph

text: tary and the purely visual. Inside the space of the room, one already senses the
label: Paragraph

text: continuous and unending cycle of nature — of growth, movement, and change —
label: Paragraph

text: that the view of the house from below the falls ultimately confirms in the retro-
label: Paragraph

text: spective view it affords of the house’s place in the overall environment of Bear Run.
label: Paragraph

text: As an integral part of its natural environment, Fallingwater appears as mutable as
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape. It registers its effects and continually changes with the seasons. In the
label: Paragraph

text: fall, the autumn leaves bring out a burnished quality in the originally light ochre
label: Paragraph

text: color of the painted concrete, while the falls slowly diminish to a mere trickle as
label: Paragraph

text: winter comes along. In winter, when the ice takes over, the house itself seems to
label: Paragraph

text: become frozen in time, only to return to life, with a vengeance, with the early
label: Paragraph

text: spring rains. Such an engagement on the part of architecture with the elements
label: Paragraph

text: of nature is extraordinary and sets Fallingwater apart. To animate, activate, and
label: Paragraph

text: give life to buildings, architects have often used water in the form of fountains.
label: Paragraph

text: But while the water itself may be natural, the shape and movement imparted to
label: Paragraph

text: it are artificial and controlled. The liveliness is merely an illusion. More to the
label: Paragraph

text: point, the illusion, like that of a play, only lasts for a limited amount of time. Even-
label: Paragraph

text: tually, the fountain is turned off and all becomes static once again. As in the theater,
label: Paragraph

text: when the play ends and the lights come back on, the audience is made aware of the
label: Paragraph

text: gulf between art and reality — which is to say, art and life.
label: Paragraph

text: The extraordinary thing about Fallingwater is that the illusion, the spectacle, the
label: Paragraph

text: movement of water never stops. This may sound simplistic, but it is profound. Once
label: Paragraph

text: it gets dark, and especially after the lights in the house have been turned off, one
label: Paragraph

text: naturally expects the falls to be turned off as well — but they cannot be. Fallingwater
label: Paragraph

text: is continuous with the stream and waterfalls that preceded it and with the entire nat-
label: Paragraph

text: ural system that has grown up around them and takes its life from them. The expe-
label: Paragraph

text: rience of the house is an experience of time as duration. Wright liked to say that in his
label: Paragraph

text: own house, Taliesin, you could not easily “tell where pavements and walls left off
label: Paragraph

text: and ground began.”’° In Fallingwater, by contrast, you do not ask where the house
label: Paragraph

text: ends and the natural environment begins. Instead, you ask when — and the answer is
label: Paragraph

text: never. This finally is what gives the building its magic, its uniqueness, and its lasting
label: Paragraph

text: significance. The house is, as the architect Paul Rudolph once wrote, a “realized
label: Paragraph

text: dream.””” It is a palpable mental space where time both expands and contracts inde-
label: Paragraph

text: pendent of one’s volition and not always fully comprehensible to the conscious mind,
label: Paragraph

text: though always and inevitably in tune with natural laws.
label: Paragraph

text: DANTEUM
label: Title

text: Giuseppe Terragni
label: Title

text: Jonathan Mekinda
label: Title

text: Giuseppe Terragni, Danteum Paradiso, 1938. L’architettura 153 (July 1968): 251.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: The Danteum is one of the most enigmatic projects by one of the most enigmatic
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the twentieth century: Giuseppe Terragni.’ An organization dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to encouraging the study of Dante and promoting his work, the Danteum was the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of Rino Valdameri, the director of the Brera Academy of Fine Arts in Milan and
label: Paragraph

text: a leading literary and cultural figure in Italy during the 1930s. An ardent fascist and
label: Paragraph

text: a passionate champion of the poet, Valdameri conceived the new organization in
label: Paragraph

text: 1938; with the financial and political support of the Milanese industrial magnate
label: Paragraph

text: Count Alessandro Poss, he then approached Mussolini to secure official state
label: Paragraph

text: approval for the organization and support for the construction of its headquarters
label: Paragraph

text: in Rome. This effort was at first successful, and the two men met with Mussolini in
label: Paragraph

text: Rome on November 10, 1938 to discuss the project in more detail. After the meet-
label: Paragraph

text: ing, however, Valdameri struggled to sustain Mussolini’s interest in the project,
label: Paragraph

text: and with the start of the war in the fall of 1939 the plans for the Danteum were
label: Paragraph

text: officially put on hold. Valdameri’s untimely death in June 1943 brought an end
label: Paragraph

text: to the project.
label: Paragraph

text: Also in attendance at the meeting with Mussolini were the two architects that
label: Paragraph

text: Valdameri had commissioned to design the Danteum, Giuseppe Terragni and Pie-
label: Paragraph

text: tro Lingeri.” Terragni and Lingeri had a longstanding relationship with Valdameri
label: Paragraph

text: and a well-established professional partnership — together they had designed sev-
label: Paragraph

text: eral highly regarded buildings and participated in numerous state-sponsored com-
label: Paragraph

text: petitions.’ Likely the most important factor in their selection, however, was
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s leading position among Italian modernist architects.* Terragni’s prom-
label: Paragraph

text: inence was largely due to his passionate efforts to synthesize the principles of inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national modernism with the traditions and needs of fascist Italy, in particular the
label: Paragraph

text: demand for new forms of architectural expression that would effectively engage
label: Paragraph

text: the cultural ideology of Mussolini’s regime. Terragni was certainly not alone
label: Paragraph

text: among Italian modernists in devoting energy to this question, but with his Casa
label: Paragraph

text: del Fascio in Como, completed in 1936, he achieved a degree of renown that
label: Paragraph

text: few equaled. The Danteum was an ideal project for such an architect, and Valda-
label: Paragraph

text: meri commissioned Terragni and Lingeri well before the November meeting with
label: Paragraph

text: Mussolini, where the two architects presented a series of evocative drawings, many
label: Paragraph

text: with water-color washes.’ After the meeting, Terragni and Lingeri continued to
label: Paragraph

text: work on the project, producing additional drawings as well as a model and a writ-
label: Paragraph

text: ten “report” on their design, the “Relazione sul Danteum.”° The Danteum is known
label: Paragraph

text: today through that model and approximately 40 drawings and two albums of
label: Paragraph

text: photographs of drawings that are held in various archives; substantial portions
label: Paragraph

text: of the “Relazione sul Danteum” also remain.’
label: Paragraph

text: History
label: Title

text: In the statutes that he drafted for it, Valdameri explained the functions that the
label: Paragraph

text: Danteum was to perform: “A ‘Danteum’ is to be created in Rome: A National
label: Paragraph

text: Organization that proposes to erect, on the via dell’Impero, in this epoch, in which
label: Paragraph

text: the will and the genius of the Duce have realized the Imperial dream of Dante, a
label: Paragraph

text: Temple to the greatest of Italian poets. The Danteum is proposed to: carry out the
label: Paragraph

text: celebration of the words of Dante, considered a primary source for Mussolini’s
label: Paragraph

text: creations...
label: Paragraph

text: As these lines make clear, Valdameri conceived the Danteum to pro-
label: Paragraph

text: mote an understanding of the poet and his works that would emphasize their
label: Paragraph

text: direct and vital connection to the fascist present. In this view, Dante’s significance
label: Paragraph

text: rested not only on the beauty of his poetry, but also on his vision of Italian uni-
label: Paragraph

text: fication and imperial expansion rooted in Catholicism, a vision that was widely
label: Paragraph

text: understood during the fascist era as foretelling Mussolini's rise to power. This con-
label: Paragraph

text: ception of Dante as an avant-garde prophet of fascism, at once temporally distant
label: Paragraph

text: and spiritually intimate to the present, was also shared by Terragni and Lingeri.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, the two architects explicitly designed the Danteum both to commemorate
label: Paragraph

text: the poet and to illuminate the significance of his work as a prophecy of the fascist
label: Paragraph

text: empire.
label: Paragraph

text: The site in Rome chosen for the Danteum was an irregular trapezoid set in the
label: Paragraph

text: acute comer of the intersection of the Via Cavour and what is now the Via dei Fori
label: Paragraph

text: Imperiali. The longest side of the site fronted on to what was then the recently
label: Paragraph

text: constructed Via dell’Impero (Street of Empire). This broad avenue had been built
label: Paragraph

text: to link the Piazza Venezia with the Colosseum and to reveal the remnants of var-
label: Paragraph

text: ious ancient fora, which had been almost completely built over during the centu-
label: Paragraph

text: ries since their construction. The Via dell’Impero is one of the most striking
label: Paragraph

text: examples of the policy of sventramento (clearing out) implemented under Mussolini
label: Paragraph

text: that demolished large swaths of the modern city in order to uncover remnants of
label: Paragraph

text: the ancient city. In its willful destruction of anonymous medieval structures to
label: Paragraph

text: reveal more fully antique monuments and inscribe into the fabric of the city more
label: Paragraph

text: direct relationships between those monuments and the centers of fascist power,
label: Paragraph

text: this policy demonstrates the same attitude to history that inspired the Danteum.
label: Paragraph

text: In the view of Valdameri and other fascists, the value of the past was determined
label: Paragraph

text: primarily by the present to which it led, and that value was only made visible —
label: Paragraph

text: literally “abstracted” from history — with the passage of time.’ Terragni and Lingeri
label: Paragraph

text: evoked this attitude in their description of the ancient monuments crowded around
label: Paragraph

text: the site of the Danteum:
label: Paragraph

text: But here is the great revelation: The contingent pretext that, when they were built,
label: Paragraph

text: seemed the only reason and the only justification for their need (because it was the
label: Paragraph

text: most obvious) has disappeared, and what remains standing, with terrible mutilations,
