label: Paragraph

text: are stone blocks in which monumentality resides, transformed, through the funda-
label: Paragraph

text: mental laws of numerical or geometric harmony that bind spaces and volumes, solids
label: Paragraph

text: and voids, materials and colors.’°
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni and Lingeri were intensely interested in this rich context, which they
label: Paragraph

text: already knew well from their participation in the competition for the Palazzo del
label: Paragraph

text: Littorio in 1934. Planned as a new national headquarters for the fascist party, the
label: Paragraph

text: Palazzo del Littorio was conceived as a massive structure that would have fully
label: Paragraph

text: occupied the triangular site delineated by the Via Cavour, the Via dell’Impero,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Via del Colosseo, including the area later chosen for the Danteum. For that
label: Paragraph

text: competition, Terragni and Lingeri joined a larger team of artists and architects,
label: Paragraph

text: including Marcello Nizzoli and Mario Sironi, that produced two entries as the
label: Paragraph

text: Gruppo Milanese.'’ Their work on this project provided Terragni and Lingeri
label: Paragraph

text: the opportunity not only to study this section of Rome closely, but also to develop
label: Paragraph

text: a method of site analysis that embodied the fascist vision of history in its identifi-
label: Paragraph

text: cation and assertion of direct connections between ancient ruins, existing struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tures, and future programs. But while the 1934 competition yielded a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable range of entries, the program was eventually moved to another site
label: Paragraph

text: and the lot on the Via dell’Impero was left vacant.
label: Paragraph

text: Building on their experience with the Palazzo Littorio, Terragni and Lingeri pre-
label: Paragraph

text: pared a site plan, drawn at a scale of 1:2500, to situate the Danteum more precisely
label: Paragraph

text: within its context. Notably, and against convention, Terragni and Lingeri did not
label: Paragraph

text: depict existing structures on this plan. Instead, they included plans of the recently
label: Paragraph

text: uncovered fora and other ancient structures in the area, including the Basilica of
label: Paragraph

text: Maxentius and the Baths of Trajan, as well as other, more recent monuments such
label: Paragraph

text: as Michelangelo’s Campidoglio in order to illustrate what they described as an
label: Paragraph

text: “experimental field of eight centuries of concrete and documented architecture.”
label: Paragraph

text: Heightening the oddity of this quasi-archaeological plan, which shows the contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary street grid blending into the field of ancient structures, are two aerial photo-
label: Paragraph

text: graphs of the Via dell’Impero arrayed on the periphery of the sheet alongside two
label: Caption

text: illustrations of the Palace of King Sargon in Persia and the Temple Complex at Kar-
label: Caption

text: nak in Egypt. Together with the plan, these illustrations present an overview of the
label: Paragraph

text: site and reveal how the design of the Danteum was conceived in concert with his-
label: Paragraph

text: tory in order to establish connections across time and space that would not simply
label: Paragraph

text: legitimize the present, but power it toward a better future.’’
label: Paragraph

text: Rooms
label: Title

text: From the extant materials, it is possible to construct a view, albeit partial, of the
label: Paragraph

text: complex that Terragni and Lingeri designed. The proposed building is essentially
label: Paragraph

text: a golden-section rectangle in plan, oriented longitudinally east-to-west on its site
label: Paragraph

text: and with the primary facade facing south onto the Via dell’Impero. Upon closer
label: Paragraph

text: inspection, it becomes clear that the plan also comprises two equal but slightly
label: Paragraph

text: overlapping and offset squares, which largely define the interior spaces within
label: Paragraph

text: the primary rectangle. As Thomas Schumacher has noted, Le Corbusier's Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Stein at Garche of 1927 was likely a model for this “slipped rectangle” configura-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, but the architects identified the Basilica of Maxentius as the fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: inspiration for their design.’* Standing directly across the Via dell’Impero and
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular in plan, with an apse on its northern side, the Basilica not only embo-
label: Paragraph

text: dies the golden ratio that Terragni and Lingeri adopted for the Danteum, but the
label: Paragraph

text: length of its short ends determined the length of the long sides of the Danteum."? In
label: Paragraph

text: addition, the interior divisions of the Basilica demarcate two overlapping squares as
label: Paragraph

text: well as a series of smaller golden-section rectangles, motifs that also play a funda-
label: Paragraph

text: mental role in the organization of the Danteum.
label: Paragraph

text: For the architects, the adoption of the golden ratio and slipped-rectangle config-
label: Paragraph

text: uration was motivated by their rejection of symbolism and representation as the
label: Paragraph

text: means with which to “celebrate the words of Dante.” Instead, Terragni and Lingeri
label: Paragraph

text: deployed geometry and numerical logic to construct a sympathetic and harmoni-
label: Paragraph

text: ous resonance between the building and the ideas of the poet:
label: Paragraph

text: In our case the architecture could adhere to the literary work only through an exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ination of the admirable structure of the Divine Poem, itself faithful to a criterion of
label: Paragraph

text: division and interpretation through certain symbolic numbers: 1, 3, 7, 10 and their
label: Paragraph

text: combinations, which happily can be synthesized into one and three (unity and trinity).
label: Paragraph

text: Now, there is only one rectangle that clearly expresses the harmonic law of unity in
label: Paragraph

text: trinity, and this is the rectangle known historically as the “golden”: the rectangle, that
label: Paragraph

text: is, whose sides are in the golden ratio (the short side is to the long side as the long side
label: Paragraph

text: is to the sum of the two sides). One is the rectangle, three are the segments that deter-
label: Paragraph

text: mine the golden ratio.'®
label: Paragraph

text: Embracing the interplay between the perimeter rectangle and the two interlock-
label: Paragraph

text: ing squares, Terragni and Lingeri conceived the interior of the Danteum as four
label: Paragraph

text: primary spaces, with additional spaces interspersed uniformly between them.
label: Paragraph

text: All of these primary spaces are either squares or golden-section rectangles in plan,
label: Paragraph

text: and though in most cases these geometries would not have been visible to visitors,
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni and Lingeri felt that they would have been perceptible as pure, abstract
label: Paragraph

text: forms.’” Despite this regular arrangement, the interior is not divided into simple
label: Paragraph

text: uniform quadrants as the architects also took full advantage of the height of the
label: Paragraph

text: building to arrange the primary spaces in a sequence that varies both their horizon-
label: Paragraph

text: tal and vertical position with respect to one another.'* The result is a series of inter-
label: Paragraph

text: locking and interpenetrating spaces that articulate an ascending spiral through the
label: Paragraph

text: complex, echoing Dante’s own journey in The Divine Comedy.
label: Paragraph

text: After passing through the narrow entryway on the main facade, visitors would
label: Paragraph

text: enter a square, open courtyard occupying the south-west corner of the complex.
label: Paragraph

text: Across this courtyard, they would see an enclosed array of 100 densely-packed col-
label: Paragraph

text: umns, filling the north-west quadrant. (Some drawings for the project also show a
label: Paragraph

text: regular grid of thin members mounted in front of the columns as a display system.)
label: Paragraph

text: To enter the interior, visitors would pass through the columns and move into a
label: Paragraph

text: narrow corridor running laterally through the center of the complex.'” From this
label: Paragraph

text: corridor they could enter the library and study center, set slightly below the main
label: Paragraph

text: level in the north-east corner of the building, or move along its length back toward
label: Paragraph

text: the front facade in order to enter the room of Inferno in the south-east corner.”°
label: Caption

text: The room of Inferno contains seven columns, each a different diameter ranging
label: Paragraph

text: from 2.78 m to 0.48 m, arranged in a spiraling pattern determined by a series of
label: Paragraph

text: seven squares ranging in size from 17 m to 0.7 m on a side, inscribed on the floor.
label: Caption

text: The largest square, located next to the entry, was derived directly from the golden-
label: Paragraph

text: section rectangle that is the plan of the room, and the remaining squares follow this
label: Paragraph

text: logic, each derived from the next largest. The columns are positioned at the center
label: Paragraph

text: of these squares and support an identical arrangement of squares inscribed into the
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling, which was also to be incised so as to admit a dim light to the room. Oppres-
label: Caption

text: sive and heavy in its affect, the room deploys numerical logic, geometry, and scale
label: Paragraph

text: to evoke the descent into hell.
label: Paragraph

text: To enter the next room, Purgatory, visitors would cross the room of Inferno and
label: Paragraph

text: ascend a long, narrow staircase with three groups of three stairs squeezed into the
label: Paragraph

text: gap between the room of Inferno and the eastern exterior wall. The room of Pur-
label: Paragraph

text: gatory echoes the room of Inferno: a spiraling arrangement of seven squares would
label: Paragraph

text: lead visitors across the room and back toward the center of the complex. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: Inferno, however, Purgatory contains no columns and the squares are not inscribed
label: Paragraph

text: in a level floor but rather rise toward the exit, each square set slightly above the
label: Paragraph

text: larger square preceding it. Through this gentle ascent, the viewer would slowly rise
label: Paragraph

text: toward the passage to Paradise, located, as in the room of Inferno, across from the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance and in another gap between the overlapping and offset squares governing
label: Paragraph

text: the plan. Also like the room of Inferno, the room of Purgatory was to be lit from
label: Paragraph

text: above, but rather than narrow slits emitting a dim light the ceiling in Purgatory is
label: Paragraph

text: pierced with wide openings to allow sunlight to flood into the space. After the
label: Paragraph

text: heavy darkness of Inferno, the passage through Purgatory would lift the visitor
label: Paragraph

text: with its light-filled and dematerialized architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The rooms of Inferno and Purgatory show most clearly how Terragni and
label: Paragraph

text: Lingeri synthesized the architectural elements of geometry and scale with numer-
label: Paragraph

text: ical logic to establish abstract harmonies between two distinct “structures,” Dante’s
label: Paragraph

text: Divine Comedy and the Danteum itself. Unlike the rooms of Inferno and Purgatory,
label: Paragraph

text: the room of Paradise is not described in much detail in the existing portions of the
label: Paragraph

text: “Relazione”; the few extant drawings and plans, however, offer a captivating
label: Paragraph

text: glimpse of the architects’ vision for the space. The passage to Paradise consists
label: Paragraph

text: of another staircase with three flights of three stairs each, but shorter and narrower
label: Paragraph

text: than the passage from Inferno to Purgatory. At the top of the stairs, visitors would
label: Paragraph

text: find an open space, or antechamber, equal in size and orientation to the entry cor-
label: Paragraph

text: ridor on the main floor. Across this space, a square, gridded array of 33 glass col-
label: Paragraph

text: ummns demarcates Paradise. The use of glass produces shimmering columns of
label: Paragraph

text: breathtaking lightness, light-filled and light-weight. The sensation of lightness is
label: Paragraph

text: further emphasized by the thin trellis above, opening the room almost completely
label: Paragraph

text: to the sky, as well as the arrangement of the columns: 24 of the 33 columns demar-
label: Paragraph

text: cate three sides of square, while the remaining nine define another square at its
label: Paragraph

text: center. (The fourth side of the larger square is formed by the rear wall of the
label: Paragraph

text: complex.) Continuing their trajectory of dematerialization, Terragni and Lingeri
label: Paragraph

text: constructed in the room of Paradise an otherworldly environment in which sub-
label: Paragraph

text: stance and matter — the fundamental elements of architecture and of the world —
label: Paragraph

text: have been abandoned almost entirely.
label: Paragraph

text: As in the other major rooms of the Danteum, visitors would cross the room of
label: Paragraph

text: Paradise in order to exit it. There is an alternative, however: the room of Empire.
label: Paragraph

text: Stretching eastward from the antechamber before Paradise, the room of Empire
label: Paragraph

text: occupies the narrow slot between the golden-section rectangles of Inferno and Pur-
label: Paragraph

text: gatory below. For the architects, the room of Empire was the physical and spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: heart of the Danteum, the “germ of the architectural whole as the conclusion of the
label: Paragraph

text: experience of the spaces traversed.””' The design of the room embodies its impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tance: a row of 12 paired piers, with a single pier at its end, stretches down the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the room, leading to a monumental statue of an eagle (depicted with only
label: Paragraph

text: a rough sketch in the sole remaining drawing of the room). This is the only room in
label: Paragraph

text: the complex without a clear, direct path from entrance to exit and the visitor would
label: Paragraph

text: follow the piers to the monumental eagle and then double back in order to exit the
label: Paragraph

text: building. This pathway sets the room of Empire as the culmination of the visitor’s
label: Paragraph

text: spiraling journey, thereby proclaiming Dante’s stature as a prophet of Mussolini’s
label: Paragraph

text: rise and the formation of the fascist empire under his rule.””
label: Paragraph

text: The merging of Dante’s ideas and contemporary politics in the room of Empire
label: Title

text: confirms the Danteum’s function as an indoctrination “machine.” For Terragni,
label: Paragraph

text: Lingeri, and Valdameri, the purpose of the Danteum was not only to encourage
label: Paragraph

text: the study of the poet through its library and study center, but also to promote
label: Paragraph

text: an understanding of Dante that celebrated his vital and still constructive contribu-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to present-day life. Wielding the fundamental elements of architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: poetry, Terragni and Lingeri designed a complex that would literally carry visitors
label: Paragraph

text: through Dante’s vision to the culmination of history: the fascist empire. In the Dan-
label: Paragraph

text: teum, history is deployed alongside architecture and poetry as an abstract material,
label: Paragraph

text: stripped of its particularities and transformed into an “eternal” substance that bears
label: Paragraph

text: meaning only for the present that it helps to construct.
label: Paragraph

text: Walls
label: Title

text: For all of the richness of its interior, the Danteum would have revealed little to
label: Paragraph

text: passers-by on the Via dell’Impero. This aspect of the design is not only in keeping
label: Paragraph

text: with the architects’ rejection of symbolism and representation, but also reflects
label: Paragraph

text: their appreciation for the surrounding ruins and remnants, which they saw trans-
label: Paragraph

text: formed by the passage of time into pure, powerful forms. The most prominent
label: Paragraph

text: exterior element of the Danteum is a monumental wall of marble blocks that
label: Paragraph

text: the architects arranged in front of the facade, parallel to the Via dell’Impero. Stand-
label: Caption

text: ing approximately 16 m tall and stretching almost the entirely length of the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing, the wall would have separated the Danteum from the adjacent street and
label: Paragraph

text: obscured the main entryway. (A single pier of equal height to the wall stands
label: Caption

text: slightly apart at the western end, directly in front of the stairs leading down from
label: Caption

text: the exit from Paradise.) The wall was designed to act in several capacities: first, as a
label: Paragraph

text: counterpoint and equal to the massive wall of the Basilica of Maxentius, just across
label: Paragraph

text: the Via dell’Impero; second, as a plane to demarcate the view along the street
label: Paragraph

text: toward the monuments at either end; and third, as a mounting surface for a series
label: Paragraph

text: of shallow, sculptural panels, illustrating the cantos of The Divine Comedy.”
label: Paragraph

text: Based on the remaining drawings, the exterior of the Danteum was to be as flat
label: Paragraph

text: and opaque as the ante-wall, serving primarily to demarcate and protect the care-
label: Paragraph

text: fully calibrated ambience of the interior. (While the southern wall of the courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: is regularly punctuated by tall, narrow slits, all the other walls of the complex are
label: Paragraph

text: free of windows; light in the primary interior spaces was to be provided exclusively
label: Paragraph

text: by openings in the ceiling.) The walls themselves were to be constructed of stone
label: Paragraph

text: laid in a precise sequence that continued the numerical logic governing the interior
label: Paragraph

text: plan: three courses of regular stones with equal height would be followed by a
label: Paragraph

text: string course, and each string course would in turn correspond to an interior level
label: Paragraph

text: (either floor or ceiling). Through this masonry pattern, the architects aimed to
label: Paragraph

text: transform the numerical structure of The Divine Comedy into physical form once
label: Paragraph

text: again and literally “cement” it into the physical structure of the Danteum.
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond the reliefs on the ante-wall and the regular masonry pattern of the main
label: Caption

text: block, the Danteum is devoid of ornament and decoration. As a result, the building
label: Paragraph

text: appears in the drawings as a solid, massive block, equal in stature and substance to
label: Paragraph

text: the remnants of the ancient empire that surround it. While the bulk of the
label: Paragraph

text: Danteum sits comfortably within that context, when considered in light of
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s other work, the solidity and weightiness of the design is striking.
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni was an ardent fascist who devoted substantial energy to understanding
label: Paragraph

text: the philosophical structure of the revolutionary movement that he proclaimed.”*
label: Paragraph

text: As numerous scholars have pointed out, this engagement profoundly shaped
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s design of the Casa del Fascio in Como. Known chiefly for its open,
label: Paragraph

text: transparent facade and rich use of materials to generate visual and spatial effects
label: Paragraph

text: that evoke core tenets of fascism, the Casa del Fascio is a remarkable work that
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrates the deep intertwining of the tenets of international modernism with
label: Paragraph

text: t
label: Title

text: he ideals of fascism at the core of Italian rationalism.”
label: Paragraph

text: As different as it is from the Casa del Fascio, the Danteum is a more powerful
label: Paragraph

text: example of rationalist architecture; indeed, it highlights some of the most distinc-
label: Paragraph

text: tive elements of Italian modernism, which are effaced at the Casa del Fascio pre-
label: Paragraph

text: cisely because that building so neatly deploys the most familiar tropes of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The synthesis of architecture, poetry, and history at the Danteum was
label: Paragraph

text: fundamentally rooted in the way in which modern architects in Italy conceived the
label: Paragraph

text: possibilities of modernism. Terragni and Lingeri saw the abstract purity of geom-
label: Paragraph

text: etry and structure, matter and material as the foundation of all powerful architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and they recognized this lesson in the ancient ruins and monuments that
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded them. Furthermore, with the Danteum, the architects aimed explicitly
label: Paragraph

text: to rectify the failure of international modern architecture to articulate a new
label: Paragraph

text: approach to monumentality, an essential program for the fascist regime. The spare,
label: Paragraph

text: unbroken walls of the Danteum, towering over the Via dell’Impero, offer a pow-
label: Paragraph

text: erful vision for a modern monumentality that synthesizes abstraction and history,
label: Paragraph

text: modernism and fascism.
label: Paragraph

text: Notes
label: Title

text: * Image courtesy of the Ryerson and Burnham Libraries, Art Institute of Chicago.
label: Caption

text: 1. Ironically, much of the confusion about Terragni is the result of various campaigns to
label: Paragraph

text: celebrate his work. The effort of contemporary figures such as Peter Eisenman and
label: Paragraph

text: Daniel Libeskind to separate his architecture entirely from its context is just one exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ple, and Italian scholars such as Bruno Zevi, looking to cleanse modernism in Italy of the
label: Paragraph

text: taint of fascism, have also done much to complicate Terragni’s significance.
label: Paragraph

text: 2. The exact nature of the partnership between Terragni and Lingeri on the Danteum proj-
label: Caption

text: ect is still debated by architectural historians. The two architects had a longstanding
label: Paragraph

text: partnership and a substantial portion of the extant archival material relating to the proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect is held by the Lingeri family; nonetheless, the project is typically described as
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s alone. For two different treatments of the issue see Thomas L. Schumacher,
label: Paragraph

text: Terragni’s Danteum, 2nd ed. (New York: Princeton Architectural Press, 1996) and the
label: Caption

text: catalogue entry on the Danteum in Giorgio Ciucci, ed., Giuseppe Terragni: Opera Com-
label: Caption

text: pleta (Milan: Electa, 1996).
label: Caption

text: 3. Lingeri had studied under Valdameri at the Brera academy during the 1920s, and both
label: Caption

text: architects worked with him on a number of projects, including a never realized proposal
label: Paragraph

text: to renovate the Brera Academy, before the Danteum.
label: Paragraph

text: 4. Terragni had been a member of the Gruppo Sette (Group of Seven), which in 1926 and
label: Caption

text: 1927 issued the first calls for Italian architects to align themselves with the growing
label: Paragraph

text: international modern movement in architecture. In the years following, he
label: Paragraph

text: contributed to numerous conferences, exhibitions, and competitions within Italy
label: Paragraph

text: and without, realized several notable projects, including the Casa del Fascio in Como,
label: Paragraph

text: and established himself as a leading advocate for an intimate relationship between fas-
label: Paragraph

text: cism and modernism. The literature on Terragni is vast, but a good starting point is
label: Paragraph

text: Ciucci, Giuseppe Terragni.
label: Caption

text: 5. The letter that Valdameri sent to Mussolini’s secretary in October 1938 requesting a
label: Caption

text: meeting implies that the selection of Terragni and Lingeri for the Danteum had already
label: Paragraph

text: been approved by Mussolini. See Schumacher, Terragni’s Danteum, 154
label: Caption

text: 6. Giuseppe Terragni is widely accepted as the sole author of the “Relazione sul
label: Caption

text: Danteum,” the extant portions of which have been analyzed and translated by Thomas
label: Paragraph

text: Schumacher in Giuseppe Terragni, “Relazione sul Danteum,” in Schumacher, Terragni’s
label: Paragraph

text: Danteum, 127-49.
label: Caption

text: 7. The bulk of material is held at the Centro Studi Giuseppe Terragni in Como and the
label: Caption

text: Lingeri archive in Milan.
label: Caption

text: 8. Schumacher, Terragni’s Danteum, 153.
label: Caption

text: MAISON DU PEUPLE
label: Title

text: Jean Prouvé
label: Title

text: Anne Beim
label: Title

text: Jean Prouvé, Eugéne Beaudoin, Marcel Lods, and Vladimir Bodianski, Maison du Peuple,
label: Caption

text: Clichy, France, 1939.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: THE CRAFT OF INDUSTRIALIZED
label: Title

text: CONSTRUCTION
label: Title

text: Steel sheet, aluminum sheet ... will make for lighter construction, and this results in
label: Paragraph

text: economy as well as speed for execution and installation, quality in terms of the equip-
label: Paragraph

text: ment used, economy in terms of mass production, and a new dawn for the new archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture that will characterize our times.’
label: Paragraph

text: In light of Jean Prouvé’s vivid proclamation — although it was written 15 years
label: Paragraph

text: later than the progressive time period to which it refers — one might anticipate a
label: Paragraph

text: striking technological achievement when one searches for Maison du Peuple in the
label: Paragraph

text: streets of Clichy, a working-class district in the north-west of Paris. Yet, what is
label: Paragraph

text: portrayed in most general histories of architecture is something less inspiring:
label: Paragraph

text: black-and-white photographs portray the building during its period of construction
label: Paragraph

text: from 1935 to 1939, or immediately after its completion, when it was not yet in use
label: Paragraph

text: and the streets were still free of the commotion caused by today’s endless small
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian cars.” These images show what appears to be a pragmatic, grave, and
label: Paragraph

text: opaque structure made of steel and glass that is characterized by its limited number
label: Paragraph

text: of different material components and its blunt design features.
label: Paragraph

text: Viewed again and more closely, the building is striking. Remarkable glass awn-
label: Paragraph

text: ings that mime outstretched wings cover the wide sidewalks and divide the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing horizontally into two halves: an elevated upper part primarily covered with
label: Paragraph

text: glass panels held by slender vertical mullions that reach from the level of the awn-
label: Paragraph

text: ings to the roof edge — emphasizing the grand height of the upper floor of the
label: Paragraph

text: building — and a lower part at ground level that is accessible directly from the street,
label: Paragraph

text: offering market activities the ability to spread across the edges of the building struc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture. But the images do not leave a clear sense ofa public building complex that was
label: Paragraph

text: meant to serve social gatherings and cultural events. The main impression is a con-
label: Paragraph

text: spicuous structure stripped bare, to its very essence one might say. It has the
label: Paragraph

text: appearance of a rather rational and functionally optimized shelter for large group
label: Paragraph

text: activities, expressing a “machine aesthetics.” All of this is emphasized by the indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trialized components of the construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, when the Maison du Peuple de Clichy is approached from Boulevard du
label: Paragraph

text: Général Leclere (former Rue de Lorraine) one finds a building structure that —
label: Paragraph

text: despite its clear-cut box shape of roughly three to four stories — appears surprisingly
label: Paragraph

text: delicate, due to its relatively small size in terms of scale and the clarity of the detail-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. The Maison du Peuple de Clichy has an elegant simplicity that results from
label: Paragraph

text: the soft, monotone reflection of the light-gray sheet metal, the steady repetition
label: Paragraph

text: of the slender mullions, and the elongated glass panels of the upper floor that mir-
label: Paragraph

text: ror the neighboring buildings. A balanced mix of refined details and crude struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural elements, in particular the significant slanting glass awnings that are mounted
label: Paragraph

text: on all sides, provide the building with a combined sense of materialized lightness
label: Paragraph

text: and blunt appearance. In addition to this, you might see groups of people who have
label: Paragraph

text: casually set up a small, spontaneous flea market in one of the corners of the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. The double-leaf glass doors to the present food market may have been pushed
label: Paragraph

text: open, as an invitation to passing pedestrians to enter or walk through the covered
label: Paragraph

text: market. Today the entrance to the community hall is blocked due to ongoing res-
label: Paragraph

text: toration and posters have been stuck on the glass doors declaring that the building
label: Paragraph

text: is now listed as a “monument historique.”’ A lengthy text explains that the final part of
label: Paragraph

text: the restoration is still to be carried out on the interior, including mechanical parti-
label: Paragraph

text: tions and movable floor elements, as well as the roof construction, and that further
label: Paragraph

text: funding is needed for this.
label: Paragraph

text: In the study that follows, both cultural concerns and technical matters of con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction will be kept in view. This double focus follows the arguments set forth
label: Paragraph

text: in Prouvé’s paper, “Sheet metals and welding,” presented to the Société des ingé-
label: Paragraph

text: nieurs soudeurs on January 19, 1950.* Prouvé’s arguments will not only help me
label: Paragraph

text: explain the Maison du Peuple de Clichy’s founding ideas, but also its construction
label: Paragraph

text: and inspiring outcome. Yet my basic aim is to elucidate how human aspirations are
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilled when rare qualities of craftsmanship are transformed into a refined culture
label: Paragraph

text: of industrialized production. I believe this is what happened in the work of the arti-
label: Paragraph

text: san, constructeur,’ and manufacturer, Jean Prouvé.
label: Paragraph

text: Building for the People
label: Title

text: In the period between 1930 and 1935...architecture was not very exciting. It was no
label: Paragraph

text: longer in tune with everything else in life. It was meeting with bold architects who
label: Paragraph

text: were just as committed and concerned in their research as we were in ours, that
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in the first designs...entirely built in the factory using sheet steel. Shortly
label: Paragraph

text: thereafter, we designed and built the covered market at Clichy.®
label: Paragraph

text: Maison du Peuple was designed and built for the municipality of Clichy-la-
label: Paragraph

text: Garenne on the initiative of the Mayor Charles Auffray (1887-1957), a left-wing
label: Paragraph

text: politician and member of Front Populaire. The building was the outcome of a
label: Paragraph

text: call to design a modern administration building for the city council combined
label: Paragraph

text: with a covering roof for an existing open-air market located in the heart of
label: Paragraph

text: Clichy.”
label: Paragraph

text: The area was dominated by industry at the time, and the Citroen foundry® —a
label: Paragraph

text: huge, widespread manufacturing complex — was a close neighbor to the market
label: Paragraph

text: site. Here, primarily motor parts were produced inter alia for the “peoples car,”
label: Paragraph

text: the sparse, utilitarian and affordable 2CV, conceived in 1936. The Bic factory
label: Paragraph

text: was also located in the area, producing ballpoints and pocket lighters that were
label: Paragraph

text: efficient substitutes for the fountain pens and matchboxes of former times. These
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturing units mass produced useful commodities for daily life that also
label: Paragraph

text: evoked the spirit of modern living — expressions of the desire for convenience,
label: Paragraph

text: consumerism, and prosperity. Naturally, these industries left a mark on the urban
label: Paragraph

text: fabric, but it also influenced the demographic structure of this part of the city where
label: Paragraph

text: a growing population of well-paid industrial workers wanted facilities that offered
label: Paragraph

text: social and cultural activities.
label: Paragraph

text: The designers who collaborated on the building — architects Eugéne Beaudoin
label: Paragraph

text: (1898-1983) and Marcel Lods (1891-1978), engineer Vladimir Bodianski
label: Paragraph

text: (1894-1966), and constructeur Jean Prouvé — read this particular cultural setting
label: Paragraph

text: clearly and put forward an innovative idea: making maximum use of the site by
label: Paragraph

text: adding more functional elements than conceived in the original program by the
label: Paragraph

text: municipality and by proposing a large-span, flexible steel structure.’ The design
label: Paragraph

text: proposal offered a multi-purpose spatial frame, which could serve as a cultural cen-
label: Paragraph

text: ter that included a market (preferably larger than the existing one), a film theatre
label: Paragraph

text: seating roughly 700 people, a community hall spread across several floors and capa-
label: Paragraph

text: ble of accommodating 1,500-2,000 people, and a number of offices for the local city
label: Paragraph

text: council and labor unions.'° It was conceived as a genuine “House for the People” —
label: Paragraph

text: a tribute to the collective spirit of ordinary men, demonstrating the most advanced
label: Paragraph

text: technical solutions to be applied in construction, based on the rationale of “up-to-
label: Paragraph

text: date industrialized production.”
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, it grew out of an already well-established institution of Maisons du Peuple,
label: Paragraph

text: which had been fostered by a self-confident growing workers’ movement, and
label: Paragraph

text: houses for these organizations had been designed and built around the turn of
label: Paragraph

text: the twentieth century in a number of European cities. The Maisons du Peuple
label: Paragraph

text: were initially meant to host community activities associated with the labor unions
label: Paragraph

text: and their political groupings; in the course of time, however, these cultural envir-
label: Paragraph

text: onments for the common man were influenced by left-wing intellectuals and
label: Paragraph

text: artists, in particular members of the art nouveau movement,'’ who were attracted
label: Paragraph

text: to the idea of the enlightened worker and the authenticity found in crafts done
label: Paragraph

text: by hand.”
label: Paragraph

text: Well-known examples are the Maison du Peuple de Bruxelles, built in 1896-99
label: Paragraph

text: and demolished in 1965, designed by the Belgian architect Victor Horta
label: Paragraph

text: (1861-1947), and the Maison du Peuple de Nancy, built in 1902 and designed
label: Paragraph

text: by the French architects Paul Charbonnier (1865-1953) and Eugéne Vallin
label: Paragraph

text: (1856-1922). The design of the latter included contributions from the sculptor
label: Paragraph

text: and painter Victor Prouvé (1858-1944), the father of Jean Prouvé. For this building
label: Caption

text: he had sculptured the decorations of the stone facades. Yet, in Nancy, Victor
label: Paragraph

text: Prouvé was better known for his affiliation with the Ecole de Nancy’’ out of which
label: Paragraph

text: the art nouveau movement grew. Being a central figure, he was a vital agitator of
label: Paragraph

text: the linkage between the making of artwork and industrial production.’*
label: Paragraph

text: Two basic architectural ideas guided the development of these early Maisons
label: Paragraph

text: du Peuple: the means by which industrial manufacture could aid the progress of
label: Paragraph

text: skillful craftsmanship, and the ways buildings could be enriched by established
label: Paragraph

text: fine arts traditions in order to reach a contemporary architectural expression that
label: Paragraph

text: cherished both structural expression and ornament. The ideas that had force in
label: Paragraph

text: the design of the Maison du Peuple de Clichy were related but different. First,
label: Paragraph

text: there was a serious concern for the deeds of ordinary people, their everyday con-
label: Paragraph

text: cerns and practical lives. Second, there was the conversion of deep-rooted craft
label: Paragraph

text: traditions into industrialized manufacture. These two ideas matured into expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sions of the essentials of modern industrialized culture. Evidence of this type of
label: Paragraph

text: expression — unlike anything found in the earlier Maisons — is the subtle use of the
label: Paragraph

text: colors red and yellow for selected building elements, which could supplement
label: Paragraph

text: the metal gray of the bare metal. Recent commentators have suggested refer-
label: Paragraph

text: ences to the color schemes of the Russian constructivists and the workers’
label: Paragraph

text: movement.'”
label: Paragraph

text: In sum, several factors determined the uniqueness of this solution to the “Peo-
label: Paragraph

text: ple’s House” design problem: the integration of various programmatic aspects that
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged social, cultural, and political activities, the flexibility of the spatial
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement and adaptable construction features, and finally the preference for
label: Paragraph

text: unconventional materials such as steel plate and glass (mostly used in industrial
label: Paragraph

text: architecture). When finished in 1940 it was the first of a new kind of Maisons
label: Paragraph

text: du Peuple.
label: Paragraph

text: Structural Ambitions, Playful Mechanics
label: Title

text: and Honest Functioning
label: Title

text: For the architects and for us, it [the factory built design of sheet metal] was an oppor-
label: Paragraph

text: tunity to apply our ideas in an absolute sense, without the least restriction, especially
label: Paragraph

text: in terms of shape. With a new technique, new way of modeling; no camouflage, no
label: Paragraph

text: lies, no deception.'*
label: Paragraph

text: The site meant for the Maison du Peuple de Clichy-la-Garenne was relatively
label: Paragraph

text: small compared to the ambitions of the extended program. It measured 40 x 50
label: Paragraph

text: meters, and the proposed building structure was designed in such a way that
label: Paragraph

text: the street market could keep its original size, filling out the space located between
label: Paragraph

text: four streets: Rue Martissot, Rue Morilion, Rue Kloch, and Boulevard de Lorraine
label: Paragraph

text: (now Boulevard du Général Leclerc). In the new scheme the market area still had
label: Paragraph

text: priority and was planned to be accessible from all sides of the building. Each of the
label: Paragraph

text: four facades was designed with a number of centered, wide, double-leaf glass doors
label: Paragraph

text: that corresponded to the layout of the opposite facade. In each corner of the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing, wide stairways were placed to serve the community hall and the offices.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the architectural design did not tend to celebrate one facade over the
label: Paragraph

text: other, the main entrance to the covered market and the community hall faced
label: Paragraph

text: the main street Boulevard de Lorraine. Above this hung a wide balcony that
label: Paragraph

text: was cleverly integrated in the construction features of the awning. It offered visitors
label: Paragraph

text: the opportunity to step out to enjoy some fresh air during intermissions, or to fol-
label: Paragraph

text: low the activities of local festivals or political gatherings in the streets. Opposite the
label: Paragraph

text: main entrance the office spaces were placed in a taller, closed part of the four-story
label: Paragraph

text: building. It looked like a “backrest,” shaped like an elevated box, allowing free
label: Paragraph

text: access to the covered market but also offering a view across the building’s roo
label: Paragraph

text: scape and a glance down into the cinema hall when the huge skylights were rolled
label: Paragraph

text: aside.
label: Paragraph

text: Due to the need for large spans, in order to keep the floors free of too many load
label: Paragraph

text: bearing columns or walls, the main supporting structure was conceived as a mod
label: Paragraph

text: ular frame system. This type of structure allowed for sizeable parts of the interior
label: Paragraph

text: walls and the exterior envelope to remain unobstructed and to be used for movable
label: Paragraph

text: partition walls, fenestration, or door openings. The structural principle was non.
label: Paragraph

text: load-bearing facades hung on a load-bearing structural frame — a true curtain-wall
label: Paragraph

text: system — which incorporated panels with and without windows, the great glazed
label: Paragraph

text: facades and the awnings. Even though curtain-wall construction was known as
label: Paragraph

text: early as the late nineteenth century, used, for example in the Reliance Building
label: Paragraph

text: in Chicago,’” and Jean Prouvé previously had designed a prefabricated building
label: Paragraph

text: system based on similar principles for the Aéro-Club Roland-Garros at Buc in
label: Paragraph

text: 1935,'* the curtain-wall construction of Maison du Peuple de Clichy was the first
label: Paragraph

text: of its kind in France.’”
label: Paragraph

text: In the first design proposals Jean Prouvé suggested a modular system of folded
label: Paragraph

text: steel sheets for the entire building, which also included the load-bearing structure.
label: Paragraph

text: The idea was to minimize the number of parts and different materials, and to sim-
label: Paragraph

text: plify and thereby optimize the construction procedure in order to keep to a small
label: Paragraph

text: budget.” However, for reasons of safety, in the final project the chief engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Bodiansky, altered the load-bearing structure of folded steel sheets into Vierendeel
label: Paragraph

text: trusses of rolled steel.”"
label: Paragraph

text: The heavy load-bearing structure, the mobile slab, and roof elements were
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Bodiansky and fabricated by the firm Schwartz-Haumont. All the other
label: Paragraph

text: construction features — the facade panel systems, staircases, sanitary units, move-
label: Paragraph

text: able and operable partitions, and furniture — were designed and manufactured by
label: Paragraph

text: Jean Prouvé in his workshop.” According to Prouvé, he and his employees
label: Paragraph

text: designed most of the building and were responsible also for the execution of
label: Paragraph

text: the construction and the mechanical features, yet he always named Beaudoin
label: Paragraph

text: and Lods as the architects of the building.”’
label: Paragraph

text: Asa structural typology, the Maison du Peuple de Clichy can be compared to the
label: Paragraph

text: covered markets built in European cities through the nineteenth century. In par-
label: Paragraph

text: ticular there are parallels to the original central market of Paris, Les Halles, con-
label: Paragraph

text: structed in the 1850s,’* which consisted of spacious, open frame structures
label: Paragraph

text: made of cast iron columns and girders with a majority of glass infill and wooden
label: Paragraph

text: elements.” Lightweight awnings of stretched canvas were mounted along the
label: Paragraph

text: facades of Les Halles to offer the traders shelter from the weather. Similar to
label: Paragraph

text: the glass awnings of the Maison du Peuple de Clichy, they give the advantage
label: Paragraph

text: of scaling down the appearance of the building, and more importantly they create
label: Paragraph

text: a smooth transition between the interior space and the outdoor areas around the
label: Paragraph

text: building, in terms of both extending the market space and how the urban context
label: Paragraph

text: is met.
label: Paragraph

text: Since street markets traditionally take place in the morning, and meetings,
label: Paragraph

text: dance, and film-shows in the evening, the Maison du Peuple de Clichy was required
label: Paragraph

text: to fulfill different programmatic purposes at different times of the day. The market
label: Paragraph

text: activities could spread out on the covered sidewalks and up stairs to the first floor
label: Paragraph

text: galleries, which spatially could be connected to the market area by opening the
label: Paragraph

text: center part of the deck. This was made of modular floor elements extending side
label: Paragraph

text: by side from the wall of the Boulevard de Lorraine frontage to the very back of the
label: Paragraph

text: building. With the push of a button, seven movable floor elements, each measuring
label: Paragraph

text: 17.5 x 5.4 meters and weighing 16 tons with fixed rows of chairs, would slip aside
label: Paragraph

text: toward the back of the room where they were elevated and stacked above the
label: Paragraph

text: stage. The two handrails along the edge of the longitudinal galleries were hidden
label: Paragraph

text: inside the floor construction.”®
label: Paragraph

text: When another button is pressed, two large skylights, made of two bays of
label: Paragraph

text: metal trusses covered with textured cathedral glass, were pushed aside and pro-
label: Paragraph

text: vided access to fresh air and a view of the sky. When the community hall was
label: Paragraph

text: needed for gatherings or film-shows the deck was restored, creating a more or
label: Paragraph

text: less box-shaped hall 40 meters long with the option of having the roof closed or
label: Paragraph

text: opened for ventilation. The mechanical maneuvers for changing this setting
label: Paragraph

text: would take about 45 minutes altogether. The third movable or mechanical fea-
label: Paragraph

text: ture was a suspended wall system, which could close off part of the community
label: Paragraph

text: hall from the surrounding galleries and thereby provide an enclosed space for
label: Paragraph

text: the film theatre. This modular wall system comprised a total of 60 panes.
label: Paragraph

text: The panes measured approximately 1 x 7 meters and were made of thin metal
label: Paragraph

text: frames clad with sheet metal at the bottom (up to 2 meters). Above they were
label: Paragraph

text: covered with stretched raphan fabric and filled with mineral wool for acoustical
label: Paragraph

text: reasons.”” The fixed ceiling panels were similarly designed to hold additional
label: Paragraph

text: performative properties and had incorporated an advanced steam heating sys-
label: Paragraph

text: tem that was intended to provide a moderate temperature by heat radiation
label: Paragraph

text: from the panes.
label: Paragraph

text: Jean Prouvé was particularly concerned with the operable partitions, which
label: Paragraph

text: had “flexible and articulated joints” that gave a delicate finish to the partition wall.
label: Paragraph

text: n 1931 his workshop already had patented movable metal partitions. By 1933
label: Paragraph

text: they designed and manufactured operable partitions for the town hall of
label: Paragraph

text: Boulogne-Billancourt. In the Maison du Peuple de Clichy, however, numerous
label: Paragraph

text: design proposals and the testing of prototypes allowed the technical accuracy
label: Paragraph

text: and the elegance of the detailing to mature.** The way in which the structural
label: Paragraph

text: principles, the spatial (thereby programmatic) flexibility offered by movable
label: Paragraph

text: construction systems, and the performative aspects in terms of accessibility,
label: Paragraph

text: ventilation, acoustics, and heating were conceived as integrated and realized
label: Paragraph

text: by inventive skill can be seen as the great tectonic achievement of the Maison
label: Paragraph

text: du Peuple de Clichy.
label: Caption

text: Material Nature and Craftsmanship — A Credo of
label: Paragraph

text: Industrialized Construction
label: Title

text: ...it seemed to me that the possibilities afforded by steel sheet were limitless: after
label: Paragraph

text: cutting, it could be formed, rolled, beaten to create profiles, each perfectly adapted to
label: Paragraph

text: whatever use, from the rectilinear to the most elaborately shaped and curved. Adopt-
label: Paragraph

text: ing this technique, it resulted in an abundance of ideas, designs, constructions, mod-
label: Paragraph

text: els, prototypes, structures or coachwork for airplane wings in all varieties of steel,
label: Paragraph

text: including stainless steel.”
label: Paragraph

text: Prouvé was brought up in an environment permeated by craft traditions and art,
label: Paragraph

text: and throughout his life he spent most of his time in the workshop surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: workmen, and with metal, tools, and machines in his hands. Trained as a black-
label: Paragraph

text: smith and wrought iron craftsman, he was extremely experienced in the material
label: Paragraph

text: properties of metals, and he continued studying by experimenting with the latest
label: Paragraph

text: technology, tools, and ways to use them in his lifelong dedicated work to pushing
label: Paragraph

text: the limits of construction technologies. For these reasons Prouvé was naturally
label: Paragraph

text: interested in the design and technologies that evolved in other fields, such as
label: Paragraph

text: the aerospace and the car industry; they were, he thought, similar ways of thinking
label: Paragraph

text: about efficiency, lightweight structures, and prefabricated systems based on kits
label: Paragraph

text: of parts.
label: Paragraph

text: He was also inspired and influenced by the people with whom he worked, from
label: Paragraph

text: the skilled craftsman in his workshop to visionary architects or clients. Prouvé often
label: Paragraph

text: spoke about the need for sharing the same ideas when working on a project and the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of collaborative work, and how architecture in particular was depend-
label: Paragraph

text: ent on this understanding. He saw the Maison du Peuple de Clichy as proof of this
label: Paragraph

text: collective spirit where men with different skills and expertise were all equal’’ and
label: Paragraph

text: shared the same goals.”?
label: Paragraph

text: Prouvé recognized that the new types of methods for steel construction pro-
label: Paragraph

text: vided the buildings with a distinct architectural character of their own; they were
label: Paragraph

text: elegant and dynamic, and presented the true characteristics of industrialized con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction. Yet, he was concerned about avoiding depersonalization provided by
label: Paragraph

text: technology and he brought a human dimension into his designs through the con-
label: Paragraph

text: sideration of scale and detailing. Prouvé presented this understanding in a conver-
label: Paragraph

text: sation with Jean-Marie Helwig in 1982 about the Maison du Peuple de Clichy. He
label: Paragraph

text: explained how critical attention to the properties of the steel material, technical
label: Paragraph

text: ingenuity, and understanding of execution was embedded in the design of the cur-
label: Paragraph

text: tain-wall panels:
label: Caption

text: This panel was put in place by a single man, was hung on like hanging an overcoat on
label: Paragraph

text: a coat-peg... The hanging systems had a device for adjusting the vertical hang of the
label: Paragraph

text: joints... This alignment was achieved by an adjustment device on each panel hook. It
label: Paragraph

text: worked down to the last millimeter, micrometer you might say, so the result was
label: Paragraph

text: perfect... The section of the joint was very carefully worked. It seems quite simple
label: Paragraph

text: but needed a lot of thought. You can see on the outside the panels are not joined,
label: Paragraph

text: there is a gap between the two panels. The reason for the gap: maintenance. ..It was
label: Paragraph

text: also necessary to consider the expansion of these panels, which are independent of
label: Paragraph

text: each other. At 4m high and 1m wide, they change in the heat or the cold. It’s impos-
label: Paragraph

text: sible to imagine a joint that could survive such alteration in size. So this was the trick:
label: Paragraph

text: by folding we made a rebate which is a hollow grove, at the bottom of which we fixed
label: Paragraph

text: between the two panels a strip of asphalt... Then we decided that it was absolutely
label: Paragraph

text: necessary to find a flexible joint that stays compressed in all weathers... You can see
label: Paragraph

text: the purity we achieved by using a sheet of metal. There was a real possibility of large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale serial industrial production, components that would have made possible the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of very varied buildings.”
label: Paragraph

text: It is evident that Prouvé’s commitment to evolve architectural form both from
label: Paragraph

text: systems of fabrication and from the expression of construction principles placed
label: Paragraph

text: him in a structural-_rationalist linage running back to Viollet-le-Duc. In Viollet-
label: Paragraph

text: le-Due’s lecture XIII, concerning “The Construction of Buildings,” Viollet offered
label: Paragraph

text: the following proclamation (referring to the use of cast iron in construction):
label: Paragraph

text: “Forms proper to the nature of the materials employed may not have been discov-
label: Paragraph

text: ered in a single day, or by a single artist, even though a man of genius; but it is
label: Paragraph

text: desirable to begin. For in architecture a true and rational form reveals itself only
label: Paragraph

text: after a series of efforts and trials methodically conducted.””’
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, Prouvé had an artisanal side to his work, which he obviously had
label: Paragraph

text: inherited from growing up in an art environment influenced by the ideas of art
label: Paragraph

text: nouveau. The glass awnings of the Maison du Peuple de Clichy may serve as
label: Paragraph

text: an illustration. Although the awnings were conceived as functional and rational
label: Paragraph

text: building elements without any superfluous ornamental features, they hold similar
label: Paragraph

text: tectonic principles to the elaborate glass-covered entrances of the Parisian Métro
label: Paragraph

text: designed by the art nouveau architect Hector Guimard (1867-1942). Guimard’s
label: Paragraph

text: Métro entrances, designed and built from 1902 to 1913, were the outcome of a
label: Paragraph

text: mass-produced building system. Forged iron was used to create various kinds of
label: Paragraph

text: arches and furnishings in nature-inspired forms. The roofed entrances, known
label: Paragraph

text: as édicules,’* of which Porte Dauphine is one of the finest examples, included
label: Paragraph

text: prominent, fan-shaped, frosted glass awnings, much smaller but comparable to
label: Paragraph

text: the glass awnings of the Maison du Peuple de Clichy. Despite the ornate character,
label: Paragraph

text: these forms were also tightly constrained by functional discipline and by a ration-
label: Paragraph

text: alist tendency to express material properties through structural details.””
label: Paragraph

text: Prouvé’s pioneering work of the 1930s, which included furniture, metal struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tures, cladding systems,”° and service units, culminated in the various building
label: Paragraph

text: components and prefabricated prototype systems developed for the Maison du
label: Paragraph

text: Peuple de Clichy. After World War II, Prouvé continued to design and manufac-
label: Paragraph

text: ture numerous prototypes for the mass production of everyday objects and build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing constructions.*”” These products and systems were first executed in his own
label: Paragraph

text: factory in Maxville** and later as a consultant for Compagnie industrielle de material
label: Paragraph

text: de transport (CIMT), which was known for the fabrication of trains. In his position as
label: Paragraph

text: chair at Conservatoire national des arts et métiers (CNAM) in Paris, Prouvé had great
label: Paragraph

text: influence on a generation of architects and engineers, who studied and cultivated
label: Paragraph

text: the opportunities rooted in technology. Moreover, as head of the jury for the com-
label: Paragraph

text: petition of the Pompidou Centre in 1971, Prouvé was the driving force behind the
label: Paragraph

text: decision of appointing the young architects, Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers. This
label: Paragraph

text: project, as a contemporary “House of the People” with its machine aesthetics,
label: Paragraph

text: showed a similar desire to integrate the urban environment, social life, and the
label: Paragraph

text: new technology. The construction was particularly interesting because it presented
label: Paragraph

text: the first metal structures made of cast steel; a sort of metal that unites the strength
label: Paragraph

text: of the steel with the formability of the cast iron. Curtain-wall construction was also
label: Paragraph

text: developed further by placing the load-bearing superstructure outside the cladding,
label: Paragraph

text: leaving space for stairs, lifts, and services within the external structure.”?
label: Paragraph

text: Ata time when Le Corbusier’s dense, sculptural buildings in reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: were dominating another side of French architecture, Prouvé offered an alternative
label: Paragraph

text: route of exclusive metal carpentry and a true industrialized construction that
label: Paragraph

text: served architecture.*° The effect of this lingered on and manifested itself in the steel
label: Paragraph

text: and glass architecture of the 1980s in France.*' Similar ideas can be seen in contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary work by Lacaton & Vassal, who use industrialized systems off the shelves to
label: Paragraph

text: create quality space, despite low budgets.
label: Paragraph

text: In the development of the architectural design, construction, and manufacturing
label: Paragraph

text: of the Maison du Peuple de Clichy, Prouvé was far ahead of his time. Similar to
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary industrialized construction, which through computerized design
label: Paragraph

text: and manufacture seeks to overcome the limitations of mechanized fabrication
label: Paragraph

text: and rigid standardization, he anticipated a post-Fordian industry that can be char-
label: Paragraph

text: acterized as third-generation industrialization. However, his practical experiments
label: Paragraph

text: were based on the intelligence of the worker and the culture of enterprise, and not
label: Paragraph

text: on removing skill from the work force.*” He believed in an industry of the work
label: Paragraph

text: collective instead of piecemeal work, and tailor-made production instead of simple
label: Paragraph

text: serial reproduction.
label: Paragraph

text: All in all, the Maison du Peuple de Clichy shows genuine architectural invention
label: Paragraph

text: rooted in a craft tradition that embraces unbiased inspiration provided by the
label: Paragraph

text: opportunities offered by new materials, investigation into manufacturing pro-
label: Paragraph

text: cesses, and, not least, a critical, humanistic reading of technology.
label: Paragraph
