text: VILLA MAIREA
label: Title

text: Alvar Aalto
label: Title

text: Scott Poole
label: Title

text: Alvar and Aino Aalto, Villa Mairea, living room with Aino Aalto and Maire Gullichsen,
label: Caption

text: Noormarkku, Finland, 1939.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: As late as 1927, at a time when modernism was making bold advances in the centers
label: Paragraph

text: of European culture, Alvar and Aino Aalto were designing neoclassical buildings
label: Paragraph

text: and handcrafted furniture in an array of historical styles in Jyvaskyla.’ A small city
label: Paragraph

text: in the countryside of central Finland, Jyvaskyla was far from Turku and Helsinki,
label: Paragraph

text: the cultural centers of a country that was already on the periphery of European
label: Paragraph

text: civilization. There was little out of the ordinary in the Aaltos’ work.” It was com-
label: Paragraph

text: petent, conventional in its style and appropriate for its place. Looking forward from
label: Paragraph

text: this point in time, the prospect that a modern masterpiece would emerge from
label: Paragraph

text: their office seemed unlikely, let alone inevitable.’ Yet, looking back from 1939,
label: Paragraph

text: the year the Villa Mairea was completed, the trajectory seems clearer. In fact,
label: Paragraph

text: by early 1938, Alvar Aalto’s exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in
label: Paragraph

text: New York was announced in a press release: “The Exhibition of Furniture and
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture by Alvar Aalto presents the first American survey of the work of
label: Paragraph

text: the Finnish architect, who is recognized as one of the most important and original
label: Paragraph

text: modern architects and furniture designers of the past decade.”*
label: Paragraph

text: In retrospect, from 1938, one sees how this improbable outcome was forged by a
label: Paragraph

text: number of factors: A resolute artistic will, an uncanny ability to win competitions,
label: Paragraph

text: and a propensity to attract highly influential, like-minded clients.” In addition, Alvar
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto had developed, in a small number of brief but surprisingly mature writings, a
label: Paragraph

text: thoughtful approach to some of the most pressing architectural issues of his time,
label: Paragraph

text: including questions concerning form and content, national character, international
label: Paragraph

text: influence, the right relation of the avant-garde to the authority of the past, the sig-
label: Paragraph

text: nificance of emotional content, the importance of social equity, and the potential
label: Paragraph

text: impact of industrialized manufacturing on the everyday life of the common man.°
label: Paragraph

text: Moreover, his emergence was serendipitous: The groundwork for modernism had
label: Paragraph

text: already been prepared abroad; he and his partner Aino were professionally aligned
label: Paragraph

text: with an industry that continued to provide work during the bleak years of the
label: Paragraph

text: world economic depression; and their commissions varied in range and scale, pro-
label: Paragraph

text: viding the opportunity to test innovative ideas.”
label: Paragraph

text: A New Cosmopolitan Outlook
label: Title

text: As modernists, Alvar Aalto and Aino Aalto may have been late to arrive, but once
label: Paragraph

text: they did, they advanced quickly. In mid-1927, the Aaltos, with their baby daughter,
label: Paragraph

text: moved to the port city of Turku, taking advantage of the cultural, social, and eco-
label: Paragraph

text: nomic opportunities offered by Finland’s gateway to western Europe.* More
label: Paragraph

text: broadly, the atmosphere was right for modernism to thrive in northern
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. That same year, in Stuttgart, more than 500,000 visitors toured the
label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhofseidlung housing exposition where they encountered a new domestic
label: Paragraph

text: culture for modern city dwellers, characterized by, among other qualities, flat
label: Paragraph

text: roofs, taut and unornamented volumes, flexible open plans, and terraces linking
label: Paragraph

text: interior rooms to abundant light and fresh air. Just three years later, across the
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish archipelago at the Stockholm Exhibition, the dream of better living through
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture and industrial production would draw nearly four million
label: Paragraph

text: visitors.”
label: Paragraph

text: During this three-year interval, the Aaltos jettisoned neoclassicism and began
label: Paragraph

text: assimilating the culturally progressive architecture emerging from mainland
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. In this short span of time, the Aalto firm won major architectural competi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions, designed and realized the construction for one of Finland’s first internation-
label: Paragraph

text: ally recognized modern buildings, forged a pivotal relationship with the technical
label: Paragraph

text: director of a well established furniture manufacturer, and encountered leading fig-
label: Paragraph

text: ures of the modern movement at International Congresses of Modern Architecture
label: Title

text: (CIAM) conferences in Frankfurt and Brussels, making lasting friendships that
label: Paragraph

text: would have a major impact, particularly on Alvar Aalto’s career.'°
label: Paragraph

text: One of those colleagues, Uno Ahrén, introduced Aalto’s work to Philip Johnson,
label: Paragraph

text: leading to the inclusion of Aalto’s first large-scale modern building in Hitchcock
label: Paragraph

text: and Johnson’s influential book, The International Style: Architecture Since 1922
label: Paragraph

text: (1932), as well as MoMA’s first exhibit of modern architecture installed that same
label: Paragraph

text: year." Like other work, included in the book and exhibit, the Turun Sanomat
label: Paragraph

text: newspaper plant and office building (1928-29) were characterized by a clear expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion of volume, structured by reinforced concrete columns, a dynamically balanced
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetrical composition, and an absence of ornament, features clearly identify-
label: Paragraph

text: ing it with other modern buildings of its type over the specificity of its place.” In
label: Paragraph

text: this sense, Aalto’s first international style building in the city of Turku would have
label: Paragraph

text: been equally out of context in Prague, Paris, or Amsterdam.
label: Paragraph

text: Alvar Aalto’s ascendency as a leading figure of the modern movement was based
label: Paragraph

text: on more than the force of an engaging personality. Without doubt, charisma
label: Paragraph

text: allowed him to establish relationships quickly among key figures within modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’s vanguard. The major breakthrough, however, came in his own coun-
label: Paragraph

text: try, where he began to win important architectural competitions and receive com-
label: Paragraph

text: missions from industry, leading to the opportunity to build at a scale that allowed
label: Paragraph

text: him to experiment, make discoveries, and innovate at a level that would begin to
label: Paragraph

text: substantiate his unique direction within the modern movement.'’
label: Paragraph

text: Shaping the Values of a New Society
label: Title

text: When the design of Villa Mairea was first discussed in autumn 1936, Alvar Aalto
label: Paragraph

text: was 38 years old and Aino, 42. Their clients and close friends, Harry and Maire (née
label: Paragraph

text: Ahlstrom) Gullichsen, son and daughter of prominent industrialists, were even
label: Paragraph

text: younger at the time of the commission; Harry was 34, and Maire was 29.\* The
label: Paragraph

text: Gullichsens, like the architects of their home, were keen advocates for modern cul-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and shared their architects’ ideological interest in shaping, through architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and design, the values of Finland’s rapidly developing, increasingly urban
label: Paragraph

text: and industrialized society.””
label: Paragraph

text: In 1935, Alvar and Aino Aalto, together with Maire Gullichsen and Nils-Gustav
label: Paragraph

text: Hahl, had already formed the Artek Company with the intention of selling the line
label: Paragraph

text: of modern bent wood furniture and fittings the Aaltos had been designing since the
label: Paragraph

text: late 1920s. The purpose of the company was more than a commercial enterprise; it
label: Paragraph

text: was, among other objectives, an extension of their mutual interest in promoting
label: Paragraph

text: social and cultural progress. *°
label: Paragraph

text: By means of affordable, well-made things, realized through serial industrial pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction, the company could, through the quality of the Aalto’s furnishings and a
label: Paragraph

text: limited number of other products, reinforce traditional Finnish values of simplicity
label: Paragraph

text: and functionality, elevate the aesthetic judgment of Finland’s emerging middle
label: Paragraph

text: class, and advance their society’s acceptance of a new modern outlook.” By chan-
label: Paragraph

text: ging the public perception of standardized products, Artek could contribute to the
label: Paragraph

text: day-to-day physical and emotional well-being of modern families and play a mean-
label: Paragraph

text: ingful part in the aesthetic and ethical development of a new egalitarian society.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Two years before founding Artek, the Aaltos had moved from Turku to Helsinki
label: Paragraph

text: where the reality of rapid urbanization was an integral part of everyday life. In
label: Paragraph

text: Helsinki and throughout Europe, workers were crowding into cities and relocating
label: Paragraph

text: to the districts surrounding factories. Housing was an urgent issue, and its place in
label: Paragraph

text: urban and regional planning was compelling to both Aalto and the CIAM-centered
label: Paragraph

text: vanguard of the modern movement. Advances in the quantity, quality, and costs of
label: Paragraph

text: housing made possible by new materials, standardized mass production, a focus on
label: Paragraph

text: public health, and the new practice of functional zoning dominated the discourse of
label: Paragraph

text: the time, underscoring the modern movement's progressive ideals as well as heigh-
label: Paragraph

text: tened expectations of an architect’s social responsibility.
label: Paragraph

text: An Ethical Dilemma
label: Title

text: In this context, Mairea, a private country villa for a wealthy art patron and a captain
label: Paragraph

text: of industry seems an unusual development for architects whose foundation as
label: Paragraph

text: modernists was substantially influenced, less than a decade earlier, by the practical
label: Paragraph

text: difficulties of the Minimum House.’* The Aaltos addressed this ethical dilemma in
label: Paragraph

text: their description of the project where they advanced the thought that the villa
label: Paragraph

text: could be conceived as an opportunity for experiment and innovation.” In this
label: Paragraph

text: sense, any architectural assignment: a house, hospital, library, factory — could pro-
label: Paragraph

text: vide an opportunity for discoveries that had general implications for architecture
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the specifics of a particular program. The Aaltos explained: “The individual
label: Paragraph

text: architectural assignment can be treated as a laboratory experiment of sorts, in
label: Paragraph

text: which things can be done that would be impossible with present-day mass produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and those experiments can spread further and eventually become available to
label: Paragraph

text: one and all as production methods advance.””? Alvar Aalto elaborated on the idea
label: Paragraph

text: of a luxury villa as an experimental laboratory in a lecture at Yale University on
label: Paragraph

text: May 9, 1939: “[W]e may use the house as a laboratory to tackle some of the central
label: Paragraph

text: problems in architecture today ... [YJou use this house to work out those things
label: Paragraph

text: especially, and the solutions you discover in this building can later be applied in
label: Paragraph

text: connection with larger buildings and under different conditions. ...””*
label: Paragraph

text: The utopian idea that technological progress would give designers and manu-
label: Paragraph

text: facturers the capacity to bring good, high-quality, mass-produced objects to the
label: Paragraph

text: general public had already been realized in the Aaltos’ domestic objects — furniture,
label: Paragraph

text: 23 It
label: Title

text: was not unrealistic, therefore, to believe that innovations made in a large villa for
label: Paragraph

text: glassware, fabrics, and lighting fixtures — in production since the early 1930s.
label: Paragraph

text: private clients, could translate to conventional housing and, later, industrially man-
label: Paragraph

text: ufactured dwellings and public buildings.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Expanding the Concept of Rationalism
label: Title

text: But Alvar Aalto was struggling with modernism’s orthodox formalism and had
label: Paragraph

text: largely withdrawn from the idea that an objective approach, driven by science,
label: Paragraph

text: technology, and the logic of construction, would inevitably resolve the fundamen-
label: Paragraph

text: tally human purpose at the core of architecture.” He did not dismiss the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: highly analytical working methods; he simply believed that the architecture of the
label: Paragraph

text: time, as it developed in the direction of “functional and constructive necessity,” and
label: Paragraph

text: “the new aesthetic of mechanized life,” had excluded too many critical issues to
label: Paragraph

text: remain relevant.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Hence, experiments carried out in the villa were not in the areas of standardized
label: Paragraph

text: construction or technical innovation but rather primarily in the realms of character,
label: Paragraph

text: identity, and milieu. In particular, their focus was the distinctiveness of the epoch,
label: Paragraph

text: the specificity of the place, and a fitting domestic atmosphere for a modern family.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from the Aaltos’ own industrially manufactured furnishings, the relationship
label: Paragraph

text: between the art of building and technological production was typically down-
label: Paragraph

text: played. In fact, only one standardized element, a white, off-the-shelf, circular metal
label: Paragraph

text: staircase, was employed in the villa.””
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, Aalto worked to conceal industrially produced items, deferring to an
label: Paragraph

text: overall ambience of intimacy, warmth, and welcome rather than specific demon-
label: Paragraph

text: strations of technical logic. The steel columns in the main living spaces, for exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ple, are finished with a soft black gloss and wrapped in twisted rattan,
label: Paragraph

text: transforming a cold, hard material that embodies strength and durability, into
label: Paragraph

text: one that exudes warmth, delicacy, and an irresistible invitation to touch. Simi-
label: Paragraph

text: larly, steel beams that support the prominent stair that separates the main living
label: Paragraph

text: area from the private family rooms above, are painted white, and almost com-
label: Paragraph

text: pletely hidden by the thickness, length, and breadth of the wooden stair treads.
label: Paragraph

text: The structure is further concealed by numerous wooden poles that run floor to
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling on either side, and by a low wall in the entry hall, partially obstructing a
label: Caption

text: view of the underside of the stair landing, where the steel structure would be
label: Paragraph

text: most evident.
label: Paragraph

text: Masterful Coherence
label: Title

text: judging from photographs of the villa, there seems to be too much there; too many
label: Paragraph

text: unusual details and contrasts, too much accommodation of circumstance, too
label: Paragraph

text: many motifs, materials and textures — simply too much to control.”* Added to this
label: Paragraph

text: multitude are numerous disjunctions in time and place. In the courtyard, for exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ple, there are free-standing elements; a traditional sod-roofed sauna, an archaic gar-
label: Paragraph

text: den gate, and a thick stone wall forming the outer boundary at the edge of the
label: Paragraph

text: forest — that appear much older than the new villa, as if the house itself were sited
label: Paragraph

text: to form a counterpoint to a place already inhabited long ago. Particular aspects of
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish farms and lakeside retreats are combined with features from Swiss Alpine
label: Paragraph

text: villages and traditional Japanese gardens to evoke an informal, even rustic atmos-
label: Paragraph

text: phere. This curious amalgam hangs together through a common thread of associ-
label: Paragraph

text: ation: The straightforward simplicity and down-to-earth utility of vernacular forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Under the entry canopy, for example, vernacular details seeming to belong to both
label: Paragraph

text: Finnish and Japanese traditional architecture, merge with surprising ease, as if they
label: Paragraph

text: always belonged together.”
label: Paragraph

text: Here, and throughout the villa, Aalto employs the integrity, utility, and time-
label: Paragraph

text: tested veracity of vernacular elements as a complement to the progressive archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture of the epoch. The constant interchange of polarities, between the timeless
label: Paragraph

text: authority of the vernacular and the unproven character of the new, is one of the
label: Paragraph

text: principal artistic devices employed to unify the villa. One encounters, throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the villa, oppositions of handcraft and industrial manufacture, austerity and embel-
label: Paragraph

text: ishment, hard edge and soft contour, nature and culture.*® But the manner in
label: Paragraph

text: which Aalto plays with time — with the backward and forward reach of key ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments at pivotal moments — is the villa’s dominant motif.
label: Paragraph

text: On the surface, the Villa Mairea gives the impression of being improvisational.
label: Paragraph

text: But what may appear to be a series of idiosyncratic, one-of-a-kind experiments is,
label: Paragraph

text: more typically, iterative versions of elements, motifs, and techniques that Aalto had
label: Paragraph

text: previously tested in other works. What makes the Villa Mairea one of the marvels
label: Paragraph

text: of modern architecture is the masterful coherence of those artistic forces: Their
label: Paragraph

text: wholeness, internal consistency, and seeming inevitability.
label: Paragraph

text: Orchestrating Time and Perception
label: Title

text: The choreography of the architectural encounter with the villa is distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: by tempo, by the gradual unfolding of a relaxed domestic atmosphere.” The
label: Paragraph

text: approach to the villa is oblique, coursing through a winding gravel drive that
label: Paragraph

text: begins at the edge of the forest. At first, the home is not visible. Gradually,
label: Paragraph

text: glimpses of the villa framed between tall pines reveal key features: White ren-
label: Paragraph

text: dered brick walls, wood cladding, an unusual entry canopy, and several unortho-
label: Paragraph

text: dox windows on an upper floor. The disclosure is purposely slow and
label: Paragraph

text: indistinct.” At a sharp curve in the entrance drive, after passing much of the
label: Paragraph

text: south-eastern facade, the front corner of the villa and the prominent entry por-
label: Caption

text: tico are fully revealed. The gradual build-up becomes a sudden unveiling. But
label: Paragraph

text: the calming effect of the leisurely approach remains, prolonging the subtle awak-
label: Paragraph

text: ening of the senses set in motion by the slow approach through the forest.’
label: Paragraph

text: While the villa is now in the foreground, it continues to be inseparable from
label: Paragraph

text: the presence of the forest and its profound quietude — a theme Aalto will
label: Paragraph

text: continues to reinforce throughout the villa.
label: Paragraph

text: In the approach, there is then no long view; no place to distantly analyze the
label: Paragraph

text: villa. Not only is the forest drawn close, but also the villa itself is presented, for
label: Paragraph

text: the first time, from a relatively short distance, prompting a visceral response.”**
label: Paragraph

text: Contrasting dark wooden features are visually balanced yet set in sharp contrast
label: Paragraph

text: to the primary structure, a crisp white volume characteristic of orthodox moder-
label: Paragraph

text: nity. While the dark wood and light stucco are visibly balanced, the wood features
label: Paragraph

text: dominate one’s inward experience of the villa, drawing attention to the earthiness
label: Paragraph

text: of texture and patina: engaging the sense of touch through the eye.” While these
label: Paragraph

text: wood forms are new, their earthy ambience appears historically backward looking,
label: Paragraph

text: even primitive, appealing to what Alvar Aalto, in an essay from 1922, described as
label: Paragraph

text: the subconscious content associated with old architecture. “The emotions it
label: Paragraph

text: arouses,” he wrote, “are so elevated, even intoxicating, that we usually pay no
label: Paragraph

text: attention at all to details — if there are any.”*°
label: Paragraph

text: Just ahead, under the entry portico, however, it is precisely the discrete details —
label: Paragraph

text: twisted rattan joinery, tiny geometric steel feet that transition between wood and
label: Paragraph

text: stone, and an unusual cast bronze door pull — that captivate attention, keeping one
label: Paragraph

text: fully engaged in the present moment. Again, time is drawn-out, as it was in a literal
label: Paragraph

text: sense, by the length of the route to the front door, then by memory through asso-
label: Paragraph

text: ciation with times past at the southernmost corner of the facade, and finally, under
label: Paragraph

text: the portico, by the strangeness of small individual features and the curiosity they
label: Paragraph

text: arouse.””
label: Paragraph

text: Likewise, inside the front door of the villa, the architects skillfully control the
label: Paragraph

text: visitor’s tempo. After a brief pause in a small, sky-lit antechamber, one arrives
label: Paragraph

text: at an entry hall defined by the low angled wall that directs the visitor away from
label: Paragraph

text: a formal dining area straight ahead and within view. The contrast between the una-
label: Paragraph

text: dorned emptiness of the antechamber and the rich abundance of forms, textures,
label: Paragraph

text: and subdued colors immediately visible from the entry hall, is stunning.”* The vis-
label: Paragraph

text: ual impact of the interior’s spatial flux is augmented by the sounds of floor surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: that alternate between hard and soft, tile and wood, defining key moments of tran-
label: Paragraph

text: sition. An upholstered settee, designed by Aino, follows the contour of the vesti-
label: Paragraph

text: bule wall inviting the visitor to sit, relax, and be at home.” Similarly, beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: vestibule near the hearth, a cozy sitting area defined by a rug and furnished with
label: Paragraph

text: comfortable chairs further encourages the visitor to feel at home. Here, and
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the villa’s interior, an atmosphere of domestic intimacy, warmth,
label: Paragraph

text: and solicitude is pervasive.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture and Landscape
label: Title

text: It is at this point, between the vestibule and the sitting area near the hearth, that
label: Paragraph

text: Aalto situates the principal place of arrival. Passing screens of wooden poles that
label: Paragraph

text: define the end of the vestibule wall and then encase the open stair to the second
label: Paragraph

text: floor, the visitor reaches the view of the garden courtyard, the sauna, and the vast
label: Paragraph

text: forest beyond. From this standpoint, in one of the best-known architectural photo-
label: Paragraph

text: graphs of the period, Eino Makinen captured Maire Gullichsen and Aino Aalto.
label: Paragraph

text: They are at the edge of the villa’s living room looking outward, transfixed, in a
label: Paragraph

text: scene reminiscent of the archetypal aura of I.K. Inha’s nineteenth-century photo-
label: Paragraph

text: graphs of Finland’s forests, or the unsettling solitude that Edward Hopper depicted
label: Paragraph

text: in his paintings of the time.*’ The focused view, framed by a floor-to-ceiling sliding
label: Paragraph

text: glass window, is an archetypal image laden with the memories of generations of
label: Paragraph

text: Finns who built with wood at the edge of the forest.*” Signs of domesticity dom-
label: Paragraph

text: inate the photograph’s foreground. Freshly cut flowers, an indoor plant, and the
label: Paragraph

text: informal arrangement of the Aaltos’ furnishings lend a sense of calm and tranquility
label: Paragraph

text: to the scene. The distinctive aroma of crisp Nordic summer air mingled with earth
label: Paragraph

text: and pines is almost palpable. The wooden poles screening the living room stair, the
label: Paragraph

text: thick wood mullions of the expansive window, and the steel columns supporting
label: Paragraph

text: the second floor mirror the trees in the forest. A small rise near the garden gate,
label: Paragraph

text: evocative of a mound in a Japanese garden, a hillock in the woods, or a miniatur-
label: Paragraph

text: ized knoll, links rather than divides, forest and courtyard.”
label: Paragraph

text: By bringing the outside in and projecting the inside out, Aalto underscores the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that the cultivated landscape within the courtyard, and the forest beyond, are
label: Paragraph

text: all part of the Villa Mairea’s composition, all part of one whole thing.** This idea is
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced from the opposite perspective; looking back at the villa and its courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: facades from the forest. From this vantage point, wood window mullions begin to
label: Paragraph

text: soften the great expanse of white rendered brick that clads the second-floor bed-
label: Paragraph

text: rooms. Moreover, on the walls and roof of the first floor, wood veneers, numerous
label: Paragraph

text: wood mullions, stripped sapling rails, and sod roofing continue the theme of con-
label: Paragraph

text: trast. Likewise, the hard edge of the southwest corner of the second-floor guest
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom wing is visually dominated by its opposite, the curvilinear wooden tower
label: Paragraph

text: of Maire Gullichsen’s painting studio, on the other southwest corner. These fea-
label: Paragraph

text: tures, combined with tall pines in the background and lush creepers in the fore-
label: Paragraph

text: ground, nullify the severity of the modernist treatment of the courtyard facades,
label: Paragraph

text: further unifying the architecture and landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Cosmopolitan Localism”
label: Title

text: The expansive artistic scope of the villa, in particular its sense of place, could not
label: Paragraph

text: have been realized without the complex integration of architecture, landscape
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, interior design, and industrial design. It would be difficult, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, to imagine the villa on another site.“ The nearby sites of Isotalo (1884)
label: Paragraph

text: and Havulinna (1901), Maire Gullichsen’s grandfather’s and father’s homes, are
label: Paragraph

text: located within view of cultivated clearings — a universal sign of human civiliza-
label: Paragraph

text: tion.*” Aalto, by contrast, locates the granddaughter’s house apart from the
label: Paragraph

text: Ahlstrom estate’s fields and at the periphery of the forest.
label: Paragraph

text: A compelling photo, taken by Heikki Havas, from the entry door, looks out at
label: Paragraph

text: a stand of carefully pruned pine trees fronted by a modest area of cropped grass
label: Paragraph

text: and plantings in the foreground. Acres of cultivated fields are nearby, but not
label: Paragraph

text: within view. From here, the house merges with the landscape. Even the irregular
label: Paragraph

text: stones that comprise the floor under the entry canopy are separated, allowing
label: Paragraph

text: earth and grass to identify with the nearby garden and the floor of the forest.
label: Paragraph

text: Here, again, anachronistic wooden canopy supports and numerous slender sap-
label: Paragraph

text: lings screen the portico, visually intertwining it with the forest, dominating
label: Paragraph

text: the single modern element, a concrete column, and effectively obscuring its tec-
label: Paragraph

text: tonic logic.
label: Paragraph

text: Likewise, the villa’s interior furnishings — the birch furniture in particular — aug-
label: Paragraph

text: ment the interior’s unity and breadth, contributing to its sense of place. The mate-
label: Paragraph

text: rials, labor, and technology to fabricate Aalto’s bent wood furniture were all locally
label: Paragraph

text: sourced. Birch is Finland’s national tree and the most abundant deciduous wood in
label: Paragraph

text: the country and skilled craftsmen and unskilled workers were also abundant fol-
label: Paragraph

text: lowing the rural migration to Finland’s cities. Moreover, the high quality machine
label: Paragraph

text: craft employed to fabricate Aalto’s bent wood furniture helped advance Finland’s
label: Paragraph

text: evolving national identity by promoting the idea that this new nation was progres-
label: Paragraph

text: sive and forward thinking, yet ethnographically linked to the archaic realm of the
label: Paragraph

text: forest.”
label: Paragraph

text: By linking the vernacular, the familiar language of ordinary people, with the
label: Paragraph

text: strangeness of the new, Aalto created a work with broad appeal. Whereas the com-
label: Paragraph

text: positional, constructive and functional priorities of many examples of early mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernist housing created distance from geographic and historical contexts in an effort
label: Paragraph

text: to be universal, the Villa Mairea emphasized features particular to Finland — the
label: Paragraph

text: regional economy, local materials, available labor, and established traditions —
label: Paragraph

text: to create a place with which Finns could identify and in which they could recognize
label: Paragraph

text: themselves.” In doing so, Aalto created a safe middle ground between tradition
label: Paragraph

text: and modernity, between the security of a familiar past and the promise of an exhil-
label: Paragraph

text: arating future, a place where everyday people could engage the new forms of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity from a frame of reference they were familiar with — from the mirror
label: Paragraph

text: of history, their history.
label: Paragraph

text: What gives the Villa Mairea its distinctive place in the history of architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: not only a skillful play with contrasting forms or a mastery of time and tempo, scale
label: Paragraph

text: and density, politics and geography but also how prescient it was and how relevant
label: Paragraph

text: it remains.*° Questions of national identity and international influence, the right-
label: Paragraph

text: balance between the newness of the present and the aura of the past, the integra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of architecture and its natural site, and the role that new technologies play in
label: Paragraph

text: making a better life for the common man, are recurring difficulties brought into
label: Paragraph

text: sharp focus in the villa.”
label: Paragraph

text: Looking forward, Aalto’s brilliant resolution to these issues prefigures one of the
label: Paragraph

text: daunting challenges of the twenty-first century: Being rooted in a specific place, its
label: Paragraph

text: local economy, and its indigenous traditions, while at the same time being globally
label: Paragraph

text: intertwined with the larger world and its fluid movement of ideas, forms, and tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nical innovations.” It is here, in this fertile middle ground, that Aalto created a
label: Paragraph

text: house with lasting global significance.
label: Paragraph

text: PART IV
label: Title

text: Postwar Trends
label: Title

text: Introauction
label: Title

text: BEGINNING AGAIN, BUT NOT
label: Paragraph

text: AT THE BEGINNING
label: Title

text: David Leatherbarrow
label: Title

text: Houses chopped by bombs while ladies were still sitting on the lavatory, the rest
label: Paragraph

text: of the house gone but the wallpaper and the fires still burning in the grate. Who
label: Paragraph

text: can hold a candle to that kind of real life Surrealism?
label: Paragraph

text: Nigel Henderson
label: Title

text: Buildings and cities designed and constructed in the late 1940s and 50s through-
label: Paragraph

text: out the world were deeply affected by the fact that a terrible — and terribly wide-
label: Paragraph

text: spread — war had taken place. Although a “world war,” different locations suffered
label: Paragraph

text: its consequences in dissimilar ways. Stylistic categories for the architecture of this
label: Paragraph

text: period should therefore be used with caution. A case in point is the use of the term
label: Paragraph

text: “brutalist” to characterize postwar buildings in Britain and Brazil. Postwar con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction sites in these countries had little in common. London locations, for exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ple, often presented a blistered earth and ruins of bombing. The site of Brasilia, by
label: Paragraph

text: contrast, was an open and verdant savannah. “Brutalist” meant something very dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferent in each location, likewise for sites in the United States and Japan. Similar
label: Paragraph

text: contrasts among works grouped under similar headings could be easily adduced.
label: Paragraph

text: Within each of the movements that emerged in the decades just after the war —
label: Paragraph

text: brutalism, the new empiricism, metabolism, and so on — there were different
label: Paragraph

text: responses to a single catastrophe; admittedly, a very great one.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, with this stipulation in mind one can still say that the architects
label: Paragraph

text: considered in the following chapters shared a number of responses to the war,
label: Paragraph

text: regardless of where their buildings were built or urban settlements laid out.
label: Paragraph

text: The first of these was that this was not a time for the speculations of disengaged
label: Paragraph

text: intellectuals or detached visionaries. Concrete action was the order of the day. Nor
label: Paragraph

text: did it make sense to uncritically follow any form of party doctrine, right or left,
label: Paragraph

text: despite the current growth of cold war rhetoric. Architects felt summoned to
label: Paragraph

text: respond to locally specific material consequences of the war. They also saw the
label: Paragraph

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

label: Caption

text: need to take a stand against the ideas (ideologies) that were believed to have
label: Paragraph

text: prompted and sustained the fighting, for the conceptions and institutions of order
label: Paragraph

text: that had preceded the conflict did not lose their force after the truce; ideas of the
label: Paragraph

text: nation-state, for example, but also more deeply rooted institutions of nationalistic
label: Paragraph

text: culture, starting with language and extending into the fabric of cities. More basi-
label: Paragraph

text: cally, the existence of evil was not something to discuss idly or theorize, but to live
label: Paragraph

text: with. It was, indeed, a time of recovery and rebuilding. But the war’s end did not
label: Paragraph

text: eliminate aggression and inhumanity; it only signaled the end of open conflict. Mil-
label: Paragraph

text: itarization took on different forms. Forces no less threatening extended their effects
label: Paragraph

text: in these years: the hyper-rationalized, technocratic, and universalizing dimensions
label: Paragraph

text: of modern civilization. Many believed these were the very same forces that had
label: Paragraph

text: formed the “spiritual substance” of the war itself. New proposals for “habitat,”
label: Paragraph

text: “community,” and “urban reality” can only be understood against the background
label: Paragraph

text: of the war had taken place and the dehumanizing mechanisms that continued to
label: Paragraph

text: operate. The same background set the stage for the reorientation of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: design toward the actual conditions of human existence; more importantly, of
label: Paragraph

text: coexistence.
label: Paragraph

text: Although each of them posed the problem in their own way, all of the architects
label: Paragraph

text: studied in the chapters that follow took a stand against the narrow sort of “ration-
label: Paragraph

text: alism” that was said to have dominated the thought and action of the preceding
label: Paragraph

text: years. Their texts and public statements attest to deep unease with the anonymity,
label: Paragraph

text: isolation, and dehumanization of life in industrial society, and even more so with its
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation in patterns of urbanization. The problem was neither the impulse
label: Paragraph

text: nor the aesthetics of early and high modernism, but the reduced and extrapolated
label: Paragraph

text: versions that had become more widespread than their source.
label: Paragraph

text: In Chile, for example, Alberto Cruz argued against modernist functionalism and
label: Paragraph

text: the reductions it represented. Le Corbusier was not the target of his criticism, but
label: Paragraph

text: his epigones who had not seen his built works, only read his books and taken their
label: Paragraph

text: polemics at face value. As Rodrigo Pérez d’Arce observes in his chapter, Cruz’s
label: Paragraph

text: alternative was an architecture that embraced ritual and historically constituted
label: Paragraph

text: social practices. The geometry and physical body of Cruz’s Pajaritos Chapel also
label: Paragraph

text: indicated a conviction about the preeminence of direct observation and experience.
label: Paragraph

text: Posture and procession were key. What wine is to a glass, embodied action was to
label: Paragraph

text: geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: Cruz’s project was designed in 1952. Three years later the construction of the
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam Orphanage broke ground. In his chapter, Nathaniel Coleman shows
label: Paragraph

text: that Aldo van Eyck was similarly critical of the narrowed version of “functionalism”
label: Paragraph

text: at the root of the rapidly built settlements at the outskirts of the city. Again, it was
label: Paragraph

text: not the leaders of the modern movement who posed the problem but the bureau-
label: Paragraph

text: cratic professionals who operated with less imagination, reduced budgets, greater
label: Paragraph

text: speed, and the sort of self-confidence that accompanies a restricted view of the
label: Paragraph

text: world. Already by 1953, the year of the CIAM 9 conference at Aix-en-Provence,
label: Paragraph

text: van Eyck, together with others there, had concluded that an approach to “habitat”
label: Paragraph

text: that captured only those aspects of dwelling that could be analyzed functionally
label: Paragraph

text: (elsewhere called “rationally” and “mechanistically”) would fail to grasp what
label: Paragraph

text: was essential about architectural and urban reality.
label: Paragraph

text: On the face of it, the approach to design taken by Eladio Dieste would seem to
label: Paragraph

text: be wholly different, insofar as he worked as an engineer as much as an architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet, Stanford Anderson explains in his chapter that Dieste saw industrialism as a
label: Paragraph

text: very mixed blessing. “What we see around us,” Dieste wrote, “is not acceptable
label: Paragraph

text: .. The industrial revolution took place with such great injustice that the repercus-
label: Paragraph

text: sions from the fierce indignation that its inequities produced in mankind are the
label: Paragraph

text: reason for the destructive madness that has spread throughout the world.” His
label: Paragraph

text: alternative, Anderson explains, was to combine art and science to produce an archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture that would reclaim “the home of mankind.” One suspects that he would
label: Paragraph

text: have agreed with the observation made by the Spanish philosopher José Ortega
label: Paragraph

text: y Gasset in a text from 1939 called “Man the Technician”: “to be an engineer it
label: Paragraph

text: is not enough to be an engineer.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Reactions to Walter Gropius’ presentation at the end of the CIAM 9 confer-
label: Paragraph

text: ence just mentioned provide vivid evidence of growing unease with any nar-
label: Paragraph

text: rowly defined technocratic approach to architecture and city building. Having
label: Paragraph

text: been absent for the preceding speeches that argued for a change of direction
label: Paragraph

text: in modern architecture, Gropius argued for teamwork, industrial production,
label: Paragraph

text: standardization, and system building. To many in the audience it sounded
label: Paragraph

text: like a repudiation of all that the younger generation had proposed in the
label: Paragraph

text: preceding days.
label: Paragraph

text: Peter and Alison Smithson must have been at least ambivalent, in not indig-
label: Paragraph

text: nant, for their proposal, illustrated with photographs of street life by Nigel Hen-
label: Paragraph

text: derson, argued for the re-identification of man with his house, community, and
label: Paragraph

text: city in opposition to “the functional hierarchy of the Charte d’Athens.” Perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: the most emphatic rejection of what they saw as the hyper-rationalized approach
label: Paragraph

text: to architecture and urbanism of the postwar years was offered by Guy Debord
label: Paragraph

text: and Asger Jorn. Simon Sadler in his chapter renders the conflict bluntly: if the
label: Paragraph

text: Ville Radieuse was a provocation, The Naked City was a response. Clearly, the full
label: Paragraph

text: amplitude of Le Corbusier’s work and writing was abbreviated in this compar-
label: Paragraph

text: ison. Nevertheless, the rationalizing dimensions of Corbusian urbanism provided
label: Paragraph

text: situationalist critics with an easy target: the Radiant City was seen as an exercise
label: Paragraph

text: in planning and the Naked City the outcome of art practices that verged on anar-
label: Paragraph

text: chy. Both projects addressed the city, of course, then seen by many as the most
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated, eloquent, and challenging articulation and embodiment of human
label: Paragraph

text: culture.
label: Paragraph

text: If the city was understood as the fundamental frame of reference for architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, was it also seen as the subject matter of project making? To some degree the
label: Paragraph

text: answer must be yes, for not only were urban scale projects designed at this time,
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo Bay, for example, but entire cities were planned; Chandigarh and Brasilia
label: Paragraph

text: are perhaps the most obvious cases in point. A tough question presents itself,
label: Paragraph

text: then: Is the design of a building the same sort of task as the design of a city? Can
label: Paragraph

text: single individuals, which is to say individual architects, be responsible for both?
label: Paragraph

text: Do entire settlements and buildings require the same set of skills and kinds of
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge? With Aldo van Eyck’s often repeated analogy between the house
label: Paragraph

text: and the city in mind, the answer would seem to be yes. Speaking of the Amster-
label: Paragraph

text: dam Orphanage, and with reference to the axiom set forth by Leon Battista
label: Paragraph

text: Alberti in the Renaissance and Plato in antiquity, van Eyck observed: “a house
label: Paragraph

text: must be like a small city it it’s to be a real house; [and] a city must be like a large
label: Paragraph

text: house if it is to be a real city.” Modularity was a key in the Orphanage, for it
label: Paragraph

text: allowed extension (through additions and varying combinations) and invited
label: Paragraph

text: movement through different layers of space, as Coleman shows. Van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: was not alone in holding on to the city-as-house premise. Still, one suspects an
label: Paragraph

text: essential difference between the two scales because of the typical shift in vocab-
label: Paragraph

text: ulary: then as now it was common to talk of designing buildings and planning
label: Paragraph

text: cities. This distinction recognizes the temporal, financial, and cognitive challenges
label: Paragraph

text: of “inventing” something as large and complex as an urban settlement. Single
label: Paragraph

text: buildings are difficult enough.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, Brasilia was designed and then built, largely according to Lucio
label: Paragraph

text: Costa’s plan, as Carlos Eduardo Comas indicates in his chapter. Costa’s plan
label: Paragraph

text: won the competition because it was compact, cohesive, and contemporary. For
label: Paragraph

text: Comas it was also timeless, pragmatic, and emblematic. Clear signs of this were
label: Paragraph

text: its car-oriented efficiency on the one hand and its monumentality on the other.
label: Paragraph

text: Reduced to a useful pairing, these qualities suggested a plan that promised an “effi-
label: Paragraph

text: cient urbs and proud civitas.” Yet, different conceptions of urban and architectural
label: Paragraph

text: work were inscribed into the plan. Costa made a distinction between the architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture of the monumental center and of the ordinary city at its margins; the first was
label: Paragraph

text: comparatively stable, the second transitory, fugitive, and contingent. This suggests
label: Paragraph

text: that different skills and kinds of knowledge were required for the design of build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings and planning of cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Different methods for different scales are less in evidence in Kenzo Tange’s
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo Bay Plan. Zhongjie Lin explains that two kinds or degrees of permanence
label: Paragraph

text: were envisaged by Tange: those of infrastructure and housing. Change, to which
label: Paragraph

text: I will refer again shortly, was obviously important for someone who played a key
label: Paragraph

text: role in the emergence of the Metabolist Group; but the repetitive forms and inter-
label: Paragraph

text: vals of the (megastructural) circulation framework indicate that stability and per-
label: Paragraph

text: mianence were topics of equal importance. In this case, as with Brasilia, the project
label: Paragraph

text: was not developed in response to war damage in cities. Decisive instead were the
label: Paragraph

text: momentum of Tokyo’s urban growth and need for housing. The increasing use of
label: Paragraph

text: automobiles was one part of the problem, another was land shortage and specu-
label: Paragraph

text: lation. Continued dedication to the urban core would not provide the answer,
label: Paragraph

text: Tange thought; instead, a linear configuration, centered on the spine of the trans-
label: Paragraph

text: portation system. His system of routes established sites for housing and public insti-
label: Paragraph

text: tutions, suggesting that the design of urban scale settlements was essentially the
label: Paragraph

text: same kind of work as the design of individual buildings. In coming years this prac-
label: Paragraph

text: tice would come to be called urban design.
label: Paragraph

text: Alison and Peter Smithson’s Golden Lane project was also envisaged as an
label: Paragraph

text: expansive urban pattern. As with Tange’s superstructure over the bay, this design
label: Paragraph

text: proposed a network of routes and accommodations built above an unstable sub-
label: Paragraph

text: strate; a bombed remnant, Eric Mumford explains in his chapter, of pre-existing
label: Paragraph

text: urban structure. Had the site not included ruins, increased automobile traffic
label: Paragraph

text: would still have “invalidated” traditional configurations. “Streets in the air” were
label: Paragraph

text: proposed as the preferred alternative to traditional urban elements. The promise
label: Paragraph

text: was for human association — hardly new to cities — and contemporary kinds of
label: Paragraph

text: urban experience. Meant to be no less innovative than early modern proposals,
label: Paragraph

text: the design was also supposed to elaborate “found” conditions, hence the inclusion
label: Paragraph

text: of Henderson’s ethnographic photography in the Smithsons’ CIAM presentation.
label: Paragraph

text: No sharp distinction between the design of buildings and urban areas was allowed.
label: Paragraph

text: The same would be true for the configurations they envisaged in subsequent pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects: networks, webs, mat buildings, and so on.
label: Paragraph

text: From the very start of their arguments in support of The Naked City, Asger
label: Paragraph

text: Jorn and Guy Debord assumed the wider urban landscape to be design’s proper
label: Paragraph

text: frame of reference. Unlike Tokyo Bay and Brasilia, though, it was not city form
label: Paragraph

text: imagined by architects, but a pre-existing ensemble. The Naked City collage, like
label: Paragraph

text: their thinking more generally, argued for the intensification of already-existing
label: Paragraph

text: situations. The aim of this intensification would be a unitary urbanism. The city
label: Paragraph

text: was understood as a work of art and a domain of experience. As a work it included
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of course, but also, more importantly, events. Paris in particular, but
label: Paragraph

text: cities in general, were understood as totalities (even if they could only be per-
label: Paragraph

text: ceived in fragments), complete ensembles of human relations. The street was
label: Paragraph

text: the locus of popular culture, which in turn served as the subject matter of build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing design.
label: Paragraph

text: In The Naked City and a number of the other projects studied in this volume,
label: Paragraph

text: works of art disclosed the urban reality architects imagined their projects would
label: Paragraph

text: embody. Art and architectural subject matter was often described as discovered —
label: Paragraph

text: because it had been either lost or overlooked until then — but conditions that were
label: Paragraph

text: said to be found were often invented. Beauty, such as it could exist in art and archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture, was to be recognized in the world, even if was both unfamiliar and inex-
label: Paragraph

text: plicable. Striking as it may appear, the art movement that seems to have had an
label: Paragraph

text: especially strong influence on projects seen in this way was surrealism.
label: Paragraph

text: While there are very few examples of what might be called “surrealist
label: Paragraph

text: architecture,” the ways of working associated with the movement can be seen
label: Paragraph

text: in many of the projects of these years. An obvious case in point is the work of Frie-
label: Paragraph

text: drich Kiesler; his shop window designs, for example, but even more so his Endless
label: Paragraph

text: House. William Braham’s chapter provides a concise account of Kiesler’s involve-
label: Paragraph

text: ment with European and American surrealists, involvement that did not prevent
label: Paragraph

text: him from associating with members of the De Stijl group or becoming one of
label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller’s Structural Studies Associates. Yet, through his friendship with
label: Paragraph

text: Marcel Duchamp and Peggy Guggenheim he was seen (in New York at least) as the
label: Paragraph

text: architect of the surrealists.
label: Paragraph

text: Aldo van Eyck’s frequent allusions to van Doesburg’s work might suggest dis-
label: Paragraph

text: tance between him and a figure like André Breton. Yet, as a collector of works by
label: Paragraph

text: Tanguy, Klee, Dali, and Ernst, a reader of Breton, Aragon, Crevel, and Minotaure —
label: Paragraph

text: the pages of which seem to have kindled his interest in Africa — it is plain that van
label: Paragraph

text: Eyck, too, saw surrealism as one of the keys to reality. After all, Breton himself had
label: Paragraph

text: said that the basic intention of the movement was the mutual interpenetration of
label: Paragraph

text: “interior and exterior reality.”
label: Paragraph

text: No less obvious are the connections between surrealism and Debord and Jorn’s
label: Paragraph

text: Naked City, for the dérive that opened the richness and mysteries of Paris closely
label: Paragraph

text: followed the format and “method” of Louis Aragon’s Paris Peasant, Louis Sou-
label: Paragraph

text: pault’s Last Nights in Paris, and André Breton’s Nadja, all of which gained narrative
label: Paragraph

text: momentum from the “chance encounters” that resulted from errance in the city.
label: Paragraph

text: And finally, the close association between the Smithsons and members of the
label: Paragraph

text: Independent Group, particularly Eduardo Paolozzi, show that projects like Golden
label: Paragraph

text: Lane had roots in surrealist art practices as well. Nigel Henderson had been intro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced to Duchamp, Ernst, and Tanguy by Peggy Guggenheim. Translating a key
label: Paragraph

text: surrealist idea, he linked “selective accidents” to both “found” phenomena and
label: Paragraph

text: “recognition.” If the city was the subject matter of creative thinking about archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture in these years, then the urban reality disclosed in surrealist art was deci-
label: Paragraph

text: sively important.
label: Paragraph

text: Other art movements were, of course, also influential. Simon Sadler explains
label: Paragraph

text: the importance of collage in the conception of the city Debord and Jorn developed.
label: Paragraph

text: Its origins are found in Dada and cubist art. Kiesler’s involvement in the De Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: movement has been mentioned. De Stijl architecture was of course interconnected
label: Paragraph

text: with neoplasticism in art, particularly that of Piet Mondian, to whom Aldo van
label: Paragraph

text: Eyck frequently referred. The artists and works associated with these movements
label: Paragraph

text: did not provide the architects with solutions to the problems they encountered in
label: Paragraph

text: building and city design, but some of their ways of working were adapted to proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect making, as was their focus on the situations, patterns, and institutions of
label: Paragraph

text: urban life.
label: Paragraph

text: The research into the urban conditions of architectural order undertaken by the
label: Paragraph

text: architects of this period can be likened to archaeology or anthropology insofar as
label: Paragraph

text: the possibilities of creative work were discovered beneath the surface or within the
label: Paragraph

text: depth of social and cultural norms. One of the most heated debates of the entire
label: Paragraph

text: history of CIAM arose over interpretations of what Ernesto Rogers called “pre-
label: Paragraph

text: existing conditions” (preesistenze ambientali). He had published his famous paper
label: Paragraph

text: on the subject in 1955. We need not side with either Rogers or Peter Smithson
label: Paragraph

text: to say that many, though certainly not all of the architects of the time felt that
label: Paragraph

text: the urban order their designs would shape and give substance to conditions that
label: Paragraph

text: pre-dated their projects. Tange was one of those who did not hold this position.
label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, the meaning of the term “conditions” was interpreted very widely.
label: Paragraph

text: Did “ambient” mean the vicinity of the site, something like “neighborhood”? In
label: Paragraph

text: some cases, yes; but it was also taken to mean elsewhere in the same city, at
label: Paragraph

text: the time of the project, of course, but also in some distant period of its historical
label: Paragraph

text: development. “Parallel worlds,” as van Eyck described a project’s pre-existing
label: Paragraph

text: frame of reference, could be exceedingly remote, on another continent in fact;
label: Paragraph

text: Africa or America, for example. For connections that distant to be maintained, a
label: Paragraph

text: premise (an ontology) of basic human commonality had to be assumed; the idea —
label: Paragraph

text: so difficult for us to accept today — that cultural differences do not prohibit simila-
label: Paragraph

text: rities between oneself and others. Perhaps this was less a premise than a promise:
label: Paragraph

text: that the project would set the stage for the renewal of “human association.”
label: Paragraph

text: What non-European sites were for van Eyck, working class neighborhoods were
label: Paragraph

text: for the Smithsons. Eric Mumford explains that the grille they presented at the 1953
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM conference “implicitly questioned the uniform rationality of the grid pres-
label: Paragraph

text: entation by placing on theirs a series of photographs by Nigel Henderson that
label: Paragraph

text: showed street children playing in the Bethnal Green district of London’s East
label: Caption

text: End.” The Hendersons had moved to that part of the city the year the war ended.
label: Paragraph

text: It was a part of London unknown to them, a borough that had been bombed and
label: Paragraph

text: was suffering extreme poverty, overcrowding, and poor sewerage. Vibrant life was
label: Paragraph

text: apparent nonetheless. Behaviors that Henderson likened to “living theater” seemed
label: Paragraph

text: to follow “a pre-determined script ... rituals [that were] formal, very strong and
label: Paragraph

text: coercive to me [and] because of their unfamiliarity exotic.” Citing George Bra-
label: Paragraph

text: que’s comments on the importance of limitations in creative work, he also
label: Paragraph

text: observed a “poetic homogeneity in the patient tired faces of people and houses
label: Paragraph

text: and pavements; a savage humility begotten of limited means.” Cultural norms
label: Paragraph

text: interested him especially, as they were evident in public life; but the culture to
label: Paragraph

text: which he, and then later the Smithsons, referred was surprisingly foreign. The
label: Paragraph

text: same “strangeness of the everyday” is evident in the writings of Aragon, Soupault,
label: Paragraph

text: and Breton on the neighborhoods of Paris. When Debord and Jorn advocated for
label: Paragraph

text: “drifting” through the city, their observations were not meant to be as “documen-
label: Paragraph

text: tary” as Henderson’s, but they were no less open to the ways the city’s uncanny and
label: Paragraph

text: marvelous situations could provoke a “derangement of the senses.”
label: Paragraph

text: As was observed earlier, ritualized patterns were also recognized as important in
label: Paragraph

text: the ideas and projects of Alberto Cruz. There is no sense in suggesting that he
label: Paragraph

text: found these kinds of conduct either foreign or unfamiliar. Yet, they were not mun-
label: Paragraph

text: dane or prosaic either. His critique of functional thinking was strengthened by his
label: Paragraph

text: reference to ritual because the latter offered an extraordinary alternative that was,
label: Paragraph

text: nevertheless, a dimension of contemporary existence. That patterns of behavior
label: Paragraph

text: established in the past interested Cruz should not be surprising, for in his text
label: Paragraph

text: on the chapel he described cities as “frames of retention.” Each city, he said, “lives
label: Paragraph

text: in the nostalgia of another city retaining it,” cities within cities, circling in on their
label: Paragraph

text: antecedent forms, the origin of which is unknown. Different scales do not prevent
label: Paragraph

text: analogous structures: “a church,” Cruz wrote, “brings a city with it” Obviously,
label: Paragraph

text: the “city” to which he referred was to be implicitly present in the church, which is
label: Paragraph

text: to say, strangely familiar.
label: Paragraph

text: Carlos Eduardo Comas makes a comparable observation about the vast open
label: Paragraph

text: spaces of Brasilia. Lucio Costa intended the square and esplanade of the monumen-
label: Paragraph

text: tal quarter to be “purposefully empty most of the time, waiting to burst with
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary and massive civic joy, anger, or grief.” That city spaces were
label: Paragraph

text: designed to wait is an instructive point, but the occasional and atypical or disruptive
label: Paragraph

text: character of the events that fill them is what I want to stress. Brasilia’s monumental
label: Paragraph

text: public spaces anticipated what could not be foreseen; the life they accommodated
label: Paragraph

text: was allowed to exceed what had been imagined. The thesis here is that the least
label: Paragraph

text: memorable event is the one that goes according to plan. Project making is, thus,
label: Paragraph

text: something besides the shaping and sizing of anticipated behaviors; it is also a way of
label: Paragraph

text: allowing for occurrences that are too improbable to be planned.
label: Paragraph

text: The design topic that was addressed in each of the projects studied in the chap-
label: Paragraph

text: ters that follow is movement. As with their interpretations of “rationalism,” “the
label: Paragraph

text: city,” “art,” and “parallel worlds,” however, movement was understood in very
label: Paragraph

text: different ways in each of these cases. For Dieste, the accent was not on the person
label: Paragraph

text: but on the metaphorical movement of the building’s “dynamic” forms. Obvi-
label: Paragraph

text: ously, the roof and walls were not supposed to move, only seem to, and the
label: Paragraph

text: seeming is what mattered in perceptual experience. When Kiesler described
label: Paragraph

text: the “flow of space” in his Endless House he alluded to a comparable dynamism
label: Paragraph

text: of the building’s body, but also to the capacity of its smooth and continuous sur-
label: Paragraph

text: faces to adapt to the circumstances of life, and to do so continually. The notions
label: Paragraph

text: of movement set forth in the Japanese texts that argued for a “Metabolist” con-
label: Paragraph

text: ception of buildings and cites were many. Generally speaking, organic rather than
label: Paragraph

text: mechanic movements were preferred; yet, for these architects the most vivid and
label: Paragraph

text: insistent expression of change was the vehicular route. Transportation was the
label: Paragraph

text: key to Tokyo Bay’s organization and operation. Brasilia, too, was a cat-oriented
label: Paragraph

text: city, but the several sorts of pedestrian passage Costa imagined, attuned to the
label: Paragraph

text: city’s distinctly monumental, gregarious, and bucolic settings, were no less impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant. Circulation was also decisive in the layout of the Smithsons’ Golden Lane
label: Paragraph

text: project, along the run of its “streets in the air,” at different speeds, within eddies
label: Paragraph

text: and flows of movement on a single deck, or from one block to the next. The pace
label: Paragraph

text: of passage envisaged by Aldo van Eyck was not only slower, but allowed — even
label: Paragraph

text: invited — delays and interruptions. Hesitations and divergences gave perceptual
label: Paragraph

text: depth and variety to what he called “labyrinthine clarity.” Perhaps the most
label: Paragraph

text: extreme form of unprescribed passage is the dérive intended for The Naked City.
label: Paragraph

text: The meander or wander through the streets, courts, alleys, and gardens of the city
label: Paragraph

text: presented perception with changing prospects that would not only alter one’s
label: Paragraph

text: sense of the several places, but also the city’s history and the person’s subjectivity.
label: Paragraph

text: Remaking was intended in this and the other projects; and also reconstruction, of
label: Paragraph

text: the city first and foremost, but also of the culture that architectural design
label: Paragraph

text: intended to renew.
label: Paragraph
