text: THE DESIGN AND URBANISM OF
label: Title

text: MEGASTRUCTURES
label: Title

text: At the ninth International Congresses for Modern Architecture (CIAM), held in
label: Paragraph

text: Aix-en-Provence, France in 1953, the young British architects Alison and Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Smithson presented a recent urban housing competition project that put forward
label: Paragraph

text: a new sensibility about the potential for architecture to shape urban life. Although
label: Paragraph

text: never built, as it was an unplaced design in a competition for rebuilding a war-
label: Paragraph

text: damaged area of the City of London known as Golden Lane, their well-known
label: Paragraph

text: set of drawings and photographs for this project, a series of linked 16-story
label: Paragraph

text: high-rise slab buildings connected by “streets in the air,” altered the postwar history
label: Paragraph

text: of modern architecture and urbanism.*
label: Paragraph

text: This project was exhibited at CIAM 9 in the same late-CIAM context where
label: Paragraph

text: some of the members of what would become Team 10 in 1954 first met, and it
label: Paragraph

text: was soon followed by other works by the Smithsons, Candilis-Josic- Woods, Kenzo
label: Paragraph

text: Tange, and others that developed and extended its influential challenge to the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: century urbanistic certainties of CIAM. These designs were premised on the con-
label: Paragraph

text: cept of continuous pedestrian circulation systems as generators of human associ-
label: Paragraph

text: ation and urban social identity, and they profoundly shifted the focus of the
label: Paragraph

text: field away from its more traditional concerns with creating monumental urban
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian spaces linked to political discourse and official social representations.”
label: Paragraph

text: Instead, Golden Lane and its successors — which included the Smithsons’ Berlin
label: Paragraph

text: Hauptstadt competition entry and Kenzo Tange’s Tokyo Bay project, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: the numerous built mass housing, campus, and airport projects that these inspired
label: Paragraph

text: — sought to generate and shape pedestrian activity to create and celebrate new
label: Paragraph

text: kinds of urban experiences. By the mid-1970s these efforts themselves were begin-
label: Paragraph

text: ning to be criticized in terms often borrowed from Team 10’s own earlier attacks
label: Paragraph

text: on CIAM functionalism, but the urban sensibility that they celebrated has remained
label: Paragraph

text: central to the field since then.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1952, the year of the Golden Lane competition,’ the Smithsons had already
label: Paragraph

text: become famous in Britain for winning a competition for the Hunstanton Secondary
label: Paragraph

text: Modern School in East Anglia (1949-54). This built project combined the minimal-
label: Paragraph

text: ism of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, then becoming the mainstream icon of mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernism in the United States, with a tough, industrial-era sensibility about
label: Paragraph

text: exposed materials that would develop into what they and their colleague, the critic
label: Paragraph

text: Reyner Banham, would term “the new Brutalism.”* The Smithsons’ work and
label: Paragraph

text: bohemian persona, which involved many links through the London Independent
label: Paragraph

text: Group (IG) to artists like Eduardo Paolozzi and critic-historians like Banham, as
label: Paragraph

text: well as more distantly to Le Corbusier, was intentionally provocative. Inspired
label: Paragraph

text: by their membership in the IG, their goal was to create conceptual projects in archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture, urbanism, and exhibition and graphic design that both continued the
label: Paragraph

text: innovations of prewar modernists and, at the same time, challenged their postwar
label: Paragraph

text: institutionalization. The Smithsons insisted that their work and activities could lead
label: Paragraph

text: a younger generation of architects to recover the lost energy and social relevance of
label: Paragraph

text: the modernism of the 1920s by overturning the bland official acceptance of mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernism in Europe after the war.’
label: Paragraph

text: The Smithsons’ design work reflected their working class backgrounds far from
label: Paragraph

text: London, and like other young British architects of their generation, they were
label: Paragraph

text: angrily contemptuous of the paternalistic and perhaps sometimes patronizing
label: Paragraph

text: efforts of mainstream British architects and artists to adapt modernism to the more
label: Paragraph

text: egalitarian postwar British society, which was largely the creation from 1945 to
label: Paragraph

text: 1951 of the socialist Labour Party.° For the Smithsons and the generation that fol-
label: Caption

text: lowed them, those well-meaning official efforts did not go nearly far enough, and
label: Paragraph

text: they saw the New Towns and the Festival of Britain (1951) whose design was over-
label: Paragraph

text: seen by the MARS group member Jane Drew, as lacking both the rough authen-
label: Paragraph

text: ticity that they found in British working class urban life and in the cultural and
label: Paragraph

text: urban vitality that they saw in continental Europe and in the cities of North Africa.
label: Paragraph

text: The Golden Lane project reflects this moment clearly: the Smithsons’ “urban re-
label: Paragraph

text: identification” CIAM grid for CIAM 9 in 1953 was structured to intentionally sub-
label: Paragraph

text: vert the grid’s rationalistic intentions and provoke new ways of thinking about
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism.’ Instead of the highly systematic format based on the CIAM “four func-
label: Paragraph

text: tions” of dwelling, work, transportation, and circulation, much of it quite influen-
label: Paragraph

text: tial in postwar planning internationally, at CIAM 9 the Smithsons instead suggested
label: Paragraph

text: reorganizing the CIAM grid with their new categories of “house, street, district,
label: Paragraph

text: and city.” They also implicitly questioned the uniform rationality of the grid pres-
label: Paragraph

text: entation by placing on theirs a series of photographs by Nigel Henderson that
label: Paragraph

text: showed street children playing in the Bethnal Green district of London’s East
label: Caption

text: End. As their activities as youth members in CIAM would soon make clear, the
label: Paragraph

text: Smithsons wanted to overturn the postwar consensus in CIAM about the validity
label: Paragraph

text: of the four functions and the authority of Le Corbusier’s The Athens Charter (1943), a
label: Paragraph

text: widely used codification of the results of the 1933 CIAM 4 conference on “The
label: Paragraph

text: Functional City.” They also sought to disrupt what they saw as the overly pater-
label: Paragraph

text: nalistic and officially apolitical workings of CIAM itself, controlled by a handful of
label: Paragraph

text: figures around Le Corbusier, such as its President from 1947 to 1956, Josep Lluis
label: Paragraph

text: Sert, and one of its Vice-Presidents, Walter Gropius, Chair of Architecture at the
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard Graduate School of Design from 1937 to 1951.°
label: Paragraph

text: Golden Lane and Team 10
label: Title

text: The Golden Lane project was one of the first projects of the group that became
label: Paragraph

text: Team 10, some of whose antecedents could be found in the Sigtuna, Sweden CIAM
label: Paragraph

text: meeting of 1952. There, Jacob Bakema (Holland), Aldo van Eyck (Holland),
label: Paragraph

text: William Howell (Britain), and Georges Candilis (France and Morocco), had begun
label: Paragraph

text: discussing the future of CIAM in light of postwar concerns about the “human hab-
label: Paragraph

text: itat” generally. At CIAM 9 in 1953, these men, joined by Shadrach Woods, found
label: Paragraph

text: that they shared some dissatisfactions with CIAM as it then existed with the young
label: Paragraph

text: British MARS group members John Voelcker and the Smithsons, who were invited
label: Paragraph

text: to CIAM 9 by Howell at the last minute. At that event, van Eyck vehemently
label: Paragraph

text: opposed Walter Gropius’ technocratic, American-based postwar architectural
label: Paragraph

text: views centered on prefabrication in CIAM. At the same time, the Moroccan hous-
label: Paragraph

text: ing work of Candilis and Woods exhibited there sharply raised the issue in CIAM of
label: Paragraph

text: design for what their ATBAT-Afrique associate Vladimir Bodiansky called “the
label: Paragraph

text: greater number,” the rapidly growing populations in industrial cities outside of
label: Paragraph

text: Europe.” Energized by a common sense of discontent with CLAM, this group then
label: Paragraph

text: began to meet as Team 10, and with some changes in membership issued the
label: Paragraph

text: “Doorn Manifesto” in 1954.'° They subsequently became famous in the 1960s after
label: Paragraph

text: the publication of Alison Smithson’s Team 10 Primer and the teaching of Team
label: Title

text: 10 members in architecture schools worldwide."
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to the aspirations of the older generation of CIAM to systematically
label: Paragraph

text: shape postwar urban development through legislation, pedagogy, and the exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of model projects, the new youth-oriented sensibility of the Smithsons and
label: Paragraph

text: Team 10 was more elusive. Disseminated in art exhibitions and events, publica-
label: Paragraph

text: tions, and charismatic design studio teaching, the irrational, surrealist-inspired qua-
label: Paragraph

text: lities of their work resonated widely in architecture in the late 1950s and early
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s, in an era of worldwide popularity for Hollywood films, rock and roll,
label: Paragraph

text: Coca-Cola, cigarettes, and other products of American consumer capitalism. Alison
label: Caption

text: Smithson praised American advertising in avant-garde London journals, particu-
label: Paragraph

text: larly the 1954 Cadillac advertising campaign,” and a photo cut-out of French movie
label: Paragraph

text: star Gerard Philippe appears in the Golden Lane photomontage where a prewar
label: Paragraph

text: worker might have been expected to stand. In another perspective of the project,
label: Paragraph

text: magazine cut-outs of movie star Marilyn Monroe and baseball star Joe Dimaggio
label: Caption

text: interact along the Corbusian pedestrian street deck.’* At the same time, the Smith-
label: Paragraph

text: sons claimed that the Golden Lane project would recover the structure of London
label: Paragraph

text: working-class urban living. Its streets in the air would retain a “vital relationship”
label: Paragraph

text: between the house (recast as two-story Corbusian flats with outdoor open spaces)
label: Caption

text: and the street, allowing residents to feel a sense of ownership of more than just
label: Paragraph

text: their individual apartments.’
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, in their many publications about the project, the Smithsons
label: Paragraph

text: noted how the plan of the Golden Lane project evoked the loose, “all-over” quality
label: Paragraph

text: of Jackson Pollack’s recent drip paintings, which they much admired, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: how its non-orthogonal and open-ended structure of “streets in the air” was like
label: Paragraph

text: that of the London sewer and drainage system. Using the concept of tall slab build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings linked by open pedestrian decks — already present in some of Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: earlier unbuilt urban projects’’ — the Smithsons suggested with the Golden Lane
label: Paragraph

text: project that war-destroyed European cities could be rebuilt as continuously linked
label: Paragraph

text: activity zones, where modernist housing units would add up to form larger urban
label: Paragraph

text: districts of pedestrian social vitality. These zones would encourage “human asso-
label: Paragraph

text: ciation” and would provide a sense of “identity” for the residents — key concepts
label: Paragraph

text: that the Smithsons introduced to architectural discourse with the Golden Lane
label: Paragraph

text: project.’®
label: Paragraph

text: Many of the other basic premises of the Golden Lane project were not new.
label: Paragraph

text: Most European cities were then rapidly constructing a new, modernist-inspired
label: Paragraph

text: urban social environment centered on mass housing and based (in Western
label: Paragraph

text: Europe at least) on the values of the democratic socialist welfare state, of which
label: Paragraph

text: Sweden was then the prime example. While prewar debates in European and
label: Paragraph

text: American cities still continued after the war about the virtues — social or eco-
label: Paragraph

text: nomic — of high-rise versus low-rise housing, until the 1960s there was extensive
label: Paragraph

text: international agreement about the general applicability of the urban strategies of
label: Paragraph

text: modem architecture. At CIAM 9, the Smithsons’ Golden Lane project was pre-
label: Paragraph

text: sented in the context of four other grids by older MARS (British CIAM) group
label: Paragraph

text: members for urban housing projects, including Chamberlin, Powell, and Bon’s
label: Paragraph

text: winning scheme for the Golden Lane site, a series of mid-rise housing blocks
label: Caption

text: with one high-rise, all facing a series of courtyards, and each provided with a
label: Paragraph

text: local community center.'? Another MARS project shown at CIAM 9 was the
label: Paragraph

text: more directly Le Corbusier-inspired slabs of the redevelopment project for
label: Paragraph

text: the Alton Estate, Roehampton, by a London County Council (LCC) Architects’
label: Paragraph

text: team led by J. Leslie Martin, who in 1956 would be appointed Professor of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture at Cambridge University. In the design of the Alton Estate the
label: Paragraph

text: LCC Architects had divided into two factions, one favoring the Swedish modern
label: Paragraph

text: direction (called “new empiricism” by the editor of the Architectural Review, J. M.
label: Paragraph

text: Richards), which used brick and pitched roofs, and sometimes vaguely evoked
label: Paragraph

text: other traditional forms, while the other LCC group advocated Corbusian-
label: Paragraph

text: inspired concrete slab blocks, like Le Corbusier’s own recently completed Unité
label: Paragraph

text: d’Habitation in Marseille (1945-52). This second LCC Architects faction was less
label: Paragraph

text: overtly political — the new empiricism was then associated in Britain with left-
label: Paragraph

text: wing socialism — and it included William Howell, Colin St. John Wilson, and
label: Paragraph

text: Alan Colquhoun, whose Corbusian leanings would soon make them interested
label: Paragraph

text: in, if not always fully convinced by, the urban ideas of the Smithsons and
label: Paragraph

text: Team 10.
label: Title

text: The Smithsons’ Golden Lane project differed from these four built London high-
label: Paragraph

text: rise slum clearance housing projects in its novel presentation techniques, which
label: Paragraph

text: spurned the precise social and technical data on which CIAM had attempted to base
label: Paragraph

text: its work in favor of what Banham described as an “aformal” engagement with art
label: Paragraph

text: and popular culture. It also went beyond those projects in linking Corbusian high-
label: Paragraph

text: rise housing slabs into a large urban network of pedestrian circulation. This was
label: Paragraph

text: well before Fumihiko Maki would coin the term “megastructure” to describe such
label: Paragraph

text: projects a decade later, a term that Banham would then popularize in the 1970s.'*
label: Paragraph

text: Although they themselves were unable to construct any such projects until 1966,
label: Paragraph

text: the Smithsons had made further elaborations of the idea in unbuilt competition
label: Paragraph

text: entries for Sheffield University (1953)'° and in their entry to the Berlin Hauptstadt
label: Paragraph

text: (Capital City) competition in 1957-58, designed with a German associate, Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Sigmond.”° Although their team was awarded only third place in that competition,
label: Paragraph

text: their well-publicized project was intended to suggest a new urban structure that
label: Paragraph

text: would “give the motorist and the pedestrian equal rights to freedom of move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment.” This echoed the demand in postwar West Berlin for a rebuilt city that “does
label: Paragraph

text: justice to the car,” and in their Berlin Hauptstadt project the Smithsons elaborated
label: Paragraph

text: their concept of continuous pedestrian street decks, suggesting that these be built
label: Paragraph

text: over what remained of the street grid of the heavily bombed central city. Their
label: Paragraph

text: project indicated that these streets should be the channels for auto traffic and casual
label: Paragraph

text: parking, while various new and existing cultural institutions would be accessed by
label: Paragraph

text: continuously running escalators to the upper level pedestrian deck 30 meters
label: Caption

text: above.”
label: Paragraph

text: Pedestrian Urbanism and Modern Architecture
label: Title

text: This new focus on urban pedestrian experience and mixed use activity in urban
label: Paragraph

text: centers was not in itself introduced into modern urbanism by the Smithsons
label: Paragraph

text: and Team 10, though they often presented it that way in their many publications.
label: Paragraph

text: Like some other revisionist modern urban proposals of the same time, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Edmund Bacon and Louis Kahn’s proposals for Center City Philadelphia, which
label: Paragraph

text: began with Kahn’s Triangle District project of 1946-48, or Victor Gruen’s influen-
label: Paragraph

text: tial downtown pedestrianization proposal, A Greater Fort Worth Tomorrow (1956),
label: Paragraph

text: the Smithsons’ projects also rejected prewar modern urban functionalism, which
label: Paragraph

text: typically denigrated existing pedestrian streets and the mixing of functions. All
label: Paragraph

text: these proposals were similar in attempting to bring suburban residents back to
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian center city areas, assuming that most pedestrians would no longer live
label: Paragraph

text: nearby but would arrive by train or car from the new suburbs. At the same time,
label: Paragraph

text: their Berlin Hauptstadt project made it clear that the Smithsons had a radically dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferent attitude than Sert, Gropius, Kahn, or Gruen about how urban pedestrian
label: Paragraph

text: experience should be shaped. In the Smithsons’ Berlin project, the raised street
label: Paragraph

text: decks suggest a new pedestrian world of changing views and multiple new experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ences, and it and Golden Lane became the source for many such projects then actu-
label: Paragraph

text: ally constructed by others.
label: Paragraph

text: These included many British urban and university projects designed along sim-
label: Paragraph

text: ilar lines, including the Park Hill public housing project in Sheffield (1957-61), a
label: Paragraph

text: direct and successful application of the Golden Lane concept by the Sheffield City
label: Paragraph

text: Architects Department J. Lewis Womersley, Jack Lynn, and Ivor Smith),”’ and
label: Paragraph

text: Denys Lasdun’s University of East Anglia, Norwich (1963-66),”* a classic example
label: Paragraph

text: of the Smithsons’ megastructural campus idea that would also be widely imitated
label: Paragraph

text: in North America in the 1960s. Lasdun’s work, a departure from his earlier CIAM-
label: Paragraph

text: inspired slab housing with detached public facilities, was praised by the Smithsons,
label: Paragraph

text: indicating the complete triumph of the ideas first put forward in their Golden Lane
label: Paragraph

text: project over the earlier CIAM planning concepts favored by the older generation of
label: Paragraph

text: MARS group members.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Smithsons’ Berlin Hauptstadt proposal appeared just after Sert had launched
label: Paragraph

text: the new design discipline at the First Harvard Urban Design conference in 1956,
label: Paragraph

text: which included presentations by Gruen of his Fort Worth proposal and by Bacon
label: Paragraph

text: of Kahn’s Mill Creek public housing redevelopment in West Philadelphia. At this
label: Paragraph

text: event Sert advocated adapting Corbusian high-density urbanism to create islands of
label: Paragraph

text: pedestrian activity at the heart of American cities, accepting that cars were becom-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the normative form of postwar middle-class transportation, but also advocating
label: Paragraph

text: the retention of urban pedestrian vitality in that era of massive, Federally-funded
label: Paragraph

text: decentralization. While Sert and the Smithsons were profoundly opposed to each
label: Paragraph

text: other in the context of late CIAM, as the Golden Lane project demonstrated, both
label: Paragraph

text: shared an interest in proposing projects that attempted to adapt or extend Corbu-
label: Paragraph

text: sian urbanism to create more vital urban environments, evident in Sert’s choice of a
label: Paragraph

text: perspective of Le Corbusier’s Antwerp project (1934) as the first image in the pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lication of the First Harvard Urban Design conference.”*
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, the Smithsons and their fellow CIAM youth members who
label: Paragraph

text: formed Team 10 in 1954 realized that North American and European urban condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions were developing in sharply differing ways. Team 10 sought to suggest urban
label: Paragraph

text: approaches that engaged what they saw as the more nuanced and complex Western
label: Paragraph

text: European and North African situation, and for the most part they disregarded Sert’s
label: Paragraph

text: and other North American efforts to encourage university and government spon-
label: Paragraph

text: sored responses to the changing conditions of postwar central cities. With the excep-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of Louis Kahn’s mostly unbuilt urban ideas for Center City Philadelphia, which
label: Paragraph

text: were admired by both Sert and Team 10, the Smithsons and their Team 10 collea-
label: Paragraph

text: gues ignored the emergence of Sert’s new discipline of urban design, leaving con-
label: Paragraph

text: siderable historical confusion even today about the many ideals that they shared.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead of Sert’s urban design approach, easily dismissed by more radical young
label: Paragraph

text: architects at the time as the product of elite master planners and powerful centra-
label: Paragraph

text: lized American business interests, the Smithsons sought to develop a more vernac-
label: Paragraph

text: ular-based direction, inspired to some extent by their awareness of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: debates in postwar Japan. In 1955 in “The New Brutalism,” Architectural Design’s
label: Paragraph

text: editors had called attention to how the Smithsons had sought the “harmony
label: Paragraph

text: between buildings and man” often found in traditional Japanese architecture, by
label: Paragraph

text: looking to “peasant dwelling forms,” which had “a poetry without rhetoric.”?”
label: Paragraph

text: The New Brutalism soon resonated in Japan, where a politically charged cultural
label: Paragraph

text: debate (prompted by the Paris-trained painter Taro Okamoto) opposed the ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese cultures of the traditional Yayoi and the earlier hunter-gather Jomon.
label: Paragraph

text: Under Okamoto’s influence, the Japanese CIAM member Kenzo Tange, whose
label: Paragraph

text: Hiroshima Peace Center was the first work by a “non-Western” architect to be
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited in CIAM (at CIAM 8 in 1951), made a widely publicized effort to reconcile
label: Paragraph

text: these two directions. Yayoi at the time became strongly identified with the Western
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiasm (exemplified by Frank Lloyd Wright’s early work) for traditional Jap-
label: Paragraph

text: anese culture, with its architecture of spatial openness and modulor platform based
label: Paragraph

text: structures, but by the mid-1950s Yayoi had also become suggestive to many Japa-
label: Paragraph

text: nese of the cultural strategies of the American military occupation (1945-52).
label: Paragraph

text: A critical reaction emerged that evoked the more marginal ancient JOmon culture,
label: Paragraph

text: which was identified with early pit dwellings and decorative ceramic pottery, and it
label: Paragraph

text: acquired an aura of cultural resistance, especially among students.”
label: Paragraph

text: Tange himself remained somewhat tied to the Yayoi direction, especially in his
label: Paragraph

text: Hiroshima project, but in 1960, just as CIAM was being supplanted by Team 10,
label: Paragraph

text: Tange began to suggest that a synthesis of Yayoi and Jomon might best exemplify post-
label: Paragraph

text: war Japanese modern architecture. After being an invited participant at the Tear 10-
label: Paragraph

text: organized CIAM’59 in Otterlo event and a visiting critic at MIT in 1959, Tange played
label: Paragraph

text: a leading role in the 1960 Tokyo World Design Conference. For this event he pre-
label: Paragraph

text: sented on Japanese network television his ambitious, 30 km-long megastructural pro-
label: Paragraph

text: posal for new mixed-use development over Tokyo Bay, a response to the rapid
label: Paragraph

text: overdevelopment of central Tokyo.” The project was a further development of
label: Paragraph

text: the megastructures of his Boston MIT studio project, and was meant as a serious
label: Paragraph

text: response to Tokyo development pressures in the rapidly expanding Japanese cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Returning to its earlier importance as commercial and administrative center after the
label: Paragraph

text: massive destructions of the 1923 earthquake and the wartime fire bombings, by 1960
label: Paragraph

text: Toyko had surpassed New York City as the world’s largest city, and corporate and
label: Paragraph

text: government figures there were highly receptive to Tange’s new urban concepts.””
label: Paragraph

text: Tange also instigated the formation of the group of younger architects known as
label: Paragraph

text: the Metabolists, who included the architects Kiyonori Kikutake and Kisho Kuro-
label: Paragraph

text: kawa, the graphic designer Kiyoshi Awazu, and the critic Noboru Kawazoe; these
label: Paragraph

text: figures were soon joined by Fumihiko Maki, a Toyko architect and Harvard stu-
label: Paragraph

text: dent of Sert then teaching at Washington University in St. Louis. Tange and the
label: Paragraph

text: Metabolists further extended in varying ways the concepts already evident in
label: Paragraph

text: the urban structuring work of the Smithsons, Bakema, and Candilis-Josic- Woods,
label: Paragraph

text: further emphasizing the idea of the plant-like urban growth and the need to design
label: Paragraph

text: for change in urban environments over time. In all their work, relatively perma-
label: Paragraph

text: nent urban elements like highways, rail lines, and elevator shafts were seen as
label: Paragraph

text: similar to the trunks or spines of plants, trees, and other organisms, while the indi-
label: Paragraph

text: vidual housing units and commercial and office uses attached to them were
label: Paragraph

text: designed to be easily changed or replaced as necessary.
label: Paragraph

text: The World Design Conference was also attended by many invited Western
label: Paragraph

text: architects, who included Alison and Peter Smithson, Louis Kahn, Paul Rudolph,
label: Paragraph

text: Minoru Yamasaki, and Jean Prouvé. Immediately afterward, Candilis invited Maki
label: Paragraph

text: to the first Team 10 meeting after CIAM ’59, held near a Candilis-Josic-woods hous-
label: Paragraph

text: ing project at Bagnols-sur-Céze, France, in 1960. Soon after, Maki coined the term
label: Paragraph

text: “megastructure” to describe urban projects like those of Tange and the Smithsons.
label: Paragraph

text: Maki and his collaborator Masao Otaka (a design associate of Japanese CIAM mem-
label: Paragraph

text: ber Kunio Maekawa from 1947 to 1961) began to generate a variant of Metabolism
label: Paragraph

text: that they called “group form,” which was less reliant on heavy interconnecting infra-
label: Paragraph

text: structure and based on the use of repetitive, often traditional and vernacular, ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments to generate and maintain a consistent overall urban image, like that of a
label: Paragraph

text: Greek island village.” Team 10 continued to explore and debate such urban struc-
label: Paragraph

text: turing concepts in its subsequent meetings, including the one held at Abbaye Roy-
label: Paragraph

text: aumont near Paris in 1962, where James Stirling presented his Archigram-influenced
label: Paragraph

text: Leicester Engineering Building and Kisho Kurokawa his idea of a “capsule tower.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Smithsons and Candilis-Josic-Woods continued to advocate large urban mega-
label: Paragraph

text: structural urban projects of the kind that the French Team 10 firm was then actually
label: Paragraph

text: building, at Toulouse-le-Mirail and elsewhere, based on ideas of pedestrian “stems”
label: Paragraph

text: organized into large “webs” of housing, commerce, and social services.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Royaumont Team 10 meeting also caused a rupture between the Smithsons
label: Paragraph

text: and Aldo van Eyck and his student Piet Blom. Among the many presentations of
label: Paragraph

text: new urban concepts at that meeting, van Eyck offered Blom’s “Noah’s Ark” proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect, a proposal for large scale development near Amsterdam that consisted entirely
label: Paragraph

text: of low-rise, complexly interwoven urban uses and circulation inspired by the “lab-
label: Paragraph

text: ytinthine clarity” of North African urban Kasbahs. The Smithsons were dismissive
label: Paragraph

text: of the project, suggesting that its tightly woven urban design was too controlling
label: Paragraph

text: and “completely fascist.” Although this ended Blom’s involvement with Team 10,
label: Paragraph

text: his Noah’s Ark project inspired Le Corbusier’s design associate Guillermo Jullien
label: Paragraph

text: de la Fuente, who was also present at Royaumont, to use a similar approach in the
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier office’s Venice Hospital project (1963), and Blom’s ideas also seem to
label: Paragraph

text: have affinities with Candilis-Josic- Woods’ Frankfurt-R6merburg competition proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect (1963), the first use of the “mat building” concept that they would then build at
label: Paragraph

text: the Berlin Free University campus (1965).7
label: Caption

text: By that point many of the directions in modern architecture that had begun with
label: Paragraph

text: the Golden Lane project had transformed urban thinking in the field. Sert himself
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to acknowledge this with his invitation to Maki and Shadrach Woods to
label: Paragraph

text: teach in the Harvard Urban Design program in the mid-1960s, with Woods making
label: Paragraph

text: an important speech on architects’ responsibilities to design and think globally at
label: Paragraph

text: the Twelfth Harvard Urban Design conference in 1968.°* Within Team 10 itself,
label: Paragraph

text: the Anglo-Swedish architect Ralph Erskine extended and improved the Smithsons’
label: Paragraph

text: Golden Lane concept at his Byker redevelopment project in Newcastle, continuing
label: Paragraph

text: its emphasis on continuous pedestrian circulation and vernacular expression in
label: Paragraph

text: both its curving slab blocks and a variety of low-rise housing types.””
label: Paragraph

text: After the Master Plan
label: Title

text: Yet the triumph of Team 10 urban concepts in the 1960s also began to shift the focus
label: Paragraph

text: of the field away from specific urban design concepts toward broader political and
label: Paragraph

text: cultural concerns about the urban environment. As early as 1959, Reyner Banham
label: Paragraph

text: had introduced concepts from the situationist group into urbanism, questioning the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar CIAM emphasis on compactly designed urban cores, which he described as
label: Paragraph

text: being like an “egg.” Inspired by the situationist idea of “psycho-geographical drift,”
label: Paragraph

text: the experiencing of the urban environment as a series of mental states, in 1959
label: Paragraph

text: Banham advocated instead the idea of “The City as Scrambled Egg.” He suggested
label: Paragraph

text: that a complete transformation of architects’ core and periphery urban model was
label: Paragraph

text: then emerging in auto-based American metropolitan areas like Los Angeles, with
label: Paragraph

text: their dispersed new popular centers such as drive-in cinemas, shopping malls, and
label: Paragraph

text: suburban schools.”* By the 1960s, Team 10 and its successor groups like Archigram
label: Paragraph

text: could argue that their urban concepts could be seen as vital pedestrian elements
label: Paragraph

text: within this pattern, concepts that often took the form of new campus environments
label: Paragraph

text: in the higher education boom of those years. Large regional airports also began to be
label: Paragraph

text: reshaped along similar lines, though, even then, these were more controlled envir-
label: Paragraph

text: onments than what Team 10 and the Metabolists has envisioned. Nonetheless they
label: Paragraph

text: used many of these urban structuring concepts, notably at Gyo Obata’s pioneering
label: Paragraph

text: Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport (DFW), designed in 1965 with his St. Louis
label: Paragraph

text: based firm of HOK,’’ which was subsequently widely imitated elsewhere.
label: Paragraph

text: Enthusiasm among architects for these Golden Lane inspired directions began to
label: Paragraph

text: wane by the 1970s, in many cases because of the opposition of local residents and
label: Paragraph

text: an emerging dissatisfaction with large government initiatives generally. In response
label: Paragraph

text: architects began to transpose some of the goals the Smithsons had written on their large
label: Paragraph

text: sectional drawing of the Golden Lane project — “site, circulation, habitation, human
label: Caption

text: presence” — into less architectonic and perhaps more realizable efforts for neighbor-
label: Paragraph

text: hood development, community design, and historic preservation, often in existing
label: Paragraph

text: urban neighborhoods. An ironic outcome of this changed atmosphere was that when
label: Paragraph

text: the Smithsons were finally able to build a scaled-down version of the Golden Lane con-
label: Paragraph

text: cept as their Robin Hood Gardens housing project in London (1966-72),** centered on
label: Paragraph

text: a green mound made of the rubble from demolished buildings on the site, it seemed to
label: Paragraph

text: many architects as simply another brutalist Corbusian high-rise slab project.
label: Paragraph

text: “The making of this church entailed covering extensive ground ... how should that
label: Paragraph

text: (ground) form be, within which one prays?” So asked Alberto Cruz in his 1954
label: Paragraph

text: introduction to the presentation of this little chapel designed between 1952 and
label: Caption

text: 1953.’ Although it was never built, the scheme stands as a key example of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in Chile, and was arguably a source of inspiration for Martin and Guar-
label: Paragraph

text: da’s 1961-64 Benedictine chapel in Santiago, which is generally recognized as a
label: Paragraph

text: highlight of the modern period.”
label: Paragraph

text: The project was conceived almost in parallel with the urban scheme for Achu-
label: Paragraph

text: pallas Vifia del Mar (1953), where Cruz was exploring a significant urban strategy
label: Paragraph

text: for 50,000 inhabitants as a fully integrated district — an alternative to the requested
label: Paragraph

text: satellite workers housing concept. These projects therefore covered the full profes-
label: Paragraph

text: sional spectrum, one at the lesser scale of building and the other at the geographical
label: Paragraph

text: scale of urban infrastructures. Coincidentally, they also shared a distinct geometric
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis and a formal economy that rendered them easily memorable. A cubic
label: Paragraph

text: system made the chapel, whereas a straight axis with the status and quality of
label: Paragraph

text: an urban sign became the fulcrum of the Achupallas urban scheme, somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: recalling Le Corbusier’s viaducts for Rio de Janeiro.
label: Paragraph

text: The Valparaiso School of Architecture
label: Title

text: These schemes, together with the architect’s own statement, became something of
label: Paragraph

text: a manifesto for the Valparaiso School of Architecture where Alberto Cruz was lead-
label: Paragraph

text: ing a highly innovative program of studies that had just been initiated in 1952.’ This
label: Paragraph

text: institution was being conceived along unusual lines for an architectural school.
label: Paragraph

text: Firmly committed to the modern project, it was nevertheless cautious about its
label: Paragraph

text: functionalist bias, and outright critical about the idea of a “modern style.” Their
label: Paragraph

text: attitude was characterized by an interest in ritual and social practices (rather than
label: Paragraph

text: program or function), a conviction about the preeminence of direct observation,
label: Paragraph

text: and a commitment to the creation of a new architecture. Later, these commitments
label: Paragraph

text: lead the Valparaiso group on to the design of several churches and religious insti-
label: Paragraph

text: tutions, notably the 1960 master plan for the Benedictine Monastery in Santiago
label: Paragraph

text: (unrealized) and a handful of churches erected in Southern Chile as a contribution
label: Paragraph

text: to the reconstruction efforts that followed a devastating earthquake in the same
label: Paragraph

text: year." The articulation of professional and school activities became an objective,
label: Paragraph

text: and it is within that context that the arguments and presentations of the Pajaritos
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel were delivered to the school. This presentation also honored the group’s
label: Paragraph

text: professed conviction about the essential public-ness of the architect’s métier.
label: Paragraph

text: Further reinforcing their status as guiding models of a committed design prac-
label: Paragraph

text: tice, Pajaritos and Achupallas were compiled together with other selected projects
label: Paragraph

text: and studies in a volume produced for the school that was significantly entitled Foun-
label: Paragraph

text: dations (Fundamentos de la Escuela de Arquitectura, 1971). Here were not only the
label: Paragraph

text: chapel, the Achupallas urban scheme, and a collective scheme for Valparaiso’s
label: Paragraph

text: waterfront, but also studies on the Pacific Ocean and the southern fiords that char-
label: Paragraph

text: tered historical voyages and contemporary traffic patterns. The volume also
label: Paragraph

text: included the school’s 1967 proclamation for the reform of the university that pre-
label: Paragraph

text: ceded the revolutionary events of 1968 in Paris and elsewhere, denouncing the
label: Paragraph

text: authorities and the servility to imported models, and calling for the free contem-
label: Paragraph

text: plation and study of the Latin American reality.
label: Paragraph

text: Located on farmland on the outskirts of Santiago (the area is now fully urba-
label: Paragraph

text: nized), the chapel was placed within the luscious irrigated plains that characterize
label: Paragraph

text: the valley and its temperate climate. Facing forking country roads, it stood against a
label: Paragraph

text: background of trees, silos, workshops, and stables. It was raised six steps above the
label: Paragraph

text: dirt road and preceded by a podium that acted as its atrium. This raised platform
label: Paragraph

text: solved the symbolic and actual distinction between the secular space of agrarian
label: Paragraph

text: labors and the sacred ground. It was a modest scheme: the interior only measured
label: Paragraph

text: 106.7 square meters.
label: Caption

text: Always bathed in sunlight, its main front was oriented due north-west and slightly
label: Paragraph

text: askew as regards the shaded main road, where the trees and towering silos rose way
label: Paragraph

text: above the chapel’s height of 8.85 meters. The cube — its primary feature — was artic-
label: Paragraph

text: ulated at different scales. First was the chapel proper, measuring 10.5 x9 x 8.85 meters,
label: Paragraph

text: with the podium extending forward another 10 meters and its flanks strictly aligned to
label: Paragraph

text: it. On axes to the entrance, a 1.9-meter cubic niche resting on a square base and slightly
label: Paragraph

text: raised from the podium sheltered a devotional image of the Virgin. The 3.5-meter sac-
label: Paragraph

text: risty cube was located to the left; with its independent entrance, the sacristy offered a
label: Paragraph

text: secondary access. Perched upon the main cornice and coinciding with the cube’s apex,
label: Paragraph

text: there was a cubic belfry, 1.75 meters on each side, its metal lattices drawing eight
label: Paragraph

text: empty cubes against the background of the sky. As all the main elements conformed
label: Paragraph

text: to a strict orthogonal matrix, every contour was sharp and rectilinear.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite its undeniable simplicity the project embodies a certain density of
label: Paragraph

text: thought about modern architecture, its potentials, and the possibility of its realiza-
label: Paragraph

text: tion within any given environment, program, or budget. A particular consciousness
label: Paragraph

text: about place, ambiances, and ritual also characterized it, as became explicit in the
label: Paragraph

text: extensive written commentaries that were to follow. These considerations ranged
label: Paragraph

text: from the phenomenal to the symbolic and prosaic. Any effort to disentangle its
label: Paragraph

text: various levels of definition becomes futile, for all of them concur in a single syn-
label: Paragraph

text: thetic whole.
label: Paragraph

text: Light as a Prime Material
label: Title

text: The manipulation of daylight within became fundamental to the creation of its
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate ambiance. To this end, clerestory lights were arranged all around the
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter, while ceiling contours supplied light deflectors so as to avoid direct sun-
label: Paragraph

text: light. Even though light was to be a prime material, care was taken to de-dramatize
label: Paragraph

text: its effect; efforts were made to create a propitious atmosphere rather than the
label: Paragraph

text: theatricality that was sought in so many contemporary churches. Wall surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: would have been bathed in a soft and rather homogenous light. Cruz also observed
label: Paragraph

text: in traditional farmhouse interiors how, given the harshness and intensity of natural
label: Paragraph

text: ight (located in latitude 33.27 south, Santiago, would coincide with Casablanca,
label: Paragraph

text: Morocco 33.32 north), small crevices between slightly open shutters sufficed to sup-
label: Paragraph

text: ply a subtle and agreeable twilight. Consequently, the main reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: doors were also conceived as light diffusers. Small doors inscribed within the large
label: Paragraph

text: ones could calibrate the light’s quality and intensity. The homogeneity of door and
label: Paragraph

text: wall materials reinforced the monolithic cubic quality, although slight differences in
label: Paragraph

text: hue and texture were induced through finishes: white concrete for interior renders
label: Paragraph

text: in walls and doors, white paint for exterior renders, oil paint for all metal elements.
label: Paragraph

text: Finishes were to be tested on-site for possible adjustments.
label: Paragraph

text: Acoustic considerations combined with geometric and perceptual concerns in
label: Paragraph

text: the definition of the precise outlines that at one stage included consultations about
label: Paragraph

text: the type of optical correctives usually discussed for Greek temples.
label: Paragraph

text: Against this seemingly purist agenda, Cruz evinced a relaxed attitude as regards
label: Paragraph

text: significant elements such as the icons and the altar, which were to be supplied by the
label: Paragraph

text: client. Overcoming stylistic anxieties, and despite their heterogeneity or potential
label: Paragraph

text: discordance with accepted “modern” canons, these were to be simply incorporated.
label: Paragraph

text: What mattered was not so much stylistic consistency but the consistency of the prop-
label: Paragraph

text: osition as a setting ready to articulate diverse devotional expressions. Hence the ico-
label: Paragraph

text: nography of the chapel did not — as would have been the common expectation —
label: Paragraph

text: become specially commissioned for the occasion. Other “as found” parts comprised
label: Paragraph

text: wooden steps and some recycled materials such as the stone that was to cover the
label: Paragraph

text: floors. Geometric precision did not preclude diverse devotional expressions.
label: Paragraph

text: A Background for Outdoor Ceremonies
label: Caption

text: The chapel’s reduced scale guaranteed the required intimacy of an interior that was
label: Paragraph

text: usually to be devoted to solitary prayer and meditation. Articulating this interior
label: Paragraph

text: domain with the open atrium, the large doors folded outward so that, embracing
label: Paragraph

text: the atrium, the chapel became the backdrop for large outdoor ceremonies in a man-
label: Paragraph

text: ner not unlike the tradition of Spanish colonial open-air chapels.
label: Paragraph

text: Consisting of a rough brick masonry framed in reinforced concrete pillars and
label: Paragraph

text: beams, the main structure conformed to low-cost structural anti-seismic conven-
label: Paragraph

text: tional practice. Resting upon steel girders, simple beams, their timbers salvaged
label: Paragraph

text: from older constructions, made the roof structure. The copping detail allowed
label: Paragraph

text: for on-site adjustment if required for a final tuning of the proportions. The design
label: Paragraph

text: was conceived for realization by non-specialized labor.
label: Paragraph

text: The practice of observation included formal, tectonic, behavioral, and ritual
label: Paragraph

text: issues. Drawing from his concerns about ritual, Cruz had already decided that
label: Paragraph

text: in this chapel the position of the official was to be face-to-face with the assembly;
label: Paragraph

text: this was some time in advance of the II Vatican Council (1962-65) where this prin-
label: Paragraph

text: ciple was endorsed together with the adoption of vernacular language and various
label: Paragraph

text: levels of liturgical renovation.’
label: Paragraph

text: Pondering the issues involved in making the chapel, Cruz made reference to
label: Paragraph

text: Notre Dame in Paris where the simultaneous presence of diverse interior elements
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to concur in inducing a corporeal and spiritual mood that was particularly
label: Paragraph

text: apt for prayer. Reflecting upon this observation, he stated that the orchestration of
label: Paragraph

text: those interior conditions operated in a manner that was analogous to the way we
label: Paragraph

text: experience the beach, where the surfaces of sand place us — body and mind — in an
label: Paragraph

text: expectant relationship to the sea. Criticizing the extensive deployment of design
label: Paragraph

text: features and theatrical effects that were common to the average modern church
label: Paragraph

text: project, he set himself the task of achieving that mood with a handful of materials
label: Paragraph

text: and a precise deployment of form, divesting his design of any excess.
label: Paragraph

text: The chapel was never realized. It stands as a highlight of the first period of activ-
label: Paragraph

text: ities of the Valparaiso Group. In addition to the strictly academic occupations
label: Paragraph

text: involved in devising new study methods and the school curricula, several profes-
label: Paragraph

text: sional projects were pursued in this early period, thus relating teaching and prac-
label: Paragraph

text: tice; but very few could be realized. A second period of activities was inaugurated
label: Paragraph

text: with the creation of the “Open City” in 1970, a sort of experimental ground that
label: Paragraph

text: was established on an extra-urban tract of land fronting the Pacific Ocean that com-
label: Paragraph

text: prised 270 hectares of land. Here the relationship between living, working, and
label: Paragraph

text: teaching would become even more intense, as most building activity summoned
label: Paragraph

text: the efforts of students and tutors alike. Within the Open City every construction
label: Paragraph

text: would be a special product of research.®
label: Paragraph

text: The relationship between extreme formal rigor and elementary building meth-
label: Paragraph

text: ods was pursued in some of these buildings, notably in the Music House, an
label: Paragraph

text: inward-looking room lit through a single light column placed somewhat off center.
label: Paragraph

text: Light ambiance rather than spectacular views (the Music House stands near the
label: Paragraph

text: shoreline) was a prime subject. The enclosure was devised to keep the roar of
label: Paragraph

text: waves away while fostering the right mood for experiencing musical performances.
label: Paragraph

text: As in Pajaritos, the simple interior accommodates different modes of use while the
label: Paragraph

text: scale is such as to preclude a sense of solitude.
label: Paragraph

text: Distancing himself from the idea of totality implied in the Gesamtkunstwork, Cruz
label: Paragraph

text: welcomed constraints and contributions. Likewise, the urban conception of the
label: Paragraph

text: Achupallas scheme hinged upon the correct delineation of an urban avenue that
label: Paragraph

text: maintained a steady incline in its transit from hill to seashore. Its flanking system of
label: Paragraph

text: terraces organized the topography, solving all transverse links and transactions. There
label: Paragraph

text: was no prescription about style for the buildings to be erected, simply an acceptance of
label: Paragraph

text: things as they are, and a conviction about the value of its inscription within the acci-
label: Paragraph

text: dental terrain, its declared linkage to the Pacific shore and its urban status.
label: Paragraph

text: As we have seen, in Pajaritos there was no anxiety about the nature and quality
label: Paragraph

text: of devotional elements: it was the strength of the atmosphere that would keep this
label: Paragraph

text: intimate world infused with the mood of prayer.
label: Paragraph
