text: WHY PUT A COLLAGE IN A BOOK ON
label: Paragraph

text: MODERN ARCHITECTURE?
label: Title

text: Why discuss a collage in a book on modern architecture? This chapter seeks to
label: Paragraph

text: account for the ingress of The Naked City, a 1957 print, into architecture culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Has any other particular work of art held quite such a sway for quite so long in the
label: Paragraph

text: neighboring medium of architecture?
label: Title

text: Works of art do have a talismanic effect for architects. Cubist works, for instance,
label: Paragraph

text: had a long and profound impact on architecture (and can be sensed too in The
label: Paragraph

text: Naked City). In the same decade as The Naked City’s creation, Jackson Pollock
label: Paragraph

text: showed architects an “aleatory” aesthetic; art brut’s exponents, like Jean Dubuftet,
label: Paragraph

text: suggested textures for architectural brutalism; pop art pointed forward to postmod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern collage. The grid — a motif from the Italian Renaissance depiction of The Ideal
label: Paragraph

text: City (1480-84, attributed to Fra Carnevale) to the abstract paintings of Piet Mon-
label: Paragraph

text: drian — was fundamental to the modern spirit in architecture exemplified, say, in Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's Ville Radieuse (1924).
label: Paragraph

text: The Ville Radieuse is a good place to pause this brief inventory, though, because
label: Paragraph

text: it was exactly its rationalist mathematical repetition that The Naked City opposed.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ville Radieuse was a provocation; The Naked City was a response. The former
label: Paragraph

text: intrigued postwar planners, and the latter intrigues their successors. In the couple
label: Paragraph

text: of decades following the Second World War, grids extended like carpets and cur-
label: Paragraph

text: tains across the plans and elevations of reconstructed and redeveloped buildings
label: Paragraph

text: and cities. The grids of postwar urbanism were calm and clinical in a way which
label: Paragraph

text: defied that cubist vigor revived in the 1950s by The Naked City, art brut, abstract
label: Paragraph

text: expressionism, and pop, whose virtual spaces were not those of the grid’s linear and
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal and repetitive relation, but of seeming overlap and contingency:
label: Paragraph

text: vanguard art in the 1950s was strenuously of the moment, as though unfolding
label: Paragraph

text: in time. This admitted the possibility of change, of history, otherwise seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: come to an “end” in some Hegelian grand resolution of all art and all buildings
label: Paragraph

text: and all cities subjected to the grid. History is still propelled, in The Naked City
label: Paragraph

text: as in abstract expressionism and art brut and pop, by a human subjectivity with
label: Paragraph

text: its unruly desires that only pretend to conform to the iron law of grids and their
label: Paragraph

text: reason. Spatially, temporally, cognitively, postwar aesthetics suggested the rein-
label: Paragraph

text: vention of architectural epistemology.
label: Paragraph

text: That said, features particular to The Naked City were at best only implicit in the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar avant-garde at large. The first was The Naked City’s topic: the city. Here,
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps for the first time since the postwar triumph of the grid, an artistic intelli-
label: Paragraph

text: gentsia was rethinking the city as an experience and as a work of art whose affect
label: Paragraph

text: was not simply of built forms (buildings) but of events (the life of citizens). The
label: Paragraph

text: Naked City simply collaged an existing street atlas, as though assigning to its cit-
label: Paragraph

text: izen-observers (who may or may not be trained in the arts of government and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture) the task of making the city of the future. The invitation was literally
label: Paragraph

text: anarchic, a memorandum about the greater possibilities of modernity. And addres-
label: Paragraph

text: sing as it does the city — the largest material artifact of human culture — The Naked
label: Paragraph

text: City is about the totality of lived human relations.
label: Paragraph

text: It was, then, a manifesto for intervention in the city — intervention led by the
label: Paragraph

text: vanguard intelligentsia who created The Naked City in accordance with a revolu-
label: Paragraph

text: tionary avant-garde program. The radicalism of early twentieth-century avant-
label: Paragraph

text: gardism had been mostly succeeded by the progressive reformism of the economic,
label: Paragraph

text: governmental, and creative coalitions imposing the grid. The Naked City, by con-
label: Paragraph

text: trast, was a Marxist-anarchist manifesto in visual form. It purportedly addressed the
label: Paragraph

text: working class as the revolutionary force of history, a class whose freedoms were
label: Paragraph

text: being “exchanged” for participation in a burgeoning postwar consumer economy,
label: Paragraph

text: and whose organizations were being “bought out” by the promise of physical and
label: Paragraph

text: social mobility.
label: Paragraph

text: The aspiration to a new revolution in Paris, the city depicted in The Naked City,
label: Paragraph

text: peaked in the May Events of 1968. One might then expect The Naked City to be
label: Paragraph

text: little more than an avant-garde souvenir. But The Naked City has joined other van-
label: Paragraph

text: guard icons (like those of interwar Soviet constructivism and assorted postwar
label: Paragraph

text: countercultures) that help us contemplate design’s largest purposes. It remains a
label: Paragraph

text: memorandum to activists insistent that politics and aesthetics are intertwined.
label: Paragraph

text: Some of those activists teach and practice architecture. Not that the meanings
label: Paragraph

text: of The Naked City are solely radical, either: its central insight that a plan is indef-
label: Paragraph

text: inite, that history moves, and that the human aspires to a more than functional
label: Paragraph

text: existence has been learned by postmodern urbanism, too.
label: Paragraph

text: The Context of The Naked City
label: Title

text: Between the world wars, surrealists wondered about the fate of class, intervention,
label: Paragraph

text: desire, and history in the wake of Europe’s rationalization by science, industrial
label: Paragraph

text: capitalism, and the state. Rationalization had been inscribed in the very body of
label: Paragraph

text: Paris through Haussmannisation, brilliantly and poetically surveyed in surrealist
label: Paragraph

text: circles by Louis Aragon and Walter Benjamin. The makers of The Naked City
label: Caption

text: found each other through the tiny network of Dadaist and surrealist legatees of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s. The Naked City (the best-known of a series of maps)’ served as one
label: Paragraph

text: of the formative documents of the Situationist International, which was constituted
label: Paragraph

text: in one form or another from 1957 to 1972. It allied two groups, the International
label: Paragraph

text: Movement for an Imaginist Bauhaus and the Lettrist International. The Lettrist
label: Paragraph

text: International (1952-57), dominated by one of The Naked City’s two creators, film-
label: Paragraph

text: maker and philosopher Guy Debord, was inclined toward the minimal and concep-
label: Paragraph

text: tual rather than the visual. In contrast, the founder of the Imaginist Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: (1954-57), artist Asger Jorn, who was the second of The Naked City’s two creators,
label: Paragraph

text: preferred a hands-on, expressionist approach to the production of art.
label: Paragraph

text: The Situationist International was overtly politicized at a time when the intelli-
label: Paragraph

text: gentsia at large was downplaying class conflict. By the late 1950s in France there
label: Paragraph

text: were more white-collar than blue-collar workers, the average worker's purchasing
label: Paragraph

text: power for consumer goods and leisure increasing through an economic expansion
label: Title

text: sponsored by the United States’ “golden era” of capitalism. But the result was an
label: Paragraph

text: increase in a standard of living only narrowly defined, argued the situationists, who
label: Paragraph

text: promised to divert this era of material and technological plenty to the collective
label: Paragraph

text: transformation of human existence. This new leftist politics demanded not mere
label: Paragraph

text: workplace equality, but the supersession of the workplace. This Freudian-Marxist
label: Paragraph

text: politics of desire was a riposte to the dead weight of the state and its aspirant polit-
label: Paragraph

text: ical parties (including the Communist Party) on both sides of the Iron Curtain.
label: Paragraph

text: Situationists believed that the city was the front line for the next revolution, just
label: Paragraph

text: as it had been for past political revolutions. As France shifted its economy from an
label: Paragraph

text: agrarian to an industrial and commercial base, urban redevelopment and housing
label: Paragraph

text: were the most visible reminders of the presence and power of a welfare—capitalist
label: Paragraph

text: state anxious to secure domestic consensus at the violent twilight of its imperial era.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps a third of the old Ville de Paris was demolished between the mid-1950s and
label: Paragraph

text: mid-1970s, during which its working-class population fell by more than 40%. The
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian built environment had not encountered a stylistic revolution as authorita-
label: Paragraph

text: tive as rationalism since the Renaissance, and the scale of postwar redevelopment
label: Paragraph

text: planned for Paris in the 1950s and 1960s was unprecedented since Haussmann. It
label: Paragraph

text: was epitomized by its servility to the private automobile. Debord’s 1959 “Situation-
label: Paragraph

text: ist Theses on Traffic” satirized the strict zoning and ease of traffic circulation called
label: Paragraph

text: for in the 1933 Athens Charter, which had been issued by the representative body
label: Paragraph

text: of modernist architecture, the Congrés internationaux d’architecture moderne, under
label: Paragraph

text: the influence of Le Corbusier, who revised the Charter in 1943 as ratification of his
label: Paragraph

text: Radiant City program. “The mistake made by all urbanists is to consider the private
label: Paragraph

text: automobile ... essentially as a means of transportation,’ Debord laconically
label: Paragraph

text: observed. “We must replace travel as an adjunct to work with travel as
label: Paragraph

text: pleasure,” he recommended, turning on “those who believe that the particulars
label: Paragraph

text: of the problem are permanent” but who “want in fact to believe in the permanence
label: Paragraph

text: of the present society” that encouraged the “circulation of things and of human
label: Paragraph

text: beings trapped in a world of things.”” Urbanism offered an “official,” homogenizing
label: Paragraph

text: representation of the state and capital — an orchestrated “spectacle,” as the situa-
label: Paragraph

text: tionists called the ascent of bourgeois visual culture across all media, from archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture to cinema to advertising.
label: Paragraph

text: The situationists discarded the awe in modernity exhibited by earlier vanguards
label: Paragraph

text: (the impressionists and futurists, for instance) to scrutinize modernity for seeds of
label: Paragraph

text: authentic, open-ended living. Situationism was not quite alone in its thoroughgo-
label: Paragraph

text: ing reassessment of modernity and rationalist modernism. Even Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: postwar work was marked by growing informality. The American urban historian
label: Paragraph

text: Lewis Mumford, increasingly skeptical of urban technological culture, influenced
label: Paragraph

text: the situationists, though his admiration for Garden City principles were of little
label: Paragraph

text: relevance to them. Structuralist philosophy and anthropology eroded and claim of
label: Paragraph

text: modernity’s absolute novelty when it discovered common cultural structures
label: Paragraph

text: underlying all eras. The dominant mode of thought in postwar France, existential-
label: Paragraph

text: ism, assigned priority to subjectivity over objectivity. The Critique of Everyday Life,
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1946 by the Marxist philosopher, Henri Lefebvre, joined a growing
label: Paragraph

text: book list on the role of play, festivity and carnivalization in human culture authored
label: Caption

text: by Mikhail Bakhtin, Johan Huizinga, and Roger Caillois. Against this background,
label: Paragraph

text: situationism offered a framework by which to invert every assumption of contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary urbanism and the life it inscribed.
label: Paragraph

text: The Naked City as a Guide to Paris, Urbanism, and Life
label: Title

text: In the later 1950s, members of the formative Situationist International, who in the
label: Paragraph

text: early part of the decade could still take the remarkable social and architectural une-
label: Paragraph

text: venness of Paris for granted, began to map the disappearing city using “psychogeo-
label: Paragraph

text: graphic drift.” This was their practice of explorative urban wandering, following
label: Paragraph

text: individual and collective instinct and desire. “In a dérive [drift],’ Debord explained
label: Paragraph

text: in his 1958 “Theory of the Dérive,” “one or more persons during a certain period
label: Paragraph

text: drop their usual motives for movement and action, their relations, their work and
label: Paragraph

text: leisure activities, and let themselves be drawn by the attractions of the terrain and
label: Paragraph

text: the encounters they find there.” Journeying usually on foot, the situationist drifter
label: Paragraph

text: was the new fldneur, the wandering spectator of the modernizing urban scene that
label: Paragraph

text: had emerged in the early nineteenth century and was later celebrated in the writ-
label: Paragraph

text: ings of Charles Baudelaire. Unlike the fléneur, though, the drifter was repelled by
label: Paragraph

text: homogenizing modernization and was instead propelled along her or his
label: Paragraph

text: unplanned journey by the complex geography and aesthetics of social and architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural history. Drift helped situationists identify those urban qualities worthy of
label: Paragraph

text: “diversion” into the “constructed situations” of a “unitary urbanism.”
label: Paragraph

text: Although some ambition for a coherent urbanist program may have existed
label: Paragraph

text: among situationists in the late 1950s, none really formed. Our understandings
label: Paragraph

text: of its key concepts like psychogeography and unitary urbanism must therefore
label: Paragraph

text: remain as manifold as the urbanism and lived totality that it addressed. We might
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless summarize unitary urbanism as the situationist dream city, conjec-
label: Paragraph

text: tured as a future construction or experienced in the present through drift — an envi-
label: Paragraph

text: ronment in which collective and individual life is truly fulfilled because all
label: Paragraph

text: separation, all alienation, has ceased. Art would be indistinguishable from life,
label: Paragraph

text: work indistinguishable from pleasure, need from want, self from species. Such
label: Paragraph

text: compartmentalization that survived would be through the intensification of the
label: Paragraph

text: differing ambiances of the city’s units, ambiances of the sort discovered by psycho-
label: Paragraph

text: geographic drift in Paris’s old quartiers. Gathered together in the grand “unity” of
label: Paragraph

text: the city, the future city quarters of unitary urbanism would serve every emotional,
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual, and corporeal need of the new citizen. The reconstituted city, for
label: Paragraph

text: which The Naked City might have been a preliminary mental or psychogeographic
label: Paragraph

text: survey, would emancipate its occupants from the alienation of life under rational-
label: Paragraph

text: ism, functionalism, and capitalism. The Naked City was therefore inherently crit-
label: Paragraph

text: ical of Paris and all cities that adhered to redevelopment programs that did not
label: Paragraph

text: make the subjective and collective experience of humanity the beginning and
label: Paragraph

text: end of design.
label: Paragraph

text: Borrowing its title from a 1948 drama-documentary film of detectives at work in
label: Paragraph

text: New York, The Naked City recorded investigative work into those areas of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ville de Paris so far by-passed by the grands boulevards of traffic and retail but threa-
label: Paragraph

text: tened by redevelopment. One example was the slum of the Marais, the early
label: Paragraph

text: seventeenth-century centerpiece of Henri IV’s Paris that briefly offered refuge
label: Caption

text: to situationists Guy Debord and Michele Bernstein. It appeared as chunks floating
label: Paragraph

text: in the north-east corners of the map. The very fact that the Marais was generally
label: Paragraph

text: recognized as worthy of conservation, its fate debated within the Conseil municipal
label: Paragraph

text: de Paris, threatened to make it a part of the state’s official, “spectacular” heritage.
label: Paragraph

text: This was indeed its destiny — at the time of writing, one of the mansions of the Place
label: Paragraph

text: des Vosges is swathed in a photographic reproduction of the building underneath,
label: Paragraph

text: the gauze sponsored by the corporate computer giant Apple, which is subsidizing
label: Paragraph

text: the restoration. Situationists complained of the tendency “to restore a few old
label: Paragraph

text: urban spots as sights of touristic spectacle, a simple extension of the principle of
label: Paragraph

text: the classical museum by means of which an entire neighborhood can become a
label: Paragraph

text: monument.”
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1950s no such official patronage extended to the Marais’ neighbors,
label: Paragraph

text: though — the decrepit Beaubourg and the marketplace of Les Halles, placed at
label: Paragraph

text: the very center of The Naked City. These were still working-class areas — not
label: Paragraph

text: to say areas of the lumpen proletariat and vice — where pedestrians rather than
label: Paragraph

text: motorized traffic had priority on the streets, and where commercial exchange still
label: Paragraph

text: took place over transitory market stalls, or in small stores, rather than in the bou-
label: Paragraph

text: tiques or department stores a little further north and west. But its market halls were
label: Paragraph

text: ignominiously demolished in 1971 to make way for the RER train interchange, a
label: Paragraph

text: sunken shopping and entertainments center, and the Pompidou Center — the epit-
label: Paragraph

text: ome, argued many critics, of the “spectacle” of Parisian culture — which opened
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond the record of preservation and destruction it offered, The Naked City
label: Paragraph

text: was an epistemological device. The fact that it clearly was not a regular map
label: Paragraph

text: implied a new understanding of geography and cartography.° Debord was intri-
label: Paragraph

text: gued, for example, by the urban social geography of Paul-Henri Chombart de
label: Paragraph

text: Lauwe, which heightened awareness of the complex social structuring of the city
label: Paragraph

text: ordinarily invisible on political maps. By contrast, rationalist urban planning
label: Paragraph

text: reduced the intricacy of city life to fallaciously simplistic levels. The disturbed grid-
label: Paragraph

text: lines of the Guide Taride de Paris, sliced to make The Naked City, emphasized the
label: Paragraph

text: incompatibility of Cartesian logic with the lived reality of the city. Debord and Jorn
label: Caption

text: pasted down the chunks of map at some odd angles, as much as 45° from the mean,
label: Paragraph

text: suggesting the pivoting, pinball trajectory of drifting pedestrians following their
label: Paragraph

text: own desire lines. The situationist map described a drifting urban navigational sys-
label: Paragraph

text: tem operating independently of Paris’s dominant patterns of circulation. The vary-
label: Paragraph

text: ing weights of the map’s arrows suggested the strength of psychogeographic
label: Paragraph

text: passages.
label: Paragraph

text: Purely “objective” geographical analysis, in other words, was placed by The
label: Paragraph

text: Naked City in a dialectical tension with the subjective geography of experience
label: Paragraph

text: and occupation. This is critically important for the activist politics of the map,
label: Paragraph

text: and also for the culture of architecture into which the map would be imported,
label: Paragraph

text: since architecture, too, holds the objective and subjective in tension. On the
label: Paragraph

text: one hand the self could not be divorced from the urban environment; on the other
label: Paragraph

text: hand, psychogeography had to pertain to more than just the psyche of the individ-
label: Paragraph

text: ual if it was to be useful in the collective rethinking of the city. Psychogeography
label: Paragraph

text: directed its practitioners to obscure places in the built environment, in community
label: Paragraph

text: life, and in the mind simultaneously. With this, the situationists hoped, unitary
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism would begin.
label: Paragraph

text: The promise of this new epistemology wasn’t academic, then; it was of urban
label: Paragraph

text: reoccupation, of the critical deconstruction of political economy, of the restoration
label: Paragraph

text: of the street as locus of popular culture, and of the diversion of quartiers of existing
label: Paragraph

text: Paris into a more intensely lived life, the city a giant revolutionary festival. This
label: Paragraph

text: future has not yet come to pass. To understand why, we would need another sort
label: Paragraph

text: of essay that discusses revolutionary organization and the endurance of late capi-
label: Paragraph

text: talism. Instead we will conclude by tracing The Naked City’s integration into archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture culture, where it is safely contained as a contributor to postmodern
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism, but where it is also cared for as an incomplete project. The Naked City
label: Paragraph

text: reminds designers to pay attention to the qualities of the city beyond positivist
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism.
label: Paragraph

text: The Assimilation of The Naked City into
label: Title

text: Architecture Culture
label: Title

text: The Naked City aimed to transcend disciplinary art and architecture, yet archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture as a discipline assimilated and attempted to learn from situationism.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture has a remarkable capacity to digest its anarchic and indeterminate
label: Paragraph

text: Others — the vernacular, for instance, or popular culture, or ecology, or the long
label: Paragraph

text: revolution in communications that would seem to obviate the need for buildings
label: Paragraph

text: and cities. Situationism meanwhile did not develop entirely autonomously, but in
label: Paragraph

text: contact with a vanguard common culture of which architecture was a part. Lettr-
label: Paragraph

text: ism and situationism caught the attention of the architectural discipline’s van-
label: Paragraph

text: guard almost immediately, and assimilation was assured after 1968, the high
label: Paragraph

text: watermark of radical questioning about all relations to capitalism, architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: and urbanism.
label: Paragraph

text: This integration was eased by the fact that situationism was already related to a
label: Paragraph

text: wider post-Athens Charter network around the Team 10 group in architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: to the intertwined avant-garde scene of the Independent Group at the Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary Arts in London. For the Situationist International, Team 10 and
label: Caption

text: Independent Group alike, rationalism’s pretensions to represent universal truth
label: Paragraph

text: were obsolete. A rallying cry like that delivered by architect Aldo van Eyck to Team
label: Paragraph

text: 10 in 1959 — “Instead of the inconvenience of filth and confusion, we have now got
label: Paragraph

text: the boredom of hygiene ... mile upon mile of organised nowhere”’ — echoed the
label: Paragraph

text: sentiments of the situationists. Van Eyck proposed that buildings and cities be
label: Paragraph

text: designed not around strict hierarchies but according to a “labyrinthine clarity”
label: Paragraph

text: granting users a relative freedom of choice in the use and discovery of its spaces
label: Paragraph

text: and places. He eventually published an article on the subject in a 1963 edition of the
label: Paragraph

text: Situationist Times.” Van Eyck had worked on an installation at the Stedelijk
label: Paragraph

text: Museum in 1953 with the artist Constant (Nieuwenhuys), a founder of the Situa-
label: Paragraph

text: tionist International whose design for a situationist city of the future, which he
label: Paragraph

text: called New Babylon, drew on the complex, multi-layered spatial planning of
label: Paragraph

text: van Eyck and his Team 10 colleagues, Alison and Peter Smithson. Borrowing lib-
label: Paragraph

text: erally from situationist unitary urbanism in 1959, meanwhile, the Independent
label: Paragraph

text: Group architectural historian Reyner Banham proposed the “city as scrambled
label: Paragraph

text: egg,” as a mixed cultural field rather than a compartmentalized functional machine.
label: Paragraph

text: Illustrating his article with the 1956 Guide Psychogéographique de Paris — which was
label: Paragraph

text: Debord and Jorn’s precursor to 1957’s The Naked City — Banham was able to strip
label: Paragraph

text: situationist unitary urbanism of its politics and append it to planning discourse.
label: Paragraph

text: But an insurmountable ideological difference between militant anarchism and
label: Paragraph

text: liberal leftism separated situationism from other vanguard tendencies. Yes, the
label: Paragraph

text: situationists looked forward to pleasurable speed and mobility through the city
label: Paragraph

text: at large, but not to its degeneration into autopia (Banham loved Los Angeles as
label: Paragraph

text: well as Paris). Yes, they wanted, in Banham’s phrase, “a whole lot of special interest
label: Paragraph

text: belts overlapping and colliding, to their mutual benefit,” but not so as to attract the
label: Paragraph

text: troupes of “brainstormers” that Banham considered essential to the life of the urban
label: Paragraph

text: core, “the cool jazz connection, action painters, documentary camera crews, [and]
label: Paragraph

text: advertising copy-writers.”” This was the professional creative class, invested in con-
label: Paragraph

text: sumer society, within which Britain’s Archigram group (working close to Banham)
label: Paragraph

text: also wanted to position architecture. In a sense, the gulf between situationism and
label: Paragraph

text: architectural vanguardism was never more graphic than when Archigram incorpo-
label: Paragraph

text: rated ideas of “Situation” into its seminal 1963 Institute of Contemporary Arts
label: Paragraph

text: show, “Living City,” which again featured Debord and Jorn’s Guide Psychogéogra-
label: Paragraph

text: phique de Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: This consumption of the city as an urban theme park, its psychogeography
label: Paragraph

text: hypostatized as a post-industrial product, has of course accelerated in postmodern
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism since the 1960s, as a flurry of sociological and journalistic attacks on
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning (notably led by Jane Jacobs) prompted strict urban zoning to lose
label: Paragraph

text: favor to mixed use, while many “post-industrial” city centers in Europe and the
label: Paragraph

text: United States — their industries evacuated to the exurbs or to Asia — became domi-
label: Paragraph

text: nated by leisure use. Situationism was destined then to haunt the conventional wis-
label: Paragraph

text: dom of postmodernism. Architectural epistemology was markedly affected by
label: Paragraph

text: poststructuralism and the turn to history, both somewhat anticipated in situation-
label: Paragraph

text: ism — recall the “poststructural” fragmentation of The Naked City, and its concern
label: Paragraph

text: for the city’s disappearing “history.”
label: Paragraph

text: Poststructuralism in effect found that the creation of meaning through cinema,
label: Paragraph

text: literature, the city and everyday life is as “decentered” as the geographical reading
label: Paragraph

text: of Paris by psychogeographic drift. But this in turn undermined the potential for
label: Paragraph

text: the co-ordinated collective action sought by situationism; poststructural theorists
label: Paragraph

text: became suspicious of 1968’s broad front of action, which, they argued, homoge-
label: Paragraph

text: nized heterogeneous revolutionary desire. Hereon the city would nurture the inter-
label: Paragraph

text: play of multiple desires and identities. Urbanism’s historical turn, meanwhile, was
label: Paragraph

text: captured for example in 1978 by historian Anthony Vidler’s argument that cities are
label: Paragraph

text: a consistent background to human affairs, furnishing a “third typology” (following
label: Paragraph

text: the first two typologies of nature and machines from which modernism aimed to
label: Paragraph

text: birth a new society).'° The third typology of the city contained architectural ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments that could be reused according to their past use and meaning and their capac-
label: Paragraph

text: ity to be put to new uses. This third typology suggested the uncanny qualities of
label: Paragraph

text: The Naked City, in which the city was at once familiar yet unfamiliar, and was at
label: Paragraph

text: once as reassuring and as disconcerting as the past itself.
label: Paragraph

text: Further to these epistemological turns, The Naked City’s fragmented Dadaist
label: Paragraph

text: and surreal collage, which implied “deterritorialized,” “nomadic” struggle, sug-
label: Paragraph

text: gested a method by which to design the poststructural, postmodern city. Announced
label: Paragraph

text: in Colin Rowe’s Collage City of 1978, a certain fantasy of designed disorder fasci-
label: Paragraph

text: nated a generation of architects. As a master-planner, Rem Koolhaas in effect recon-
label: Paragraph

text: stituted unitary urbanism as a way of reconciling his loyalties both to populism and
label: Paragraph

text: to the role of the architect as heroic master of ceremonies.'' Likewise Bernard
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi, a contemporary of Koolhaas’ at the Architectural Association in London
label: Paragraph

text: in the early 1970s, has written that “the insertion of the terms event and move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment” into urbanism “was influenced by situationist discourse and by the *68
label: Paragraph

text: era,” when “the unlikely combination of events and spaces was charged with sub-
label: Paragraph

text: versive capabilities.”’” Tschumi’s student group at the Architectural Association in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1970s, which included Nigel Coates, pursued ethereal investigations of the
label: Paragraph

text: experience of space and the imagination. And New York’s High Line park (Field
label: Caption

text: Operations, Diller Scofidio + Renfro, Piet Oudolf, Buro Happold, 2008) — arguably
label: Caption

text: the quintessence of contemporary urbanism — has about it that situationist quality
label: Paragraph

text: of urban history and infrastructural use made strange.
label: Paragraph

text: Although income is not an absolute determinant of the ability to walk the High
label: Paragraph

text: Line, however, it certainly is a determinant of the ability to inhabit an apartment
label: Paragraph

text: alongside it. Not only has the gentrification prefigured by the postwar city to which
label: Paragraph

text: The Naked City bore witness accelerated wildly, but urban fragmentation has also
label: Paragraph

text: coalesced with spectacle culture. And a new myth of societal selforganization —
label: Paragraph

text: abetted by poststructuralism, accelerated capital flows, information technology,
label: Paragraph

text: and neo-Darwinian theory — has since the 1960s assumed the mantle earlier filled
label: Paragraph

text: by the anarchism of situationism. The myth is claimed by left and right — to the
label: Paragraph

text: right, the behemoth of capital accumulation, now in its neoliberal phase, and to
label: Paragraph

text: the left, the vibrant networked opposition to globalized capital accumulation, Lil-
label: Paragraph

text: liputian but capable of surprise in the venerable manner of the situationists and
label: Paragraph

text: other avant-gardes.
label: Paragraph

text: Both coalitions compete for occupation of the city, and both are represented
label: Paragraph

text: within the schools and offices of architecture. To be candid, architecture’s default
label: Paragraph

text: role is to service capital while trying to extract from it some surplus aesthetic or
label: Paragraph

text: public value. But architects were reportedly active in Occupy, for example — that
label: Paragraph

text: resurgence of radicalism in the United States around 2011 which part reprieved
label: Paragraph

text: some of the “spirit” of situationism and its lineage to the communards of 1968
label: Paragraph

text: and the Parisian communards of 1871. The architectural discipline thus serves
label: Paragraph

text: as a repository of politico-aesthetic devices available for reuse, and we can make
label: Paragraph

text: a safe bet that the new politico-aesthetic devices of Occupy will reappear in archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture in coming decades: watch for some architectural version of the “mic check”
label: Title

text: technique for collective discussion to appear in due course.
label: Paragraph

text: Coincidentally, then, The Naked City’s resonance with recent architectural
label: Paragraph

text: design helps us understand how architecture looks, learns, formalizes, interjects.
label: Paragraph

text: The Naked City suggested that fragments of culture and place benefit by inter-
label: Paragraph

text: meshing and surrendering their separate currencies. It depicted an evolving, trans-
label: Paragraph

text: formative matrix. It questioned our need for the new when the possibilities of the
label: Paragraph

text: past are yet to be discovered. It presented a procedure without instructions, an invi-
label: Paragraph

text: tation to agency, and a transformed future. These processes of creativity are well
label: Paragraph

text: known to architects and became the better known to them as their discipline
label: Paragraph

text: turned, in the late twentieth century, away from strict rationalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Carlos Eduardo Comas

text: Lucio Costa, Brasilia Pilot Plan, Brazil, 1957.*
label: Caption

text: THE PILOT PLAN AND ITS MONUMENTS
label: Title

text: Cities are not built in a single day. Brasilia was the name suggested for a new capital
label: Paragraph

text: in the hinterland when Brazil became an independent empire (1822). The idea was
label: Paragraph

text: written into the country’s first republican constitution (1891), and land surveys in
label: Paragraph

text: the central plateau subtropical savanna followed (1892-93); after that, nothing
label: Paragraph

text: much happened before the end of World War II. When President Juscelino
label: Paragraph

text: Kubitschek was inaugurated in January 1956, a federal district had been demarcated
label: Paragraph

text: and a plan had been drawn up by José de Oliveira Reis, Raul Penna Firme, and
label: Paragraph

text: Roberto Lacombe (1955).' They recommended damming the Paranoé River to cre-
label: Paragraph

text: ate a lake and consequently reduce the aridity of the climate. Called Vera Cruz, the
label: Paragraph

text: new capital would stand on a triangular site extending and rising dome-like to the
label: Paragraph

text: west between two branches of the lake.”
label: Paragraph

text: Building the new capital became a priority in Kubitschek’s ambitious development
label: Paragraph

text: program for a democratic Brazil, which included establishing an auto industry with
label: Paragraph

text: the participation of foreign investment. His slogan was “Fifty years in five.” The
label: Paragraph

text: “march toward the west” started when Congress approved the creation of a devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opment agency, NOVACAP (1956). Oscar Niemeyer, Director of its Department of
label: Caption

text: Urbanism and Architecture, supported a national competition for the pilot plan for
label: Paragraph

text: Brasilia, the definitive name of the city. The Vera Cruz plan was shelved. Nonethe-
label: Paragraph

text: less, Niemeyer co-authored the competition brief with Penna Firme and Lacombe.’
label: Paragraph

text: Competitors had to present a schematic plan and a report. Data included the
label: Paragraph

text: location of two Niemeyer designs beside the Paranoa Lake, the presidential resi-
label: Paragraph

text: dence (Palacio da Alvorada), and a hotel. There were only a few programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: specifications. Brasilia was conceived as a company city whose industry was gov-
label: Paragraph

text: ernment, so the city would be an administrative one accommodating 500,000 peo-
label: Paragraph

text: ple, presumed to consist mostly of middle class politicians, lawyers, diplomats,
label: Paragraph

text: military personnel, civil servants, lobbyists, and their families. An implicit but cru-
label: Paragraph

text: cial requirement was the possibility of implementing the pilot plan in three years,
label: Paragraph

text: so that Kubitschek could inaugurate the city before leaving the presidency on Jan-
label: Paragraph

text: uary 1961.
label: Paragraph

text: In all, 26 plans were submitted. Led by Niemeyer, the jury analyzed their adap-
label: Paragraph

text: tation to topography, their extension in relation to population density, and the
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of their urban elements and regional connections, while also looking
label: Paragraph

text: for a modern architectural statement communicating the city’s role as national
label: Paragraph

text: capital. Historicism was out of the question. Lucio Costa’s entry was considered
label: Paragraph

text: the best, given its compactness, cohesiveness, coherence, and character. It was at
label: Paragraph

text: once contemporary and timeless, pragmatic and emblematic, befitting both an
label: Paragraph

text: efficient urbs and a proud civitas.* Knowingly or not, it improved on the Vera
label: Paragraph

text: Cruz plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Two grade-separated axes crossed at the center of the checkerboard layout of
label: Paragraph

text: Vera Cruz, making up the bulky arm of the T-shaped scheme. Commerce Avenue
label: Caption

text: ran north-south, and Independence Avenue ran east-west on the ridge of the site.
label: Paragraph

text: The former widened south of the crossing into a square bounded by a cultural and
label: Paragraph

text: entertainment complex, the town hall, and the cathedral. The latter widened west
label: Paragraph

text: of the crossing into the U-shaped national government center, with longer sides
label: Paragraph

text: perpendicular to that square, the short western end enclosed by the capitol at mid-
label: Paragraph

text: point. The capitol defined a triangle with the presidential palace and the supreme
label: Paragraph

text: court of justice, each heading a row of ministries perpendicular to the intermediary
label: Paragraph

text: mall. Embassies stood in a garden neighborhood behind the capitol. Independence
label: Paragraph

text: Avenue bifurcated at the checkerboard’s eastern boundary. The forks led to the
label: Paragraph

text: university campus and public parks at the lakeshore and defined a prominent tri-
label: Paragraph

text: angle inscribed in the short, slender stem of the plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Bilateral symmetry made sense in terms of topography and drainage, construction
label: Paragraph

text: and performance. Emphasizing the singularity of each axis made even more sense.
label: Paragraph

text: Costa bent the north-south axis. Instead of a commercial boulevard, he devised a
label: Paragraph

text: sunken highway between two arterials bordered by rows of trees and apartment
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Thanks to the excavated material, the eastern half of the straight axis
label: Paragraph

text: turned into a raised platform; the natural slope of its western half went largely undis-
label: Paragraph

text: turbed. As if streamlining the Vera Cruz layout, Costa placed Brasilia’s key civic
label: Paragraph

text: buildings on a single strip, those of national scope upon the platform and those of
label: Paragraph

text: local interest upon the slope; squares set off both ends of this monumental axis.
label: Paragraph

text: The platform comprised two pieces, like Independence Avenue, but both
label: Paragraph

text: advanced into the savanna. The capitol was the common central element to the
label: Paragraph

text: triangular Plaza of the Three Powers at the end of the platform and the rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: Esplanade of the Ministries opposite, including the cathedral in front of one of its
label: Paragraph

text: two rows. The town hall and the railway station graced the western end of the
label: Caption

text: slope. Counterpart to the capitol, a telecommunications tower rose halfway up
label: Paragraph

text: the slope’s highest point. Unlike Vera Cruz, the heart of Costa’s Brasilia was a void:
label: Paragraph

text: a multilevel bus station occupied the crossing of the axes. The cultural and enter-
label: Paragraph

text: tainment sectors adjoined it respectively to the east and west, integrating into both
label: Paragraph

text: the highway-residential axis and the monumental axis. The entertainment sector
label: Paragraph

text: bridged the business districts in front of the residential wings, comprising retail
label: Paragraph

text: stores to the west and office buildings to the east. Hotels rose between the shop-
label: Paragraph

text: ping areas and the entertainment sector. Sports facilities were dispersed along the
label: Paragraph

text: green slope. Embassies and campus were envisaged between the superblocks, the
label: Paragraph

text: platform, and the lake.
label: Paragraph

text: Costa proposed an efficient, car-oriented city with no grade crossings and no
label: Paragraph

text: traffic lights. Its linearity facilitated the provision of bus services. Its monumentality
label: Paragraph

text: was structural. Costa abhorred the confusion of monumentality with grandilo-
label: Paragraph

text: quence. He understood “monumentality” in its strict sense as the quality of a mon-
label: Paragraph

text: ument, by definition a structure acting as a commemoration device, a machine for
label: Paragraph

text: remembrance, and therefore required to appear as a memorable object in itself. For
label: Paragraph

text: him, both urbs and civitas were worthy of commemoration. The whole was to be as
label: Paragraph

text: memorable as the part.
label: Paragraph

text: Grade separation and bending updated the cross as a planning tool, with no loss
label: Paragraph

text: of its elementary formal vigor. Costa’s pilot plan’s resemblance to a bird, airplane,
label: Paragraph

text: or bow and arrow reinforced popular associations of the city with movement and
label: Paragraph

text: development. Stylized figuration alluding to nature or machine was not new in
label: Paragraph

text: Costa’s and Niemeyer’s work, as demonstrated by the Ministry of Education head-
label: Paragraph

text: quarters in Rio or the Pampulha Chapel.’ It recalled the traditional association of
label: Paragraph

text: columns with trees and human bodies, or temples with arks, and employed the
label: Paragraph

text: formal strategies of caricature, a flourishing art in Brazil since the mid-nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century. In the context of the Cold War, it suggested an abstract modern answer
label: Paragraph

text: to the precepts of social realism. Costa avoided political statements, but was con-
label: Paragraph

text: cerned about communicating with the common man. He shared this desire with
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer, a Communist Party member who loathed Stalinist architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The differentiation of the monumental sector from the natural setting added to
label: Paragraph

text: the movement-related imagery. Built like a road, its platform would rise above the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding savanna like a cruise-ship or pier. The Square of the Three Powers at
label: Paragraph

text: the tip was at once stern and quay, ship and harbor. The metaphor was based on
label: Paragraph

text: geometry — their horizontality — as much as literature; the transformation of the
label: Paragraph

text: north-eastern savanna into a seashore was prophesied by messianic leader Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: Conselheiro, according to Euclides da Cunha in Os sertées (1902).° A latter day obe-
label: Paragraph

text: lisk, the telecommunications tower followed the lead of the Eiffel Tower and reaf-
label: Paragraph

text: firmed the alliance of the city with technical progress and the media.
label: Paragraph

text: The differentiation of the monumental sector proper from the ordinary urban
label: Paragraph

text: fabric suggested institutional stability. Thus, the depiction of the body politic was
label: Paragraph

text: quite literal. Costa put government at the head of the city, as Le Corbusier had
label: Paragraph

text: done in Chandigarh, giving it greater visibility with no loss of connectivity, thanks
label: Paragraph

text: to the cruciform layout and its central void. The equivalence of the three govern-
label: Paragraph

text: ment branches was conveyed in an elementary and effective way. If their seats
label: Paragraph

text: made up a head, the ministries were their arms. Most occupied standard slab build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings; proximity and distinctive physiognomies should signal the special links
label: Paragraph

text: between the executive branch and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the legislative
label: Paragraph

text: branch and the Ministry of Justice.
label: Paragraph

text: Assertions of typological continuity amid political change were not absent. The
label: Paragraph

text: Square of the Three Powers had buildings on three sides, as did Praca XV de
label: Paragraph

text: Novembro in Rio or Praca do Comércio in Lisbon. The former related to Brazilian
label: Paragraph

text: emperors and Guanabara Bay, the latter to Portuguese kings and the Tagus River.
label: Paragraph

text: Known first as Terreiro do Paco (Square of the Palace), both were relevant histor-
label: Paragraph

text: ical examples of marginal centralities. French urbanist Alfred Agache had remem-
label: Paragraph

text: bered this in his plan for Rio de Janeiro (1930), by proposing a square opening on
label: Paragraph

text: one side to Guanabara Bay as the Parliament's lobby.” As for the Esplanade of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ministries, it recalled the Washington Mall reformed by Beaux-Arts-trained Burn-
label: Paragraph

text: ham and McKim (1901) in another city designed from scratch, the capital of the first
label: Paragraph

text: independent American country. Both the square and the esplanade were vast
label: Paragraph

text: stages, purposefully empty most of the time, waiting to burst with extraordinary
label: Paragraph

text: and massive civic joy, anger, or grief.
label: Paragraph

text: Costa’s own work was also a reference, for Vera Cruz as well as Brasilia, despite
label: Paragraph

text: the stripped down academic classicism of the buildings illustrating the earlier plan,
label: Paragraph

text: which were no different from those illustrating the Agache plan. Designed with
label: Paragraph

text: similar elements and a divergent parti to replace an earlier proposal by Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: the University of Brazil campus project (1936) featured an entrance plaza with three
label: Paragraph

text: main elements including a tower, schools in rows of slab buildings perpendicular to
label: Caption

text: the ceremonial axis, and another square at the latter’s opposite end.*
label: Paragraph

text: The “man in the street” did not need to be literate to understand Brasilia as the
label: Paragraph

text: hub of a vast and mostly unsettled nation on the move, proud of its brand new
label: Paragraph

text: automobile industry and eager to increase its air routes, marching to the west with
label: Paragraph

text: a new-found enthusiasm for democracy, but mindful of its complex heritage. This
label: Paragraph

text: heritage was not confined to parochial precedents, and the duality of the endeavor
label: Paragraph

text: could also be conveyed in more esoteric disciplinary terms. The counterbalance of
label: Paragraph

text: dynamism that came from the emphasis on focal objects and stable compositions
label: Paragraph

text: was achieved by aptly intersecting the Linear City of Spanish and Russian lineage
label: Paragraph

text: with the City Beautiful of French pedigree in the light of the Corbusian Radiant
label: Paragraph

text: City and ancient Chang’an, the former capital of China planned in the sixth century
label: Paragraph

text: with the Imperial Palace as its head. Beaux-Arts-trained Costa would have assumed
label: Paragraph

text: that the Roman Campidoglio, another relevant palace square open on one side,
label: Paragraph

text: was hardly worth a comment, but his memoirs disclose an infatuation with
label: Paragraph

text: the Chinese tradition of man-made terraces, platforms, and embankments at
label: Paragraph

text: that time.?
label: Paragraph

text: As if paraphrasing Baudelaire, International Congresses of Modern Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (CIAM) member Costa treated the ordinary city as the transitory, fugitive, contin-
label: Paragraph

text: gent half of modernity, while the monumental sector, the sunken highway, and the
label: Paragraph

text: central void pointed to the eternal and immovable other half, the world of
label: Paragraph

text: unchanging forms valid for all time’® — arguably the abstract world of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: types and archetypes, such as crossroads and nodes, or squares open on one side,
label: Paragraph

text: not their concrete instances.
label: Paragraph

text: The bus station at that central void did not mirror the airport of Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary City (1922), an offspring by subtraction of the train station-cum-
label: Paragraph

text: airport by Sant’Elia (1914), in turn an offspring by the addition of the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth-century train terminal. Although all could be described as transportation
label: Paragraph

text: nodes at a central crossroads, the Brasilia bus station was earthbound like older
label: Paragraph

text: train terminals and more plausible if less glamorous than the airports. Like the
label: Paragraph

text: Square of the Three Powers and the Esplanade of Ministries, it shows how
label: Paragraph

text: double-edged referencing can be. As long as the reiteration involved is partial, it
label: Paragraph

text: announces change as well as continuity, criticism as well as endorsement, maybe
label: Paragraph

text: improvement, maybe adaptation. It places even the recent past at a distance. The
label: Paragraph

text: same applies when referencing is multiple and combines manifold sources,
label: Paragraph

text: typological variation giving way to compositional development within the modern
label: Paragraph

text: architectural tradition of urban planning. Stressing evolution, Costa reasserted the
label: Paragraph

text: vitality of that tradition under attack by a younger generation since CIAM 8 at Aix-
label: Paragraph

text: la-Provence (1953).""
label: Paragraph

text: The scale was unprecedented, but Costa’s monumental axis reflected an early
label: Paragraph

text: and longstanding concern with spaces of public assembly shared by Niemeyer
label: Paragraph

text: and other Brazilian architects, as the University of Brazil project shows. Their port-
label: Paragraph

text: folio included settings for human association of varying size and character. For
label: Paragraph

text: Costa, the core of a modern capital city required spaces and structures belonging
label: Paragraph

text: to three scales: the monumental, the gregarious, and the bucolic. He contrasted the
label: Paragraph

text: formal grandeur of the civic sector and the green expansiveness around the sports
label: Paragraph

text: facilities with the intricacy of the intermediary entertainment center, envisioned
label: Paragraph

text: as a mix of Piccadilly Circus, Times Square, the Champs Elysées, Carioca travessas,
label: Paragraph

text: Venetian calli, and arcaded streets. Liveliness around the clock would follow from
label: Paragraph

text: the juxtaposition of areas for different, complementary uses instead of fine-grain,
label: Paragraph

text: mixed-use patterns. The concentration of hotels bordering the shopping areas and
label: Paragraph

text: the entertainment center added a residential component to the city center. An ele-
label: Paragraph

text: vated walkway with restaurants and services crossing each row of ministries added
label: Paragraph

text: vertical layering to the juxtaposition of with different activities. Shopping areas
label: Paragraph

text: included offices in the upper floors. The expanded bases of office buildings
label: Paragraph

text: included shops and services.
label: Paragraph

text: No permanent dwellings showed in the business districts of Costa’s ordinary
label: Paragraph

text: city, so it might be said that it combined the Linear City with CIAM’s Functional
label: Paragraph

text: City-in-the-park. Brasilia was a green, car-oriented capital with a government, cul-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, and entertainment core adjoined by business, administration, shopping, and
label: Paragraph

text: temporary housing, in turn extended by the residential wings, plus special sectors
label: Paragraph

text: for warehouses, workshops, barracks, and so on. Zoning sensibly recognized the
label: Paragraph

text: pressures toward both mixing and separating uses in the city, along with the advan-
label: Paragraph

text: tages of typological specialization regarding speed of implementation. Costa’s
label: Paragraph

text: design criticized the existing Brazilian city, subject to a process of uncoordinated
label: Paragraph

text: vertical and horizontal expansion within narrow plots and street networks. At the
label: Paragraph

text: same time, it rationalized the Rio de Janeiro situation. The distinction between the
label: Paragraph

text: core and the residential areas was becoming sharper in the old capital. Few people
label: Paragraph

text: still lived downtown, and the best residential areas succeeded each other along the
label: Paragraph

text: sea, apartment buildings being the prevalent housing type.
label: Paragraph

text: Costa’s residential city was made up of superquadras, 240 x 240 meter superb-
label: Paragraph

text: locks in single or double rows, with four superblocks corresponding to a neighbor-
label: Paragraph

text: hood unit. Each superblock, surrounded by a 20 meter-wide, tree-lined walk, hada
label: Paragraph

text: single entry point for vehicles. Inside, vehicular and pedestrian traffic were segre-
label: Paragraph

text: gated through design. A dozen 80 meter-long slab buildings with six floors of apart-
label: Paragraph

text: ments and a ground floor pilotis accommodated 2,500 people. Internal facilities
label: Caption

text: comprised a primary school and a convenience newsstand store. Distribution of
label: Paragraph

text: population by income could be done by assigning greater value to certain groups
label: Paragraph

text: of superblocks — such as the single row alongside the embassies or those closest to
label: Paragraph

text: downtown — and then offering apartments of varying size, layout, materials, and
label: Paragraph

text: finishes. Whatever the case, the land between buildings remained in public own-
label: Paragraph

text: ership. The interquadras, 80 meter-wide strips between superblocks, alternately
label: Caption

text: accommodated one- to two-story shops and neighborhood facilities (secondary
label: Paragraph

text: school, community center, movie theater, and church) at walking distance from
label: Paragraph

text: the adjoining superblocks; in the second row, shops succeeding neighborhood facil-
label: Paragraph

text: ities, and vice-versa, furthered alternation and added diversity.
label: Paragraph

text: Endowed with both local and citywide accessibility, these strips retained a
label: Paragraph

text: degree of independence in terms of change over time. It was another instance
label: Paragraph

text: of juxtaposing uses — dwelling, shopping, or services — amounting to a coarse,
label: Paragraph

text: mixed-use pattern. Concurrently, Costa provided opportunities for projects of a
label: Paragraph

text: gregarious or bucolic character along with projects that might be monumental
label: Paragraph

text: in terms of form but low-key in terms of size, such as the interquadra church. Some
label: Paragraph

text: traditional attributes of the street-corridor were retained on occasion. Acting alone
label: Paragraph

text: or together, topography, landscaping, and the block-like length of certain structures
label: Paragraph

text: with arcades could insinuate enclosure, continuity, and alignment, as in the high-
label: Paragraph

text: way-residential axis, the entertainment center, the local shopping areas, or the
label: Paragraph

text: walks surrounding superblocks.

text: Inauguration
label: Title

text: The jury praised Costa’s design, but had some reservations. There was too much
label: Paragraph

text: indeterminate land between the platform and the lake, the airport was too close,
label: Paragraph

text: there was no single-family housing along the lake as there should have been, and
label: Paragraph

text: the regional road pattern was not shown, especially in relation to eventual satellite
label: Paragraph

text: cities. As a result, the whole city was moved toward the lake. A band of row houses
label: Paragraph

text: was added to the west for NOVACAP lower-rank employees, the service road
label: Paragraph

text: along the outer row of superblocks became a commercial thoroughfare, and a
label: Paragraph

text: row of superblocks was added to the east, originally for cheaper three-story high
label: Caption

text: apartment buildings with no ground floor pilotis. The eastern bank of the lake was
label: Paragraph

text: subdivided into large lots for upscale single-family houses. The entertainment cen-
label: Paragraph

text: ter bridging the business districts gave way to a pair of shopping centers. The ordi-
label: Paragraph

text: nary city thickened and got a sharper curvature; the width of the highway
label: Paragraph

text: residential axis was reduced.
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer then widened the monumental axis, adding to Costa’s rhetoric the
label: Paragraph

text: representation of the capitol as balance. Instead of a single dome signaling the
label: Paragraph

text: National Congress, as suggested by Costa, a dome for the Senate and a bowl
label: Paragraph

text: for the Chamber of Deputies evidenced the duality of the Congress; twin office
label: Paragraph

text: towers acted as a pivot. Customary elements of monumental architecture distin-
label: Paragraph

text: guished his palaces: domes as much as colonnades, arcades, symmetries, sweeping
label: Paragraph

text: prospects, elaborate landscaping and works of art, marbles, mirrors. More often
label: Paragraph

text: than not, their unconventional aspect implied change as well as continuity. Pecu-
label: Paragraph

text: liarly shaped peristyles contributed to the lightness and transparency of the palaces
label: Paragraph

text: against the enclosure provided by the hills surrounding the city and the ever-pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ent, ever-moving clouds.’* As Norma Evenson remarked, “they did not convey a
label: Paragraph

text: secure sense of possessing the land” but awareness of the ephemeral, “a melan-
label: Paragraph

text: choly and sophisticated perception of how tenuous is man’s grasp of earth and
label: Paragraph

text: how transient are his works.”’? Abhorring grandiloquence as much as Costa,
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer invented a wholly memorable, thoroughly modern, anti-monumental
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality.
label: Paragraph

text: The esoteric typological variation was not missing. Costa and Niemeyer had
label: Paragraph

text: shown explicit interest in drawing a modern parallel to the classical orders. Costa
label: Paragraph

text: contrasted the Doric severity of the Ministry of Education with the Ionian elegance
label: Paragraph

text: of the Brazilian Pavilion at the New York World’s Fair of 1939.'* Niemeyer evoked
label: Paragraph

text: Corinthian luxury at the Pampulha Casino and took archaizing to another level
label: Paragraph

text: with the Ibirapuera Park pavilions’ tree-like columns. Stamo Papadaki had good
label: Paragraph

text: reason to compare the Alvorada external columns to caryatids: bulging, bellied,
label: Paragraph

text: folding, static figures contrasting with their counterparts at the Palacio do Planalto,
label: Paragraph

text: the presidential workplace, and the Supreme Court.’? The Alvorada external col-
label: Paragraph

text: umns develop both sculpturally and lengthwise in a matronly way, as befits the
label: Paragraph

text: conventions of domesticity. The Planalto and Supreme Court external columns
label: Caption

text: develop crosswise and almost flat, recalling a plate cut along two opposed arcs.
label: Paragraph

text: All of them are colossal and barely touch the ground, but the Planalto and Supreme
label: Paragraph

text: Court columns are lean and taut like a Minoan dancer, graceful Atlantes working
label: Paragraph

text: hard. The Planalto collonades define ground floor galleries with a virtual vaulted
label: Paragraph

text: ceiling, reinforcing the reference to government palaces facing a square, like
label: Paragraph

text: Palladio’s Basilica in Vicenza. The colonnades at the Supreme Court mask an under-
label: Paragraph

text: ground basement, and evoke Laugier’s primitive hut, archetype of the temple. The
label: Paragraph

text: executive branch has bourgeois republican overtones; at the legislative branch, law is
label: Paragraph

text: seen to be rooted in nature and, maybe, religion. Neoclassical Brazilian plantation
label: Paragraph

text: houses with freestanding chapels inform the Alvorada composition.
label: Paragraph

text: Binary oppositions and similarities highlight the programmatic complementari-
label: Paragraph

text: ness of the Alvorada and the Planalto, as well as the situational complementariness of
label: Paragraph

text: the Planalto and the Supreme Court. The suppression of the intermediate sector of
label: Paragraph

text: the frontal longitudinal colonnade, almost surreally, signals the entrance at the
label: Paragraph

text: Planalto and the Alvorada; it contrasts with the plain Supreme Court entrance on
label: Paragraph

text: the frontal short side devoid of intermediate columns, contributing to lightness
label: Paragraph

text: and recalling the porosity of earlier Brazilian modern masterpieces. Projecting
label: Paragraph

text: entrance ramps strengthen the institutional character of the Planalto and the
label: Paragraph

text: Supreme Court, while no obstacle interferes with the gaze at the residential Alvor-
label: Paragraph

text: ada. The gendered connotations of protuberances and cavities combine with those
label: Paragraph

text: of columnar rotundity and sharpness, as well as those of standing up and lying
label: Paragraph

text: down; at the National Congress, the phallic overtones of the twin towers contrast
label: Paragraph

text: with the feminine aura of the two domes, the depression in front of the access and
label: Paragraph

text: the horizontal spread of the roof-terrace. Costa emphasized the expression of foun-
label: Paragraph

text: dation. Fecundation — and fecundity — was Niemeyer’s forte since Pampulha.’°
label: Paragraph

text: Binary oppositions and similarities reappear at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and
label: Paragraph

text: the Ministry of Justice, squarish two-story buildings surrounded by reflecting pools.
label: Paragraph

text: The former displays round sculptural arcades in all sides, recalling the old neoclas-
label: Paragraph

text: sical Foreign Office in Rio. The latter displays flat round arcades in a Romanesque
label: Caption

text: spirit at the front and rear, contrasting with irregularly spaced pillars in the side ele-
label: Paragraph

text: vations, a muscular version of the Corbusian ondulatoires. Here, water falls noisily
label: Paragraph

text: from giant gargoyles; there, the upper floor verandah does not disturb the prevail-
label: Paragraph

text: ing serenity. Gendered connotations return as harsh law and suave diplomacy face
label: Paragraph

text: and complement each other. Double coding gains a twist, as the easy appreciation of
label: Paragraph

text: one building gives the clues for understanding its esoteric counterpart.
label: Paragraph

text: The same applies in a more complex way to the cathedral and the National
label: Paragraph

text: Theater. Built with exo-skeletons, endowed respectively with a receptive and a
label: Paragraph

text: protruding ramp, both display the frame of a tent on a cave-like basement. The
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuary is a circular hyperboloid rising on a platform shared with the egg-shaped,
label: Paragraph

text: womb-like baptistery and menorah-like bell tower. The compact, angular theater
label: Paragraph

text: presses down, a truncated pyramid on a grassy sloping ground. Glazed surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: extend between the curved and sculptural ribs of the sanctuary and the plain
label: Paragraph

text: oblique ribs in the short sides of the theater, over the foyers. The affinity between
label: Paragraph

text: religious ritual and stage performance validate the insinuation of a Theater of
label: Paragraph

text: Faith and a Temple of Spectacle, both exemplifying elaborate compositional
label: Paragraph

text: development.
label: Paragraph

text: Believers enter after going down a ramp and wandering through spaces remi-
label: Paragraph

text: niscent of catacombs. They may not know that in the Treasury of Atreus an
label: Paragraph

text: exposed entry ramp leads to an underground parabolic dome, the largest space
label: Paragraph

text: without supports before the Pantheon, or that the additive composition points
label: Paragraph

text: to the Campo Santo in Pisa, and the sanctuary counterpoints Le Corbusier's assem-
label: Paragraph

text: bly hall in Chandigarh. ’” Yet, going from darkness to light, they would remember
label: Paragraph

text: the Passion, death, and resurrection of Christ as well as the Roman and Jewish ori-
label: Paragraph

text: gins of their faith, hopefully recognizing the Church’s claim to be His bride and the
label: Paragraph

text: mother of the Catholic Apostolic Christendom, as well as the Mycenaean origins of
label: Paragraph

text: monumental domed architecture. Spectators must also go down to reach their seat
label: Paragraph

text: at one of the two auditoria flanking the same scenic box. They may not know that
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer bowed to Mies’ Mannheim project,’* or that he hid the fly-tower to fash-
label: Paragraph

text: ion a modern mastaba, the house for the dead that replicated the house of the living
label: Paragraph

text: in ancient Egypt. Yet going from light to darkness they would remember the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: origins of the fan-shaped auditoria, ifnot the Dyonisian cult at the root of the scenic
label: Paragraph

text: art or the Egyptian origins of monumental trabeated architecture.

text: Like Costa’s pilot plan, Niemeyer’s palaces contributed to the longstanding
label: Paragraph

text: debate about democratic monumentality, now unfolding in the Cold War con-
label: Paragraph

text: text. Their peristyles and exoskeletons reasserted the vitality of the modern tra-
label: Paragraph

text: dition. Subtler in the expression of tectonics than the Glass House, the Crown
label: Paragraph

text: Hall, and the American Embassy in India, or the Lincoln Center and the National
label: Paragraph

text: Reappraisal
label: Title

text: The monumental sector was completed according to the inauguration plan by
label: Paragraph

text: 1970, along with the cathedral, the theater and a tourist information center adjoin-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the bus station. Criticism had started even before the inauguration in 1960. Peo-
label: Paragraph

text: ple like Zevi said that democracy had no use for monumentality.'” Others thought
label: Paragraph

text: that Brasilia lacked solemnity and paled in comparison to Chandigarh; it was not
label: Paragraph

text: monumental enough.” Then came the criticism of zoning, comprehensive pla-
label: Paragraph

text: nning, and the functionalist ideology behind them, followed by the criticism of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism and its architectural and urban typologies. Order, progress, and pla-
label: Paragraph

text: nning themselves became suspect. Small was beautiful, and spontaneity idolized
label: Paragraph

text: to the left and to the right. The spaces and structures of green, car-oriented, bureau-
label: Paragraph

text: cratic Brasilia appeared too vast, too restrictive, wasteful, improvident, perverse,
label: Paragraph

text: and inhuman. Brasilia was increasingly seen as the late manifestation of a demo-
label: Paragraph

text: cratic utopia that turned out to be simple-minded, elitist, and authoritarian —
label: Paragraph

text: and exclusionary too, unable or unwilling to fight the spread of satellite cities
label: Paragraph

text: and favelas housing the poor. The fact that the country had been taken over by
label: Paragraph

text: a military dictatorship did not help. Well-meaning First World intellectuals were
label: Paragraph

text: quick to malign the efforts of “underdeveloped colonials,” and the symbolic coup
label: Paragraph

text: hurt. Brazil was no longer pioneering and daring; it had reverted to being retarded
label: Paragraph

text: and peripheral.”' It was no comfort to realize that Brasilia was being made the
label: Paragraph

text: scapegoat for the perceived sins of the car-oriented American city of the 1950s
label: Paragraph

text: while the virtues of the rail-oriented European city of the 1850s, so maligned during
label: Paragraph

text: the 1920s and 1930s, were being reappraised.
label: Paragraph

text: All the same, Kubitschek’s decision to build Brasilia’s key infrastructure from the
label: Paragraph

text: outset had been sound, because it made the city irreversible. Brasilia did not cease
label: Paragraph

text: to grow, even if this was disorderly, and “new town blues” gave way to consider-
label: Paragraph

text: able contentment with the quality of life in the pilot plan; many satellite cities
label: Paragraph

text: became enriched, diversifying their population composition and diminishing their
label: Paragraph

text: dependency on government jobs. Brazil became democratic again in the late 1980s,
label: Paragraph

text: and prospered. Modern architecture was rehabilitated. As of 2013 the federal dis-
label: Paragraph

text: trict population is 2.5 million, of which 380,000 live in the pilot plan area. It is the
label: Paragraph

text: country’s fourth largest metropolitan area. Although social inequality still ranks
label: Paragraph

text: high, income per capita is highest of all Brazilian cities.” The march toward the
label: Paragraph

text: west was rather successful. The vitality of the pilot plan shows in the number
label: Paragraph

text: of cars using the city’s roads and parking areas. The city was not made for either
label: Paragraph

text: the tourist or Baudelaire’s flaneur. Yet, contrary to expectations, the vitality of the
label: Paragraph

text: pilot plan also shows in the number of people walking its central areas and residen-
label: Paragraph

text: tial wings. So the demonization of Brasilia seems to be coming to an end and a less
label: Paragraph

text: sectarian reappraisal is under way.
label: Paragraph

text: Oddly enough, from the architect’s standpoint, it is the lack and not the excess
label: Paragraph

text: of planning that appears most problematic. Uncoordinated public and private
label: Paragraph

text: planning decisions regarding the federal district contributed to the prevention of
label: Paragraph

text: adequate evaluation of their systemic implications, such as the increase in public
label: Paragraph

text: transportation costs brought about by excessive distances between settlements
label: Title

text: in the metropolitan region. In that sense, the pilot plan was being undermined from
label: Paragraph

text: without, even before its inauguration. Erosion from within is more recent and
label: Paragraph

text: insidious. Occupation of its sectors is now intensive, and the new visual density
label: Paragraph

text: is not unlike any other Brazilian city. The exceptionality of the monumental sector
label: Paragraph

text: has been reinforced. By and large, the general formal characteristics that Costa pro-
label: Paragraph

text: posed for each sector have been respected. Unlike any other Brazilian city, there is
label: Paragraph

text: no single-family house cheek by jowl with a high-rise building. Arguably, this for-
label: Paragraph

text: mal order is more important than what goes on within the buildings, as the same
label: Paragraph

text: typology may shelter different functions. Given this relative autonomy, zoning can
label: Paragraph

text: be considered more a legal than a design issue, and its specifications far from
label: Paragraph

text: irreversible. After all, simplicity precedes complexity. Incidentally, many people,
label: Paragraph

text: including Europeans, do like the separation of dwelling from workplace, and it
label: Paragraph

text: does not offend reason to prioritize motorized movement in the main circulation
label: Paragraph

text: network ofa city, buses and taxis included. However, emptiness within sectors was
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by confusion. The distribution of buildings and open spaces feels arbitrary
label: Paragraph

text: or random, and is not redeemed by the open ground floor, as in the superblocks.
label: Paragraph

text: The basic but efficient logic of the street-corridor is missing, and there is no alter-
label: Paragraph

text: nate order on view.
label: Paragraph

text: It is a design challenge, and an opportunity to turn clay into marble, as Augustus
label: Paragraph

text: did with Rome. But then, Venetians took 300 years to complete Piazza San Marco.
label: Paragraph

text: By that yardstick, Brasilia has not even reached adolescence, and the present situ-
label: Paragraph

text: ation is far from hopeless.
