text: ENDLESS HOUSE
label: Title

text: Friedrich Kiesler
label: Title

text: William W. Braham
label: Title

text: Friedrich Kiesler, Endless House, 1959. Credit: Irving Penn. Reproduced by permission of
label: Caption

text: Condé Nast and the Austrian Friedrich and Lillian Kiesler Private Foundation.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: As Frederick (born Friedrich) Kiesler (1890-1965) explained, “it is called the end-
label: Paragraph

text: less house because all the areas can be opened up into one continuous flow of
label: Paragraph

text: space, but they can also be separated for privacy and seclusion.”’ In specific
label: Paragraph

text: terms, the endless house is a building Kiesler designed in the late 1950s, which
label: Paragraph

text: had been commissioned by Arthur Drexler, Director of the Department of Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture and Design at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), for construction in
label: Paragraph

text: the museum’s garden. It consists of four interpenetrating ovoid volumes that sit
label: Paragraph

text: on somewhat awkward hollow piers, which in the best photographs are con-
label: Paragraph

text: cealed in shadow, allowing the organic forms to float freely in space. More gen-
label: Paragraph

text: erally, the endless house was a concept that Kiesler began exploring in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1940s, published initially as a single ellipsoid in 1950, and then elaborated in a
label: Paragraph

text: variety of forms, for a variety of clients, galleries, and exhibitions, until his death
label: Paragraph

text: in 1965. He ultimately claimed that the “endless” was his one “basic creative
label: Paragraph

text: idea,” which he had first conceived in the early 1920s and explored for more than
label: Paragraph

text: 40 years.
label: Paragraph

text: A full-sized endless house was never built in the MoMA garden, or anywhere
label: Paragraph

text: else, though a large, 8 foot model of concrete on a wire-mesh frame was prepared
label: Paragraph

text: for MoMA’s “Visionary Architecture” exhibition in 1960, which featured more than
label: Paragraph

text: 30 projects “considered too revolutionary to build.”” Philip Johnson called Kiesler,
label: Paragraph

text: “the best-known non-building architect of our time,” and through this period, one
label: Paragraph

text: prospective client after another declined to actually build an endless house.’ Nev-
label: Paragraph

text: ertheless, the project received a decade of commentary and discussion, even includ-
label: Paragraph

text: ing a CBS television special in 1960, after which Ada Louise Huxtable, the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture critic of the New York Times, observed that Kiesler’s “theory has
label: Paragraph

text: become an almost legendary canon of progressive thought among professionals.”*
label: Paragraph

text: The particular appeal of the endless house was its radical formal difference from the
label: Paragraph

text: high-modernist buildings of the postwar period, combined with Kiesler’s sophisti-
label: Paragraph

text: cated architectural theories, and his decades of careful positioning with the
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde.
label: Paragraph

text: Kiesler’s endless house project stands as a precursor, if not a progenitor, of the
label: Paragraph

text: biomorphic buildings of the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries, and o:
label: Paragraph

text: the successes and challenges they have encountered. It also exemplifies the full
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of what Detlef Mertins called the “architecture industry,” the paralle
label: Paragraph

text: world of architectural manifestos, publications, galleries, and exhibitions that mir-
label: Paragraph

text: ror the social and economic arrangements of the artistic avant-garde. Kiesler’s
label: Paragraph

text: career was almost entirely conducted within that economy — only a few buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were ever completed — but it allowed him to explore and refine his theories o
label: Paragraph

text: space, continuity, correalism, biotechnique, universality, and even health, which
label: Paragraph

text: sought to capture the living “nucleus of the ‘dwelling universe’: the nervous system
label: Paragraph

text: of the house.”* The inability of the different manifestations of the “endless” to fulfil
label: Paragraph

text: the promise of these theories exemplifies the dilemma of any project that offers
label: Paragraph

text: endless transformation and adaptation with a specific, fixed form. Kiesler seems
label: Paragraph

text: to have recognized the dilemma himself, and shortly after the successes of the end-
label: Paragraph

text: less house began to advocate a fully “process architecture”:
label: Paragraph

text: If we could convert our static functions of design into design-flows of life forces and
label: Paragraph

text: thus replace defunct functional architecture with: Process Aychitecture we will have
label: Paragraph

text: done our share as social beings and conceded our conceit as pseudo functionalists.°
label: Paragraph

text: Always Avant-Garde
label: Title

text: By all accounts, Kiesler was charming, persuasive, and talented. Like other early
label: Paragraph

text: architectural émigrés — Richard Neutra, Richard Schindler, and William Lescaze —
label: Paragraph

text: he traveled to America in the 1920s, in his case from Austria, carrying the messages
label: Paragraph

text: of the European avant-garde. He never ceased joining groups and adapting to new
label: Paragraph

text: movements, shuttling between architecture and the fine arts, and working concur-
label: Paragraph

text: rently in product, furniture, display, and theatrical design. He was the youngest
label: Paragraph

text: member of De Stijl, helped found the American Union of Decorative Artists
label: Paragraph

text: and Craftsmen, joined Buckminster Fuller’s Structural Studies Associates, the the-
label: Paragraph

text: ater faculty at Julliard, and formed the Laboratory of Design Correlation at Colum-
label: Paragraph

text: bia University. Through his friendship with Marcel Duchamp and the exiled
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian art community, he became the “official” architect of the surrealists and
label: Paragraph

text: was commissioned by Peggy Guggenheim to design the Art of the Century gallery.
label: Paragraph

text: He frequented the Cedar Tavern in Greenwich Village, befriending de Kooning
label: Paragraph

text: and the New York School of artists, just as the center of the art world was shifting
label: Paragraph

text: from Paris to New York, and even helped a young Andy Warhol get his start.
label: Paragraph

text: Kiesler counted himself as belonging to the third generation of Viennese modern
label: Paragraph

text: architects: “[Otto] Wagner (1841-1918) was the first generation. Then came Adolf
label: Paragraph

text: Loos (1870-1933) and Josef Hoffmann (1870-1956). I was the third generation. And
label: Paragraph

text: there is a fourth generation continuing.”” He had been born in Czernowitz, now
label: Paragraph

text: part of the Ukraine, and studied painting and printmaking in Vienna just before the
label: Paragraph

text: First World War in the final years of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. He is reported
label: Paragraph

text: to have worked briefly for Adolf Loos, but found his place in the avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: through theatrical design. He was inducted into De Stijl in 1923, when Theo
label: Paragraph

text: van Doesburg saw his “electro-mechanical” staging for Karel Carpek’s play, “R.
label: Paragraph

text: U.R.,” in Berlin. In 1924 he prepared an “International Exhibition of New Theater
label: Paragraph

text: Techniques” for the Music and Theater Festival of Vienna, using an explicitly De
label: Paragraph

text: Stijllike “L + T” mounting arrangement, which firmly established him within the
label: Paragraph

text: group. The exhibition also featured his Space Stage, an elevated circular stage, sur-
label: Paragraph

text: rounded by two interlocking circular ramps, which he subsequently developed into
label: Paragraph

text: an ellipsoidal configuration that he called the “endless theater” and later cited as the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of his obsession.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1925 he was invited by Josef Hoffman to prepare a theater display for the Aus-
label: Paragraph

text: trian section of the Exposition Internationale des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels
label: Caption

text: Modernes in Paris. He configured the exhibition design as a utopian “City in
label: Paragraph

text: Space,” using the characteristic elements and colors of De-Stijl in a massive con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction suspended from the ceiling. Le Corbusier (whose |’Esprit Nouveau pavil-
label: Caption

text: ion was also in the exposition) asked, “Do you intend to hang the houses from
label: Paragraph

text: Zeppelins?” to which Kiesler replied enigmatically, “by suspension in tension,”
label: Paragraph

text: and his manifesto detailed the utopian principles that prefigured many of the ambi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of the endless house:*
label: Title

text: Transformation of the surrounding area of space into cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Liberation from the ground, abolition of the static axis.
label: Paragraph

text: No walls, no foundations.
label: Paragraph

text: A system of spans (tension) in free SPACE
label: Paragraph

text: Creation of new kinds of living, and, through them, the demands which will
label: Paragraph

text: remold society.”
label: Paragraph

text: VR ON
label: Title

text: It was the success of the theater exposition that brought Kiesler to the United
label: Paragraph

text: States in 1926, specifically to mount a version of the show under the sponsorship
label: Paragraph

text: of Jane Heap, editor of the Little Review. But despite the acclaim with which he had
label: Paragraph

text: arrived, he struggled for professional success in New York for more than 20 years,
label: Paragraph

text: until the postwar period, when his ideas for the endless house began to attract
label: Paragraph

text: attention. Though he prepared many design proposals, the one building of signif-
label: Paragraph

text: icance that he completed in that period was the Film Guild Cinema of 1928, whose
label: Paragraph

text: facade followed De Stijl compositional principles, though the theater itself
label: Paragraph

text: was a dramatically spare, rectilinear “megaphone,” focused on a transformable
label: Paragraph

text: “screen-o-scope.”'°
label: Paragraph

text: To make ends meet, he began designing display windows for Saks Fifth Ave-
label: Paragraph

text: nue, leading to a fascinating book, Contemporary Art Applied to the Store and Its Dis-
label: Paragraph

text: play, as well as a variety of events, including the exposition of the American Union
label: Paragraph

text: of Decorative Artists and Craftsmen in 1930, which featured an elegant Flying
label: Paragraph

text: Desk, illustrating his continued fascination with liberation from the ground.”
label: Paragraph

text: Though his projects in this period included designs for a Performing Arts Center
label: Paragraph

text: for Brooklyn Heights, and The Universal, a winning entry for a theater competi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion for Woodstock, New York, he only returned to stage design in 1933 with his
label: Paragraph

text: appointment as scenic designer for the opera department at Julliard, a position he
label: Paragraph

text: held until 1957.
label: Paragraph

text: Ultimately it was through his publication in architectural journals through the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s and 1940s that Kiesler established his own identify as an architect, distinct
label: Paragraph

text: from De Stijl. Beginning with his explanation of the “Space House” exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: in 1934, then his “Design Correlation” series of 1937, and his most challenging
label: Paragraph

text: piece, “On Correalism and Biotechnique” of 1939, Kiesler’s articles in the Architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural Record were a polemical combination of his developing theory of “correality”
label: Paragraph

text: and his fascination with “continuous construction.”’” Kiesler’s theory of technol-
label: Paragraph

text: ogy, and the evolution of tools, was clearly influenced by his experience with Buck-
label: Paragraph

text: minster Fuller and the Structural Studies Associates (SSA), a group Fuller founded
label: Paragraph

text: in 1932 to provide an architectural response to the Committee on Technocracy and
label: Paragraph

text: which briefly transformed the staid T-Square Journal into Shelter, one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: radical journals of the era.’* In 1940, Kiesler even presented a resolution, “Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture as Biotechnique,” at the Ann Arbor Design Conference, which was “unan-
label: Paragraph

text: imously endorsed by the participants, including Walter Gropius, Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, and Eero Saarinen.” *
label: Paragraph

text: Through the 1940s he worked more closely with the surrealists, especially Duch-
label: Paragraph

text: amp and Max Ernst. Starting with the Art of this Century gallery in 1942, he
label: Paragraph

text: designed a number of surrealist exhibitions in Paris and New York, published
label: Paragraph

text: pieces in VVV Almanac, the surrealist journal, and even participated in Duchamp’s
label: Paragraph

text: “Imagery of Chess” event at the Levy Gallery in 1945.’* In 1949 Kiesler published a
label: Paragraph

text: translation and expansion of the Record article on Correalism in L’Architecture d’au-
label: Paragraph

text: jourdhui; subtitled “Les Etats unis de l'art plastique,” which collaged fragments of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1939 article with his sculptures and surrealist gallery designs of the intervening
label: Paragraph

text: decade. At some point in this period, he began exploring the “endless” more
label: Paragraph

text: directly, mentioning it in the VVV article and preparing sketches titled “Paris End-
label: Paragraph

text: less” while he was designing the Salle de Superstition at the Gallerie Maeght
label: Paragraph

text: The first public appearance of an endless house was in an exhibition, “The
label: Paragraph

text: Muralist and the Modern Architect,” at the Koontz Gallery in 1950, which was con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceived to feature collaborations between artists and architects. Invited by the sculp-
label: Paragraph

text: tor, David Hare, who had contributed a sculpture to the exhibition at Gallerie
label: Paragraph

text: Maeght, Kiesler prepared a small, ellipsoid model “about a foot long, and eight
label: Paragraph

text: or nine inches wide and seven or eight inches high,” for which Hare designed a
label: Paragraph

text: stair/pedestal.'® Philip Johnson immediately acquired Kiesler’s model for the
label: Paragraph

text: MoMA collection, and Arthur Drexler, then the editor of Interiors magazine, wrote
label: Paragraph

text: a long article on the project and its “psychological lighting,” which led to the com-
label: Paragraph

text: mission for the MoMA garden a few years later.’”
label: Paragraph

text: This abbreviated biography makes visible the degree to which Kiesler’s career,
label: Paragraph

text: and the endless house itself, were made possible by the social and economic
label: Paragraph

text: arrangements of the architectural (and artistic) avant-garde. Very much like the
label: Paragraph

text: growth and commercialization of the art world through the nineteenth and twen-
label: Paragraph

text: tieth centuries, the mutually supporting and evolving interests of architectural jour-
label: Paragraph

text: nals, museums, galleries, and schools supported a world of activities increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: independent from the immediate service industry of architectural design and con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction. Architects have competed for the patronage of clients since Vitruvius
label: Paragraph

text: crafted his treatise for the emperor Augustus, but the steadily increasing numbers
label: Paragraph

text: of architects, building projects, and building types only intensified the competition.
label: Paragraph

text: The growing wealth and population of industrialized countries and the further spe-
label: Paragraph

text: cialization of the professions involved in design and construction provided the
label: Paragraph

text: grounds for the emergence of an almost autonomous system of evaluating and
label: Paragraph

text: ranking designers and their ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: It has become common in recent years to complain about the positioning of
label: Paragraph

text: “starchitects,” but in a period of dramatic economic growth, with an abundance
label: Paragraph

text: of construction, the sorting mechanisms and status of the “A-list” takes on real
label: Paragraph

text: value. It is a thoroughly rational form of ranking and stratification, with archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects ascending through the stages from local, to national, to international
label: Paragraph

text: acclaim, and also serves as a sorting process for ideas and priorities within
label: Paragraph

text: disciplines.
label: Paragraph

text: In the competition within (and among) European capitals through the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century, the early forms of the process were bound up with university pro-
label: Paragraph

text: fessorships and institutional exhibitions, often state sponsored, and they provided
label: Paragraph

text: both a stamp of authority and access to commissions. Rebellions such as the staging
label: Paragraph

text: of the Salon des Refusés in 1863 or against Viollet le Duc’s teaching at the Ecole des
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts in 1864 (both of which occurred just as the population of Paris reached
label: Paragraph

text: two million) signal the existence of a sufficient population of artists, architects, stu-
label: Paragraph

text: dents, professors, galleries, and commentators to form opposing groups, and a pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lic with enough leisure to care.
label: Paragraph

text: The original patrimony described by Kiesler — Wagner, Hoffman, Loos — also
label: Paragraph

text: involved the emergence ofa distinct class of artists and architects, vying for position
label: Paragraph

text: and recognition in Vienna at the turn of the century. Kiesler even drew a diagram
label: Paragraph

text: of the Karlsplatz to explain the ferment of the time and compared it to exchanges in
label: Paragraph

text: the Cedar Tavern of the New York School.’* It was these worlds of ideas and
label: Paragraph

text: debate that Kiesler loved, and it helps explain his movement from De Stijl to
label: Paragraph

text: the SSA, AUDAC, the surrealists, and the New York School, allowing him to stay
label: Paragraph

text: always avant-garde, contributing new ideas to the discipline rather than serving
label: Paragraph

text: clients. Arthur Drexler may have described it most cogently in the press release
label: Paragraph

text: for the “Visionary Architecture” exhibition:
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture too has an existence prior to its becoming real, and there is a second
label: Paragraph

text: history of architecture that parallels the real one. It is the history of an architecture
label: Paragraph

text: unhampered by technical details and uncompromised by the whims of patrons, or
label: Paragraph

text: the exigencies of finance, politics, and custom.
label: Paragraph

text: The true visionary project usually combines a criticism of society with a strong per-
label: Paragraph

text: sonal preference for certain forms. In the past such projects were unbuildable for one
label: Paragraph

text: or both of two reasons: they may have been technically impossible to execute at the
label: Paragraph

text: time they were designed; or society could find neither the justification nor the money
label: Paragraph

text: for their construction. Today virtually nothing an architect can think of is technically
label: Paragraph

text: impossible to realize. Social usage, which includes economics, determines what is
label: Paragraph

text: visionary and what is not.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Kiesler’s restless navigation of the avant-garde provided him with the support to
label: Paragraph

text: develop his ideas of the endless, but he was also acutely aware of the distortions of
label: Paragraph

text: that cultural echo-chamber, and with each transformation in his affiliation — from
label: Paragraph

text: De Stijl to SSA to Surrealist — he sought his own, more fundamental insight. His
label: Paragraph

text: criticisms of functionalism and the International Style could as easily be applied to
label: Paragraph

text: his own early work and must have driven him on his search: “Modern functional-
label: Paragraph

text: ism in architecture has its roots far more in contemporary abstract painting than in
label: Paragraph

text: the ‘functionalism of living.’””°
label: Paragraph

text: Stages for Living
label: Title

text: Kiesler provided so many explanations, justifications, and illustrations for the end-
label: Paragraph

text: less house, and its underlying theories of correalism, biotechnique, and continuous
label: Paragraph

text: construction, that it can be difficult to discern his intentions. In 1961, he even linked
label: Paragraph

text: it to the space age — “let’s be honest; the satellites, the rockets, the flying dogs and
label: Paragraph

text: monkeys have taken us by surprise, and now everyone is concerned with continu-
label: Paragraph

text: ity” — which perplexed the interviewer who recorded the observation and who had
label: Paragraph

text: initially thought the “endless” was part of the “New Sensualism.””’ But for all the
label: Paragraph

text: twists and turns, for all his adaptations to the fashionable forms or topics of the
label: Paragraph

text: moment, he had a fundamental insight at some point early in his career and
label: Paragraph

text: wrestled with its architectural consequences ever after.
label: Paragraph

text: It is not accidental that the first example of an “endless” construction, the ellipsoi-
label: Paragraph

text: dal endless theater of 1926, was configured to house a continuous and adaptable
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of staging without a stage. Kiesler was a man of the theater first,
label: Paragraph

text: and his deepest insight was that architecture provides a kind of stage for living,
label: Paragraph

text: for accommodating the entrances and exits of its players and the changes in scenery,
label: Paragraph

text: lighting, and mood that they require.” That view certainly fits comfortably in the
label: Paragraph

text: Viennese architectural milieu from which Kiesler emerged, particularly within the
label: Paragraph

text: many interpretations of Gottfried Semper’s principle of Bekleidung, or dressing,
label: Paragraph

text: developed in his culminating work, Der Stil (1860), and which even inspired the nam-
label: Paragraph

text: ing of De Stijl. Semper’s frank embrace of artifice and his careful analysis of technique
label: Paragraph

text: set the terms of debate for the generations that followed — Wagner, Loos, Hoffman,
label: Paragraph

text: Riegl, Fiedler, even Schmarsow — and helps explain the roots of Kiesler’s dilemma:”
label: Paragraph

text: I think that dressing and the mask are as old as human civilization, and the joy in both
label: Paragraph

text: is identical with the joy in those things that drove men to be sculptors, painters, archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects, poets, musicians, dramatists, in short, artists. Every artistic creation, every artis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic pleasure presupposes a certain carnival spirit, or to express myself in a modern
label: Paragraph

text: way — the haze of carnival candles is the true atmosphere of art.”
label: Paragraph

text: From the Endless Theater, to the Space House, to “Correalism and
label: Paragraph

text: Biotechnique,” to the Salle de Superstition, Kiesler sought to understand fully
label: Paragraph

text: the complex “functionalism of living” and to imagine an architecture adequate
label: Paragraph

text: to its mystery and vitality.
label: Paragraph

text: His first sustained effort was the Space House of 1933, which was the center-
label: Paragraph

text: piece of a furniture exhibition assembled in the Modernage showroom in New
label: Caption

text: York. He described it as a “proportional substitute” for a single-family house
label: Paragraph

text: on four connected levels with movable and flexible partitions. Architectural Record
label: Caption

text: published it in a continuous 18-page photographic spread of which only the first
label: Paragraph

text: three or four images actually disclose any spatial features. There are no plans or
label: Paragraph

text: diagrams, and while the first pages include a few establishing shots, the compo-
label: Paragraph

text: sition of the last 12 pages follows a precise format that pairs portrait and detail
label: Paragraph

text: photographs of the materials. The role of each material detail is also subtly
label: Paragraph

text: explained by the insertion of a hand, the toe of a shoe, a product label, or a
label: Paragraph

text: silhouette of scissors.
label: Paragraph

text: The final image of the Space House article shows a ferninine hand presenting a
label: Paragraph

text: twine curtain with a knot held between the thumb and forefinger, the knot used to
label: Paragraph

text: make the house’s fishnet curtains. It is an ancient knot, known as both the fisher-
label: Paragraph

text: man’s and the weaver’s knot, which does not easily unravel and in a network allows
label: Paragraph

text: for ready splicing and repair. Semper cited precisely this knot in Der Stil as the “old-
label: Paragraph

text: est technical symbol” and illustrated it twice in a similar fashion. He explained the
label: Paragraph

text: knotted network first as a principle of construction, then as a decorative tradition in
label: Paragraph

text: fabric and, most importantly, as it was translated into tectonic materials, “dressing”
label: Paragraph

text: the surface of walls.”” The knot is part of his extended demonstration that textiles
label: Paragraph

text: and architecture arose together from the principle of Bekleidung; what first appears
label: Paragraph

text: as a textile enclosure later becomes a mask concealing and representing the mys-
label: Paragraph

text: teries of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In a subsequent article on the Space House in Hound and Horn, Kiesler outlined
label: Paragraph

text: the theory of the house using the stilted language of the SSA into which he had
label: Paragraph

text: recently been inducted: “The Space-House at Modernage represents two modern
label: Paragraph

text: architectural principles, besides its solution as a One-Family-Shelter: (a) the Time-
label: Paragraph

text: Space-Concept of architecture; (b) the Shell-Construction in continuous ten-
label: Paragraph

text: sion.””° The complex arrangement of rooms, levels, and spaces has a filial relation
label: Paragraph

text: to the Raumplan of Loos; it also established the need for the fabric curtains and
label: Paragraph

text: flexible partitions to accommodate the changing needs of the (imagined) occu-
label: Paragraph

text: pants. Kiesler opposed this time-space-concept to the “esthetic or techno-func-
label: Paragraph

text: tional” approach of “Le Corbusier, Mies, Oud, and others,” referring obliquely
label: Paragraph

text: to the International Style show then on tour, and claimed for his work a “unified
label: Paragraph

text: architectural dogma.”
label: Paragraph

text: The “dogma” was evidently in transition from “time-space” to “correlation,” a
label: Paragraph

text: term developed within the SSA and used prominently by Buckminster Fuller in
label: Paragraph

text: Shelter (1932). The altered spelling of Kiesler’s neologism, “correalism,” signals a
label: Paragraph

text: further transformation from co-relation to co-reality, which he claimed as his
label: Paragraph

text: own. Fuller and the SSA used the term quite variously to describe mutual relations
label: Paragraph

text: between events or conditions, but Kiesler put it in designer’s terms: “A bench is
label: Paragraph

text: restful, a rocking chair is more, but correlated to a desk, a straight chair is better.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Correalism
label: Title

text: “On Correalism and Biotechnique” of 1939 was the mature explanation of Kiesler’s
label: Paragraph

text: theory: “the term ‘Correalism’ expresses the dynamics of continual interaction
label: Paragraph

text: between man and his natural and technological environments.””* This definition
label: Paragraph

text: drew on the evolutionary view of tools and society developed by the sociolo-
label: Paragraph

text: gist/planner Patrick Geddes and applied by Lewis Mumford in Technics and Civi-
label: Paragraph

text: lization of 1934. Aspects of Kiesler’s previous work, particularly the “Morphology-
label: Paragraph

text: Chart of Architecture” from the Hound and Horn article, show a kinship with the
label: Paragraph

text: gridded “thinking machines” prepared by Geddes. With Kiesler’s talent for graphic
label: Paragraph

text: means, the charts and diagrams in “On Correalism” achieve a particular elegance.
label: Paragraph

text: He summarized the three relationships of correality in a tripartite diagram illustrat-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the co-evolution of nature, technology, and society, with man at the center. He
label: Paragraph

text: subsumed tools and machines under the concept of the technological environment
label: Paragraph

text: (from “shirts to shelter”) and traced the stages of transformation. Dismissing the
label: Paragraph

text: idea that technology is simply produced by scientific advance, he observed, instead,
label: Paragraph

text: that “the technological environment is produced by human needs,” which led him
label: Paragraph

text: to a critical set of questions about functional design:
label: Paragraph

text: What is a need? How do needs arise? Are they natural or artificial? Are they static or in
label: Paragraph

text: evolution? A definition of needs has today become of prime importance to the
label: Paragraph

text: designer of technological environment. Investigations on this crucial point cannot
label: Paragraph

text: be based upon the study of architecture but must be based on upon the study
label: Paragraph

text: of man.”
label: Paragraph

text: Shifting the focus onto man and his needs led to the key insight of On Correal-
label: Paragraph

text: ism: “Needs are not static: they evolve.” Only a few of these needs are “natural” —
label: Paragraph

text: hunger, thirst, and so on — and even these are culturally conditioned. The needs by
label: Paragraph

text: which most technologies are shaped have progressed step-by-step with the devices
label: Paragraph

text: meant to accommodate their demands. The aspirations or even luxuries of one
label: Paragraph

text: generation become the needs of the next and so drive the progressive advance
label: Paragraph

text: of innovation and of fashion. This well exceeds the structural argument of conti-
label: Paragraph

text: nuity, pointing to the “endless” construction of human identity and its mirroring in
label: Paragraph

text: architectural constructions.
label: Paragraph

text: The mechanistic logic of functionalism rests on the identification of stable needs
label: Paragraph

text: that can be satisfied by design. The emerging paradigm of the 1930s drew on the
label: Paragraph

text: formulations of ecology in the late nineteenth century and developed in the full
label: Paragraph

text: flowering of systems-theory in the mid-twentieth. The reach of the paradigm into
label: Paragraph

text: which Kiesler’s theory fits was described by Mumford in Technics and Civilization:
label: Paragraph

text: The humane arts of the physician and the psychologist and the architect, the hygien-
label: Paragraph

text: ist and the community planner, have begun during the last few decades to displace
label: Paragraph

text: the mechanical arts from their hitherto central position in our economy and our life.
label: Paragraph

text: Form, pattern, configuration, organism, historical filiation, ecological relationship are
label: Paragraph

text: concepts that work up and down the ladder of the sciences: the esthetic structure and
label: Paragraph

text: the social relations are as real as the primary physical qualities and the sciences were
label: Paragraph

text: once content to isolate. This conceptual change, then, is a widespread movement that
label: Paragraph

text: is going on in every part of society: in part it arises out of the general resurgence of
label: Paragraph

text: life — the care of children, the culture of sex, the return to wild nature and the
label: Title

text: renewed worship of the sun — and in turn it gives intellectual re-enforcement to these
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneous movements and activities.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Ecology was initially formulated to account for the changes in the “environ-
label: Paragraph

text: ment” that directed the incremental evolution of species, and those ideas had been
label: Paragraph

text: extended to tools and technologies within the first years after Darwin’s Origin of
label: Paragraph

text: Species was published. Kiesler’s ambition was to explain the genesis and evolution
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings over time, and with his students in at Columbia, he designed and built
label: Paragraph

text: an example that helps illustrate the process he imagined. They designed and built a
label: Paragraph

text: “Mobile Home-Library” — a bookcase — not only based on a conventional analysis of
label: Paragraph

text: ergonomics and material constraints, but also to accommodate anticipated changes
label: Paragraph

text: in the capacity and usage of the library, and the progressive evolution of the media
label: Paragraph

text: of information storage. He claimed it as a “nucleus of possibilities which will be
label: Paragraph

text: developed through coordination with other elements,” though the same could
label: Paragraph

text: be said of any artifact.”’ The resulting bookcase was both banal and elegant,
label: Paragraph

text: and illustrates Kiesler’s dilemma: designing discrete objects within a comprehen-
label: Paragraph

text: sive theory of evolution and adaptation over generations. From the perspective
label: Paragraph

text: of evolutionary theory, every object is just another experiment.
label: Paragraph

text: After his decade with the surrealists, Kiesler re-presented his theory of correalism
label: Paragraph

text: in 1949, reviewing the stages of its development from Space House to Home-Library
label: Paragraph

text: to the Salle de Superstition, and concluded with a restated Manifeste du Corréalisme:
label: Paragraph

text: When a constructed space is conceived as a unified ensemble, that is to say, as a con-
label: Paragraph

text: tinuum of colors, forms, and mechanical structures, there must be an essential, inter-
label: Paragraph

text: nal force that holds the structure together in a state of coordination. This force is the
label: Paragraph

text: specific ideology and represents the atom of the field of architecture.”
label: Paragraph

text: Kiesler’s dilemma becomes visible when he argues that the smooth walls of the
label: Paragraph

text: endless house represent that unified ensemble, that the continuity of surface or
label: Paragraph

text: structure somehow translates to a state of continuous coordination with the forces
label: Paragraph

text: that engender buildings. He restates his aspirations for “spherical space” and
label: Paragraph

text: “houses without walls,” but concludes with a prediction of a kind of an autono-
label: Paragraph

text: mous, architecture without architects”: “by itself, gradually and naturally, Folk-
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture will develop ... For the nature of Folk-Architecture is found in its will-
label: Paragraph

text: ingness to adapt to the circumstances of life, to the laws of society, and to assume
label: Paragraph

text: responsibility for their creation as well as their transformation.”
label: Paragraph

text: The endless house was both a simulation of that Folk-Architecture and an orig-
label: Paragraph

text: inal, sculptural exploration by Kiesler, which prefigures both the formal qualities of
label: Paragraph

text: the biomorphic buildings of recent years and the theories with which they are pre-
label: Paragraph

text: sented. Although Greg Lynn, for example, questioned the rigor of Kiesler’s topo-
label: Paragraph

text: logical techniques, it is hard not to see the connection of Kiesler’s “essential,
label: Paragraph

text: internal force” and “unified ensemble” with the “abstract machine” and “assem-
label: Paragraph

text: blage” of Deleuze that guided the experiments of the 1990s. And the dilemma
label: Paragraph

text: has been nearly identical. As Michael Speaks asked in 1998, “when it becomes form,
label: Paragraph

text: the audience asks, when it becomes architecture, does it remain dynamic?” Kies-
label: Paragraph

text: ler’s answer, and Lynn’s as well, was to move more away from claims about a total
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and to attend to the artistic qualities of the objects he had made, to
label: Paragraph

text: retreat into the freedoms of the art-world.
label: Paragraph

text: Kiesler’s endless house stands as an important precursor of the digitally-
label: Paragraph

text: enabled experiments with non-orthogonal form. And to give him his full credit,
label: Paragraph

text: he even speculated about the possibility: “I cannot understand why ... none of
label: Paragraph

text: the industries has closed a pact with IBM to produce machines for the planning
label: Paragraph

text: and redesign of architecture.”** But even as he speculated about the variables
label: Paragraph

text: that would have to be included, he returned to the biological inspiration that
label: Paragraph

text: underwrites so much of twentieth century architectural thought, seeking to
label: Paragraph

text: describe the “single germ cell which contained the whole.” It is the image of
label: Paragraph

text: that single cell, full of abstract potentials and that owes “its origin to the erotic
label: Paragraph

text: and creative instinct,” that might best explain the simple ellipsoids of the endless
label: Paragraph

text: theater and first endless house. They are eggs, after all, and what could be more
label: Paragraph

text: endless?

label: Title

text: THE WORKER
label: Title

text: Eladio Dieste
label: Title

text: Stanford Anderson
label: Title

text: Eladio Dieste, Church of Christ the Worker, interior, Atlantida, Uruguay, 1958-60.*
label: Caption

text: Eladio Dieste, Church of Christ the Worker, exterior, Atlantida, Uruguay, 1958-60.**
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: ee med ated oe Bt a dd pane Loo pd srry
label: Title

text: Overture
label: Title

text: In a Uruguayan village inhabited by farmers and laborers one finds a singular
label: Paragraph

text: church, traditional in its material but radical in form. This is not a story of enlight-
label: Paragraph

text: ened patronage on the part of a community or a wealthy individual. It is the story of
label: Paragraph

text: aremarkable engineer who, asked to make a modest work with his proven capacity
label: Paragraph

text: in economical building, chose rather to challenge himself in realizing an unprece-
label: Paragraph

text: dented work that would come to be recognized as an outstanding architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural work.
label: Paragraph

text: The Church of Christ the Worker in Atlantida, with its bold curving forms,
label: Paragraph

text: stands proud in its featureless context, accompanied by its brick campanile. The
label: Paragraph

text: energetic brick walls of the church embrace an open-air narthex or porch that gives
label: Paragraph

text: access to a space, complexly configured, yet also providing direct, intimate relation
label: Paragraph

text: between the parishioner and the sanctuary. Though there is no immediately evi-
label: Paragraph

text: dent source of light, this is a luminous interior possessed of a radiance that elevates
label: Paragraph

text: both the humble material of its construction and the sensibility of its viewers.
label: Paragraph

text: The visitor is readily drawn into the experiential wealth of this place. The
label: Paragraph

text: designer of the church provides a vivid account of what supports this experience:
label: Paragraph

text: “A lightness, a mysterious ease, a concise simplicity, something like dance without
label: Paragraph

text: effort or fatigue,” are the words Eladio Dieste used to describe the goals for his
label: Paragraph

text: work.’ Such were the necessary conditions, he argued, for a convinced acceptance
label: Paragraph

text: of a building by its users.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste wrote those words out of the specific concern that his work should com-
label: Paragraph

text: municate with ordinary people. In the same essay, “Art, People, Technocracy,” he
label: Paragraph

text: tells of his experience of a humble woman with coarse shoes covered in mud at the
label: Paragraph

text: Church of Christ the Worker: “The itinerary that she followed, the places where
label: Paragraph

text: she paused, the things that she said with complete simplicity and without acco-
label: Paragraph

text: lades: these were the things that made me realize she was really seeing it.” Dieste
label: Paragraph

text: assures us this was not a singular experience. He was certain that people are not
label: Paragraph

text: moved when a difficulty is resolved by brute force. On the contrary, they want to
label: Paragraph

text: perceive a problem resolved with the effortlessness of a hawk soaring in the sky ora
label: Paragraph

text: flower unfolding in the sun. It is one thing to have such an ethereal ambition and
label: Paragraph

text: quite another to realize it. Yet that is what Dieste achieved in his buildings. It is no
label: Paragraph

text: accident that the phrase “light as a brick” was invented for his work.” The buildings
label: Paragraph

text: of this master and innovator of reinforced brick construction address us so
label: Paragraph

text: effortlessly, and yet forcefully, that a brief first exposure suffices to assure a deep
label: Paragraph

text: engagement.
label: Paragraph

text: Eladio Dieste was born in 1917 in Artigas in northern Uruguay, near the border
label: Paragraph

text: with Brazil. He was educated in structural engineering at the University of the
label: Paragraph

text: Republic in the capital city of Montevideo, graduating in 1943. He lived and pre-
label: Paragraph

text: dominantly built in his South American homeland, a small country of high educa-
label: Paragraph

text: tional and cultural levels but not of generous resources. In 1956 Dieste joined with
label: Paragraph

text: Eugenio Montaiiez, a fellow graduate of the university, in founding a practice,
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste y Montafiez, which has continued since the death of the master in 2000.’
label: Paragraph

text: With the Church of Christ the Worker in Atlantida, 1958-60 early in his career,
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste courageously disciplined himself, his client, and his collaborators to achieve a
label: Paragraph

text: work that went far beyond its initial program and established Dieste as an architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural force. I see in a later church, San Pedro in the provincial town of Durazno, an
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual as well as spiritual power, a refinement in both thought and execution,
label: Paragraph

text: that make it, I argue, one of the major architectural achievements of the second half
label: Paragraph

text: of the twentieth century.* Dieste recognized that he had achieved architectural
label: Paragraph

text: works of excellence, even if he was loath to title himself an architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste’s Reinforced Ceramic Vaults
label: Title

text: Strong claims such as these raise questions about the what and how of Dieste’s
label: Paragraph

text: achievements.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste made himself a master of construction in reinforced ceramics, advancing
label: Paragraph

text: that technology far beyond its primitive roots. It was virtually the only mode in
label: Paragraph

text: which he built. The vast majority ofhis structures serve everyday purposes of work
label: Paragraph

text: and storage. He invented two distinctive forms of reinforced brick vaulting that
label: Paragraph

text: were instrumental in winning the economic competition to receive the commis-
label: Paragraph

text: sions for such utilitarian structures. Serving pragmatic purposes and doing so eco-
label: Paragraph

text: nomically, in terms of both time and cost, was the fundamental business model of
label: Paragraph

text: the design/build engineering firm of Dieste y Montafiez. It is not despite these con-
label: Paragraph

text: straints but largely because of them that Dieste’s buildings rise above their quotid-
label: Paragraph

text: ian settings and achieve an ennobling architectural presence.
label: Paragraph

text: Of Dieste’s two major innovations in structural types in reinforced brick
label: Paragraph

text: masonry, consider first what he termed “self-carrying vaults.” These are barrel
label: Paragraph

text: vaults with none of the usual conditions of support for such a vault: no continuous
label: Paragraph

text: side-wall supports or buttresses, no tympanum or arch under the vault at its ends.
label: Caption

text: Dieste’s vaults rest on columns — or even a single column, as in the tour-de-force of
label: Paragraph

text: the four-direction cantilever vault of the “Sea Gull” in Salto.
label: Caption

text: Less demonstrative but equally impressive are the true self-carrying vaults
label: Paragraph

text: whose basic variants are well illustrated by the warehouses for Massaro Agroin-
label: Paragraph

text: dustries, north of Montevideo. The main storage area is formed by a set of five
label: Paragraph

text: parallel barrel vaults carried on a sparse grid of columns, with a cantilever of 54
label: Caption

text: feet at one end. Freely sliding under that cantilever are three still more astound-
label: Paragraph

text: ing vaults with 43 foot cantilevers in both directions, carried on a single row of
label: Paragraph

text: four columns.
label: Caption

text: Such minimal support is only possible if the vault, unlike traditional masonry
label: Paragraph

text: vaults, can resist bending forces.’ This Dieste accomplished by introducing pre-
label: Paragraph

text: stressing steel that pre-compresses the vault. In cross section, the vaults are given
label: Paragraph

text: the most effective structural form — a catenary. This, together with ordinary rein-
label: Paragraph

text: forcing bars between the rows of bricks, yields a thin and light vault. This lightness
label: Paragraph

text: reduces the lateral forces but, of course, there are forces to be counteracted.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste’s characteristic elegant solution is a horizontal edge beam at the outer limit
label: Paragraph

text: of any group of vaults — a beam that collects the lateral forces and brings them back
label: Paragraph

text: to point supports. In the long direction of a barrel vault supported on columns, the
label: Paragraph

text: vault acts as a beam. In these self-carrying vaults, the few and distant points of sup-
label: Paragraph

text: port and the thin, unsupported ends of the vaults directly convey the seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: effortless lightness of these constructions.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste’s second major structural innovation was in what he termed “Gaus-
label: Paragraph

text: sian” double-curvature vaults. Barrel vaults rise high in relation to their trans-
label: Paragraph

text: verse span and thus are not well suited to broad spans. However, a thin vault
label: Paragraph

text: of long span and low rise is susceptible to buckling and thus not sound structur-
label: Paragraph

text: ally. Dieste would not give strength to such vaults by making them more mas-
label: Paragraph

text: sive (a solution through brute force that he naturally resisted). He developed
label: Paragraph

text: strength in the section through shape, through double curvature. There are
label: Paragraph

text: the catenary curves of the transverse section of the vault, but also the S-shaped
label: Paragraph

text: curves of varying amplitude in the longitudinal section of the covered space.
label: Paragraph

text: Typically Dieste made these roofs with successive narrow vaults, with the
label: Paragraph

text: S-curves of neighboring vaults varied so as to be discontinuous — and thus
label: Paragraph

text: sources of light within the structure.°
label: Paragraph

text: The Church of Christ the Worker, Atlantida
label: Caption

text: It is Gaussian vaults that cover the space of the Atlantida church. However, here, in
label: Paragraph

text: a church, Dieste sought not the equally distributed light of his utilitarian buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: but a differentiated, controlled light. The S-curves of the longitudinal section of the
label: Paragraph

text: vaults become a continuous sin-curve of generous amplitude at the centerline —
label: Paragraph

text: thus strong and lightless. The S-curves diminish in both directions laterally, becom-
label: Paragraph

text: ing flat as they come to rest on the level tops of the enclosing walls. The amply
label: Paragraph

text: curved walls are generated by ruled surfaces — that is, every vertical section of
label: Paragraph

text: the curved wall is a simple straight line, tilting successively at gradually changing
label: Paragraph

text: angles. What is already implicit in this description nevertheless deserves emphasis:
label: Paragraph

text: the curves of the walls and the curves of the vault meet in a level surface. Equally
label: Paragraph

text: impressive: the low points of the S-curves yield a straight line at the level of the
label: Paragraph

text: meeting of vault and wall — a limit of the transverse catenary curves. Aside from
label: Paragraph

text: the geometrical elegance of this organization, it is also this that allowed Dieste to
label: Paragraph

text: resolve, so elegantly, the lateral forces of the vault. The tie-rods that are usually
label: Paragraph

text: necessary to counteract the lateral forces of a Gaussian vault, that are then a visual
label: Paragraph

text: distraction below the masonry vault, a condition that Dieste himself deplored, can
label: Paragraph

text: here be obscured with the tie-rod enclosed in the level bottom surface of the vault.
label: Paragraph

text: The forces resisted by the tie-rods must be resolved in the strength of the wall. This
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste achieves with flat edge beams at the top of the walls, themselves strength-
label: Paragraph

text: ened by the curvature of the walls.
label: Paragraph

text: If this lightly technical account of the structure of the church seems dry, it is
label: Paragraph

text: nevertheless the direct exposition of this structure that provides the experientially
label: Paragraph

text: rich immediate impressions one receives upon approaching the building. The tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nically generated but enticing image of the church of Christ the Worker surely
label: Paragraph

text: accounts for the fact that the appreciation of Dieste’s work long rested on this sin-
label: Paragraph

text: gular work.
label: Paragraph

text: Upon approaching the church, the strong impression of the curving walls
label: Paragraph

text: is matched by the open-air projection of the vault, sliced at the line of its greatest
label: Paragraph

text: amplitude. Walls and vault are statically balanced and self-sufficient; the recessed
label: Paragraph

text: facade of the church is an infill structure, as is emphasized by the reciprocating
label: Paragraph

text: curves and voids of the lower wall, and still more by the folded plates and the inde-
label: Paragraph

text: pendence of the upper part of the facade from the enclosing structural walls.
label: Caption

text: Entering the church, the visitor is already prepared for the drama of the walls
label: Paragraph

text: and vaults.” The first impression is a still stronger one of the whole of the church
label: Paragraph

text: space, the warm brick surfaces radiant — from unknown sources of light. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: the dynamic forms, the space is simple. The space of the congregation and that of
label: Paragraph

text: the clergy is intimate and with a minimal sense of hierarchy. There is a full satis-
label: Paragraph

text: faction in the quality of a space that is rich both aesthetically and spiritually.
label: Paragraph

text: Movement toward the altar reveals a significant, though not the most important,
label: Paragraph

text: source of light. The vault in front of the altar is perforated to give a beam of light in
label: Paragraph

text: the sanctuary. The terminating rear wall, with close-spaced bricks laid diagonally,
label: Paragraph

text: yields a fabric-like surface suggesting its non-structural, merely enclosing role.*
label: Paragraph

text: Turning, looking laterally, one is impressed anew by the precision with which
label: Paragraph

text: the ruled-surface wall meets the Gaussian vault. In this church, as in that of Dur-
label: Paragraph

text: azno, the brickwork is exquisite. As a design/build firm, Dieste y Montafiez closely
label: Paragraph

text: controlled the construction and, when necessary, employed adept masons working
label: Paragraph

text: evotedly within the ambitions of the firm.
label: Paragraph

text: Also apparent as one turns within the space, the principal source of light is
label: Paragraph

text: revealed: groups of small, freely composed rectangular openings, high on the
label: Paragraph

text: reverse side of the curving walls, glazed with some colored but dominantly clear
label: Caption

text: glass. Dieste was a cultured man; he could not have failed to know of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s renowned pilgrimage chapel in Ronchamp, France, with its demonstra-
label: Paragraph

text: tive use of varied light openings in a thick wall. Dieste’s use of this device is modest
label: Paragraph

text: by comparison, but of maximum effectiveness through this restraint. The struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural discipline of Dieste’s church contrasts markedly with that of Ronchamp.
label: Paragraph

text: Turning further, the final source of light is seen to be the alabaster infill between
label: Paragraph

text: the non-structural plates of the entrance facade. That the entrance wall is non-
label: Paragraph

text: bearing is still more evident as a band of light maintains its independence from
label: Paragraph

text: the bearing walls of the church.
label: Paragraph

text: a
label: Title

text: Brick constitutes the whole of the Atlantida church. Observing the interior
label: Paragraph

text: entrance area of the church, it is not only the choir loft that is sustained by brick;
label: Paragraph

text: the stair, too, and even the open-work of the balustrades, are in brick.
label: Caption

text: Brick
label: Title

text: Brick was the focus of all that Dieste built. It set him apart from other great engi-
label: Paragraph

text: neers of his time who worked in the presumptively “modern” materials of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: and steel — Felix Candela, Eduardo Torroja, Robert Maillart, and Pier Luigi Nervi
label: Paragraph

text: are examples.” It can well be assumed that the comparative neglect of Dieste’s
label: Paragraph

text: accomplishments is due to a modern architectural historiography that insisted
label: Paragraph

text: on the pre-eminence of works in concrete and steel.
label: Paragraph

text: Brick is one of the most ancient, even primitive, materials. Brick is the
label: Paragraph

text: enduring common, environmentally defining material of great cities like
label: Paragraph

text: London or Hamburg or Boston. Dieste’s devotion to brick, however, stems nei-
label: Paragraph

text: ther from those historic associations nor from any nostalgia for traditional
label: Paragraph

text: materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste saw a number of advantages in the use of brick, the central one being an
label: Paragraph

text: economy of construction that allowed his firm to underbid those using “modern”
label: Paragraph

text: materials. First, brick was a locally available, inexpensive material. Still more
label: Paragraph

text: important were economies of construction. Gaussian vaults were repetitive.
label: Paragraph

text: A movable formwork could be used for the entire building; so much would be true
label: Paragraph

text: for a similar construction in reinforced concrete. But consider a group of facts of
label: Paragraph

text: construction: brick is a dry material; in his utilitarian buildings, Dieste used
label: Paragraph

text: unskilled laborers to place bricks at designated places on the formwork; reinforcing
label: Paragraph

text: was laid between the bricks; steel mesh and/or pre-stressed steel, depending on the
label: Paragraph

text: type of vault, was laid over the vault; and a thin parging protected the steel and
label: Paragraph

text: completed the roof. Because there was so little liquid cement, in such small
label: Paragraph

text: volumes, Dieste could strike the forms in as little as a day — and move on to
label: Paragraph

text: the next bay. Mortar at the joints could still be tooled, enabling the fine finish
label: Paragraph

text: of Dieste’s brick vaults. A concrete vault of similar form might require a week
label: Paragraph

text: for the concrete to cure. While Dieste’s innovative brick structures grew out of
label: Paragraph

text: precedents and practice in reinforced concrete, he quite reasonably argued that
label: Paragraph

text: new materials do not necessarily displace earlier materials of demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: effectiveness.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste found compelling reasons for the use of ceramic materials in the margin-
label: Paragraph

text: alized economy of Uruguay. However, he also supported brick construction for
label: Paragraph

text: reasons that rely only partially on that local condition. He claimed advantages
label: Paragraph

text: for brick over concrete, including relative strength for weight, better resistance
label: Paragraph

text: to temperature changes and aging, better acoustic and environmental qualities,
label: Paragraph

text: and, in comparable quality, lower cost.'° In this Dieste provided good, hardheaded
label: Paragraph

text: reasons for preferring to work in brick. Further, he believed that the tectonic sense
label: Paragraph

text: of a durable material with agreeable qualities of color and texture, worked with
label: Paragraph

text: sound craftsmanship, had a general appeal.
label: Paragraph

text: Feedback Process of a Design/Build Enterprise
label: Title

text: There are still more fundamental advantages that flowed from Dieste’s practice asa
label: Paragraph

text: design/build engineer, particularly an immediate feedback from the experience of
label: Paragraph

text: each project that formed Dieste’s ability, constantly and assuredly, to increase the
label: Paragraph

text: daring of his structural work.
label: Paragraph

text: I was not the first person to be impressed by the daring of Dieste’s structures.
label: Paragraph

text: I was unusually fortunate, however, that after my first day in Uruguay, after my
label: Paragraph

text: first surprisingly substantive tour of works by Dieste, I was taken by a mutual
label: Paragraph

text: friend to meet Dieste in his home. I quickly revealed, in effect, my own conviction
label: Paragraph

text: about Dieste’s work as a “dance without effort or fatigue” — though I had not yet
label: Paragraph

text: had occasion to learn these words. As genuine and motivated as were my first
label: Paragraph

text: words to Dieste, I was too enthusiastic in my appreciation. Though suffering
label: Paragraph

text: the effects of a degenerative disease, Dieste, with a friendly, knowing sparkle in
label: Paragraph

text: his eyes, calmed me with the words: “I too obey the laws of physics!”
label: Paragraph

text: In the presence of Dieste’s buildings, one may sometimes wonder if he truly
label: Paragraph

text: obeyed those laws. But, yes, he was a rigorous engineer, and there the buildings
label: Paragraph

text: stand. The laws of physics are satisfied. Nonetheless, we must also observe that
label: Paragraph

text: there is all the difference in the world between engineering work that follows
label: Paragraph

text: the laws of physics while safely controlled within the conventions of ordinary prac-
label: Paragraph

text: tice as compared to work that challenges what is physically viable. Dieste imagined
label: Paragraph

text: new possibilities and then, yes, observed only the laws of physics, not cautious
label: Paragraph

text: standard practice or rules of thumb. In consequence, one can follow in Dieste’s
label: Paragraph

text: work his own maturation both in theory and technique.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste and Architecture
label: Title

text: The taut brick surfaces of Dieste’s buildings convey a clear sense of an economy of
label: Paragraph

text: means that is much more than a mere material matter. Also in the utilitarian build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings, Dieste performed a “dance without effort or fatigue.” He explained:
label: Paragraph

text: The resistant virtues of the structures that we are searching for depend on their form.
label: Paragraph

text: It is through their form that they are stable, not because of an awkward accumulation
label: Paragraph

text: of matter...there is nothing more noble and elegant from an intellectual viewpoint
label: Paragraph

text: than this resistance through form.'*
label: Paragraph

text: We know there are buildings that are technically sound without becoming archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. And there are buildings of widely recognized architectural standing that
label: Paragraph

text: are open to technical and tectonic criticism. There remains a special place for
label: Paragraph

text: technically sound buildings that achieve high tectonic standards and thus deserve to
label: Paragraph

text: be recognized as architecture. This is all the more true when the designers of these
label: Paragraph

text: buildings also ran the risks inherent in technical and tectonic innovation. Dieste
label: Paragraph

text: successfully took such risks. His are works that do not indulge the arbitrary, but
label: Paragraph

text: in which the form of the structure is also the form of the building and the delimiter
label: Paragraph

text: of space. Dieste stated this more strictly:
label: Paragraph

text: A building cannot be profound as a work of art unless it has an earnest and subtle
label: Paragraph

text: fidelity to the laws of matter. Only the reverence that this fidelity requires can make
label: Paragraph

text: our buildings serious, lasting, and worthy parmers in our contemplative journey.’*
label: Paragraph

text: The utter directness of Dieste’s work — its “earnest and subtle fidelity to the
label: Paragraph

text: laws of matter” — moves us. It is obvious that Dieste’s innovations are not in
label: Paragraph

text: the pursuit of novelty. They are the result of a continuous quest, a reasoned
label: Paragraph

text: approach to building well, addressing the pragmatic problems at hand but also
label: Paragraph

text: satisfying his own profound demands, aesthetic, ethical, and spiritual, that lay
label: Paragraph

text: behind his dance.’’
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste, Man of Ethics and Culture
label: Title

text: Dieste was still more than an engineer and architect; he was a man with deep eth-
label: Paragraph

text: ical concerns and broad intellectual interests. In his two churches he sought to unify
label: Paragraph

text: the congregation and the priest and liturgy for the well-being of people, especially
label: Paragraph

text: those who labored or were dispossessed. At Atlantida, Dieste had fulfilled this ideal
label: Paragraph

text: prior to the dictates handed down by the Second Vatican Council. He was a reli-
label: Paragraph

text: gious man; a crucifix hung on the wall of his study. But his concerns were not
label: Paragraph

text: framed by the Church or even by religion more generally. His was a concern
label: Paragraph

text: for humanity, expressed in both political and ethical terms:
label: Paragraph

text: I think that we would reach a wide consensus if we proposed as a common aim the
label: Paragraph

text: fulfillment and happiness of mankind. This is an aim that would certainly produce
label: Paragraph

text: different principles in accordance with each individual’s philosophy of life and his
label: Paragraph

text: religion...what we see around us is not acceptable... The industrial revolution took
label: Paragraph

text: place with such great injustice that the repercussions from the fierce indignation that
label: Paragraph

text: its inequities produced in mankind are the reason for the destructive madness that
label: Paragraph

text: has spread throughout the world."
label: Paragraph

text: Deeply concerned for the inequities suffered by the majority of the world pop-
label: Paragraph

text: ulation, and committed to the maintenance of well-being in countries like his own
label: Paragraph

text: that were buffeted both by local constraints and the harms of international devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opment activities, Dieste did not lose sight of the higher goals of humankind. In his
label: Paragraph

text: essay “Technology and Underdevelopment,” he maintained:
label: Paragraph

text: Efforts that are put to good use are efforts that help man to be happier, to be more
label: Paragraph

text: himself. Efforts dedicated to science, art, health care, and efforts to make the earth,
label: Paragraph

text: our countryside and cities, the true home of mankind, are efforts that are put to
label: Paragraph

text: good use. If we understand development in this way, then it is both good and
label: Paragraph

text: desirable.”
label: Paragraph

text: Embracing this general position, Dieste’s own efforts were conducted as both
label: Paragraph

text: science and art, and were directed to the home of mankind as well as to our edi-
label: Paragraph

text: fication. Recognizing that calls for simplicity usually entail unjustified simplifica-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and those for economy address merely money and its movement, Dieste
label: Paragraph

text: advanced a much larger cause:
label: Paragraph

text: “The things that we build must have something that we could call a cosmic economy,
label: Paragraph

text: that is, to be in accord with the profound order of the world. Only then can our work
label: Paragraph

text: have the authority that so surprises us in the great works of the past.”'®
label: Paragraph

text: While here Dieste refers to structures, we should see his notion of “cosmic econ-
label: Paragraph

text: omy” in terms of that “profound order of the world.” The inexplicable harmonies
label: Paragraph

text: of Dieste’s churches are the fundamentals of his cosmic economy, but so too are his
label: Paragraph

text: understandings of how his country should conduct itself within a world of disparate
label: Paragraph

text: opportunities, and how genuine goods must reach equitable distribution.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste’s thought and work are undeniably metaphysical. Yet he rejects any tel-
label: Paragraph

text: eology and his ambitions are always grounded:
label: Paragraph

text: Ic is not easy to have a clear image of the goal. On the other hand, it is much easier to
label: Paragraph

text: have a clear image of the foundations and principles that will shape that goal. This is
label: Paragraph

text: why the idea that “the ends justify the means” is a drastic mistake. We do not know
label: Paragraph

text: what the end will be. We have an image of our goals, but these will never be realized
label: Paragraph

text: if in our actions we betray the principles that will shape and form these goals. We
label: Paragraph

text: cannot postpone for the future city the beauty and dignity that we need so badly to
label: Paragraph

text: endure the severities of life. We cannot postpone them as principles even though we
label: Paragraph

text: might have to compromise in practice. When we have no other choice, we will have
label: Paragraph

text: to compromise, but we should always continue to try to achieve the principles that
label: Paragraph

text: will shape the goal, our future.'”
label: Paragraph

text: With this confrontation of principles and reality, it is tempting to recall
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste’s story of one of his professors, who, hearing the word “theoretical” used
label: Paragraph

text: with disdain, retorted, “Theoretical, theoretical, the theoretical that fails in real-
label: Paragraph

text: ity, fails because it isn’t theoretical enough!”'* Dieste’s thought, his search for
label: Paragraph

text: “cosmic economy,” took him readily to large and small issues in quite different
label: Paragraph

text: domains, but there remained a selective and rational mind behind these
label: Paragraph

text: ambitions.
label: Paragraph

text: Dieste’s achievement has a strong moral and intellectual basis. It offers funda-
label: Paragraph

text: mental lessons. Within a period marked by naive modernist determinisms and
label: Paragraph

text: conservative resistances, Dieste provided an unusual and strong counter-exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ple. He was an engineer working rationally from first principles, but he was also
label: Paragraph

text: a pragmatic humanist who chose his course in accord with both limiting condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions and social ideals. He knew how to make his situation work for him and
label: Paragraph

text: others.
label: Paragraph
