text: A CITY-LIKE HOUSE
label: Title

text: A New Reality
label: Title

text: The terrifying nature of human uncertainty, according to Aldo van Eyck (1918-99),
label: Paragraph

text: becomes less frightening when opposites are reconsidered as parts of complex
label: Paragraph

text: wholes. Multiple languages and rituals harbor clues as to how complexity can
label: Paragraph

text: be given a place in rooms, buildings, and cities capable of assuaging intense emo-
label: Paragraph

text: tions. The project of collapsing rigid oppositions, which dualistic thinking presents
label: Paragraph

text: as final, and which van Eyck was certain contributed to the uncertainty and anxiety
label: Paragraph

text: of modern life, could be advanced through a complex understanding of relative
label: Paragraph

text: patterns of relations — revealed in the parallel realities of diverse architectures
label: Paragraph

text: and cultures. It is precisely the creation of a setting that was rich and complex
label: Paragraph

text: enough to receive the full range of haman emotion — in particular ambivalence —
label: Paragraph

text: that van Eyck attempted to achieve in the Amsterdam Municipal Orphanage
label: Paragraph

text: (hereafter the Amsterdam Orphanage, or the orphanage), Amstelveenseweg
label: Paragraph

text: The Amsterdam Orphanage was van Eyck’s first major independent commission
label: Paragraph

text: and brought him international acclaim. As such, it was the crowning achievement
label: Paragraph

text: of his early career and remains his best known building. The orphanage’s antece-
label: Paragraph

text: dents can be traced back to van Eyck’s trips to Africa during the late 1940s and into
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s, where he developed his interest in how the discoveries of anthropology
label: Paragraph

text: could enrich modern architecture. He was certain that an anthropological approach
label: Paragraph

text: could furnish modern architecture with sorely needed depth and breadth, in much
label: Paragraph

text: the same way that many of the greatest innovators of twentieth-century art, includ-
label: Paragraph

text: ing Picasso (1881-1973) and Paul Klee (1879-1940), sought inspiration from Africa
label: Paragraph

text: and other non-Western traditions. During his journeys to Africa, van Eyck col-
label: Paragraph

text: lected artifacts, complementing his collection of modern art (which had been influ-
label: Paragraph

text: enced by his contact with Carola Giedion-Welcker (1893-1979), who introduced
label: Paragraph

text: him to modern art, and her husband, Sigfried Giedion (1881-1968), who had been
label: Paragraph

text: a founding member of CIAM, and its secretary from its inception until 1956.7
label: Paragraph

text: Just as modern art expressed a new reality for van Eyck, he likewise observed a
label: Paragraph

text: distinct and unified cosmology in the ethnographic materials he collected from the
label: Paragraph

text: African villages he visited. For him, these artifacts expressed the interrelationship of
label: Paragraph

text: each thing that makes life possible and comprehensible, to all of the other things
label: Paragraph

text: that contribute to this, across the full range of scales, from the smallest object to the
label: Paragraph

text: largeness of the world. He was especially impressed by the Dogon people of sub-
label: Paragraph

text: Saharan Africa, who wove a rich web of orienting relations at all scales from the
label: Paragraph

text: elements of their daily life, including baskets, homes, and the arrangement of their
label: Paragraph

text: villages. Drawing on this experience, van Eyck attempted to translate such
label: Paragraph

text: configurative arrangements into a modern Western form, most prominently at the
label: Paragraph

text: orphanage. This is achieved in the overall planning of the building through the use
label: Paragraph

text: of a basic modular unit, which in turn is made out of the specific elements that form
label: Paragraph

text: it. The configuration of these elements creates a discernible overall form that is
label: Paragraph

text: varied enough to accommodate a full range of uses, both planned for and unantic-
label: Paragraph

text: ipated. The contact with the rich cosmological patterns of village life that van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: encountered with the Dogon — persisting parallel to the diagrammatic settings of
label: Paragraph

text: affluent industrial societies — not only revealed the limitations of narrow function-
label: Paragraph

text: alism, particularly its fundamental inability to provide an adequate home for West-
label: Paragraph

text: em men and women, but also suggested how just these limitations might be
label: Paragraph

text: overcome. Of particular interest are the ways in which van Eyck attempted to give
label: Paragraph

text: form to emotional functionalism as a topic of postwar architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: An Enriched Modern Architecture
label: Title

text: Most of van Eyck’s key concerns, in particular his conviction that parallel traditions
label: Paragraph

text: distant in both space and time, and close at hand, offer— when considered together —
label: Paragraph

text: amore complete perspective on reality, are depicted in his Otterlo Circles emblem,
label: Paragraph

text: the first version of which was presented at the 11th and final CIAM congress, in
label: Paragraph

text: Otterlo, the Netherlands, in 1959. However, the description here relates to a later
label: Paragraph

text: version of the Circles. The dissolution of CIAM was organized by a grouping of
label: Paragraph

text: architects, including van Eyck, the Smithsons, Giancarlo De Carlo, and Jacob
label: Paragraph

text: Bakema, who banded together at CIAM X for this very purpose. Team X, named
label: Paragraph

text: in honor of the CIAM congress at which the group formed, could be seen as the
label: Paragraph

text: first decisively postmodern movement in architecture.’ Nevertheless, van Eyck’s
label: Paragraph

text: aim at Otterlo was progressive rather than destructive. While van Eyck’s Otterlo
label: Paragraph

text: Circles are worth considering in detail because they represent the main themes of
label: Paragraph

text: his work, they also reveal the debt of his thinking (writing and buildings as well) to
label: Paragraph

text: American linguist Benjamin Lee Whorf’s (1897-1941) ideas on linguistic relativity,
label: Paragraph

text: which van Eyck attempted to translate to architecture and urbanism.“ As the clear-
label: Paragraph

text: est expression of this, the Otterlo Circles also offer insights into the Amsterdam
label: Paragraph

text: Orphanage. If the Otterlo Circles are a translation of Whorf’s conception of linguis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic relativity for architecture, in the form of a textual and visual manifesto, the
label: Paragraph

text: orphanage demonstrates the efficacy of these ideas in the invention of an enriched
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture. In this sense, the orphanage is a verification of Whorf’s
label: Paragraph

text: theory (translated to architecture) by design. Ultimately, if the Otterlo Circles
label: Paragraph

text: introduce van Eyck’s complex mode of thinking about architecture and the human
label: Paragraph

text: habitat more generally, he attempted to give it a tangible and testable form in the
label: Paragraph

text: orphanage.”
label: Paragraph

text: Asa distillation of Aldo van Eyck’s psychosocial and anthropological approach to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, informed by his understanding of Whorf’s linguistic relativity, the
label: Paragraph

text: Otterlo Circles record his understanding of “relativity” as revealing parallel
label: Paragraph

text: traditions (no matter how distant in space or time) as equally valid and thus rele-
label: Paragraph

text: vant to the invention of an enriched modern architecture capable of receiving the
label: Paragraph

text: full spectrum of human emotion, and inhabitation. Every element of the Otterlo
label: Paragraph

text: Circles — visual and textual — has a correlate in the Amsterdam Orphanage, struc-
label: Paragraph

text: turally, symbolically, organizationally, and programmatically. Even the placement
label: Paragraph

text: of the two circles adjacent to one another, close enough to suggest an association,
label: Paragraph

text: but far enough apart to maintain their independence, suggests the space in between
label: Paragraph

text: them, or the in-between realm of human association, so important to van Eyck and
label: Paragraph

text: evident in almost every corner of the orphanage. The left-hand Circle includes a
label: Paragraph

text: meditation on the parallel relevance of architectural forms from disparate traditions
label: Paragraph

text: (in space and time), whereas the right-hand Circle considers community.
label: Paragraph

text: The inheritance of classical antiquity (the classical tradition) as depicted by a
label: Paragraph

text: Greek temple plan, was characterized by van Eyck as embodying “immutability
label: Paragraph

text: and rest.” The structural system of the orphanage, established out of a basic mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ular unit made up of a square defined — at least conceptually — by columns in each of
label: Paragraph

text: its four corners, traversed in each direction by an architrave, is the most obvious
label: Paragraph

text: translation of the classical inheritance. The clearly identifiable primary structural
label: Paragraph

text: element of the orphanage is a trabeated system of construction that emphasizes
label: Paragraph

text: the symbolic importance of the column as a structural, symbolic, and space-
label: Paragraph

text: defining element.
label: Paragraph

text: The basic structural unit of the orphanage consists of two concrete columns sur-
label: Paragraph

text: mounted by an architrave, distinguished by a rectangular slot cut into it. In actu-
label: Paragraph

text: ality, this basic unit is reducible even further to just a single column. Although
label: Paragraph

text: distinctly modern, this assembly also refers to the Doric order of ancient Greek
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. As such, the unit forms a threshold by establishing a portal that
label: Paragraph

text: defines entry points and in-between spaces throughout the orphanage, in the exte-
label: Paragraph

text: rior and interior alike. The orthogonal extension of these primary elements is made
label: Paragraph

text: up of multiples of the initial column/architrave unit, each located a uniform dis-
label: Paragraph

text: tance from the other, spanned by beams resting above the architraves that are a
label: Paragraph

text: double width apart.
label: Paragraph

text: Conceptually and concretely, the four columns and the spatial unit formed by
label: Paragraph

text: the columns traversed by four architraves form the basic constructive structural
label: Paragraph

text: unit of the orphanage. It establishes a primary structural element of shelter, com-
label: Paragraph

text: prehensible as a house-room, referring at once to both Abbe Laugier’s primitive
label: Paragraph

text: hut and Le Corbusier’s Dom-ino structural system. The initial module, an infinitely
label: Paragraph

text: extensible cellular unit, is a distinctly modern assembly that also refers to aborigina
label: Paragraph

text: and classical architecture. The evidence of the extensibility of the initial cellular
label: Paragraph

text: structural unit out of which the orphanage is assembled remains legible through-
label: Paragraph

text: out, even where it has been manipulated. As such, it achieves a stable degree o:
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensibility across a variety of scales, even where the basic elements have
label: Paragraph

text: been altered. This derives from a very precise articulation of initial elements in both
label: Paragraph

text: the interior and exterior of the building. The most emphatic representation of both
label: Paragraph

text: occurs at the roof level, where each house-room is reasserted by the 336 individua
label: Paragraph

text: precast concrete domes, capping each single-story unit with its own roof. It is this
label: Paragraph

text: assembly that gives the Amsterdam Orphanage its distinctive Kasbah-like roof-
label: Paragraph

text: scape. The only exceptions to this arrangement are four larger single-story units
label: Paragraph

text: assembled out of nine initial cellular units, and four larger two-story units,
label: Paragraph

text: assembled out of nine initial cellular units extended upward by an additional nine
label: Paragraph

text: units above. Each of these larger units is in turn capped by a larger precast concrete
label: Paragraph

text: dome, the effect of which is to clearly define them as distinct (a further exception is
label: Paragraph

text: the building’s administrative block, which is raised up one story on columns).
label: Paragraph

text: When the orphanage first opened, the children were housed in the eight larger
label: Paragraph

text: units according to their age group. The four larger single-story units housed the
label: Paragraph

text: younger children, from infants to ten years old, with living areas and bedrooms
label: Paragraph

text: on the single level. The four two-story larger units housed the older children from
label: Paragraph

text: 10 to 20 years old, with living areas on the lower level and the bedrooms above.
label: Paragraph

text: Although extensible in any direction, including upward, the basic structural unit of
label: Paragraph

text: the orphanage is sophisticated enough to gain in richness through multiplication
label: Paragraph

text: rather than be diminished by it. Although standardization was employed in the con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction of the orphanage as a reality of modern building methods and as an eco-
label: Paragraph

text: nomic necessity, richness was generated from repetition and layering.
label: Paragraph

text: The Greek temple plan in the left Otterlo Circle is followed by an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: counter-construction by Theo van Doesburg (1883-1931), reminiscent of Gerrit
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld’s (1888-1964) Schréder House (Utrecht, 1924), and suggestive of Piet
label: Paragraph

text: Mondrian’s (1872-1944) painting. All three of these artists shared an effort to intro-
label: Paragraph

text: duce the fourth dimension of time into art and architecture, which preoccupied van
label: Paragraph

text: Eyck as well, particularly its association with relativity. In attempting to introduce
label: Paragraph

text: this aspect to the Amsterdam Orphanage, van Eyck referred to the work of van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg, which for him embodied “change and movement,” a crucial character-
label: Paragraph

text: istic of modernity in art and architecture in general. It is no surprise that van Does-
label: Paragraph

text: burg represents the “authentic” tradition of modern architecture for van Eyck, who
label: Paragraph

text: wished to associate himself with his Dutch origins.
label: Paragraph

text: Although experience of the built environment inevitably includes the fourth
label: Paragraph

text: dimension of time as a consequence of human action, the orphanage embraces this
label: Paragraph

text: as a worthy topic of investigation. For example, by allowing elements of the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing to flow ambiguously into one another, while assuring that the lattice of the
label: Paragraph

text: structure is nonetheless sensed, a degree of dynamic, perhaps generative, tension
label: Paragraph

text: is introduced, which calls to mind a kind of push-pull action, analogizing the move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment encouraged by the arrangement of the building. Through this means the
label: Paragraph

text: usual oppressive character of institutions is avoided by making the building into
label: Paragraph

text: a web of small pavilions looking into private courts. Further evidence of van Eyck’s
label: Caption

text: preoccupation with “change and movement” is the meandering street inside the
label: Paragraph

text: complex, which is convincingly rendered as street-like largely by way of the dura-
label: Paragraph

text: ble materials used for the wall and floor surfaces, and the furniture as well.
label: Paragraph

text: All of the main areas of the orphanage — the children’s housing and the support
label: Paragraph

text: areas including the infirmary, dining hall, and administrative wing — are threaded
label: Paragraph

text: together by the interior street. The dynamism of the building is further enhanced
label: Paragraph

text: by subtle shifts of level, changes of material, color, and infill material throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: Ina move that is at once distinctly modern and traditional, the building is organized
label: Paragraph

text: according to what van Eyck called “labyrinthine clarity,” suggesting paths enriched
label: Paragraph

text: by derivations analogous to unfolding experience, which the interior street empha-
label: Paragraph

text: sizes. This conceptualization of architectural paths is related to what van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: called “twin phenomena,” which is the linking of conditions usually separated
label: Paragraph

text: by strict dualities. In this instance, it is revealed in the building as an arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: that encourages the possibility of wandering, as analogous to intuition and wonder.
label: Paragraph

text: Organized in this way, the orphanage also suggests alternatives to the rigidity of
label: Paragraph

text: diagrammatic planning.
label: Paragraph

text: As stated earlier, in contrast to the “immutability and rest” that van Eyck asso-
label: Paragraph

text: ciated with classical antiquity in the Otterlo Circles, the modern period is one of
label: Paragraph

text: “change and movement.” Even so, antiquity and modernity are linked for van Eyck
label: Paragraph

text: as both being “concepts of the mind,” suggesting the value of considering and inte-
label: Paragraph

text: grating divergent ideas on reality, education, thought, spatial organization, and
label: Paragraph

text: society.
label: Paragraph

text: Continuing to move clockwise around the left of the Otterlo Circle, one arrives
label: Paragraph

text: at the plan of a Pueblo village in New Mexico, emblematic of what van Eyck is
label: Paragraph

text: called the “vernacular of the heart,” (the “tradition of spontaneous building”). This
label: Paragraph

text: suggests there is a depth of understanding available to the developed world from
label: Paragraph

text: apparent unity of traditional societies, from their social organization to the organ-
label: Paragraph

text: ization of their villages, including the constant resonance between microcosm and
label: Paragraph

text: macrocosm that seems to define such societies. Order of this kind stood in sharp
label: Paragraph

text: contrast to the binary (either/or) worldview of developed societies.
label: Paragraph

text: At the Amsterdam Orphanage, “the vernacular of the heart” is discernible in at
label: Paragraph

text: least three ways: first, the organization of the building derives directly from the
label: Paragraph

text: organization of the Dogon villages van Eyck had visited; second, the cellular struc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture of the building is reminiscent of the Pueblo depicted in the left Otterlo Circle;
label: Paragraph

text: and third, the organization of the building, including the distinctive roofscape,
label: Paragraph

text: together with its effect on the interior, relates to van Eyck’s belief that a Kasbah
label: Paragraph

text: organization was better suited to the complexity of human life than typical insti-
label: Paragraph

text: tutional structures. The orphanage is organized into two wings that slip past each
label: Paragraph

text: other in a manner reminiscent of the Dogon settlements. The several hundred
label: Paragraph

text: house-room units extend outward from the entry court, which is the social rather
label: Paragraph

text: than geometric center of the building, and is terminated at one end by the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing’s administrative wing, which is rendered slightly differently from other parts of
label: Paragraph

text: the building and, as noted earlier, is raised one story above ground on columns to
label: Paragraph

text: define the unmistakable threshold to the complex. The extension of the cellular
label: Paragraph

text: units is broken in many places by the introduction of numerous courts, including
label: Paragraph

text: the entry court, but mainly by much smaller open outdoor spaces, either fully
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed by the building or partially so. This assemblage is crucial for giving
label: Paragraph

text: the orphanage its unique village-like character. Although made up of repetitive
label: Paragraph

text: square units, the building is diverse and dynamic, largely resulting from the
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of each wing as an opposing stepped diagonal in plan, an organization
label: Paragraph

text: that would likely never have been possible without the influence of vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: models, in particular the Dogon villages. Apart from establishing the two main
label: Paragraph

text: wings of the orphanage, organizing the building in this way made possible the
label: Paragraph

text: inclusion of the variety of the open-air places described above. In addition, the play
label: Paragraph

text: between inside and outside is further inflected by loggias in several places. The
label: Paragraph

text: thoughtful articulation of the building — materially, spatially, and psychologically —
label: Paragraph

text: has resulted in great social legibility, of the sort van Eyck found in traditional
label: Paragraph

text: societies.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the “vernacular of the heart” is represented in the left Otterlo Circle by
label: Paragraph

text: a Pueblo village, this should be taken as only one example of a general concept, in
label: Paragraph

text: the same way that the Greek temple plan and the van Doesburg counter-
label: Paragraph

text: construction are suggestive rather than definitive. The text that links the Pueblo
label: Paragraph

text: and the temple, above the former and below the latter — “extensions of collective
label: Paragraph

text: behavior” — suggests that vernacular, classical, and, one imagines, even the modern
label: Paragraph

text: are all wrapped around the similar habits of a given culture, though inflected by the
label: Paragraph

text: specificity of “place and occasion.” The phrase also relates to the desirable possi-
label: Paragraph

text: bility that architecture can be a counter-form to human being (a frame that contains
label: Paragraph

text: and is inflected by it), especially ambivalence (the in between).
label: Paragraph

text: The three headline mottos in the left of the Otterlo Circle — Immutability and
label: Paragraph

text: Rest; Change and Movement; and Vernacular of the Heart — are apparently con-
label: Paragraph

text: tradictory conceptions that nevertheless promise a more complete perspective on
label: Paragraph

text: reality, which the consideration of parallel traditions offers. Taken together, each of
label: Paragraph

text: the traditions represented in the left Otterlo Circle, and many more besides,
label: Paragraph

text: “encompass” according to Frances Strauven, van Eyck’s biographer, “a formal
label: Paragraph

text: and structural potential sufficiently fertile to produce variable answers to the
label: Paragraph

text: complex reality of human relationships,” as they did in the past, suggest in the
label: Paragraph

text: present, and promise for the future.° It matters little that from the perspective
label: Paragraph

text: of the present, one or another tradition appears to be spent. Silted up within each
label: Paragraph

text: is an ever-flowing wellspring of possibility, which is precisely what van Eyck sought
label: Paragraph

text: to confirm in the translation of numerous and varied influences in the Amsterdam
label: Paragraph

text: Orphanage. It is the degree to which the orphanage derives from a habit of mind
label: Paragraph

text: that is open to myriad influences that are never redeployed literally but translated,
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps interpreted, or even more accurately, abstracted to reveal something new
label: Paragraph

text: and complete in itself, but still associated with its origins, that makes the building a
label: Paragraph

text: unique and enduring structure.
label: Paragraph

text: The right-hand Otterlo Circle summarizes what is for van Eyck the reality of the
label: Paragraph

text: human condition, made up as it is of complex individual and social relationships.
label: Paragraph

text: Here, the constant and variable relation between individuals and the society within
label: Paragraph

text: which they are embedded is symbolized by a high-contrast, black-and-white, three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional image of dancing Brazilian Kayapd people, forming concentric
label: Paragraph

text: circles.” Arching above this image are the words: “For each man and all men,”
label: Paragraph

text: referring to the necessary mutuality that underpins any society, highlighting the
label: Paragraph

text: value of both individual and group for the whole, which van Eyck believed ought
label: Paragraph

text: to find its analogy in architecture. The contents of this Circle clearly sets out van
label: Paragraph

text: Eyck’s aspirations for the orphanage. He wanted it to be a significant lived-in exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ple of what he called “built homecoming.” And for the short while that it was
label: Paragraph

text: inhabited as planned it appears to have been just that: genuinely a home for the
label: Paragraph

text: most vulnerable children.
label: Paragraph

text: The remaining text of the Otterlo Circles is also worth considering, as it has
label: Paragraph

text: direct relevance not only to an understanding of the motivations of the orphanage
label: Paragraph

text: but also to what it embodies. The largest text sits above the left Circle and sepa-
label: Paragraph

text: rately above the right Circle, though in neither case does it sit above the apex of
label: Paragraph

text: either; rather, text descends to the right above the left Circle, and to the left above
label: Paragraph

text: the right Circle. “BY US” sits above the left Circle and “FOR US” above the right,
label: Paragraph

text: which taken together is intended to convey that the origin of architecture is to be
label: Paragraph

text: found within social life, and as such, its main aim is to be convivial (welcoming).
label: Paragraph

text: This thesis stands in direct opposition to the excesses of instrumental social science
label: Paragraph

text: that typified the worst failures of modernist architecture constructed during the
label: Paragraph

text: two to three decades immediately following World War II. Van Eyck’s ethos also
label: Paragraph

text: opposes both the facile stylistic postmodernism that emerged during the 1960s, an
label: Paragraph

text: example of which could be the designs set out Robert Venturi’s (b.1925) Complexity
label: Paragraph

text: and Contradiction in Architecture (1966), and the dehumanizing tendencies of stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: deconstructivism in architecture, as outlined in Deconstructivist Architecture (1988),
label: Paragraph

text: by Philip Johnson and Mark Wigley (though its origins are identifiable in the
label: Paragraph

text: supposed post-structuralism of American architect Peter Eisenmen (b.1932), from
label: Paragraph

text: as early as the mid-1960s). The smaller text of the Otterlo Circles further clarifies
label: Paragraph

text: and emphasizes what makes van Eyck and the Amsterdam Orphanage unique.
label: Paragraph

text: Each line of text is numbered from 1 to 4, establishing something like the four
label: Paragraph

text: points of van Eyck’s architectural ethos, interfused with the principles already
label: Paragraph

text: discussed above.
label: Paragraph

text: Point 1 ascends upward from the bottom of the left Circle along its right edge,
label: Paragraph

text: and asks: “When is Architecture going to bring together opposite qualities and
label: Paragraph

text: solutions?” Rendered affirmatively the question offers a plea for architects to learn
label: Paragraph

text: from parallel traditions and contradictory human situations, so that their works will
label: Paragraph

text: be infused with “relativity,” making it possible, in van Eyck’s words, for buildings
label: Paragraph

text: to “breathe in and out.” Point 2, which sits to the left of the midpoint below and
label: Paragraph

text: between both Circles, posits that “To discover anew implies discovering something
label: Paragraph

text: new.” This premise identifies the value of learning from the great human inherit-
label: Paragraph

text: ance at our disposal, from all times and places (which raises a challenge to the
label: Paragraph

text: tabula rasa approach of the worst excesses of modernist architecture and planning,
label: Paragraph

text: but also to novelty for its own sake, which characterizes much architectural pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction since the 1980s). Revisiting what exists already invites interpretation of it;
label: Paragraph

text: which is to say, opening it up to translations into something new. In this way, van
label: Paragraph

text: Eyck was an adherent of tradition, but in particular, the etymological origins of the
label: Paragraph

text: word in betrayal, suggesting that working with sources is as much a process of their
label: Paragraph

text: inheritance being “handed down’ (from one generation to the next, in the conven-
label: Paragraph

text: tional sense of tradition), as it is a “handing over” of tradition (by surrendering it to
label: Paragraph

text: the next generation), so that it might be renewed. Point 3, which extends along the
label: Paragraph

text: bottom arc of the right Circle, implores architects to “Get close to the center — the
label: Paragraph

text: shifting center — and build,” which introduces the possibility of residing at both the
label: Paragraph

text: core of tradition and at the core of human experience simultaneously, while recog-
label: Paragraph

text: nizing the relative instability, or flux, of culture. Point 4, the last, extends under-
label: Paragraph

text: neath and slightly beyond both Circles, and is laid out as a concave curve, so that it
label: Paragraph

text: appears to cup the three previous points, and the two Circles and other text above
label: Paragraph

text: it. The text, “We can discover ourselves everywhere — in all places and ages — doing
label: Paragraph

text: the same things in a different way, feeling the same differently, reacting differently
label: Paragraph

text: to the same,” is largely a restatement of all of the ideas laid out by the Otterlo Cir-
label: Paragraph

text: cles and introduced above. It is as much van Eyck’s motto, as the Otterlo Circles are
label: Paragraph

text: an emblem for his architecture, especially the orphanage.
label: Paragraph

text: A More Complete Perspective
label: Title

text: To say that we experience the same things across time and space, just differently, is
label: Paragraph

text: not so much relativist — in an equivocal sense — as it is a restatement of van Eyck’s
label: Paragraph

text: debt to Whorf. This thesis also posits the generative potential of the tension resid-
label: Paragraph

text: ing between the universal and the local, between groups and individuals. In short, if
label: Paragraph

text: all people do the same things everywhere, only differently, it is reasonable that
label: Paragraph

text: relativity, which values the validity of each of these responses, offers us a more
label: Paragraph

text: complete perspective on reality and thus amplifies the potential to build a more
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensively encompassing environment attuned to human reality by being
label: Paragraph

text: its counter-form. Important in this as well is the suggested lineage of human bodies
label: Paragraph

text: that binds all human beings together by way of a shared genetic as well as a physical
label: Paragraph

text: inheritance: bodies are more the same everywhere than they are different, which is
label: Paragraph

text: why architecture ignores bodies at its peril. In another sense, this approach suggests
label: Paragraph

text: that the best forms may already be given, associating van Eyck’s preoccupation
label: Paragraph

text: with the experience of his buildings by the individuals who would inhabit them,
label: Paragraph

text: with Adolf Loos’ (1870-1933) conviction that the “the best form is always there
label: Paragraph

text: already and no one should be afraid of using it, even if the basic idea for it comes
label: Paragraph

text: from someone else.”* Using chairs as an example, in an attack on the Deutscher
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund, Loos argued that “we do not sit in a particular way because a cabinet-
label: Paragraph

text: maker has made a chair in this or that way, the cabinetmaker makes the chair in a
label: Paragraph

text: particular way, because that is the way we want to sit”; in short, sitting makes
label: Paragraph

text: chairs, rather than chairs making sitting.” The uncanny tension between the famil-
label: Paragraph

text: iar and the alien at the Amsterdam Orphanage, as in much of van Eyck’s work,
label: Paragraph

text: derives from just such an understanding of architecture’s vocation. Paradoxically,
label: Paragraph

text: Whorf’s ideas of linguistic relativity encouraged van Eyck’s inquiry into the
label: Paragraph

text: generative potential of valuing parallel traditions in the invention of an architecture —
label: Paragraph

text: realized in the orphanage — that would be far more comprehensible than much
label: Paragraph

text: modernist architecture could ever be. In this sense, for van Eyck, an architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to embody the extreme rationality of modern techno-science would
label: Paragraph

text: always tend toward alienation, away from satisfying emotional function. For him,
label: Paragraph

text: the comprehensibility of the constructed environment would persist as a real
label: Paragraph

text: possibility so long as its invention and making occurs within a horizon of shared expe-
label: Paragraph

text: rience graspable by a language capable of giving form to reality and desire.
label: Paragraph

text: In short, van Eyck was convinced that modern architecture could offer a richer
label: Paragraph

text: setting for human reality if architects valued the parallel views of existence acces-
label: Paragraph

text: sible to them through contact with non-Western cultures. Architecture could
label: Paragraph

text: become felt meaning — expression rather than representation — if its invention ben-
label: Paragraph

text: efitted from a fuller comprehension of varied human experience, across time and
label: Paragraph

text: space, demonstrated when the design of a complex building takes account of the
label: Paragraph

text: exceedingly complex structure of human existence, in particular in-between con-
label: Paragraph

text: ditions, which are inevitably varied, contradictory, and filled with ambivalence,
label: Paragraph

text: only partially understood on a fully conscious level.
label: Paragraph

text: In response to the reductive and banalizing tendencies of modern methods and
label: Paragraph

text: means of construction, van Eyck sought a way to turn the inevitability of modular-
label: Paragraph

text: ized and assembled construction into an advantage for architectural expression.
label: Paragraph

text: Viewing modern elements through a lens suggested by ancient Greek, as much
label: Paragraph

text: as by vernacular and early modernist architecture, van Eyck conceived the elements
label: Paragraph

text: out of which buildings are assembled as a lexicon. In a manner similar to the design of
label: Paragraph

text: sentences, van Eyck believed that individual architectural elements could gain in
label: Paragraph

text: meaning if configured into comprehensible forms by being assembled semantically.
label: Paragraph

text: Because modern assembled construction, along with gravity, life safety, and matters
label: Paragraph

text: of practical necessity are inescapable, an architectural syntax is also required.
label: Paragraph

text: A Configurative Discipline
label: Title

text: Van Eyck’s combinatory scheme is not quite as simple as the traditional notion of
label: Paragraph

text: “wholes made up of parts,” but takes account of modern construction techniques
label: Paragraph

text: by recognizing that “a whole is more than the sum of its parts.” In the same way
label: Paragraph

text: that words gain in meaning through their association with the other words in a
label: Paragraph

text: sentence, each architectural element is whole in itself and will carry its own asso-
label: Paragraph

text: ciative charge of meaning. The overall sense of a greater whole can only emerge by
label: Paragraph

text: fitting the individual elements together, which, by way of the relationships estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lished among the parts, gains in significance through expanding associations with
label: Paragraph

text: other equally charged elements of the same size, as well as smaller or larger ones.
label: Paragraph

text: The configuration of patterns out of meaningful individual parts — whole in
label: Paragraph

text: themselves — promises to achieve a more complex result than modern building
label: Paragraph

text: as simple assembly or industrial production ever can.
label: Paragraph

text: When a building’s several elements are brought together in a comprehensible
label: Paragraph

text: way, as in the orphanage, they hold out the possibility of revealing a pattern that is
label: Paragraph

text: far denser in expressive potential than any one of the elements could sustain on its
label: Paragraph

text: own. Assemblage of a whole of this sort, van Eyck believed, could result in a com-
label: Paragraph

text: prehensible setting able to contain (and sustain) curiosity, improvised inhabitation,
label: Paragraph

text: and an excess of human emotion. Individual parts retain their distinctness, but are
label: Paragraph

text: enriched through relations to other equally specific parts. Thus, the configuration
label: Paragraph

text: of comprehensible places suited to varied occasions depends on developing an
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of the limitations and possibilities of individual parts, in particular
label: Paragraph

text: their combinatory potential, out of which the intended overall expression of a built
label: Paragraph

text: form is construed.’
label: Paragraph

text: With this in mind, van Eyck could be considered an adherent of philosophical
label: Paragraph

text: structuralism, which also explains his rejection of, and by, for example, Peter Eisen-
label: Paragraph

text: man (b.1932), who characterizes himself as an adherent of philosophical post-struc-
label: Paragraph

text: turalism, and Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas (b.1944), who is perhaps the purest
label: Paragraph

text: adherent of neoliberalism in architecture. However, it is worth recollecting that
label: Paragraph

text: van Eyck’s structuralism has a much longer lineage than do most of the myriad
label: Paragraph

text: architecture fashions of the past 60 years or so, which, at the very least, lends
label: Paragraph

text: his work the authority of tradition. In particular, van Eyck’s “configurative
label: Paragraph

text: discipline,” according to which the Amsterdam Orphanage was conceived, shares
label: Paragraph

text: much in common with the fifteenth-century Italian architect and theorist, Leon
label: Paragraph

text: Battista Alberti (1404-72), specifically his concept of concinnitas. According to
label: Paragraph

text: Alberti, concinnitas is the method by which beauty (as wholeness) emerges out
label: Paragraph

text: of a consonance among separate parts that together make up a whole:
label: Paragraph

text: Itis the task and aim of concinnitas to compose parts that are quite separate from each
label: Paragraph

text: other by their nature, according to some precise rule, so that they correspond to one
label: Paragraph

text: another in appearance. |... This is the main object of the art of building, and the
label: Paragraph

text: source of her dignity, charm, authority, and worth."
label: Paragraph

text: Concinnitas effectively sums up much of what van Eyck attempted to achieve with
label: Paragraph

text: the orphanage. His configurative discipline, akin to Alberti’s concinnitas,
label: Paragraph

text: conceptualizes the coincidence of parts in buildings as interrelated and interdepend-
label: Paragraph

text: ent, which has implications for cities as well. As the practice of configuring the com-
label: Paragraph

text: plex association of all the elements that form a building, or any constructed setting,
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’s vocation, according to van Eyck, is to provide a holistic human realm.
label: Paragraph
