text: When Kenzo Tange travelled to Otterlo to attend the last meeting of the Congrés
label: Paragraph

text: internationaux d’architecture moderne (CIAM) in September 1959, he seemed to be
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupied by questions of the urban form of the future. Like other participants
label: Paragraph

text: in this conference, organized by Team 10, that ended with a formal dissolution of
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM, Tange was asked to present “a project which he considered to express in
label: Paragraph

text: the best way possible his conception of the task of the architect and urbanist, and
label: Paragraph

text: his thoughts on how the architect and urbanist might rationalize and harmonize
label: Paragraph

text: the connections between people and their surroundings.”’ Tange concluded his
label: Paragraph

text: presentation with two projects by another young Japanese architect, Kiyonori
label: Caption

text: Kikutake, including his own residence, Sky House, and a utopian city design
label: Paragraph

text: called the Marine City. This became the first exposure of the Metabolism group’s
label: Paragraph

text: work in an international event. Tange particularly referred to the project of
label: Paragraph

text: Marine City and claimed: “Tokyo is expanding but there is no more land, and
label: Paragraph

text: we shall have to expand into the sea.”* This bold statement launched his explo-
label: Paragraph

text: ration of alternative urban forms for this emerging megacity with a series of
label: Paragraph

text: visionary projects that culminated with the Plan for Tokyo 1960, also known
label: Paragraph

text: as the Tokyo Bay Plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Kenzo Tange is a landmark figure in Japanese architecture of the twentieth cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury. His unrivalled reputation was primarily accomplished through a series of
label: Paragraph

text: iconic buildings, including the Hiroshima Peace Memorial (1955), Tokyo City
label: Paragraph

text: Hall (1957), Tokyo National Gymnasium (1964), the master plan and main struc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture of Osaka World Expositions (1970), and Tokyo Metropolitan Government
label: Paragraph

text: Tower (1991), through which he led the resurrection of Japanese architectural
label: Paragraph

text: culture after the Second World War. However, this impressive list represents
label: Paragraph

text: only part of his prolific and influential career as an architect, urbanist, and edu-
label: Paragraph

text: cator. Tange’s ideas of urbanism are equally important, even though few of his
label: Paragraph

text: urban designs were actually carried out. His visionary urban projects, which often
label: Paragraph

text: came with profound social implications, set up the foundation for Tange’s exper-
label: Paragraph

text: imentation in architectural forms and tectonics. In turn, each of his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: designs was often taken as part of an incremental process toward the realization
label: Paragraph

text: of his urban ideal. Such convergence of architecture and urbanism was the trade-
label: Paragraph

text: mark of many progressive architect-urbanists in the late 1950s through the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s, when utopia was a universal language — as was argued by Reyner Banham
label: Paragraph

text: in Megastructure and Manfredo Tafuri and Francesco Dal Co in Architettura
label: Caption

text: contemporanea, both published in 1976 — and Tange’s work represented a prom-
label: Paragraph

text: inent example.’
label: Paragraph

text: In this sense, the Tokyo Bay Plan not only summed up what Tange tried to
label: Paragraph

text: accomplish as the ideal form of a megacity in the postindustrial age, but also
label: Paragraph

text: steered his architectural creations for a few decades. It unfolded issues that are
label: Paragraph

text: essential to a full understanding of postwar Japanese architecture: reinterpretation
label: Title

text: of the Japanese tradition, transformation of the city, the theory of Metabolism,
label: Paragraph

text: and the mutual influence between Tange and the Metabolist group. Like most
label: Paragraph

text: Metabolist projects, however, the plan was often reduced to iconic images of
label: Paragraph

text: megastructure in the historiography of the past, and cut off from its socio-
label: Paragraph

text: historical and cultural context, in order to be aligned with the work of the West-
label: Paragraph

text: erm avant-garde. This chapter rebuilds these linkages and addresses these critical
label: Paragraph

text: issues related to the Tokyo Bay Plan. Tracing Tange’s work in the 1950s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s, it examines what Tange regarded as the essential qualities of the
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary city, namely, mobility, openness, and adaptability, which dictated
label: Paragraph

text: his design methodology, as applied to projects at both architectural and urban
label: Paragraph

text: scales.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s Early Career
label: Title

text: Tange recalled that it was when he concluded his apprenticeship with Kunio Mae-
label: Paragraph

text: kawa and returned to the University of Tokyo to pursue a graduate degree during
label: Paragraph

text: wartime that he began to consider “the importance of urban design, not in the
label: Paragraph

text: sense of mere city planning involving land-use and street-network composition,
label: Paragraph

text: but three-dimensional urban design.”* He conducted historical surveys of classical
label: Paragraph

text: public spaces and familiarized himself with modernist planning principles used in
label: Paragraph

text: cities in Japanese-occupied Manchuria. In 1942, he won first place in the national
label: Paragraph

text: competition for the Memorial of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. This
label: Paragraph

text: unbuilt scheme organized the complex with a hierarchical layout along a central
label: Paragraph

text: axis linking major memorial structures, for which Tange was inspired by “the pure
label: Paragraph

text: image of the Ise Shrine.”
label: Paragraph

text: this memorial site at the foot of Mount Fuji the nation’s new cultural center and
label: Paragraph

text: A broader agenda of this project, however, was to make
label: Paragraph

text: link it to Tokyo and Kyoto through a linear highway system forming the nation’s
label: Paragraph

text: development spine.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange became a member of the Governmental Agency for Reconstruction after
label: Paragraph

text: the war and led the survey team for the rebuilding of Hiroshima. In 1949, he won
label: Paragraph

text: the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park competition, a site that was hoped to revital-
label: Paragraph

text: ize the city center and commemorate victims of the atomic bombing. This memo-
label: Paragraph

text: rial, built in 1955, was once again based on an axial configuration. The central area
label: Paragraph

text: of the park followed the Capitoline layout employed in Tange’s 1942 competition
label: Paragraph

text: project. An Atomic Memorial Museum, resting on 20-foot pilotis, formed the cen-
label: Paragraph

text: terpiece of the architectural grouping. The building’s extensive horizontality and
label: Paragraph

text: the lattice pattern on the facade recalled the forms of Japanese traditional architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture. The museum was fronted by the memorial’s iconic figure, a fragment from a
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical dome that was the only structure to survive the bombing of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange presented this project at the CIAM meeting in Hoddesdon, England in
label: Paragraph

text: 1951, addressing the conference theme of “Urban Core” in a unique way, in that
label: Paragraph

text: this memorial would trigger the resurrection of the urban core and inspire the reju-
label: Paragraph

text: venation of Hiroshima. His design successfully devised a new architectural
label: Paragraph

text: language with a recognizable Japanese identity, yet it was modern in every sense,
label: Paragraph

text: with a minimalist form using concrete and steel frame structure and flat roof. This
label: Paragraph

text: combination of modernism and tradition provided the city a new sense of order out
label: Paragraph

text: of the chaotic urban scene of the immediate postwar years, and became a prototype
label: Paragraph

text: for postwar Japanese architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Rising through the Hiroshima project and several other high-profile buildings
label: Title

text: including Tokyo City Hall and Kagawa Prefectural Building, Tange advocated a
label: Paragraph

text: “new tradition” for Japanese architecture.° His designs went beyond the function-
label: Paragraph

text: alist approach to combine three distinct qualities: the dramatic expression of up-to-
label: Paragraph

text: date technology, the incorporation of civic spaces, and unmistakable revisions of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional architectural vocabulary. They exposed raw concrete on surfaces and
label: Paragraph

text: used concrete structure to present an abstract order of classical composition.
label: Paragraph

text: The proposal for the “new tradition” was intended to transcend the naive imitation
label: Paragraph

text: of traditional form in the prewar period, and to focus instead on modern aesthetics
label: Paragraph

text: or “spirit,” a word he repeatedly employed on different occasions. When he argued
label: Paragraph

text: with Ernesto Rogers about the relationship between tradition and innovation at the
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM meeting in 1959, Tange insisted that architects should “inherit spirit, not
label: Paragraph

text: specific idioms.”” This new tradition became an important part of effort of
label: Paragraph

text: re-establishing Japan’s cultural identity, a position he made clear in two of his
label: Paragraph

text: monographs, one on Katsura and the other on Ise.*
label: Paragraph

text: After he left Otterlo in 1959 Tange travelled to the United States for a visiting
label: Paragraph

text: professorship at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he started to
label: Paragraph

text: develop a new methodology of urban design. For his fifth-year architectural studio
label: Paragraph

text: he chose a design question called “New Community on the Sea: 25,000 Inhabitants
label: Paragraph

text: on the Boston Bay.” Tange apparently had in mind the Marine City that he had just
label: Paragraph

text: presented in Otterlo. The design brief, however, reversed Kikutake’s formula for a
label: Paragraph

text: more dramatic idea by placing the residential program directly over the water. He
label: Paragraph

text: picked one of the student projects for which he had provided the primary concept,
label: Paragraph

text: and presented it at the World Design Conference in 1960 and sent it to journals.
label: Paragraph

text: This design consisted of two gigantic linear constructions over the bay and linked
label: Paragraph

text: by an internal highway to the land. The blocks were characterized by an A-frame
label: Paragraph

text: section, and carried numerous dwelling units arranged upon layers of artificial
label: Paragraph

text: ground supported by the structure. Extraordinary in both its scale and form, the
label: Paragraph

text: scheme became Tange’s first attempt at what Fumihiko Maki and Reyner Banham
label: Paragraph

text: later called megastructure.” Le Corbusier’s 1931 plan for Algiers, which featured a
label: Paragraph

text: bookshelflike megastructure along the seashore, housing a highway and resi-
label: Paragraph

text: dences for an entire city, provided a precedent for such a concept. Tange’s A-frame
label: Paragraph

text: structure, as an improvement of Le Corbusier's mega-form, derived from a mas-
label: Paragraph

text: sive housing design by Masato Otaka, characterized by enormous structural mem-
label: Paragraph

text: bers and Corbusian pilotis. The A-frame megastructure was also used in Tange’s
label: Paragraph

text: 1959 competition entry for the World Health Organization Headquarters — dis-
label: Caption

text: missed as “unbuildable” — and evolved into the residential structures in the Plan
label: Paragraph

text: for Tokyo, 1960.
label: Caption

text: Metabolism
label: Title

text: The World Design Conference in Tokyo in 1960 was the highest level interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional event for design professions that Japan hosted in the postwar decades. Its
label: Paragraph

text: own significance in history, however, was outshone by the emergence of Metab-
label: Paragraph

text: olism at this event. Architects Kiyonori Kikutake, Kisho Kurokawa, Masato Otaka,
label: Caption

text: and Fumihiko Maki, architectural critic Noboru Kawazoe, industrial designer
label: Paragraph

text: Ekuan Kenji, and graphic designer Kiyoshi Awazu, formed the team preparing
label: Paragraph

text: the conference programs under the supervision of Tange’s colleague Takashi
label: Paragraph

text: Asada, and published their manifesto, Metabolism: Proposals for New Urbanism at
label: Paragraph

text: the conference, calling for a radical and futuristic approach to city design.° They
label: Paragraph

text: chose the name “Metabolism” for the group to indicate a fundamental idea shared
label: Paragraph

text: among these architects and designers — an understanding of the “city as an organic
label: Paragraph

text: process,” in opposition to what they saw as the modernist paradigm of the city as a
label: Paragraph

text: machinic system. Kurokawa’s Helix City, a scheme featuring gigantic helix mega-
label: Paragraph

text: structures inspired by DNA’s double helix form as representation of genic repro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction, as demonstrated by the Metabolists’ fascination for biological metaphor
label: Paragraph

text: in conceptualizing urban forms.
label: Paragraph

text: In their theoretical urban projects, the Metabolists often envisioned the sea and the
label: Paragraph

text: sky become human habitats of the future, and suggested that a city would grow, trans-
label: Paragraph

text: form, and die like an organism. In order to accommodate the growth and regenera-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the modern city, they called for the establishment of a system of urban design
label: Paragraph

text: distinguishing elements of different scale and duration, namely, the “permanent
label: Paragraph

text: element,” such as urban infrastructure, versus the “transient element,” such as indi-
label: Paragraph

text: vidual houses. Responding to these distinct “metabolic cycles” in the city, the Metabo-
label: Paragraph

text: list designs often proposed a combination of a megastructure, serving as the
label: Paragraph

text: permanent base, and numerous individual units attached to the megastructure and
label: Paragraph

text: subject to more frequent replacement. Kikutake’s Marine City was characterized
label: Paragraph

text: by standardized housing units clipped onto a few enormous ferroconcrete cylindrical
label: Paragraph

text: towers. The towers, serving as the main structure of the city, would grow as the pop-
label: Paragraph

text: ulation increased, and the individual living pods would conduct periodical self-
label: Paragraph

text: renewal. As a dramatic representation of the concept of “metabolism,” this combina-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of megastructure and cell became the trademark of their architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The architects dreamed of an alternative social order for the world through these
label: Paragraph

text: radical schemes for the city. Their design concepts were full of political implica-
label: Paragraph

text: tions, often based on a modem vision of collective society.’’ Such a utopian notion
label: Paragraph

text: can be detected in such projects as “City in the Air” by Arata Isozaki, then a grad-
label: Paragraph

text: uate student at the University of Tokyo under Tange’s supervision and an ally of
label: Paragraph

text: the Metabolists in many regards.'* The project challenged the status quo of the
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese city and its social organization by reversing Tokyo’s 31-meter building
label: Paragraph

text: height limit to erect several clusters in the air. These megastructures, consisted
label: Paragraph

text: of gigantic vertical cores carrying numerous inhabitable arms stretching far out like
label: Paragraph

text: canopies over the old city.”’
label: Paragraph

text: Tange played an important role as mentor of the Metabolists and facilitator of
label: Paragraph

text: the movement. His Boston Bay project, characterized by a separation of megastruc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and minor-structure, inspired the Metabolists’ urban concepts. His appoint-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of Asada in charge of the preparation of the World Design Conference
label: Paragraph

text: had led to the foundation of Metabolism. On a theoretical level, Tange’s progres-
label: Paragraph

text: sive notion of “tradition,” commitment to technological expression, pursuit of
label: Paragraph

text: articulated monumentality, and comprehensive approach to urban planning freed
label: Paragraph

text: the young Metabolists from Modernist doctrines and encouraged them to pursue
label: Paragraph

text: new paradigms.'* The Metabolists continued to explore new concepts of architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and urbanism and established their own identity through biological metaphors
label: Paragraph

text: and futuristic designs, which in turn inspired the elder master. This reciprocal rela-
label: Paragraph

text: tionship to a great extent shaped the Metabolist movement.
label: Paragraph

text: Plan for Tokyo, 1960
label: Caption

text: The Tokyo Bay Plan, involving Metabolist architects like Kurokawa and Isozaki,
label: Paragraph

text: was not only a thorough representation of Tange’s ideal city, but also a sophisti-
label: Paragraph

text: cated synthesis of the Metabolist concepts on a grander scale. However, unlike
label: Paragraph

text: most Metabolist schemes, which suggested no specific site, Tange’s plan was based
label: Paragraph

text: on an extensive analysis of Tokyo. Like many European cities, Tokyo was con-
label: Paragraph

text: fronted with numerous problems of urban reconstruction after the Second World
label: Paragraph

text: War. The rapid growth of population, proliferation of automobiles, inadequacy of
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure and social services, shortage of land, and scattered private land own-
label: Paragraph

text: ership led to the city’s fragmental urban landscape and ineffective planning inter-
label: Paragraph

text: vention. As Tokyo’s population swelled from 2.78 million in 1945 to 8.31 million in
label: Paragraph

text: 1960 and the population of the metropolitan area reached around 16 million in
label: Paragraph

text: 1960, there was enormous pressure to redevelop and decentralize the city.’ It
label: Paragraph

text: became evident that exceptional methods were required to regulate Tokyo’s pat-
label: Paragraph

text: tern of expansion, and solutions could only be found on a regional scale. The great
label: Paragraph

text: constructive energy released during the economic miracle and the preparation for
label: Paragraph

text: the Olympic Games offered fresh opportunities to rethink Tokyo’s urban future
label: Paragraph

text: and, to a great extent, prompted the emergence of Tange’s plan.
label: Paragraph

text: Several ideas had been proposed to reclaim Tokyo Bay for a new city prior to
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s plan. In 1958, the year Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced the
label: Paragraph

text: National Capital Region Development Plan, the president of the Japan Housing
label: Caption

text: Corporation, Hisaki Kano, published his own concept plan of Tokyo. He called
label: Paragraph

text: for the creation of several artificial islands that would fill about one third of the
label: Paragraph

text: bay between Tokyo and Chiba with residential areas, an industrial belt, an inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national airport, and parks surrounding a central island as the city center. A double-
label: Paragraph

text: loop expressway and a railroad would connect the new city districts with the exist-
label: Paragraph

text: ing ones.’* Architects were inspired by Kano’s vision and follow up enthusiastically
label: Paragraph

text: with even bolder concepts. Instead of filling up the bay or building permanent
label: Paragraph

text: supports, Kikutake’s Floating City of Tokyo envisaged an enormous rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: floating city on Tokyo Bay with communities and factories laid out like a check-
label: Paragraph

text: erboard. He claimed that this plan would make the city adaptable to the demands
label: Paragraph

text: arising from the ever-changing uses of the land. Each urban block was detachable
label: Paragraph

text: from the system and the city could be reconfigured when needed.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Building upon Kano’s and the Metabolists’ concepts, Tange’s plan was a sensible
label: Paragraph

text: progression toward a new Tokyo Bay City, yet far more sophisticated. It combined
label: Paragraph

text: the regional and local conditions of Tokyo with modern technologies of urban con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction and struck a balance between two contrasting approaches: the pragma-
label: Paragraph

text: tism of industrialists and the idealism of utopian architects. It manifested
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s position on urbanism that he had made clear at the CIAM meeting in
label: Paragraph

text: 1959: “We must reject ‘aestheticism’ in town planning. Tradition and regional char-
label: Paragraph

text: acters should be re-examined with critical eyes and minds. I shall repeat again that
label: Paragraph

text: all Ihave said above begins with the positive denial of the attempt to make order
label: Paragraph

text: out of existing reality. Vitalism is always destructive to existing reality, but is very
label: Paragraph

text: constructive in the building of our future.”’® Tange’s resolution to break away
label: Paragraph

text: from the “existing reality” to pursue a new paradigm of planning had set the tone
label: Paragraph

text: for his plan.
label: Paragraph

text: The project was completed in Tange’s laboratory at the University of Tokyo with
label: Paragraph

text: the assistance of five young architects: Keji Kamija, Arata Isozaki, Sadao Watanabe,
label: Paragraph

text: Kisho Kurokawa, and Heiki Koh. Instead of being disclosed in an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: publication, it was first presented on Japan’s national television network, NHK,
label: Paragraph

text: ina special New Year's program of 1961.'” This indicated that, instead of conceiving
label: Paragraph

text: of it as a purely experimental scheme, Tange intended to bring the project to public
label: Paragraph

text: attention and influence the authorities, hoping to realize such an idea.
label: Paragraph

text: Mobility, Openness, and Adaptability
label: Title

text: As rendered on a model of about 10 feet by 10 feet, Tange’s plan envisioned a new
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo expanding across the bay to reach the opposite shore in Chiba. The most
label: Paragraph

text: notable feature was a central spine carrying an elevated highway system, which
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of a series of interlocking loops and spanned 18 miles over the sea.
label: Paragraph

text: The spine started with a loop framing the existing city center of Tokyo, then it
label: Paragraph

text: moved onto the sea. The third, fourth, and fifth loops would accommodate a
label: Paragraph

text: new civic center and a port. The subsequent links would be occupied by office
label: Paragraph

text: and public buildings until the spine landed on the shore again. The buildings on
label: Paragraph

text: the spine took the form of habitable bridge trusses spanning gigantic service
label: Paragraph

text: towers, which were arranged on a rectangular grid at 200-meter intervals.
label: Paragraph

text: A number of secondary freeways departed from the central spine at right angles,
label: Paragraph

text: connecting to clusters of tent-shaped residential structures that spread over the bay.
label: Paragraph

text: The whole plan was conceived as an enormous megastructure with a hierarchical
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of circulations and programs.”°
label: Paragraph

text: In the monograph on this plan, Tange claimed that his concept stemmed from
label: Paragraph

text: the characteristics of what he called the world’s “pivotal cities,” namely, cities with
label: Paragraph

text: populations of ten million or more. In his view, such cities, including Tokyo, were
label: Paragraph

text: in a state of paralysis because their physical structures had “grown too old to cope
label: Paragraph

text: with the current rate of expansion,” and the only way to save the cities was by a
label: Paragraph

text: radical transformation.”’ He argued that the transportation system was the foun-
label: Paragraph

text: dation of a city’s operation, and mobility would bring a city vitality and order. The
label: Paragraph

text: pursuit of greater mobility underlay all parts of the plan. By projecting the infra-
label: Paragraph

text: structure of his new city directly onto the water, the highway system was presented
label: Paragraph

text: with a startling clarity as the dominant element. The great size of this linear system,
label: Paragraph

text: the perspicuity of its loop and branch road network, and the formal inventiveness
label: Paragraph

text: of the office buildings that were clipped onto the highway, all combined to make
label: Paragraph

text: the plan an articulated statement of an urban form generated in the age of
label: Paragraph

text: automobile.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s notion of mobility was apparently influenced by his Western predeces-
label: Paragraph

text: sors and contemporaries, whose work celebrated this fundamental quality of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern city and used it to construct a hierarchical order by separating automobiles
label: Paragraph

text: from pedestrians and distinguishing different movements by speed. Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: Ville contemporaine, Louis Kahn’s series of plans for Philadelphia, and Alison and
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Smithson’s Hauptstadt Berlin competition entry were great precedents. Push-
label: Paragraph

text: ing this concept further, Tange used mobility not only to create order but also as a
label: Paragraph

text: form giver to provide legibility of the city’s social organization. Besides the unique
label: Paragraph

text: fishbone-shaped highway system, he developed an urban design strategy called
label: Paragraph

text: “pilotis and core system,” combining Corbusian concept of pilotis with his favorite
label: Paragraph

text: uniform shaft of vertical circulation into a three-dimensional modular system. With
label: Paragraph

text: the “pilotis and core,” architects would not only be able to separate automobile
label: Paragraph

text: transportation from pedestrians, but also provide a more coherent structure
label: Paragraph

text: because architecture and infrastructure would be virtually integrated into one sys-
label: Paragraph

text: tem. The ultimate goal was to substitute the traditional two-dimensional planning
label: Paragraph

text: method of zoning with this three-dimensional generative system, through which
label: Paragraph

text: mobility and social interaction could be developed.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange declared three objectives for his plan:
label: Paragraph

text: 1 To shift from a radial centripetal system to a system of linear development
label: Title

text: 2 To find a means of bringing the city structure, the transportation system, and
label: Title

text: urban architecture into organic unity
label: Title

text: 3 To find a new urban spatial order that would reflect the open organization and
label: Title

text: the spontaneous mobility of contemporary society.”
label: Paragraph

text: The first and foremost aim of the plan, was apparently transform Tokyo’s cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tripetal structure into a linear structure. In 1958, two years before Tange’s project,
label: Paragraph

text: the Tokyo Metropolitan Government implemented the National Capital Region
label: Paragraph

text: Development Plan to regulate metropolitan development. This plan was inspired
label: Paragraph

text: by Sir Patrick Abercrombie’s 1944 Greater London Plan and the Garden City idea,
label: Paragraph

text: and proposed an enlarged centripetal layout with a green belt 16 to 27 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: away from the city center to contain the further sprawl of Tokyo’s 23-ward urban
label: Paragraph

text: core, and a series of new towns beyond this ring to house the growing population
label: Paragraph

text: and industries.” Tange’s plan was a polemical counterthrust to this governmental
label: Paragraph

text: plan. He argued that creating satellite cities would not solve Tokyo’s problems
label: Paragraph

text: because as these satellite cities would also grow and mature, the dispersion of pop-
label: Paragraph

text: ulation and industries would create more transportation in the center city and sub-
label: Paragraph

text: centers, and thus would only aggravate Tokyo’s overcrowding and traffic conges-
label: Paragraph

text: tion. In contrast, a linear city could provide a greater mobility characteristic of the
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary age. The centripetal form, he contended, represented a “closed” and
label: Paragraph

text: medieval system, not only outdated but also incompatible with a city of such mag-
label: Paragraph

text: nitude. The linear city, instead, embodied the very essence of social progress and
label: Paragraph

text: represented the structure that would lead to an “open society.”
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s argument departed from CIAM’s concept of the “urban core,” which
label: Paragraph

text: called for city building around an identifiable core modeled after traditional civic
label: Paragraph

text: centers, an idea he had previously accepted. In the plan for Tokyo he rejected the
label: Paragraph

text: notion of civic center and turned to the linear form that he called the “civic axis.”
label: Paragraph

text: Combined with the arterial movement that sustained urban life, the civic axis
label: Paragraph

text: would serve as the symbol of an “open” modern city, just as a cathedral sitting
label: Paragraph

text: at the center of a centripetal organization was the symbol of the medieval city.
label: Paragraph

text: What distinguished Tange’s civic spine from the precedents of linear cities was
label: Paragraph

text: an organic idea. In a Metabolist manner, Tange invoked a biological metaphor to
label: Paragraph

text: defend his linear plan, comparing the transformation of a city from a radial form to
label: Paragraph

text: a linear form with the evolution of living organisms. He contended that the
label: Paragraph

text: amoeba and the asteroid have radial centripetal forms, while vertebrates have lin-
label: Paragraph

text: ear bone structures with parallel radiations because the radial pattern was no longer
label: Paragraph

text: suitable for complex functions and had to evolve into a linear one. Tange’s “civic
label: Paragraph

text: spine” was characterized by a sophisticated cyclical system of transportation, which
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of a double-loop composition in each link for different speeds of automo-
label: Paragraph

text: bile traffic. He claimed that this cyclical unit would make gradual expansion of the
label: Paragraph

text: civic axis possible: at each stage of development the system was complete, but it
label: Paragraph

text: would always be possible to add another unit, thus making the city growth a vital
label: Paragraph

text: process.
label: Paragraph

text: The awareness of urban transformation and the consideration of adaptability not
label: Paragraph

text: only informed the design of general structure, but were also presented on a local
label: Paragraph

text: scale. Tange noted that under the regulation of the superstructure, short-term ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments, like housing, should be reserved as expressions of individual choice and
label: Paragraph

text: changing fashion. In the plan for Tokyo, the A-shaped dwelling structures demon-
label: Paragraph

text: strated the effort to bring the “permanent elements” and the “transient elements”
label: Paragraph

text: into a harmonious whole. The enormous concrete structures provided artificial
label: Paragraph

text: grounds made possible by communal investment, upon which individual invest-
label: Paragraph

text: ments would take place in the form of private constructions that would reflect
label: Paragraph

text: diversity of tastes and needs. Tange expected the longer life cycles of the infrastruc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture to be organically connected with the shorter life cycles of individual construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tions to propel the city’s evolution.
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s concept of an open, adaptable linear megacity, however, was not agreed
label: Paragraph

text: upon by all architectural critics of his time, and some accurately pointed out the uto-
label: Paragraph

text: pian nature of this project. Christopher Alexander criticized Tange’s fishbone struc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture as a “tree,” rigidly hierarchical and monotonous, without the flexibility and
label: Paragraph

text: openness of a real urban society.” Peter Smithson liked the “pyramidal housing
label: Paragraph

text: units over-the-water’; however, he was unconvinced by the idea of adaptability
label: Paragraph

text: and noted: “unhappily as in a thousand student projects (from the time of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's Algiers project onwards), the romance of the idea of ‘each man building
label: Paragraph

text: his own house’ on man-made platforms, stands unsupported by a demonstration of
label: Paragraph

text: how it is to be done.””’ Even within the circle of Metabolism, there were debates on
label: Paragraph

text: the criteria of differentiating long-term structures and short-term elements. Fumi-
label: Paragraph

text: hiko Maki noted that Tange’s mega-form was based on the assumption that
label: Paragraph

text: designers would be able to ascertain which functions to be dealt with had long cycles
label: Paragraph

text: of change, and which shorter; however, this might not be the case. He wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Can the designer successfully base his concept on the idea that, to give an example,
label: Paragraph

text: transportation methods will change less rapidly than the idea of a desirable residence
label: Paragraph

text: or retail outlet? Sometimes, the impact and momentum of technology become so
label: Paragraph

text: great that a change occurs in the basic skeleton of social and physical structure. It
label: Paragraph

text: is difficult to predict to which part of a pond a stone will be thrown and which
label: Paragraph

text: way the ripples will spread.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Thus Maki argued that even though a megastructure allowed for changeable
label: Paragraph

text: infill, the main structure itself could become obsolete and lead to the failure of
label: Paragraph

text: the entire system.
label: Paragraph

text: An Unfolding Plan
label: Title

text: Mobility, openness, and adaptability constitute three pillars of Tange’s plan, repre-
label: Paragraph

text: sented in a bold vision projecting a future Tokyo based on a linear city principle and
label: Paragraph

text: integrating infrastructure, urban space, and architecture into a dynamic system. The
label: Paragraph

text: plan not only imposed a new pattern to regulate the city’s continuing growth, but
label: Paragraph

text: demanded a complete redefinition of its social system based on these three charac-
label: Paragraph

text: teristics that Tange deemed essential in contemporary society. He made accurate
label: Paragraph

text: observations of Japan’s postwar cities, as the country underwent a fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction and pursued economic modernization. Tange approached these
label: Paragraph

text: issues in a symbolic and utopian manner; however, his proposal encountered tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nical problems and was also entangled in political and economic constraints. The
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between order and spontaneity, both critical to a contemporary city,
label: Paragraph

text: was fully represented in the plan but hardly reconciled. Here, the Metabolist notion
label: Paragraph

text: of change was combined with the pursuit of monumentality, a quality Tange had
label: Paragraph

text: developed in his earlier work. The result was an ideal city responding to the trans-
label: Paragraph

text: formation of culture and attempting to provide a new communal symbol.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Tange failed to carry out the plan, his concept proved to be one that
label: Paragraph

text: would profoundly influence Tokyo’s urban development in the following decades.
label: Paragraph

text: While Tokyo retained its radial urban structure and fragmented urban landscape
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the rest of the twentieth century, the city has today been brought into a
label: Paragraph

text: larger linear urban cluster, known as “Tokaido Megalopolis” after Jean Gottmann’s
label: Paragraph

text: 1961 study.?” By 1970, the linear region between Tokyo and Osaka called Tokaido
label: Paragraph

text: had linked together a series of big cities and accommodated around 40% of Japan’s
label: Paragraph

text: total population. The Tokaido high-speed rail line serves as the spine of this meg-
label: Paragraph

text: alopolis, just as the linear highway system in the 1960 plan was the spine of the new
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo. Not long after the publication of Tange’s Plan for Tokyo, the reclamation
label: Paragraph

text: of Tokyo Bay was also underway, although not in the systematic manner Tange
label: Paragraph

text: envisioned. Many mega-projects have been built or are under construction on arti-
label: Paragraph

text: ficial islands in the bay, including some new business districts, such as Tokyo Tel-
label: Paragraph

text: eport Town and Minato Mirai 21.”
label: Caption

text: To a great extent, the Plan for Tokyo, 1960 epitomizes Tange’s ideas of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture and urbanism, which continued to inform his practice. In some cases, a frag-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of the plan was isolated and applied to a particular building project with a
label: Paragraph

text: more refined tectonic vocabulary. For instance, Tokyo National Gymnasium with
label: Paragraph

text: its tent-shaped structure was reminiscent of the residential megastructure floating
label: Paragraph

text: on the bay. Shizuoka Press and Broadcasting Center, with several cantilevered
label: Caption

text: office spaces clipped on a singular cylindrical shaft, commemorated the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: “core.” On other occasions, part of the unfulfilled vision of Tokyo Bay was devel-
label: Paragraph

text: oped into more a concrete urban design and applied to a particular urban area. For
label: Paragraph

text: instance, the new headquarters of Dentsu Corporation in Tokyo’s Tsukiji District
label: Paragraph

text: was conceived as a seed project to develop a central business district based on the
label: Paragraph

text: “three-dimensional generative network” delineated for the central spine in the
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo Bay Plan. The complex was characterized by an enormous space lattice:
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular cores soaring up and lifting gigantic horizontal trusses carrying inhab-
label: Paragraph

text: itable spaces that were interconnected in the air, with a tendency to grow into the
label: Paragraph

text: rest of the city. In a similar manner, a reduced version of the linear mega-form was
label: Paragraph

text: used in the 1965 plan for the reconstruction of Skopje in Macedonia and in the cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tral axis of the 1970 World Expositions in Osaka, which were given the metaphoric
label: Paragraph

text: names of “City Gate” and “Trunk” respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: Yamanashi Press and Broadcasting Center, built in the city of Kofu in 1964, exem-
label: Paragraph

text: plified this cross-scale and coherent approach to architecture and urban design in
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s built work. It was conceived as an “open-ended” building and a miniature
label: Paragraph

text: city based on the “pilotis and core” system. Tange wrote of this project: “The build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing is at once a single spatial type capable of change and growth, and a space estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lished within a three-dimensional communications grid. This is a proposal for both a
label: Paragraph

text: single building and for urban design.””? The building took the form of a three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional lattice made up of the vertical cores carrying people, material, energy,
label: Paragraph

text: and information up and down, the horizontal containers housing various programs,
label: Paragraph

text: and a few “voids” randomly left on different levels. The capacity for accommodat-
label: Paragraph

text: ing future growth and change was achieved through the differentiation of structural
label: Paragraph

text: and non-structural elements. The structural elements, in this case comprising
label: Paragraph

text: 16 cylindrical towers, were the “vertical streets” of a city, providing the necessary
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure for all sorts of developments. As Tange explained, “The result is that
label: Paragraph

text: the vertical roads are built, but unoccupied voids remain here and there. These will
label: Paragraph

text: provide the extra space needed for expansion.”*® The project thus reconfirms
label: Paragraph

text: Tange’s ideal urban form emanating from the Tokyo Bay project, which remains
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most powerful statements of urbanism addressing the transformation of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary culture centered on mobility, openness, and adaptability.
label: Paragraph

text: PART V
label: Title

text: THE 1960s
label: Title

text: AND 1970s
label: Title

text: Introauction
label: Title

text: QUESTIONING MODERN WORLDS
label: Title

text: Alexander Eisenschmidt
label: Title

text: For architecture, the 1960s and 1970s were framed by the dissolution of CIAM and
label: Paragraph

text: the First International Architecture Exhibition in Venice. But the mentality of these
label: Paragraph

text: years might best be described as the time before and after 1968; which is to say, the
label: Paragraph

text: years between Jerry Lee Lewis’ “Great Balls of Fire” (1957) and the premature dis-
label: Paragraph

text: solution of the Sex Pistols (1978), years of protest that challenged the status quo.
label: Paragraph

text: Equally, it was the time of remembering, since forgetting had happened far too
label: Paragraph

text: quickly after World War II; of re-engaging history (particularly the dramatic parts);
label: Paragraph

text: and of envisioning another kind of city and architecture for another kind of society.
label: Paragraph

text: It was also a moment of pause within the path of modernity, when seemingly estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lished paradigms of modernism were questioned, challenged, and detoured.
label: Paragraph

text: In the aftermath of World War II, under the auspices of reconstruction, many
label: Paragraph

text: modern dreams of the 1920s and 1930s were implemented at a large scale. Massive
label: Paragraph

text: building ensembles, even entire cities, were to be rebuilt on an unprecedented scale
label: Paragraph

text: from Japan to Spain, resulting in the wide-reaching implementation of modern set-
label: Paragraph

text: tlement patterns and construction techniques. While the forces of war had previ-
label: Paragraph

text: ously accelerated research into and implementation of new material dimensions
label: Paragraph

text: and assembly techniques, these developments later found their way into post-
label: Paragraph

text: war mass-production of architecture and urbanism. In addition, the formation of
label: Paragraph

text: the Eastern and Western Blocs expedited many of the rebuilding efforts on both
label: Paragraph

text: sides. While modernist principles were prominent forces in postwar reconstruc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, the dream of a unified vision (from Le Corbusier via Rudolf Schwarz to
label: Paragraph

text: Max Bill) never came to pass.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead, geographical changes in the constellation of the architectural scene that
label: Paragraph

text: now included a wider network of protagonists, together with generational conflicts
label: Paragraph

text: that increasingly questioned modernist agendas and their reliance on technology,
label: Paragraph

text: motivated a younger generation of architects and urbanists to move new sets of
label: Paragraph

text: values into the foreground. As the previous chapters have indicated, several influ-
label: Paragraph

text: ential projects had already announced the shift in attitude by the 1950s. Examples
label: Paragraph

text: include Oscar Niemeyer’s work in Brazil, from his own private house (Canoas
label: Paragraph

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: House) in Rio de Janeiro to his collaborations with Lucio Costa (on a much larger
label: Paragraph

text: scale — Brasilia); the buildings and plans that were implemented in Algiers and
label: Paragraph

text: Morocco by Fernand Pouillon; the office of Candilis, Josic, and Woods; and projects
label: Paragraph

text: in Japan and England that were driven by biological processes and sociological stud-
label: Paragraph

text: ies respectively. One of the most striking demonstrations of diverging ideas during
label: Paragraph

text: this time was the urban design competition for Berlin in 1958 (“Hauptstadt Berlin’),
label: Paragraph

text: where rigid modernist schemes were exhibited next to organicist and, occasionally
label: Paragraph

text: even, playful urbanisms. One year later, the geographic and generational
label: Paragraph

text: conflicts escalated during the final meeting of CIAM, which sealed the fate of that
label: Paragraph

text: organization.
label: Paragraph

text: Aldo van Eyck charged the older generation with “betray[ing] society in betray-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the essence of contemporary thought,” and added, “Nobody can really live
label: Paragraph

text: in what they concoct.”’ In essence, he and his allies questioned what they saw
label: Paragraph

text: as the universalist approach of CIAM and aimed at shifting emphasis to notions
label: Paragraph

text: of community, user participation, and social organization. “Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture,” for the members of Team 10, was “firmly attached to the architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural problems of around 1920,”* which since had long been superseded. Team 10’s
label: Paragraph

text: fascination with human relations and the complex patterns of interaction within the
label: Paragraph

text: city led to a new understanding of what they called “levels of association,” which
label: Paragraph

text: ran counter to the programmatically divided Functional City of the Athens Charter.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architecture had lost touch with contemporary relationships between
label: Paragraph

text: house, street, district, and city — a verdict that drew attention to the social realities
label: Paragraph

text: of present-day life and called on architecture and urbanism to find forms that would
label: Paragraph

text: be able to represent these new conditions. As Team 10 members generally, and
label: Paragraph

text: Alison and Peter Smithson especially recognized, the potentials of working-class
label: Paragraph

text: street life in the existing city could give shape and form to new projects.
label: Paragraph

text: By the end of the 1950s, the interest in the current condition combined with
label: Paragraph

text: dissatisfaction with modernist totalities developed into directions that often
label: Paragraph

text: seemed diametrically opposed. One of these tendencies was the re-imagination
label: Paragraph

text: of material properties. The rough textures and raw surfaces in Le Corbusier’s Unité
label: Paragraph

text: d’Habitation in Marseilles represented not only a departure from the smooth sur-
label: Paragraph

text: faces of prewar modernism but came to be seen as a way of exposing and expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sing both the material conditions and mechanical and structural elements of a
label: Paragraph

text: building; which is to say, as a form of communication. In the work of James Stirling
label: Paragraph

text: and James Gowan, for example, these material tendencies were combined with an
label: Paragraph

text: expressive functionalism, resulting in a deliberate manipulation of the fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: ideas of modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: But Stirling was only able to achieve these new architectural forms, driven by
label: Paragraph

text: programmatic extrapolations, through a heightened awareness of history, one that
label: Paragraph

text: utilized precedents not to recap the past but to mold a new present. Unlike early
label: Paragraph

text: modernism’s intentional leap into the present, without detouring through the
label: Paragraph

text: recent past, history became a driving force in the form-finding processes of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture by the 1960s. For some, even the search for transcendent architectural
label: Paragraph

text: values and truths were again made possible through a reevaluation of traditions.
label: Paragraph

text: While firmly rooted in early modernist ideas and committed to the more recent
label: Paragraph

text: modernism of a New Monumentality, Louis I. Kahn combated some of its most
label: Paragraph

text: important tropes (the “free plan” and simplified functionalism) in his search for
label: Paragraph

text: an “architecture of connection.” In the chapter on the Salk Institute, Daniel
label: Paragraph

text: Friedman shows that the “type-forms” employed by Kahn were drawn “into a
label: Paragraph

text: larger picture that both incorporated and transcended the building’s deeply
label: Paragraph

text: thought pragmatism.” In the work of both Stirling and Kahn, modernism was taken
label: Paragraph

text: on as a project worth extending, but under new sets of historical references. In
label: Paragraph

text: terms that could easily be applied to this work, Alan Colquhoun observed that
label: Paragraph

text: “Modernism was to survive, but only after abandoning its totalizing claims and
label: Paragraph

text: by a process of self-cancellation.”*
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most potent engagements with history came from Italy with the neo-
label: Paragraph

text: rationalism of the Tendenza movement, which, under the guidance of Aldo Rossi
label: Paragraph

text: and Giorgio Grassi, sought to recognize and work within the limits of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Troubled by postwar consumerism and its threat to architecture, the discipline was
label: Paragraph

text: to retreat into its own confines in order to not be overrun by the overpowering
label: Paragraph

text: forces of the market or other fields. While modernism commonly sought to over-
label: Paragraph

text: turn current conditions in order to remake the world, Rossi speculated on resisting
label: Paragraph

text: them through an architecture of relative autonomy. Operating within and through
label: Paragraph

text: history was a matter of analyzing urban artifacts and morphologies in the history of
label: Paragraph

text: the city, detecting inherent formal typologies in buildings of the past, and utilizing
label: Paragraph

text: these formal types as compositional vehicles to contribute monumental buildings
label: Paragraph

text: toward a collective memory. For the Gallaratese apartment block, completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 1973, Rossi recalled the traditional Milanese tenement; and in the Teatro del
label: Paragraph

text: Mondo of 1979 the floating theater evoked the very same typology in the history
label: Paragraph

text: of Venice. As Mary Lou Lobsinger outlines in her chapter on the latter project, the
label: Paragraph

text: Teatro would “become part of the city” as it participated in the realities of Venice
label: Paragraph

text: and the importations and exportations of its image — an analogous architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: in all its disciplinary focus was acutely linked to the urbanity that surrounded it.
label: Paragraph

text: At the time when Rossi’s international status reached new heights in Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, other works surfaced from previous obscurity. By 1974 Portugal
label: Paragraph

text: had emerged as a new democracy after long years under dictatorship, giving expo-
label: Paragraph

text: sure to the work of Alvaro Siza. Similarly, the work of Carlo Scarpa was only slowly
label: Paragraph

text: becoming noticed by the late 1970s, toward the end of his life. Michael Cadwell’s
label: Paragraph

text: detailed chapter on Scarpa’s Brion Cemetery explains how the organization of rela-
label: Paragraph

text: tionships between materials, dimensions, craft, and circulation often led to surpris-
label: Paragraph

text: ing architectural constellations rooted in a “strange sensibility.” While Scarpa’s
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate, invented details necessitated Venetian craftsmanship, Siza’s projects
label: Paragraph

text: point toward another kind of contextual link related to site. But as Christian
label: Paragraph

text: G4nshirt explains in his chapter on the Swimming Pool on the Beach of Lega,
label: Paragraph

text: contextual relationships were not the “artful idealization of nature ... but the expo-
label: Paragraph

text: sure and restrained presentation of a primal, wild, inhospitable situation.” This new
label: Paragraph

text: focus on local contexts would also become the point of departure for theories such
label: Paragraph

text: as Kenneth Frampton’s “critical regionalism,” intended as a form of resistance to
label: Paragraph

text: cultural homogeneity or “universal civilization” — essentially countering interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Alongside those developments, unparalleled projects emerged from many other
label: Paragraph

text: countries, some of which had only gained independence from colonial rule in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1940s. Geoffrey Bawa in Sri Lanka, Balkrishna Doshi in India, Hassan Fathy in
label: Caption

text: Egypt, and Glenn Murcutt in Australia all found ways to promote an architecture
label: Paragraph

text: that engaged local specificities. Kazi Ashraf's chapter identifies Doshi’s work as
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously indebted to Le Corbusier and Kahn (with whom Doshi had previ-
label: Paragraph

text: ously collaborated) and in touch with India’s ancient civilization. Out of this
label: Paragraph

text: combination of references Doshi attempted to create a new modern Indian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The chapter by Maryam Gusheh and Catherine Lassen highlights
label: Caption

text: Murcutt’s use of local timber and consideration of local climate in his design for
label: Paragraph

text: the Marie Short House, which according to the authors forms an architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: combines a local familiarity with material abstraction. Hassan Radoine’s chapter
label: Paragraph

text: directs attention to the larger repercussions of Fathy’s efforts in the region. With
label: Paragraph

text: the publication of Architecture for the Poor in 1970,* however, Fathy influenced the
label: Paragraph

text: discourse far beyond the region by outlining the construction of a new village via
label: Paragraph

text: the participation of its inhabitants, who used local techniques and materials. The
label: Paragraph

text: ingenuities of local forces and the inclusion of inhabitants into the design and
label: Paragraph

text: building process simultaneously foregrounded a new form of populism and con-
label: Paragraph

text: tributed to the emerging interest in the existing city.
label: Paragraph

text: In the West a similar dualism appeared in the early work of Robert Venturi. Mar-
label: Paragraph

text: tino Stierli’s chapter on the Vanna Venturi House outlines the expressive registers
label: Paragraph

text: displayed by the building (classical, vernacular/ popular, and modern) and explains
label: Paragraph

text: that this “invocation initiated and preluded the classical and vernacular revivals that
label: Paragraph

text: informed postmodernist architecture in the three subsequent decades.” For Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: and his later partner, Denise Scott Brown, popular culture — from TV commercials
label: Paragraph

text: to billboards — rendered previous forms of urban space obsolete and became a
label: Paragraph

text: source for developing “a changing architectural sensibility”’ that superseded con-
label: Paragraph

text: ventional aesthetic preferences, functional paradigms, and formal typologies.
label: Paragraph

text: The pop consumerism that Venturi and Scott Brown experienced first-hand was
label: Paragraph

text: in Europe initially seen as exotic and only slowly became a more integrated per-
label: Paragraph

text: sonal experience. In England, for example, this transition is visible in the depiction
label: Paragraph

text: of consumer objects by the Independent Group versus the broadcasting of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural pop by Archigram. The American vernacular — the one that Venturi and
label: Paragraph

text: Scott Brown in collaboration with Steven Izenour felt architects could “learn from”
label: Paragraph

text: — became for the members of the Archigram group the vehicle for visualizing anew
label: Paragraph

text: kind of architecture and a new public entirely; one that would speak “to the cultural
label: Paragraph

text: imagining of the epoch,” as Sarah Deyong writes in her chapter on Archigram’s
label: Paragraph

text: pursuit of style. Indeed, by 1971, high-voltage, color-saturated, and slogan-aided
label: Paragraph

text: architectural drawings (in the style of Archigram) became the basis for a building
label: Paragraph

text: in the center of Paris — only this time, the drawings were not by Archigram mem-
label: Paragraph

text: bers but the then relatively unknown Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers, whose
label: Paragraph

text: Centre Pompidou would couple the technological ingenuities of Cedric Price’s
label: Paragraph

text: Fun Palace with the logics of Archigram’s Instant City. This not only expressed
label: Paragraph

text: the adaptability that architecture had long sought but, as Hadas Steiner describes
label: Paragraph

text: in her chapter, the Centre Pompidou’s “attempt to address the idea of culture
label: Paragraph

text: defined as the dissemination of information” made an important contribution in
label: Paragraph

text: a time of visual saturation and social connectivity.
label: Paragraph

text: The radicalization of contemporary life proposed by these young practitioners
label: Title

text: resonated in images of the city as decentralized, free, and in motion. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM’s city of the urban core with designated outskirts, the center was now seen
label: Paragraph

text: to be everywhere. Reyner Banham had already challenged CIAM’s zoned urban-
label: Paragraph

text: ism in 1959 by combining the situationist psychogeographic drift with his love for
label: Paragraph

text: Los Angeles. His essay, “City as Scrambled Egg” effectively produced a new urban
label: Paragraph

text: image and introduced a new outlook on postwar modernization, communication,
label: Paragraph

text: and leisure.° By 1971 Banham had published his account of Los Angeles as an
label: Paragraph

text: exhilarating new form of urban ecology. Only one year later, Venturi, Scott
label: Paragraph

text: Brown, and Izenour published Learning from Las Vegas,’ a book that sought to sus-
label: Paragraph

text: pend judgment on a popular American city in order to invent new ways of looking
label: Paragraph

text: at what was commonly regarded as taboo. Here, the increasing suburbanization
label: Paragraph

text: and decentralization of the existing city that was being propelled by new electronic
label: Paragraph

text: technologies and mass media was for Venturi and Scott Brown “almost all right”
label: Paragraph

text: and, after all, inescapable. Joining these explorations was a long list of writings that
label: Paragraph

text: studied urban life and repositioned architecture’s relationship to the city, includ-
label: Paragraph

text: ing: Aldo Rossi’s city of urban artifacts (Architecture of the City); the popular city
label: Paragraph

text: of Venturi, Scott Brown, and Izenour; the traditional city of Robert Krier’s
label: Paragraph

text: Stadtraum; the Collage City of Colin Rowe and Fred Koetter; the congested city
label: Paragraph

text: of Rem Koolhaas’ Delirious New York; and the experiential city of Bernard
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi’s Manhattan Transcripts.”
label: Paragraph

text: This latest focus on the urban condition took the city’s past and present as starting
label: Paragraph

text: points in a search for new forms of urban architecture. Much of the skepticism
label: Paragraph

text: toward modernist ideas came from a reevaluation of urban life, which had been
label: Paragraph

text: substantially affected by the modernization of postwar reconstruction and urban
label: Paragraph

text: growth. The political and social movements of 1968 had a strong impact on these
label: Paragraph

text: theories. After all, the student protests, political upheavals, and workers strikes
label: Paragraph

text: across the world were primarily concerned with policies, decision-making, and
label: Paragraph

text: urbanity in general. By the mid-1970s, however, architecture’s position within
label: Paragraph

text: urban culture and its social responsibilities were increasingly questioned. The
label: Paragraph

text: postmodern turn to historical references (neatly coinciding with the rise of neo-con-
label: Paragraph

text: servatism, visible in the election of Margaret Thatcher in 1979 and Ronald Reaganin
label: Paragraph

text: 1980) would eventually revoke architecture’s heightened insecurity but, at its best,
label: Paragraph

text: only playfully reposition architectural form and ornament. With the legendary La
label: Paragraph

text: Strada Novissima at the Venice Biennale of 1980, architectural postmodernism
label: Caption

text: found its most influential celebration. Among the 20 facades that were staged along
label: Paragraph

text: the interior street of the Corderie dell’ Arsenale, two contributions set themselves
label: Paragraph

text: apart: the installations of Rem Koolhaas and Frank Gehry. With their non-
label: Paragraph

text: conformity in mind, the 1960s and 1970s might best be understood as one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most contentious and, therefore, productive periods of the twentieth century.
label: Paragraph

text: For that reason alone these years might hold the key to many of today’s misunder-
label: Paragraph

text: standings, for going beyond the modern was then as much about a return to the past
label: Paragraph

text: as about a different conception of the future — the one that we have inherited.
label: Paragraph
