text: VANNA VENTURI
label: Title

text: HOUSE
label: Title

text: Robert Venturi
label: Title

text: Martino Stierli
label: Title

text: Robert Venturi, Vanna Venturi House, Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania, 1964.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: Mother's House
label: Title

text: The Vanna Venturi House in Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania, lovingly known as the
label: Caption

text: “Mother’s House,” was arguably Robert Venturi’s quintessential architectural
label: Paragraph

text: statement. It was planned and built between 1959 and 1964, a wide time span that
label: Paragraph

text: is telling of the exceedingly large amount of thought and intellectual work that
label: Paragraph

text: went into its realization. A house of modest scale, commissioned by the architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: widow mother, is a typical brief for a young architect’s first commission, for obvi-
label: Paragraph

text: ous social and economic reasons. In many ways, little houses are a testing ground
label: Paragraph

text: for the young architect to consider, evaluate, modify, and adjust his/her theoretical
label: Paragraph

text: conception of space against the reality. Given the special relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: architect and client, such early projects for a small house typically are more daring
label: Paragraph

text: and experimental than larger buildings for corporate clients. Ideally, they expand
label: Paragraph

text: the known limitations of construction, excel on the level of aesthetics, and enhance
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary discourse by exemplifying the theoretical standpoint of an emerging
label: Paragraph

text: voice. For these reasons, such houses bear great potential for the discipline of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture, being capable of transcending current standards and opening up new hor-
label: Paragraph

text: izons for this specific form of knowledge.’
label: Paragraph

text: “The Biggest Small Building”
label: Title

text: It is for this reason that, paradoxically, small first houses often reach a celebrity
label: Paragraph

text: status that transcends by far their initially modest nature. This is certainly the case
label: Paragraph

text: in the Mother’s House. Deemed by many to be Robert Venturi’s finest achieve-
label: Paragraph

text: ment in a long and controversial career, it stands handsomely besides his two major
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical contributions, both of which were pivotal in establishing a paradigm
label: Paragraph

text: shift in architectural discourse from late modern to postmodern.” The canonical
label: Paragraph

text: importance of this small house for the architecture of the past 50 years is reflected
label: Paragraph

text: in the numerous awards it received. The house won instant recognition with the
label: Paragraph

text: sole honorable mention in the 1965 Art and Architecture Awards competition of
label: Paragraph

text: the Architectural League of New York, and by being chosen as one of the projects
label: Paragraph

text: in “40 under 40: Exhibition of young talent in architecture,” in New York in 1966. In
label: Paragraph

text: the same year the American Builder selected the house as a prototype for future res-
label: Paragraph

text: idential buildings. In retrospect, it received the American Institute of Architects’
label: Paragraph

text: (AIA) Twenty-five Year Award in 1989, preluding Venturi’s selection for the
label: Paragraph

text: 1991 Pritzker Architecture Prize. In 1992, the Vanna Venturi House was dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: its own monograph, in which the complex design process is meticulously docu-
label: Paragraph

text: mented.’ In his essay commemorating the occasion, the eminent architectural his-
label: Paragraph

text: torian Vincent Scully, author of the introduction to Venturi’s Complexity and
label: Paragraph

text: Contradiction in Architecture and avid promoter of the Philadelphia-based architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: work and early career, qualified the house as “the biggest small building of the
label: Paragraph

text: second half of the twentieth century.”* In 2005 it featured among “twelve master-
label: Paragraph

text: works of modern American architecture” in a series of postage stamps issued by the
label: Paragraph

text: US Postal Service. The house received the 2012 AIA Philadelphia Landmark Build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing Award, and in 2013 was featured as one of “10 Buildings That Changed Amer-
label: Paragraph

text: ica” in a TV production on the national Public Broadcasting Service (PBS).
label: Paragraph

text: The Vanna Venturi House is situated in a suburban setting at 8330 Millman
label: Paragraph

text: Street in the Philadelphia neighborhood of Chestnut Hill. Set back from the street
label: Caption

text: and connected to it by a subtly angled driveway, it was built on the rear edge of a lot
label: Paragraph

text: newly acquired by the client. The plans and elevations of the house — whose con-
label: Paragraph

text: ception coincided with Venturi’s writing of Complexity and Contradiction in Architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture — epitomize the architect’s interest in mannerist ambiguity, historical reference,
label: Paragraph

text: and the layering of space. The front elevation with its characteristic split gabled roof
label: Paragraph

text: and its large square opening at the center is strictly symmetrical, of “almost Palla-
label: Paragraph

text: dian rigidity.”” The symmetry is subtly broken and dialectically subverted by the
label: Paragraph

text: system of window openings, which reflect the interior spatial configuration: The
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal strip on the right indicates the kitchen behind; it is counterbalanced by a
label: Paragraph

text: small square opening for the bathroom and the large, almost disproportionate lat-
label: Paragraph

text: tice window of the guest bedroom. This contradiction confirms the notion funda-
label: Paragraph

text: mental for Venturi’s architectural thinking that the facade acts as a zone of conflict
label: Paragraph

text: between the public and domestic domains. Accordingly, it is conceived as a screen
label: Paragraph

text: that both represents a building’s public face and displays its interior spatial organ-
label: Paragraph

text: ization; it serves as a stage upon which the drama of this conflict is performed and
label: Paragraph

text: resolved. Therein, for Venturi, lies precisely architecture’s defining moment. As he
label: Paragraph

text: states in Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture:
label: Paragraph

text: Designing from the outside in, as well as the inside out, creates necessary tensions,
label: Paragraph

text: which help make architecture. Since the inside is different from the outside, the wall —
label: Paragraph

text: the point of change — becomes an architectural event. Architecture occurs at the
label: Paragraph

text: meeting of interior and exterior forces and use of space...Architecture as the wall
label: Paragraph

text: between the inside and the outside becomes the spatial record of this resolution
label: Paragraph

text: and its drama.°
label: Paragraph

text: Flatness
label: Title

text: Besides the troubled symmetry, the ostentatious flatness is the facade’s other strik-
label: Paragraph

text: ing characteristic, an aspect that is emphasized by the prime medium of contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary architectural representation: photography. It seems, as Stanislaus von Moos
label: Paragraph

text: has pointed out with regard to the other major building of Venturi’s early career,
label: Paragraph

text: the Guild House in Philadelphia, “intentionally thin and un-tectonic, not much
label: Paragraph

text: more than the two-dimensional image of a facade.””’ As a matter of fact, both
label: Paragraph

text: the front and the rear facades make a point in extending horizontally and vertically
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the building’s margins, thus emphasizing the notion of a screen that is
label: Paragraph

text: merely leaning against the house. As such, it cannot be considered as an extension of
label: Paragraph

text: the interior but has emancipated itself from it and takes on an autonomous dimen-
label: Paragraph

text: sion. It serves as amedium between the two spatial realms. Itis this transformation of
label: Paragraph

text: the facade into a flat surface that has been theorized by Fredric Jameson, among
label: Paragraph

text: others, as epitomizing postmodernism.* The quasi-civic front of the house is coun-
label: Paragraph

text: tered by the ducked back elevation and its irregular distribution of openings. Moving
label: Paragraph

text: around the house is pivotal for understanding and appreciating the complex organ-
label: Paragraph

text: ization of planes and spaces as well as the contradictory, multiple function of indi-
label: Paragraph

text: vidual elements. Thus, what appears at the front like a massive, broadly based
label: Paragraph

text: chimney turns out to be the clerestory of the second-floor studio, which served
label: Paragraph

text: as Robert Venturi’s private room in the first years after its completion.
label: Paragraph

text: At the main facade, the transition between exterior and interior spaces is
label: Paragraph

text: mediated by one of Venturi’s characteristically ambiguous interstitial spaces clearly
label: Paragraph

text: cut out at the center, thus lending depth and signaling spatial complexity in an oth-
label: Paragraph

text: erwise conspicuously flat, screen-like front. The entrance area defined by this con-
label: Paragraph

text: figuration is lit from above through a vertical channel, which serves at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time to split the gables in two. Its visual appearance is symbolically reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: by a horizontal beam and a competing, fragmentary semicircular arch; a conflation
label: Paragraph

text: of motifs familiar from palimpsest-like brick walls in ancient (European) cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Promenade
label: Title

text: While the strictly rectangular ground floor plan preserves the vestiges of a symmet-
label: Paragraph

text: rical configuration, the architect superimposes a secondary spatial system of diag-
label: Paragraph

text: onal interior walls, a feature familiar from the Philadelphia School’s buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: those years, such as, for example, Louis Kahn’s Goldenberg House project
label: Paragraph

text: (1959). The visitor’s path from the entrance is bent and twisted several times so
label: Paragraph

text: as to produce a spatially intricate, exciting architectural promenade that opens
label: Paragraph

text: up to a generous living room, from where the kitchen, the master bedroom,
label: Paragraph

text: and the guest room can be accessed. Reminiscent of English country houses
label: Paragraph

text: and of Frank Lloyd Wright’s family residences, the center of the plan and of the
label: Paragraph

text: main space is taken up by the fireplace and chimney, around which is wrapped
label: Paragraph

text: the stair that leads up to the second floor. It is not an ordinary stair of common
label: Paragraph

text: form and proportions, but one that is — again — in ostentatious conflict with the
label: Paragraph

text: chimney with which it competes: on the ground level, it extends well into the
label: Paragraph

text: room, serving at the same time as a spatial partition. After a few steps, it is reduced
label: Paragraph

text: to a narrow passage that allows the visitor only barely to continue further up. Ven-
label: Paragraph

text: turi’s manifest interest in the stair as a spatial agent is taken up again in the famous
label: Paragraph

text: little “nowhere-stair” that leads from the second-floor studio to nowhere. Being a
label: Paragraph

text: quasi-surrealist element seemingly out of a boy’s dream, it was inspired by a small
label: Paragraph

text: stair that leads to the large tower of the Art and Architecture Library at the Uni-
label: Paragraph

text: versity of Pennsylvania by Frank Furness (1888-91),” the demolition of which
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi and his future partner Denise Scott Brown successfully opposed in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1960s. The interior of the Mother’s House thus contradicts many critics
label: Paragraph

text: who have seen in Venturi an “imagineer” less interested in issues of space than
label: Paragraph

text: in visual representation, a verdict not least based on polemical statements against
label: Paragraph

text: the International Style and its premises by the architect and his partner Scott Brown
label: Paragraph

text: themselves. In Learning from Las Vegas, they dismissed the notion of architecture as
label: Paragraph

text: space, suggesting that attention be shifted to its symbolic dimension.’® That this
label: Paragraph

text: rhetoric does not do justice to the Mother’s House’s interior configuration has been
label: Paragraph

text: rightly pointed out by David Brownlee: “For all the flatness of the facades, this was
label: Paragraph

text: an architecture of space.”'*
label: Paragraph

text: The Building as Exhibition
label: Title

text: The Vanna Venturi House is thus characterized by a dialectic interrelationship between
label: Paragraph

text: intricate interior spatial organization and two-dimensional flatness on the facade, both
label: Paragraph

text: of which aspects together synthesize into an idea of a complex and contradictory archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. But the facade takes on another function that is fundamental for Venturi’s archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural thinking. Not merely confined to the role of an interface between exterior and
label: Paragraph

text: interior spaces mediating and juxtaposing the two realms, it serves also as ground for an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural exhibition. As Venturi and Scott Brown have stated with regard to some of
label: Paragraph

text: their small house projects that followed the Vanna Venturi House:
label: Paragraph

text: ...the heuristic use of historical models was important in the development of their
label: Paragraph

text: designs and therefore helpful in describing them (but not because we think it is nec-
label: Paragraph

text: essarily the right method for all architects or for seeing all issues and solving all pro-
label: Paragraph

text: blems. We unashamedly lift our analogs out of their historical context...”'?
label: Paragraph

text: For the architects, referencing the vocabulary of the historical language of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture is a method for contemporary design. Theirs is a formalistic approach in that
label: Paragraph

text: an analogy beyond the formal is explicitly not intended. The Vanna Venturi House
label: Paragraph

text: references three different registers of architectural language, assembling them into an
label: Paragraph

text: almost encyclopedic display of architectural history: the classical; the vernacular/
label: Paragraph

text: popular; and the modern. Their invocation initiated and preluded the classical
label: Paragraph

text: and vernacular revivals that informed postmodernist architecture in the three subse-
label: Paragraph

text: quent decades.
label: Paragraph

text: Concerning the references to the classical language of architecture, Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: illuminated this aspect of his design in his 1982 Walter Gropius lecture delivered
label: Paragraph

text: at the Harvard University Graduate School of Design in a “postscript” on his
label: Paragraph

text: Mother’s House:
label: Title

text: My mother’s house...is an explicitly Classical building in the substance of its plan and
label: Paragraph

text: form and in the ornament of its elevation. ...But the house, though Classical, is not
label: Paragraph

text: pure. Within the Classical aesthetic it conforms to a Mannerist tradition which admits
label: Paragraph

text: contradiction within the ideal order and thereby enhances the ideal quality of that
label: Paragraph

text: order through contrast with it. ...Some Classical and contradictory aspects of my
label: Paragraph

text: mother’s house are: the plan and the front and back elevations are symmetrical,
label: Paragraph

text: about a central axis, but within the consistent perimeter of the plan, the extremities
label: Paragraph

text: vary to accommodate exceptions in the plan; and within the consistent profile of the
label: Paragraph

text: elevations, the extremities vary to conform the exceptions within. The configuration
label: Paragraph

text: of windows is asymmetrical, if balanced, for the same reason. The central core of the
label: Paragraph

text: house is a solid, not the void typical of a Palladian plan. The solid core consists of a
label: Paragraph

text: fireplace, chimney, and staircase, like that of a New England house of the 17° cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tury. The central entrance reads on the front elevation as a void, rather big in scale
label: Paragraph

text: like that ofa porticoed Palladian villa, but it is contradicted by the blank, set-back wall
label: Paragraph

text: of the solid core which is itself distorted in plan to accommodate circulation around
label: Paragraph

text: it. Symmetry in plan is therefore modified at the extremities via exceptions, and
label: Paragraph

text: nearer the centre via distortions.’
label: Paragraph

text: Operating within a classical frame of reference, Venturi displays a mannerist sen-
label: Paragraph

text: sibility, and the buildings he explicitly refers to are often from the pertaining his-
label: Paragraph

text: torical age.'* In the Vanna Venturi House, Palladio’s and Alessandro Vittoria’s
label: Caption

text: Nymphaeum in the garden of the Villa Barbaro at Maser (circa 1560) served as
label: Paragraph

text: an explicit reference,” but a number of additional buildings may also be cited
label: Paragraph

text: as being part of the visual repository of the Mother’s House: Michelangelo’s Porta
label: Paragraph

text: Pia in Rome (1561-65) for the general layout of the main facade as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: superimposition of gable and are motifs; the broken gables in the main elevation
label: Paragraph

text: of Sir John Vanbrugh’s Blenheim Palace (1705-24); and even details of the neo-
label: Paragraph

text: baroque exuberance of Armando Brasini’s Convento del Buon Pastore near Rome
label: Caption

text: (1929-43) as well as the Italian architect’s use of layered space in the (now demol-
label: Paragraph

text: ished) Forestry Building at the EUR in Rome from 1942."°
label: Paragraph

text: All of these buildings were reproduced in Complexity and Contradiction in Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture, some of them on the basis of Venturi’s own photographs. The American
label: Paragraph

text: architect travelled through Great Britain and southern Europe extensively, first
label: Paragraph

text: on a summer trip as a student in 1948, and then again on the occasion of this fel-
label: Paragraph

text: lowship at the American Academy in Rome from 1954 to 1956. These travels gave
label: Paragraph

text: him the opportunity to study historical and contemporary architecture at first hand
label: Paragraph

text: and on site, much of it under the guidance of or stipulated by art historian Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Krautheimer.’’ The back elevation of the Vanna Venturi House displays a tripartite
label: Caption

text: thermal window, referencing both Roman architecture as well as its interpretation
label: Paragraph

text: in the buildings and drawings of Palladio and Venturi’s former mentor Louis Kahn,
label: Paragraph

text: who had himself studied Roman architecture on site during his tenure at the Amer-
label: Paragraph

text: ican Academy in Rome in 1950/51.'* Venturi’s use of overhead light may also be a
label: Paragraph

text: digest of his Roman experience. While Kahn later developed this feature into per-
label: Paragraph

text: fection in his museum buildings, Venturi’s use of it is most likely based on his own
label: Paragraph

text: in-situ experience.’
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn is not the only modern architect Venturi alludes to in his Mother’s House.
label: Paragraph

text: The broken pediment motif, while also having older predecessors, is clearly
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by the Roman architect Luigi Moretti’s Casa del Girasole apartment build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in Via Parioli in Rome from 1950, a building Venturi once described as “one of
label: Paragraph

text: the most inspiring buildings of my life.”*° Moretti’s Girasole and his slightly earlier
label: Paragraph

text: Casa Astrea (1949), also in Rome, equally display the treatment of the facade as a
label: Paragraph

text: thin, atectomic screen, a feature deemed characteristically postmodern but obvi-
label: Paragraph

text: ously having its own genealogy that dates back to the immediate Italian postwar
label: Paragraph

text: period. Other elements in Venturi’s design pay tribute to the vocabulary of the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style, which in this way becomes historicized as yet another formal
label: Paragraph

text: repertoire from which a contemporary architect around 1960 can borrow. This
label: Paragraph

text: applies in particular to the exposed steel column in the living room, which is rem-
label: Paragraph

text: iniscent of Le Corbusier’s pilotis (such as in the celebrated Villa Savoye in Poissy,
label: Paragraph

text: another of Venturi’s favorite buildings), the horizontal strip of windows in the main
label: Paragraph

text: facade, another characteristically Corbusian feature, and, generally, the open plan
label: Paragraph

text: of the house.
label: Paragraph

text: The exhibition of architectural styles and epochs in the Vanna Venturi House is
label: Paragraph

text: completed by references to vernacular and popular traditions taken from the archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect’s mental musée imaginaire. (Contrary to Venturi’s later emphasis on the “clas-
label: Paragraph

text: sical” nature of the house, he first published photographs of the completed building
label: Paragraph

text: in 1965 under the heading of “A Justification of Pop Architecture.”)”’ If the architect
label: Paragraph

text: had given his Mother's House a dress of cedar shingles in his early drawings (it was
label: Paragraph

text: eventually built of stuccoed concrete), various reminiscences of the American Shin-
label: Paragraph

text: gle Style remain in the executed building, most notably the low, near-to-the-ground
label: Paragraph

text: pediment and the sash windows of McKim, Mead and White’s Low House in
label: Caption

text: Bristol, Rhode Island (1887). Venturi read Vincent Scully’s study on the topic dur-
label: Paragraph

text: ing his tenure at the American Academy in Rome, and the Vanna Venturi House
label: Paragraph

text: would later be incorporated into the historian’s essay on the Shingle Style’s con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary heritage as a prominent example, another fact telling of the fruitful intel-
label: Paragraph

text: ectual exchange between architect and historian.” In this vein may also be
label: Paragraph

text: mentioned other late nineteenth-century reformist architects and their contribu-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to a new domestic architecture, most notably Sir Edwin Lutyens, who is fre-
label: Paragraph

text: quently referred to in Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture and whose
label: Paragraph

text: Middlefield House (1908) in Stapleford, Cambridgeshire, provided a model for
label: Paragraph

text: the ostentatiously out-of-scale chimney in Venturi’s Beach House project, a pred-
label: Paragraph

text: ecessor of his early designs for the Mother’s House (before this element was trans-
label: Paragraph

text: formed into the more modest version of the executed building).”* Moreover, like
label: Paragraph

text: tract houses in places like Levittown (which became the object of study in one of
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi’s and Scott Brown’s co-taught research studios at Yale University in
label: Paragraph

text: 1970),”* the Vanna Venturi House features a number of decorative ornamentations
label: Paragraph

text: such as the moldings around the windows, the arch above the entrance, or the cor-
label: Paragraph

text: nice-like element that girdles the house at the level of the windowsills. Another
label: Paragraph

text: popular element is the color: originally painted taupe gray (in itself a statement
label: Paragraph

text: for the “grays” as opposed to the “whites” in contemporary architectural
label: Paragraph

text: discourse),”’ Venturi had the house repainted in green, apparently (and provoca-
label: Paragraph

text: tively) reacting to a statement by modernist architect Marcel Breuer that this color
label: Paragraph

text: was to be avoided.”®
label: Paragraph

text: These architectural references demonstrate Venturi’s extraordinary erudition as
label: Paragraph

text: a practitioner of a learned and reflexive architecture. It has been pointed out that his
label: Paragraph

text: pronounced knowledge of and interest in architectural history must be seen as a
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of his exposure to the so-called “Princeton System” as an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: student in the late 1940s and early 1950s. In a then seemingly antiquated educa-
label: Paragraph

text: tional model, Princeton University’s School of Architecture kept affording the
label: Paragraph

text: study of art and architectural history substantial attention, making it a singular
label: Paragraph

text: stronghold among major American educational institutions in the Beaux-Arts tra-
label: Paragraph

text: dition and against Bauhaus-influx.”” However, the various references to modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and the International Style pointed out earlier also indicate that the
label: Paragraph

text: prevalent evaluation of postmodern architecture as dogmatically opposing mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernism cannot be upheld. As Venturi’s architecture demonstrates, postmodernism
label: Paragraph

text: should better be understood as a revisionist critique from within the tenets of mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernism that a radical break with it. Venturi’s architecture and the Mother’s House
label: Paragraph

text: borrow from many, historically widely diverging sources. This indicates that the
label: Paragraph

text: architect is really not interested in favoring a specific historical period or style
label: Paragraph

text: (which would make him an epigone or a copyist), but rather in certain formal char-
label: Paragraph

text: acteristics of architectural features from throughout history, including the recent
label: Paragraph

text: past, that allow for an ambiguous reading.
label: Paragraph

text: Media Age Architecture
label: Title

text: Ifthe Vanna Venturi House can be seen as an exhibition of architectural styles and
label: Paragraph

text: histories, it is perhaps less important for the evaluation of its importance to metic-
label: Paragraph

text: ulously chart the numerous individual sources. Rather, the historical significance of
label: Paragraph

text: the building and its design method lies in the ready availability of visual historical
label: Paragraph

text: reference of (almost) any kind. Seen this way, the Vanna Venturi House is a striking
label: Paragraph

text: example of a media age architecture, a product of the era of reproducibility. Its
label: Paragraph

text: author received his architectural and aesthetic training through photographic
label: Paragraph

text: reproductions of buildings, and his own work is a fragmentary but conscious recon-
label: Paragraph

text: struction based on a selection of these mentally stored images. To a certain degree,
label: Paragraph

text: the characteristic museification of historical and contemporary architectural fea-
label: Paragraph

text: tures in Venturi’s building may be compared to examples of historicist architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture.” However, if architects of the late nineteenth century had still striven for
label: Paragraph

text: relative stylistic unity and had remained within an exclusively “high” architecture
label: Paragraph

text: register, the postmodern practitioner is characteristically liberated from any such
label: Paragraph

text: constrictions, having potentially at his or her disposal the imagery of the entire —
label: Paragraph

text: Western, but increasingly global — visual culture. As the Vanna Venturi House
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrates, the architect’s role goes much beyond the mere “select and arrange”
label: Paragraph

text: of readily available visual elements; his task is to bring them into a meaningful
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement. Needless to say, practices of citation and borrowing have been pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ent throughout architectural history, as evidenced, for example, in the use of spoils
label: Paragraph

text: from antiquity to modernity. Even seemingly iconoclastic modern architects such
label: Paragraph

text: as Mies van der Rohe or Le Corbusier have been shown to more or less explicitly
label: Paragraph

text: digest and cannibalize historical references such as Schinkel’s Berlin classicism or
label: Paragraph

text: Palladio’s mannerism.”? In postwar and postmodern architecture however, this
label: Paragraph

text: practice becomes a fundamental epistemological operation in that the broken rela-
label: Paragraph

text: tionship to the past is ostentatiously reflected. Postmodern architecture produces
label: Paragraph

text: meaning by ambiguously paying tribute and marking irreverence to the — historical
label: Paragraph

text: or modernist — model at the same time.”°
label: Paragraph

text: The allusion to historical and vernacular models allows the architect to give a
label: Paragraph

text: building architectural as well as cultural meaning. Symbolic meaning in architecture
label: Paragraph

text: is indeed akey concern in the intellectual and built work of Venturi and Scott Brown,
label: Paragraph

text: and this aspect can again be traced back to and illustrated in the Mother’s House. Its
label: Paragraph

text: raison d’étre is, in architectural critic Paul Goldberger’s terms, “to explore the notion
label: Paragraph

text: of what a house means, both architecturally and culturally, in the society of the pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ent day.”’? Through the exaggerated scale of architectural elements such as the
label: Paragraph

text: gable or the chimney discussed, the building evokes a “general domestic symbol-
label: Paragraph

text: >? and visually plays upon the very — culturally transported — idea of a house.
label: Paragraph

text: As Venturi explicates in Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture: “The front, in its
label: Paragraph

text: conventional combinations of door, windows, chimney and gable, creates an almost
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic image of a house.””’ Scully, among others, rightly pointed to the fact the
label: Paragraph

text: Vanna Venturi House strongly resembled the “ur-dwelling as a child would draw
label: Paragraph

text: it,”** an impression that is confirmed not only by the strong visual invocation of
label: Paragraph

text: the symbolic elements of a house, but also by Venturi’s own drawings.
label: Paragraph

text: If the visual rhetoric of the house thus contributes toward a theoretical discourse
label: Paragraph

text: on the primordial beginnings of architecture in the tradition of Marc-Antoine
label: Paragraph

text: Laugier and others, in turn the exaggerated scale of various elements in both
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior and the interior are reminiscent of the technique of blow-up and other
label: Paragraph

text: strategies of de-familiarization employed by contemporary pop art. These artistic
label: Paragraph

text: devices aimed at giving fresh and unexpected meaning to ordinary, often over-
label: Paragraph

text: looked objects.”” As Stanislaus von Moos has pointed out, this strategy leads to
label: Paragraph

text: a “built gap” in the buildings of Venturi and Scott Brown: the observer is aware
label: Paragraph

text: of the difference between the historical and vernacular sources on the one hand
label: Paragraph

text: and their contemporary interpretation on the other. The architects’ stance is not
label: Paragraph

text: that of simple identification with the past or historicist make-believe, but of ironical
label: Paragraph

text: distanciation. It is repetition, but with a difference.** This is the meaning and poten-
label: Paragraph

text: tial of irony in postmodernist architecture: it should not be mistaken as mere for-
label: Paragraph

text: mal fun in the sense of anything goes, but quite on the contrary be understood as a
label: Paragraph

text: way to signal that the postmodern condition no longer allows a direct or innocent
label: Paragraph

text: appropriation of history, modernity, and popular culture. The architect’s and
label: Paragraph

text: ism
label: Title

text: artist’s prime cultural and aesthetic task is to visually represent the broken and trou-
label: Paragraph

text: bled relationship of his/her historical and cultural situation vis-a-vis the past and
label: Paragraph

text: society at large. The technique of defamiliarization and the ensuing ironical stance
label: Paragraph

text: may also be seen as an instance of an “allegorical” use of imagery in a postmod-
label: Paragraph

text: ernist vein as described by art critic and theorist Craig Owens.”
label: Paragraph

text: American Suburbia and Its Discontents
label: Title

text: Given that the conspicuously exaggerated architectural elements of the Vanna
label: Paragraph

text: Venturi House symbolize the very idea of the American dwelling, they also com-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, whether consciously or not, on the American dream of life in a single-family
label: Paragraph

text: house. Books like Richard Yates’ Revolutionary Road (1961) had already tarnished this
label: Paragraph

text: ideal by addressing the stifling conformity this way of life imposed, especially on
label: Paragraph

text: women. It is therefore not surprising that Vincent Scully, reflecting upon the famous
label: Paragraph

text: photograph showing Vanna Venturi sitting in the entrance of her house, has inter-
label: Caption

text: preted the building as an “anti-heroic and feminist” gesture against the “macho pre-
label: Paragraph

text: tensions of architects” prevailing in the 1960s, and even not without pathos, “a
label: Paragraph

text: harbinger of healthier things to come.”** In a similar vein, Alice T. Friedman has
label: Paragraph

text: commented on the house as follows:
label: Paragraph

text: ...there was something peculiar and unsettling about the look of the oversimplified
label: Paragraph

text: gable and the flat wall surface with all those architectural spare parts stuck onto it.
label: Paragraph

text: Such an image of a suburban home — an image simultaneously comforting in its sim-
label: Paragraph

text: plicity and jarring in its disjunctive complexity — could easily be read as an ironic com-
label: Paragraph

text: mentary not simply on the traditions and language of architecture, but also on the
label: Paragraph

text: American dream of life in a suburban, single-family home. ...Thus, while Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: himself may not have wanted to focus on such a reading, there is no doubt that these
label: Paragraph

text: themes constituted a significant part of the meaning of his works in their time.””
label: Paragraph

text: Seen in this way, the Mother’s House was an architectural swan song to an increas-
label: Paragraph

text: ingly obsolete way of life, but one with an emancipatory and liberating tune.
label: Paragraph

text: From the very beginning, Venturi intended it to be a built manifesto of his archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural theory and thinking. As noted, the house was conceived in parallel to the
label: Paragraph

text: writing of Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture, where it was not only ana-
label: Paragraph

text: lyzed in detail in the last chapter of the book (besides other early works and pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects). It was also presented as a quintessential object embodying the notion of a
label: Paragraph

text: complex and contradictory architecture, along with its principle features of
label: Paragraph

text: “ambiguity,” “both-and,” conventionality (as well as its transgression), or the dia-
label: Paragraph

text: lectics between inside and outside, while remaining true to the “obligation toward
label: Paragraph

text: the difficult whole”; a whole generated by the dialectical interrelationship and con-
label: Paragraph

text: tradictory tension between competing elements. Thus, Venturi describes his early
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece as being:
label: Paragraph

text: both complex and simple, open and close, big and little; some of its elements are
label: Paragraph

text: good on one level and bad on another; its order accommodates the generic elements
label: Paragraph

text: of the house in general, and the circumstantial elements of a house in particular. It
label: Paragraph

text: achieves the difficult unite of a medium number of diverse parts rather than the easy
label: Paragraph

text: unity of few or many motival parts.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Significantly, Venturi’s verbal interpretation was at least as important as the building
label: Paragraph

text: itself for the dissemination of his ideas in contemporary architectural discourse. In fact,
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and literature, building and text from the beginning formed a complex
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid, a multimedia hypertext, as it were, and are hardly thinkable without one
label: Paragraph

text: another. The Vanna Venturi House exists as much in the medium of the text as it does
label: Paragraph

text: in the form ofa built structure. Venturi’s “text” was potentially “open” in the sense of
label: Paragraph

text: the Italian semiotician Umberto Eco’s theory of signification in the contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: work of art, according to which meaning cannot be found in the work itself, but in
label: Paragraph

text: its “communicative structures,” that is, in the way the viewer or reader is addressed.**
label: Paragraph

text: In the case of the Vanna Venturi House, its author acted as its prime reader, and
label: Paragraph

text: through time, supplied a number of competing interpretations. In his first publication
label: Paragraph

text: of the house in 1965, Venturi stressed its “pop” dimension, emphasizing the conven-
label: Paragraph

text: tional aspects of the building, and defining the architect’s role as that ofa “combiner of
label: Paragraph

text: old clichés ... in new contexts.”“” In Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture, he cited
label: Paragraph

text: it as a model for a “mannerist” architecture. In his 1982 “postscript,” the architect
label: Paragraph

text: underlined the “classical” dimension of the house. Finally, in his “Mother’s House
label: Paragraph

text: 25 Years Later,” written on the occasion of the publication of the monograph dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to the design of the house, Venturi reread it as a predecessor of postmodernism and
label: Paragraph

text: focused in particular on the symbolic dimension of his architecture. And he added:
label: Paragraph

text: “That I saw and explained the house differently then from now is not a bad thing;
label: Paragraph

text: it means its architecture has dimensions and makes sense from several perspectives.”
label: Paragraph

text: To underline the “openness” of a work of art is one thing; but Venturi’s shifting
label: Paragraph

text: interpretations could also be seen as a strategic move to inscribe his creation with
label: Paragraph

text: new meaning and signification according to changing moods in architectural dis-
label: Paragraph

text: course. There is nothing wrong in that: it demonstrates that the modern (and perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: more so, the postmodern) architect has to be as clever in managing media and publicity
label: Paragraph

text: as in mastering the art of building or organizing space. Ifthe Vanna Venturi House has
label: Paragraph

text: become an icon in the history of modern architecture, it is thus both for its indisputable
label: Paragraph

text: spatial and formal qualities as well as its author’s insight that architecture, in the age of
label: Paragraph

text: technical reproducibility, has more than ever become a form of discourse.
label: Paragraph
