text: HARD-WON CALM
label: Title

text: The feeling that our present-day architecture needs embellishment stems in part
label: Paragraph

text: from our tendency to fair joints out of existence — in other words, to conceal how
label: Paragraph

text: parts are put together. If we were to train ourselves to draw as we build, from
label: Paragraph

text: the bottom up, stopping our pencils at the joints of pouring or erecting, ornament
label: Paragraph

text: would evolve out of our love for the perfection of construction and we would
label: Paragraph

text: develop new methods of construction. It would follow that the pasting on of lighting
label: Paragraph

text: and acoustical material, the burying of tortured unwanted ducts, conduits, and pipe-
label: Paragraph

text: lines would become intolerable. How it was done, how it works, should filter
label: Paragraph

text: through the entire process of building, to architect, engineer, builder, and craftsman
label: Paragraph

text: in the trades.’
label: Paragraph

text: Little wonder arguments over Louis I. Kahn collect along the centerline of the
label: Caption

text: Salk Institute, as though debate surrounding his truer intentions might somehow
label: Paragraph

text: ? “Kahn was involved
label: Title

text: solely with the physical experience of physical form: with Empathy, though he did
label: Paragraph

text: not call it that,” Vincent Scully wrote, 12 years after Kahn’s death.’ Kahn’s empathy
label: Paragraph

text: is rarely contested, though the words he used to express it often are — for example,
label: Paragraph

text: his famously having asked bricks what they “want to be.”* What scholars seem to
label: Paragraph

text: disagree about most is the source of Kahn’s empathy — what it meant in practice,
label: Paragraph

text: influence the physical sensation of standing in its courtyard.
label: Paragraph

text: how it shaped his approach to problems of architectural form, and what those
label: Paragraph

text: forms contribute to our understanding of modernity and “the haunting sorrows
label: Paragraph

text: of twentieth century experience.”
label: Paragraph

text: For the 50 years since its completion, the Salk Institute has served not only as a
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory for the study of biological science, which continues to thrive; it has also
label: Paragraph

text: served as a laboratory for the study of modern architectural history and theory,
label: Paragraph

text: which leverages the building’s magnetism in their evolving assessments of form,
label: Paragraph

text: function, technology, and representation. Yet as well traveled a topic as Salk is,
label: Paragraph

text: there are many ways of doing it justice.° This chapter will further explore these
label: Paragraph

text: themes through Kahn’s approach to construction, in particular his use of concrete,
label: Paragraph

text: which Adrian Forty describes as “a process rather than a material,” a property befit-
label: Paragraph

text: ting both Salk’s client and its program.”
label: Paragraph

text: As always, material specificity presupposes a context. Most architectural his-
label: Paragraph

text: torians agree that Salk was a significant turning point in Kahn’s practice, if not
label: Paragraph

text: his first fully mature or even greatest built work.* The Salk commission
label: Caption

text: sprang from his design for the Richards Medical Research Laboratories at
label: Paragraph

text: the University of Pennsylvania (1957-65). Scully called Richards “one of the
label: Paragraph

text: greatest buildings of modern times”; he credits Kahn with finally breaking
label: Paragraph

text: “the mental barrier which the International Modern Style has set up between
label: Paragraph

text: the present and the past.” In 1962, the Museum of Modern Art anointed Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: with an exhibition devoted solely to Richards, celebrating a “new synthesis” of
label: Paragraph

text: modern structure and enclosure that boldly rhymed the composition of its
label: Paragraph

text: taut brick-clad utility towers with the profile of San Gimignano — neither imi-
label: Paragraph

text: tating historical form nor even alluding to it so much as expressing its recom-
label: Paragraph

text: binant potential in a freshly contemporary, situated language.’° Its confident
label: Paragraph

text: break with ahistorical orthodoxy opened up conceptual space for Salk, which
label: Paragraph

text: firmly established the modern archaism that distinguishes Kahn’s later projects
label: Paragraph

text: from all the rest.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn worked on Salk from 1959 to 1965. The laboratories command a vivid, 27-
label: Paragraph

text: acre coastal site surrounding a deep, T-shaped ravine in the Torrey Pines mesa,
label: Paragraph

text: high above Black’s Beach.’' In plan, two symmetrical wings delimit a central
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard, a kind of open-air nave. Serrating the edge of the central space are
label: Paragraph

text: 10 freestanding four-story towers, five per side, walls splayed west toward the
label: Caption

text: Pacific view. Each wing houses three laboratories, each row of towers houses
label: Paragraph

text: 18 private studies (four per tower save the easternmost, which house two). Despite
label: Caption

text: the subsequent construction of adjacent institute facilities, the original building
label: Paragraph

text: continues to hold its own, attracting hundreds of visitors every month.
label: Paragraph

text: The world identifies Salk by its central courtyard, which critics variously
label: Paragraph

text: describe as “sublime,” “iconic,” “rigorist,” even “dangerous.”! The souvenir
label: Paragraph

text: perspective of this space typically positions viewfinders at a station point near Salk’s
label: Paragraph

text: east entry, square between the laboratory wings. Sightlines track the water
label: Caption

text: channel, which ribbons down the full length of the courtyard into a reflecting pool
label: Paragraph

text: on its far western edge, barely visible — beyond that, a stubble of California
label: Paragraph

text: chaparral; beyond that, the blue Pacific expanse; beyond that, sky.
label: Paragraph

text: Jonas Salk was “the most impressive intellectual Kahn ever had as a client.
label: Paragraph

text: Salk’s inactivated poliovirus vaccine helped to end a terrifying nationwide polio
label: Paragraph

text: epidemic, and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, sponsor of the March
label: Paragraph

text: of Dimes, offered to fund an independent lab. Salk called Kahn in December 1959
label: Paragraph

text: to seek his advice on the choice of an architect for his new facility.‘ Quickly recog-
label: Paragraph

text: nizing Kahn’s native hospitality to his own code, Salk issued just two instructions
label: Paragraph

text: after offering him the commission: first, he needed about 100,000 ft’, roughly the
label: Paragraph

text: size of Richards; second, he wanted to invite Picasso to the laboratory.”
label: Paragraph

text: Salk’s mental picture of the project grew out of his experience at the monastery
label: Paragraph

text: of St. Francis Assisi, which he visited during a retreat in Italy in the 1950s. Later,
label: Paragraph

text: Salk and Kahn discussed monastery architecture as a model for the new institute. “I
label: Paragraph

text: remembered the cloister there and I conveyed to Kahn the idea that this is what
label: Paragraph

text: I would like — the cloistered garden,” Salk recalled. “It became the court ... The
label: Paragraph

text: studies then grew, evolved, and developed along the sides of the laboratories, like
label: Paragraph

text: a necklace strung along a building, and provided the basis for the colonnade.””°
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn recorded his interpretation of these preliminary conversations in an early
label: Paragraph

text: (undated) exploratory drawing, clearly rendering a small but unmistakable sketch
label: Caption

text: of the site elevation of the Basilica of St. Francis, which he annotated with the word
label: Paragraph

text: v1
label: Title

text: “Assisi.”’” Opposite this, he drew another tiny sketch of a rectangular courtyard over-
label: Paragraph

text: looking landscape and horizon, bounded on the right by four arcaded bays reminiscent
label: Paragraph

text: of the basilica’s cloister; the sheet also clearly adumbrates Kahn’s plan to distribute
label: Paragraph

text: three discrete elements — a lab with a courtyard, a circular meeting house, and court-
label: Paragraph

text: yard housing — wrapped around the ravine. Despite these forms, no prior architecture
label: Paragraph

text: or building type — monastery, cloister, campanile, or piazza — distracted Kahn from
label: Paragraph

text: what he called “Volume Zero ... a search for the sense of beginning.”’” It was both
label: Paragraph

text: his habit of mind and his methodology to seek out the beginnings of “laboratory,”
label: Paragraph

text: which in the case of Salk conflated both religious and secular antecedents.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn regarded programs with disdain. “The program is nothing,” he said; the
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s “first act” is “to ... change it’.’? Programs hindered the search for a
label: Paragraph

text: “realm of spaces” that ennobles both human activity and institution, which room
label: Paragraph

text: schedules, area requirements, and conventional building standards obscure.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s way of engaging type resides nearer to Plato and Quatremére de Quincy
label: Paragraph

text: than Nicholas Pevsner — he searched for “something fundamental and
label: Paragraph

text: irreducible,” as Michael Merrill notes, “a germ or starting point” strong enough
label: Paragraph

text: to drive pragmatic design, yet poetically supple, “vague and uncertain’ enough
label: Paragraph

text: to invite invention and change.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn notoriously expanded programs beyond the client’s budget, which often
label: Paragraph

text: resulted in incomplete or lost commissions — the Dominican Motherhouse, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, or the Fort Wayne Fine Arts Center and the campus of the Philadelphia
label: Paragraph

text: University of the Arts, among other projects.” In the case of Salk, Kahn took his
label: Paragraph

text: client’s simple instructions — “make me a laboratory congenial to art” — and
label: Paragraph

text: tripled its scope, adding the aforementioned meeting house and housing for fel-
label: Paragraph

text: lows. Sometime during the early phase of schematic design, Kahn produced an
label: Paragraph

text: undated handwritten brief that his office staff transcribed into a double-spaced
label: Paragraph

text: typewritten draft.”* The buildings “are to serve the science of Biology and
label: Paragraph

text: men as men aware of their total being,” he wrote, “a place for men in the arts
label: Paragraph

text: and letters and men in this particular science ... where Question is always pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ent.”** Salk’s indulgence of Kahn’s expanded brief doubtless reflected their
label: Paragraph

text: shared vision for an institute that reunified what in 1959 C. P. Snow famously
label: Paragraph

text: described as the “two cultures” of science and the humanities, cleft by modernity
label: Paragraph

text: into a “gulf of mutual incomprehension.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Less than nine months after the start of the construction of the laboratories,
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn signed an amendment to his original contract effectively terminating work
label: Paragraph

text: on housing and the meeting house, one of Kahn’s most celebrated unbuilt works.”*
label: Caption

text: Thereafter these components remained “in statu nascendi,” as Jonas Salk later noted
label: Paragraph

text: — “neither denied nor dismissed.”*” Whether or not the cessation of work on the
label: Paragraph

text: meeting house and residences influenced Kahn’s final design for the courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: remains a matter of speculation. Two years after the start of construction, the cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tral court contained nothing but “mud pits.””* Apocryphal stories crowd the history
label: Paragraph

text: of the final design as built. Kahn invited the renowned Mexican modernist Luis
label: Paragraph

text: Barragan to visit La Jolla and talk with him about the central space, which he
label: Paragraph

text: previously drew and modeled as a garden.”° “I told him at first sight ... ‘not one
label: Paragraph

text: leaf,” Barragan recalled, “nor plant, nor one flower, nor dirt. Absolutely nothing.””*°
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s first iteration for the laboratory had been a throwaway, a tower complex
label: Paragraph

text: featuring gear-shaped ancillary structures, which Salk rejected outright, perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: because it echoed Richards. The second scheme introduced four, parallel, two-story
label: Paragraph

text: wings framing two arcaded, poplar-lined courtyards. August Komendant, Kahn’s
label: Caption

text: engineer for Richards, worked with Kahn to design an innovative system of folded
label: Paragraph

text: plates and box girders that freed the labs of columns. The resulting servant spaces for
label: Paragraph

text: each lab featured accessible and adaptable story-high mechanical spaces. Salk ini-
label: Paragraph

text: tially accepted this version and signed a contract for construction, only to abandon
label: Paragraph

text: the design the next day, fearing its plan would foster competition between “A-court”
label: Paragraph

text: and “B-court” scientists.’” During this unexpected pause, the contractor tried to per-
label: Paragraph

text: suade the funders to substitute a less expensive steel-frame structure, but Salk and
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn resisted.*” With Komendant’s help, Kahn proposed column-free lab space
label: Paragraph

text: using concrete Vierendeel trusses, which they had successfully employed at
label: Paragraph

text: Richards. The depth of the Vierendeels provided even greater flexibility for the
label: Paragraph

text: maintenance and modification of specialized laboratory services — ducts, pipes,
label: Paragraph

text: vents, valves, and sensors controlling all of the varieties of liquid, gas, water, air,
label: Paragraph

text: and waste flowing in and out of bench work over the daily course of research. Salk
label: Paragraph

text: read Kahn’s building design in physiological terms: “The laboratories and studio
label: Paragraph

text: [carry] the cerebral function; the service spaces [carry] the arteries, veins, and nerv-
label: Paragraph

text: ous system; the mechanical [spaces act] as the respiratory system ... each integral.”*?
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn in turn incorporated Salk’s analogy to describe the story-high volume between
label: Paragraph

text: labs: “It all comes from what Dr. Salk called the mesenchyme space,” he explained;
label: Paragraph

text: “one serves the body, and one is the body itself.”** Concrete prevailed.
label: Paragraph

text: For the third and final version of the laboratories, Kahn modified the four-
label: Paragraph

text: building design, compressing its program into two, mirrored laboratory wings
label: Paragraph

text: flanking a single, central garden. He paired labs and mechanical floors and stacked
label: Paragraph

text: them three high — six stories total — but to preserve the scale of the courtyard he
label: Paragraph

text: drove the lower two stories below the courtyard level, lighting them with sunken,
label: Paragraph

text: brick-paved patios open to the sky. This deep, richly layered, shaded arcade lines
label: Paragraph

text: the north and south edge of the central court, further enriching the spatiality of its
label: Paragraph

text: edges. He located the studies on the same level as the mechanical floors, preserving
label: Paragraph

text: the courtyard and upper two laboratory levels for the arcade and open porches.
label: Caption

text: The cantilevered slabs of the middle and upper level mechanical floors supply both
label: Paragraph

text: circulation and shade to the glass-enclosed labs; open concrete stairways and
label: Paragraph

text: bridges connect the freestanding studies with laboratory walkways.
label: Paragraph

text: All of the building’s paired and overlapping elements — structure, enclosure, cir-
label: Paragraph

text: culation, view, orientation, even drainage — converge here, in the parallactic voids
label: Paragraph

text: between the labs and the studies, dilating circulation and layering up space — “fold-
label: Paragraph

text: ing it, capsizing it, doubling it”? The strong California sun washing Salk’s taut
label: Paragraph

text: concrete surfaces give these passageways the character of an abstract, syncopated
label: Paragraph

text: chiaroscuro. Whether in section or plan, twos tumble into threes: two wings
label: Paragraph

text: consist of three laboratories, each with two floors (pipe space over bench space,
label: Paragraph

text: servant and served); mirror-wise across the building’s centerline, labs adjoin studies
label: Paragraph

text: adjoining the plaza adjoining studies adjoining labs, A-B-C-B-A.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Second only to the central courtyard in significance is Kahn’s mastery of con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete. “When you look at Salk,” Komendant observed after its completion, “you
label: Paragraph

text: unhesitatingly answer that it could not have been built in any other material.”’”
label: Paragraph

text: Although no other major project by Kahn staked so much on concrete, he had
label: Paragraph

text: worked with it throughout his career.’* During World War II, Kahn proposed con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete as a suitable material for mass housing, which he revisited after the war in
label: Paragraph

text: projects designed for the Israeli Housing Survey Committee (1949).”” In the con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete tetrahedral ceiling for the Yale University Art Gallery (1951-53), Kahn clearly
label: Caption

text: loosened the early binds of his ill-fitting interwar and postwar architectural vocab-
label: Paragraph

text: ularies, bringing him closer to what his associate Anne Griswold Tyng calls “the
label: Paragraph

text: realization of [a] more profound truth [in] three dimensional geometry.”*° Yale
label: Paragraph

text: is “perhaps the first of Kahn’s works,” Joseph Rykwert observes, “in which concrete
label: Paragraph

text: cast in smooth plywood shuttering becomes the dominant material of the
label: Paragraph

text: building.”*”
label: Paragraph

text: On January 10, 1963, a week before he released the full architectural package to
label: Paragraph

text: the contractors, Kahn laid of piece of yellow tracing paper over a blueline print of
label: Paragraph

text: a hardline drawing of the proposed elevation of the easternmost retaining wall,
label: Caption

text: located below grade in Salk’s mechanical room, beneath the entrance garden.”
label: Paragraph

text: The mechanical room was the first space built, and Kahn and Salk, along with
label: Paragraph

text: project architect Fred Langford, hoped to use its first wall as a test bed for what
label: Paragraph

text: Langford described as “print block” formwork, pours that took the shape of a
label: Paragraph

text: huge running bond brick pattern defined by a specific “imprint.’*’ This wall
label: Paragraph

text: memorializes Kahn’s experimental joint details, which he later rejected — too
label: Paragraph

text: big, too inelegant; the wall still bears Kahn’s sketches of alternative solutions,
label: Paragraph

text: which he drew in red china marker directly on the surface of the concrete.** Jonas
label: Paragraph

text: Salk was enthusiastic about this record of experimentation and closely inspected
label: Paragraph

text: the results.*? He recalled having initially disliked the color, whereupon he
label: Paragraph

text: pressed Kahn to create something “warm and alive ... something that looked like
label: Paragraph

text: man-made marble.”*°
label: Paragraph

text: An atypical four-page single-spaced memo from Kahn’s office to Salk’s general
label: Caption

text: contractor, Fervor & Dorland, dated April 5, 1963, captures the intensity of
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s approach to concrete. In this memo, project architect Fred Langford reg-
label: Paragraph

text: isters urgent concern over the quality and control of the concrete formwork.
label: Paragraph

text: Langford states that his purpose is to remedy the “contention ... between Builder
label: Paragraph

text: and Architect in the area of form work design” and “explain the construction
label: Paragraph

text: process as an architectural expression’; he notes that arguments over the design
label: Paragraph

text: of the formwork have persisted “since the beginning of this job” and warns that
label: Paragraph

text: “conventional attitudes will produce a conventional building.”*” However, noth-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in this careful delineation of process and effect prepares the reader for his
label: Paragraph

text: concluding paragraph:
label: Title

text: We must make the concrete in this building say “I am expressive of the hands and
label: Paragraph

text: forms that held me in place until I could grasp my inner steel and gain the strength
label: Paragraph

text: and power that I now possess; that I must possess to hold back the tremendous earth
label: Paragraph

text: pressures with my retaining walls, to span the laboratories in a single leap, to lift the
label: Paragraph

text: studies to the grand view of the sea, and still be friendly enough to touch with human
label: Paragraph

text: hands.” All this should contribute to the total architecture that we believe will
label: Paragraph

text: encourage and provide productive research and discovery at the Salk Institute.
label: Paragraph

text: “Architects are responsible for mediating concrete to us, for causing it to be seen
label: Paragraph

text: in one way rather than another,” Adrian Forty writes, which helps explain why in
label: Paragraph

text: this memo Langford articulates emphatically precise instructions for every detail of
label: Paragraph

text: the formwork — how and why its polyurethane coated plywood panels, expendable
label: Paragraph

text: parting strips, hydrostatic relief valves, bleed lines, corners and panel junctures,
label: Paragraph

text: wall ties, shrinkage joints, and pour line chamfers constitute “a record of the con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction process” and “produce an architecture where the construction process is
label: Paragraph

text: expressed honestly.”“* Langford and Kahn tested more than a dozen different con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete mixtures looking for a precise color, “something warmer, russet ... warm
label: Paragraph

text: brown tones, not blue or green.”” Kahn later explained, “When you’re making
label: Paragraph

text: something you must consult nature, like the conversation with the brick. And
label: Paragraph

text: you can make the same conversation with concrete.””°
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s January 1963 sketch of formwork provides insight into the nature of this
label: Paragraph

text: “conversation.” He develops the drawing in graphite on yellow tracing paper, as
label: Paragraph

text: was his habit. He positions the wall in the space of a gentle single-point perspective,
label: Paragraph

text: lightly delineates its elevation, and then floats disembodied section cuts of form-
label: Paragraph

text: work details in the space between the wall and the picture plane. He renders
label: Paragraph

text: the thickness of concrete in red and yellow colored pencil, reserving yellow for
label: Paragraph

text: the horizontal slab that divides the two floors depicted in this view, but draws only
label: Paragraph

text: enough thickness to show the relation between the assembly of the seams of the
label: Paragraph

text: formwork and the shape and form of the concrete joint. In addition to dimensions
label: Paragraph

text: and alternative details, Kahn visualizes the problem of the construction not through
label: Paragraph

text: strictly rational or quantitative analysis, but through a kind of analogical reasoning —
label: Paragraph

text: reasoning through resemblances — that incorporates the graphic equivalent of
label: Paragraph

text: figures of speech and tropes including spatial depth, human figures, and shadows.
label: Paragraph

text: The theoretical site of this drawing is the union of formwork and concrete. The
label: Paragraph

text: drawing explores early designs for the construction of the “parting strips” described
label: Paragraph

text: by Langford in his April 1963 memo to the contractors. Kahn explores a V-shaped
label: Paragraph

text: joint routed into the wood junctures between panels, and also the formwork detail-
label: Paragraph

text: ing for an inset marble base he intended to employ in the meeting house. His anal-
label: Paragraph

text: ysis of this joint documents two interdependent conditions, which he labels
label: Paragraph

text: “projection” and “indenture,” male and female. His annotation in the lower right
label: Paragraph

text: hand corner of the drawing documents their interdependency: “the projection as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the indenture expresses the joint.”*’ He uses both a positive and negative
label: Paragraph

text: application of the V detail, opposing then coupling protrusion and incision.
label: Paragraph

text: Here we can clearly see Kahn drawing ornament out of the methods of con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction, “stopping [his] pencil to make a mark at the joints of pouring or erect-
label: Paragraph

text: ing.””*
label: Paragraph

text: between cladding and structure, which converge into a surface unity condi-
label: Paragraph

text: He intends to leave the concrete exposed, eliminating the distinction
label: Paragraph

text: tioned only by internal material properties activated at the point where those
label: Paragraph

text: properties meet their limit — first in the darkness, against the formwork, then
label: Paragraph

text: in the sunlight, when the formwork is removed. “The way things are made,
label: Paragraph

text: the way they are put together, the way one thing comes to the other, is the
label: Paragraph

text: place where ornament begins,” Kahn says. “It is the glory of the joint which
label: Paragraph

text: is the beginning of ornament.”’? He uses seams to gather the material of the
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon-building and the lineaments of the idea-building into a single detail
label: Paragraph

text: of construction.”
label: Paragraph

text: Like other mid-century modern architects closely scrutinized by Kahn — Mies
label: Paragraph

text: van der Rohe and especially Le Corbusier — Kahn eschews capriciously additive
label: Paragraph

text: embellishment. Instead, he works through the process of construction to create
label: Paragraph

text: surface effects that are simultaneously intrinsic and extrinsic to the body of the
label: Paragraph

text: wall. The raised single and double fillets order other formwork details in the walls
label: Caption

text: of Salk, which together comprise a deeply-thought surface vocabulary: smooth
label: Paragraph

text: planarity left by polyurethane-coated plywood panels; thousands of blow holes,
label: Paragraph

text: the minor “imperfections caused by air bubbles in the liquid concrete”; ”’ slight
label: Paragraph

text: variations in color; the tie rod holes, precisely spaced and filled with lead plugs;
label: Paragraph

text: and the spacing and impressions of other formwork elements, where walls end
label: Paragraph

text: and turn corners and where pouring starts and stops. These raised fillets and the
label: Paragraph

text: other impressions and marks of construction both finish the wall and brighten it,
label: Paragraph

text: as though “a form of auxiliary light.””° The raised fillets catch the strong sun and
label: Paragraph

text: cast a sharp shadow, and by so doing order and delineate both the decorum of the
label: Paragraph

text: emerging institution and the decorum of modern construction. These surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: condition Salk’s luminosity and spatial power: one without the other results in
label: Paragraph

text: neither.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the aggregate effect is, strictly speaking, artificial, chance irregularities
label: Paragraph

text: are “natural” to poured-in-place concrete and its processes: the size and distribution
label: Paragraph

text: of air pockets and cavities, say, or the “broken edges [and] abrasive textures” of the
label: Paragraph

text: protrusions and impressions designed into the formwork — aleatory occurrences, a
label: Paragraph

text: kind of planned unpredictability."” As Thomas Leslie notes, concrete is “a risky
label: Paragraph

text: material when exposed, as its ... appearance and finish are dependent on processes
label: Paragraph

text: that are irreversible, hidden from view until complete, and sensitive to a range of
label: Paragraph

text: variables.””* Yet in so consciously seeking to fuse the problem of material and orna-
label: Paragraph

text: ment into a single act of construction — and so consciously seeking qualities equiv-
label: Paragraph

text: alent to “man-made marble” — Kahn clearly invests in ways to both reveal and
label: Paragraph

text: suppress concrete’s “roughness” or “raw truth,” not to mention his willful aban-
label: Paragraph

text: donment of its historically economic or pragmatic attributes. Here Kahn’s little
label: Paragraph

text: drawing may help to better distinguish his approach from others who likewise
label: Paragraph

text: seized on the potential of modern béton brute — Le Corbusier, for example, or Alison
label: Paragraph

text: and Peter Smithson and Paul Rudolph, among many others. As David Leatherbar-
label: Paragraph

text: row argues, “No material is essentially rough or smooth; these qualities depend as
label: Paragraph

text: much on the way the material is treated or finished as on its so-called inherent qua-
label: Paragraph

text: lities. This means that concern for a material’s qualities — let’s say its roughness — is
label: Paragraph

text: less important than interest in the conditions under which that quality becomes
label: Paragraph

text: apparent.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn seeks and finds convergence between the technical necessities of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: construction and the surplus benefits of tectonically derived ornamental lines. In
label: Paragraph

text: this respect, his assiduous attention to the design for the concrete walls of Salk cor-
label: Paragraph

text: relates with A. K. Coomaraswamy’s observation that in traditional culture orna-
label: Paragraph

text: ment derives not from anything inessential or surplus, but rather from the
label: Paragraph

text: principle of suitability, sufficiency, and fitness for use.°° Kahn achieves ornament
label: Paragraph

text: that is inherent in and moreover drawn from the material properties and require-
label: Paragraph

text: ments of concrete. Ornament, he says, “evolve[s] out of our love for the perfection
label: Paragraph

text: of construction.”*’ This love finds expression in Kahn’s fidelity to the essence of
label: Paragraph

text: material — what it “wants to be” — as a means to realize the architectural identity
label: Paragraph

text: of the Salk Institute, what it wants to be.
label: Paragraph

text: Of course, there is more to Kahn’s drawing than a wall. Three analogous bodies
label: Paragraph

text: populate his analysis of Salk’s formwork: the figure in the foreground, which holds
label: Paragraph

text: two books; the figure in the middle ground, striding; and, in the background, the
label: Paragraph

text: wall itself. Insofar as figures such as these do not typically inhabit analyses of con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction details, their prominent appearance in Kahn’s drawing suggest an analog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical and poetic framework for Kahn’s supposition, often repeated, that how-we-are-
label: Paragraph

text: made and how-to-make-the-wall constitute the same essential question.”
label: Paragraph

text: A fourth body inhabits Kahn’s picture: the sun. “The sun never knew how great
label: Paragraph

text: it was until it struck the side ofa building,” Kahn once said, paraphrasing the Amer-
label: Paragraph

text: ican poet Wallace Stevens.” Kahn is mindful that his subject is below grade, yet in
label: Paragraph

text: this rendering he washes it with sunlight. His underground sun casts a shadow off
label: Paragraph

text: the middle body onto the surface of the wall. This shadow has an odd complexion.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the shaft of an arrow, it rises out of the vertex of a V-shape formed by the right
label: Paragraph

text: arm of the foreground figure and the right leg of the background figure, which
label: Paragraph

text: intersect hand over calf. Kahn relieves his shadow of any obligation to the actual
label: Paragraph

text: posture and velocity of the body that casts it, giving it a conspicuous uprightness.
label: Paragraph

text: As a substance, this shadow-column oscillates between two conditions: light and
label: Paragraph

text: no light, surface and interior, both phallus and gnomon. Its tumescence supplies
label: Paragraph

text: what Marco Frascari would call “the index of corporeality.”** This shadow is
label: Paragraph

text: the central analogy of the drawing: it both doubles and fecundates the composition
label: Paragraph

text: of the wall. Walls form the way bodies form: “... two touches between boundaries
label: Paragraph

text: ... [which] are not the same,” in the words of Luce Irigaray: “the touch of one’s
label: Paragraph

text: body at the threshold; the touch of the contained other ...; the internal touch of
label: Paragraph

text: the body of the child.” An analogy is an “assimilating influence exerted by one
label: Paragraph

text: form on another.” The concrete is red, like cut flesh. “Red” alerts us to particular
label: Paragraph

text: substances and states — blood, fire, and heat. Kahn’s drawing reveals the cardinal
label: Paragraph

text: humor of the concrete. The building is alive, as Salk requested, like a body. It con-
label: Paragraph

text: sists of joints that demarcate the limits of bodily extension.
label: Paragraph

text: Donald Kunze once noted insightfully, “drawing equals whatever gets us from
label: Paragraph

text: one arrow to another.”®” In this drawing all arrows point to union, to the mystery
label: Paragraph

text: of the conjunction of three bodily limits. That odd-looking shadow indicates the
label: Paragraph

text: fusion of body and wall in the union of concrete and wood. Kahn’s drawing of this
label: Paragraph

text: coupling suggests a union between the constitution of the wall and the knowledge of
label: Paragraph

text: the wall, that is, knowledge of its means of becoming: light issuing forth from no
label: Paragraph

text: light. Among twentieth-century architects, we would not be going too far to iden-
label: Paragraph

text: tify Kahn as a “strong poet,” in the words of the literary critic Harold Bloom. “We
label: Paragraph

text: can define a strong poet,” Bloom writes, “as one who will not tolerate standing
label: Paragraph

text: between him and the Muse. But that means the strong poet in effect takes up
label: Paragraph

text: the stance of the Gnostic, ancestor of all major Western revisionists.”™*
label: Paragraph

text: “The novelty of Gnostic knowledge,” Giovanni Filoramo writes, “consists in its
label: Paragraph

text: need to fuse together not only subject and object, but also the means of [our]
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge [of them],”” three terms into one. In this remarkable construction
label: Paragraph

text: drawing for the first wall at Salk, Kahn records the “means of knowledge” not only
label: Paragraph

text: in his representation of the analogical intertwining of sun, flesh, and wall, but also
label: Paragraph

text: in his analogous projection of this vision across the whole institutional matrix of
label: Paragraph

text: Salk — as above, so below. Look at the ground level building in plan and divide
label: Paragraph

text: it along its centerline reading either left or right from the central runnel: Salk con-
label: Paragraph

text: sists of three elements — west lab, court, and south lab — within which reside the
label: Paragraph

text: triadic relationship between the lab, the studies, and the court.
label: Paragraph

text: The three primary bodies in this drawing correspond to these three domains.
label: Paragraph

text: This bookish gentleman in the foreground (who draws us into his speculation with
label: Paragraph

text: an oddly interrogative tilt of the head), suggests theoretical understanding, a won-
label: Paragraph

text: dering reflection or contemplation of extramundane principles. If in theory “draw-
label: Paragraph

text: ing equals whatever gets us from one arrow to another” — if an arrow’s job is to
label: Paragraph

text: point — then the space of the figure in the foreground points to the space of the
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard: empty, transcendent, open to the sky.
label: Paragraph

text: The middle figure is already underway, like Hermes (a go-between), moving to
label: Paragraph

text: and from possibilities located beyond the picture plane, translating the language of
label: Paragraph

text: theory into the language of practice. The space of the figure in the middle corre-
label: Paragraph

text: sponds to the space of the studies, which Kahn locates between the courtyard and
label: Paragraph

text: the laboratories.”” The model for the studies came from the Salk’s early references
label: Paragraph

text: to Assisi: he wanted the secular equivalent of monks’ cells — “thinking cells,” he
label: Paragraph

text: called them.”’ The activity of the studies is not prayer or meditation so much as
label: Paragraph

text: disciplined thought, which mediates between reflection and application. The stud-
label: Paragraph

text: ies house the space of ethics, properly speaking the space of practice, which decides
label: Paragraph

text: the right course of action for a given set of changing circumstances.
label: Paragraph

text: Lastly, beyond this middle figure, we see our telltale wall, in both strength and
label: Paragraph

text: delineation the analogy or projection of the logic of the bodies that stand in front of
label: Paragraph

text: it. Kahn’s wall suggests technical understanding — know-how, skill, and fabrication.
label: Paragraph

text: The wall corresponds to the space of the laboratories, where ethical scientists pro-
label: Paragraph

text: pelled by theoretical insight manipulate and modify the material properties of the
label: Paragraph

text: world.”” Consciously or unconsciously, the composition of Kahn’s construction
label: Paragraph

text: drawing is analogous to the composition of the Salk Institute itself.
label: Paragraph

text: But perhaps most compelling of all in this context are the floating, vaguely appa-
label: Paragraph

text: ritional figures of formwork details, which show us how to make the wall so that
label: Paragraph

text: the wall shows how it was made. To this demonstration of Kahn’s problem-solving
label: Paragraph

text: process I would adjoin Filoramo’s observation that gnosis is “the intuition of one’s
label: Paragraph

text: true nature”; gnostic insight “is not pure, disinterested contemplation,” Filoramo
label: Paragraph

text: notes, “but immersion in the vital, throbbing realities of origins, the ability to tune
label: Paragraph

text: into the divine energy.””
label: Paragraph

text: dimensions and form of the wall — its “character,” which results from the way
label: Paragraph

text: the formwork design and the hydrostatic properties and admixtures of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: converge in surface effects and lineaments — and also the way these effects create
label: Paragraph

text: and embody an analogous transaction between the wall and its perceiving subject,
label: Paragraph

text: who is likewise constituted both of measurable and unmeasurable qualities. “Dur-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the time when I was thinking about form and design and making distinctions
label: Paragraph

text: between the two,” Kahn said, “I thought that the unmeasurable aspects of our exist-
label: Paragraph

text: ence are the ones that are the most important. Such things as thought, feeling, real-
label: Paragraph

text: ization are all unmeasurable. It seems that this is also the concern of scientists.””*
label: Paragraph

text: There is also a fifth actor in this drawing, and that of course is Kahn himself, by
label: Paragraph

text: which I mean Kahn in his own body, who by virtue of the face in the foreground
label: Paragraph

text: insists we fit our gaze into his. We sit looking where Kahn sits drawing. The cone of
label: Paragraph

text: vision moves both in and out, a converging and inverted double V, back and forth
label: Paragraph

text: between the gaze of the foreground figure and the gaze of its author, each head
label: Paragraph

text: curious, each seizing on the other with their distinctively leonine eyes, likewise
label: Paragraph

text: our eyes. Their reciprocity constitutes what Maurice Merleau-Ponty calls a “the
label: Paragraph

text: third term” — “always tacitly understood, in the figure-background structure
label: Paragraph

text: [where] every figure stands out against the double horizon of external and bodily
label: Paragraph

text: space.””* The drawing affords viewer-participants unusually close proximity to the
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s drawing simultaneously explores the physical
label: Paragraph

text: psychic material of Kahn’s inquiry into construction. The foreground figure gazes
label: Paragraph

text: out deliberately: he is there to carry us over, the way all metaphors carry qualities
label: Paragraph

text: across the gap separating unlike entities, such as scientists and monks. He mediates
label: Paragraph

text: our own body’s encounter with the yellow sheet, one kind of limit, on the way to
label: Paragraph

text: our encounter with another kind of limit, the wall.
label: Paragraph

text: “Every detail in Kahn’s late buildings convinces us that he has thought it through
label: Paragraph

text: from the beginning, lived his life through it, and finally assembled it with every-
label: Paragraph

text: thing else into a hard-won calm,” Scully concludes.”® Close to the end of his life,
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn reflected on the interdependence of idea and phenomenon. “The architect
label: Paragraph

text: must always ask himself,” he said, “to what ‘dominion’ does this construction
label: Paragraph

text: belong?””’ In the very structure of this question, he persists in his conviction that
label: Paragraph

text: the duty of architecture is to use measurable means to put us in touch with our own
label: Paragraph

text: unmeasurable nature, bodies in touch with soul.
label: Paragraph

text: Manfredo Tafuri is unsparing in his characterization of this pattern in Kahn’s
label: Paragraph

text: practice. He argues:
label: Paragraph

text: “|Kahn sought to open] ineffable spaces for the narration of a nostalgia: nostalgia for a
label: Paragraph

text: sign that retraces its own adventures in search of the moment, forever lost in the
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinth of an unspeakable history, in which it loses its own referent; nostalgia
label: Paragraph

text: for universes of discourse that architecture can no longer frequent without renoun-
label: Paragraph

text: cing its own presence in the world; nostalgia for a reassuring relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: norm and deviation, capable of making gush forth, from the alembie through which
label: Paragraph

text: ruptures and lacerations are distilled, a ‘circularity’ and fullness of the word, the word
label: Paragraph

text: in its entirety.”
label: Paragraph

text: Within the sphere of Tafuri’s assessment, Kahn’s insistence on concrete makes
label: Paragraph

text: perfect sense. As Forty observes, “Kahn’s buildings, while thoroughly modern in
label: Paragraph

text: his attention to the structural systems and finish of the concrete, are ancient in the
label: Paragraph

text: way that the structure seems to exist as something independent of the uses to
label: Paragraph

text: which it has been put.””
label: Paragraph

text: If the construction of Salk is manifestly modern and practical, its modernism and
label: Paragraph

text: practicality thoroughly avoid contemporary formulas and styles, sui generis. And
label: Paragraph

text: yet its novel techniques, materials, and systems of composition clearly derive from
label: Paragraph

text: recombined formal and typological molecules — cloistered seclusion, neoclassical
label: Paragraph

text: axiality, and a basilican poché achieved in part through the adaptation and close
label: Paragraph

text: scrutiny of formwork design and concrete construction. Kahn draws these
label: Paragraph

text: “type-forms” into a larger picture that both incorporates and transcends the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing’s deeply thought pragmatism — its “mesenchyme” tissue, its pipe space, its
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of oak table and rug. The construction of what we see in our minds
label: Paragraph

text: when we envision Salk belongs neither to the dominion of science nor the domin-
label: Paragraph

text: ion of art, nor even to the dominion of the twentieth century. Well past the scope
label: Paragraph

text: and life of its original purpose and program, what makes Salk Salk is the hard-won
label: Paragraph

text: calm of an inconcrete void, which as both modern architecture and future ruin
label: Paragraph

text: keeps us freshly awake to questions that lie beyond its frame, cognizant yet empty.
