text: THE PRESENCE OF THE ATLANTIC OCEAN
label: Title

text: Atlantic waves break against rocky outcroppings of rusty granite. The horizon
label: Paragraph

text: traces a clear line in the painfully bright light; a sandy breeze from the north-west
label: Paragraph

text: fills the air with the smell of the sea. It is high summer and despite the wind, the
label: Paragraph

text: heat of the sun is hard to bear. From the coastal road, little can be seen of the swim-
label: Paragraph

text: ming pool — gray concrete and a few shallow-pitched roofs covered with tarpaper,
label: Paragraph

text: punctuating a kilometer-long wall with parked cars in front of it. A few meters
label: Paragraph

text: below is a landscape of rocks and sand. The view from above encompasses the
label: Paragraph

text: Atlantic Ocean, two swimming pools, stairs, and concrete walls. To the left is a
label: Caption

text: large beach full of people, bounded in the distance by the harbor pier jutting far
label: Paragraph

text: out into the sea.
label: Paragraph

text: Along the retaining wall, a ramp sinks down into the earth. Below is a small
label: Paragraph

text: wooden shed, just large enough for the ticket office. The space widens and the con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete wall becomes an opening, hardly taller than a person. Its long concrete lintel
label: Paragraph

text: seems to float, suggesting a gentle touch, a sense of closeness, despite the coarse
label: Paragraph

text: material. In the dressing rooms it is cool and dark — at first almost too dark to
label: Paragraph

text: see. The booths are fashioned of dark brown wood affixed to crossbeams that vanish
label: Paragraph

text: into the black ceiling. All is pervaded by an air of simplicity, an almost Far Eastern
label: Paragraph

text: austerity. From the dressing rooms, the path leads into a long courtyard enclosed by
label: Paragraph

text: weathered concrete walls. The sun on the visitor’s skin, the smoothness of the con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete floor under his or her tentative footsteps has a soothing effect. Two attendants
label: Paragraph

text: take each visitor's clothes. A tall gateway, twice as high as the building, points the
label: Paragraph

text: way. Above, the lamellae of a roof construction are discernable; below, near the floor,
label: Paragraph

text: the coarse gray walls become benches. The space widens; you step down, and a view
label: Paragraph

text: of the sea, the horizon, opens up to the right. Cliffs and sand appear through a narrow
label: Paragraph

text: aperture in the wall; another step up, and the concrete floor becomes rougher.
label: Paragraph

text: Slowly, hesitantly, you emerge as from a dream, entering another world.
label: Paragraph

text: Street and cars have disappeared; you have become part of a scene you viewed
label: Paragraph

text: from above only a short time earlier. No paths are visible in this miniature land-
label: Paragraph

text: scape of rock formations and sand plateaus, but small, geometric constructions
label: Paragraph

text: point the way through the craggy terrain. Everywhere are children, young people,
label: Paragraph

text: in the sand, in the water, between the rocks. A small bridge, open on one side with
label: Paragraph

text: a low railing on the other, suggests an entrance. Below it is a children’s pool with a
label: Caption

text: broadly curving edge. You take your first uncertain steps across the coarse-grained
label: Paragraph

text: sand toward the swimming pool, feeling lost in a strange landscape. Then a con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete platform appears between the rocks; from here, you overlook the pool. Steps
label: Paragraph

text: lead downward, a small landing turns toward the horizon, then three more steps.
label: Paragraph

text: The water in the white basin sparkles; it is almost as green as the sea. It is cold and
label: Paragraph

text: salty, but you feel a sense of lightness as you swim. The wind is colder now on your
label: Paragraph

text: wet skin; later, you will find a sheltered place between the rocks, a small room with
label: Paragraph

text: a warm sand floor, and sleep in the sun.
label: Paragraph

text: Design Process
label: Title

text: The swimming pool on the beach of Leca de Palmeira was planned and built in
label: Paragraph

text: small stages over a period of about 14 years.’ Since all the building phases
label: Paragraph

text: employed the same materials and formal language, the whole is marked by the
label: Paragraph

text: impression of self-evident coherence. Rough shell concrete was used for walls
label: Paragraph

text: and floors, dark wood for the roof construction and interior finishing, and tarpaper
label: Paragraph

text: for the roof covering, which was later replaced by patinated sheet copper. The
label: Paragraph

text: broad spectrum of the architectural vocabulary, however — expanded continually
label: Paragraph

text: over the course of the design and construction — produces a sense of uncertainty.
label: Paragraph

text: The complexity of the structure, as difficult to grasp on location as in the drawings,
label: Paragraph

text: becomes more easily comprehensible when the individual steps in its development
label: Paragraph

text: are examined one at a time.
label: Paragraph

text: The history of the project begins in November 1959, when the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Matosinhos — where Alvaro Siza was brought up and to which the district of
label: Paragraph

text: Leca de Palmeira belongs — commissioned the construction firm Ribeiro da Silva,
label: Paragraph

text: L* to produce a feasibility study and cost estimate for a swimming pool on the
label: Paragraph

text: beach of Leca. The original idea was a tide pool that would be supplied with fresh
label: Paragraph

text: seawater through the flow of the tide. Co-proprietor of the firm, engineer Bernardo
label: Paragraph

text: Ferr4o, chose a site somewhat to the north of a large sandy beach where the rocks
label: Paragraph

text: already formed a small pond, at that time used for breeding lobsters.” Here the
label: Paragraph

text: retaining wall of the coastal road was interrupted by a platform at street level
label: Paragraph

text: (Meia-Laranja”). Ferraéo proposed replacing the pond with a rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: swimming pool measuring 20 x 33.33 meters, whose long sides would lie parallel
label: Paragraph

text: to the retaining wall of the platform.’
label: Caption

text: In view of the urbanistic implications of the plan, the city followed the suggestion
label: Paragraph

text: of the engineer and commissioned an architect as well, Alvaro Siza Vieira, whom
label: Paragraph

text: Ferrao knew from the architecture office of his brother Fernando Tavora.‘
label: Paragraph

text: Siza, at that time 26 years old, at first proposed a large lake amid the rocks instead
label: Paragraph

text: ofa swimming pool.’ When the city rejected this idea, he suggested opening Ferrao’s
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular basin so that the edge toward the sea would be defined by the existing
label: Paragraph

text: granite rock formations. In this way, the basin was skillfully integrated into the
label: Paragraph

text: topographical situation, making it easier and less expensive to construct. The
label: Paragraph

text: proposal was accepted.
label: Paragraph

text: The concept of a tide pool, however, proved unrealizable for both hygienic and
label: Paragraph

text: topographic reasons. The basin was positioned too high in relation to sea level, and
label: Paragraph

text: in order to comply with health regulations, the seawater had to be filtered before it
label: Paragraph

text: was introduced to the pool. Nonetheless, as early as March 15, 1960, Bernardo
label: Paragraph

text: Ferrao submitted the final drawings for the swimming pool. After the construction
label: Paragraph

text: work had been completed by the firm of Ribeiro da Silva L**, Siza’s proposal to raze
label: Paragraph

text: the “Meia-Laranja” and expose the rocks beneath was put into action. In this way,
label: Paragraph

text: additional space was created for the pool’s guests and the site prepared for the con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction of the dressing rooms.
label: Paragraph

text: The second phase of the project commenced in the summer of 1961, when Siza
label: Paragraph

text: was commissioned to plan the “facilities necessary for the full functioning of the
label: Paragraph

text: swimming pool.” The commission was awarded by the mayor of Siza’s hometown
label: Paragraph

text: Matosinhos, Fernando Pinto de Oliveira,” who was to support the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: the pool for many years to come. Already at that time, the project was integrated
label: Paragraph

text: into the development plan for the entire coastal area from Leca to Boa Nova, where
label: Paragraph

text: Siza’s famous restaurant Casa de Cha was currently being built.
label: Paragraph

text: The preliminary design, presented by Siza in October 1962,’ called for a building
label: Paragraph

text: consisting of an access ramp, 24 dressing rooms — 12 each for women and men-—a
label: Paragraph

text: central check-room, sanitary facilities, and a room for the pumps and filters for pur-
label: Paragraph

text: ifying the seawater, as well as a partially roofed, wind-protected courtyard as an
label: Paragraph

text: entrance to the bathing zone. This complex was conceived as a modulation of
label: Paragraph

text: the kilometer-long retaining wall. In order not to disfigure the view of the horizon
label: Paragraph

text: from the coastal road, the buildings were inserted into the wall like internal organs.
label: Paragraph

text: A small restaurant with a fan-shaped plan in front of the wall adjoined the dressing
label: Paragraph

text: rooms at the northern end, while a children’s pool and a small bridge completed
label: Paragraph

text: the bathing zone.
label: Paragraph

text: In the final drawings for this phase of the design, the restaurant was replaced by a
label: Paragraph

text: complex rectangular building. This structure was shown only in outline, however,
label: Paragraph

text: and remained unrealized for lack of funds. The preliminary design was supplemen-
label: Paragraph

text: ted with steps leading through the rocks to the swimming pool. The construction
label: Paragraph

text: work was carried out from 1963 to late 1964. In addition, a snack bar and a free-
label: Paragraph

text: standing WC were incorporated as temporary measures. It proved difficult to
label: Paragraph

text: obtain clean seawater, as water drawn from between the rocks contained too high
label: Paragraph

text: a proportion of sand. Accordingly, a spring well was installed in the proximity of
label: Paragraph

text: the shore wall, drawing water from a subterranean canal extending a hundred
label: Paragraph

text: meters out into the sea.* By the summer of 1965, the complex was fully functional
label: Paragraph

text: for the first time and a regular swimming business commenced.
label: Paragraph

text: It soon became clear, however, that the facilities were insufficient for the
label: Paragraph

text: demand. Thus in September 1965, Siza submitted a preliminary design for the
label: Paragraph

text: “expansion of the swimming pool area, consisting of restaurant, storage spaces,
label: Paragraph

text: sanitary facilities, bar, and esplanade.”” South of the dressing rooms, he planned
label: Paragraph

text: a second retaining wall four meters in front of the existing shore wall, ending as
label: Paragraph

text: aramp leading to the beach of Leca. The space between the two walls was set aside
label: Paragraph

text: for the sanitary facilities and storage areas. To the north, the provisional snack bar
label: Caption

text: was replaced by a permanent building with a triangular esplanade, protected from
label: Paragraph

text: the powerful north wind by a concrete wall at a 45-degree angle to the shore wall.
label: Paragraph

text: This protecting wall was precisely aligned with the north-east corner of the swim-
label: Paragraph

text: ming pool, finding its continuation in a part of the west edge of the basin. Further to
label: Paragraph

text: the north, additional sanitary facilities were incorporated into the shore wall.
label: Paragraph

text: Continuing northward another hundred meters, a platform, tapering to produce a
label: Paragraph

text: perspectival effect, was planned in front of the shore wall to serve as a connection
label: Paragraph

text: to the future restaurant. The restaurant itself, a structure about 70 meters long, like-
label: Paragraph

text: wise stood at a 45-degree angle to the shore wall on the ridge of a rock and served as
label: Paragraph

text: wind protection for the northern part of the beach. From 1993 to 1995 Siza further
label: Paragraph

text: developed the project of this restaurant, but nothing more has yet been built.
label: Paragraph

text: This preliminary design was subdivided into a third phase — consisting of all the
label: Paragraph

text: expansions with the exception of the restaurant and the platform — and a fourth
label: Paragraph

text: one, which was set aside for the time being. The working plans for the third phase
label: Paragraph

text: were submitted in February 1966.'° When difficulties with the building permit
label: Paragraph

text: arose, Siza and Ferrao once again submitted a comprehensive project description
label: Paragraph

text: in July 1967, including a “Survey of Development Phases.”*’ Construction itself
label: Paragraph

text: probably only began the following year.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 1970s, new health regulations necessitated improvements to the
label: Paragraph

text: snack bar as well as the installation of dressing and sanitary facilities for the person-
label: Paragraph

text: nel. These and other measures were presented in a design for the “connection of
label: Paragraph

text: the third and fourth phase,” submitted in April 1973.’? In the corresponding ground
label: Paragraph

text: plan, the large platform south of the dressing rooms appears for the first time with a
label: Paragraph

text: stair cut into it at a 45-degree angle, as do the platform and ramp in front of the
label: Paragraph

text: children’s pool. According to the survey of development phases, however, the
label: Paragraph

text: ramp appears already to have been realized before 1965. According to the plan,
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior wall of the men’s dressing area was to be replaced by a diagonal wall,
label: Paragraph

text: which however was not built.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from measures necessary for maintenance, the complex remained unal-
label: Paragraph

text: tered throughout the following years. In early 1993, Siza revised the design of
label: Paragraph

text: the restaurant from the fourth phase and by 1995 had produced a complete set
label: Paragraph

text: of execution drawings. For lack of funds or support, however, the project once
label: Paragraph

text: again remained unrealized. During the same period, the existing buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: renovated. Among other measures, the roofs were covered with patinated copper,
label: Paragraph

text: as already specified in the original plan.
label: Paragraph

text: The properties alongside the coastal avenue, which in 1990 were still open green
label: Paragraph

text: areas, have since been urbanized. Today, large apartment blocks, most of them
label: Paragraph

text: several stories high, face the avenue. In the first decade of the new millennium,
label: Paragraph

text: Siza had been commissioned to redesign the whole coastal avenue and public space
label: Paragraph

text: area, starting from Leca port’s North Mole, all the way up to the Boa Nova site. On
label: Paragraph

text: May 25, 2011, Siza’s Boa Nova restaurant and the swimming pool on the beach at
label: Caption

text: Leca da Palmeira were the two first modern projects in Portugal to be classified as
label: Paragraph

text: national monuments.’ At the same time, the coastal area between the swimming
label: Paragraph

text: pool and the restaurant were declared a “specially protected zone,” in order to
label: Paragraph

text: “guarantee the continuity of the dialogue between the Casa de Cha da Boa Nova
label: Paragraph

text: and the Piscinas de Marés, the coastal avenue, the beach area and the sea.”** In spite
label: Paragraph

text: of this legal protection, in 2012 the local government tolerated the use of the big
label: Paragraph

text: lawn area in front of the Casa de Cha to be used as an uncontrolled parking lot,
label: Paragraph

text: causing the devastation of almost all vegetation.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Nature and Geometry
label: Title

text: One of the fundamental themes of the project is its relation to the natural environ-
label: Paragraph

text: ment: “In these first works, there ripened a definite, undeniable feeling that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture does not end at a specific point, but extends from object to space
label: Paragraph

text: and thus — through the relation to space — finds its completion in nature.”'® But
label: Paragraph

text: what does “nature” mean in this context? Here there is no occasion for Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: glorification or even the relaxed enjoyment of nature. The site is a wild, inhospi-
label: Paragraph

text: table one, exposed to the wind and the waves. It lacks the idyllic quality of the
label: Paragraph

text: Quinta da Conceicdo park, also a part of Leca de Palmeira, where shortly before
label: Paragraph

text: Siza had realized a smaller swimming pool with white plastered walls and red-tiled
label: Paragraph

text: roofs in the shadow of old pines. Nor is it as dramatic and picturesque as the rocks
label: Paragraph

text: of Boa Nova, where Siza’s restaurant was built. Yet it draws its primal power from
label: Paragraph

text: the presence of the Atlantic Ocean, from the sound of the wind and the breaking
label: Paragraph

text: waves, from its closeness to the industrial harbor of Matosinhos and the view of a
label: Paragraph

text: horizon whose infinitely distant yet precise line is echoed in the retaining wall of
label: Paragraph

text: the coastal road.
label: Paragraph

text: The wall, about a kilometer and a half in length and up to ten meters in height,
label: Paragraph

text: constitutes a powerful, clear boundary separating the cultivated land from the
label: Paragraph

text: beach and the rugged, inaccessible rocky coast, an area visibly exposed to the
label: Paragraph

text: assault of the sea. The wall does not appear as an object, but rather forms a kind
label: Paragraph

text: of base for the land bounded by it. Into this wall is incorporated the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: complex of the dressing rooms. They represent a modulation of the work of engi-
label: Paragraph

text: neering that structures the entire coastal area and establishes a connection between
label: Paragraph

text: Leca and the restaurant of Boa Nova. Despite its modest scale, the architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: thus effectively incorporated into its landscape context. Seen from the bathing
label: Paragraph

text: zone, the wall functions as a background before which a dramatic scenery unfolds.
label: Paragraph

text: The ideal of a harmonious balance between architecture and the existing land-
label: Paragraph

text: scape, formulated at that time by Siza’s mentor Fernando Tavora,’” was certainly
label: Paragraph

text: one of the fundamental principles underlying the project. But how does the struc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture that was actually built relate to its context? While it may distantly evoke a
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese stone garden, it in fact represents its exact opposite — not the artful ide-
label: Paragraph

text: alization of nature in an architectural setting, but the exposure and restrained pres-
label: Paragraph

text: entation of a primal, wild, inhospitable situation. The design respects the natural
label: Paragraph

text: setting and the already existing structures, adapting them to the new functional
label: Paragraph

text: demands with sparing interventions.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the strict geometry of the architecture clearly distinguishes it from the
label: Paragraph

text: rugged, rocky landscape, this approach is not informed by the classical opposition
label: Paragraph

text: between nature and art. The change of material and the clearly defined forms
label: Paragraph

text: permit the eye to distinguish between the built and the pre-existing; yet both are
label: Paragraph

text: intensified by the presence of the other. The effect is not that of an isolated object
label: Paragraph

text: contrasting with the landscape — as is still the case with the restaurant in Boa Nova —
label: Paragraph

text: but rather of a multiplicity of structures carefully incorporated into the topography
label: Paragraph

text: and integrally connected to the given situation. Walls find their continuation in
label: Paragraph

text: stairs and platforms of the same material, which in turn create transitions to areas
label: Paragraph

text: of rock and sand. Even the texture and color of the rough shell concrete is less of a
label: Paragraph

text: contrast than a harmonious complement to the existing granite rocks. The material
label: Paragraph

text: has even taken on something of a brownish patina, which also darkens the granite.
label: Paragraph

text: At times, the concrete even seems older, more weathered than the rocks — craggy
label: Paragraph

text: forms that, as if alive, seem to spring up everywhere.
label: Paragraph

text: Taking into account that a large part of the rocky topography we perceive as
label: Paragraph

text: “natural” when we visit the pool area today had been covered by a large platform
label: Paragraph

text: (in Portuguese called Meja-Laranja) when Siza started the project, it becomes obvi-
label: Paragraph

text: ous that the “natural” is as much part of his architectural conception as is the “arti-
label: Paragraph

text: ficial” or “architectural.” The rocks had literally to be discovered by demolishing
label: Paragraph

text: the existing platform, which at the beginning of the project had even defined the
label: Paragraph

text: positioning and the alignment of the larger swimming pool. As in a traditional Chi-
label: Paragraph

text: nese garden, nature is understood as part of, not opposite of the artificial, even if
label: Paragraph

text: the contrast between the rocks and the geometry of the concrete structures seems
label: Paragraph

text: to suggest this opposition.
label: Paragraph

text: The strategy of interweaving the built and the existing is associated less with the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of a Gesamtkunstwerk than with the dissolution of architecture into a complex
label: Paragraph

text: topography. Even the reduction of the materials to concrete and black impregnated
label: Paragraph

text: wood gives the buildings a sense of the transient, like ruins. The pronounced
label: Paragraph

text: boundary of the shore wall confronts the boundlessness of the beach; as the years
label: Paragraph

text: pass, the buildings grow outward along the shore wall. The conceptual boundary
label: Paragraph

text: of this landscape is established to the south only by the harbor pier, to the north by
label: Paragraph

text: the rocks and the restaurant of Boa Nova. In this way, there originate perspectival
label: Paragraph

text: relations whose dimensions recall the scale of baroque landscape design. On the
label: Paragraph

text: esplanade, bounded by the diagonal wall, a perspectival space is created whose
label: Paragraph

text: opposite side is formed by the harbor pier — a triangle with kilometer-long sides.
label: Paragraph

text: Finally, a slit-like window in the bathrooms concealed in the shore wall offers a
label: Paragraph

text: view of the Atlantic horizon.
label: Paragraph

text: And what position is reserved for the visitor to the swimming pool? Carefully, in
label: Paragraph

text: a complicated ritual, you cross the boundary of the shore wall, the line that divides
label: Paragraph

text: a landscape cultivated by man from the rocky beach, at the mercy of the powers of
label: Paragraph

text: the sea. A zigzag parcours along the wall compensates for the narrowness of the site,
label: Paragraph

text: establishing distance to the mundane world. The access ramp leading northward,
label: Paragraph

text: the darkness of the dressing rooms, and the longitudinal, southerly courtyard are
label: Paragraph

text: all stations in a path leading to the narrow, almost hidden aperture in the wall that
label: Paragraph

text: opens out onto the beach. Only shortly before you viewed the complex from a
label: Paragraph

text: distance; now, having performed the gestures of “submersion,” “undressing,”
label: Paragraph

text: and “surfacing,” you feel part of a natural landscape into which you have been sub-
label: Paragraph

text: tly and sensitively introduced. The decisive moment — as you emerge from a court-
label: Paragraph

text: yard protected by concrete walls into the open landscape — now calls for initiative
label: Paragraph

text: and active involvement as you begin the exploration of the complex topography.
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural References
label: Title

text: A number of modern architects have been named as possible influences on the
label: Paragraph

text: design of the swimming pool in Leca. Alvaro Siza himself repeatedly emphasizes
label: Paragraph

text: the importance of Frank Lloyd Wright, an influence that probably goes back to
label: Paragraph

text: travel reports by Fernando Tavora, who visited Taliesin West in 1960. “When
label: Paragraph

text: I began the project, I bought a publication on Wright’s work, and particular aspects
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Desert House had a positive influence on my work ... I remember that
label: Paragraph

text: at the time, Wright was a kind of liberation for me.”* William Curtis describes this
label: Paragraph

text: influence as follows: “There is a reminiscence of Wright’s Taliesin West of 1937, in
label: Paragraph

text: which parallel galleries and through-ways also precede a diagonal expansion across
label: Paragraph

text: water towards a distant view.”!” The stair cut into the southern platform at a 45-
label: Paragraph

text: degree angle may likewise be interpreted as the negative form of a terrace from
label: Paragraph

text: Taliesin West. The fan-shaped ground plan of an early version of the restaurant
label: Caption

text: from the second phase, however, also recalls the work of Alvar Aalto. Others have
label: Paragraph

text: seen references to the longitudinal volumes of Aalto’s university cafeteria in
label: Paragraph

text: Jyvaskyla, to neo-plasticism, and to the architecture of Mies van der Rohe.”° Finally,
label: Paragraph

text: Curtis sees the form of the children’s pool as an “reinterpretation of Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: free plan curves,” one that also reminds him of cubist paintings.”’ On the other
label: Paragraph

text: hand, Le Corbusier’s conception of the promenade architecturale” has obviously
label: Paragraph

text: been more important for the project than any artwork.
label: Paragraph

text: The question arises as to whether these associations truly suffice to explain the
label: Paragraph

text: motivation for this design. According to Siza, “learning in architecture actually
label: Paragraph

text: means an expansion of references ... I think it is possible to isolate individual influ-
label: Paragraph

text: ences in a work, but in a mature work this would be very difficult, for there the
label: Paragraph

text: references are not one, but many.””’ The identification of models may perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: serve to build bridges, enabling us to understand an architecture that is “unique”
label: Paragraph

text: in the best sense of the word and thus also somewhat alienating. Yet while such
label: Paragraph

text: references help make the work more accessible, they by no means suffice to explain
label: Paragraph

text: its specific qualities; rather, these are manifested in the very aspects that most
label: Paragraph

text: clearly differ from their alleged models.
label: Paragraph

text: Together with the “Cooperativa Lordelo” built at almost the same time, the
label: Paragraph

text: design of the swimming pool on the beach of Leca marks a new phase in the devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opment of Siza’s architecture: “Tt is the first building that no longer makes reference
label: Paragraph

text: to traditional Portuguese architecture, in terms of either formal language or mate-
label: Paragraph

text: rials.”** Its language is characterized by a high degree of abstraction and the dom-
label: Paragraph

text: inance of horizontals; its longitudinal, rectangular volumes of coarse exposed
label: Paragraph

text: concrete are staggered in a number of levels, with no visible openings, doors, or
label: Paragraph

text: windows in the traditional sense. Siza employed this formal vocabulary only during
label: Paragraph

text: those years and in only a few of his designs; the street facade of the Alves Santos
label: Paragraph

text: house is related to it, as is the house of Manuel Magalhies, realized a few
label: Paragraph

text: years later.
label: Paragraph

text: Siza describes the basic idea of the project as a further development of the
label: Paragraph

text: approach used in his design for the restaurant Boa Nova, created a few years earlier:
label: Paragraph

text: “I considered that this solution was too direct a translation of the accidents of the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape. The profile of the restaurant is almost a direct parallel to the profile of
label: Paragraph

text: the rocks. After I finished, I found it too much dependent on the landscape.””* “[For
label: Paragraph

text: the swimming pool]! said to myself, this time it has to be two elements, as in many
label: Paragraph

text: compositions, completely separated, each with its own language, but they have to
label: Paragraph

text: stand in relation to each other.””°
label: Paragraph

text: A comparison of the Leca swimming pool with the pool in the park of Quinta da
label: Paragraph

text: Conceicao, built by Siza from 1958 to 1965, shows the completely different, even
label: Paragraph

text: antithetical character of the two projects. The pool in the park represents an almost
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean idyll in the shadow of the pines, its white plastered walls contrasting
label: Paragraph

text: with the red-tiled roofs and grassy lawns; the pool on the coast, on the other hand,
label: Paragraph

text: appears gray against gray with no vegetation, more industrial than idyllic. Siza
label: Paragraph

text: knew not only how to react to the peculiarities of these radically different locations,
label: Paragraph

text: but also how to transform their qualities into the theme of the architecture. The
label: Paragraph

text: background for this approach is not least of all a culture of architectural landscape
label: Paragraph

text: design that has shaped northern Portugal for centuries and whose remnants leave a
label: Paragraph

text: striking impression even today.
label: Paragraph

text: Tender Indifference
label: Title

text: My first exposure to this project was through a series of photographs by Giovanni
label: Paragraph

text: Chiaramonte, published in Quaderni di Lotus in 1986.” They showed gray-blue sky
label: Paragraph

text: and weathered concrete walls with deep black shadows, empty spaces with no
label: Paragraph

text: apparent meaning, no visible trace of human life. What were they? An abandoned
label: Paragraph

text: industrial complex? The remains of a military fortification? The name “swimming
label: Paragraph

text: pool’ usually evokes a different image. Looking back at these photographs today,
label: Paragraph

text: we can see the influence of existentialist Italian cinema from the 1950s, in the way
label: Paragraph

text: Chiaramonte perceives the maze of concrete walls as much as in their austere pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ence, denying any opening or other way to escape.
label: Paragraph

text: My first visits to the site were likewise discomfiting, though in a different way —
label: Paragraph

text: an experience of confrontation with the elemental forces of nature, the primal
label: Paragraph

text: power of the Atlantic coast of northern Portugal. The logic of this only seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinthine architectural landscape was perceptible from the first visit, although
label: Paragraph

text: comprehension of at least some of the mechanisms of its fascination was long in
label: Paragraph

text: coming. It is an architecture that, despite its geometric precision, seems to dissolve
label: Paragraph

text: into the landscape, one whose very radicality enables it to sensitively respond to the
label: Paragraph

text: needs of the visitors. It is the result of an approach that accepts challenges without
label: Paragraph

text: acquiescing to aesthetic or ideological formulas. In this way, it is able to react ina
label: Paragraph

text: very direct, as it were unprejudiced way, with a pragmatism that is not reducible to
label: Paragraph

text: technical or economical demands, but which acknowledges the totality of human
label: Paragraph

text: existence as its parameter.
label: Paragraph

text: The philosophy of existentialism, with its focus on the human individual and his
label: Paragraph

text: actions and feelings in the face of an apparently meaningless world, was highly influ-
label: Paragraph

text: ential in southern Europe when this project was conceived. Yet it would be specu-
label: Paragraph

text: lation to consider it a main reference. Rather, we may see the way this architecture
label: Paragraph

text: creates meaning by precisely shaping and positioning its elements in the concrete
label: Paragraph

text: world as a means to escape the existentialist notion of the absurd. The influence
label: Paragraph

text: of traditional Chinese and Japanese architecture and gardening seems more evident,
label: Paragraph

text: primarily in the subtle and austere aesthetics, and the prominent role of context and
label: Paragraph

text: nature in the project, at the time unobserved in European design practice.
label: Paragraph

text: On the beach of Leca de Palmeira, we encounter an essential architecture
label: Paragraph

text: reduced to only a few elements, one whose harshness is necessary to assert its pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ence in this place. It is an architecture whose very simplicity — the unaffected
label: Paragraph

text: wooden construction, the coarsely executed, weathered, and in many places
label: Paragraph

text: patched concrete walls — evokes the aesthetic of paupertas, of dignified poverty.
label: Paragraph

text: For precisely this reason, it is capable of providing a foothold for the groundless
label: Paragraph

text: emotions of Albert Camus’ L’Etranger; it speaks of the “tender indifference of
label: Paragraph

text: the world. To find it so similar to me, so brotherly in the end, made me feel that
label: Paragraph

text: I have been happy, and I still am.””*
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Carlo Scarpa
label: Title

text: Michael Cadwell
label: Title

text: Carlo Scarpa, Brion Vega Cemetery, San Vito d’Altivole, Italy, 1969-78. View from water
label: Caption

text: pavilion.*
label: Paragraph

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.

text: BETWEEN WORLDS
label: Title

text: Late in his career, in November of 1976, Carlo Scarpa lectured at the Academy of
label: Paragraph

text: Fine Arts in Vienna. Entitled “Can Architecture Be Poetry?,” Scarpa’s lecture
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged his respect for Oriental architecture as well as that of Hoffmann,
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, Le Corbusier, and Kahn. Scarpa also defended his project under construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, a private cemetery in honor of the successful industrialist Giuseppe Brion and
label: Paragraph

text: his wife Onorina Tomasin Brion. Opposition to the project was pronounced, espe-
label: Paragraph

text: cially within academia, where the extravagance of a memorial to a wealthy patron
label: Paragraph

text: flew in the face of prevailing egalitarian ideology. During the discussion that fol-
label: Paragraph

text: owed his presentation, Scarpa bemoaned the graffiti that students had scrawled on
label: Paragraph

text: the cemetery walls, yet closed with his typical equanimity, “Allow me a small per-
label: Paragraph

text: sonal idea. A large work of art is always small.”"
label: Paragraph

text: Much of Scarpa’s work is small in size. Beginning with his limpid vases and table-
label: Paragraph

text: ware for the Murano glassworks, through his masterful installations of historical arti-
label: Paragraph

text: facts at the Museo Correr and modern artwork at Venice Biennales and exhibitions
label: Paragraph

text: throughout Europe and the Americas, including his subtle restorations and additions
label: Paragraph

text: at the Palazzo Abatellis, the Canova Museum, the Castelvecchio, and the Querini
label: Caption

text: Stampalia, and extending to his exquisite retail shops for Olivetti and Gavina and
label: Paragraph

text: renovations of the Banca Popolare, and, finally, the scattering of private houses —
label: Paragraph

text: Veritti, Benedetti-Bonito, and Ottolenghi — in size, at least, Scarpa’s work is small.
label: Paragraph

text: And it was not just in size that Scarpa’s work countered the grand aspirations of
label: Paragraph

text: his time. Scarpa aligned himself with private mythologies rather than social agen-
label: Paragraph

text: das; he delighted in historical contexts rather than heroic gestures; he mined the
label: Paragraph

text: narrative potential of a building’s circulation rather its organizational efficiency;
label: Paragraph

text: and he exploited the articulation of envelope rather than the manipulation of space.
label: Paragraph

text: It is not too much to assert that while many of Scarpa’s contemporaries struggled
label: Paragraph

text: with the collapse of any Enlightenment project, Scarpa followed a Counter-
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment trajectory whereby truths are provisional and created by individual
label: Paragraph

text: subjects rather than absolutes discovered through objective reason. Interestingly
label: Paragraph

text: enough, Scarpa’s work would inspire emerging American architects such as Steven
label: Paragraph

text: Holl, Jorge Silvetti, Billie Tsien, and Michael Rotundi,” and his insistence that archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture was a material practice would presage the work of emerging European
label: Paragraph

text: architects such as Peter Zumthor, Peter Markli, and Herzog & de Meuron. Scarpa
label: Paragraph

text: was averse to theoretical proclamations, yet declared his sympathies as Director of
label: Paragraph

text: the Architecture Institute of Venice University by inscribing a quotation of Giam-
label: Paragraph

text: battista Vico on the school gate: verum ipsum factum, truth is made.
label: Caption

text: Scarpa made his truths in architecture’s smallest dimension, its construction
label: Paragraph

text: details. In part this was afforded by the craft of the Venetian artisans with whom
label: Paragraph

text: he collaborated and the forbearance of clients who indulged cost overruns
label: Paragraph

text: and prolonged schedules. Yet refinement and expense often accommodate con-
label: Paragraph

text: ventions rather than challenge them. Craft is necessary but not sufficient to
label: Paragraph

text: Scarpa’s cultural achievement. The experience of Scarpa’s projects is sensual,
label: Paragraph

text: yet what is remarkable is how the experience challenges habits and suggests
label: Paragraph

text: new ways of engaging the world. Scarpa’s native Venice seems to have informed
label: Paragraph

text: his strange sensibility. In Venice, the ground is constructed against the encroach-
label: Paragraph

text: ments of the sea rather than assumed as a static given, and the unifying gaze of
label: Paragraph

text: perspective is thwarted by the maze of streets, the reflections of water, and the
label: Paragraph

text: shifting effects of sun and fog. Scarpa’s detailing draws us into a world where the
label: Paragraph

text: ground drifts, solids double and liquefy, and atmospheric conditions trump stable
label: Paragraph

text: perceptions.
label: Paragraph

text: Vico may have reinforced Scarpa’s enthusiasm for the Brion project. Certainly,
label: Paragraph

text: there were the luxuries of Venetian craftsmen, indulgent patronage, and a Veneto
label: Paragraph

text: site that Scarpa knew and loved. More to the point, the modest program of a family
label: Paragraph

text: tomb includes the institutions that Vico asserted as the foundation of civilization:
label: Paragraph

text: religion, which projects a future through divine providence; burial, which institutes
label: Paragraph

text: the past through ritual commemoration; and matrimony, which seals the contract
label: Paragraph

text: between predecessor and progeny.’ Scarpa could not have wished for a larger small
label: Paragraph

text: commission.
label: Paragraph

text: The commission grew by degrees. Onorina Brion first approached Scarpa upon
label: Paragraph

text: the death of Giuseppe Brion in late 1968. At the time, the family owned a rec-
label: Paragraph

text: tangular site and funeral chapel at the north-east corner of the public cemetery
label: Caption

text: in Giuseppe Brion’s hometown, San Vito d’Altivole. In May of 1969, the family
label: Paragraph

text: purchased an L-shaped lot of 2,000 m* along the northern and eastern edges of the
label: Paragraph

text: cemetery. Scarpa located key elements of his proposal in corners of the site. At
label: Caption

text: the western tip, a small cubic funeral chapel rotated 45°, arose from a pool, and
label: Paragraph

text: connected to the access road through a cypress grove. At the southern tip, a
label: Paragraph

text: diminutive wood and steel pavilion floated in a larger pool dotted by smaller
label: Paragraph

text: planted islands. Pinning the joint of the L at the northeast corner, the sarcophagi
label: Caption

text: of Giuseppe and Onorina Brion nested in a circular depression of the extensive
label: Paragraph

text: lawn, while the sarcophagi’s winged roof, also rotated at 45°, pointed to the fam-
label: Paragraph

text: ly graves hidden beneath an extension of the north perimeter wall. Burial, reli-
label: Caption

text: gion, and marriage fuse as burying the dead combines the public rituals of the
label: Paragraph

text: chapel and the private meditations of the pavilion, and both are leavened by
label: Paragraph

text: the enduring love of the married couple memorialized by the sarcophagi. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: couples animate the scheme — chapel and pavilion, lawn and pool, earth and sky —
label: Paragraph

text: establishing differences while their effects suggest sympathies. Central to this
label: Paragraph

text: dynamism is the cemetery’s concrete construction, which plays upon
label: Paragraph

text: concrete’s duplicity as it shifts between light and heavy, solid and liquid, and time-
label: Paragraph

text: less and timely.‘ Bodily perceptions are unmoored even as bodily demise is
label: Paragraph

text: commemorated.
label: Paragraph

text: Propylaeum
label: Title

text: The Brion cemetery is approached from the north, following a narrow lane
label: Paragraph

text: through fields that are often planted with corn. Within this agrarian remove,
label: Paragraph

text: the complex asserts its boundary with a battered concrete wall. Flanges project
label: Paragraph

text: from the wall giving measure to its length much as the wall provides a datum
label: Paragraph

text: for the elements behind: cypress grove, chapel, promenade, and family tombs.
label: Caption

text: Yet, the wall’s base is obscured and the complex seems to drift on a sea of green
label: Paragraph

text: vegetation.
label: Paragraph

text: From a closer oblique view, the wall betrays any stolid role. Especially in sum-
label: Paragraph

text: mer afternoon light, the battered wall is caught in earthen shadows, while the
label: Paragraph

text: flanges catch the hot western glare in a silvery sheen that merges with the sky.
label: Paragraph

text: Lichen and weather staining appear, the concrete participating with nature as well
label: Paragraph

text: as standing apart from it, registering the passage of time as well as standing against
label: Paragraph

text: it. The original formwork of horizontal planks registers on the concrete’s rough
label: Paragraph

text: aggregate, yet the conceit of primitive construction also falls away since the wall’s
label: Paragraph

text: tilt can only be achieved through the studied insertion of steel reinforcing. Under-
label: Paragraph

text: cutting any notion of concrete’s stable presence, concrete exchanges with wood as
label: Paragraph

text: the wall dissolves into stout latticework at its corners.
label: Paragraph

text: Continuing to the west, the municipal cemetery comes into view, its conven-
label: Paragraph

text: tional grid of tombs on graveled ground punctuated by the entry to the Brion com-
label: Paragraph

text: plex. Scarpa referred to the entry by the Greek term “propylaeum,” and heightened
label: Paragraph

text: its somber mood by placing a weeping cedar to its right.” Yet, this is no simple
label: Paragraph

text: threshold. While the concrete’s unsettling effects were glimpsed along the north-
label: Paragraph

text: ern boundary wall, they are confronted at the propylaeum.
label: Paragraph

text: Steps abound. The propylaeum refuses to present a solid front, and defers in a
label: Paragraph

text: proliferation of small steps as if the entire assembly were a variation on traditional
label: Paragraph

text: door moldings. Certainly, passage is offered through a kind of wall even if the wall
label: Paragraph

text: will not locate itself. Yet, moldings vary their dimensions to reinforce a sense of
label: Paragraph

text: scale and vary their orientation to substantiate an upright stance. There is no var-
label: Paragraph

text: iation in the dimension of the propylaeum’s steps. That the steps’ dimension
label: Paragraph

text: matches that of a hand does not help; their proliferation provides rhythm but oblit-
label: Paragraph

text: erates scale. The stepping also refuses to support an upright stance. To the right of
label: Paragraph

text: the entry, the stepping runs vertically (confirming the stance), but then folds to the
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal (denying it). To the left of the entry, the steps engage in an extended
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal play, receding into the distance as if announcing the opening in a floor
label: Paragraph

text: rather than a wall.
label: Paragraph

text: Walls stabilize within the propylaeum. Concrete work is refined, the pours agi-
label: Paragraph

text: tated to project a fine slurry that tattoos the veining of the formwork’s wood planks
label: Paragraph

text: onto the concrete surface. This was a common technique by the time of the Brion’s
label: Paragraph

text: construction, predated by Le Corbusier’s Unité at Marseille and successive Brutalist
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, yet the existential drama of man’s will forced on obdurate materials that
label: Paragraph

text: often pervades the earlier work does not prevail at the Brion. Here, the planks’
label: Paragraph

text: varied widths and intimate veining seem to memorialize the trees that were har-
label: Paragraph

text: vested for the walls’ realization. Light adds an elegiac tone to this association, its
label: Paragraph

text: mood shifting from skeletal grays in the morning to a golden luminosity as the
label: Paragraph

text: day wanes.
label: Paragraph

text: Just ahead is a stair, announced by the walls’ white plaster panels that are
label: Paragraph

text: accented by muntz buttons in the manner of Roman tombs. The ceiling also
label: Caption

text: receives this honorific treatment, but only belatedly. The lintel’s undercarriage
label: Paragraph

text: recapitulates the propylaeum’s stepping with a finer corbelling. Location, orienta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, and scale shatter with an upward gaze into a mini-sublime of indetermi-
label: Paragraph

text: nate depth.
label: Paragraph

text: If the steps destabilize perception, a second figure lends a kind of coherence.
label: Paragraph

text: A pair of large interlocking circles appears in the wall ahead, the ring at the right
label: Paragraph

text: trimmed with blue mosaics and that at the left with red mosaics. Often referred to
label: Paragraph

text: as vesica piscis, the figure is prominent in early Christian, Byzantine, and Gothic art
label: Paragraph

text: where the overlapping circles generate an almond frame for the body of Christ or
label: Paragraph

text: the Virgin Mary.° Scarpa was well versed in art history, yet a singular reading of the
label: Paragraph

text: Brion circles is misleading.
label: Paragraph

text: Associations of the vesica piscis include everything from the female anatomy (the
label: Paragraph

text: vulva), to wedding ceremonies (the wedding rings), to astronomical movements
label: Paragraph

text: of
label: Title

text: le-
label: Title

text: (the solar eclipse), to arcane proportioning systems (particularly Gothic). All
label: Paragraph

text: these are at play at the Brion: the entry sequence is invaginated; the precinct ce
label: Paragraph

text: brates a married couple; the siting adheres to cardinal orientations; and Scarpa
label: Paragraph

text: favored a proportioning system of double numbers.’ However, these associations
label: Paragraph

text: support the Brion’s shifting effects rather than dictate them. After all, the Brion
label: Paragraph

text: circles do not fulfill the strict geometries of the vesica piscis whereby the circles
label: Paragraph

text: ying on the perimeter of the other, their
label: Paragraph

text: intersect with the center of each circle
label: Paragraph

text: intersection stabilized and generating a host of secondary stable geometries.
label: Paragraph

text: The Brion circles stop short of this intersection and implied unity, as if the circles
label: Paragraph

text: were moving closer together or drifting further apart. Overlapping rings will
label: Paragraph

text: appear throughout the cemetery, but they are always physically engaged rather
label: Paragraph

text: than read from a safe remove. Scarpa’s
label: Paragraph

text: in flux, and the physical experience of the
label: Paragraph

text: insisting on any singular reading.
label: Paragraph

text: Here, the circles fulfill a simple arc
label: Paragraph

text: circles are multivalent, their relationship
label: Paragraph

text: m suggests a range of associations without
label: Paragraph

text: hitectural role by countering the propy-
label: Paragraph

text: laeum’s confusions of location, orientation, and scale. A flat wall finally presents
label: Paragraph

text: itself, one that can be located in plan and gauged in depth. An upright stance is
label: Paragraph

text: confirmed by the figure of the almond, and the circle’s diameters match human
label: Paragraph

text: height. Earth and sky are also reestablished as the concrete boundary wall bisects
label: Paragraph

text: the circles. A balance is achieved. It is temporary.
label: Paragraph

text: The stairs modulate the circle’s equivalences with a leftward bias at the
label: Paragraph

text: T-junction to the proscenium’s north-south extension.” The hollow echo of the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete planks underfoot announces that the propylaeum is now a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: bridge. Blackened planks are embalmed in the ceiling, hastening the movement
label: Paragraph

text: from darkness to light, bridge to ground, constriction to expanse, and concrete to
label: Paragraph

text: vegetation.
label: Paragraph

text: Arcosolium
label: Title

text: After a prolonged passage, then, the public cemetery’s urban plate is left behind for
label: Paragraph

text: a garden’s lush grass, scent of flowers, and gurgle of water. The lawn is three feet
label: Paragraph

text: above the surrounding fields, the canted boundary wall protecting against views
label: Paragraph

text: from the outside. Now coming to eye-level within the precinct, the boundary wall
label: Paragraph

text: eliminates the view of the middle landscape of fields and snaps the transition to the
label: Paragraph

text: distant town and mountains. There is a sensation of hovering, of being ungrounded
label: Paragraph

text: and detached.
label: Paragraph

text: Closer by, water flows in a narrow concrete channel that extends from the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: scenium, tapers, and culminates in a pair of small circular pools. The pools bloom
label: Paragraph

text: into a narrow planter that turns and is terminated with a cruciform planter and its
label: Paragraph

text: double, a stout column. This last doubling of plant and concrete intersects with the
label: Paragraph

text: circular steps rippling outward from the sarcophagi of Giuseppe and Oriana, which
label: Paragraph

text: claim the water’s source and its regenerative capacity.
label: Paragraph

text: Scarpa called the concrete construction that shelters the sarcophagi an arcoso-
label: Paragraph

text: lium, which is an arched cell in a catacomb for the entombment of an early Chris-
label: Paragraph

text: tian martyr or prominent citizen, the tomb’s lid serving as an altar. Now
label: Paragraph

text: freestanding, the arch’s plated surface is mated with beams to bridge the depressed
label: Paragraph

text: circle upon which the sarcophagi rest. Incessant steps articulate an elaborate knuck-
label: Paragraph

text: ling and then extend horizontally in counterweight. Barely two inches, the steps
label: Paragraph

text: inflate the scale of the arcosolium, as if it were appended to miniature cities, while
label: Paragraph

text: oleaster and yew conceal the stainless steel rods that pin the knuckles to founda-
label: Paragraph

text: tions. Festooned with red roses, the arcosolium seems both heavy and light as its
label: Paragraph

text: concrete mass hovers above the ground.
label: Paragraph

text: The sarcophagi, too, are solidly constructed yet seem weightless. Their regal
label: Paragraph

text: materiality divides at ground level, white Carrara marble below and purple
label: Paragraph

text: granite above. Both marble and granite faces are enhanced with miniature step-
label: Paragraph

text: ping, and their rhomboid profiles lean toward one another in sympathy and
label: Paragraph

text: point to the arch’s apex, this gentle rocking, it would seem, afforded by the
label: Paragraph

text: sarcophagi’s curved bases. Scarpa’s preliminary plans show the circular depres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion filled with water,’® and the blue, turquoise, and gold mosaics that now line
label: Paragraph

text: the arch’s undercarriage recall the liquid effect. Linked circles reappear, the
label: Paragraph

text: gentle arch and sloped flooring approximate the almond shape that is explicit
label: Paragraph

text: in Scarpa’s earlier studies.’’ Thus described, the married couple are not buried
label: Paragraph

text: but float between sky and ground, an aquatic zone both hallowed and fertile.
label: Paragraph

text: An invitation is offered to follow the ancient custom and descend to the
label: Paragraph

text: sarcophagi’s polished ebony lids. Wood, too, is revived and bathed in aquatic
label: Paragraph

text: reflections. The lawn, it is now apparent, gently rolls as if liquid. The view is
label: Paragraph

text: framed of the funeral chapel to the west and the water pavilion to the south,
label: Caption

text: this combination reinforcing the early Christian theme of a regenerative, numi-
label: Paragraph

text: nous world.’
label: Paragraph

text: The arcosolium’s longitudinal axis suggests a detour to the family tombs. From
label: Paragraph

text: the lawn, a small four-square stair of cantilevered treads announces the descent to
label: Paragraph

text: the tomb’s depressed path of porphyry cobblestones.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to the arcosolium’s gentle curve, aquatic effects, and sympathetic
label: Paragraph

text: plantings, the family tomb is severe, arid, and barren. The tomb’s roof abstracts
label: Paragraph

text: the rocky summits of the distant Dolomites, while its heavy toppled form sits hel-
label: Paragraph

text: met-like on a thick neck. Metal rainspouts protrude from its face as if to underscore
label: Paragraph

text: concrete’s modern allegiance with fortifications and bomb shelters.'* The entrance
label: Paragraph

text: is mean, gained by ducking below the lintel to hunker against the canted perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: wall. Plaster reappears in adamant blue-black tones, its somber mood unrelieved by
label: Paragraph

text: slashes of southern clerestory light and reinforced by the scattering of memorial
label: Paragraph

text: stones. Scarpa had intended for one of the stones to collect the steady drip of rain-
label: Paragraph

text: water from the beam above,'* countering water’s regenerative capacity with its
label: Paragraph

text: entropic shadow. Even without this reminder, however, an oppressive gloom per-
label: Paragraph

text: vades the space. The path continues to the west, but seems to dead-end. The lawn
label: Paragraph

text: offers a more attractive alternative.
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel
label: Title

text: While the propylaeum wall facing the garden is horizontal, thin, and masklike, its
label: Paragraph

text: double leading to the chapel is a thick arcade. Steps reappear to define the wall as a
label: Paragraph

text: series of pilasters that recede to deeply set glass, and turn at their tops as if to define
label: Paragraph

text: capitals. These are curious pilasters, irregular in their widths and obeying a synco-
label: Paragraph

text: pated rhythm rather than a structural logic. Indeed, the pilasters do not support the
label: Paragraph

text: roof at their capitals but below them, and they lack bases as if erupting from the
label: Paragraph

text: ground rather than standing upon it. This final intimation is confirmed as
label: Paragraph

text: the arcade retreats into horizontal steps that descend into the pool from which
label: Paragraph

text: the chapel rises. Concrete maintains its crisp form, yet it seems caught in a change
label: Paragraph

text: of state, passing from solid to liquid.
label: Paragraph

text: The chapel facade reinforces these ambiguous effects with a return to confusions
label: Paragraph

text: of location, scale, and orientation. At first glance, the facade seems simple, the cha-
label: Paragraph

text: pel’s four-square organization called out by the cupola’s taller quadrant, vertical
label: Paragraph

text: formwork, and cornice. Yet, the chapel is ungrounded, rising from water and
label: Paragraph

text: doubled in reflection. Tiny windows dot the facade, fitted with alabaster lenses,
label: Paragraph

text: and coupled with stepped reveals. The windows’ doubles appear at the cornice, erod-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the wall to the sky. A simple wall flips to a vast disorienting terrain, one mirrored
label: Paragraph

text: in reflection, animated with ziggurats, and riddled with skyward views.
label: Paragraph

text: The little four-square stair marks the depressed path to the chapel. Concrete’s
label: Paragraph

text: liquefactions return as the path’s stepped retaining wall becomes the arcade’s defin-
label: Paragraph

text: ing edge that vanishes into the pool. Footsteps resonate on porphyry cobblestones
label: Paragraph

text: as the walls press in, the honorific plaster wall to the left and the arcade wall to the
label: Paragraph

text: right. Glimpses of forsythia, lilacs, and Japanese maples relieve the arcade’s com-
label: Caption

text: pression, somber acoustics, and tattoos of wood. As the arcade turns to meet the
label: Paragraph

text: chapel’s 45° rotation, the corridor expands to a small triangular vestibule that opens
label: Paragraph

text: to the funerary way to the left and a view of the arcade’s watery descent to
label: Paragraph

text: the right.
label: Paragraph

text: The wall ahead is actually a double door. Its large screen of stainless steel is inlaid
label: Paragraph

text: with white concrete panels and swings wide for coffins, while a second smaller
label: Paragraph

text: wood door set within it pivots for everyday use. Beyond the double door is a sec-
label: Paragraph

text: ond triangular space that holds an exquisite white marble font. Double circles reap-
label: Paragraph

text: pear as the holy water’s basin. While the first threshold is a door within a door, the
label: Paragraph

text: second is a frame within a frame. The defining wall is freestanding, retreating from
label: Paragraph

text: the larger chapel opening with tiny steps at its sides and sheered free from the ceil-
label: Paragraph

text: ing. Slicing through it, a large circular portal reveals the wall as a lamination of two
label: Paragraph

text: thin facings, the infill accented with a royal blue jamb and golden steps. With this
label: Paragraph

text: proliferation of doubling, the murmurings of water, and the memory of the
label: Paragraph

text: arcade’s aquatic descent, the suggestion arises that here, too, the double circles
label: Paragraph

text: might appear, again oriented vertically, the circular portal matched with its virtual
label: Paragraph

text: double in the water below. Much as the arcosolium mates earth and sky in a buoy-
label: Paragraph

text: ant aquatic zone, the chapel threshold links sky and water on a consecrated ground
label: Paragraph

text: upon which the living commemorate the dead.
label: Paragraph

text: The chapel space is simple and mated to the body. A person’s height is doubled
label: Paragraph

text: in elevation, this doubled height turns horizontal as the dimension of a square, and
label: Paragraph

text: this square, in turn, doubles twice to generate the four-square plan. Golden reflec-
label: Paragraph

text: tions from the pulpit’s muntz cladding illuminate the white marble that marks the
label: Paragraph

text: casket’s placement, this placement echoed above by the ceiling’s recapitulation of
label: Paragraph

text: the propylaeum’s concrete steps. The pulpit is centered within this most sacred
label: Paragraph

text: quadrant, pinned with a diminutive crucifix. A candelabra drifts to the side, its gen-
label: Paragraph

text: tle sway accompanied by a soft grinding, while the dark corner behind the pulpit is
label: Paragraph

text: relieved by the miniature windows glazed with translucent alabaster. Above, the
label: Caption

text: cupola extends as an inverted ziggurat that transforms lifeless concrete into pear-
label: Paragraph

text: wood’s flesh tones and strips away any scalar reference as it releases to the sky.
label: Paragraph

text: Below, the quadrant’s defining corner is relieved at the floor with double doors
label: Paragraph

text: of white concrete marked with blue and pink interlocking rings. This is, no doubt,
label: Paragraph

text: a space charged with Christian ritual, yet the affect of the upward gaze has more in
label: Paragraph

text: common with James Turrel’s skyspaces than it does with ecclesiastical architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: and the downward view is infected with the double circles’ shifting allegiances as
label: Paragraph

text: the doors open to white water lilies floating on the pool’s unfathomable depths.
label: Paragraph

text: It is telling, therefore, that a vertical gaze does not dominate the chapel else-
label: Paragraph

text: where. By doubling a person’s height, the other three quadrants set eye-level in
label: Paragraph

text: an equivalent position between floor and ceiling and encourage horizontal exten-
label: Paragraph

text: sion. The diagonal orientation of the space reinforces this bias, as does the black
label: Paragraph

text: plaster ceiling and daylight’s reflections on the porphyry pavers. Views are directed
label: Caption

text: outward not upward. Especially late in the day, sunlight catches the concrete’s
label: Paragraph

text: insistent steps at the floor to ceiling windows to the west, alternately dissolving
label: Paragraph

text: the gray concrete and casting it in deep shadow. The windows offer views to
label: Paragraph

text: the cypress grove beyond and here, too, the mood shifts with atmospheric effects.
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion
label: Title

text: Daylight beckons at the lawn where the arcosolium deflects southward to the
label: Paragraph

text: water pavilion. Tailored to the human body and comprised of a tripartite system
label: Paragraph

text: of base, columns, and hood, the pavilion, nevertheless, dodges clear connections.
label: Paragraph

text: The concrete base is wafer-thin as if it is floating on the pool, and the wood
label: Paragraph

text: hood drifts casually above. Steel columns accent this disjunction, barely distin-
label: Paragraph

text: guishable from a distance and deflecting any structural logic by sprouting from
label: Paragraph

text: the water, staggering at mid height, and pinwheeling about the hood to grab at
label: Paragraph

text: its sides.
label: Paragraph

text: Compounding these unsettling effects, a line of mosaics bisects the tall concrete
label: Paragraph

text: wall that brackets the pool and pavilion. Set at eye-level, the flickering mosaics
label: Paragraph

text: forge an equivalence of sky and water, a view unyoked from the ground. Water
label: Paragraph

text: lilies, roses, cotoneaster, and miniature bamboo animate the pool without resol-
label: Paragraph

text: ving the confusion, doubled in reflection as they float on water or drift on minia-
label: Paragraph

text: ture islands. A strange effect permeates the garden: a body and world unmoored.
label: Paragraph

text: The arcosolium’s waterway leads back to the propylaeum, where the dark
label: Paragraph

text: dampness is relieved by sunlight beyond the double circles. Footsteps echo
label: Paragraph

text: as the concrete planks leave solid ground for bridging. The honorific plastered
label: Paragraph

text: wall staggers, pressing inward, marking the pool’s edge. Only one person
label: Paragraph

text: may pass.
label: Paragraph

text: A glass door bars the way and dully reflects your image like a shade. Pressed
label: Paragraph

text: downward, the glass door slices into the water below. You step forward over your
label: Paragraph

text: image and into daylight, announced by the clanking of counterweights and the
label: Paragraph

text: whirring of pulleys. You notice that chapel and pavilion complement each other.
label: Paragraph

text: The pavilion’s wood cladding mimics the chapel’s stepped ceiling in pattern, color,
label: Paragraph

text: and effect. The hood’s light baffles have a golden sheen that mirrors that of the
label: Paragraph

text: chapel’s pulpit. The steel columns’ bundling of bar stock is akin to the bundling
label: Paragraph

text: of the chapel’s candelabra. The pavilion’s foundation, it is now apparent, is also
label: Paragraph

text: elaborately stepped and concealed beneath the water’s surface. Yet, the pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: is open and sits more lightly on its pool, which is larger than that of the chapel,
label: Paragraph

text: more varied in its plantings, and less ominous in its depths. Clearly, too, the cel-
label: Paragraph

text: ebrant is you (not the priest), your gaze is always horizontal (never vertical), and
label: Paragraph

text: honorific light is shed on the living (not the dead.)
label: Paragraph

text: You can rest, seated on an extension of a planter that holds a miniature spruce.
label: Paragraph

text: The garden presents itself: propylaeum, pool, lawn, arcosolium, and the surprise
label: Paragraph

text: gift of the boundary wall’s brace of tamarisk. Or you can stand, the hood’s low
label: Paragraph

text: green skirt limiting your view to the pool’s lush foliations. There are, also, two
label: Paragraph

text: framed standing views.
label: Paragraph

text: Small brass double circles appear at eye-level punctuating the bottom edge of the
label: Paragraph

text: north and south faces of the green skirt. Looking through these spectacles, you now
label: Paragraph

text: wear the hood, majestic and remote. To the north the view is framed of the pool,
label: Paragraph

text: lawn, arcosolium, and beyond, the town’s rooftops and church bell tower, and the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Hassan Fathy
label: Title

text: Hassan Radoine
label: Title

text: Hassan Fathy, Kharga Market inner court, New Baris, Egypt, 1967*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
