text: FROM VERNACULARISM TO REGIONALISM
label: Title

text: Unity is in variety and not in uniformity.
label: Paragraph

text: The first generation of “modern” architects who practiced between the 1930s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1970s in the Middle East was deeply influenced by what has been termed “pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gressive” architectural ideas. Viewed historically, however, their influence may not
label: Paragraph

text: have resulted in real progress. This generation, mainly graduates of European
label: Paragraph

text: schools, imported modernist architectural models to the Middle East, regardless
label: Paragraph

text: of whether they were in harmony with the local climate and culture. This should
label: Paragraph

text: have been expected, for they had taken the same stance with respect to their own
label: Paragraph

text: cultural antecedents. Traditional or vernacular architecture was perceived as a con-
label: Paragraph

text: glomeration of dead archaeological vestiges and obsolete buildings, incongruous
label: Paragraph

text: with modern times.
label: Paragraph

text: With respect to Egyptian architects specifically, Abdelbaki Ibrahim, a former
label: Paragraph

text: Chairman of the Centre of Planning and Architecture Studies (CPAS) in Cairo,
label: Paragraph

text: published an article entitled “The Architecture Circus”’ that described the work
label: Paragraph

text: of architects in some Middle Eastern countries as an attempt to manipulate
label: Paragraph

text: imported forms and building materials without any relevance to local culture or
label: Paragraph

text: environment — a circus performance that was obviously more of an entertainment
label: Paragraph

text: than a solution. Many Egyptian architects performed in this circus, he observed,
label: Paragraph

text: noting that only a few resented the attitude it expressed and tried to find ways
label: Paragraph

text: to apply values learned from the ancient soil of their own land. Of major influence
label: Paragraph

text: in the Middle East region and later worldwide, the prominent architect Hassan
label: Paragraph

text: Fathy was among this second wave of architects who shifted the paradigm of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, and offered a fresh appraisal of regional architecture, discovering in
label: Paragraph

text: it an internal dynamism and potential for change that would make it relevant
label: Paragraph

text: for contemporary times.
label: Paragraph

text: With Fathy’s project at Kharga as my point of focus, I shall try to show how his
label: Paragraph

text: work constituted a unique regional critical response to modernism, and how he
label: Paragraph

text: challenged its subsequent internationalism through a genuine reuse of regional
label: Paragraph

text: and vernacular Egyptian architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Regionalism and Internationalism in the Middle East
label: Title

text: In general terms, internationalism seeks the globalization of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to its geographical ambitions, it is a form or aestheticism that transcends
label: Paragraph

text: the individual and contextual characteristics of particular places. Despite the fact
label: Paragraph

text: that internationalism so defined seems to bear the seeds of liberty and appears
label: Paragraph

text: to free architecture from some of the negative aspects of power-heritage, it has had
label: Paragraph

text: an adverse impact on what the philosopher Paul Ricoeur called the “creative
label: Paragraph

text: nucleus” of cultures and traditions.’
label: Paragraph

text: It is often assumed that culture ought to be modernized and therefore globa-
label: Paragraph

text: lized. However, both terms are antagonistic to critical dimensions of existing con-
label: Paragraph

text: ditions. Is modernization only a question of change of tools or is it a change of a
label: Paragraph

text: culture’s “creative nucleus?” If modernization is concerned with standardizing the
label: Paragraph

text: means of building and patterns of living, which surely provide an improved stand-
label: Paragraph

text: ard comfort for the global masses, it is far from obvious how particular cultures
label: Paragraph

text: can meet the requirements of standardization in order to produce modern com-
label: Paragraph

text: fort at their particular civilizational level. Nor are the forms of modernist archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture — the aestheticism to which I referred already — adequate to the goals
label: Paragraph

text: of modernization, positive though they may be. The importation of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: forms rarely escapes the dogma of modernism and ironically fails to achieve
label: Paragraph

text: the aims of modernization.
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist architects often sought to enforce so-called rational rules on regional
label: Paragraph

text: and vernacular architecture in order to attune it to modern reason. Assumed in this
label: Paragraph

text: procedure is a judgment that labels pre-modern building practices as primitive or
label: Paragraph

text: disorderly; in other words, irrational. This assumption is sustained by the neglect of
label: Paragraph

text: local knowledge — knowledge of considerable complexity and richness that can be
label: Paragraph

text: grasped through direct contact with the people for whom the work is intended.
label: Paragraph

text: Often proposed as an alternative to the modernist stance is the regionalist position,
label: Paragraph

text: which is supposed to remedy the defects of modernism by planting its abstraction
label: Paragraph

text: in local soil, making the global local. Instead of questioning the reliability of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, the place is criticized for not being subservient to it.
label: Paragraph

text: Regionalism and modernism are thus two sides of the same coin, even if the
label: Paragraph

text: imagery of the first was proposed as a cure for the emptiness of the second. When-
label: Paragraph

text: ever the genius of a place is revealed in an architectural project, the concept of
label: Paragraph

text: regionalism is applied to situate it vis-a-vis modernism in conformity with its inter-
label: Paragraph

text: national minimalist abstraction. The abandonment ofa cultural past only generates
label: Paragraph

text: chaos in the evolutionary patterns of architecture that are intertwined with
label: Paragraph

text: embedded social and cultural fabrics.
label: Paragraph

text: In point of fact, modernism was seldom applied in the Middle East region ide-
label: Paragraph

text: ologically; rather as an evidence and outcome of a fascination with technology, its
label: Paragraph

text: tools and new forms. Alan Colquhoun’s comments on the relationships between
label: Paragraph

text: cultural patterns and technologies remain pertinent. The tensions between
label: Paragraph

text: traditions and technologies were “to some extent, obscured in the West, because
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization evolved out of local cultural traditions, and adaptation to a post-
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized culture was already quite far advanced.”* He added that “the
label: Paragraph

text: problem is glaring, however, in the East and in Africa because of the friction
label: Paragraph

text: between two worlds and two times: the agrarian and the industrial. Are cultural
label: Paragraph

text: patterns absolutely dependent on an industrial base, or can they maintain certain
label: Paragraph

text: independence? Is an industrialized culture irrevocably Eurocentric?”*
label: Title

text: The gap between imported modernism and local sustainable culture in the
label: Paragraph

text: Middle East is therefore very wide. To bridge this gap and resolve the paradox
label: Paragraph

text: it represents, a retrospective measure must be sought. Is architecture in the Middle
label: Paragraph

text: East trapped between corrective measures of its own tradition and imported rules?
label: Paragraph

text: What is lost due to modernism? And what is to be gained from sustainable cultures?
label: Paragraph

text: Unquestionably, the solution is beyond “critical regionalism.”
label: Paragraph

text: Kenneth Frampton’s description of the “universal civilization” as a victory over
label: Paragraph

text: “inflected culture” in order to advocate a “critical regionalism” is, | think, too sub-
label: Paragraph

text: jective to provide a convincing alternative.° To use Ernesto Nathan Rogers’ term
label: Paragraph

text: “formalistic aestheticism,” the “freestanding high-rise and the serpentine freeway”
label: Paragraph

text: are yet to surrender to the pre-existences of their milieu. “The context is the place
label: Paragraph

text: of these preexistences and anything that did not feel their influence would be vague
label: Paragraph

text: and indeterminate.”” When Frampton proposes “critical regionalism” as a way to
label: Paragraph

text: counter-balance “sentimental regionalism,” it seems that he creates a vicious cycle
label: Paragraph

text: rather than a solution to the dilemma. If regionalism stems from a rectification of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, then on what new basis does Frampton suggest the pursuit of this new
label: Paragraph

text: approach? When referring to Alex Tzonis and Liliane Lefaivre in the “Grid and the
label: Paragraph

text: Pathway,” (1981) it is essential to state that regionalism has not dominated “archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture in almost all countries at some time during the past two centuries and a
label: Paragraph

text: half’® but rather it is a specific architecture that has dominated all regions with
label: Paragraph

text: monotonous aesthetics, widening the time gap between people and their built envi-
label: Paragraph

text: ronment. When this time gap persists confusion prevails, making a sense of place
label: Paragraph

text: irrecoverable.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture is among the key vehicles of memory and place that translates
label: Paragraph

text: communal, spiritual, and environmental elements to living contexts. Hassan
label: Paragraph

text: Fathy’s legacy is thus pertinent to this discussion, as he attempted to bridge this
label: Paragraph

text: gap and provide a genuine sense of a communal space. Applying regional materials
label: Paragraph

text: and forms and activating the dormant memory of know-how, he was able to
label: Paragraph

text: generate a regional response to imported, international, and abstract architecture
label: Paragraph

text: that attempted neither to resolve the dichotomy of modern versus regional, nor
label: Paragraph

text: depend on architectural ideas and techniques alone. His model and contribution
label: Paragraph

text: to what may be termed a “constructive and intuitive regionalism” grounds archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture in its milieu without positioning it against modern forms. Nor was his work
label: Paragraph

text: “essentialist.” Fathy’s constructive regionalism went far beyond a simple rejection of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism or a sheer submission to tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: The Birth of a Regional Architect
label: Title

text: Hassan Fathy was born in Alexandria in 1900 and died in 1989 in Cairo. He grad-
label: Paragraph

text: uated as an architect in 1926 from Cairo University, where he also taught (1930-46).
label: Paragraph

text: He designed around 160 projects. The key project that displayed his painstaking
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to achieve an affordable and regional architecture was the New Gourna
label: Paragraph

text: design of 1946, which relocated villagers living in dwellings built over tombs to
label: Paragraph

text: constructions built entirely out of mud.
label: Paragraph

text: Fathy felt that during the critical periods of colonization and World War II the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural crisis in Egypt was due to an extraneous architecture that dictated
label: Paragraph

text: materials, costs, and politics that were far beyond the capacities of Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: resources, builders, and citizens. In response he devoted his whole career to the
label: Paragraph

text: development of a regional architecture that would derive solutions from affordable
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular materials and methods. Although the Egyptian government did not
label: Paragraph

text: recognize his efforts and his New Gourna project faced several issues of implemen-
label: Paragraph

text: tation, his ideas were well received internationally by the 1970s as one genuine
label: Paragraph

text: answer to dilemmas of high modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: His intuitive regionalism started with a childhood fascination with the country-
label: Paragraph

text: side and rural areas. The landscape of his youth inspired him to conceive of an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture suitable to the peasant’s way of life. In The Architecture for the Poor,
label: Paragraph

text: he wrote, “This ... wish had deep roots, going back to my childhood. I had always
label: Paragraph

text: had a deep love for the country, but it was a love for an idea, not for something
label: Paragraph

text: I really knew. The country, the place where the fellaheen [peasants] lived...”” The
label: Paragraph

text: pursuit of this idea by Fathy was translated later by the term ‘sustainability’ of
label: Paragraph

text: nature and place. In order to preserve the building tradition and communal living,
label: Paragraph

text: he vehemently defended the use of local materials and local building typologies. He
label: Paragraph

text: believed the ancestral crafts are affordable to the peasant and adequate to his
label: Paragraph

text: natural milieu. Regarding his earthen village, New Gourna, Fathy wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Besides the man-made environment of Gourna, with which the village would have to
label: Paragraph

text: harmonize, there is the natural environment of landscape, flora, and fauna.
label: Paragraph

text: A traditional architecture would have accommodated itself to this natural environ-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, both visually and practically, over many centuries. The new village would
label: Paragraph

text: have to tone with this environment from the very beginning, and its buildings must
label: Paragraph

text: look as if they were the product of centuries of tradition...'°
label: Paragraph

text: Following this line of constructive regionalism, Christian Norberg-Schulz later
label: Paragraph

text: argued for the importance of nature and place in the creation of a sustainable sense
label: Paragraph

text: of belonging, particularly his search for Genius Loci, by referring to local and
label: Paragraph

text: traditional forms.”? Yet, the position of Fathy vis-a-vis nature and place was more
label: Paragraph

text: for reestablishing continuity with a lost tradition, as he stated: “The tradition is lost,
label: Paragraph

text: and we have been cut off from our past ... This gap of continuity in Egyptian tra-
label: Paragraph

text: dition has been felt by many people and all sorts of remedies have been
label: Paragraph

text: proposed.”!
label: Paragraph

text: In his pursuit of a regional architecture Fathy inclines more toward sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: technical and practical innovation than the emotional revival of tradition by explor-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the techniques of construction and generating essential forms. He subsequently
label: Paragraph

text: created an intrinsic contemporary design through the fertilization of the peasant’s
label: Paragraph

text: memory of skills. Fathy distanced himself from archaeological mimicry by
label: Paragraph

text: discerning real possibilities within the contemporary world. He nuanced his posi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion by stating: “We condemn contemporaneity in architecture as decorative archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural details such as mukarnassat, arches, or musharabiat. This is an
label: Paragraph

text: archaeological view that is very far from the concept of architecture, which is based
label: Paragraph

text: on the principles of design.”’’ Fathy pushed the dynamic regional design process to
label: Paragraph

text: explore sustainable elements, as they responded to climate, landscape, local mate-
label: Paragraph

text: rials, culture, and nature. He consequently challenged the inability of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as a sophisticated building process to produce a more genuine com-
label: Paragraph

text: munal physical context. As with the writings of John Ruskin, his position in The
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture for the Poor is essentially ethical. He attempted to expose the ways that
label: Paragraph

text: modern and imported practices were isolated from the spirit of people and
label: Paragraph

text: their place.
label: Paragraph

text: It was perhaps for this reason — rather than his specific forms and solutions — that
label: Paragraph

text: Fathy became very influential both in Egypt and abroad, and that his teachings gen-
label: Paragraph

text: erated a school of thought that attracted numerous followers in the Middle East, an
label: Paragraph

text: example of which is Abdel Wahid Wakil in Egypt. He was indeed among the very
label: Paragraph

text: few regional architects who stirred international interest. J. M. Richards observed
label: Paragraph

text: that “news of Hassan Fathy’s enterprises and beliefs in Egypt first reached the
label: Paragraph

text: Western World, perhaps not coincidently, just as concern was becoming wide-
label: Paragraph

text: spread about the growing gap between what technology claimed to do for human
label: Paragraph

text: welfare and what it was actually achieving in buildings that answered the needs of
label: Paragraph

text: ordinary people...”’* Richards added that “Their philosophy [the philosophy of
label: Paragraph

text: high modernism] required a total break with the past, whereas Fathy has looked
label: Paragraph

text: always for continuity. The modernists’ break with the past proved disastrous to
label: Paragraph

text: the relationship between architecture and the public.” Fathy’s purpose as not,
label: Paragraph

text: however, polemical. He did not waste his time attacking modernists, but
label: Paragraph

text: devoted himself to working with his own people, heritage, and environment in
label: Paragraph

text: order to realize sustainable design solutions. More than ethical, his mission was
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual:
label: Title

text: Ifthe architect does not respect the God-made environment, he commits a sin against
label: Paragraph

text: God. The God-made environment is the landscape, the atmosphere, the flora, the
label: Paragraph

text: fauna, and the human beings who live in this environment. In this God-made envi-
label: Paragraph

text: ronment there is nothing that is inharmonious. If we become one with nature, beauty
label: Paragraph

text: is defined as it is. Beauty, then is obtained when form considers the forces that are
label: Paragraph

text: working on it.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the criticism that his New Gourna project did not work well because it
label: Paragraph

text: was difficult to convince tomb dwellers to move there — mainly because it meant
label: Paragraph

text: ending their trade in stolen treasures — it remains a unique experiment at a time
label: Paragraph

text: when regionalism was seen as an arriere-garde and modernism as the avant-garde.
label: Paragraph

text: Far from impeding progressive tendencies, this project inspired several action
label: Paragraph

text: groups: ADAUA, Craterre, and Development Workshop.
label: Paragraph

text: Kharga Oasis and Bariz village
label: Title

text: Kharga is a town in the western desert of Egypt. It contains different villages,
label: Paragraph

text: including Bariz where the Desert Development Organization (D.D.O) commis-
label: Paragraph

text: sioned Fathy in 1963 to design a new community village (New Bariz, where Kharga
label: Paragraph

text: Market is located). It is a rural housing project that aimed at creating a new com-
label: Paragraph

text: munity around a newly discovered well with a potential of irrigation of 1,000 acres.
label: Paragraph

text: As stated by Fathy, “this enterprise would need scientific research to be done and
label: Paragraph

text: pilot projects to be carried out to ensure the success of this most important enter-
label: Paragraph

text: prise for redressing the ecological balance in the country.”'® Projected to be the
label: Paragraph

text: core of a new town, the Bariz urban center was designed to serve a population
label: Paragraph

text: of 5,000 to 10,000 people.
label: Paragraph

text: Learning from the mistakes of his Gourna project that he had designed 20 years
label: Paragraph

text: before, Fathy planned this project from scratch with a totally new population and a
label: Paragraph

text: new program. Although there was no man-made environment on the site of the
label: Paragraph

text: project, Fathy recognized that he was “...not freed from the constraints imposed
label: Paragraph

text: on the designer by respecting the work of this predecessors in the area, and Bariz
label: Paragraph

text: should be a continuity of human response to the natural environment.”’” Referring
label: Paragraph

text: to local know-how, Fathy sought the contemporary engineering skills of scientists
label: Paragraph

text: from Egyptian universities, mainly in soil studies and structural research, in order
label: Paragraph

text: to evaluate the ancestral techniques to be explored in his new large-scope project.
label: Paragraph

text: A full understanding of the social and cultural milieu, supported by the technical
label: Paragraph

text: and engineering expertise, enabled him to create a truly human-scale architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: and one that answered both traditional and contemporary expectations. Contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary public spaces, for example, were accommodated by mud-brick vaults and
label: Paragraph

text: domes, traditional in form and construction but contemporary in dimension
label: Paragraph

text: and use.
label: Paragraph

text: The layout of the new village of Bariz was inspired from the neighboring old
label: Paragraph

text: mud settlements that had existed for long periods of time and were able to with-
label: Paragraph

text: stand the harsh desert climate. Without duplicating verbatim the existing old
label: Paragraph

text: Kharga fabrics, Fathy resorted to drawing lessons and interpreting techniques of
label: Paragraph

text: sustaining this context in a contemporary manner. The key factors taken into con-
label: Paragraph

text: sideration by Fathy according to his accounts’* were:
label: Paragraph

text: 1 Climate and airflow considerations were crucial in order to protect the site and
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants from harsh climate changes as well as to prevent harm to their
label: Paragraph

text: bodies due to high desert temperatures (that reach 48 °C), exceeding by far
label: Paragraph

text: the norms of thermal comfort. In the design process Fathy tried to integrate
label: Paragraph

text: natural cooling and insulation against hot air by exploring traditional methods
label: Paragraph

text: in a contemporary architectural envelope. His elements included musharabiyat
label: Paragraph

text: (latticework) and badgeers (wind catchers). In addition to mud and brick walls,
label: Paragraph

text: the size of shaded areas created a reasonable indoor thermal comfort for inha-
label: Paragraph

text: bitants in the whole village.
label: Paragraph

text: 2 Demographic factors were also important. In contrast to his project at Gourna
label: Paragraph

text: in Cairo, Fathy did not know his clients and had to design based only on factual
label: Paragraph

text: and numerical statistics. This challenge made the project an abstract design
label: Paragraph

text: process of creating a virtual village that never existed. However, Fathy’s con-
label: Paragraph

text: cern about the human factor was key to designing a settlement for an organic
label: Paragraph

text: community, based on balancing activities and reaching a certain economic self-
label: Paragraph

text: sufficiency.
label: Paragraph

text: 3 Aesthetic factors were also significant. The design of housing units were related
label: Paragraph

text: to likely users and were not duplicated for the sake of quantity, as family lives
label: Paragraph

text: were dissimilar in terms of size, wealth, and social status. Neighborhood units
label: Paragraph

text: encompassed houses of different needs and created a sense of community in
label: Paragraph

text: one semi-public place.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to these factors, Fathy treated his village as a small urban entity
label: Paragraph

text: where all urban facilities and amenities were provided in order to encourage
label: Paragraph

text: new inhabitants to settle and not migrate to more urban centers in Egypt. These
label: Paragraph

text: facilities, centered in the core area of the village, included schools, a crafts center, a
label: Paragraph

text: cultural center, a self-sufficient construction center (for the training of local
label: Paragraph

text: masons), an agricultural co-operation center, a Turkish bath, a grocery center, a
label: Paragraph

text: hospital, a mosque, and a central market. It was the vibrant heart of the village with
label: Paragraph

text: services and commerce, planned to engender social interaction at different times of
label: Paragraph

text: the day, week and year according to secular or spiritual needs.
label: Paragraph

text: Among those buildings that deserve close attention is the market. This is a stra-
label: Paragraph

text: tegic function in the complex of activities that seeks to create the village’s auton-
label: Paragraph

text: omy in an isolated and harsh desert environment.
label: Paragraph

text: Kharga Market
label: Title

text: The market of Kharga is located in the western central part of the urban core of
label: Paragraph

text: Bariz village in a compound of public buildings surrounding a number of large
label: Paragraph

text: courtyards that bind them all. Except for the building of the mosque, the plan
label: Paragraph

text: of which is twisted in order to face the orientation of prayer (qibla), all other build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings including the market are oriented north with regular orthogonal layouts.
label: Paragraph

text: In order to understand the architecture of Kharga Market it is critical not to
label: Paragraph

text: isolate its plan form from the building’s constructional and structural logic and
label: Paragraph

text: purpose; more specifically, the technology of the building’s envelope and details.
label: Paragraph

text: The complexity of Fathy’s architecture in the market resides in the fact that the
label: Paragraph

text: construction and sculpting of the building’s form was based on the craft techniques
label: Paragraph

text: of mud-brick construction. The structural systems generated essential forms
label: Paragraph

text: without any camouflage or illusion that would hide the skeleton of construction.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan consists of a large central courtyard around which all other spaces are
label: Paragraph

text: planned. Domes and vaults define the spaces as much as walls. The intriguing
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of this way of building and arranging spaces is that all of them are connected
label: Paragraph

text: with a circulation circuit that travels throughout the entire ensemble without any
label: Paragraph

text: sense of rupture. Ease and continuity of passage were considerations in this layout,
label: Paragraph

text: but so were other kinds of movement as well. Thermal comfort was achieved
label: Paragraph

text: through the circulation of cooling air along the focal and linear spaces. Structural
label: Paragraph

text: integrity was achieved through the association of domes and vaults that worked
label: Paragraph

text: together to form a cohesive structural ensemble.
label: Paragraph

text: The functions vary in different parts of the building. They range from a series of
label: Paragraph

text: linear shops along one covered passage in the northern aisle to a coffee shop in the
label: Paragraph

text: left side that serves as a large public area for gathering. This covered passage
label: Paragraph

text: extends to an outside palm courtyard that orients the walker to the adjacent mos-
label: Paragraph

text: que ina natural way. It also links the market building, through extending its domed
label: Paragraph

text: walkway, to the northern administrative building. The southern aisle, on the other
label: Caption

text: hand, is divided into sections, some for food storage and others for related shops.
label: Paragraph

text: The divisions within this aisle permit the positioning staircases that lead to the sec-
label: Paragraph

text: ond floor and upper terraces. The outside passageway on this side of the building is
label: Paragraph

text: articulated through a series of continuous domes along the outside porticos that
label: Paragraph

text: engender a special spatial and visual experience for the passerby. The lateral spaces
label: Paragraph

text: of the building are more for services, enclosed and covered by the same structural
label: Paragraph

text: elements used elsewhere.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the subdivision of the market building into several functional parts, its
label: Paragraph

text: massing creates a coherent architectural complex with a clear sense of human scale.
label: Paragraph

text: The complex has an aerodynamic outside form due to the curvilinear shapes of
label: Paragraph

text: long vaults and central domes that are ideal for dispersing strong desert winds
label: Paragraph

text: as well as sandy storms. A sense of massiveness — that could easily have resulted
label: Paragraph

text: from the use of thick walls and load-bearing brick work — is avoided because of the
label: Paragraph

text: ways macro and micro forms are careful handled as structural elements, which in
label: Paragraph

text: some cases even become ornamental elements. This is obvious mainly in the out-
label: Paragraph

text: side gates and external facades, whose austerity and simplicity present several
label: Paragraph

text: arched openings filled with musharabiyyat (lattice work) that have both functional
label: Paragraph

text: and aesthetic dimensions — controlling the air, presenting geometries, and playing
label: Paragraph

text: with the light that permeates from outside to inside.
label: Paragraph

text: The overall form of the market building grows out of and expresses human
label: Paragraph

text: movements and comfort. These expressions are enhanced by the effects of
label: Paragraph

text: controlled lighting that temper the shaded areas, allowing light to trickle through.
label: Paragraph

text: Maximum visibility is achieved, without disturbing the interior visual experience,
label: Paragraph

text: due to the strong desert sunshine.
label: Paragraph

text: A combination of traditional and modern methods is also apparent in the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing’s structural system. Mud brick construction is in evidence, but so too are large
label: Paragraph

text: spans and complex configurations. Fathy’s knowledge of craft traditions was
label: Paragraph

text: formative, but it was augmented by his knowledge of the outcomes of recent
label: Paragraph

text: research in soil mechanics and building materials, undertaken in the engineering
label: Paragraph

text: departments of Egyptian universities. New to the landscape — because of its size
label: Paragraph

text: and composition — the market seems, nevertheless, to have arisen from the ground
label: Paragraph

text: on which it stands, as if it were akin to the buildings from the neighboring desert
label: Paragraph

text: villages that had inspired the project in the first place.
label: Paragraph

text: Conclusion
label: Title

text: The architecture of Hassan Fathy presents a unique alternative to abstract modern-
label: Paragraph

text: ism. He discovered ways to meet the needs and desires of people within a particular
label: Paragraph

text: region through the modernization of their visual and cultural anchors. Fathy never
label: Paragraph

text: said that he followed modernism, regionalism, or other contemporary architectural
label: Paragraph

text: trends. Instead, he explored regional conditions in situ through an intuitive search
label: Paragraph

text: for an architecture that would be suitable for people living under contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: conditions. The result cannot easily be canonized though attempts of researchers
label: Paragraph

text: to locate its vocabulary in the modern era.
label: Paragraph

text: However, this work does present a new regional architectural discourse, one
label: Paragraph

text: that goes beyond the conventional “regionalism” and “critical regionalism,”
label: Paragraph

text: proposing instead what I have called “constructive regionalism.” It is a way of
label: Paragraph

text: working that situates the inner forces of a region in order to appreciate its unique-
label: Paragraph

text: ness, history, culture, heritage, and geography, a constructive regionalism that was
label: Paragraph

text: germinated out of a place and not dictated by it, generative of its own idioms and
label: Paragraph

text: not corrective of failed modern ones. Thus, Hassan Fathy provides us with a new
label: Paragraph

text: way to define the regionalist position, an imperative for appraising the large num-
label: Paragraph

text: ber of competitions and projects launched under the umbrella of this unfathomed
label: Paragraph

text: concept in the whole Middle East.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
