label: Paragraph

text: According to one eyewitness, Polytechnic alumnus John Outram, Polygon was
label: Paragraph

text: the progenitor of the Archigram magazine, founded in 1961 by recent graduates
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Cook, Michael Webb, David Greene, Ron Herron, Warren Chalk, and
label: Title

text: Dennis Crompton.° In their first issue, they declared that the magazine would
label: Paragraph

text: be devoted to “the outlook of the new Generation of Architecture” in its quest
label: Paragraph

text: for “an aesthetic original to the mood.” And in the second (1962), they published
label: Paragraph

text: their first definitive statement on the question of style as it pertained to popular
label: Paragraph

text: culture. Cook, for example, claimed that the inspiration behind Bowellism was
label: Paragraph

text: not the biomorphic architecture of Gaudi, Kiesler, or Mendelsohn, but the psychol-
label: Paragraph

text: ogy of mass media. “The “Dan Dare’ quality these buildings have,” he wrote,
label: Paragraph

text: “springs from their common involvement with Dan Dare’s psychology — with that
label: Paragraph

text: of Superman, Lunar architecture and shredded wheat, and in physical terms, with
label: Paragraph

text: that of the radiator grille and the launching pad.”” By 1964, they dedicated their
label: Paragraph

text: fourth issue, “Zoom,” to the space comic, and produced their first iconic projects:
label: Paragraph

text: Plug-In City, Walking City, and Computer City. These projects evoked visionary
label: Paragraph

text: cities of the future inspired by popular images of technology, gleaned from the
label: Paragraph

text: pages of science-fiction comics, Life Magazine, and Paris-Match.*
label: Paragraph

text: Besides referencing mass media, classic projects such as Plug-In City also donned
label: Paragraph

text: features of anew urban typology called the megastructure: a large framework sup-
label: Paragraph

text: porting infrastructure and plug-in housing components that could be interchanged
label: Paragraph

text: as consumer needs changed. Early instances of this postwar typology include Yona
label: Paragraph

text: Friedman’s Mobile City (1957), Kiyonori Kikutake’s Floating City (1959), and
label: Paragraph

text: Kenzo Tange’s Tokyo Bay (1961).’ Along with Webb’s Furniture Building, these
label: Paragraph

text: and other megastructures, which had emerged at the margins of high modernism
label: Paragraph

text: in response to the twin specters of world population growth and rapid urbanization
label: Paragraph

text: appeared in a MoMA exhibition in 1960 on “Visionary Architecture” and in a special
label: Paragraph

text: issue of L’Architecture d’aujourd’hui (June-July 1962) on “Fantastic Architecture.”'°
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram further legitimized the movement, publishing their own special issue on
label: Paragraph

text: the megastructure phenomenon in an attempt to define its formal characteristics.
label: Paragraph

text: In Archigram 5 on the “Metropolis” (Autumn 1964), Cook classified the megastruc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture’s “crumbly aesthetic” according to formal attributes such as “crusts,”
label: Paragraph

text: “molehills,” and “mounds.” He observed that the dominant orientation of
label: Paragraph

text: multi-level circulation was not the horizontal or vertical but the diagonal.'’ And
label: Paragraph

text: he compared the mythical and figurative City Study (1962) by newcomers, Hans
label: Paragraph

text: Hollein and Walter Pichler, with nineteenth-century utopias, specifically Tony
label: Paragraph

text: Gamnier’s Cité industrielle and Piranesi’s prison studies.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, by 1964 Archigram had sealed their reputation at home and abroad. But
label: Paragraph

text: despite their fame, few historians saw their contribution to the ongoing problem of
label: Paragraph

text: style with the same regard they held for the likes of Louis Kahn, Alison and Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Smithson, or James Stirling. Neither Giedion, nor Pevsner, nor Rowe, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: saw much value in either their pop aesthetic or their interest in the megastructure,
label: Paragraph

text: but the exception that proved the rule was Banham, whose definition of style con-
label: Paragraph

text: fronted what many saw as modernism’s midlife crisis with functionalism. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: Pevsner or Rowe, however, Banham ’s thesis did not go against functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: per se, but more precisely, against an overly narrow definition of it. Indeed, for
label: Paragraph

text: Banham, what was missing from contemporary practice was modern architecture’s
label: Paragraph

text: capacity to symbolically express its intimate relation with technology. As he stated
label: Paragraph

text: in Theory and Design in the First Machine Age (1959): “The true aim of the style [in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s] had clearly been, to quote Gropius’ words about the Bauhaus and its relation
label: Paragraph

text: to the world of the Machine Age: *...to invent and create forms symbolizing that
label: Paragraph

text: world.’ And it is in respect of such symbolic forms that its historical justification
label: Paragraph

text: must lie.”’?
label: Paragraph

text: Reyner Banham’s Influence
label: Title

text: Banham’s definition of style in terms of symbolic expression certainly corresponded
label: Paragraph

text: with Archigram’s preoccupation with “an aesthetic original to the mood.””* But a
label: Paragraph

text: deeper look reveals a key difference between them. While Banham argued for a
label: Paragraph

text: strong indexical relation between a building’s symbolic expression and its technical
label: Paragraph

text: performance, Archigram, on the other hand, tended to reify modern technology into
label: Paragraph

text: an image. As Banham himself stated, “Archigram is short on theory, long on
label: Paragraph

text: draughtsmanship and craftsmanship. They’re in the image business and they have
label: Paragraph

text: been blessed with the power to create some of the most compelling images of
label: Paragraph

text: our time.”"* Notwithstanding this difference, however, Banham’s influence on Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: gram proved considerable due, in part, to his involvement in the 1950s with the Inde-
label: Paragraph

text: pendent Group, the so-called “Fathers of Pop.”’’ So when they finally met each other
label: Paragraph

text: in 1964, he would again profoundly influence Archigram’s pursuit of style.
label: Paragraph

text: The Second World War had brought about enormous technological change in
label: Paragraph

text: the built environment, and cognizant of these transformations, Banham lamented
label: Paragraph

text: the growing division between form and function: “the idea that architecture
label: Title

text: belongs in one place and technology in another.”’® Moreover, in his view, the true
label: Paragraph

text: significance of this shift from “weaponry to livingry,” as Buckminster Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: famously put it, was that they had broadened the purview of architecture from
label: Paragraph

text: the simple matter of shelter to environmental control or “the provision of fit envir-
label: Paragraph

text: onments for human activities.” For Banham this definition meant that the origins of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture began not with the cave or primitive hut, but with clothing (“the first
label: Paragraph

text: furs worn by our earliest ancestors”) and the discovery of fire.'’ From a historical
label: Paragraph

text: perspective, he praised the buildings of Frank Lloyd Wright for inventively incor-
label: Paragraph

text: porating mechanical services, and saw contemporary relevance in Fuller’s work,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly his proposal for a “standard-of-living package,” a portable service unit
label: Paragraph

text: that could be clipped on to any building.
label: Paragraph

text: In Banham’s view, then, technologies of environmental control (climatology)
label: Paragraph

text: had far more implications for modern architecture than traditional design
label: Paragraph

text: principles or even new construction techniques.'* Borrowing Fuller’s idea of a
label: Paragraph

text: standard-of- living package, he believed that the mechanization of the total environ-
label: Paragraph

text: ment would revolutionize domesticity, and speculated that one day architecture
label: Paragraph

text: would no longer need to be fixed, heavy, and permanent, but portable, lightweight,
label: Paragraph

text: and variable. In his seminal essay, “A Home is not a House,” he described a mobile
label: Paragraph

text: environment unencumbered by all that is solid and pondered whether we might
label: Paragraph

text: live in pneumatic bubbles, an idea that came to him at a campus beach in Southern
label: Paragraph

text: Illinois.’? For Banham, the standard-of living package was the modern equivalent
label: Paragraph

text: of the campfire, “breathing out warm air..., radiating soft light and Dionne
label: Paragraph

text: Warwick in heart-warming stereo, with well-aged protein turning in an infra-
label: Paragraph

text: red glow in the rotisserie, and the ice-maker discreetly coughing cubes into glasses
label: Paragraph

text: on the swing-out bar.””°
label: Paragraph

text: Upon the publication of “A Home is not a House” in 1965, Archigram shifted
label: Paragraph

text: their attention from the megastructure to the portable environment.”’ This shift
label: Paragraph

text: is evident in Archigram 6 (1965), which featured pneumatic structures made by
label: Paragraph

text: American companies for use as warehouses. While the magazine still highlighted
label: Paragraph

text: the odd megastructure, including one by future High Tech architect, Nicholas
label: Paragraph

text: Grimshaw, the Archigram group nevertheless questioned the need for fixed struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tures. In the editorial, Cook asked: “Do we still need houses when we have the
label: Paragraph

text: ability to evolve the complete environment, completely sustained, and infinite vari-
label: Paragraph

text: ety within?” This desire for greater portability and flexibility was further under-
label: Paragraph

text: scored in Archigram 7, which featured a computer motherboard on its cover in
label: Paragraph

text: homage to electronics and miniaturization. In 1966, Webb proposed his first stand-
label: Paragraph

text: ard-of-living packages as clothing and rucksack in the Suitaloon and the Cushicle,
label: Paragraph

text: respectively. And these personalized and deployable environments were followed
label: Paragraph

text: by a series of nomadic scenarios premised on the idea of open networks: the
label: Paragraph

text: Moment Village (1968), Instant City (1970) and L.A.W.U.N. (the acronym for
label: Paragraph

text: “Locally Available Worldwide Unseen Networks,” 1970).
label: Paragraph

text: Image versus Sign
label: Title

text: Archigram’s pop aesthetic and portable environments gave rise to some of the most
label: Paragraph

text: compelling images of the day. In Austria, Hollein, Pichler, and Giinther Feuerstein
label: Paragraph

text: curated their own Archigram-inspired issue of the magazine, Bau (1965), filling its
label: Paragraph

text: pages with a cornucopia of images from pop art, aerospace technologies, the post-
label: Paragraph

text: industrial landscape, and visionary projects, including Archigram’s Walking City
label: Paragraph

text: and Hollein’s collages, aptly called Transformations. Just as Chalk had transformed
label: Paragraph

text: the Manhattan skyline with his giant, mechanical insects, Hollein metamorphosed
label: Paragraph

text: an aircraft carrier into a picturesque monument on the Austrian hills. Inspired by
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram’s example, new groups and little magazines popped up across Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: and architectural students in Austria, France, and Italy invented their own standard-
label: Paragraph

text: of-living packages: enviro-helmuts (Coop Himmelblau), simulated environments
label: Paragraph

text: (Hollein), and tropical oases in plastic bubbles (Haus Rticker Co). These counter-
label: Paragraph

text: environments were not confined to the drawing board, but were built and
label: Paragraph

text: deployed as installations in galleries or as agitprops in the streets.”
label: Paragraph

text: While Hollein and Pichler’s 1962 manifesto, “Absolute Architecture,” spoke of
label: Paragraph

text: the sublime purposelessness of symbolic expression illustrated by their City
label: Paragraph

text: Study, Hollein’s 1969 statement, “Everything is Architecture,” echoed Banham’s
label: Paragraph

text: thesis on environmental control;”* although here it applied to the psychological
label: Paragraph

text: realm rather than the physical. “From a primitive being, [man] has continually
label: Paragraph

text: expanded himself by means of media,” wrote Hollein; “new media of environ-
label: Paragraph

text: mental determination emerge ... Environments of this kind ... are ... the helmets
label: Paragraph

text: of jet pilots who, through telecommunications, expand their senses.””’ To this
label: Paragraph

text: end, Hollein proffered that “nonmaterial means (like light, temperature or
label: Paragraph

text: smell)” will soon replace steel and concrete, and for his design of the Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion at the 14th Milan Triennale in 1968, he built a series of parallel passage-
label: Paragraph

text: ways that simulated different kinds of atmospheres: snowstorm, crowding, iso-
label: Paragraph

text: lation, and frustration. “[S]paces will more consciously have haptic, optic and
label: Paragraph

text: acoustic properties, and contain informational effects while directly expressing
label: Paragraph

text: emotional needs,” he stated.”®
label: Paragraph

text: The Italian radicals proposed their own counter-environments, but in so doing,
label: Paragraph

text: their projects often struck an ironic note. In a 1966 studio project called Luna Park
label: Paragraph

text: (1966), for example, students at the University of Florence collaged Webb’s Furni-
label: Paragraph

text: ture Factory into the scene as a single component in their mega-megastructure.””
label: Paragraph

text: Led by Leonardo Savioli, the studio spawned the groups Archizoom and Superstu-
label: Paragraph

text: dio, who had come across their first Archigram issue at a Florentine bookshop in
label: Paragraph

text: 1966. As latecomers to the megastructure, they pushed the logic of Archigram’s
label: Paragraph

text: thesis (following Banham) on environmental control to an extreme — to the point
label: Paragraph

text: of dreamlands or impossible utopias. In No-Stop City, Archizoom presented an
label: Paragraph

text: ironic image of a nomadic leisure environment in the context of the American
label: Paragraph

text: supermarket.”* And in “Twelve Cautionary Tales for Christmas,” Superstudio pro-
label: Paragraph

text: posed ideal cities as both utopia and dystopia, and concluded their visual essay with
label: Paragraph

text: a witty questionnaire meant to shock the reader out of their dream reality.”” Their
label: Paragraph

text: older comrade, Ettore Sottsass, told similar tales of a utopian/dystopian world
label: Paragraph

text: beyond work. In “The Planet as a Festival,” Sottsass contrasted colorful drawings
label: Paragraph

text: of a domed stadium for rock concerts in the desert and a temple for erotic dancers,
label: Paragraph

text: with black-and-white drawings of a giant pasta machine rolling out Italian sports
label: Paragraph

text: cars and the Walking City transformed into a monumental ruin, as if to present
label: Paragraph

text: the reader with an ambiguous either/or proposition.”°
label: Paragraph

text: These delectable parodies register the changing mood at the end of the 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: from the technological optimism of mass-consumer culture to the critical utopia
label: Title

text: that challenged the capitalist assumptions on which that optimism was based. They
label: Paragraph

text: resonated with student protest movements, which spread across Europe after May
label: Paragraph

text: 68. At the 14th Milan Triennale (1968), for example, students occupied the
label: Paragraph

text: grounds, holding placards that read: “Designers for Containers of Napalm.”*?
label: Paragraph

text: While the Italian radicals escaped heavy criticism from the Marxist left, Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: gram fared less well and their magazine survived only one and a half issues after the
label: Paragraph

text: heady events of 1968. Although they had earlier positioned themselves firmly
label: Paragraph

text: against the architectural establishment, their critique apparently did not extend
label: Paragraph

text: far enough to the military industrial complex that had produced the Second
label: Paragraph

text: Machine Age. Consequently, in a report on student activism at the Ecole des
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts, Martin Pawley and Bernard Tschumi noted that Archigram’s brand
label: Paragraph

text: of radicalism paled in comparison to the militant UP6 students “who work on
label: Paragraph

text: building sites, go to prison for spraying slogans on walls, build community centers
label: Paragraph

text: for immigrant laborers, float newspapers demanding ‘EVERYTHING’, invade the
label: Paragraph

text: offices of government ministers, hold lectures in the Louvre, department stores, or
label: Paragraph

text: the street.”’? Banham, for his part, reacted with indifference, but nevertheless
label: Paragraph

text: understood the Marxist critique of the fiction of flexibility and individual choice.
label: Paragraph

text: “When the Left finally began to mount cogent criticism of [the] megastructure,”
label: Paragraph

text: he wrote, “it was with arguments that probably derive from the neo-Marxism
label: Paragraph

text: of Herbert Marcuse, maintaining that the permissive freedoms offered by [the]
label: Paragraph

text: megastructure’s adaptability and internal transiences were illusory, since all they
label: Paragraph

text: involved were choices between different products offered by the capitalist system’s
label: Paragraph

text: supermarkets.””’
label: Paragraph

text: This commentary appeared in a historical survey on the megastructure, which
label: Paragraph

text: Banham wrote in an attempt to comprehend why the visionary projects of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s had passed into oblivion so quickly. In Megastructure, Urban Futures of the
label: Paragraph

text: Recent Past (1976), he identified their high point with 1964, coinciding with the pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lication of Archigram’s Plug-in City, but mentioned only briefly the countercultural
label: Paragraph

text: projects of the Italians. Perhaps one reason for this inattention is that their ironic
label: Paragraph

text: projects went against his very definition of style and had turned the idea of sym-
label: Paragraph

text: bolic expression into a mere sign. Ever a critic of postmodernism, Banham
label: Paragraph

text: remained true to his convictions before and after May ’68, and never quite forsook
label: Paragraph

text: the indexical relation between form and function for the ironies of semiology.**
label: Paragraph

text: This fact is evident in Banham’s well-known admiration for High Tech. For
label: Paragraph

text: Banham, the true heir of Archigram’s Plug-In City was not so much the coun-
label: Paragraph

text: ter-environments but the Pompidou Center in Paris by Richard Rogers and Renzo
label: Caption

text: Piano, precisely because it put back together what postmodernism tore apart:
label: Paragraph

text: style’s intimate relation with technical performance.”’ In his appraisal of modern-
label: Paragraph

text: ism’s now anachronistic reappearance in High Tech, Banham wrote in 1979:
label: Paragraph

text: The collapse of the Modern Movement, when it finally happened, proved not to be as
label: Paragraph

text: much fun as had been anticipated. The brave new Post-Modern world...coincided
label: Paragraph

text: with an economic recession that left the new avant/arriére-garde impotent to build.
label: Paragraph

text: Even so, the most galling aspect of their unrealized millennium must be that “that old
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Architecture” survived as the dominant element in the new pluralism ... and
label: Paragraph

text: (High Tech] is building them with its mythologies (social, economic, technological)
label: Paragraph

text: still intact.”
label: Paragraph

text: MARIE SHORT
label: Title

text: HOUSE
label: Title

text: Glenn Murcutt
label: Title

text: Maryam Gusheh and
label: Title

text: Catherine Lassen
label: Title

text: Glenn Murcutt, Marie Short House, Kempsey, Australia, 1975 & 1982.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: Glenn Murcutt’s Kempsey farmhouse is a six-hour car journey north from Sydney
label: Paragraph

text: through towns and state forests. One turns at last from the major highway onto a
label: Paragraph

text: regional road that is less and less groomed and the final approach is a long bumpy
label: Paragraph

text: track. Signposts only just mark the slow dusty drive through mature forest where
label: Paragraph

text: enormous eucalypts suggest the age and locale of this landscape. A gate or two in
label: Paragraph

text: farm fences at the road’s end reveals almost nothing. It is only by opening a gate
label: Paragraph

text: and stopping to look closely, that far off a small structure of perhaps two horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: houses is visible. Through a large paddock one reaches another gate leading
label: Paragraph

text: directly to a silvered timber building hovering on a lawn. Drawing close, stopping
label: Paragraph

text: just past the house, arrival is at an open-ended porch.
label: Paragraph

text: This unexpectedly refined, abstracted double pavilion floats above a grassy
label: Paragraph

text: floodplain surveying a lyrical landscape. Under a protective roof of apparently
label: Paragraph

text: immaterial sheet steel the repetitive horizontal structure mimes surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: weathered wood fences. Alison Smithson apparently described Murcutt as “the
label: Paragraph

text: timber and tin Miesian’”* and this work offers an illustration. Both centered enclo-
label: Paragraph

text: sure and spatial extension associated with mechanical extrusion, the building is an
label: Paragraph

text: abstract and original reconception of familiar elements such as the pitched roof and
label: Paragraph

text: entrance porch in local building materials and techniques. It occupies an important
label: Paragraph

text: position within the pursuit and evolution of modernist architecture in Australia.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed in 1974-75, the home, interestingly, was purchased by Murcutt in
label: Paragraph

text: 1980. At that time already the recipient of several distinguished architecture
label: Paragraph

text: awards, it is now viewed as critical in the evolution of his work.
label: Paragraph

text: The project was commissioned by the mother of a previous client, Laurie Short,
label: Paragraph

text: for whom Murcutt had recently completed a house (1972-73) on the northernmost
label: Paragraph

text: edge of Sydney, adjacent to Ku-Ring-Gai Chase National Park. Sharply present
label: Caption

text: in that project was the debt to late Mies characteristic of the architect’s work at
label: Paragraph

text: that time.” The Farnsworth House, in particular, appears a recurrent reference.
label: Paragraph

text: A photograph of renovations to his early Sydney home,’ his first project as an inde-
label: Paragraph

text: pendent practitioner, suggests an explicit connection. In that image a white post
label: Paragraph

text: and beam structure frames a glazed enclosure floating above a “wilderness”* gar-
label: Paragraph

text: den. Linking the house to the landscape is a parallel, similarly framed, horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: open platform. The implied pavilion with its low offset stage, screened and bor-
label: Paragraph

text: dered by delicate tree foliage, presents the suburban home as an open glazed hor-
label: Paragraph

text: izontal volume within an extended landscape. With a tiled roof and timber
label: Paragraph

text: boundary fence downplayed in the background, the cropped black and white
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction bears a surprising resemblance to iconic photographs of Mies’ famous
label: Paragraph

text: glass house.”
label: Paragraph

text: Situated in extensive farmland in Northern Coastal New South Wales, Murcutt’s
label: Paragraph

text: 1974 proposal for Marie Short was more pragmatically framed. Required was a
label: Paragraph

text: modest, efficient, economical building as a permanent residence for the client
label: Paragraph

text: and her family. Two particular client directives were crucial to the construction:
label: Paragraph

text: to use previously stockpiled local wood and to allow for the potential relocation
label: Paragraph

text: of the building to a new site. Murcutt developed the project around the precise
label: Paragraph

text: quantity and dimensions of these available timbers,® which included brushbox,
label: Paragraph

text: coachwood, tallow-wood, and oregon (pine). He broadly drew on farm-shed con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction traditions and local building expertise to develop an expressed post and
label: Paragraph

text: beam timber structure in a component-based system that could be pulled apart and
label: Paragraph

text: reassembled. Invested in the repetitive organization was the further potential for
label: Paragraph

text: modular adaptation. The proposed house was a double elevated volume as a
label: Paragraph

text: repeated pitched roof shed.
label: Caption

text: Disarmingly simple, the resultant plan was two parallel, almost identical, rotated
label: Paragraph

text: and slipped pavilions, one for sleeping, the other for living. Six 10 foot structural
label: Caption

text: timber bays, the last two treated as an entry porch, formed each 17 foot, 2 inches-
label: Paragraph

text: wide wing. Between the two, an implied external corridor linked the porches and
label: Paragraph

text: accommodated rainwater collection via an oversized valley gutter with doubled
label: Paragraph

text: downpipes at each end. Rendering the wings spatially discrete, it also provided
label: Paragraph

text: thresholds articulating each entrance from the adjacent pavilion. Murcutt located
label: Caption

text: the building between two large bodies of water, giving each protected open end an
label: Paragraph

text: outlook. One faced west toward the tidal freshwater river, the other east to a three-
label: Paragraph

text: hectare lagoon. The selected site on higher ground overlooked the floodplain and
label: Paragraph

text: the architect has emphasized the practical advantages of further elevating the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing where the floating floor assisted in catching summer sea breezes and allowed
label: Paragraph

text: for visibility of termites and the avoidance of snakes. Repetition as a mechanism
label: Paragraph

text: was used throughout, extending to the internal organization, where in each pavil-
label: Paragraph

text: ion service elements were individuated and grouped as a minor cluster of econom-
label: Paragraph

text: ical units. Basin, toilet, shower, and kitchen compartments formed precisely
label: Paragraph

text: dimensioned, independently functioning, orthogonal cells. The contrast between
label: Paragraph

text: these tightly planned functionally driven components and the apparently under-
label: Paragraph

text: articulated larger zones, manifested in those living areas a heightened spatial gen-
label: Paragraph

text: erosity and experiential freedom.
label: Paragraph

text: A methodological approach to climatic considerations in this largely subtropical
label: Paragraph

text: humid coastal environment informed the orientation of the house and its detailed
label: Paragraph

text: resolution. The living pavilion was located on the northern side in order to receive
label: Paragraph

text: sun for the majority of the day. A skylight in this volume had fixed louvers angled
label: Paragraph

text: to provide summer shade but allow winter sun. External floor to ceiling retractable
label: Caption

text: metal louvers (one per bay) controlled light and privacy levels, and walls of internal
label: Paragraph

text: operable glass and metal louvers (four per bay) allowed varying degrees of venti-
label: Paragraph

text: lation. Fine screen insect mesh between these layers gave a further level of protec-
label: Paragraph

text: tion to the naturally ventilated spaces and was used independently to completely
label: Paragraph

text: enclose the western porch. Both louver elements were selected as inexpensive,
label: Paragraph

text: standardized, off-the-shelf components and the resulting three-part exterior skin
label: Paragraph

text: suggested a corresponding combined standard cladding solution. The system
label: Paragraph

text: offered a high degree of individual orchestration to manipulate the building envel-
label: Paragraph

text: ope for both physical comfort and experiential connection to the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Climatic performance also informed the details of the double-pitched corrugated
label: Paragraph

text: metal roof. Overlapped curved corrugated sheets on a three-foot radius formed
label: Caption

text: ridge caps just separated by a continuous horizontal slot. The gap provided for nat-
label: Paragraph

text: ural ventilation to the space beneath, enhanced by the aerofoil shape and resultant
label: Paragraph

text: wind draft on the leeward side. Doubling the layers gave a sense of immateriality to
label: Paragraph

text: the edge and presented the roof as a continuous, strikingly delicate, metal mem-
label: Paragraph

text: brane, its lack of apparent mass made plausible by the naturally ventilated roof
label: Paragraph

text: space. The repetition and shadowed slot reinforced the horizontality of the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing wings and the roof rendered as abstracted planar corrugated sheets powerfully
label: Paragraph

text: lightened the expected weight of a traditional pitched volume. Suspended machine
label: Paragraph

text: in a garden, the design was a clear registration of its immediate environmental
label: Paragraph

text: conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: Three substantial monographs on the architect, clearly varied in style and
label: Paragraph

text: emphases, consistently refer to this project as a key moment in the development
label: Paragraph

text: of his practice. Beck and Cooper describe the design as “the beginnings of the
label: Paragraph

text: mature Murcutt. He is relinquishing Mies and establishing his own aesthetic hall-
label: Paragraph

text: marks — although still incorporating many references ... This is certainly a labora-
label: Paragraph

text: tory building,”” an emphasis in accord with Francoise Fromonot who notes that
label: Paragraph

text: “The Kempsey house is, if not a manifesto, a seminal work that explains and sig-
label: Paragraph

text: nificantly shapes his later development.”* Even Philip Drew’s earlier idiosyncratic
label: Paragraph

text: Leaves of Iron introduces the project as one “which ushered in a new phase of
label: Paragraph

text: Murcutt’s architecture and which foreshadows his mature technique. It was a cru-
label: Paragraph

text: cial building, both personally as well as artistically.”” All three identify the personal
label: Paragraph

text: significance of the work, an observation underpinned by Murcutt’s later acquisition
label: Paragraph

text: of the farmhouse and his subsequent architectural adjustment and clarification.
label: Paragraph

text: Inventive Acclimatization
label: Title

text: Appreciation of the Kempsey home is united via the extent to which the presence
label: Paragraph

text: of Mies is less insistent than earlier projects yet found on a regional farm in a taut
label: Paragraph

text: and convincing response to the particular circumstances of realization. Specific cli-
label: Paragraph

text: ent requirements, conditions of climatic control, on-site water management, and
label: Paragraph

text: local economies of scale, material, technique, and labor all appear apparently effort-
label: Paragraph

text: lessly optimized. According to Beck and Cooper, numerous pragmatic criteria and
label: Paragraph

text: desired experiential outcomes are all addressed “with a high degree of formal
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction.”'° They note that the “proportioning system of the timber frame
label: Paragraph

text: recalls late Miesian monumental bay spacing, of course here on a completely
label: Paragraph

text: domestic scale.”*' Of recurrent critical interest is the perceived absorption of earlier
label: Paragraph

text: modernist mastery, reinvigorated in an acclimatized, attentive vernacular transla-
label: Paragraph

text: tion. In a drawing folio on the architect’s work exploring a selection of key projects
label: Paragraph

text: (2006), Kenneth Frampton suggests that the slipped pavilion plan “may well have
label: Paragraph

text: been inspired by the subtle displacement of the upper and lower terraces in the
label: Paragraph

text: Farnsworth House, both of which were also elevated to raise the structure clear
label: Paragraph

text: of a flood plain.”’* He introduces the building as a reformulation of the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: local woolshed, emphasizing that Murcutt’s adoption of the associated economical
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated iron roof form was “as technically and tectonically compelling as Mies’
label: Paragraph

text: comparable appropriation of the standard steel-frame as a ‘found object’ some fifty
label: Paragraph

text: years before.””?
label: Paragraph

text: Evident in the design for Marie Short is an engagement with mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: materials, logically and elegantly assembled. Off-the-shelf systems were here pre-
label: Paragraph

text: cisely adapted and refined to propose useful inventive combinations that, once
label: Paragraph

text: tested, became new standard detailed solutions. Rational yet carefully particular-
label: Paragraph

text: ized thought in construction is present in numerous components and priorities that
label: Paragraph

text: became preoccupations in subsequent projects, a clear example being the layered
label: Paragraph

text: exterior operable skin. Frampton comments: “Irrespective of whether ordinary
label: Paragraph

text: builders were indeed that familiar with Murcutt’s particular combination of lou-
label: Paragraph

text: vers, mesh and glazing is a moot point, the architect would henceforth employ this
label: Paragraph

text: tripartite cladding principle, with subtle variations, in one house after another.”"*
label: Paragraph

text: Corrugated metal roofs are similarly successively employed after this building as
label: Paragraph

text: elemental explorations conceived in utilitarian terms. Strong, lightweight, and eco-
label: Paragraph

text: nomical, they are typically reexamined and in some cases further abstracted in later
label: Paragraph

text: iterations. Practically driven yet expressive water management and downpipe
label: Paragraph

text: details are also repeated and adapted in new projects. From this moment “the con-
label: Paragraph

text: ical hopper and downpipe trope”’’ becomes expected in Murcutt’s houses.
label: Paragraph

text: This mode of working is underpinned by the desire for an efficient yet flexible
label: Paragraph

text: set of elements, which can be repeated and continually adapted. The architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: consistent engagement with standardized building systems, initially well designed,
label: Paragraph

text: affordable and locally produced, is through a process of integration and attentive
label: Paragraph

text: adjustment to each new project. It typically consists of reducing the number of
label: Paragraph

text: parts, simplifying the appearance, minimizing the size of the structural members,
label: Paragraph

text: and optimizing the number of simultaneous functions each part performs. An
label: Paragraph

text: ongoing effort to rethink each element occurs from the scale of individual details
label: Paragraph

text: to larger building components, and occasionally extends to entire building types.
label: Paragraph

text: Reexamination of first principles allows for a constant commitment to particularize
label: Paragraph

text: whereby reassembled modules and all their details operate as if they are one shift-
label: Paragraph

text: ing yet internally coherent framework. One finds a resultant tension in this work
label: Paragraph

text: between system building, component development, and reuse of the ordinary on
label: Paragraph

text: one hand and a terse final minimal singularity on the other.
label: Paragraph

text: Critical Transformations
label: Title

text: Purchasing the Marie-Short farm in 1980 provided Murcutt with a tangible early
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to reevaluate the house elements and their broader interconnections.
label: Paragraph

text: The potential for reuse was architecturally tested and clarified by reframing the
label: Paragraph

text: original spatial relationships while maintaining the internal systematic order. In this
label: Paragraph

text: project, adjustment and literal extension were used to demonstrate the potential
label: Paragraph

text: for the repetitive system to adapt; reemployed details and built components were
label: Paragraph

text: used to reformulate the house as a whole. The development focused both an ele-
label: Paragraph

text: mental materiality together with a more refined abstraction. Both wings were sub-
label: Paragraph

text: stantially lengthened in 1981-82 to accommodate the architect’s larger family
label: Paragraph

text: needs and each pavilion was extended three structural bays to the east; in the proc-
label: Paragraph

text: ess one veranda was unbolted and moved to its new location. Distinguishing the
label: Paragraph

text: first and expanded versions of the house suggests a critical agency in the moment of
label: Paragraph

text: transformation. Rigorous consistencies as well as shifts inherent in the two versions
label: Paragraph

text: sharply focus the productive tensions that underpin both Murcutt’s working
label: Paragraph

text: method and his inventive disciplinary contribution.
label: Paragraph

text: Comparing the early and later plans implies an almost magical ease with which
label: Paragraph

text: the systematic built “machine” was extruded, and yet many essential relationships
label: Paragraph

text: were reconceived. In the new configuration the northern living wing was length-
label: Paragraph

text: ened with additional service facilities and a two-bay bedroom, while on the south-
label: Paragraph

text: erm pavilion a three-bay living room with fireplace was inserted between the
label: Caption

text: original bedrooms and relocated end porch. The previous programmatic day-
label: Caption

text: wing/night-wing hierarchy was thus shifted to create independent possibilities
label: Paragraph

text: for living, sleeping, and bathing in each pavilion, suggesting one “house” for the
label: Paragraph

text: parents and another for the children. The close proximity of the new living room
label: Paragraph

text: to the northern kitchen and dining areas amplified internal cross-connections
label: Caption

text: between the north and south wings and offered more possibilities for diverse living
label: Paragraph

text: arrangements. The resultant plan implied a greater flexibility of use with appar-
label: Paragraph

text: ently less architectural determination.
label: Paragraph

text: Marie Short’s version of the house had five’® entrances. Ceremonial double
label: Paragraph

text: doors connected the kitchen and dining areas to one porch and the other verandah
label: Paragraph

text: to a vestibule between the bedrooms. A minor hierarchy to this doubling was sug-
label: Paragraph

text: gested with an additional layer of entry doors into the northern, screened, other-
label: Paragraph

text: wise exterior room. Large sliding glass doors allowed both pavilions additionally to
label: Paragraph

text: be entered from these outside spaces through either the living room or the second
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom. A final pair of double exterior timber doors in the easternmost face of the
label: Caption

text: northern wing led directly to a toilet, shower, and laundry at the back of the kitchen
label: Caption

text: service facilities. With its flight of steps, minor protective extra roof and close prox-
label: Paragraph

text: imity to the entry gate, this centralized opening in the gable end implied a strikingly
label: Paragraph

text: classical, face-like primary entrance, yet its suggested operation was as a service
label: Paragraph

text: back door.
label: Paragraph

text: In Murcutt’s extensions, this entrance and associated centralized facade disap-
label: Paragraph

text: peared. Retained laundry and bathing elements were expanded as a much larger
label: Paragraph

text: core, and a newly blind wood bedroom wall formed a clarified abstracted east
label: Paragraph

text: end. Inserting the new living room created a more public entry through the
label: Paragraph

text: eastern porch and sliding glass wall. A 1975 photograph’” of the house shows
label: Caption

text: venetian blinds enclosing that verandah, perhaps in response to the more private
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom then adjacent. In the alterations the porches were thus focused as
label: Paragraph

text: entrance voids, clear expansions of their associated public living spaces, yet with
label: Paragraph

text: a cross movement leading from the steps toward the other pavilion. Entrance
label: Caption

text: legibility and implied gridded spatial extension into the landscape was
label: Paragraph

text: sharpened.
label: Paragraph

text: The new southern living room mirrored the dimensions of the existing kitchen
label: Paragraph

text: and living spaces. Proportionally identical rooms now provided a symbolic center
label: Paragraph

text: along each pavilion, and the cross-combination of the two spaces precisely regis-
label: Paragraph

text: tered the house’s physical center. Each space was respectively identified with a sig-
label: Paragraph

text: nificant function — eating, or gathering around the fire. Multiple possible entrances,
label: Paragraph

text: combined with these shifting spatial hierarchies, offered freedom of use within a
label: Paragraph

text: simple order. A clear yet dispersed center was manifest.
label: Paragraph

text: In the first house conspicuously thick external doors read as implied pivoting
label: Paragraph

text: wood walls. Offthe-shelf cladding on a familiar timber frame was used to make
label: Paragraph

text: these doors as de-familiarized, abstracted pieces of wall. Frampton describes them
label: Paragraph

text: thus: “hieratic in feeling, perhaps, are the thick pivoting doors, the tongued and
label: Paragraph

text: grooved timber cladding of which lies flush with the surrounding boarded wall
label: Caption

text: when the doors are closed.”’* As strangely physical edges to the spaces, the pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ence of these elements was intensified in the alterations. Unchanged in location,
label: Paragraph

text: one pair was newly employed to internally connect both living rooms. The adjust-
label: Paragraph

text: ments resituated these external elements at a clearly interior center. Murcutt, in
label: Paragraph

text: discussing the design of a theoretical future home, alluded to the psychological
label: Paragraph

text: reassurance provided by their heaviness: “When I eventually get around to design-
label: Paragraph

text: ing myself a house, I will have a bedroom which has that sort of a Chubb safe qual-
label: Paragraph

text: ity, enormous security.”’® These unusually thick, apparently exterior doors at the
label: Paragraph

text: core of the house created an abstract yet uncanny material presence.
label: Paragraph

text: The color and specificity of the predominantly timber lined interiors, as experi-
label: Paragraph

text: enced in the physical and visual weight of these doors, is in productive tension with
label: Paragraph

text: the mechanical quality in most of the building’s exterior skin. An inventive combi-
label: Paragraph

text: nation of layers, the apparently extruded wall system is striking for the extent to
label: Paragraph

text: which it is largely composed of air. Moveable blades of glass and fine metal provide
label: Paragraph

text: a thickened zone of operability to individuate the degree to which one can experience
label: Paragraph

text: particular atmospheric aspects, whether breezes, light, or transparency. As with the
label: Paragraph

text: roof, the floating sheet-like elements are plausible partly because natural climatic
label: Paragraph

text: effects have been engaged to maintain personal comfort. Airflow, rather than build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing mass, helps protect the ceiling from heat gain beneath an upper roof metal sheet.
label: Paragraph

text: In the vertical plane, sheltered warmth or cooling can occur without added wall
label: Paragraph

text: weight. The movement, temperature, and presence of air are all part of this screen
label: Paragraph

text: system, with the barest amount of material employed to articulate a subtle, precise
label: Paragraph

text: separation. Distinct from Miesian transparency, the prosaic glass louvers are more
label: Paragraph

text: mechanically present and one has individual control over degrees of privacy and con-
label: Paragraph

text: nection to the landscape. Here minimal expression also offers experiential freedom.
label: Paragraph

text: Air as a material seems similarly engaged in the design of the screened northern
label: Paragraph

text: porch, where a delicate stretched membrane renders just enough edge to delineate
label: Paragraph

text: a bubble of hazy light. The gauze void offers separation from the landscape yet
label: Paragraph

text: immersion in the environment. Familiar yet elevated, this apparently ordinary
label: Paragraph

text: entrance is materially present yet highly abstract. Pierre Chareau’s Maison d’Verre,
label: Paragraph

text: feels present in this building, and particularly here. Murcutt has discussed being
label: Paragraph

text: moved by that building, as “a confirmation that Modernism could be open-ended”
label: Paragraph

text: and his reaction is captured by Fromonot: “once enveloped by the abstract atmos-
label: Paragraph

text: phere of the interior, he experienced an unexpected feeling of security mixed witha
label: Paragraph

text: sensation of lightness, of floating in light.”° Experienced as an interior, the room
label: Paragraph

text: renders the particular atmospheric condition of the landscape as a material effect. It
label: Paragraph

text: is as if the weather is observed and experienced at the same time. Changing pat-
label: Paragraph

text: terns of light, breeze, and mist become part of the architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Economical Abstraction
label: Title

text: Murcutt’s recent reception has largely been framed in terms of environmental con-
label: Paragraph

text: trol and “green design.” In the introduction to her anthology, Constructing a New
label: Paragraph

text: Agenda: Architectural Theory 1993-2009, Krista Sykes frames his contribution as a
label: Paragraph

text: response to current climatic imperatives: “Glenn Murcutt (relies) on combinations
label: Paragraph

text: of local or salvaged materials, attention to geography, and awareness of proven
label: Paragraph

text: regional solutions to create sustainable and environmentally responsive architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture.”*) The Marie Short Murcutt house is potent within this narrative. Particula-
label: Paragraph

text: rities of the building locate architectural priorities in this regard, but Murcutt’s
label: Paragraph

text: precise position and working method remains under-described. Floating, sur-
label: Paragraph

text: rounded by light on the northern porch, this elevated experience in relation to
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape, qualitatively captures his ambition. In many ways, the house is more
label: Paragraph

text: about environmental experience than control. It operates as an instrument to con-
label: Paragraph

text: tinuously adjust the relationship between architecture and its situation. A broad
label: Paragraph

text: ethic for living deliberately, modestly, and attentively in a specific place prevails.
label: Paragraph

text: In his own description of this project, Glenn Murcutt typically begins with the
label: Paragraph

text: incidental details of the timber he had to work with. “Marie had just said ... ‘Any-
label: Paragraph

text: thing that you’ve got left over, I'll take it.’ And every time they had something left
label: Paragraph

text: over, they'd bring it out, and deliver it and just charge her for a leftover quantity. It
label: Paragraph

text: was by measuring the materials in the shed that I was able to determine the size of
label: Paragraph

text: the building.””* Evoked by his account is the value of “making do,” an aspect of
label: Paragraph

text: Murcutt’s work contextualised by writers such as David Malouf: “materials that
label: Paragraph

text: had belonged to the world of the make-do and temporary — corrugated iron, reused
label: Paragraph

text: timber, louvers — became, rather in the manner of the contemporary Italian art
label: Paragraph

text: movement L’arte povera, the stuff of an architecture whose aim was to turn limi-
label: Paragraph

text: tation into opportunity, and with what might appear to be the poorest means, the
label: Paragraph

text: achievement of a definite lightness and permanency.””’ Literally formed from
label: Paragraph

text: found timber pieces, the Marie Short house is also an early example of Murcutt’s
label: Paragraph

text: gradual transfiguration of standardised material components. This transformative
label: Paragraph

text: process lies in the initial conception of the house but more perspicuously in its
label: Paragraph

text: translation: Marie Short’s farmhouse rethought as Murcutt’s home. The highly pre-
label: Paragraph

text: cise sequence of architectural adjustments and refinements, which constitute this
label: Paragraph

text: reconfiguration, are the substance of his economical method. Working in this way,
label: Paragraph

text: an unexpectedly familiar yet heightened material abstraction is found.
label: Paragraph

text: CENTRE POMPIDOU
label: Title

text: Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers
label: Title

text: Hadas A. Steiner
label: Title

text: i
label: Title

text: [ae 7
label: Title

text: Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers, Centre Nationale d’Art et Culture Georges
label: Caption

text: Pompidou, Paris, France, 1977.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption
