label: Caption

text: The Centre Nationale d’Art et Culture Georges Pompidou (1971-77), also known
label: Paragraph

text: as the Pompidou Center, makes a striking impression even today. From afar, the
label: Paragraph

text: scale of the inside-out structure with its vast public plaza retains a monumental
label: Paragraph

text: status within the densely populated medieval quarter from which it differentiates
label: Paragraph

text: itself. The building takes up half of its site, with the rest given over to a plaza,
label: Paragraph

text: known as the Plateau Beaubourg, which remains an animated civic space in its
label: Paragraph

text: own right. In proximity, the skeletal structure of steel columns, trusses, tension
label: Paragraph

text: rods, and gerberettes that together with the mechanical and circulation systems
label: Paragraph

text: make up the facades of the building cause the eye to follow the latticework of struc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and focus on the connective details. The Pompidou Center continues to pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ent itself as a vision of technologically enabled adaptability that clearly exhibits
label: Paragraph

text: what became known in architectural discourse as “High Tech.” Effectively, the
label: Paragraph

text: building has become “a manifesto of late modernism with its commitment to
label: Paragraph

text: the public realm, the integration of design and technology, and the unflinching
label: Paragraph

text: belief in total flexibility.”
label: Paragraph

text: Scheme
label: Title

text: When Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers won the commission for the Pompidou in
label: Paragraph

text: 1971, they were both little-known architects who entered into competition with
label: Paragraph

text: some of the most high-profile architects in France for a complex project in the his-
label: Paragraph

text: toric center of Paris. Indeed, the competition attracted some 680 entries. The
label: Paragraph

text: immediate area of Les Halles, which had long accommodated the principle food
label: Paragraph

text: market for Paris, was in the process of being demolished and its functions trans-
label: Paragraph

text: ferred to the outskirts. It was also a socially depressed area considered to be in need
label: Paragraph

text: of revitalization. Georges Pompidou, then president of France, proposed a new
label: Paragraph

text: center, geared in his mind toward the elevation of the cultural level of the
label: Paragraph

text: “man in the street,” to stand on the vacant plateau that had once accommodated
label: Paragraph

text: the delivery trucks for the market as a grand gesture of urban renewal. The pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gram was to include a large public library, a museum of modern art, a center for
label: Paragraph

text: industrial design, and a center for music and acoustical research. Other facilities for
label: Paragraph

text: administration, bookshops, restaurants, cinemas, children’s play, and parking were
label: Paragraph

text: also required.
label: Paragraph

text: France was not prone to holding international design competitions but in this
label: Paragraph

text: case a famous intercontinental jury, including Oscar Niemeyer, Jean Prouvé,
label: Paragraph

text: and Philip Johnson, sat as judges. The entry submitted by Piano and Rogers
label: Paragraph

text: reflected their shared affinity for innovative applications of building technology.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, the two believed that technology released architects from the traditions
label: Paragraph

text: of the past and allowed for new expressions in architectural form. In this case,
label: Paragraph

text: the desire for a large open structure with its six extended floor spans — to be exe-
label: Paragraph

text: cuted with the able assistance of Peter Rice of the Ove Arup engineering firm —
label: Paragraph

text: dictated the nature of the structure needed on the exterior to carry the load. Expo-
label: Paragraph

text: sure of the vertical structure of the building, and most all of its infrastructure, was
label: Paragraph

text: intended to maximize the flexibility of the internal space. In turn, each structural
label: Paragraph

text: member was then highly thought out. As Rice expressed it: “Each piece was sep-
label: Paragraph

text: arate, an articulated assembly where the members only touched at discrete points.
label: Paragraph

text: As in music, where the space between the notes defines the quality, here it was the
label: Paragraph

text: space between the pieces that defined the scale.”” Thus the complexity of the highly
label: Paragraph

text: visible structure stemmed from the overarching concept of adaptability and change
label: Paragraph

text: that was vital to the proposal.
label: Paragraph

text: Circulation
label: Title

text: The flow of people from the open plaza through which one entered the ground
label: Paragraph

text: floor of the building emphasized the notion of continuous circulation. The effect,
label: Paragraph

text: both programmatically and theoretically, was a conceptualization of the structure
label: Paragraph

text: as movement: of people, programs, and services. The idea of passage was further
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized through one of the most iconic aspects of this building: the painting of
label: Paragraph

text: the different systems on the exterior of the building in diagrammatic colors: blue,
label: Paragraph

text: for instance, illustrated ventilation, or air. Electrical elements were picked out in
label: Paragraph

text: yellow and orange. Plumbing, or water, was demarcated in green. Most of the
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical services made their debut outside of the glass skin on the eastern,
label: Paragraph

text: street-side elevation. The transition of people around and through the building
label: Paragraph

text: was highlighted in red. The best known of these elements continues to be the
label: Paragraph

text: underside of the glass tubes encapsulating the escalator that steps up the west
label: Caption

text: facade that faces the plaza. The visibility of the movement of visitors through
label: Paragraph

text: the glass corridors that are clipped to the externalized infrastructure also transforms
label: Paragraph

text: the people themselves into part of the facade. These corridors are reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: the “streets-in-the-air” concept that Peter and Alison Smithson popularized with
label: Paragraph

text: their housing projects of the 1950s.’ From inside the glass corridors, one is both
label: Paragraph

text: contained within the building and, at the same time, connected visually to the out-
label: Paragraph

text: side world of the plaza and to Paris beyond.
label: Paragraph

text: Context
label: Title

text: Ina manner familiar from contemporary site planning in England, transported here
label: Paragraph

text: to densely populated Paris, the building was pushed right to the edge of the site
label: Paragraph

text: with the side that faces the city encroaching the outside like a protective wall.* Thus
label: Paragraph

text: the experience of approach from the historic city quarter is one of the color-coded
label: Paragraph

text: servicing tubes, while the narrowness of the street guarantees fragmented views of
label: Paragraph

text: the facade. From this vantage point in particular, the Pompidou Center appeared
label: Paragraph

text: not even to have the trappings of a traditional building or urban context. Not only
label: Paragraph

text: did it stand out in the city fabric and appear to have no architectural referent from
label: Paragraph

text: the past, the building did not follow in the programmatic footsteps for a museum or
label: Paragraph

text: cultural center. Indeed, the architects took a stance on the nature of culture in the
label: Paragraph

text: present age, declaring it to be about the dissemination of information rather than
label: Paragraph

text: the presentation of art. The library, too, unlike most others in France, was designed
label: Paragraph

text: so that readers could browse the stacks themselves and have control over access to
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, the Pompidou had acknowledged roots in the history of structural
label: Paragraph

text: and infrastructural innovation, at the larger scale the Crystal Palace (1851) by
label: Paragraph

text: Joseph Paxton and at the domestic one, the Maison de Verre (1932) by Pierre Char-
label: Caption

text: eau. Rogers admired both these examples for their groundbreaking conceptualiza-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of architecture for a Machine Age that went beyond the aestheticization of
label: Paragraph

text: technology. The Crystal Palace famously used prefabricated construction and
label: Paragraph

text: the assembly of parts to make up its structure. The association of these kit-of-parts
label: Paragraph

text: architectures was clear within architectural culture. In The Language of Post-Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture (1977), for example, Charles Jencks juxtaposed an image of the brand
label: Paragraph

text: new Pompidou Center with a text on World’s Fair constructions.’ At the intimate
label: Caption

text: scale, the Maison de Verre was bold in its raw expression of the materiality of steel,
label: Paragraph

text: glass, and rubber. Moreover, the wires for its utilities ran through tubular metal
label: Paragraph

text: hannels that were punctuated by power switches and sockets.° Another reference
label: Paragraph

text: for the overt expression of infrastructure at the scale of an institutional building was
label: Paragraph

text: the more recent Richards Medical Research Laboratories (1961) by Louis I. Kahn,
label: Paragraph

text: where the service towers appeared prominently, illustrating that architect’s famous
label: Paragraph

text: distinction between served and servant spaces.’ In addition, Piano and Rogers
label: Paragraph

text: made their case for the building by associating it with Buckminster Fuller’s argu-
label: Paragraph

text: ment for architectural efficiency and flexibility through the application of up-to-
label: Paragraph

text: date technologies.
label: Paragraph

text: fal
label: Title

text: Concept
label: Title

text: Most overtly, however, the Pompidou Center drew visually and conceptually on
label: Paragraph

text: the work of the Archigram group from the 1960s. That group — composed of War-
label: Paragraph

text: ren Chalk, Peter Cook, Dennis Crompton, David Greene, Ron Herron, and Mike
label: Title

text: Webb — had placed the concept of flexibility of program and structure at the heart
label: Paragraph

text: of their architecture. Archigram reacted in words and images to what they
label: Paragraph

text: described as the tedium of the built environment and the outdated notion that
label: Paragraph

text: a collection of individual monuments was the life-blood of the city. Instead, their
label: Paragraph

text: projects presented the city as a series of unpredictable events that were to be
label: Paragraph

text: accommodated by its architecture. Architecture would only remain relevant, they
label: Paragraph

text: believed, if it was not designed to outlive its relationship to patterns of occupation.
label: Paragraph

text: The lack of permanent architectural resolution resulted in a new aesthetic that was
label: Paragraph

text: not based on fixed form. In their first common activity, the Living City exhibition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1963, the Archigram group sought to define urban space as primarily a sphere of
label: Paragraph

text: interaction. The forms of the city, defined through the transmission of information,
label: Paragraph

text: were implied by the circulatory structure of movement. The shift was toward a
label: Paragraph

text: networked conception of circulation that prioritized distribution, flow, and direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, and relied heavily on connection. These qualities are all apparent in the think-
label: Paragraph

text: ing that generated the design for the Pompidou Center.
label: Paragraph

text: When the British architectural critic Reyner Banham spoke of the Pompidou
label: Paragraph

text: Center, he often cited it as the only realization of an Archigram drawing.* Certainly
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram’s most enduring legacy for architectural culture has been predicated on
label: Paragraph

text: the strength of its imagery. Archigram’s projects were presented as colorful adver-
label: Paragraph

text: tisements for the idea of architectural and urban structure as a scaffold for life’s
label: Paragraph

text: activities. The sensibility of their drawings transported the “pop” aesthetic into
label: Paragraph

text: architectural discourse. In the images that the six publicized in the nine issues
label: Paragraph

text: of their Archigram magazine, as well as on the pages of other publications and
label: Paragraph

text: through exhibitions, the city was transformed into a place of leisure in which archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture acted as an enabler of social situations. Through the conflation of collage
label: Paragraph

text: and orthographic drawing, not unlike the one produced by Rogers and Piano for
label: Paragraph

text: their initial submission for the Pompidou Center, Archigram fabricated a visual
label: Paragraph

text: language to express the agenda of a reflexive architecture to be populated by peo-
label: Paragraph

text: ple who participated in the life of street culture. Often the original drawings were
label: Paragraph

text: highlighted in bright colors, similar in palette to the ones used by Piano and Rogers
label: Paragraph

text: to diagram the services of the Pompidou Center. The use of ebullient color in archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural drawings was uncommon at the time and Archigram’s embrace of the new
label: Paragraph

text: tool of Zip-A-Tone and felt-tipped markers to produce these effects was emphatic.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, it could be said that Archigram invented the visual language on which the
label: Paragraph

text: Center was predicated.
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram also used polemical language to make the case for what they argued
label: Paragraph

text: would be a more relevant kind of architecture. They famously spoke of the need
label: Paragraph

text: for new technologies to stand along the space capsules and disposable commodities
label: Paragraph

text: of anew age. Most importantly, however, the role of architecture was to enable the
label: Paragraph

text: liberties promised by the technologies of contemporary life. The language of the
label: Paragraph

text: text written by Piano and Rogers to support their submission, with its ideals of
label: Paragraph

text: social freedom enabled through radical flexibility of structure, was redolent of
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram-like prose:
label: Paragraph

text: It is our belief that buildings should be able to change, not only in plan, but in
label: Paragraph

text: section and elevation, allowing people the freedom to do their own things, the order
label: Paragraph

text: and scale and grain coming from a clear understanding and expression of the process
label: Paragraph

text: of building, and the optimization of each individual element, its system, of manufac-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, storage, transportation, erection and connection, all within a clearly defined and
label: Paragraph

text: rational framework. This framework must allow people to perform freely inside and
label: Paragraph

text: out, to change and adapt, in answer to technical or client needs, this free and
label: Paragraph

text: changing performance becoming an expression of the architecture of the building —a
label: Paragraph

text: giant Meccano set rather than the traditional static transparent or solid doll’s house.
label: Paragraph

text: Exciting things happen when a variety of overlapping activities designed for all peo-
label: Paragraph

text: ple, the old and the young, the blue and white collar workers, locals and visitors all
label: Paragraph

text: meet, opening up the possibility of interaction outside institutional limits. When this
label: Paragraph

text: takes place, deprived areas become dynamic places where all can participate, rather
label: Paragraph

text: than less or more beautiful ghettos.”
label: Paragraph

text: The common rhetoric embraced the cause for buildings to be more lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: and responsive, acknowledging that culture was in the midst of an electronic and
label: Paragraph

text: computer revolution that would push architecture beyond its old terrain of
label: Paragraph

text: established answers.'°
label: Paragraph

text: The idea of a building as a giant Meccano — or Erector — set was particularly
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of Peter Cook’s Plug-in-City (1964), a megastructural proposal in
label: Paragraph

text: which all the components had designated lifespans, from the masts, ties, and con-
label: Paragraph

text: nections of the structure itself, to the clip-on pods that accommodated urban activ-
label: Paragraph

text: ity. In its understanding of culture as information, the Pompidou Center also
label: Paragraph

text: harkened back to Archigram’s “Instant City’(1968) project that had as its goal
label: Paragraph

text: the delivery of information from the city to the farther flung provinces and vice
label: Paragraph

text: versa. Collage illustrations told the story of how the travelling components of
label: Paragraph

text: the Instant City would arrive at a “sleeping town” and thoroughly infiltrate the
label: Paragraph

text: ocale by creating an event through which a network of information and entertain-
label: Paragraph

text: ment would take over. Thus, cultural activity would be spread far afield from the
label: Paragraph

text: usual concentrations in major cities. Likewise, on the very first page of the
label: Paragraph

text: Pompidou Center competition entry Rogers and Piano, too, proposed that the
label: Paragraph

text: building be “developed as a ‘Live Centre of Information’ covering Paris and
label: Paragraph

text: beyond. Locally, it was to be a meeting place for the people. The Plateau
label: Paragraph

text: Beaubourg information centre would be linked up with information dispersal
label: Paragraph

text: and collection centers, throughout France and beyond; for example, university cen-
label: Paragraph

text: ters, town halls, etc.”'! Thus, the network of cultural exchange would take over.
label: Paragraph

text: The theme of culture presented as the democratization of information and
label: Paragraph

text: thoroughly linked to structural flexibility was also directly connected to the work
label: Paragraph

text: of Cedric Price, whom both Archigram and Rogers admired for his commitment to
label: Paragraph

text: indeterminacy at every stage of the design process. For Price, architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: always conceived primarily as program, with a result that may or may not turn
label: Paragraph

text: out to be a building. The Fun Palace (1961-65), in particular, was a source of inspi-
label: Paragraph

text: ration for the Pompidou Center. This unexecuted project that Price designed as a
label: Paragraph

text: “people’s theater” for the politically-driven theater company of Joan Littlewood,
label: Caption

text: was, like the Pompidou, conceived of as less of a building and more of an instru-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of social change Price had an ideal client for this sort of proposal, unlike the
label: Paragraph

text: governmental agency that Piano and Rogers had to convince about the complex-
label: Paragraph

text: ities of the cultural notions of leisure at this time. From the start, for example, Price
label: Paragraph

text: and Littlewood interchangeably used the words “learning” and “fun” to describe
label: Paragraph

text: _ 8 Dm
label: Title

text: Littlewood’s ideal theater, improvisation and participation from performers and
label: Paragraph

text: audience alike would be encouraged by the environmental conditions surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: the activities.
label: Paragraph

text: Littlewood wanted a center with no designated program or even a set of fixed activ-
label: Paragraph

text: ities. Price translated this “brief” into an “anti-building” with no specific form or fixed
label: Paragraph

text: floor plan.’’ There is no doubt that the vision portrayed by Price in the Fun Palace was
label: Paragraph

text: more radically flexible than the Pompidou could ever be. While the Pompidou Center
label: Paragraph

text: deployed tensile and compressive structure in a novel way, Price wanted to do more
label: Paragraph

text: than reconceive architecture in the light of advanced building technologies. The Fun
label: Paragraph

text: Palace was essentially a system for moving things around, depending on what the
label: Paragraph

text: space was being used for at any designated time. With the assistance of the structural
label: Paragraph

text: engineer Frank Newby, the Fun Palace was designed as a structural grid of towers that
label: Paragraph

text: contained the circulation and services that allowed for flexibility of program in the
label: Paragraph

text: bays. The frame was the only permanent part of the structure. Gantry cranes
label: Paragraph

text: mounted on rails provided the means for redeploying the floor, wall, and ceiling mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ules and other variable elements within the spaces. There were even moving walk-
label: Paragraph

text: ways and pivoting escalators. To further increase responsivity, the project drew on the
label: Paragraph

text: expertise of the cybenetician Gordon Pask, who was well versed in the application of
label: Paragraph

text: the emerging technologies that Archigram only envisioned. The cybernetic element
label: Paragraph

text: allowed the input of feedback into the adjustable system to further its responsivity
label: Paragraph

text: during use. As Price would say about the Fun Palace, it was only meant to be “a
label: Paragraph

text: kit of parts, not a building. I doubt that it will ever look the same twice.”'*
label: Paragraph

text: Banham, who vocally promoted the agendas of Archigram and Price throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s, positioned the Pompidou Center in relation to those two practices in his
label: Paragraph

text: book that were dedicated to what he called the “megastructure idea.”"* Megastruc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture: Urban Futures of the Recent Past was in fact written at the same time as the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing of the Pompidou Center was in progress. The book had a chapter devoted to
label: Paragraph

text: the work of Archigram and Price under the heading of “Fun and Flexibility.” In this
label: Paragraph

text: section, the connection of the attitude toward leisure and the structural typology o:
label: Paragraph

text: the megastructure was cast as a British contribution to the discourse. If the Fun
label: Paragraph

text: Palace was described as one of the most radically flexible versions of a megastruc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, Archigram had served to “create the illusion of the existence of some kind o
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Megastructure International.””'® Banham then concluded the epilogue for the
label: Paragraph

text: book with the example of the Pompidou Center, comparing it favorably to the sen-
label: Paragraph

text: sibility of this British contribution, but adversely to the greater cause of structura
label: Paragraph

text: flexibility. He found that in the end the Pompidou, as it was being realized, shared
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps more with the less variable qualities of the ongoing New Babylon project
label: Paragraph

text: by Constant Nieuwenhuys, included in the book as a megastructure of a less jovial
label: Paragraph

text: category. That project, too, used scaffolds and the notion of computing technology
label: Paragraph

text: to imagine a radically flexible world for the homo ludens, or the “archetypal ‘man at
label: Paragraph

text: play.’””” This reconceptualization of the world as a series of sectors that through
label: Paragraph

text: space frames provides a “new skin that covers the earth” was meant to “suit the
label: Paragraph

text: totally different needs of a creative race of homo ludens” by being “flexible, change-
label: Paragraph

text: —— IR el ae
label: Title

text: sectors in such a world. With this analysis Banham firmly contextualized the Pom-
label: Paragraph

text: pidou Center in terms of these kinds of neo-avant-garde practices in his criticism of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1970s.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pompidou Center was certainly far more bound to the conventions of a cul-
label: Paragraph

text: tural center than any of the unrealized structures by Archigram, Constant, or Price.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, the Pompidou was for Banham a monument to the megastructural
label: Paragraph

text: movement in the sense that it looked like one.'” As Banham reflected, even as a fixed
label: Paragraph

text: image that was perhaps a necessary outcome of the design process, the significance of
label: Paragraph

text: the Pompidou Center as a building would be for it to retain the power of that image
label: Paragraph

text: into the twenty-first century.” Banham concluded: “Whatever the social or anti-
label: Paragraph

text: ‘ocial, mechanical or functional, civic or environmental, professional, radical or con-
label: Paragraph

text: ervative meanings that have been demonstrated by or imputed to megastructures,
label: Paragraph

text: hey are also a body of imagery, carrying the kind of imprecise but intensely emotive
label: Paragraph

text: ignifications that visual images always do.””’ Indeed, when the Archigram group
label: Paragraph

text: ogether with Cedric Price took a bus trip to visit the completed Pompidou Center
label: Paragraph

text: in 1977, they immediately recognized their cartoons in the work.” They were, none-
label: Paragraph

text: theless, disappointed with the literal application of diagrammatic color to the over-
label: Paragraph

text: blown external ducts that converted what in the drawings was a metaphor of
label: Paragraph

text: tH ane
label: Title

text: circulation and exchange into a monumentalization of services. On-camera musings
label: Paragraph

text: reveal bewilderment at the fundamental lack of dynamism on display. While the
label: Paragraph

text: frame enabled internal flexibility of arrangement, the core issue of transience, from
label: Paragraph

text: the structural incorporation of time to the exchanges of technology and consump-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, was untouched. The consensus was that the Pompidou Center, despite being
label: Paragraph

text: filtered through the representational lens of Archigram, remained a static building.
label: Paragraph

text: Whether the idea of a cultural center that uses technology to enable a flexible
label: Paragraph

text: and evolving set of programs for the person in the street is a viable one remains an
label: Paragraph

text: open question. The success of a building that proposes to be a response to the
label: Paragraph

text: movement of services, people, and information will always leave itself open to
label: Paragraph

text: question. But static or not, the Pompidou Center maintains its iconic status. Per-
label: Paragraph

text: haps the most enduring idea captured by the building as an image for the twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: first century is in its attempt to address the idea of culture defined as the dissem-
label: Paragraph

text: ination of information. By extending the debate about what a monument can be
label: Paragraph

text: after modernism to what a cultural center might be in the information age, the
label: Paragraph

text: Pompidou Centre still raises pertinent questions about the role of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: in an increasingly visual and connected society.
label: Paragraph

text: TEATRO DEL
label: Title

text: MONDO
label: Title

text: Aldo Rossi
label: Title

text: Mary Louise Lobsinger
label: Title

text: Aldo Rossi, Teatro del Mondo, 1980.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: It could be argued that Aldo Rossi’s Teatro del Mondo is the single most memo-
label: Paragraph

text: rable contribution to the 1980 inaugural Venice Biennale of International Architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture. The project was co-sponsored by the Biennale’s theater and architecture
label: Paragraph

text: sections. Constructed on a barge in the Fusina shipyards, the theater was towed
label: Paragraph

text: by tugboat to a mooring near the Punta della Dogana, or Custom Point, across
label: Paragraph

text: the water from the Piazza San Marco. In this location it was first presented to
label: Paragraph

text: the public in 1979 on November 11 as part of an exhibition dedicated to the theme
label: Paragraph

text: of “Venezia e lo spazio scenico,” or “Venice and the Space of the Stage.” In the early
label: Paragraph

text: months of 1980 the Teatro del Mondo served as a performance space for the inau-
label: Paragraph

text: gural Carnival of the Theater held in Venice from January 28 to February 19. In
label: Paragraph

text: early August the barge with theater atop traveled across the Adriatic to Dubrovnik
label: Paragraph

text: to participate in the International Theater Festival. In late August it journeyed back
label: Paragraph

text: to Venice to participate in the first Biennale dedicated to international architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The theater as architectural object was, however transitory, a determined gesture,
label: Paragraph

text: the image of which has had lasting significance.
label: Paragraph

text: In reality, the building on a barge was composed of the simplest of materials and
label: Paragraph

text: the most basic of geometries: the composition was assembled by a cuboid center
label: Paragraph

text: piece that housed the stage and seating, appended on two sides by tall rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: stairwells and topped off with an octagonal roof that terminated in a spire that
label: Paragraph

text: pierced a sphere and was crowned by a flag. Structurally the theater was composed
label: Paragraph

text: of metal tubes clad on both sides by vertical wood panels. It stood about 25 m in
label: Paragraph

text: height above the barge and it had the capacity to seat 250 people. The rooftop of the
label: Paragraph

text: cuboid volume doubled as an in-the-round viewing platform. The ensemble was
label: Paragraph

text: painted in gold, and silver, and azure blue.
label: Paragraph

text: The Venice Biennale and Architectural Postmodernism
label: Title

text: The premiere of the Venice Biennale of International Architecture, which opened
label: Paragraph

text: on July 27 and closed on October 19, proved to be a polemicizing event. Themat-
label: Paragraph

text: ically designated by the title “The Presence of the Past” (“La presenza del passato”)
label: Paragraph

text: and curated by the Italian architect and historian Paolo Portoghesi, the exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: has been interpreted as the event that confirmed the arrival of architectural post-
label: Paragraph

text: modernism as a return to history. Recent research on the role of the Biennale in
label: Paragraph

text: establishing architectural postmodernism has persuasively argued that while mem-
label: Paragraph

text: bers of the organizational committee were critical of modern architecture there
label: Paragraph

text: was little consensus about the role history would play.’ A return to historical ref-
label: Paragraph

text: erence was but one way of making architecture more appealing to a broader public.
label: Paragraph

text: To mitigate the various contending positions the organizing committee embraced
label: Paragraph

text: inclusion: the Biennale comprised eight different sections, including individual
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitions celebrating the achievements of architects Ignazio Gardella, Mario
label: Caption

text: Ridolfi, Philip Johnson, and Ernesto Basile, who was associated with turn-of-the-
label: Paragraph

text: century Italian neo-liberty style. There was also a special critics’ exhibition curated
label: Paragraph

text: by Alessandro Mendini and Studio Alchimia. All exhibitions were housed within
label: Paragraph

text: the former Venetian shipyard (Corderie dell’arsenale) along with the exhibition desig-
label: Paragraph

text: nated as the “Strada novissima.” This main exhibition was installed as an exercise in
label: Paragraph

text: street facade design. Twenty international architects had been invited to contribute
label: Paragraph

text: a unique facade that when assembled as a whole created an eclectic interior street.
label: Paragraph

text: Some of the participants considered the invitation an opportunity to promote ideas
label: Paragraph

text: about communication through architecture language that references popular ico-
label: Paragraph

text: nography, and this presumably made for more legible urban expression. For
label: Paragraph

text: others, participation in the Biennale was an opportunity to lobby for historical ref-
label: Paragraph

text: erence as a means of deepening architectural expression. In either case, the exhi-
label: Paragraph

text: bition as street facade presented architecture as a plural, semiotic surface with the
label: Paragraph

text: intention of enabling meaningful communication. The focus on architecture as
label: Paragraph

text: communication, on pluralism, and on spectacle, swept up vague discontent with
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture, which for most was characterized reductively as functional
label: Paragraph

text: and abstract. Given this, the Biennale, following close upon the heels of Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Jencks’ 1977 The Language of Post-Modern Architecture, announced the arrival of var-
label: Paragraph

text: ied and controversial interpretations of the postmodern in architecture. Rossi was
label: Paragraph

text: twice represented at the Biennale. His design for the temporary ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: entrance gate to the exhibition area of the Arsenale contained formal references
label: Paragraph

text: and material elements that resonated with his design for the floating theater. In
label: Paragraph

text: the context of the main exhibition as a series of unrelated facades, the Teatro
label: Paragraph

text: del Mondo, moored in the waters across from the Piazza San Marco and at some
label: Paragraph

text: distance from the Arsenale, stood as a singular, spectacular object.
label: Paragraph

text: Writing about the Teatro del Mondo
label: Title

text: Rossi wrote very little about the Teatro del Mondo. He only briefly mentions it in
label: Paragraph

text: notebook number 26 of the Quaderni Azzurri, the little notebooks he kept from
label: Paragraph

text: 1968 until his death. Pasted on the cover of the notebook titled Architettura Ve
label: Caption

text: + Ny. ie. Teatro del Mondo 11 Nov 79 is a small, rectangular, colored drawing of
label: Paragraph

text: the theater. Inside the cover a closely cropped version of the same illustration
label: Caption

text: appears along with the remains of a complimentary entry ticket dated February
label: Caption

text: 1980. Rossi notes the opening of the theater on November 11, 1979, followed
label: Paragraph

text: by a loose description: “As the space of imagination and the imagination as an
label: Paragraph

text: urban intervention where architecture is realized in rapport with reality as an
label: Paragraph

text: affect. These ideas are over and above a great part of the beauty and fantasy of
label: Paragraph

text: Venice.” If Rossi’s record seems rather distracted for an event that in retrospect
label: Paragraph

text: would generate intense interest, his later entries offer some explanation. One entry
label: Paragraph

text: makes note of a date and place, Sunday November 25 in New York. Another
label: Paragraph

text: appears to be the draft of a dedication to Peter Eisenman intended for the exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion catalogue Aldo Rossi in America: 1976-1979. And another entry remarks upon a
label: Paragraph

text: gift he received from Anthony Vidler, a book titled Theatre of the World. Rossi was
label: Paragraph

text: becoming a famous international architect. The Venice Biennale was but one of
label: Paragraph

text: several exhibitions of his work that took place in 1979 and 1980. In the autumn
label: Paragraph

text: of 1979 Rossi had overlapping solo exhibitions in New York, one at the Max Pro-
label: Paragraph

text: tetch Gallery and the other at the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies.
label: Paragraph

text: These exhibitions marked a dramatic shift in the architect’s career, in the reception
label: Paragraph

text: of his work beyond Italy and Europe and more broadly, in the status of architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural drawings within an emerging culture market.
label: Paragraph

text: If Rossi wrote little about the Teatro del Mondo, others were not restrained in
label: Paragraph

text: their interpretations. In the January 1980 issue of Domus magazine, Manfredo
label: Paragraph

text: Tafuri writes that although Rossi’s Teatro del Mondo refers to the sixteenth-
label: Paragraph

text: century Teatrum Mundi, the reference is purely literary. For Tafuri, the floating
label: Paragraph

text: theater as a “closed and frozen form, destined to appear temporarily as an object
label: Paragraph

text: in the polyphonic space of St. Mark’s basin contains in itself a homage to the sense
label: Paragraph

text: of limit, to the Albertian concept of finitio, which is specifically anti-Venetian.””
label: Paragraph

text: From this elevated pronouncement Tafuri proceeds to relate the compositional
label: Paragraph

text: forms assembled in the Teatro del Mondo to those found in Rossi’s earlier work,
label: Paragraph

text: not in terms of a banal formalism but explained as a process, a compositional device
label: Paragraph

text: the architect employed to arrive at ever more precise objects. Rossi repeated the
label: Paragraph

text: same basic forms, the octagon and the cube, for example, as self-citation. Tafuri
label: Paragraph

text: claims that with each repetition the assembled parts become more refined. In Lotus
label: Paragraph

text: 25 of 1979, Francesco Dal Co’s approach to the work borrows from the title of an
label: Paragraph

text: engraving Rossi made in 1975, “Ora questo é perduto.”* The title evokes nostalgia
label: Paragraph

text: but Dal Co turns away from the cul-de-sac of memory and decay where so many of
label: Paragraph

text: the discussions of Rossi’s work from this period lie stranded. He attends to com-
label: Paragraph

text: position and typology, to Rossi’s preoccupation with significant form, and, impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tantly, to analogy. In 1982 Tafuri’s and Dal Co’s essays were republished in an
label: Paragraph

text: anthology of essays dedicated to Rossi’s Teatro del Mondo. Although Rossi’s intro-
label: Paragraph

text: duction to the anthology is not preoccupied with history or ephemeral theater con-
label: Paragraph

text: structions of previous eras, the essays and images present the project otherwise.
label: Paragraph

text: Rather, and retrospectively, it would seem Rossi saw the Teatro del Mondo as
label: Paragraph

text: emblematic of the condition of urban historical centers in the postwar period.
label: Paragraph

text: He wrote that, on one hand the project introduced a provocation, something
label: Paragraph

text: new within an old city, a city subject to age and preservation. On the other hand,
label: Paragraph

text: the project cast light upon the staid mentalities hampering new thought on the
label: Paragraph

text: city.” In Rossi’s view, the Teatro del Mondo became part of the city, not as critical
label: Paragraph

text: intervention inserted by the architect but as a participant in the contemporary real-
label: Paragraph

text: ity of Venice, a city of tourism, of souvenirs, photographs, and postcards. The
label: Paragraph

text: observation is not cynical; rather it speaks to the Teatro del Mondo as a spectacular
label: Paragraph

text: and ephemeral object, that might possibly be progressive and, if only temporarily,
label: Paragraph

text: transformative within the urban environment.
label: Paragraph

text: The Teatro del Mondo registered an important moment in the international
label: Paragraph

text: reception of Rossi’s career and it signaled a point of resolution within his architec-
label: Paragraph

text: tural thought. The floating theater was the embodiment of the concept of analogue
label: Paragraph

text: within the city: “In Venice, a city that is itself analogue, I designed ‘analogue’ archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. In this city linked to both the Orient and Occident, a city that exports and
label: Paragraph

text: imports its image.”* Rossi’s turn to analogy as the ground for his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: thought is evident in his introduction to the second Italian edition of L’architettura
label: Paragraph

text: della citta of 1970 (The Architecture of the City).’ The Architecture of the City, first pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lished in Italian in 1966 and translated into many languages before the English lan-
label: Paragraph

text: guage version appeared in 1982, would make popular retrospectively, especially in
label: Paragraph

text: North America, concepts such as typology, morphology, and the urban artifact.
label: Paragraph

text: The idea of analogous architecture and the Teatro del Mondo were of a different
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical and conceptual order than Rossi’s earlier attempt to articulate an urban
label: Paragraph

text: theory. The lectures Rossi gave at American institutions in the late 1970s are unam-
label: Paragraph

text: biguous about his shift away from a concept-based scientific urban analysis toward
label: Paragraph

text: form and the idea of analogy. In fact, Citté Analoga Drawings was the subtitle
label: Paragraph

text: attached to the “Aldo Rossi in America: 1976-1979” exhibition held at the Institute
label: Paragraph

text: of Architecture and Urban Studies in the autumn of 1979. In the essay, “My Designs
label: Paragraph

text: and Analogous Architecture,” published in the exhibition catalogue, Rossi explains
label: Paragraph

text: that when he designs he repeats himself.* Unlike his earlier, analytical and historical
label: Paragraph

text: materialist theory, repetition was a mechanism that functioned alongside analogy
label: Paragraph

text: and, in relation to sight, to empirical evidence as the central experience of reality.
label: Paragraph

text: Analogy takes place between things. As a concept adapted to architectural thought,
label: Paragraph

text: Rossi employed analogy to articulate relationships among things, leaving open to
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation how the analogical might be interpreted within an environment, an
label: Paragraph

text: interior, a drawing, or a situation. For Rossi, analogy was “already described in
label: Paragraph

text: things, was an accretion through time; it referred to different times and situa-
label: Paragraph

text: tions.”” Repetition was central to the analogical mechanism: within the design
label: Paragraph

text: process, by moving across various expressive media, and in reception, the analogic
label: Paragraph

text: mechanism triggered memory, and not history or historical reference. Analogy in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture required precise forms, the use of stripped down familiar forms that
label: Paragraph

text: could be arranged and rearranged. Against Tafuri’s accusation of a retreat to
label: Paragraph

text: silence, of playing a game with objects divested of significance, Rossi explained
label: Paragraph

text: analogy as a way of describing things that referred to different times and places
label: Paragraph

text: and, as such, annulled historical meaning for an analogic process that might pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duce temporary meanings.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Like much of Rossi’s work from this period, the Teatro del Mondo inspired var-
label: Paragraph

text: ious interpretations; among the most obvious are as a return to history and histor-
label: Paragraph

text: icism, the architectural equivalent par excellence of postmodernism, and, more
label: Paragraph

text: recently, the inauguration of the internationally celebrated architect. Reviews of
label: Paragraph

text: the exhibitions from the late 1970s tend to reference the cerebral aspects of the archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect’s work: Rossi provokes mental processes, he is a poet promoting an “intensely
label: Paragraph

text: personal analogous architecture.”'’ Most interpretations are receptive if not alto-
label: Paragraph

text: gether flattering. Writing in Archithese, Rosemarie Haag-Bletter voiced a dissenting
label: Paragraph

text: point of view, stating that Rossi’s work had become predictable and, verging on nos-
label: Paragraph

text: talgia, was too personal and nice.’* And the poet John Ashbery remarked in his
label: Paragraph

text: review of the New York exhibitions that “Rossi’s work has engendered a formidable
label: Paragraph

text: critical literature, much of it difficult, some of it merely silly...”
label: Paragraph

text: The Fortune of il Teatro del Mondo
label: Title

text: While attempts by Rossi and his supporters to have the Teatro del Mondo made
label: Paragraph

text: permanent were unsuccessful, its place in the architect’s oeuvre as well as in archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural history was immediately secured. In autumn of 1981 the Max Protetch Gal-
label: Paragraph

text: lery held an exhibition titled “Aldo Rossi Projects: The Monuments of Venice,”
label: Paragraph

text: which featured the Teatro del Mondo repeatedly and in various forms of represen-
label: Paragraph

text: tation from rigorous plan drawing to pastel and watercolor sketches to spectacular
label: Paragraph

text: photographs. The photographs of the Teatro del Mondo have always impressed
label: Paragraph

text: and invited interpretation. Black and white photographs capture the object myste-
label: Paragraph

text: riously emerging from within a shroud of fog along a sullen river somewhere in
label: Paragraph

text: north-eastern Italy. These images no doubt contribute to interpretations of Rossi's
label: Paragraph

text: work from this period as preoccupied with memory, with death and decay, and of
label: Paragraph

text: an increasingly private or nostalgic poetic connected to a specific geography. The
label: Paragraph

text: color photographs that capture dazzling sunlit aerial views of the Teatro del Mondo
label: Paragraph

text: against a backdrop of azure sky and a glistening Venetian environs invoke vague
label: Paragraph

text: connections among the historic city, water, history, and ephemeral spectacle. The
label: Paragraph

text: circulation of such images signaled a defining moment in late twentieth-century
label: Paragraph

text: architecture where the ambiguous exchange among image, object, and fame pre-
label: Paragraph

text: figure the unambiguous emergence of a market for spectacular star architecture.

text: Sangath (1979-81) sits between two phases in the oeuvre of the Indian master archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect Balkrishna Doshi: a first phase, in which machine-like cubic masses are raised
label: Paragraph

text: aloft in the landscape; and a second, characterized by crustacean-like creatures lying
label: Paragraph

text: embedded in the ground. The first includes the Institute of Indology in Ahmedabad
label: Paragraph

text: (1957-62) and the Indian Institute of Management in Bangalore (1977-85), and the
label: Paragraph

text: second the eccentric Husain-Doshi Gufa (1992-95) that followed Sangath. Sangath
label: Paragraph

text: is a key project that takes Doshi from an explicitly rational and objective approach
label: Paragraph

text: to architecture toward an openly oneiric and mythopoeic way of working.
label: Paragraph

text: As a stalwart of the first generation of Indian architects to emerge following
label: Paragraph

text: national independence in 1947, Doshi took on the enormous task of graduating
label: Paragraph

text: India into a “brave, new world,” as proposed by the first prime minister Jawaharlal
label: Paragraph

text: Nehru. Since then, through a powerful body of work, Doshi has been instrumental
label: Paragraph

text: in framing a modern architectural idiom and ethos for the country. This was made
label: Paragraph

text: possible through his personal commitment to nation-building and a unique expe-
label: Paragraph

text: rience, with two of the foremost form-makers of the modern period. Working with
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier in his Paris studio (1951-57) on his buildings in Chandigarh and
label: Paragraph

text: Ahmedabad destined Doshi to take on bigger challenges. He set up his practice
label: Paragraph

text: in Ahmedabad (1958), a city that had already positioned itself, with work by Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier and later by Louis Kahn (whom Doshi had invited and was involved with
label: Paragraph

text: in the Indian Institute of Management project), as a site for demonstrative modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Doshi also founded an architectural school (1962) that he directed and
label: Paragraph

text: established as one of the distinguished ones in India.
label: Paragraph

text: Besides his intimacy with both the mission and realization of modern architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture, Doshi has remained deeply in touch with the ethos of India’s ancient civili-
label: Paragraph

text: zation. He continues to reflect on and draw inspiration from the vast repertoire of
label: Paragraph

text: Vedic and Hindu traditions. It is this presence of two civilizational and philosoph-
label: Paragraph

text: ical strands in Doshi’s work that has always offered new possibilities and excur-
label: Paragraph

text: sions, as well as debates, in the evolution of modern Indian architecture. What
label: Paragraph

text: distinguishes Sangath from Doshi’s earlier projects is a more unabashed narrative
label: Paragraph

text: of the Indian strand as well as a deeply personal mythography.
label: Paragraph

text: In line with his expanded commitment to architecture involving professional
label: Paragraph

text: practice, research, and teaching, Doshi conceived of his design work in wider
label: Paragraph

text: terms, as a laboratory for the creation of new architectural paradigms. On a parcel
label: Paragraph

text: of land on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, Doshi designed and created a miniature
label: Paragraph

text: complex starting in the 1970s that came to reflect his synthetic vision of practice
label: Paragraph

text: and research. He gave that expanded practice the title of Sangath, or “moving
label: Paragraph

text: together through participation.” It was to include his architectural office and the
label: Paragraph

text: Vastushilpa Foundation for Studies and Research in Environmental Design. San-
label: Caption

text: gath was conceived, William Curtis notes, as Doshi’s version of an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory in the likeness of Corbusier's atelier at 35, rue de Sevres, or Frank Lloyd
label: Caption

text: Wright’s Taliesin.
label: Paragraph

text: In characterizing Sangath as a turning point that marks both a crystallization of
label: Paragraph

text: earlier experiments and deliberate movement toward a new stage, three principal
label: Paragraph

text: themes stand out: an intimate conversation between architecture and landscape; an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural formation that acknowledges a climatic narrative; and choreographed
label: Paragraph

text: movement in a highly structured spatial matrix.
label: Paragraph

text: Grounding
label: Title

text: What immediately characterizes the physiognomy of Sangath is the proposition
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture as a topographical manipulation. Producing an ambiguity
label: Paragraph

text: between building and landscape, the configuration is best understood as some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing that has evolved out of the ground, or, recognizing the fact that it is an
label: Paragraph

text: artificial work, sculpted from it. The visual imagery of Sangath is a group of
label: Paragraph

text: vaulted shapes oriented in one direction that rise from a constructed landscape
label: Paragraph

text: of planes, terraces, walls, and steps. Water runs along the interstices of the
label: Paragraph

text: vaults, on channels and troughs, often cascading down, to create a pool. While
label: Paragraph

text: the interior of the building is a mystery from the exterior, indications of subter-
label: Paragraph

text: ranean conditions are already indicated in the overall ensemble. The “miniature”
label: Paragraph

text: drawing series generated by Doshi following the construction shows the site
label: Paragraph

text: with a veritable catalog of architectural and landscape motifs: wall, steps, ter-
label: Paragraph

text: races, trees, artifacts, architectural fragments distributed throughout the larger
label: Paragraph

text: landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: While the compact ensemble sits on the site as if it has been there for a very long
label: Paragraph

text: time, architectural critics have ventured to suggest a range of metaphors: a group of
label: Paragraph

text: buildings on a hill, a small village, or a traditional building grown from the ground.
label: Paragraph

text: A reference to traditional Indian architecture invoking either an earth architecture
label: Paragraph

text: or the profile of domical architecture is only allusive and without any particularity.
label: Paragraph

text: An Indian context is more compellingly present in the climatic responses and per-
label: Paragraph

text: ipatetic experience on the site. Some of the textural modulation, although sugges-
label: Paragraph

text: tive of the work of the Spanish-Catalan architect Josep-Maria Jujol (1879-1949),
label: Paragraph

text: with whom Doshi has expressed a new kinship, may also be found in unspecific
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular traditions of India.
label: Paragraph

text: Sangath’s figural alignment may be closer to the other repertoire of Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: the work that involves a deeply imbricated mutuality between building and land-
label: Paragraph

text: scape, not the polemical antithesis represented in the Swiss-French master’s
label: Paragraph

text: cubic projects. Two residences designed at the same time by Le Corbusier for
label: Caption

text: Ahmedabad represent these dual and antagonistic strands: Villa Shodhan, as a
label: Paragraph

text: tropical reincarnation of the cubic Villa Savoye; and the Sarabhai House as recalling
label: Paragraph

text: an earth-hugging Mediterranean vernacular ethic. Sarabhai House, especially with
label: Paragraph

text: its Catalan vaults, structural parallelism, grass-covered roof, and unabashed
label: Paragraph

text: “merging” with the landscape, exonerated the territorially detached ideology
label: Paragraph

text: through a “pact with nature.” The grounded physiognomy of Sarabhai House
label: Paragraph

text: can be traced back to Le Corbusier's other, but consistent attempt at translating
label: Paragraph

text: vernacular types, works that were kept in the background in the primetime of
label: Paragraph

text: his cubic ideology in the 1920s. The strand of this series of work proceeds from his
label: Paragraph

text: own Weekend House with the vault and grass roof (1920s) to the radical postwar
label: Paragraph

text: design of Maison Jaoul (1951).
label: Caption

text: Sangath, in bringing to the foreground the ancient relational theme of architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture and landscape, and challenging the “two-ness” of the two, also remains an
label: Paragraph

text: homage to the other Le Corbusier.’ Doshi’s desire for collaboration between archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture and landscape, where the continuum of the landform merges with the
label: Paragraph

text: autonomy of the former, produces what many see as an ambiguity. This interaction
label: Paragraph

text: may be better described as an affirmation of architecture as a landscape event,
label: Paragraph

text: aware of the inevitability of the building being sited and emplaced.”
label: Paragraph

text: Doshi’s subterranean quest, and a profound mutation of the cubic paradigm
label: Paragraph

text: inaugurated at Sangath, turns toward the mythological — the realm of ruins
label: Paragraph

text: and monsters — finding its explicit expression for the gallery designed for the icon-
label: Paragraph

text: oclast artist M. F. Husain, the Husain-Doshi Gufa at a site not far from Sangath.
label: Paragraph

text: Starting from Sangath, however, Doshi increasingly seeks mythological verifica-
label: Paragraph

text: tion in the grounding of architecture, and the valorization of a primordial rela-
label: Paragraph

text: tionship with the earth. While at Sangath, embedding part of the building into
label: Paragraph

text: the ground was carried out as a tectonic and climatic strategy, the Husain-Doshi
label: Paragraph

text: Gufa was conceived as some kind of reptilian creature slithering in the ground.
label: Paragraph

text: One had to enter that part-reptilian and part-cavelike project through a mouth-
label: Paragraph

text: like orifice. Doshi himself speaks of dream encounters of divining the site and
label: Paragraph

text: figuring out the form-shape. The elaboration of a subterranean creature-form
label: Paragraph

text: is not unlike a resurrection of Vrtra, an aquatic-terrestrial monster in Vedic
label: Paragraph

text: mythology who was once slayed by the celestial god Indra. Nor is it unlike Pythia,
label: Paragraph

text: slaughtered by Apollo in Greek imagination to inaugurate a new imperium of the
label: Paragraph

text: celestial over the terrestrial. Such imagery points to Doshi’s engagement with
label: Paragraph

text: ancient Vedic and Hindu narratives, and his own deeply personal oneiric imag-
label: Paragraph

text: ination in form conception. With the deep symbolism of the cave, the Gufa reim-
label: Paragraph

text: agines architectural origins, or the original conditions of architecture submerged
label: Paragraph

text: in the onslaught of a marketplace mechanism or displaced sacrality. A disposition
label: Paragraph

text: toward earthbound construction was also developed in other projects; in fact,
label: Paragraph

text: whenever an opportunity offered itself. Even in a project with commercial cur-
label: Paragraph

text: rency, such as the National Institute of Fashion Technology in New Delhi (1997),
label: Paragraph

text: a project somewhat dressed-up with postmodern paraphernalia, Doshi discov-
label: Paragraph

text: ered an ancient well that led him to an excavated parti in the courtyard of the
label: Paragraph

text: project site.
label: Paragraph

text: Doshi’s Sangath phase speaks of his attempt to literally dig down into some pri-
label: Paragraph

text: mordial depth for a new foundational and ontological verification for architecture
label: Title

text: in India. “T tried to listen to the vibrations and activities that lay deep in her womb,”
label: Paragraph

text: Doshi confesses. “The earth always rekindles many dormant ideas in me.”* Even
label: Paragraph

text: though Sangath does not refer directly to any particular architectural tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: India, it proposes a new mythos: it presents itself as an easy and natural collabo-
label: Paragraph

text: ration with the site, as if it has been there a long time.
label: Paragraph

text: The “Vault”
label: Title

text: Sangath has also a rigorous plan, one that began as a rectilinear parti on a rectan-
label: Paragraph

text: gular plot constituted by two bays of vaulted space, a part of which gets skewed
label: Paragraph

text: into a diagonal motif to receive a layered land-form shaped as an amphitheater. The
label: Paragraph

text: amphitheater serves as the linchpin on the site, around which a circulatory rotation
label: Paragraph

text: is articulated. An earlier plan shows the site organized through four parallel rows of
label: Paragraph

text: vaulted spaces alternated by a sliver of “servant space.” Such a plan diagram recalls
label: Paragraph

text: the intertwined spatial and structural articulation of both Le Corbusier’s Sarabhai
label: Paragraph

text: House and Kahn’s Kimbell Museum at Fort Worth, Texas, making possible a rich
label: Paragraph

text: tapestry of layered and overlapped spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: The vaulted roofscape is a defining element for Sangath. Although it is essen-
label: Paragraph

text: tially a structural shell shaped as a vault, the upper enclosure is a carefully
label: Paragraph

text: wrought iconographic device that complements the landscape narrative, insofar
label: Paragraph

text: as the natural tendency of a raised vault is to return to the ground. Doshi’s form
label: Paragraph

text: has a number of possible sources: from the Sarabhai House to Doshi’s early work
label: Paragraph

text: with brick vaults for the housing for ATIRA (1957-60) and Bhandari House, New
label: Caption

text: Delhi (1966). He talks about appreciating the visual and material economy in
label: Paragraph

text: roofing an outhouse on the site with bent corrugated sheets. His sketch of a
label: Paragraph

text: museum in Egypt by Wissa Wassef, an associate of Hasan Fathy, is telling of dis-
label: Paragraph

text: covering an architectural idiom for a hot and dry milieu (1978).
label: Paragraph

text: After the adoption of the vault as a principal structural and spatial organizing
label: Paragraph

text: element in the design schema, its shape and geometry were studied closely
label: Paragraph

text: through drawings and various models. While the geometry required a structural
label: Paragraph

text: and volumetric discipline, the rigor was inflected by a largely irregular distribu-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of walls and piers from which the vaults emerged. Techniques of vault
label: Paragraph

text: construction were explored through the participation of native communities.
label: Paragraph

text: The experiments led to new possibilities, later carried out rather persuasively
label: Paragraph

text: in the Gufa.
label: Paragraph

text: Sangath is also a catalog of environmental cooling practices, in which the
label: Paragraph

text: vaulted shell structure is a key performer. Doshi realizes the sensibility of locating
label: Paragraph

text: a habitable space in Ahmedabad’s unforgiving hot and arid climate in a sheltered
label: Paragraph

text: cocoon. Besides the vaulted canopy, digging into the ground provides another
label: Paragraph

text: means of finding a cooler environment. Doshi speaks of a suggestion made by
label: Paragraph

text: the artist M. F. Husain in the early 1970s of going underground for climatic
label: Paragraph

text: reasons.”
label: Paragraph

text: In a climate-centered investigation of this kind the “vault” is conceived as a shell
label: Paragraph

text: structure created by two thin, hand-layered, ferro-cement layers with hollow ter-
label: Paragraph

text: racotta tubes in between them. The shell’s hollow layer provides an insular envel-
label: Paragraph

text: ope for the interior spaces. On its outer surface the shell is layered with a mosaic of
label: Paragraph

text: white broken china, the intention of which is to reflect the sun. Openings are min-
label: Paragraph

text: imal and when they do occur, the entry of light and view is highly modulated.
label: Paragraph

text: Water channels and troughs form a shallow area between the vaults, which in turn
label: Paragraph

text: provides another insular layer to the roofscape. In some instances, the channelized
label: Paragraph

text: water cascades over a window opening, invoking a vernacular practice of cooling
label: Paragraph

text: an interior by spreading moistened fabric over a window.
label: Paragraph

text: The Itinerary
label: Title

text: A choreographed movement is the third distinctive feature of Sangath. Upon arri-
label: Paragraph

text: val at the entry court that faces the vaulted end of the building-form, one is imme-
label: Paragraph

text: diately directed toward the left, away from the building, to encounter a series of
label: Paragraph

text: shifting axes, crossing of thresholds, and panoramic views of the main building.
label: Caption

text: The choreographed journey from the entrance to the inside of the vaulted space
label: Paragraph

text: couples one’s sense of far and near, surface tactility, and precisely located objects
label: Paragraph

text: (earthen jars and sculpture) conducted through a promenade architecturale. Along
label: Paragraph

text: this itinerary one experiences earthen jars as markers, metal sculpture, passages
label: Paragraph

text: through trees, views from under trees, landscaped grounds, water pools, low
label: Caption

text: walls and layered plinths, pavings with pebble textures, a grass-stepped amphithe-
label: Paragraph

text: ater, and a canopy under which a conversation can be held. Located like a
label: Paragraph

text: ittle plaza in a hillside town, the amphitheater is used for meetings and
label: Paragraph

text: performances.
label: Paragraph

text: Axial shifts in movement allow explorations of terrain that has been structured
label: Paragraph

text: through the techniques of landscape design. Akin to the order of movement in a
label: Paragraph

text: apanese garden, shifts are accompanied by textural changes and moments of pause
label: Paragraph

text: and reorientation. The construction of pauses — transitional spaces and thresholds —
label: Paragraph

text: in the spatial matrix becomes for Doshi a mark of Indian architectural experience.
label: Paragraph

text: Describing the spatial quality created at the Indian Institute of Management in Ban-
label: Paragraph

text: galore (1977-85), where a monolithic block has been disaggregated to create a
label: Paragraph

text: matrix of spaces and volumes with various degrees of inside and outside, Doshi
label: Paragraph

text: proposes that “supreme among architectural experiences are ones which occur
label: Paragraph

text: in spaces which could be characterized as pause or ambiguous, plural spaces.”
label: Paragraph

text: n terms of a corporeal experience, pauses initiate a breaking down of the scale
label: Paragraph

text: for a more humanized encounter. Such spaces, Doshi further argues in more mys-
label: Paragraph

text: tical terms, “activate the human psyche and induce it to sink toward the center, the
label: Paragraph

text: mythical world of man’s primordial being.”
label: Paragraph

text: From one of the farthest points, along a diagonal axis, the building is seen in its
label: Paragraph

text: skewed disposition, revealing coordinated relationships of things far and near,
label: Paragraph

text: modulating of landscape and building, anticipating arrival. Through these means
label: Paragraph

text: the elongated building form is revealed at its fullest. It is almost as if Doshi had
label: Paragraph

text: crafted that axial turn as the perfect moment to take in the full panorama of
label: Paragraph

text: Sangath: a visually controlled vantage point that establishes the image of the vaults
label: Paragraph

text: raised from the ground and modulated by terraces, plinths, walls, and steps, with a
label: Paragraph

text: grassy surface and water pools in the foreground.
label: Caption

text: The final steps toward the building pass through a tight entry, almost an inad-
label: Paragraph

text: vertent opening in the folds of the building. The itinerary continues into and within
label: Paragraph

text: the interior landscape, as one proceeds through a maze of layered spaces that often
label: Paragraph

text: connect the various levels, creating experiences of compactness and openness, giv-
label: Paragraph

text: ing different heights to the vault, as stairs mysteriously rise and fall, in a tightly-
label: Paragraph

text: packed spatial drama. The condensed and rich overlay of architectural pieces is
label: Paragraph

text: a snapshot of some old city in North India. Ultimately the itinerary climaxes toward
label: Paragraph

text: a long vista along the vaulted studio space where windows are few, but the most
label: Paragraph

text: prominent ones are those in the half-circle under the vaults that give a glimpse of
label: Paragraph

text: the Ahmedabad sky, bringing the visitor to the heart of Sangath: the long row of
label: Paragraph

text: architects’ desks in a kind of near-monastic setting not unlike, for those who know,
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's Paris studio.
label: Paragraph

text: Sangath, in its several ambiguities — vacillating between urban and un-urban
label: Paragraph

text: models, paying homage to an old master and attempting to discover something
label: Paragraph

text: new, offering the experience of a clear structural logic and a dreamlike inner
label: Paragraph

text: journey — still constitutes a wonderful, and wonderfully dense, example of
label: Paragraph

text: modern Indian architecture.

text: Alexander Eisenschmidt
label: Title

text: La Strada Novissima at the first official Architectural Biennale in Venice in 1980 not
label: Paragraph

text: only broadcasted postmodernism to the world but also announced the work of a
label: Paragraph

text: generation that shortly after was to redirect the discipline of architecture. The con-
label: Paragraph

text: tributions of Rem Koolhaas and Frank Gehry carried in their DNA approaches to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that ultimately were to question the historicism that had become one
label: Paragraph

text: of the common denominators. By the end of the 1970s and during the 1980s, the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural soul-searching in which Koolhaas and Gehry participated would largely
label: Paragraph

text: play out in institutions, schools, journals, and conferences. Different discourses
label: Paragraph

text: would emerge in various locations, from the Architectural Association (AA) in Lon-
label: Paragraph

text: don under the leadership of Alvin Boyarsky, to the New York-based Institute for
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture and Urban Studies (AUS) led by Peter Eisenman; from the journal
label: Paragraph

text: Oppositions, which was affiliated with the IAUS, to its successor, Assemblage; from
label: Paragraph

text: the initiation of the International Building Exhibition in Berlin in 1979, to the Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture New York (ANY) conferences of the 1990s. Architects, historians, and critics
label: Paragraph

text: sought to work out how architecture could play a role in the larger dynamics of the
label: Paragraph

text: world while knowing the modernist utopian downfalls far too well and thinking of
label: Paragraph

text: the possibilities of what would come to be called a “critical practice.”
label: Paragraph

text: In these years, architectural theory emerged in the United States as an independent
label: Paragraph

text: force, which steered many debates. In retrospect, Assemblage, for example, under-
label: Paragraph

text: stood itself as a “registration plane for a discourse in the process of finding its legs,
label: Paragraph

text: developing its skills, suffering its growing pains.”' The strength of theory (one indi-
label: Paragraph

text: cation of which was the founding of a new group of PhD programs in schools of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, devising a space for knowledge that was previously occupied by art his-
label: Paragraph

text: tory) provoked new engagements with practice. On the one hand, there was an
label: Paragraph

text: increasing distance as the discipline was seen as limited by existing economic, social,
label: Paragraph

text: and political realities while the discourse moved beyond these standards. On the
label: Paragraph

text: other hand, the independence and strength of theory also fostered many exchanges
label: Paragraph

text: that were documented through a wealth of publications that nourished the life cycle
label: Paragraph

text: of debates. Many of these exchanges hinted at a reformed relationship between
label: Paragraph
