text: theory and practice that was not always without tension. At one of the later ANY
label: Paragraph

text: conferences, Koolhaas, for example, would speak of the “Giedion metaphor” in
label: Paragraph

text: which thinkers adopted “architects as illustrators of their theories” only to realize that
label: Paragraph

text: their theories were “badly explained or imperfectly illustrated.””
label: Paragraph

text: One of the key moments during the reformulation of the discipline was the com-
label: Paragraph

text: petition for the Parc de la Villette in Paris in 1983. The newly elected French gov-
label: Paragraph

text: ernment under Francois Mitterrand had a big stake in Grands Projets that were to
label: Paragraph

text: announce a new beginning, not knowing that a landslide transformation would
label: Paragraph

text: come only several years later with the fall of the Berlin Wall, the subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: demise of the Soviet Bloc, and the reinvention of Europe. Bernard Tschumi and
label: Caption

text: the Office for Metropolitan Architecture (OMA, founded by Rem Koolhaas,
label: Paragraph

text: Madelon Vriesendorp, Elia Zenghelis, and Zoe Zenghelis in 1975) emerged as
label: Paragraph

text: the two most influential competition entries, with designs that at first sight could
label: Paragraph

text: not be more different. OMA’s striation of the site into narrow bands organized
label: Paragraph

text: diverging urban experiences that echoed the section of Manhattan’s skyscrapers
label: Paragraph

text: studied in Delirious New York, whereas Tschumi’s superimposed ordering systems
label: Paragraph

text: of surfaces, points, and lines choreographed an elaborate field ready to be inhabited
label: Paragraph

text: by events he tracked in The Manhattan Transcripts? Tschumi, who won the com-
label: Paragraph

text: petition, built over the duration of 15 years more than 25 structures, bridges, pro-
label: Paragraph

text: menades, and gardens. Most prominent are the markings of an expansive grid of
label: Paragraph

text: red cubes — structures that he understood as empty huts for unprescribed point-like
label: Paragraph

text: activities, folies in a constructivist red for no specific function but with the spacing
label: Paragraph

text: for events yet to come. In her chapter on the park, Julia Czerniak points out that
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi’s la Villette not only challenged the conventions between form and pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gram but that the structures were robust enough to accommodate change and
label: Paragraph

text: were, therefore, most resilient and “likely to survive.”
label: Paragraph

text: As the competition brief demanded, Tschumi and Koolhaas — who had both
label: Paragraph

text: taught at the AA in London — proposed an urban park, responding to the city
label: Paragraph

text: and reworking the common notions of the nineteenth-century garden. These pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects no longer escaped urbanity but instead drew from its culture and contributed
label: Paragraph

text: to it. Mining the city with the help of situationist techniques, constructivist visuals,
label: Paragraph

text: and surrealist mentalities led Tschumi to conclude that, just as there is no architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture without events, there is also “no architecture without the city, no city without
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.”* Or, to put it differently, architecture only exists because of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: The contemporary city became for Tschumi the true inventor of cross-, trans-, and
label: Paragraph

text: dis-programming and, therefore, remained the constant point of reference. This
label: Paragraph

text: city of emergent events would not only recast what exists but would also shape
label: Paragraph

text: a different kind of city, together with its buildings, both constructed by events.
label: Paragraph

text: More than recasting what the city is, it would suggest what the city could be.
label: Paragraph

text: What the urban manifestos of the 1960s and 1970s speculated was tested in the
label: Paragraph

text: city in the 1980s. Delirious New York, for example, examined the city of flux and
label: Paragraph

text: congestion and extrapolated lessons as a retroactive manifesto of “Manhattanism”
label: Paragraph

text: that OMA, in turn, aimed back at the city. Here, selective episodes within
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan and Coney Island (between 1890 and 1940) were viewed as generators
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural experiments that had remained unnoticed, waiting to be theorized.
label: Paragraph

text: Koolhaas drew attention to the divide between the unconscious building of met-
label: Paragraph

text: ropolitan architecture inflected by the constraints of the city (as in the policies, laws,
label: Paragraph

text: and economies of New York City) versus the conscious construction of theories
label: Paragraph

text: without limitations that remain unbuilt (as in the avant-gardes of the 1920s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s). The architectural mutations that the city provoked and Koolhaas excavated
label: Paragraph

text: were later reassembled through a kind of constructive surgery in the laboratories of
label: Paragraph

text: OMA. What began as “exquisite corpses” in true surrealist fashion developed into
label: Paragraph

text: architectures of and for the metropolis by internalizing the city’s delirium.
label: Paragraph

text: Roberto Gargiani’s chapter on OMA’s Kunsthal, for example, describes how
label: Paragraph

text: structural “pliable surfaces” were understood as “streets” that simultaneously con-
label: Paragraph

text: figured the exhibition spaces and connected the building to the avenue and park of
label: Paragraph

text: the city. By 1989, the project for the Ferry Terminal of Zeebrugge already envi-
label: Paragraph

text: sioned a space where one would have looked down from the casino, past the hotel
label: Paragraph

text: and lobby, and into the traffic of the parking garage. As in the Kunsthal, the city was
label: Paragraph

text: to sponsor architecture, not through a mimicking of images, but through an inha-
label: Paragraph

text: lation of the city’s pulsations and effects into the building’s interior. One of the first
label: Paragraph

text: built projects that explored the interiorization of the city in this way was the Check-
label: Paragraph

text: point Charlie Apartments, located at the most notorious Berlin Wall crossing point
label: Paragraph

text: and the nucleus of Cold War confrontation. Although it was part of the Interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional Building Exhibition (IBA) in Berlin, which from 1977 to 1987 invited interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional players under the auspice of “careful urban renewal” and “critical
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction,” the location of OMA’s building required a slightly different archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural urbanism. The ground level was devoted to the minutiae of border control
label: Paragraph

text: and the passage of traffic through the building and into the underground parking,
label: Paragraph

text: making the structure essentially part of the Berlin Wall that Koolhaas had
label: Paragraph

text: previously studied.
label: Paragraph

text: As OMA worked toward completing the building, world-changing events took
label: Paragraph

text: place almost overnight. They would radically alter the make-up of the globe. The
label: Paragraph

text: fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and Nelson Mandela’s release from prison in 1990
label: Title

text: changed the constellation and dynamics of the world order in the subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: phases of these developments. The distinct national colorations and sovereignty
label: Paragraph

text: of nation-states was increasingly questioned as the large ideological blocs were left
label: Paragraph

text: behind by a new de-territorialized globalization, which had profound effects on
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and urbanism.” In the case of the Checkpoint Charlie Apartments,
label: Paragraph

text: parts of the building became obsolete; in other instances the shifting territorial
label: Paragraph

text: forces seemed to be given form by architecture. Zaha Hadid’s work was one exam-
label: Paragraph

text: ple that expressed a territorial destabilization during a time of constant flux. Her
label: Paragraph

text: competition win for The Peak in Hong Kong (1982-83), for instance, let the land-
label: Paragraph

text: scape as well as the building emerge from the vibrations and shifting plains of seem-
label: Paragraph

text: ingly geological forces. Hadid, who had studied under Koolhaas at London’s AA,
label: Paragraph

text: generated geomorphic and seductive imagery that spoke vividly to and inhabited a
label: Paragraph

text: world of instability. She embraced these current conditions with the same deter-
label: Paragraph

text: mination as Koolhaas but with different techniques and formal repertoires. Taking
label: Paragraph

text: references from earlier constructivist experiments, the distinctions between land
label: Paragraph

text: and building became blurred.
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Gehry had already investigated notions of fragmentation and diversity to
label: Paragraph

text: form not only a new architectural geometry but also a new context for it in his
label: Paragraph

text: early buildings in California. According to Richard Sommer’s chapter on the
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Museum of Bilbao, these experiments had a great influence on his
label: Paragraph

text: later work in general and the Guggenheim in particular. Gehry’s Bilbao was to uti-
label: Paragraph

text: lize the capacities of this work and subsequently transform the image of the city in
label: Paragraph

text: terms of its global perception, from a little known shipbuilding Basque capital into a
label: Paragraph

text: globally acknowledged cultural destination. The time span from design to con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction (1991-97) neatly coincided with the commercialization and rapid wide-
label: Paragraph

text: spread use of the Internet, which brought images of the shimmering surfaces of
label: Paragraph

text: the museum to computer screens worldwide. But new technology not only made
label: Paragraph

text: the proliferation of images possible, it also contributed to new architectural forms.
label: Paragraph

text: The former amplified a desire for photogenic urban objects (such as Bilbao) in poli-
label: Paragraph

text: ticians and cultural officials, while the latter altered relationships between design
label: Paragraph

text: (in CAD) and manufacturing (in CAM). Programs such as CATIA, first developed
label: Paragraph

text: in automobile and aerospace technology, eased the manipulation of surfaces and
label: Paragraph

text: facilitated the construction of the exuberant and spectacular forms of Bilbao, as well
label: Paragraph

text: as the repetition of similar forms across the globe.
label: Paragraph

text: Repetition of a different kind — the one that interplays with variation in order to
label: Paragraph

text: develop families of elements and frames no longer bound to common regulations
label: Title

text: of geometry but ruled by algorithms — projected a new use of computational
label: Paragraph

text: advancements that gave architects control over highly complex non-standard geo-
label: Paragraph

text: metries. What was forecasted by Hadid’s vibrating landscapes of forms and tested
label: Paragraph

text: by Gehry’s intuitive surface modulations was a fascination long in the making,
label: Paragraph

text: dating at the very least to Erich Mendelsohn’s dynamic surface transitions and
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick Kiesler’s “polydimensional” spatial trials. These disciplinary ambitions
label: Paragraph

text: culminated in the mid-1990s in projects such as Toyo Ito’s Sendai Mediatheque
label: Paragraph

text: and the Yokohama International Ferry Terminal by Foreign Office Architects
label: Caption

text: (FOA). The chapter by Helene Furjan shows how FOA’s winning scheme capita-
label: Paragraph

text: lized on architectural visualization techniques and programmatic demands. As she
label: Paragraph

text: writes: “It was not an autonomous entity but a hybrid organization, meshed to its
label: Paragraph

text: environment, in a constant flux of thermodynamic and socio-political intensities.”
label: Paragraph

text: The visualization of complex relationships in a technologically saturated and
label: Paragraph

text: globally connected world was also on Toyo Ito’s mind when he first thought of
label: Paragraph

text: “blurring architecture.” Ito imagined an architecture between the visible (pre-
label: Paragraph

text: dominantly static) world of things and the largely invisible (ever increasing) net-
label: Paragraph

text: works of information technology. “Can I as an architect provide this ‘invisible
label: Paragraph

text: other city’ with a visible image?” The Sendai Mediatheque, its transparency
label: Paragraph

text: and the structural bundles that visibly straddle the different floors, approximate
label: Paragraph

text: Ito’s ambitions. Not only does the mesh of tubular steel structure hold all the
label: Paragraph

text: stories in place but they also work as circulation routes, light corridors, and ver-
label: Paragraph

text: tical ducts for all the wiring and HVAC systems of the building. Possibly most
label: Paragraph

text: important is the spatial delineation fostered by the shifts of these members on
label: Paragraph

text: the different floors. In his chapter, Ron Witte defines this repositioning as a “fifth
label: Paragraph

text: plan.” Witte detects unexpected possibilities in this new type of plan, which
label: Paragraph

text: “employ[s] the seemingly hardened ideologies of its ancestors in surprisingly mal-
label: Paragraph

text: leable ways,” where free-span is coupled with density, animated form with tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nological rationalism, and surface conditions turn into volumes and back again.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mediatheque serves as one example among several buildings that Witte
label: Paragraph

text: identifies as carriers of this new plan.
label: Paragraph

text: What for the Mediatheque seems effortless — namely, architecture’s involve-
label: Paragraph

text: ment in the world of images, data, and information — becomes in the work of
label: Paragraph

text: Herzog & de Meuron a relationship with contemporary art and collections
label: Title

text: respectively. Visual effects on the buildings are art-inspired and materially
label: Paragraph

text: defined. The Ricola warehouse in Muhlhouse, France, for example, presents a
label: Paragraph

text: leaf motif that is multiplied across the front and canopy of the building, while
label: Paragraph

text: the Dominus Winery in California is surrounded with gabion cladding cages
label: Paragraph

text: filled with stones from the surrounding vineyard. Here, too, works of art such
label: Paragraph

text: as Non-site: Line of Wreckage (1968) by Robert Smithson come to mind. In both
label: Paragraph

text: cases, the patterns contextualize and abstract simultaneously. Even in earlier pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects, such as the Stone House in Tavole, Italy (1988), the structure was placed in
label: Paragraph

text: conversation with traditional stone building techniques but quickly developed to
label: Paragraph

text: other ends. As Philip Ursprung points out in his chapter, the stone walls that
label: Paragraph

text: appear massive do not carry any structural load while the concrete frame that
label: Paragraph

text: holds up the building may be understood as a new form of ornament.
label: Paragraph

text: A similar poetics and sensuality is at work in the buildings of Tadao Ando.
label: Paragraph

text: The concrete frame that forms a cross in Herzog & de Meuron’s Stone House
label: Caption

text: reappears one year later in the Church of the Light by Ando (1989). This time,
label: Paragraph

text: the cross is solely formed by light and shadow, through cuts in concrete that form
label: Paragraph

text: what Jin Baek describes in his chapter as “non-materialistic iconicity.”
label: Paragraph

text: For both Ando and Herzog & de Meuron, museum buildings have become cru-
label: Paragraph

text: cial for their practices to grow and to allow them to experiment with new spatial
label: Paragraph

text: types. In the last two decades new museum projects have sponsored a large
label: Paragraph

text: amount of architecture with ever fewer architects designing them. Together,
label: Paragraph

text: Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa (SANAA) comprise one architect-duo that
label: Paragraph

text: has used design commissions to productively rethink the institution. Their 21*
label: Paragraph

text: Century Museum of Contemporary Art in Kanazawa, Japan, assembles a host of
label: Paragraph

text: individual galleries into a pristine circular plan. Each gallery is shaped differently
label: Paragraph

text: to accommodate various arts and alternating numbers of visitors, accumulating a
label: Paragraph

text: collection of individual pavilions that together form an urbanism of the interior, or
label: Paragraph

text: what Xavier Costa calls in his chapter on the museum “[an] archipelago of box-like
label: Paragraph

text: galleries.”
label: Paragraph

text: Several of these galleries pierce through the circular roof-line to generate spaces
label: Paragraph

text: with different heights and to catch sunlight from above. Here, the interior urban-
label: Paragraph

text: ism of what others termed “mat-building” surfaces on the outside and creates a
label: Paragraph

text: field of objects in the city. The project reworks the predominantly introverted pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gram of the museum as well as the interiority of the mat-building by adding to the
label: Paragraph

text: forms of the city. At the Multimedia Workshop in Gifu, Japan (1996), SANAA had
label: Paragraph

text: already responded to the city by making the building become part of the daily expe-
label: Paragraph

text: rience of the town. This time, the roof-line was lowered in one location, altering
label: Paragraph

text: the room heights in the interior and simultaneously bringing the roof in line with
label: Paragraph

text: the surrounding terrain. Separating the town from the occupiable roofscape by
label: Paragraph

text: only one step as interior demands for room height variation are fulfilled, shows
label: Paragraph

text: how forms of architecture can productively engage current urban realities. Or, bet-
label: Paragraph

text: ter, that our urban realities can propel new forms of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: In the last decade, architecture as field of cultural production has generated
label: Paragraph

text: diverging ideas of how to engage the world of today — a world confronted by clash-
label: Paragraph

text: ing opposites: vast economic surpluses and financial crises, dramatic self-inflicted
label: Paragraph

text: climate changes and technological advancements that enable us to understand
label: Paragraph

text: those, massive building endeavors and housing shortages for the poor, disurbani-
label: Paragraph

text: zation and an unprecedented number of people that now live in cities. While there
label: Paragraph

text: is no predominant direction, a common denominator and, frankly, reason for
label: Paragraph

text: hope, is that a new architecture—city relationship seems to emerge in many young
label: Paragraph

text: practices and a few academies. With a new attitude that goes beyond resistance or
label: Paragraph

text: embrace, practices increasingly understand today’s urban environment as a con-
label: Paragraph

text: stantly shifting terrain that can catalyze new forms of engagement to enter and
label: Paragraph

text: influence the contemporary world. Then, finding potential in the most unlikely
label: Paragraph

text: places becomes for architecture the prerequisite for articulating alternative prac-
label: Paragraph

text: tices that productively engage the realities of today. These practices do not resort
label: Paragraph

text: to mere problem-solving but instead define a new kind of “visionary,” one that is
label: Paragraph

text: able to project alternative worlds for the immediate future.
label: Paragraph

text: THE PROJECT AND ITS AFTERLIFE
label: Title

text: Across time and discipline, the Parc de la Villette — the competition for its design, the
label: Paragraph

text: winning project by Bernard Tschumi, and the built work — has sponsored a vast
label: Paragraph

text: amount of discourse and debate within architecture, landscape architecture, and urban-
label: Paragraph

text: ism. Since 1976, when the firstideas competition was held, to the present, its impact and
label: Paragraph

text: import have seemed wildly diverse depending upon the lens through which it is
label: Paragraph

text: viewed: the socialist agenda of President Francois Mitterrand’s Grands Projets; the
label: Paragraph

text: deconstructivist ambitions of architecture at the time; or through its contribution to
label: Paragraph

text: ongoing discussions about the history, theory, and practice of making urban parks.
label: Paragraph

text: The aim of this chapter is threefold. The first objective is descriptive: to recount
label: Paragraph

text: the significance of the competition site, the ambitions of the 1982 design competition
label: Paragraph

text: brief, and the intent of and physical proposal for the winning scheme. The second is
label: Paragraph

text: to discuss the impact of the proposed design while the park was being built and its
label: Paragraph

text: import still unfolding, evidenced in architectural and landscape publications. The
label: Paragraph

text: last is retrospectively to lookat the built work itselfand think forward about its impact
label: Paragraph

text: on urbanism and landscape design at the beginning of the twenty-first century.
label: Paragraph

text: To look again at La Villette in these ways is to see it with renewed clarity. We are
label: Paragraph

text: reminded of its vibrant life during the time of post-structuralism. We also recog-
label: Paragraph

text: nize that concerns within landscape and urbanism over the last 20 years allow us to
label: Paragraph

text: project its afterlife. In other words, if its life in theory is over, then what essential
label: Paragraph

text: part of its identity — which only time has allowed us to understand — lives on?
label: Paragraph

text: Shaping Influence
label: Title

text: La Villette is at once associated with a vibrant, evolving district in Paris’ 19th arrondisse-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, a formative international competition for a twenty-first-century park, and an
label: Paragraph

text: influential yet controversial urban landscape. Although the plot of land for the com-
label: Paragraph

text: petition and subsequent park is 135 acres (the largest park built since Baron Haussmann
label: Paragraph

text: transformed Paris), the project’s area of influence extends well beyond these edges.
label: Paragraph

text: The history of the site can be seen as an evolution of well-connected infrastruc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural improvements. Within the larger landscape, the eighteenth-century suburb of
label: Paragraph

text: La Villette grew along two arterial roads situated in a plain between the Butte de
label: Paragraph

text: Montmartre and Buttes-Chaumont.’ A nineteenth-century program of public
label: Paragraph

text: works continued to transform the site: canals were built to provide drinking water
label: Paragraph

text: (1812); the ramparts of Thiers were constructed to secure the city (1859); and a
label: Paragraph

text: centrally combined cattle market and abattoir, linked to a rail network, animated
label: Paragraph

text: the area’s economy and urban life (1867). These improvements catalyzed La
label: Paragraph

text: Villette as an important industrial hub and its subsequent annexation to Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: The abattoir and market were extraordinarily lively, employing more than 3,000
label: Paragraph

text: people and supporting them with shops and restaurants.”
label: Paragraph

text: Infrastructural changes transformed the site over time: the rampart was dis-
label: Paragraph

text: mantled, making way for the Boulevard périphérique; large-scale housing was built
label: Paragraph

text: on the abattoir’s edges; and in the early 1970s, with the closing of the abattoirs,
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were abandoned and the district began its decline.’ The plot that was
label: Paragraph

text: acquired for redevelopment by the state, and subsequently confronted by
label: Paragraph

text: designers, held significant reminders of the city’s evolution. The Canal de l’Oureq
label: Paragraph

text: bisects it and the Boulevard périphérique flanks its east side. The Grande Halle,
label: Paragraph

text: four neoclassical pavilions, a central fountain, and an immense unfinished sales hall
label: Paragraph

text: remain from its slaughterhouse days; the latter became the Museum of Science and
label: Paragraph

text: Industry, one of Mitterrand’s Grands Projets.* Through all of these changes to the
label: Paragraph

text: site, the call of the brief only supported the facts. It already was the city.
label: Paragraph

text: The brief for the international design competition for Parc de la Villette was so
label: Paragraph

text: advanced in its aspirations that it largely anticipated the results. Its ambitions were
label: Paragraph

text: threefold: to be a new model that rethought how parks would appear and perform
label: Paragraph

text: in the contemporary city; to provide a complex cultural program; and to act as a
label: Paragraph

text: catalyst for the redevelopment of the La Villette area.
label: Paragraph

text: To set a context for a new park model, the brief included thoughtful criticism of
label: Paragraph

text: historic French parks. It noted that whereas seventeenth- and eighteenth-century
label: Paragraph

text: parks offered rich places of diverse social exchange, nineteenth-century terrains
label: Paragraph

text: offered pleasant spaces to wander away from the discomforts of the industrial city.
label: Paragraph

text: Parks today — the competitors were told — were “simple, impoverished green spaces”
label: Paragraph

text: used mostly by the young and old.” Suggesting that “life and the city are elsewhere,”
label: Paragraph

text: the organizers asked for the new park to “reveal the riches of urbanism,” “exercise
label: Paragraph

text: the body and the mind,” and be “a garden of cultural superabundance.””
label: Paragraph

text: This call for a park as “cultural instrument” was enabled by a heterogeneous and
label: Paragraph

text: dense program of both dispersed and concentrated facilities, including kiosks, infor-
label: Paragraph

text: mation centers, discovery gardens, thermal baths, a skating rink, playgrounds, res-
label: Paragraph

text: taurants, snack bars, picnic areas, a post office, a police station, cycle paths, car parks,
label: Paragraph

text: and administration offices — a program for which the area of the site could scarcely
label: Paragraph

text: provide.’ Not only were competitors confronted with accommodating the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gram’s variety and day- and year-long use, they were also asked to give the park
label: Paragraph

text: a new image. As part of French culture, gardens (and by extension parks) reflect
label: Paragraph

text: a vision of the world.’ The Parc de la Villette competition brief called for innovation
label: Paragraph

text: not just in terms of use (how the park worked) but also iconography and symbolism
label: Paragraph

text: (how the park looked) — an important point with respect to its current relevancy.
label: Paragraph

text: Finally, the brief expressed political and social aims. Like parks before it, Pare de
label: Paragraph

text: la Villette was to be a catalyst for the redevelopment of the adjacent city. Its con-
label: Paragraph

text: nection to transportation infrastructure, to millions of inhabitants, and to housing
label: Paragraph

text: made the plot of land well suited for this role.’ Aptly put by the organizers, the park
label: Paragraph

text: was therefore “no longer the lung but the heart of the district,” a powerful analogy
label: Paragraph

text: that continues to serve park making.’°
label: Paragraph

text: Over 470 entries from more than 40 countries were submitted to address these
label: Paragraph

text: ambitious challenges.'’ In 1983 French-Swiss architect Bernard Tschumi was
label: Paragraph

text: awarded the commission for the initial phase of the park’s construction. Tschumi’s
label: Paragraph

text: winning response was conceived as a “large metropolitan venture, derived from
label: Paragraph

text: the disjunctions and disassociations of our time” and subsequently described as
label: Paragraph

text: “the largest discontinuous building in the world.””” The project cleverly addressed
label: Paragraph

text: the briefs numerous unknowns — the complexity and changing nature of the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gram, anticipated shifts in political structures and social needs, and the chief archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect’s role to coordinate the design contributions of others — by advancing an
label: Paragraph

text: organizing structure that could exist independent of use.’
label: Paragraph

text: To this end, Tschumi deployed three organizational systems across the site:
label: Paragraph

text: points, lines, and surfaces. The points (a system of objects) are 26 10 m-cube folies
label: Paragraph

text: organized on a 120 m grid. The lines (a system of movement) are a path of thematic
label: Paragraph

text: gardens, allées of trees, and covered north-south and east-west galleries. The sur-
label: Paragraph

text: faces (a system of spaces) are large expanses of space for activities such as games
label: Paragraph

text: and markets.'* Although superimposed, each system has its own logic. The folies
label: Paragraph

text: produced an imageable park by their accumulation of red color and cubic form, and
label: Paragraph

text: each could be transformed based on specific programmatic needs (from a work-
label: Paragraph

text: shop to a café, for instance). Two axial galleries made important urban connections.
label: Paragraph

text: The north-south gallery, conceived as a public street, connected two metro stops,
label: Paragraph

text: Porte de Pantin to the south and Porte de la Villette to the north, and linked other
label: Paragraph

text: park functions.'* The east-west gallery paralleled the Canal de l’Ourcq (which
label: Paragraph

text: extends from Claude Nicolas Ledoux’s Villa Rotunda to the suburbs) and acted
label: Paragraph

text: as an elevated viewing platform for the park. The system of surfaces consisted
label: Paragraph

text: of programmatically determined places with attendant material definition.
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi asserted that the “the overlay of systems creates a carefully staged series
label: Paragraph

text: of tensions that enhances the dynamism of the park,” all the while emphasizing
label: Paragraph

text: discovery and variety.'°
label: Paragraph

text: The resulting park is both formal and conceptual. On the one hand, its organ-
label: Paragraph

text: izational systems provided a sort of resiliency to its evolution and management.
label: Paragraph

text: The competition text stated, “It was clear that the elements of the program were
label: Paragraph

text: interchangeable and that budgets and priorities could be altered.”’” To this end
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi’s strategy of substitution was essential. On the other hand, by articulating
label: Paragraph

text: concepts such as superimposition, architectural combination, and cinematic land-
label: Paragraph

text: scape, Tschumi’s scheme proposed a new urbanistic strategy that advanced “an
label: Paragraph

text: organizing structure that could exist independent of use, a structure without center
label: Paragraph

text: or hierarchy, as structure that would negate the simplistic assumption of a causal
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between a program and the resulting architecture.”"*
label: Paragraph

text: Measuring Impact
label: Title

text: The winning scheme generated much discussion and debate in architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: landscape architecture circles while its design was developed. In architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: the park fueled a debate between theoretically motivated design agendas and more
label: Paragraph

text: traditional approaches to urban design. For landscape architecture, its reception
label: Paragraph

text: was mixed. Some welcomed its challenge to the popular understanding of the
label: Paragraph

text: appearance and performance of contemporary parks. Others were dismayed at
label: Paragraph

text: its dismissal of a rich and complex tradition of park making.
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi himself published extensively on his competition entry’s contribution
label: Paragraph

text: to architectural discourse and in so doing articulated two broad ambitions: to desta-
label: Paragraph

text: bilize architectural conventions and to rewrite the relationship between theory and
label: Paragraph

text: practice. In his book Cinégramme folie (1987) — which includes the project descrip-
label: Paragraph

text: tion he submitted to the jury, essays on the competition submission, and references
label: Paragraph

text: to earlier projects that informed it — Tschumi positioned the project in relation to
label: Paragraph

text: the literary theory of deconstruction, particularly the thesis that linguistic meaning
label: Paragraph

text: is both over-determined and indeterminate.’ He explained the design’s aim to use
label: Paragraph

text: operations such as superimposition and permutation to challenge the convention-
label: Paragraph

text: ally determined relationship between form and program, reconceptualizing it as
label: Paragraph

text: “combinatory” event versus designated function.” — “Deconstructing
label: Paragraph

text: architecture,” he wrote, “involved dismantling its conventions, using concepts
label: Paragraph

text: derived both from architecture and from elsewhere — from cinema, literary criti-
label: Paragraph

text: cism and other disciplines.” More specifically, “deconstructing a given program
label: Paragraph

text: meant showing that the program could challenge the very ideology it implied.””"
label: Paragraph

text: To this end, Pare de la Villette was intended to produce conflict, fragmentation, and
label: Paragraph

text: play, and — more broadly — to offer a vision of postmodernity that radically dis-
label: Paragraph

text: rupted meaning and established the framework for its social production.”
label: Paragraph

text: As an outstanding example of these ambitions, the project was one of seven fea-
label: Paragraph

text: tured in the “Deconstructivist Architecture” show at the Museum of Modern Art
label: Caption

text: (1988), where the curators hailed the projects’ ability to “disturb our thinking about
label: Paragraph

text: pure form.”” La Villette has always been regarded as a realized example of Tschu-
label: Paragraph

text: mi’s ongoing critique of modernism’s principles, but it attracted much criticism.”*
label: Paragraph

text: For instance, historian Robin Evans noted that while Tschumi’s deconstructivist
label: Paragraph

text: claims were adequately demonstrated in words and pictures, “La Villette is far less
label: Paragraph

text: transgressive than Haussmann’s planned butchery which it replaces.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Evans alluded to another important impact of La Villette. As the editors of The
label: Paragraph

text: SAGE Handbook of Architectural Theory describe it, the project’s self-conscious the-
label: Paragraph

text: oretical stance not only launched new discourses through which to critique built
label: Paragraph

text: work, “but also saw this critique as grounds for an enrichment of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: design process itself,” from design operations to representational strategies.”° In
label: Paragraph

text: other words, the project was a system of representation made up of words, draw-
label: Paragraph

text: ings, and the built work.
label: Paragraph

text: In an interview with architectural educator Alvin Boyarsky in La Case Vide
label: Paragraph

text: (1985), Tschumi contextualized this point by noting his theoretical thinking behind
label: Paragraph

text: La Villette and some ambitions for post-1968 architecture.” He described how his
label: Paragraph

text: earlier competition scheme for Parc de la Villette (1976), disappointing in its tra-
label: Paragraph

text: ditional approach of restitching the city, led to the start of his drawing series
label: Paragraph

text: The Manhattan Transcripts, which aimed to produce a new form of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: notation by transcribing relationships (between spaces and use, set and script, type
label: Paragraph

text: and program, and objects and events).”* In these ways, La Villette’s programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: deconstruction, experimental representation, and innovative design process chal-
label: Paragraph

text: lenged the normative distinction between theory and practice.” The project made
label: Paragraph

text: it more difficult to separate the theory of work — a place in which to develop con-
label: Paragraph

text: cepts — from the practice of work, where concepts are reified.
label: Paragraph

text: Regardless of their theoretical foundation, when T’schumi’s architectural preoc-
label: Paragraph

text: cupations hit the ground they inevitably became a landscape. As such, they encoun-
label: Paragraph

text: tered landscape architecture’s typical set of concerns: the role of parks in the city
label: Paragraph

text: and the pictorial conventions that define their appearance. The program for this
label: Paragraph

text: park was part of a larger system of cultural efforts under President Mitterrand’s
label: Paragraph

text: socialist agenda, which aimed not only to reassert the cultural prominence of Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: but also to produce a new public. In her provocative book on the Grands Projets,
label: Paragraph

text: architect and critic Annette Fierro explained that significant interventions in the
label: Paragraph

text: public realm — so important to the Parisian consciousness — illustrate “the state’s
label: Paragraph

text: responsibility and potential to advance culture over and above that of private enter-
label: Paragraph

text: prise.”’® The park was no longer a place to disperse and console discontented fac-
label: Paragraph

text: tory workers, as it was in the nineteenth century, it was to become a place to gather
label: Paragraph

text: and educate crowds. Tschumi thought similarly: “the park forms part of the vision
label: Paragraph

text: of the city.”*’ His prose describing his competition submission in fact restates the
label: Paragraph

text: missive of the competition brief, favoring a new urban park based on “cultural
label: Paragraph

text: invention, education, and entertainment.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Landscape critics received this park variously. Landscape architect James Corner
label: Paragraph

text: characterized it as the “single most significant project in terms of forging a new
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of the landscape.”*? Noting its controversy, he still advocates on its
label: Paragraph

text: behalf for the way it challenged the traditional role of nature in the city, “bringing
label: Paragraph

text: the density, congestion, and richness of the city to the park.”** In an essay written
label: Paragraph

text: 10 years after the park competition, landscape architect Christophe Girot expresses
label: Paragraph

text: less enthusiasm about “dismissing all traditional ideas related to the conventional
label: Paragraph

text: uses of plants and other natural materials in park design,” but nonetheless recounts
label: Paragraph

text: the fascination with the project in French landscape architecture circles.*” Perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: the strongest reactions to La Villette were ignited by Tschumi’s overt simplification
label: Paragraph

text: of and covert disdain for the rich traditions of park making. To those who appre-
label: Paragraph

text: ciated the complex history of parks, statements such as “we oppose the notion of
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted, widespread throughout the 19% century, that ‘in the park, the city is not
label: Paragraph

text: supposed to exist” were inflammatory.*°
label: Paragraph

text: Landscape historian and theorist Elizabeth K. Meyer challenges this through a
label: Paragraph

text: careful comparison of Jean-Charles Adolphe Alphand’s Pare des Buttes-Chaumont
label: Paragraph

text: and La Villette, despite Tschumi’s claim to radically break with tradition. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: their age difference of more than 100 years, both are characterized by systems of
label: Paragraph

text: circulation that acknowledge the presence of the city and, Meyer argues, strategies
label: Paragraph

text: of superimposition — with systems of surfaces, lines, and points. In this way, Meyer
label: Paragraph

text: says, Alphand’s nineteenth-century park “moves beyond the picturesque by fusing
label: Paragraph

text: its tradition with the facts of modern urban life.”*” She concludes by arguing that La
label: Paragraph

text: Villette’s radicalism lies in its lack of engagement with the specifics of the site; what
label: Paragraph

text: she calls a “non-landscape park” that fails to engage the most important system —
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape itself. Meyer’s text confronts misconceptions that were, and continue
label: Paragraph

text: to be, prevalent in the discipline of landscape architecture — namely that the city and
label: Paragraph

text: the park are mutually exclusive. This simplification devalues landscape history and
label: Paragraph

text: its nuances. Despite her critique, Meyer acknowledged that La Villette is nonethe-
label: Paragraph

text: less useful for landscape design, a discipline that all too often is “wallowing in kitsch
label: Paragraph

text: and in the image of the picturesque.”** Indeed, seen as a collection of landscape
label: Paragraph

text: representations, La Villette’s innovative diagrams and drawings challenged the pic-
label: Paragraph

text: torial tradition in landscape.”
label: Paragraph

text: Projecting Import
label: Title

text: On the occasion of La Villette’s 10-year anniversary, the journal Documents’ editor
label: Paragraph

text: Miwon Kwon referred to it as “not only one of the largest but probably the most
label: Paragraph

text: talked about, argued over, and publicized urban design project of the late twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century.”*° More recently, the editors of The SAGE Handbook of Architectural Theory
label: Paragraph

text: offered provocative wordplay, suggesting the importance of acquiring new ways to
label: Paragraph

text: understand it: “With its architectural fabric worn in, there is also an unavoidable
label: Paragraph

text: sense that Pare de la Villette’s theory has worn thin.”*”
label: Paragraph

text: So what of the possibilities of looking back at La Villette now as a way to think
label: Paragraph

text: forward? How has it informed the development of park design at the turn of this
label: Paragraph

text: century and, more importantly, beyond?
label: Paragraph

text: The organizational frameworks so intrinsic to La Villette’s identity are now thor-
label: Paragraph

text: oughly absorbed in design culture as a strategy for making parks. Nevertheless,
label: Paragraph

text: they have been expanded in important ways. The change and complexity these
label: Paragraph

text: frameworks enabled at La Villette — created in space — are now expanded in time.
label: Paragraph

text: An example of this expansion is Downsview Park in Toronto. Second, the compe-
label: Paragraph

text: tition’s preoccupations with a park’s performance attempted to suspend questions
label: Paragraph

text: ofa landscape’s appearance. La Villette reminds us of important lessons regarding a
label: Paragraph

text: park’s imageability. Finally, and perhaps most unlikely, the seeds of resilient design
label: Paragraph

text: — where a park is able to absorb willful and unforeseen change and maintain its
label: Paragraph

text: identity — were sown in T’schumi’s winning scheme.
label: Paragraph

text: Although La Villette and Downsview Park competition schemes were devel-
label: Paragraph

text: oped almost 20 years apart in vastly different cultural and political milieus, the
label: Paragraph

text: merit of comparing them is suggested by what appears to be an autobiographical
label: Paragraph

text: diagram in Tschumi’s scheme for Downsview.” This diagram suggests shifts in his
label: Paragraph

text: design work, and perhaps landscape work in general, since Parc de la Villette. One
label: Paragraph

text: important shift is that the Downsview competitors almost universally favored the
label: Paragraph

text: design of frameworks that organize parks systems over forms that define them.’
label: Paragraph

text: These frameworks are both infrastructural and administrative. They appear
label: Paragraph

text: diversely as strategic organizations, dynamic infrastructures, provisional programs,
label: Paragraph

text: and participatory processes. The organizational frameworks of T'schumi’s scheme —
label: Paragraph

text: spools (collections of diverse and changing programs), screens (for announcements
label: Paragraph

text: and scintillating images), and digits (fingers of diverse landscapes) — replace the
label: Paragraph

text: superimposition of points (follies), lines (galleries), and surfaces (gardens) that
label: Paragraph

text: organized La Villette. Tschumi’s earlier preoccupation with discontinuity is here
label: Paragraph

text: updated in a scheme that advances a continuous landscape enabling flows of water,
label: Paragraph

text: wildlife, and people across it.
label: Paragraph

text: The resulting project favors time over space. Its systems enable more contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary concerns of ecological emergence and change — concerns that were devel-
label: Paragraph

text: oped in even more sophisticated ways in other submissions to the competition.
label: Paragraph

text: Landscape architect James Corner and architect Stan Allen’s proposal, aptly named
label: Paragraph

text: “Emergent Ecology,” advances a “carefully gauged framework — a matrix of inter-
label: Paragraph

text: acting systems” of “circuits” (which accommodate activity programs, event spaces,
label: Paragraph

text: and circulation) and “through flows” (which support all the hydrological and eco-
label: Paragraph

text: ogical dynamics of the site) — that is both integrative and flexible.** The proposal’s
label: Paragraph

text: potential for multivalent articulation (flows, for instance, can be a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: meadow, a drift of lights, a drainage system, or a tree line) hence direct and support
label: Paragraph

text: a number of potential outcomes. This development of organizational frameworks’
label: Paragraph

text: potential continues years later in Corner’s scheme for the Freshkills Landfill
label: Paragraph

text: to Landscape competition. The “threads,” “islands,” and “mats” that organize
label: Paragraph

text: the winning scheme can be articulated by multiple material realities — unlike
label: Paragraph

text: the singularity of Tschumi’s points, lines and surfaces — thus enabling the park’s
label: Paragraph

text: robust identity despite the radical changes that are an inevitable part of any large,
label: Paragraph

text: long-term work.
label: Paragraph

text: The preoccupation of proposing frameworks over designing form in the Downs-
label: Paragraph

text: view schemes are invariably linked to designers’ interests in complex processes
label: Paragraph

text: having to do with “emergence,” “adaptation,” and “unfolding.” The changes over
label: Paragraph

text: time that these concepts infer are of course integral to landscapes. Finding in La
label: Paragraph

text: Villette ideas of open-endedness and indeterminacy, Charles Waldheim retrospec-
label: Paragraph

text: tively builds a case for the park’s nascency as a landscape urbanist pursuit. T’schu-
label: Paragraph

text: mi’s winning scheme, he argues, “represented a quantum leap in the development
label: Paragraph

text: of landscape urbanism by formulating landscape as the most suitable medium
label: Paragraph

text: through which to order programmatic and political change over time.”””
label: Paragraph

text: Such preoccupations with a park’s performance — from the scale of the medium
label: Paragraph

text: to that of the metropolis — raise a compelling question to which, surprisingly, La
label: Paragraph

text: Villette might offer clues to an answer. Must landscapes that are conceptualized
label: Paragraph

text: and formed through complex processes rely solely on these processes for their
label: Paragraph

text: image, or, can performative agendas be reconciled with representational ones?
label: Paragraph

text: Many of the La Villette competitors’ emphases on infrastructural frameworks
label: Paragraph

text: and complex processes try to delay, or even suspend, this question. Certainly
label: Paragraph

text: the growth of habitats within these parks will affect its visual identity, planned
label: Paragraph

text: and unplanned activities will leave traces on the park’s surfaces, and processes
label: Paragraph

text: of soil remediation might temporarily yield fields of clover and alfalfa. Nonetheless,
label: Paragraph

text: these effects are subtle and fail to produce strong park identities.
label: Paragraph

text: It is not surprising, therefore, that the winning scheme for Downsview Park,
label: Paragraph

text: Tree City by the Office for Metropolitan Architecture and Bruce Mau, not only
label: Paragraph

text: promised an ecological design that would emerge over time, but also offered
label: Paragraph

text: the park organizers and future users an identifiable image. The signature clusters,
label: Paragraph

text: or dots, that appear in the scheme and its representation are precisely how Tree
label: Paragraph

text: City was popularly recognized. Just as important, a big green dot, understood
label: Paragraph

text: as the park’s logo, gave it an immediate and marketable identity that promised
label: Paragraph

text: to stand for the park during the years of its making. The competition organizers
label: Paragraph

text: for La Villette asked for a symbol for the park of the twenty-first century. Notwith-
label: Paragraph

text: standing all of La Villette’s other successes, Tschumi’s scheme advances land-
label: Paragraph

text: scape’s imaging potential as an asset. The field of red follies is the image of the
label: Paragraph

text: park in both popular and disciplinary imaginations.
label: Paragraph

text: While a discussion of resilience in relation to La Villette might seem too spec-
label: Paragraph

text: ulative, Tschumi’s winning scheme is an apt example.*° As an ecological concept,
label: Paragraph

text: resilience is the ability of a system to experience disturbance (such as a fire) and
label: Paragraph

text: then return to a recognizable steady state. The important measure of an ecosys-
label: Paragraph

text: tem’s resilience is the amount of disturbance it can absorb while still maintaining
label: Paragraph

text: its function before instabilities flip the system into another kind of behavior, such as
label: Paragraph

text: grasslands becoming a shrub-desert. As a tool for conceptualizing, planning, design-
label: Paragraph

text: ing, and managing parks, it is useful to think of resilience in this sense. A park’s
label: Paragraph

text: capacity for resilience lies in the strategic design of its organizational systems —
label: Paragraph

text: whether infrastructural, formal, or operational — that enables it to absorb and facil-
label: Paragraph

text: itate change yet maintain its design sensibility.
label: Paragraph

text: Asan example, I cite Frederick Law Olmsted’s depression of transverse roads and
label: Paragraph

text: separation of circulation paths in plan and section as design strategies that enable
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park’s resilience. Despite 150 years of programming and development pres-
label: Paragraph

text: sures (disturbances) that have transformed many of the park’s green spaces, the key
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility of the park, the ability for a visitor to flow seamlessly — on foot, on abike, in
label: Paragraph

text: acar, or ona horse — without interruption, persists. This infrastructural armature for
label: Paragraph

text: the park thus enables the addition of buildings (such as the Metropolitan Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Art), the conversion of space (from the reservoir to the Great Lawn to ball fields), and
label: Paragraph

text: the shift of management strategies (that allow the Ramble to be a place for either
label: Paragraph

text: people or birds) without the park’s essential character being destroyed.
label: Paragraph

text: La Villette’s superimposed systems (the grid of follies, the ribbon of theme gardens)
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen in the same way. They enable a robust structure to which changes can be
label: Paragraph

text: made — from the shifting of folie program to the accommodation of other designers’
label: Paragraph

text: work — all the while maintaining the park’s winning identity. The park schemes that
label: Paragraph

text: are most resilient to change are the most likely to survive, regardless of whether
label: Paragraph

text: change is initiated through politics, economics, public will, or natural process. To
label: Paragraph

text: think again about La Villette, more than 30 years after the competition, provides
label: Paragraph

text: the opportunity to register specific sensibilities of thought and work at the time
label: Paragraph

text: and to track their sophisticated development in the contemporary landscape. The life
label: Paragraph

text: of the project — as a competition scheme, as a discourse in publication, and on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground as a lived experience — will no doubt continue to unfold.”
label: Paragraph

text: La Villette was designed at a time that did not yet foresee the context of global
label: Paragraph

text: environmental change in which designers must currently operate. Resilience
label: Paragraph

text: today, not just at the scale of park design but also at the scale of regions, takes
label: Paragraph

text: on new meaning. The design community is no longer asking why resilient design
label: Paragraph

text: matters. The challenge is how we innovatively produce and pay for it. To this end,
label: Paragraph

text: philanthropic organizations such as the Rockefeller Foundation, within the context
label: Paragraph

text: of their 100 Resilient Cities Centennial Challenge, offer a contemporary and provoc-
label: Paragraph

text: ative framework for economic, social, and ecologic resilience. The categories
label: Paragraph

text: they advance — “safe failure,” “flexibility,” “spare capacity,” “rapid rebound,” and
label: Paragraph

text: “constant learning” — catalyze this important conversation.
label: Paragraph

text: With twenty-first-century events surrounding global warming and sea level rise,
label: Paragraph

text: designers’ love affair with change has certainly been recontextualized. Resilience is
label: Paragraph

text: now about the survival of some of our most vital landscapes. The innovative design
label: Paragraph

text: of parks certainly has a role to play. Notwithstanding all that it is and all that it does,
label: Paragraph

text: it is hard to now imagine Parc de La Villette as “the park of the twenty-first
label: Paragraph

text: century.” That project is now our most current and urgent concern.

text: STONE HOUSE
label: Title

text: Herzog & de Meuron
label: Title

text: Philip Ursprung
label: Title

text: Herzog & de Meuron, Stone House in Tavole, Italy, 1988.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: BETWEEN THE HUMAN AND
label: Title

text: THE NON-HUMAN
label: Title

text: The very first commission of Herzog & de Meuron outside the surroundings of their
label: Paragraph

text: native city of Basel, where they founded their office in 1978, was a vacation house in
label: Paragraph

text: the Italian region of Liguria. The project started in 1982 and the building was com-
label: Paragraph

text: pleted in 1988. The house is located near the village of Tavole, about 10 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: from the Mediterranean coast, halfway between Genoa and Nice. Liguria belongs to
label: Paragraph

text: the south-western extremity of the Alps and is characterized by high mountains,
label: Paragraph

text: steep valleys, and a combination of Alpine and Mediterranean vegetation. The area
label: Paragraph

text: near the coastal port towns has been used for the cultivation of olives since antiquity,
label: Paragraph

text: but in the late twentieth century the hinterland was struck by depopulation and
label: Paragraph

text: many of the orchards in the old man-made terraces, which structure the landscape,
label: Paragraph

text: had fallen into decay. When the building was published under the title of Stone
label: Paragraph

text: House in 1988 its resonance among the architectural community was striking.
label: Paragraph

text: Together with a handful of other small buildings it triggered Herzog & de Meuron’s
label: Paragraph

text: international breakthrough. Like the Stone House, they all bear characteristic names,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Blue House (1980), the House for a Veterinary Surgeon (1984), the
label: Paragraph

text: Plywood House (1985), and the House for an Art Collector (1987).
label: Paragraph

text: Do these names allow us to look at these buildings from a different angle than
label: Paragraph

text: merely from an architectural perspective? Should we look at them as works of art,
label: Paragraph

text: as characters in a play, or as chapters that stand for different architectural themes? If
label: Paragraph

text: so, what could be the architectural theme evoked by the Stone House? I would
label: Paragraph

text: argue that the main issue of the project is the complex relationship between the
label: Paragraph

text: human and the non-human; in other words, the tension between the human scale,
label: Paragraph

text: its everyday surroundings, activities and dimensions, which go beyond the control
label: Paragraph

text: and understanding of humans. The key component of the project is obviously the
label: Paragraph

text: material of stone, both in a literal and a metaphorical sense. After all, the house
label: Paragraph

text: mainly consists of rubble and artificial stone, namely poured concrete. Its appear-
label: Paragraph

text: ance, at first sight, is stable. Stones are objects where the man-made and the natural,
label: Paragraph

text: in other words the human and the non-human, meet. Again, they are the result of
label: Paragraph

text: geological processes, objects shaped by nature over millions of years, and objects
label: Paragraph

text: that have been manipulated by humans in order to protect and separate them from
label: Paragraph

text: the rawness of nature.
label: Paragraph

text: The Concrete Skeleton and the Concept of Ornament
label: Title

text: How does the Stone House relate to the surrounding landscape, with its stark con-
label: Paragraph

text: trast of spectacular beauty on the one hand and signs of economic decline on the
label: Paragraph

text: other? The lot is located on a slope overlooking a valley. It contained the ruins ofan
label: Paragraph

text: older building and the remnants of the terraces once used for olive cultivation.
label: Paragraph

text: Herzog & de Meuron started with a concrete skeleton, which literally conquers
label: Paragraph

text: and domesticates the abandoned site. Its modular structure seems to arch over
label: Paragraph

text: the uneven rocky surface of the terrain and triumph over gravity. The cantilevered
label: Paragraph

text: terrace does not touch the ground. The skeleton is obviously man-made and could
label: Paragraph

text: theoretically expand over the entire landscape — not unlike the utopian collages of
label: Paragraph

text: the Continuous Monument by the Italian group Superstudio in the late 1960s. Its
label: Paragraph

text: orthogonal structure evokes the human dream to rationalize, survey, and control
label: Paragraph

text: nature. But the concrete structure not only recalls the age-old aspiration of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects to expand in space and to dominate the land; it also refers to a much more
label: Paragraph

text: mundane phenomenon, namely, the fact that most new houses on the Italian coun-
label: Paragraph

text: tryside consist of concrete skeletons, which, as soon as the budget allows, are then
label: Paragraph

text: gradually completed by adding brick walls. In order to save taxes, many homes are
label: Paragraph

text: left without plaster, in the state of framing. The presence of seemingly uncom-
label: Paragraph

text: pleted houses with half-finished brick walls and reinforcement rods sprouting from
label: Paragraph

text: the roughly cast concrete skeleton is a typical sight in the area. Herzog & de
label: Paragraph

text: Meuron have repeatedly referred to this everyday phenomenon. In one of the con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceptual sketches by Jacques Herzog one can read the handwritten note, “concrete
label: Paragraph

text: skeleton (with structure?) or color.”’ The question “with structure?” in the sketch
label: Paragraph

text: probably relates to the way the traces and joints of the pouring process remain vis-
label: Paragraph

text: ible on the surface. In another sketch the details of the cross are colored blue, while
label: Paragraph

text: at other instances it is proposed to paint them orange-red. The same cross-shaped
label: Paragraph

text: structure governs the organization of the floor plan.
label: Paragraph

text: It is no coincidence that Herzog & de Meuron put so much emphasis on the
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of the concrete skeleton. In fact, one could read the cross at the Stone
label: Paragraph

text: House as an ornament, which marks the beginning of Herzog & de Meuron’s
label: Paragraph

text: engagement with the ornament as architectural trope. It runs through their entire
label: Paragraph

text: oeuvre and culminated in the Beijing Olympic Stadium, the Bird’s Nest (2008),
label: Paragraph

text: where structure and shape unite. Unlike most of their predecessors in the twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century, and unlike many of their contemporaries, Herzog & de Meuron are open
label: Paragraph

text: to the concept of ornament. In a recent interview, Jacques Herzog reflects on the
label: Paragraph

text: way ornament is utilized: “Seemingly paradoxical, the ornament is what unites and
label: Paragraph

text: brings together the whole. If it reflects or contains the idea, it is an ornamental
label: Paragraph

text: concept. If it doesn’t then it is a decorative appendix, and we have always been
label: Paragraph

text: against the notion of the decorative.”
label: Paragraph

text: Is it then possible to define the ornament as the mediator between the human and
label: Paragraph

text: a non-human human scale? Could it be the element that allows an anthropomorphic
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between the users and the building, the element that facilitates an iden-
label: Paragraph

text: tification with phenomena with which humans cannot really cope? This anthropo-
label: Paragraph

text: morphic relationship is what seems to have been what art historian Alina Payne had
label: Paragraph

text: in mind when she described the role of the ornament in visual culture. She stated
label: Paragraph

text: that the “tertium comparationis that connects scale and sculpture (small or large,
label: Paragraph

text: architectural or object-based) is the human body, which engages directly,
label: Paragraph

text: physically, and haptically, the three-dimensional world that surrounds it.”? At
label: Paragraph

text: the Stone House, the architects articulated — in the guise of the concrete cross —
label: Paragraph

text: the complex relationship between the everyday economic reality of the home-
label: Paragraph

text: builder (eager to save on taxes but also participate in the ideologies of growth).
label: Paragraph

text: As such, the concrete cross symbolizes, like a hieroglyph, the intertwined ideolog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical and the economic conditions that determine architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The Stone Membranes and the Concept of the Image
label: Title

text: The concrete skeleton is filled in with rubble stones, which partially stem from a
label: Paragraph

text: ruined building on the site. Herzog & de Meuron used the stone walls to produce
label: Paragraph

text: the impression of a massive protection from the outside, almost like a medieval
label: Paragraph

text: fortifying — an effect enhanced by the fact that windows and doors recede deeply
label: Paragraph

text: into the wall and are protected with metal shutters. Inside, there is no servicing
label: Paragraph

text: space, such as a hallway, staircase, or lobby. There is no hierarchy of organiza-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, and no primary and secondary spaces; rather there are rooms that appear to
label: Paragraph

text: be added to and juxtaposed with each other, as in the farmhouses of the Enga-
label: Paragraph

text: dine, which the architects studied carefully. While the massive, compact appear-
label: Paragraph

text: ance of the building underlines this organizational logic, the stone walls seem to
label: Paragraph

text: dematerialize. The absence of mortar makes the individual stones appear free to
label: Paragraph

text: move and be reassembled in another configuration. The closer one looks the less
label: Paragraph

text: certain one becomes about the actual dimension — the facade, or rather, the stone
label: Paragraph

text: membranes of the facade, which are framed by the concrete beams, turn into
label: Paragraph

text: images.
label: Paragraph

text: Herzog & de Meuron had first worked with the concept of the image in the Blue
label: Paragraph

text: House, where the blue color — a reference to the French artist Yves Klein and his
label: Paragraph

text: invention of the Yves Klein Blue — makes the tiny building appear larger than it
label: Paragraph

text: actually is. It was developed further in the facade of Dominus Winery in Yountville,
label: Paragraph

text: California (1998), where stones appear to be floating in metal gabions. Since the
label: Paragraph

text: Millennium it has become a common tool in the realm of architecture.‘ The
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of stones resembles not so much a stack, but an accumulation of pig-
label: Paragraph

text: ments on the surface of a canvas or a plaster fresco — and in the end, pigments are
label: Paragraph

text: nothing more than very finely ground colorful stones. The variety of shapes and
label: Paragraph

text: colors produces a picturesque effect and the motif of the stone wall evokes various
label: Paragraph

text: examples from the realm of art. The sculptures of Arte Povera come to mind,
label: Paragraph

text: where, for instance, the sculptural work of Jannis Kounellis or Mario Merz, popular
label: Paragraph

text: during the 1970s and 1980s, make use of rubble stones. Another instructive point of
label: Paragraph

text: reference may be found in Paul Cézanne’s statement in regard to his paintings of
label: Paragraph

text: the Montagne Saint-Victoire: “nature isn’t at the surface, it’s in depth. Colors are
label: Paragraph

text: the expression, on the surface, of this depth.”* In addition, Robert Smithson has
label: Paragraph

text: written, although with much irony and as a critique of contemporary painting, that
label: Paragraph

text: “(tlhe word ‘color’ means at its origin to ‘cover’ or ‘hide.’ Matter eats up light and
label: Paragraph

text: ‘covers’ it with a confusion of color.”®
label: Paragraph

text: The concrete skeleton and the stone infillings are dialectically related. The
label: Paragraph

text: abstract and universal grid is confronted with a concrete and specific materiality,
label: Paragraph

text: and the optimistic gesture of expansion is confronted with the more pragmatic, or
label: Paragraph

text: nostalgic gesture of recycled material from the past. Again, it would be easy to iden-
label: Paragraph

text: tify a variety of references, such as the existing rubble stones walls in the area or the
label: Paragraph

text: practice of filling in the skeleton with bricks. But the architects are not so much
label: Paragraph

text: interested in “context,” or the direct mimesis of found shapes, but are searching
label: Paragraph

text: for something utterly different. Their project inseparably intertwines the old
label: Paragraph

text: and the new and transforms it into a phenomenon without precedent. This oper-
label: Paragraph

text: ation prefigures a theme that they will pursue in projects such as Kiippersmitihle
label: Paragraph

text: Museum in Duisburg (1999), the Tate Modern (2000), or the CaixaForum Madrid
label: Paragraph

text: (2008), which all transform existing industrial buildings into art museums. Getting
label: Paragraph

text: back to my initial hypothesis, I would argue that the potentially dangerous effects
label: Paragraph

text: of nature are held at bay by the building’s walls, which, on the other hand, frame,
label: Paragraph

text: absorb, and transform this very nature in an aesthetic phenomenon. The wall with
label: Paragraph

text: its frame becomes a membrane that mediates between the non-human and
label: Paragraph

text: the human.
label: Paragraph

text: Dealing with Discontinuity
label: Title

text: The stone walls do not have to carry the tectonic and structural load of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: In fact, they question the very existence ofa “wall,” similar to the cistern-like cover
label: Paragraph

text: of the house. At the same time, the walls do bear much semantic weight. The archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects make very clear how crucial the isolation of the house is in their view. In an
label: Paragraph

text: early sketch it bears the title “Einsames Haus” (lonely house), presumably a title
label: Paragraph

text: later discarded in favor of “Stein Haus.”’ In the lower part of the building only a
label: Paragraph

text: few openings pierce the volume, while the upper story has a row of windows that
label: Paragraph

text: open up to the spectacular view of the surrounds. Herzog & de Meuron have writ-
label: Paragraph

text: ten about the importance of the house’s exposure to nature. Among the documen-
label: Paragraph

text: tary images that they selected for the monograph of their oeuvre, one shows a
label: Paragraph

text: trunk in front of the concrete skeleton with the caption: “Tree trunk and concrete
label: Caption

text: support visually melt into a common supporting structure. The orientation of the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete skeleton toward the existing natural conditions becomes visible.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Another photograph shows how the supporting metal beams used during the con-
label: Paragraph

text: struction process and the surrounding trees overlap. The caption reads: “During
label: Paragraph

text: the construction phase, nature noticeably invades the shell, as though it could com-
label: Paragraph

text: press its rooms into a crystal. Trees and pylons commingle in the picture.””
label: Paragraph

text: The Stone House is doubly introverted: it closes itself off from the outside and it
label: Paragraph

text: focuses attention on the joints between the spaces. It deals with autarky and auton-
label: Paragraph

text: omy, but there is no modernist self-reference or artistic self-reliance. Rather it
label: Paragraph

text: relates to everything else, and triggers chains of associations of real and mental
label: Paragraph

text: images. The Stone House originated from a close reading of the site; namely,
label: Paragraph

text: the morphological, geological, geographical, climatic, historical, and economic
label: Title

text: givens, rather than from the perspective of traditions in architecture. The form
label: Paragraph

text: of the house does not echo any typology, it does not mimic the shape or materiality
label: Paragraph

text: of neighboring houses, and nor does it produce an analogy to existing traditions. In
label: Paragraph

text: an explanatory text published in 1997 Gerhard Mack states: “The seemingly clearly
label: Paragraph

text: structured classical house is not an object. It opens towards the sky like a rainwater
label: Paragraph

text: cistern.”'® What the architects in the 1980s were looking for was no less distant
label: Paragraph

text: from Aldo Rossi’s search for typological anchors, formulated in the 1960s in his
label: Paragraph

text: book The Architecture of the City (1966), than from Alexander Tzonis and Liane
label: Paragraph

text: Lefaive’s concept of “critical regionalism,” articulated in the 1970s. Herzog & de
label: Paragraph

text: Meuron’s aim was not to represent or critically comment on something that is his-
label: Paragraph

text: torically given, but rather to use architecture as a means to see the environment
label: Paragraph

text: clearer, to articulate what is there, to give a voice to something that exists latently
label: Paragraph

text: but remains invisible, or muted. Their attitude is not historicist; in other words, the
label: Paragraph

text: meaning of their work does not reside in the critical relation to the history of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. Rather, their attitude is experimental, in the sense of searching for a specific
label: Paragraph

text: relationship of architecture anew for each situation.
label: Paragraph

text: What could be simpler and more basic than a house of stone, the title seems to
label: Paragraph

text: ask. But the project is anything but irreducible. It is an architectural experiment. It
label: Paragraph

text: asks how the building relates to those forces, both natural and economic, that
label: Paragraph

text: define and shape it. But it is also an architectural statement, a built manifesto that
label: Paragraph

text: will become operational in later projects. Above all, it tells us the story of a rad-
label: Paragraph

text: ically discontinuous spatiality and temporality. History, we learn from the com-
label: Paragraph

text: pilation of stones rearranged as walls, is not a linear evolution of types, shapes,
label: Paragraph

text: and functions linked together, but a discontinuous accumulation of singularities.
label: Paragraph

text: Space, we learn from the massive shutters, the contradictory views, is not an
label: Paragraph

text: empty medium through which images and meaning can be projected and freely
label: Paragraph

text: shifted. Making connections between the “inside” and the “outside” will always
label: Paragraph

text: remain a challenge — a challenge that is continuously rehearsed with every open-
label: Paragraph

text: ing (be it a window, a door, or the roof). Even the act of placing the house on the
label: Paragraph

text: ground defies simplicity. The Stone House demonstrates that nothing can be
label: Paragraph

text: taken for granted. Architecture is not a medium to express what we know but
label: Paragraph

text: to learn and explore what we don’t know.
label: Paragraph
