text: CHURCH OF
label: Title

text: THE LIGHT
label: Title

text: Tadao Ando
label: Title

text: Jin Baek
label: Title

text: Tadao Ando, Church of the Light, Ibaraki, Osaka, Japan, 1989.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: The Church of the Light (1989) in Ibaraki, Japan, by Tadao Ando, is a significant
label: Paragraph

text: and representative Christian church in postwar religious architecture. One of its
label: Paragraph

text: notable features is the restrained atmosphere, which envelops the congregation,
label: Paragraph

text: and the altar positioned at the lowest point of the chapel. Another significant fea-
label: Paragraph

text: ture is the distinguishing “cross of light.” Despite the restrained design approach
label: Paragraph

text: that engendered an overall reductive setting, Ando acknowledged the cross, or
label: Paragraph

text: the universal symbol of Christianity, accepted it as the primary element in the proc-
label: Paragraph

text: ess of design, and eventually incorporated it into the chapel in such a way that an
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented “cross of light” came into being. The Church of the Light can thus
label: Paragraph

text: be seen as an integration of these two features: the reductive setting, and the dis-
label: Paragraph

text: tinguishing cross of light. This coupling marks Ando’s strategy in coping with the
label: Paragraph

text: cultural problem of how to present a cross at a moment when its efficacy has been
label: Paragraph

text: severely challenged under the dominance of secularized signs and of even senseless
label: Paragraph

text: signifiers.
label: Paragraph

text: Sacred Emptiness
label: Title

text: The Church of the Light is not the first to embody a restrained religious spatial
label: Paragraph

text: atmosphere. As a modern precedent, one can cite Rudolf Schwarz’s (1897-1961)
label: Paragraph

text: Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in Aachen (1930). Schwarz’s church is char-
label: Paragraph

text: acterized by the sense of “ein Raum” clothed in white thanks to the openness
label: Paragraph

text: between the congregation and the black marble altar. This church that embodies,
label: Paragraph

text: according to one critic, a “spiritual conception of space”' was a figuration of
label: Paragraph

text: Schwarz’s liturgical interpretation of emptiness, an emptiness that he saw as the
label: Paragraph

text: place where God dwells.” While it is unclear whether Ando was aware of Schwarz’s
label: Paragraph

text: church at the moment when he was designing the Church of the Light, the two
label: Paragraph

text: churches share the same ethos called “sacred emptiness.”’ In the case of Ando’s
label: Paragraph

text: church, the darkness lit by a cross of light grants the numinous to the empty space,
label: Paragraph

text: enveloping the adjacent modest altar, without any podium, and the body of the
label: Paragraph

text: congregation.
label: Paragraph

text: Within the chapel, the cross is placed not as an additional installation of religious
label: Paragraph

text: identity in an otherwise universal emptiness but as the central party that rivets one’s
label: Paragraph

text: attention fully onto itself. The cross takes on shape by excising dramatically the front
label: Paragraph

text: wall (18 m x 6 mx 6m), and through these four cut pieces of concrete a shaft of light
label: Paragraph

text: penetrates into the dark and empty space. When devising the cross, Ando was advised
label: Paragraph

text: by aconsultant to shorten its arms to ensure structural stability of the front wall. How-
label: Paragraph

text: ever, Ando eventually rejected this recommendation, and suspended the two upper
label: Paragraph

text: pieces to the ceiling. This denial ofa tectonic logic confirms his intention to present the
label: Paragraph

text: cross as the primary and central element. Indeed, the entire chapel — a molding of
label: Paragraph

text: darkness — operates as an optimal setting for an augmented presence of the cross,
label: Paragraph

text: confirming unequivocally its status as a valid and definitive symbol in Christianity.
label: Paragraph

text: In comparison with Catholicism, the reductive premise, that eliminates
label: Paragraph

text: anthropomorphic and figurative icons and images from chapels, is well acknowledged
label: Paragraph

text: in Protestantism. Despite this reductive premise, however, it is still normal in Prot-
label: Paragraph

text: estant churches to install a cross. This survival of the cross in the process of reduction is
label: Paragraph

text: due to the fact that the cross is a qualitatively different symbol compared to icons,
label: Paragraph

text: images, and figures. The cross is neither a human invention nor a figurative imitation
label: Paragraph

text: of an original in a literal fashion. Rather, it is a symbol of Jesus Christ both in a met-
label: Paragraph

text: onymic relationship, as it was the locus where Jesus was crucified, and in a figurative
label: Paragraph

text: similitude to his body that its horizontal and vertical axes arouse, not in a literal imi-
label: Paragraph

text: tation but in a highly abstracted fashion. In this regard, it is not surprising to find a
label: Paragraph

text: cross in the Church of the Light that noticeably espouses the reductive premise. In
label: Paragraph

text: this church, however, the cross has not simply survived. This is because its symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: status has now been revived and augmented. And, this is so precisely through the
label: Paragraph

text: reductive premise that operates as a prerequisite for the re-presentation of the cross.
label: Paragraph

text: The position of the cross is remarkable. Piercing the front wall, the cross stands
label: Paragraph

text: between the inside and the outside. Accordingly, the cross operates as a slit for the
label: Paragraph

text: introduction of light to the chapel. This position of the cross and its role as a vehicle
label: Paragraph

text: for light are exceptional. It is true that Ando always sought out a special location for
label: Paragraph

text: the cross throughout his religious or pseudo-religious works. For instance, in the
label: Paragraph

text: Church on the Water (1988), a wedding hall with intermittent Christian services,
label: Paragraph

text: the cross was positioned in the middle of an artificial pond. In conjunction with this,
label: Paragraph

text: he rendered the front to be completely transparent and made the glass operable
label: Paragraph

text: laterally to dramatize one’s perception of the cross from the interior. This cross,
label: Paragraph

text: which stands at the outside of the chapel and in the middle of water, demonstrates
label: Paragraph

text: influence taken from the cross found in Kaija and Heikei Siren’s Technical Univer-
label: Paragraph

text: sity Chapel (1957) in Otaniemi, Finland. Its reference is also traditional, as it
label: Paragraph

text: reminds one of the tori of the Itsukushima shrine. However, the cross in the Church
label: Paragraph

text: of the Light is different. Unlike the cross in the Church on the Water, it stands nei-
label: Paragraph

text: ther inside nor outside, but in-between. Looking back at the history of Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: Christian architecture, a similar “in-between” cross can be found in Kenzo Tange’s
label: Paragraph

text: (1913-2005) St. Mary’s Cathedral (1963) in Tokyo. This monumental church has a
label: Paragraph

text: slit on the ceiling in the form of the cross, and light thus comes in from above.
label: Paragraph

text: However, Ando was critical of this cross, claiming that the church was predicated
label: Paragraph

text: upon Western vertical conception of light. In contrast with Tange’s unambigu-
label: Paragraph

text: ously vertical light, Ando’s empty cross on the front wall in the Church of the Light
label: Caption

text: invites a penetrating beam of light, a beam that is horizontal or diagonal.
label: Paragraph

text: In reference to the chapel’s effect of light created by the cross, the smooth con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete wall surfaces of the Church of the Light are significant as well. Ando adopted
label: Paragraph

text: several tactics to formulate a refined surface. Any release agent on the surface of the
label: Paragraph

text: veneer form boards was forbidden, to prevent disagreeable marks on the surface.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead, Ando preferred to paint the surface of the boards, and in this fashion he
label: Paragraph

text: minimized the wooden grain traces on the concrete. The positions of steel bars
label: Paragraph

text: were determined as accurately as possible with the aim of securing sufficient cover
label: Paragraph

text: thickness between the outermost steel bars and the boards. Ando had concrete
label: Paragraph

text: blended, not with rough and crude aggregates but with well-rounded pebbles.
label: Paragraph

text: When the concrete was poured, Ando dispatched his employees to the construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion site to assist in the vibrating process manually. The purpose of this was to
label: Paragraph

text: remove as many vapors as possible so that a smooth surface of non-porous solidity
label: Paragraph

text: might come into being. Even when a flaw was discovered after the boards were
label: Paragraph

text: taken apart, patching it was forbidden in order to keep homogeneity of the surface.
label: Paragraph

text: It was through these tactics that Ando was able to formulate exquisitely smooth
label: Paragraph

text: and polished surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Material Light
label: Title

text: Ando explained his reasons for taking these extra measures to formulate smooth-
label: Paragraph

text: ness from the perspective of the effect of light.* The massive weightiness of the
label: Paragraph

text: concrete walls is transformed into luminous membranes onto which light, coming
label: Paragraph

text: in through the cross of light, rushes and collides. The shiny, sensitive, and refrac-
label: Paragraph

text: tory finish renders the beam of light corporeally present: palpable, tangible, touch-
label: Paragraph

text: able, and visible. Its effect is strikingly different from the exposed concrete of
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier (1887-1965), a treatment that was introduced to Japan through Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier’s National Museum of Western Art (1959) in Tokyo and Tange’s Nichi-
label: Paragraph

text: nan Cultural Center (1963) in Nichinan, Japan. The minute pockets on the jagged
label: Paragraph

text: and irregular surface of the beton brut retain the particles of light, rather than reflect-
label: Paragraph

text: ing and refracting them. In contrast, the smooth wall in the Church of the Light
label: Paragraph

text: optimizes its reflection back to the chapel. Light requires a smooth wall to get effec-
label: Paragraph

text: tively refracted and reflected so that its resplendent, corporeal manifestation in the
label: Paragraph

text: heart of darkness can be realized. At this moment of interaction, the wall appears in
label: Paragraph

text: its luminosity, for instance, as if gilded. In other words, the wall transcends its literal
label: Paragraph

text: status as a dreary concrete wall to appear in a fictive fashion that is meaningful in
label: Paragraph

text: the context of Christian spirituality.
label: Paragraph

text: This fictive presence of the wall — it appears as if it were gilded — allows us to
label: Paragraph

text: compare Ando’s approach to light with a historical case. For instance, Abbot Suger
label: Paragraph

text: (1081-1151), who administered the erection of a new chevet to replace the aged
label: Paragraph

text: Carolingian basilica of St.-Denis and opened serendipitously a path to the Gothic,
label: Paragraph

text: placed gilded objects — if possible, he could have gilded the walls, too — in expec-
label: Paragraph

text: tation of their interaction with light coming in through clerestories. The glossy
label: Paragraph

text: objects refract and reflect light, and render it to permeate the surrounding. This
label: Paragraph

text: palpable and concrete presence of material light was of course an anagogical sym-
label: Paragraph

text: bol of the eternal and intelligible light. Suger was well aware of the fact that, con-
label: Paragraph

text: ventionally, light hides itself in the field of the everyday through the very form of
label: Paragraph

text: abundance. Put differently, its being everywhere is exactly its form of self-seclu-
label: Paragraph

text: sion. Ando retained a similar stance, as he wrote that “light does not become objec-
label: Paragraph

text: tified and is not itself given form until it is isolated and accepted by physical
label: Paragraph

text: objects.”* Accordingly, in bringing this selfsecluding light to visibility, an
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s task would be to formulate an agency, such as placing costly gilded
label: Paragraph

text: objects in the case of Suger. In the case of the Church of the Light, the construction
label: Paragraph

text: budget was modest. Placing gilded objects or gilding the wall, as Suger would have
label: Paragraph

text: done, was not an option. It is from this angle that one needs to understand Ando’s
label: Paragraph

text: painstaking efforts to smooth and polish the surface of the concrete wall to the
label: Paragraph

text: point where it became a kind of depthless mirror. In the church purged of gilded
label: Paragraph

text: objects, light meets the polished surface of the prosaic concrete walls instead. The
label: Paragraph

text: effect of the efforts is extraordinary. The dull concrete wall turns into an efficacious
label: Paragraph

text: agency and produces an effect similar to that accomplished by Suger’s gilded
label: Paragraph

text: objects or walls. In its fictive performance, refined concrete operates like gold.
label: Paragraph

text: Thermal Atmosphere
label: Title

text: There is another effect of light: thermal atmosphere. Partially due to the limited
label: Paragraph

text: construction budget, the church was built without insulation, and it is cold inside
label: Paragraph

text: the church during the winter days. This coldness, however, is not merely a physical
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon. It has a spiritual and cultural significance as well. It keeps the believ-
label: Paragraph

text: ers awake and alert. It also keeps them from becoming overly ecstatic to the point
label: Paragraph

text: that the conscious and rational commitment to Jesus is supplanted by overheated
label: Paragraph

text: and hyperbolic proclamations and ambitions. Indeed, this emphasis on the intellec-
label: Paragraph

text: tual aspect of belief characterizes Japanese Christianity as the religion of the literate,
label: Paragraph

text: compared to, for instance, Shintoism, or the religion of the public. In particular, it is
label: Paragraph

text: well known that the Non-Church Movement, a remarkable indigenous Christian
label: Paragraph

text: movement established by Uchimura Kanzo (1861-1930), puts emphasis on the
label: Paragraph

text: rational side of belief. In Ando’s church, the thermal tactility of coldness, which
label: Paragraph

text: keeps the believers alert, concretizes this emphasis on the rationality of Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: Christianity. One’s being embraced by coldness as one enters the Church of the
label: Paragraph

text: Light thus has a ritualistic dimension.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as the darkness renders the beam of light more efficacious, so it is with cold-
label: Paragraph

text: ness. The light that is introduced to the Church of the Light shines through the
label: Paragraph

text: coldness. Its warmth is augmented thanks to this coldness. Put differently, the
label: Paragraph

text: pre-presence of coldness enhances the warmth of light. As coldness is not merely
label: Paragraph

text: a physical fact but a spiritual quality, warmth, also, embodies a spiritual signifi-
label: Paragraph

text: cance. Warmth analogizes itself with Jesus and his unfathomable love that any
label: Paragraph

text: rational effort to understand is destined to fail. The inexplicable Kenosis, or the
label: Paragraph

text: Absolute Irrationality, that a divine being emptied Himself to become like one
label: Paragraph

text: of His own creatures and to suffer on the cross for the sins of His own creatures,
label: Paragraph

text: tests any humane, rational approach to apprehend Christianity. In a way, the cou-
label: Paragraph

text: pling of coldness and warmth in the church is that of the rationality of Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: intellectuals who reason the cause of Christianity on the one hand, and the irra-
label: Paragraph

text: tional, unfathomable warmth of the divine love on the other. Ando’s church is thus
label: Paragraph

text: where two different corporeal engagements — one breathing cold air and the other
label: Paragraph

text: feeling warmth — are collated to connote spirituality. Upon the moment when one
label: Paragraph

text: is corporeally drawn to warmth on account of pre-given coldness, one spiritually
label: Paragraph

text: renounces rationality in favor of an ultimate unconditional acceptance of the
label: Paragraph

text: incomprehensible divine love.
label: Paragraph

text: As these observations imply, the spatial emptiness of the chapel in the Church of
label: Paragraph

text: the Light is not a geometrically defined, neutral setting but one that is imbued with
label: Paragraph

text: atmospheric qualities such as darkness and coldness. These qualities in turn oper-
label: Paragraph

text: ate as a prerequisite for the re-presentation of the cross with equally atmospheric
label: Paragraph

text: qualities such as brightness and warmth. In other words, Ando’s church utilizes the
label: Paragraph

text: dark and cold emptiness to re-present the cross that is bright and warm. It is a
label: Paragraph

text: re-presentation of the cross in and through a dialectical setting where contradictory
label: Paragraph

text: and compensatory qualities are brought toward each other. Such an approach
label: Paragraph

text: entails a criticism of the degraded status of symbols and icons into hackneyed
label: Paragraph

text: and prosaic kitsch in contemporary culture. In contemporary Japan, the perception
label: Paragraph

text: of the cross is never free from romanticism. A good testament to this is the post-
label: Paragraph

text: war surge of cross-bearing wedding chapels built exclusively for commercial pur-
label: Paragraph

text: poses. Regardless of religious orientation, young couples marry in such places
label: Paragraph

text: partially because they regard the wedding style as fancy. Interestingly, Ando is
label: Paragraph

text: not exempt from this secularized perception of the cross. He himself also designed
label: Paragraph

text: several wedding chapels, including the Church on the Water and the Church on
label: Paragraph

text: Mt. Rokko (1986). The cross here merely becomes a sign of Christianity in a coun-
label: Paragraph

text: try called the “empire of signs,” to borrow Roland Barthes’ (1915-80) characteri-
label: Paragraph

text: zation, where empty, referent-free signifiers float around aimlessly to form a
label: Paragraph

text: spectacle.
label: Paragraph

text: Blankness
label: Title

text: What is also important in understanding the status of the cross in Japan is the way it
label: Paragraph

text: is viewed by Zen Buddhism. Even when the cross could successfully convey the
label: Paragraph

text: suffering of Jesus, it was often considered as an emblem of inhumanity. The char-
label: Paragraph

text: acterization made by Daisetz T. Suzuki (1894-1966), the most influential Zen
label: Paragraph

text: scholar of the twentieth century, is a primary example. Comparing Christianity
label: Paragraph

text: and Shin Buddhism, he defined the cross as “the symbol of cruelty or of inhuman-
label: Paragraph

text: ity.”° When Suzuki used this phrase, he most likely had a baroque crucifix in mind,
label: Paragraph

text: and even imagining Jesus under crucifixion must have been too painful. Being a
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist, his conception of sacrifice was anything but bloody. Indeed, even after
label: Paragraph

text: mortification, Sakyamuni was not bleeding, but astringent and dignified.” In addi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, according to Suzuki, even when death is concerned, death for a Buddhist is not
label: Paragraph

text: anguish, distress, and pain but rest and peace.® What epitomizes this difference in
label: Paragraph

text: the conception of death is the posture, Buddha’s horizontal posture on the death-
label: Paragraph

text: bed contrasting with the Jesus hanging on the cross.” It is within this cultural con-
label: Paragraph

text: text that the “cross of light” takes on greater significance. Ando’s cross confronts
label: Paragraph

text: Zen Buddhists’ characterizations. By eliminating materiality from the cross, Ando
label: Paragraph

text: brings forth an unexampled cross that is diametrically opposite to that of the
label: Paragraph

text: baroque crucifix. This cross thus shapes a state of what one might call pure or
label: Paragraph

text: non-materialistic iconicity, and has the effect of radically Protestantizing the univer-
label: Paragraph

text: sal symbol of Christianity. The blankness of this cross, or its dimension of the invis-
label: Paragraph

text: ible, is thus a distinctive cultural achievement.
label: Paragraph

text: This blankness takes on further importance. Blankness conditions the cross’s per-
label: Paragraph

text: formance as a channel for the introduction of light. Thanks to the strong presence
label: Paragraph

text: of the phenomenal light in darkness, the cross oscillates between two values: the
label: Paragraph

text: referential value of the cross as the universal symbol of Christianity and its vehic-
label: Paragraph

text: ular value for the introduction of light. This alternation is neither vicious nor point-
label: Paragraph

text: less. It enriches the perception of the cross as both a gestalt and penetrating light.
label: Paragraph

text: This oscillation renders the cross to be the penetrating light, and the penetrating
label: Paragraph

text: light to be the cross. The cross carries out integration between the iconic and the
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenal. The substantial, permanent, and enduring aspect of the cross as an
label: Paragraph

text: icon is inseparably joined with the tangible, ecstatic, and transformative nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the phenomenal light. This union of the phenomenal with the iconic is effica-
label: Paragraph

text: cious. The light’s ceaseless alteration saves the perception of the cross from any
label: Paragraph

text: idolatrizing fixation. In turn, the immovability of the iconic prevents the perceptual
label: Paragraph

text: experience of the permeating light from being subjected to an endless manifesta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion in différance.
label: Paragraph

text: Shintai
label: Title

text: For Ando, any engagement with an architectural setting and its components is con-
label: Paragraph

text: ducted through shintai, or the Japanese notion of the body. Underneath Ando’s
label: Paragraph

text: clear statement about the role of shintai lies a distinctive philosophical tradition
label: Paragraph

text: called Kyoto Philosophical School, which dwelled upon shintai extensively during
label: Paragraph

text: the modern period. In particular the theory of perception and body in the philos-
label: Paragraph

text: ophy of nothingness by Kitaro Nishida (1870-1945), the foremost thinker in mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern East Asian intellectual history and the father of the Kyoto Philosophical School,
label: Paragraph

text: is noteworthy. Nishida understood shintai as an active, pre-reflective, sensational
label: Paragraph

text: capacity to embrace and feel the world as the content of the very self. Shintai is
label: Paragraph

text: an active, sensational vessel by which the self empties selfhood out to accept
label: Paragraph

text: the world as his or her very content. Shintai is an agency of creation, too, at the
label: Paragraph

text: moment when this sensational encounter is asymmetrical, as what the world offers
label: Paragraph

text: is greater than what shintai can internalize. At this moment, shintai transcends the
label: Paragraph

text: horizon of sensation and enters into the realm of creative act to accommodate the
label: Paragraph

text: sensational surplus.’° A piece created through shintai is thus not a sign that would
label: Paragraph

text: materialize an author's ideas, intentions, and conceptions. Rather, what is created is
label: Paragraph

text: the overturning of the self, or the exposure of the limits of the self armed with
label: Paragraph

text: ideas, intentions, and conceptions to regulate, apprehend, and measure the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Accordingly, what is created operates as a contradictory compensation of the self.
label: Paragraph

text: What is created and the self form a paradoxical ensemble of a contradictory union.
label: Paragraph

text: This union is more solid than any other type of union, as it is contradictory by its
label: Paragraph

text: nature.
label: Paragraph

text: Emerging from this cultural tradition of the body, Ando discussed shintai not from
label: Paragraph

text: the perspective of any dichotomous severance between body and mind, but from the
label: Paragraph

text: perspective of a corporeal totality, totality that he expressed variably as “a union of
label: Paragraph

text: spirit and flesh” and “a maximum effect of equilibrium.”’! Furthermore, Ando
label: Paragraph

text: understood shintai as the locus of the self that concretizes the reciprocal matrix
label: Paragraph

text: between the outside world and the interiority of the self. While Ando did not develop
label: Paragraph

text: this thesis on shintai to the extent of Nishida, this matrix is the condition for the emer-
label: Paragraph

text: gence of a creative postural articulation in resonance with that which will comple-
label: Paragraph

text: ment any sensational surplus present in the matrix. An element discovered or created
label: Paragraph

text: in this fashion is not a sign, but an extension of shintai that heightens its capacity in
label: Paragraph

text: encountering and embracing the world sensationally. Before it is a representational
label: Paragraph

text: figure to be screened by the semiotic gaze ofhegemonic and instrumental attitude, it
label: Paragraph

text: is a figure of the corporeally and pre-reflectively apprehended domain.”
label: Paragraph

text: Accordingly, shintai is also a key in apprehending the perceptual and situational
label: Paragraph

text: significance of the Church of the Light. Ando positioned the church in such a way
label: Paragraph

text: that access to the chapel from the outside is labyrinthine. This labyrinthine approach
label: Paragraph

text: is met dramatically by an axial composition of the dark and intimate chapel whose
label: Paragraph

text: terminus is marked by the cross of penetrating light. This integration between the
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinthine and the axial is intentional. Thanks to the former, the latter refreshes its
label: Paragraph

text: significance. The axial is no longer a hackneyed compositional technique. Rather, it
label: Paragraph

text: comes alive to coincide with and guide the movement of the body that orients
label: Paragraph

text: toward and faces things axially. One’s gradual procession toward the holy, an indis-
label: Paragraph

text: pensible part ofa ritual, is refreshed and enhanced in the Church of the Light. Shintai
label: Paragraph

text: —the actively knowing body through its sensational internalization of what is offered
label: Paragraph

text: — moves along the axis and encounters the cross. Curiously, in the church, the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: cession along the central aisle of the chapel is simultaneously an act of descending
label: Paragraph

text: toward the cross. The more one proceeds, the more towering and prominent the
label: Paragraph

text: cross becomes. One’s descending is thus one’s humbling, and when the journey
label: Paragraph

text: is done, the cross that — standing at the lowest point of the church and positioning
label: Paragraph

text: its arms close to the level of the eye of the visitor — symbolizes the modesty of the
label: Paragraph

text: Word God, has already altered its status into that of the highest and majestic loft-
label: Paragraph

text: iness. The cross is both humble and majestic, and each quality is apprehended based
label: Paragraph

text: upon sensational and postural reciprocity with shintai, as one faces the cross and
label: Paragraph

text: looks upon it to be imbued by the warmth and brightness. The verticality of the
label: Paragraph

text: cross, inseparably joined with warmth and luminosity, embodies not merely restive-
label: Paragraph

text: ness, toiling, struggling, and combating, but also triumph and grandeur. Suzuki is
label: Paragraph

text: indeed right in stating that the horizontal posture of the Buddha on the deathbed
label: Paragraph

text: marks a prominent contrast with the Christ hanging on the cross.’ He is also right
label: Paragraph

text: in stating that the verticality of Christ in general represents suffering and agonizing.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the cross of light in the Church of the Light is different. Being appre-
label: Paragraph

text: hended through shintai, it presents itself as a qualitatively different type of cross:
label: Paragraph

text: vertical, but warm and luminous.
label: Paragraph

text: The cross formulates an inter-expressive corporeal fabric with the shintai of the
label: Paragraph

text: perceiver. The victorious verticality of warmth and luminosity, and the shintai at a
label: Paragraph

text: lower position infected with cold and dark are joined to form an ensemble through
label: Paragraph

text: the logic of the contrasted dialectical union. The shintai desires the cross, as it offers
label: Paragraph

text: what is desired, or what shintai is lacking. The surplus of cold and dark combined
label: Paragraph

text: with the lowered postural stance is dialectically complemented by the warmth and
label: Paragraph

text: brightness of the towering cross. This bond or fabric is none other than the highest
label: Paragraph

text: form of apprehension predicated upon the efficacy of shintai, setting free the cross
label: Paragraph

text: from dry intellectual significance in favor of a corporeal resonance. This moment of
label: Paragraph

text: inseparable union in immediate attractiveness between the viewer and the cross
label: Paragraph

text: unfetters the gaze from its penchant for a programmed outline of the cross as a
label: Paragraph

text: sign of Christianity. In other words, it is not a figure that would confront the per-
label: Paragraph

text: ceiver as a sign to be deciphered, but a figure intimately joined with him by shaping
label: Paragraph

text: an inter-expressive corporeal fabric.
label: Paragraph

text: Of course, the cross can never be dissociated from death and resurrection. This
label: Paragraph

text: associational significance, however, is not a typical informative and referential kind,
label: Paragraph

text: when it is concerned with the cross of light. This is because it is integrated with
label: Paragraph

text: shintai’s pre-predicative and pre-reflective corporeal pounding, pulsation, and
label: Paragraph

text: trembling with the cross. In other words, this association is not merely intellectual
label: Paragraph

text: and cerebral, but corporeally efficacious. Again, the cross is thus not a sign merely
label: Paragraph

text: with an indicative significance, but a symbol apprehended first and foremost
label: Paragraph

text: through shintai and then amalgamated with the association of Jesus.
label: Paragraph
