text: KUNSTHAL
label: Title

text: Rem Koolhaas/OMA
label: Title

text: Roberto Gargiani
label: Title

text: Office of Metropolitan Architecture, Kunsthal, Rotterdam, 1992.*
label: Caption

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: THE PLIABLE SURFACE
label: Title

text: By the end of the 1980s a transformation had taken place in the organization of the
label: Paragraph

text: Office of Metropolitan Architecture (OMA). One of the key factors was the departure
label: Paragraph

text: of Elia Zenghelis from the firm, which was originally led by Rem Koolhaas, Madelon
label: Paragraph

text: Vriesendorp, Elia Zenghelis, and Zoe Zenghelis. In addition, projects in 1987-88
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to conclude a phase in OMA’s work that heavily polemicized its relationship
label: Paragraph

text: to the postmodern project and realigned the work with the modern avant-gardes.
label: Paragraph

text: Koolhaas was increasingly dissatisfied with architecture’s standard replies to com-
label: Paragraph

text: mon urban and structural problems. Concluding a two-year teaching commitment
label: Paragraph

text: at the Technical University of Delft, he took part ina conference entitled “How Mod-
label: Paragraph

text: ern is Dutch Architecture?” Koolhaas took this call for presentations as an opportu-
label: Paragraph

text: nity to criticize OMA’s master plan and contribution at Amsterdam’s large IJ-plain
label: Paragraph

text: social housing project. This self-criticism developed against the backdrop of the
label: Paragraph

text: decline of socialism signaled by the fall of the Berlin Wall, which disrupted the func-
label: Paragraph

text: tioning ofa part of their building at Checkpoint Charlie, designed when the Wall was
label: Paragraph

text: still standing. At the conference, Koolhaas rhetorically asked: “How is it possible, for
label: Paragraph

text: the love of God, ina century entirely marked by instability and change ... that in spite
label: Paragraph

text: of all, these buildings constructed at a distance of almost one century can so closely
label: Paragraph

text: resemble each other?” Dutch architecture had achieved a perfectly functional way of
label: Paragraph

text: building, but one that was without the ideal impulses, the sentiments of “grandeur”
label: Paragraph

text: and “mythology” of the experimental daring of the avant-gardes. Koolhaas con-
label: Paragraph

text: cluded, “we can talk about the Dutch architecture of today as an architecture without
label: Paragraph

text: intentions, a triumphalist Modernism, totally inoffensive, toothless, sterile. It won’t
label: Paragraph

text: prevent our sleep at night, nor will it awake us from slumber.”’
label: Paragraph

text: In 1989 a new synthesis of the principles outlined in Delirious New York (1978)
label: Paragraph

text: surfaced in the work of OMA that related more directly to design narratives
label: Paragraph

text: and structural forces. After many competition entries, several housing commis-
label: Paragraph

text: sions, and two major projects (Berlin’s Checkpoint Charlie Apartments and The
label: Paragraph

text: Hague’s Dance Theater), OMA was commissioned to design a building for tempo-
label: Paragraph

text: rary art exhibitions at the end of 1987. What would become known as the Kunsthal,
label: Paragraph

text: located on Maasboulevard at the southern end of a park, was a new kind of project
label: Paragraph

text: for OMA, which continued in the design for the Educatorium building that was
label: Paragraph

text: constructed a few years later in Utrecht.
label: Paragraph

text: Continuous Circuit
label: Title

text: The Kunsthal project developed in two phases, separated by the results of the com-
label: Paragraph

text: petition in 1988. In the series of variations on the first design — Kunsthal I in OMA’s
label: Paragraph

text: classification system — the building is a box with a square plan, raised from the
label: Paragraph

text: ground like a boat moored to the escarpment of the Maasboulevard. Access to
label: Paragraph

text: the box is from the quay-like roof of the lance-shaped volume placed up against
label: Paragraph

text: the escarpment. This volume contains service spaces and offices. Its overall volume
label: Paragraph

text: is shaped by the contours of the vehicle road that descends to the level of the park.
label: Paragraph

text: The elevated box contains a single vast room and has three glass facades. The light-
label: Paragraph

text: ing of the central zone is provided by a skylight that looks like a prism inserted in
label: Paragraph

text: the box. The conference room, café, and other spaces are inserted in a long volume
label: Paragraph

text: hat protrudes beyond the flat roof, perpendicular to the Maasboulevard.
label: Caption

text: Kunsthal II was designed between 1988 and 1989. Here, a compacting of func-
label: Paragraph

text: tions made it necessary to develop an exhibition system on all the levels of the
label: Paragraph

text: building that had been proposed as just one of the possible installation organiza-
label: Paragraph

text: tions in Kunsthal I. Thus, a continuous path of ramps, including the inclined slab
label: Paragraph

text: of the auditorium, would connect all the exhibition spaces on the various levels.
label: Paragraph

text: The ramp connecting the avenue and the park, along with the vehicle road —
label: Paragraph

text: respectively labeled “Street” and “Road” in the drawings — cut across the square
label: Paragraph

text: plan, generating a large square exhibition space, two orthogonal bands for a hall
label: Paragraph

text: and offices, and an exhibition gallery. In some of the design schemes an ovoidal
label: Paragraph

text: structure bridged the Road, connecting the hall to the square room; in others
label: Paragraph

text: the Road is open to the sky, while an arched covering is placed over the street,
label: Paragraph

text: symbolizing (like a Venturi and Scott Brown “Decorated Shed”) the position
label: Paragraph

text: and role of the Kunsthal as a bridge between the dike and the park.
label: Paragraph

text: The latter was also designed by OMA in collaboration with the landscape
label: Paragraph

text: designer Yves Brunier, who divided the terrain into orchard, podium, and park,
label: Paragraph

text: breaking with the traditional criteria of garden design. The apple orchard with trees
label: Paragraph

text: planted in diagonal rows on a surface of white stones, with their trunks painted
label: Paragraph

text: white, forms a luminous vestibule. The podium is a raised surface covered with
label: Paragraph

text: black tarmac, a stage for performances. Separated by a wall with a reflecting sur-
label: Paragraph

text: face, the orchard and the podium appear as abstract suprematist compositions in
label: Paragraph

text: black and white, when seen from above. The trees are planted more densely to
label: Paragraph

text: create the park in front of the Kunsthal (climbing plants conceal the differences
label: Paragraph

text: between new and old trunks), while the ground is transformed into a surface scat-
label: Paragraph

text: tered with multicolored flowers. The work evokes not only suprematist but poin-
label: Paragraph

text: tillist compositions, to be admired from an art promenade whose ends are the
label: Paragraph

text: square and the triangle of the works of architecture by OMA, a garden symbolizing
label: Paragraph

text: a Dutch Secession.
label: Paragraph

text: The final design of the Kunsthal was built between 1991 and 1992. While the
label: Paragraph

text: standard drawings show a square plan, the often-published axonometric diagram
label: Paragraph

text: reveals that a circulation spiral occupies the volume. In addition, this spiral is
label: Paragraph

text: intercepted in one direction by a vehicle road and in the other by a pedestrian
label: Paragraph

text: ramp that connects the park and the Maasboulevard. These two passages remain
label: Paragraph

text: always open and as such give the building a porosity that occasionally reveals
label: Paragraph

text: unexpected insights into the building’s workings. But, beyond the circulation that
label: Paragraph

text: ct.
label: Paragraph

text: is achieved through the complex layering of surface configurations, the move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment through the building becomes a structural device that organizes, transi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions, and paces.
label: Paragraph

text: Inhabiting Structure
label: Title

text: Developed in response to the challenges of the site conditions and the functional
label: Paragraph

text: requirements of exhibition space, the continuous interior space of the Kunsthal was
label: Paragraph

text: developed further in projects such as the Deux Bibliothéques at the university cam-
label: Paragraph

text: pus of Jussieu in Paris (1992) and the Educatorium, designed in 1993 and built
label: Paragraph

text: between 1995 and 1997. While these projects aimed at a spatial continuity, struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural challenges often stood in the way of freely developed architectural spaces as a
label: Paragraph

text: circulation path. By closely collaborating with Cecil Balmond, structural engineer
label: Paragraph

text: at Arup, OMA began to find new structural logics that worked hand-in-hand with
label: Paragraph

text: the desired spatial conditions. For the Kunsthal, Balmond proposed Vierendee
label: Paragraph

text: beams at the same height as the building, with vertical poles placed at different
label: Paragraph

text: intervals to avoid the spatial effects of repetition, and horizontal poles hidden in
label: Paragraph

text: the thickness of the slabs. This breakdown of the poles and beams generates col-
label: Paragraph

text: ummns arranged in an enigmatic order, like the trees in the park, apparently random
label: Paragraph

text: in the mathematical sense. This structural order also governed the logic of the sub-
label: Paragraph

text: sequent phases of the project, even after the Vierendeel beams had been discarded
label: Paragraph

text: for the Kunsthal. Rather than searching for the minimization of structure, the addi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of other responsibilities would lead to an inhabitable structural system that
label: Paragraph

text: became integral to the building.
label: Paragraph

text: “In section,” Balmond writes, “it may look hopelessly out of balance. But the
label: Paragraph

text: structure is designed as a double cantilever. On plan, on each side of the diagonal,
label: Paragraph

text: an equal amount of load restores equilibrium to give overall balance. A grillage of
label: Paragraph

text: strong upright beams supports the ramp slab, evening out the distortions and twists
label: Paragraph

text: due to the asymmetry.”” Because the slope of the row of pilotis does not coincide
label: Paragraph

text: with that of the roof, the placement of pilotis does not block the circulation but
label: Paragraph

text: t
label: Title

text: moves with it. At the Educatorium, most of the circular and square pillars are built
label: Paragraph

text: in reinforced concrete, while the cylindrical steel pillars have air conditioning ducts
label: Paragraph

text: installed at the base. The pillars are arranged to adapt to the forms of the two audi-
label: Paragraph

text: toria above, generating an irregular pattern that is surprisingly free of any visible
label: Paragraph

text: structural order: “‘random’ columns,” in the words of Koolhaas.’ The pattern
label: Paragraph

text: seems to be intentionally deformed to create a succession of densities, greatest
label: Paragraph

text: in the southern zone and least in the northern zone, making the structure take part
label: Paragraph

text: in and reinforce the spatial sequence, ranging from the opacity of the southern wall
label: Paragraph

text: to the transparency of the northern glass wall. Certain pillars are eliminated thanks
label: Paragraph

text: toa steel truss beam placed ona pillar of reinforced concrete. Parts of the structure
label: Caption

text: of the lecture hall sector are also suspended from beams mounted on the roof,
label: Paragraph

text: while certain pillars do not enter the ground floor thanks to the use of
label: Paragraph

text: Vierendeel beams.
label: Paragraph

text: The buildings are supported by twentieth-century structural archetypes that are
label: Paragraph

text: now transformed into sculptures: a Vierendeel beam in steel, stood on end; a
label: Paragraph

text: square pilaster in exposed reinforced concrete; a massive piloti in reinforced con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete, painted black; a cruciform steel pilaster, painted white; and, finally, a double-
label: Paragraph

text: T pilaster, painted black. While these schemes diagrammatically resemble the pio-
label: Paragraph

text: neering conceptual drawings by August Perret’s theater at the Champs-Elysées,
label: Paragraph

text: which, in turn, became the basis for Le Corbusier’s Dom-ino diagram, they depart
label: Paragraph

text: in their configuration from one another and differ in size. In OMA’s design for the
label: Paragraph

text: Deux Bibliothéques at Jussieu the earlier skeletal schemes are seemingly placed on
label: Paragraph

text: top of one another. OMA’s return to the canonical skeleton implies a reformulation
label: Paragraph

text: of the Plan Libre as well as the common stratification of floors. Here the floors are
label: Paragraph

text: transformed into a continuous ascension —a “trajectory,” Koolhaas called it — which
label: Paragraph

text: is simply the latest segment of a sequence through Paris, where Koolhaas envisions
label: Paragraph

text: “[the visitor becomes a Baudelairean fldneur, inspecting and being seduced by a
label: Paragraph

text: world of books and information — by the urban scenario. Through their scale
label: Paragraph

text: and variety, the effect of the inhabited planes becomes almost that of a street; this
label: Paragraph

text: boulevard generates a system of supra-programmatic ‘urban’ elements in the inte-
label: Paragraph

text: rior: plazas, parks, monumental staircases, cafés, shops.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Syncopated Rhythm
label: Title

text: Each floor was to be understood as a pliable surface, or, “social magic carpet” that
label: Paragraph

text: continues into the next to become one of the segments of the “trajectory.” At times
label: Paragraph

text: a slab is bent to produce lanceolate sections that cannot be utilized, with an almost
label: Paragraph

text: baroque spatial effect. OMA had already built similar continuously bent surfaces in
label: Paragraph

text: the Kunsthal, where the path of the visitor winds along an interior spiral in a syn-
label: Paragraph

text: copated rhythm. The spiral even continues outdoors, along the elevated garden,
label: Paragraph

text: and terminates at the flat, only partially accessible, roof. The brusquely truncated
label: Paragraph

text: spiral guides the visitor through the building in a sequence of scenarios, following a
label: Paragraph

text: narrative thread, “a story,” as Koolhaas put it, that “does not have to be told in
label: Paragraph

text: words, but is simply shown by movement, so that the path has a beginning,
label: Paragraph

text: and leads somewhere.” The stereometric prism, crossed by a complex continuous
label: Paragraph

text: path, was continuously reworked by OMA, always in pursuit of different solutions
label: Paragraph

text: for joining successive levels. The diagram of the spiral in the form of a long con-
label: Paragraph

text: tinuous strip composed of different segments, similar to an “exquisite corpse,”
label: Paragraph

text: would become a constant in the work of OMA that also called for new ways of
label: Paragraph

text: representation.
label: Paragraph

text: Attempts to express the notion of continuity in the design of the Deux Bibliothé-
label: Paragraph

text: ques resulted in a series of model photographs and drawings. The most striking of
label: Paragraph

text: these focuses solely on the trajectory, unraveling the entire building as a continu-
label: Paragraph

text: ous path without showing the rest of the structure. This, of course, was a true
label: Paragraph

text: departure from Perret and Le Corbusier’s diagrams of the skeleton, for now the
label: Paragraph

text: frame structured a continuous path that in turn generated the building and culti-
label: Paragraph

text: vated its different speeds. The rigidity of the Dom-ino skeleton is here sublimated
label: Paragraph

text: by a dynamic energy, similar to that unleashed by the lines in the drawings by Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Klee and analyzed by Gilles Deleuze in his writings on Leibniz.” In fact, Koolhaas’
label: Paragraph

text: project witnesses the “mixture” of the “straight line” (the Dom-ino grid) and the
label: Paragraph

text: “curve” (the bent slabs) as discussed by Deleuze with reference to the “baroque
label: Paragraph

text: mathematics” of Leibniz and Klee.*
label: Paragraph

text: A film-like sequence of photographs showing hands that hold a sheet of paper
label: Paragraph

text: that is then cut by a pair of scissors demonstrates the design process through which
label: Paragraph

text: the parvis of the university pavilions of Edouard Albert is raised, repeatedly folded,
label: Paragraph

text: and cut to give rise to the “trajectory” of the Deux Bibliothéques. The photographs
label: Paragraph

text: of this technique, as in the works of Lygia Clark,’ illustrate much better than the
label: Paragraph

text: model of the same project in wood and metal, that the regular Dom-ino skeleton
label: Paragraph

text: was introduced only to support the many facets of the “surface pliable.” The com-
label: Paragraph

text: mon series of slabs is, in the Educatorium, seemingly transformed into one single
label: Paragraph

text: continuous slab that is bent repeatedly in order to extend from the ground to
label: Paragraph

text: the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: In other preliminary solutions for the Educatorium, OMA even tested a contin-
label: Paragraph

text: uous S-shaped folding, which had to be rejected due to the excessive height
label: Paragraph

text: between the first segment of “pliable surface” and the upper level. This led to
label: Paragraph

text: the solution of two interpenetrating U-shaped slabs, partially reflecting the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of the slippage between the two units of the house at Holten. The interlocking
label: Paragraph

text: of the two forms generated a subdivision of the building to fit the lecture halls on
label: Paragraph

text: one side and the auditoria on the other. The inclined slab of the ramp and the audi-
label: Paragraph

text: toria pretends, thanks to a curved connection, to become the flat roof of the audi-
label: Paragraph

text: toria; then it deeply penetrates the other pair of slabs that are connected by a
label: Paragraph

text: vertical element. Thus, one curved “pliable surface” forms the intermediate slab
label: Paragraph

text: between the stacked lecture halls and stops before the vertical connector of the
label: Paragraph

text: other “pliable surface,” visibly celebrating the interpenetrating U-shaped slabs.
label: Paragraph

text: The effect of a continuous plane (that transforms from floor to wall to ceiling)
label: Paragraph

text: is accentuated by the outer finish of the slab in visible reinforced concrete. In
label: Paragraph

text: addition, structural elements were developed to conserve the continuous thickness
label: Paragraph

text: of the pliable surface in spite of the different structural logics of the individual
label: Paragraph

text: segments of the slab.
label: Paragraph

text: The room in the form of a Moebius strip of the Trés Grande Bibliothéque de
label: Paragraph

text: France, the continuous twisted body of the Office City, and the continuous paths
label: Paragraph

text: cut into the prismatic volumes of the Deux Bibliothéques Jussieu and the Kunsthal
label: Caption

text: form the prelude to a new, more assertive symbolic and functional continuity that
label: Paragraph

text: begins to appear in the work of OMA at this time. For the Urban Design Forum in
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama in 1992, for example, an undulated mantle extends to cover parking
label: Paragraph

text: areas and market halls. Here, the urban layering is metaphorically defined as “tap-
label: Paragraph

text: estry” that was to “avoid designing buildings, with their inevitable limitations and
label: Paragraph

text: separations; continuous and formless, the project engulfs the site like program-
label: Paragraph

text: matic lava.”?°
label: Paragraph

text: Program
label: Title

text: In these projects functions are organized along the pliable surface, so as to avoid
label: Paragraph

text: designated solid rooms and aim at a series of programmatic locations. Often, the
label: Paragraph

text: subdivision of the continuous platforms into functional sections happens by means
label: Paragraph

text: of geometric partitions. At the Kunsthal, OMA examined the possibilities of dis-
label: Paragraph

text: playing different installations through the use of panels and mobile platforms.
label: Paragraph

text: At the center, for example, exists a contraption known as the “Robot,” which is
label: Paragraph

text: based on a similar mobile platform as in the Radio City Music Hall (described
label: Paragraph

text: in Delirious New York) and capable of taking on different configurations, from a cen-
label: Paragraph

text: tral auditorium to an auto show with cars arriving from the park by means of
label: Paragraph

text: a ramp.
label: Paragraph

text: At the Educatorium the two auditoria form the most prominent enclosures but
label: Paragraph

text: their borders simultaneously generate “in between” spaces for circulation. The
label: Paragraph

text: space between the rectilinear wall in exposed reinforced concrete of the Megaron
label: Caption

text: and the convex wall of the Theatron clad in shiny steel sheets contains a flight of
label: Paragraph

text: steps covered in wood. At the Kunsthal these enclosures were already broken
label: Paragraph

text: open, in the sense that space is confined by circulation spaces and curtains rather
label: Paragraph

text: than by solid walls. The auditorium at the Kunsthal, for example, is a long and
label: Paragraph

text: relatively narrow series of steps on which chairs can be arranged. However, the
label: Paragraph

text: ramp alongside these steps is always accessible, enabling multiple parallel occu-
label: Paragraph

text: pations. The auditorium doubles as route through the building and, as such,
label: Paragraph

text: becomes part of the exhibition. In addition, parts of the auditorium can be sepa-
label: Paragraph

text: rated by a heavy curtain that becomes a sculpture in front of the hall when
label: Paragraph

text: not drawn.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1970s Koolhaas had begun to see the work of Leonidov as being charged
label: Paragraph

text: with an ideal value of revolt against the dominant ideologies in architecture and its
label: Paragraph

text: use of program. Describing the paintings of OMA, Koolhaas noted: “They are
label: Paragraph

text: really just exercises, except for the project of the Floating Swimming Pool, which
label: Paragraph

text: was a response to all the dilemmas posed by New York and Leonidov, the purest
label: Paragraph

text: demonstration of what I wanted to do with architecture: a project that was purely
label: Paragraph

text: program and almost without form, that could coexist well with any other type of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.”'’ The potential of pure program and its ability to exist alongside a
label: Paragraph

text: multiplicity of architectural forms reappears in the form of the auditorium at the
label: Paragraph

text: Kunsthal; only this time the contamination of different spaces through program-
label: Paragraph

text: matic overlaps is encouraged, forming a new kind of architecture through function-
label: Paragraph

text: ally saturated pliable surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: GUGGENHEIM
label: Title

text: MUSEUM BILBAO
label: Title

text: Frank O. Gehry
label: Title

text: Richard M. Sommer
label: Title

text: WAUeT =
label: Title

text: The Companions to the History of Architecture, Volume IV, Twentieth-Century Architecture.
label: Caption

text: Edited by David Leatherbarrow and Alexander Eisenschmidt.
label: Caption

text: © 2017 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Published 2017 by John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
label: Caption

text: A SECULAR CATHEDRAL OF ART
label: Title

text: In the middle of the twentieth century, Frank Lloyd Wright famously designed a
label: Paragraph

text: museum for Solomon R. Guggenheim, the main volume of which was comprised
label: Paragraph

text: of a continuous, spiraling, nautilus-like space. First commissioned in 1943, Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim was not completed until 1959, following the architect’s death. The
label: Paragraph

text: curving walls were seen by critics as inhospitable to traditional ways of displaying
label: Paragraph

text: art, especially paintings, the primary medium of Guggenheim’s founding collection
label: Paragraph

text: of non-objective art. Wright saw architecture as a medium equal to art, and as one
label: Paragraph

text: that should play an active role in the museum experience. The Guggenheim proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect pitted the visionary architect against New York City and the art world of mid-
label: Paragraph

text: century America.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1960, a year after the Guggenheim Museum opened, Claus Oldenburg
label: Paragraph

text: mounted his improvisational art-performance, “The Street,” in a borrowed space
label: Paragraph

text: on New York’s Bowery. Among the messages scrawled on the walls of Oldenburg’s
label: Paragraph

text: installation was: “Frank Lloyd Wright tried to eliminate painting and we are getting
label: Paragraph

text: even by eliminating architecture.” Oldenburg’s friend, Jim Dine, added “The
label: Paragraph

text: House” to Oldenburg’s “Street,” and a year later, Oldenburg rounded out this trip-
label: Paragraph

text: tych of capitalist city ur-forms by mounting “The Store.” Oldenburg’s art defiantly
label: Paragraph

text: reclaimed the artist’s rhetorical superiority in renewing the avant-garde project of
label: Paragraph

text: collapsing art and life. When he stated in his manifesto from the same period, “Iam
label: Paragraph

text: for an art that embroils itself with everyday crap and still comes out on top,” Old-
label: Paragraph

text: enburg was voicing a sentiment that was to animate much of the important art of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s.’ Oldenburg also set out a conceptual challenge that Frank Gehry later
label: Paragraph

text: took up for architecture.’
label: Paragraph

text: Warehouses for Art and Spectacle
label: Title

text: A half-century after the original Guggenheim project was initiated, Thomas Krens
label: Paragraph

text: was hired to renew the Guggenheim Foundation’s mission. Krens set out to collect
label: Paragraph

text: important works of minimalist and post-minimalist art from the 1960s and 1970s.
label: Paragraph

text: He pursued a global program of building and blockbuster exhibitions that could
label: Paragraph

text: capture the expanded size, physicality, and diversity of media associated with post-
label: Paragraph

text: war art. In an age when museums, at least in North America, came to depend more
label: Paragraph

text: and more on attendance, fees, and private philanthropy to survive, museum-
label: Paragraph

text: visiting was undergoing a change from an expression of cultivated connoisseurship
label: Paragraph

text: to experiences of popular entertainment, touristic pleasure, sociability, and the con-
label: Paragraph

text: sumption of goods and services. Although it had never been particularly useful for
label: Paragraph

text: mounting exhibitions, Krens understood the powerful potential of Wright's icon
label: Paragraph

text: on Manhattan’s Museum Mile as a spectacle for engaging this new reality, and
label: Paragraph

text: sought to reproduce that potential in a more contemporary manner elsewhere.
label: Paragraph

text: Earlier, Krens had developed the idea of repurposing a large, recently abandoned
label: Paragraph

text: nearby factory, the Sprague Electric Plant in North Adams, Massachusetts, to
label: Paragraph

text: become the largest contemporary art museum in the world. The museum would
label: Paragraph

text: be funded with state redevelopment subsidies and private donations of cash and
label: Paragraph

text: art. He continued to pursue this idea after he was hired by the Guggenheim Foun-
label: Paragraph

text: dation. Although the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art (Mass MOCA)
label: Paragraph

text: was eventually achieved in Adams by others, it became the model for creating a
label: Paragraph

text: satellite Guggenheim in Bilbao, Spain (there was already the Peggy Guggenheim
label: Paragraph

text: Gallery in Venice, Italy). Like Mass MOCA, the Bilbao project was first conceived
label: Paragraph

text: to reoccupy an old building in a dying industrial town, leverage public and private
label: Paragraph

text: investment, and provide vast spaces for exhibitions impossible to imagine in the
label: Paragraph

text: confined quarters of New York City. In June 1991, Frank Gehry, Coop Himmel-
label: Paragraph

text: blau, and Arata Isozaki were invited to submit schemes and compete for the proj-
label: Paragraph

text: ect. Gehry was selected.
label: Paragraph

text: By his own telling, Gehry, with Krens, convinced officials in Bilbao to move the
label: Paragraph

text: project from a nineteenth-century building within an historic quarter to a prominent
label: Paragraph

text: geographic knuckle in the town on the south bank of the Nervion River. The
label: Paragraph

text: museum was intended to take advantage of its adjacencies to the Old Town Hall,
label: Paragraph

text: the University of Deusto, and the city’s existing Museum of Fine Arts, and serve
label: Paragraph

text: as the first stage in the transformation of a former riverfront industrial complex. Juan
label: Paragraph

text: Ignacio Vidarte, the Director of the Guggenheim Bilbao, told Gehry they wanted a
label: Paragraph

text: building that would transform the city by giving it a new visual identity, in the man-
label: Paragraph

text: ner of the Sydney Opera House. Gehry, ever the demure architect, promised to try.’
label: Paragraph

text: The Nervion River is not Sydney Harbor, but the Puento de Salve Bridge, which is
label: Paragraph

text: the main connection across the river from Bilbao’s nineteenth-century city center to
label: Paragraph

text: the surrounding areas, passes over the eastern portion of the site, and Gehry’s design
label: Paragraph

text: is composed to encompass the bridge, and function as a new gate to the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s “Artsploitation” Architecture
label: Title

text: In retrospect, Gehry might seem like an obvious choice for this 250,000 ft’, $100 m
label: Paragraph

text: assignment. Nevertheless, there is a no small irony in Bilbao Guggenheim’s
label: Paragraph

text: deserved status as a masterwork of recent architectural history. Mastery of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture as a craft, and applying such craft to the production of cultural icons, had
label: Paragraph

text: not been Gehry’s forte or chosen path. His first and fundamental innovation was
label: Paragraph

text: bringing artistry to mundane assignments, seeing the latent possibilities of a cheap-
label: Paragraph

text: scape postwar America, and in so doing, drawing architecture out of ordinary pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects where it might be least expected.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s engagement with the art and architecture scene in Los Angeles, and
label: Paragraph

text: with the particular built geography of Southern California, beginning in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s, is critical to understanding his later success at Bilbao and beyond. He first
label: Paragraph

text: practiced with Victor Gruen Associates. Gruen, a Viennese émigré to Los Angeles,
label: Paragraph

text: who had developed a large, successful practice based in large part on his concept of
label: Paragraph

text: the shopping mall; particularly, the role that the new mall could play in the North
label: Paragraph

text: American suburb, akin to what town centers had been in European countries.‘
label: Paragraph

text: The architectural sleights of hand needed to make effective retail architecture
label: Paragraph

text: with temporary materials and limited budgets, and the ersatz urbanism of the
label: Paragraph

text: Gruen mall formulae are both foundational to the innovations associated with
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s work beginning in the 1970s. Even earlier, in work done soon after Gehry
label: Paragraph

text: established his own practice in 1962, one can find the mining of cheap materials for
label: Paragraph

text: sensual and symbolic effects and the use of theatrical effects associated with shop-
label: Paragraph

text: ping environments.” Projects for the Joseph Magnin Department Stores (1968-69),
label: Paragraph

text: the O’Neil Hay Barn (1968), and other more explicitly experimental early projects
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Danziger Studio and Residence (1964-65), reveal similar traits during
label: Paragraph

text: this first phase of his career. They were influenced by the artists and gallery owners
label: Paragraph

text: with whom Gehry forged relationships in the 1960s: Robert Irwin, Ed Ruscha, Ed
label: Paragraph

text: Kienholz, Ed Moses, and later in the 1980s, Richard Serra and Claes Oldenburg. All
label: Paragraph

text: of these artists were turning a new eye to the seeming detritus of modern industrial
label: Paragraph

text: andscapes such as Los Angeles, repurposing common materials and reconsidering
label: Paragraph

text: the broader landscape and environment as aesthetic phenomena.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s work has been taken very seriously by architects and critics since at least
label: Paragraph

text: 1978, after the house he transformed for his family in Santa Monica was widely
label: Paragraph

text: published. In the late 1970s Claes Oldenburg, with whom Gehry previously had
label: Paragraph

text: only limited contact, and his collaborator, Coosje van Bruggen, whom Gehry
label: Paragraph

text: had never met, paid a visit to the Santa Monica house. They quickly recognized
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s craft in rendering aspects of Oldenburg’s own earlier performances in a
label: Paragraph

text: more extensive, immersive, and sustained manner than any single work of art
label: Paragraph

text: might do. They subsequently collaborated on various projects, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Chiat/Day “binoculars” Building in Venice, California (1985-91).°
label: Caption

text: That Gehry had to build his creative breakthrough for himself, in the manner of
label: Paragraph

text: a modern artist (that is, without a client) is significant. A self-conscious attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: jettison the commercial basis of his earlier practice, undertaken at the risk of losing
label: Paragraph

text: important clients like the mall developer Rouse Corporation, Gehry’s house was a
label: Paragraph

text: provocation that seemingly flew in the face of architecture’s conservative tenden-
label: Paragraph

text: cies and declared Gehry’s creative ambitions as an architect.
label: Paragraph

text: The gambit worked. His house was the subject of serious theoretical speculation
label: Paragraph

text: by critics such as Frederick Jameson, who saw in it a palimpsest of old and new, an
label: Paragraph

text: incomplete structure, and a representation of the postmodern condition in which
label: Paragraph

text: time, space, and material allusion had become both indeterminate and open to inter-
label: Paragraph

text: pretation and appropriation in ways only latent in modern space.’ The period that
label: Paragraph

text: began with the creation and broad reception of Gehry’s Santa Monica House and
label: Paragraph

text: ended with Guggenheim, Bilbao is arguably the most speculative and fertile of
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s long career. He realized that in the expanded territory encompassed by
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary practice (parking structures-shopping malls—housing—furniture), all
label: Paragraph

text: of the commercial icons and industrial, utilitarian materials that his artist friends
label: Paragraph

text: had sought to appropriate were already at his disposal. He simply but ingeniously
label: Paragraph

text: retrieved “the everyday” as a conscious subject of and objective reference for
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry was awarded the Pritzker Prize in 1989 (before Bilbao was built), based on
label: Paragraph

text: a 25-year record of experimental work, primarily located in his adopted home base
label: Paragraph

text: in Los Angeles. Nevertheless, it was the project for the Guggenheim Museum at
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao, Spain, and others that Bilbao enabled, including the Disney Concert Hall,
label: Paragraph

text: that provided a whole new scale of endeavor and the circumstances to build in an
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented way, such that these projects propelled Gehry to international
label: Paragraph

text: renown at an advanced stage in his career.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s Bilbao incorporates almost all the ideas that propelled Gehry’s prior
label: Paragraph

text: work, but in many instances exceeds them, both in its degree of formal integration,
label: Paragraph

text: and in its technical execution. Gehry has never been an explicit polemicist. Taking a
label: Paragraph

text: page from the contemporary artist’s playbook, Gehry’s statements about his work
label: Paragraph

text: are always positioned to place the work outside of judgment and “theory” by refus-
label: Paragraph

text: ing any classification, leaving theoretical explanations to others. Nonetheless, since
label: Paragraph

text: he achieved prominence in the 1970s, specific themes and theoretical tropes have
label: Paragraph

text: been conveyed through his many statements and lectures accompanying his pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects, as well as the interviews with the critics and historians who have been his inter-
label: Paragraph

text: locutors over the years. An understanding of Guggenheim Bilbao as an architectural
label: Paragraph

text: performance, and how it reset the possibilities for the projects that followed is best
label: Paragraph

text: achieved by seeing it through the lens of the specific tropes, procedures, and meth-
label: Paragraph

text: ods that Gehry and his colleagues have already, to some extent, posited.
label: Paragraph

text: Exploding the Bubble
label: Title

text: Gehry’s approach to designing Bilbao followed a well-established procedure in his
label: Paragraph

text: office that had begun with his sketching and fiddling with bricolage-like models.
label: Paragraph

text: A series of organizing models by others in the office followed:
label: Paragraph

text: In our office, we tend to make three models before we start building: a small one,
label: Paragraph

text: which is purely contextual, a bigger one to work out the shapes of the building, and
label: Paragraph

text: then a final interior model, which provides us with the opportunity to simultaneously
label: Paragraph

text: develop shapes of the building and the interior. Hence, I do not simply jam the inter-
label: Paragraph

text: iors in at the end of whatever is left over.*
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s deceptively simple way of describing his working method belies the
label: Paragraph

text: complex way Bilbao’s massive program is broken into many discreet parts, arrayed
label: Paragraph

text: on the site, and then recombined into an unlikely ensemble. Gehry’s method of
label: Paragraph

text: organizing buildings brings together two established design techniques. The first,
label: Paragraph

text: the bubble diagram, a technique associated with late modernism; and the second,
label: Paragraph

text: village-making (my term), a technique associated with postmodernism, following
label: Paragraph

text: planning movements such as Townscape.
label: Paragraph

text: The bubble diagram is a graphic means of diagramming discreet building func-
label: Paragraph

text: tions into sets of differently weighted bubbles (in graphic terms, circles or ovals).
label: Paragraph

text: The proximity of one bubble to another and lines drawn between the bubbles are
label: Paragraph

text: used to create an index of needed relationships, and spatial adjacencies. Such a dia-
label: Paragraph

text: gram is essentially a reification of the functionalist approach to architecture, devel-
label: Paragraph

text: oped between the world wars, wherein scientifically derived use requirements are
label: Paragraph

text: taken as the beginning and primary basis of any architectural composition. Gehry
label: Paragraph

text: made the bubble diagram three-dimensional and loosened its functional corset:
label: Paragraph

text: entry atrium here, public auditorium there, long gallery next to that, square gallery
label: Caption

text: on top, retail, and restaurant in-between. In Gehry’s 3-D process, discreet program
label: Paragraph

text: parts are put in containers, and given the attributes of single-volume buildings.”
label: Paragraph

text: Starting in the 1950s many architects, including Louis Kahn and Philip Johnson,
label: Paragraph

text: experimented with breaking down buildings into discreet pavilions. Later, the
label: Paragraph

text: retrenchment from the large scale utopian planning, and critique of the idea that
label: Paragraph

text: buildings can perform as megastructures, is most associated with Jane Jacobs,
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Moore, and Venturi and Scott-Brown in the United States, and Leon Krier
label: Paragraph

text: and Aldo Rossi in Europe, all of whom aggressively advocated for the planning of
label: Paragraph

text: cities in small, incremental building blocks. Frank Gehry fully absorbed this attitude
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1980s. He retrospectively spoke about the disappointment he felt at the outset
label: Paragraph

text: of his career with the prospect of planning cities, after an ill-fated attempt to study
label: Paragraph

text: city planning at Harvard. He had concluded, early on, that ifhe was going to effect
label: Paragraph

text: change at the scale of the city, he could only do so at the scale of a building, or even a
label: Paragraph

text: room.’° Through a diverse set of projects beginning in the late 1970s, Gehry experi-
label: Paragraph

text: mented with breaking down buildings into many parts, the most notable of which
label: Paragraph

text: was the Loyola Law School, Los Angeles (1978), and the project for a Tract House
label: Paragraph

text: (1982), a scheme later achieved in various built projects such as the Fishdance Res-
label: Paragraph

text: taurant, Kobe, Japan (1985-87) and the Schnabel Residence (1986-89).
label: Caption

text: By the time of Bilbao, Gehry had distilled his bubble diagram programming,
label: Paragraph

text: small-building-block massing approach to an extent where he could skillfully dis-
label: Paragraph

text: aggregate a complex program into a set of different containers, and then warp and
label: Paragraph

text: fragment the containers. Where necessary, one container could be collided or
label: Paragraph

text: collapsed into the next. With this method, the interior volumes for galleries,
label: Paragraph

text: offices, auditoria, services, and so on, could be maintained as somewhat neutral,
label: Paragraph

text: geometrically simple spaces that faithfully attended to their functional require-
label: Paragraph

text: ments. The real architectural action occurred at the points of intersection between
label: Paragraph

text: the discreet volumes, especially in the cracks, seams, and splines between the
label: Paragraph

text: volumes, where the various cladding systems on the exterior leaked through
label: Paragraph

text: the joints of crudely assembled wooden boxes (or, more literally, the glue-gun
label: Paragraph

text: joints in the rough architectural models Gehry’s office is known for). This work-
label: Paragraph

text: ing of the margins happened at many scales, and across many intersections in the
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao project, including the main atrium, the largest manifestation of this inter-
label: Paragraph

text: stitial architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry had originally conceived of the atrium as a rectilinear space that would
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate art on its walls, but was persuaded by the client to develop a more
label: Paragraph

text: highly sculpted space in the spirit of Wright’s Guggenheim in New York City.’' As
label: Paragraph

text: built, the atrium rehearses the swirling, centrifugal space of Wright’s Guggenheim
label: Paragraph

text: and collects all of the fragmented volumes of the Bilbao complex, assembling them
label: Paragraph

text: like pendants on a necklace. Instead of being unified, and closing in on itself, as in
label: Paragraph

text: New York, the Bilbao atrium acts a portal and continual space of reference for the
label: Paragraph

text: museum’s visitors both through the circulation it affords, and by having the built
label: Paragraph

text: fragments of the rest of the complex on display act as material teller, or index, to the
label: Paragraph

text: vaults of art on display in the attached spaces.
label: Caption

text: The Baroque Turn
label: Title

text: Robert Venturi and Denise Scott-Brown posed the ugly and ordinary “Decorated
label: Paragraph

text: Shed” as a rhetorical, baroque foil to the overly synthetic “Duck” of modernism.’
label: Paragraph

text: In the early 1970s the Decorated Shed was a watershed concept with a serious impli-
label: Paragraph

text: cations for architecture understood as a form of city building, but one that Venturi
label: Paragraph

text: and Scott Brown nevertheless never managed to mine fully in their own work. Yet
label: Paragraph

text: early on, in Complexity and Contradiction, Venturi, alluding to the baroque,
label: Paragraph

text: described an architecture of “things in things, and things behind things.” With a
label: Paragraph

text: Decorated Shed, the exterior surface and iconography of a building is disengaged
label: Paragraph

text: from the shape and functional requirements of the interior. The exterior, as deco-
label: Paragraph

text: ration, is freed to manage its material, scalar relationships and implicit responsibil-
label: Paragraph

text: ities to the surrounding context, while the interior houses the explicit program.
label: Paragraph

text: Works such as Borromini’s San Carlo alle Quattro Fontana, from the Seventeenth
label: Paragraph

text: century forward, have been understood, in retrospect, to embody this idea.
label: Paragraph

text: The equation of sculptural exterior decoration and functional interior shed can
label: Paragraph

text: be found in almost every project from Gehry’s mature period, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim, Bilbao. Instead of rendering the decoration flat and over-determining
label: Paragraph

text: its symbolism, as was implied by Venturi and Scott Brown’s focus on signage,
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry conjures a three-dimension decoration that alternately acts as camouflage,
label: Paragraph

text: decoy, or sign. The strategy has the effect of diversifying the project’s overall
label: Paragraph

text: image, and a local effect of unifying discreet volumes and sections of a building
label: Paragraph

text: complex. The main function of the highly wrought metal, masonry, and glass clad-
label: Paragraph

text: ding that constitutes the primarily exterior decoration at Bilbao is to dissimulate the
label: Paragraph

text: perfunctory nature of the loosely stacked, plaster-lined, functional boxes that con-
label: Paragraph

text: stitute a majority of the project’s spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Understood as three-dimensional decorated sheds, Gehry’s sculpturally exuberant
label: Paragraph

text: urban compositions constitute a new baroque. Many adjectives and modifiers have
label: Paragraph

text: been attempted to describe the character of Gehry’s architecture, expressionistic being
label: Paragraph

text: the most common. Yet baroque is the most correct and evolved historical concept —
label: Paragraph

text: as opposed to style — to understand the Guggenheim Bilbao. At the advent of
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, the art historian Heinrich Wolfflin defined the baroque as “movement
label: Paragraph

text: imported into mass,” and a technique which repudiated the pure, geometric classicism
label: Paragraph

text: of Renaissance art. In more recent scholarship and theoretical speculation, from
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Benjamin’s equations of allegory and baroque theatre to Gilles Deleuze’s phi-
label: Paragraph

text: losophy of the fold, the baroque is understood as prefiguring the temporally volatile,
label: Paragraph

text: layered nature of modern consciousness (and therefore space). Gehry’s architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: baroque not just because of its lyrical quality and its circular, Crustacean-like geome-
label: Paragraph

text: tries; it is baroque because its carved, decorated surfaces unpeel from the basic
label: Paragraph

text: volumes of the building and dynamically shape space, both inside and out, in ways
label: Paragraph

text: that exceed the rectilinear logic of so much of the western, classical canon.
label: Paragraph

text: As the Decorated Shed analogy brings to light, the utility of separating the inte-
label: Paragraph

text: rior of a building and shaping it to meet specific requirements, and composing the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior envelope to meet its surroundings, is one of the technical developments
label: Paragraph

text: of baroque urbanism from the eighteenth century. In its preindustrial manifesta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, the baroque was a means to sustain a continuous, or at least the appearance
label: Paragraph

text: of a continuous architecture, across many discreet buildings and spaces. The
label: Paragraph

text: city Gehry is engaged with, whether it be Los Angeles, or Bilbao, Spain, is no
label: Paragraph

text: longer the genteel fabric of blocks, churches, and squares of the (projected)
label: Caption

text: baroque city, but is rather a post-industrial landscape of infrastructural detritus —
label: Paragraph

text: the concrete and steel spaghetti of rail and automobile geographies, and incon-
label: Paragraph

text: gruous building stock.
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque was originally a term of derision for irregular and ill-formed artistic
label: Paragraph

text: works and a precursor to the romantic elevation of the altern and the vulgar. This
label: Paragraph

text: is the tradition in which Gehry must be understood. The plastic qualities and inde-
label: Paragraph

text: terminate sculptural abstractions of buildings like Guggenheim Bilbao are baroque
label: Paragraph

text: in effect (and picturesque in sensibility) because they create a verisimilitude of vis-
label: Paragraph

text: ual continuity with their unevenly formed surroundings in ways few works of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture ever could.
label: Paragraph

text: The Vulgate, Digitally Remastered
label: Caption

text: Gehry had built buildings with dynamic, baroque-like forms before Guggenheim
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao, but never at the scale, intensity, or level of precision found there. Before the
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao phase of his career, Gehry’s process had involved working between lyrical
label: Paragraph

text: sketches and a series of models and drawings. In this highly iterative process sculp-
label: Paragraph

text: tural gestures were transcribed into buildable shapes and rendered in raw assem-
label: Paragraph

text: blies of common material. While this still occurred with the development of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao design, the building, or at least its exterior shape, looks remarkably similar
label: Paragraph

text: to the early models produced for the competition. Achieving a more direct trans-
label: Paragraph

text: lation from design-gesture to built form, and animating the material of a building at
label: Paragraph

text: this level of exuberance, required bringing new technical innovations to bear from
label: Paragraph

text: the emerging field of computation-based modeling.
label: Paragraph

text: The technology, or more precisely the digital tool Gehry and his team used to
label: Paragraph

text: develop the design for Bilbao, was adapted from software originally developed for
label: Paragraph

text: the aerospace industry, called by the acronym CATIA (Computer Aided Three-
label: Paragraph

text: Dimensional Interactive Application). First developed in France by the company
label: Paragraph

text: Dassault Systémes to aide the design and fabrication the Mirage fighter jet, CATIA
label: Paragraph

text: was later applied to other complex, engineering-intensive products such as auto-
label: Paragraph

text: mobiles and ships. Gehry’s office was the first to fully adapt CATIA to architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: They first used CATIA to develop the Fish Sculpture, built as a folly-like structure
label: Paragraph

text: for the Olympics in Barcelona, 1992. CATIA was transformative for Gehry because
label: Paragraph

text: it allows complex shapes to be digitally modeled, modified, and tested, such that
label: Paragraph

text: they can be dimensioned, styled, and subdivided into a series of parts that can then
label: Paragraph

text: be fabricated by machines, directly from a digital file.
label: Paragraph

text: Over the past two decades there has been a revolution in the use of digital mod-
label: Paragraph

text: eling in architecture. Early applications tended to repeat the rational, tectonic tradi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of modernism because the technology was largely seen as simply a replacement
label: Paragraph

text: for traditional drafting tools and construction documents. Gehry upturned this tra-
label: Paragraph

text: dition by starting with a shape that did not have a type of construction or material
label: Paragraph

text: cladding associated with it. His formal grammar allows an indeterminate logic of
label: Paragraph

text: construction. CATIA was revolutionary because it allowed Gehry’s office to reverse
label: Paragraph

text: engineer his abstract, idiosyncratic forms into buildable shapes. The key factor was
label: Paragraph

text: that the CATIA process involved a laser gun that Gehry’s office could use to scan the
label: Paragraph

text: handmade wood, plastic, and paper models that were cut, cast, and molded, as they
label: Paragraph

text: had always been in Gehry’s shop. Model scans made by the laser gun allowed shapes
label: Paragraph

text: tobe translated into a vector-based digital drawings. From these computer drawings,
label: Paragraph

text: accurate 3-D models could be developed to visualize large assemblies, integrate
label: Paragraph

text: incongruous aspects of a project, rule complex surfaces, test various material appli-
label: Paragraph

text: cations, and ultimately fabricate the project at a level of craft not imaginable before.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry had started his career with the conviction that pursuing architecture in the
label: Paragraph

text: refined, craft tradition of Europe had become impossible in the commercial context
label: Paragraph

text: of North America. He would instead make something artful with cheap, off-the-shelf
label: Paragraph

text: technology such a balloon frames, plywood, chain-link, and sliding glass doors. Even
label: Paragraph

text: with the design of Bilbao, Gehry’s mode of ideation and way of drawing and mod-
label: Paragraph

text: eling did not change. He does not personally use a computer. Nevertheless, as an
label: Paragraph

text: animator can put an artist’s sketches in motion, 3-D software enabled Gehry to
label: Paragraph

text: engage a new mode of architectural production and achieve a new mastery."
label: Paragraph

text: With Bilbao Guggenheim we see the convergence of two realities that changed
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s architecture. First, technology linking the visualization of dynamic form to
label: Paragraph

text: its fabrication developed to a point where the fantastical forms of influential early archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural avant-gardes such as the Russian constructivists could now be achieved. Sec-
label: Paragraph

text: ond, Gehry’s status as an architect was elevated to an extent where he was enabled to
label: Paragraph

text: make a museum into a cultural monument. Monuments require an air of permanence,
label: Paragraph

text: amastery of material, and a steadfastness of purpose. Therein lies the irony alluded to
label: Paragraph

text: above: Gehry’s architecture once owed it power to its temporary, incomplete, quo-
label: Paragraph

text: tidian nature, and allusions. His penchant for creating fragmentary structures that
label: Paragraph

text: were raw and unfinished gave his projects the accessible, empathic quality associated
label: Paragraph

text: with forms that reveal the way they are made. Again, in this he was following the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of 1960s art, not only the craftsman-cum-minimalists of the American West
label: Paragraph

text: Coast such as Robert Irwin, but also Oldenburg.
label: Paragraph

text: Writ large, refined in temperament, and industrially crafted at the Guggenheim
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao, Gehry’s architecture, once dynamic and pleasurably vulgar, ran the risk of
label: Paragraph

text: becoming ossified. Whether due to the high expectations that had come with suc-
label: Paragraph

text: cess, or a desire to master the execution, as opposed to the conception of his pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects, the work produced by Gehry and his office in the years after Bilbao is often
label: Paragraph

text: formulaic. Given how many prominent architects have refined and used the same
label: Paragraph

text: methods and vocabulary over and over again, it may seem unfair to hold Gehry toa
label: Paragraph

text: different standard of originality than others operating on the world stage. The dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ference is that the language and rhetoric of Gehry’s architecture is one of sponta-
label: Paragraph

text: neity, openness to circumstance, and freedom of expression, and these attributes
label: Paragraph

text: do not tend to survive repetition particularly well.
label: Paragraph

text: Democratic Form
label: Title

text: Forster: “You used the term ‘open ended’ in several ways, particularly in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: expanded vistas... [referring to the work of David Hockney|”
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry: “... I think that the idea of open-ended structure in painting or music suggested
label: Paragraph

text: openness to interpretation and a freer way of dealing with the world. It suggested
label: Paragraph

text: a way of dealing with the environment that to me was somehow easier for democ-
label: Paragraph

text: racy to adapt to than traditional western classicism.
label: Paragraph

text: What is lost if, with Guggenheim Bilbao, Gehry’s work transforms from some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing once liminal to something more reified and concrete in character?
label: Paragraph

text: In many cases, this would merely be a sign of progress and the expected mat-
label: Paragraph

text: uration of a creative project over time. Yet, Gehry and the critics who have pro-
label: Paragraph

text: pelled his work continue to use terms such as open-ended, incomplete, pluralist,
label: Paragraph

text: provisional, nonconforming, and individualistic to describe the qualities he has
label: Paragraph

text: aspired to and achieved in his architecture. Persisting in this rhetoric has utility.
label: Paragraph

text: In their capacity to embody certain liberal democratic values closely associated
label: Paragraph

text: with modern America, these terms have a political dimension that has been instru-
label: Paragraph

text: mental to the reception and success of Gehry’s work.
label: Paragraph

text: Not since Frank Lloyd Wright has an architect so strongly positioned his work as
label: Paragraph

text: democratic in spirit and American in character. Wright had claimed his work as a
label: Paragraph

text: unique expression of the self-reliant Jeffersonian strain of American democracy.
label: Paragraph

text: His architecture combined an arts and crafts influenced appeal to truth in construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and material expression, with the counter-classical and temporal aesthetics of
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese art. Wright argued for the disaggregation of the rent-based mercantile city
label: Paragraph

text: into a horizontally oriented (prairie) urbanism. To replace the commercial city,
label: Paragraph

text: Wright reimagined the agrarian grid, from which his asymmetrical, in-the-nature-
label: Paragraph

text: of-materials architecture was to rise as a living ornament to American democracy.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s earliest independent works, such as the Steeves House, Brentwood Cal-
label: Paragraph

text: ifornia (1958-59), were decisively Wrightian, and he acknowledges the degree to
label: Paragraph

text: which a Wright-influenced interest in Japanese architecture and Japanese aesthetics
label: Paragraph

text: was prevalent at the University of Southern California during his formative archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural studies there. Nevertheless, Wright’s influence was waning by the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s. His puritanical, Victorian attitude toward the popular, commercial world
label: Paragraph

text: did not ring true with a new generation contending with the reality of postwar
label: Paragraph

text: America. This generation was as apt to confront or co-opt the everyday reality
label: Paragraph

text: of the existing city as abandon it.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus, in comparison to Wright, Gehry’s appeal to democratic values is less
label: Paragraph

text: idealistic, less drawn from nineteenth-century utopias of social reform, and less
label: Paragraph

text: suspicious of the cosmopolitan artifice of modern life. While professing to be
label: Paragraph

text: left-leaning on a personal level, Gehry’s professional identity is that of the artist
label: Paragraph

text: whose self-expression can transcend ideology. Yet, his cultural references are
label: Paragraph

text: the counterculture of the 1960s, at least those aspects of it that crossed over into
label: Paragraph

text: the art world; especially the tune-in, turn-on and drop-out, and let-it-all-hang-out
label: Paragraph

text: ethos. The picture of a VW Beetle propped up on Gehry’s corrugated cardboard
label: Paragraph

text: Easy Edges chair designs from the early 1970s, his first design to achieve any wide-
label: Paragraph

text: spread attention prior to his house, is perhaps the most indicative of his identifica-
label: Paragraph

text: tion with the spirit of that time.
label: Paragraph

text: Marshall McLuhan argued that democratic media should be “cool rather than
label: Paragraph

text: hot,” that is, unfinished and open-ended to induce transformation through interac-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, rather than coercively manipulate by means of closed narratives meant for
label: Paragraph

text: whole consumption. McLuhan’s view on the role of art is also instructive for under-
label: Paragraph

text: standing both Gehry’s formation and the conflation of art, architecture, and spec-
label: Paragraph

text: tacle in his work. McLuhan took the position that the “machine turned life into an
label: Paragraph

text: art form” and argued that that proliferation of technology created a whole new
label: Paragraph

text: series of environments, wherein the arts function as “anti-environments” or “coun-
label: Paragraph

text: ter environments.” This is a curious revision of the role of the avant-garde, one in
label: Paragraph

text: which art functions as an early alarm or radar system for a technological society
label: Paragraph

text: gone awry.’
label: Paragraph

text: To some extent the culture of “Happenings” and pop art (including
label: Paragraph

text: Oldenburg’s) can be seen as presaging both the transformation of the art
label: Paragraph

text: museum, as an institution, and the role of architects, such as Gehry, in creating
label: Paragraph

text: the new spaces of art. Drawing on John Cage’s art of chance, this art privileged
label: Paragraph

text: the sensuous and temporal situation of art, effecting a collapse of the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: boundaries between visual art, music, and theatre. ° An open-ended, bohemian
label: Paragraph

text: Gesamtkunstwerk, the Happening offered a highly differentiated space of
label: Paragraph

text: engagement in an urbanizing world that was becoming ever more bereft of ale-
label: Paragraph

text: atory social encounters and sensual pleasure.’” Just as the right to public space
label: Paragraph

text: and assembly for the many became enshrined in law, at least in the Western
label: Paragraph

text: world, racial tensions, suburbanization, class stratifications, and purely market
label: Paragraph

text: driven patterns of development eroded the cosmopolitan, democratic potential
label: Paragraph

text: of the urban condition.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s abandonment of the social project of planning forced him to conceive
label: Paragraph

text: each building as if it were a self-contained Happening. He shares this approach with
label: Paragraph

text: many of the leading architects of his generation, including Rem Koolhaas. For these
label: Paragraph

text: architects, each building must summon its own provisional city (essentially a
label: Paragraph

text: walled village) that by necessity need not connect with or depend on its neighbors
label: Paragraph

text: and surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: By the late 1980s, the urban theorist Mike Davis found Gehry’s approach to the
label: Paragraph

text: city emblematic of a disturbing trend. Identifying a “fortress” mentality behind
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s vaunted everyday realism, Davis saw in Gehry’s artfulness, a false
label: Paragraph

text: consciousness:
label: Title

text: [Gehry’s] strongest suit is his straightforward exploitation of rough urban environ-
label: Paragraph

text: ments, and the explicit incorporation of their harshest edges and detritus as powerful
label: Paragraph

text: representational elements. Affectionately described by colleagues as an “old socialist”
label: Paragraph

text: or “street-fighter with a heart,” Gehry makes little pretense at architectural reform-
label: Paragraph

text: ism or “design for democracy.” He boasts instead of trying “to make the best with the
label: Paragraph

text: reality of things.” With sometimes chilling effect, his work clarifies the underlying
label: Paragraph

text: relations of repression, surveillance, and exclusion that characterize the fragmented
label: Paragraph

text: landscape of Los Angeles.’*
label: Paragraph

text: Where others have seen in Gehry’s chain-link fences, dumb-boxes, and blank
label: Paragraph

text: walls a benign verisimilitude with the modern city, Davis’ neo-Marxist analysis sees
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s slumming representations as a false bunker-like front and Trojan horse for
label: Paragraph

text: the exertion of social privilege and the forces of gentrification within the dispos-
label: Paragraph

text: sessed spaces of the contemporary city. Of course, Davis is not raising a new prob-
label: Paragraph

text: lem for architecture; in the service of the church, state, and market, architecture has
label: Paragraph

text: always represented the interests of the powerful. What has changed is that under
label: Paragraph

text: the aegis of modern democracy, many expect architecture, through both its formal
label: Paragraph

text: and informal performances, to play a more liberating role.
label: Paragraph

text: The Happening was an attempt to stage a space of authentic encounter, a
label: Paragraph

text: momentary liberation from the established norms of everyday practice, where,
label: Paragraph

text: in Kaprow’s words “ritual, magic and life” could supplant the western tradition
label: Paragraph

text: of mimesis and aesthetic reflection. What we find in the subsequent half-century
label: Paragraph

text: of partnerships between artists and cultural entities such as museums is the enshrin-
label: Paragraph

text: ing of this idea in a quasi religious space. Architecture plays an essential role in the
label: Paragraph

text: secular rituals associated with this new art, which often requires a scale of space,
label: Paragraph

text: and technological and administrative support well beyond the picture galleries of
label: Paragraph

text: the past. The extreme of this is Gehry’s design for the Experience Music Project in
label: Paragraph

text: Seattle, built just after Bilbao in 2000, in which visitors get to “interact” by, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, play-acting guitar licks with a virtual Jimi Hendrix, and where Gehry’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture plays a contributing role in the commodification of creative freedom,
label: Paragraph

text: artistic play, and alternative culture as brand-identity clichés. What was once an
label: Paragraph

text: insurgent practice of counter-culture art becomes a pragmatic way of coping with
label: Paragraph

text: the difficulties of sustaining authentic modes of public life in societies where the
label: Paragraph

text: promise of freedom of access and xenophobia play equal parts in making every-
label: Paragraph

text: place a kind of ghetto.
label: Paragraph

text: Conclusion: The Secular Cathedral
label: Title

text: How then do we evaluate the Guggenheim Bilbao’s success as a public work of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture? Soon after it was completed in 1997 it had entirely transformed
label: Paragraph

text: the prospects of what had been a little known and declining industrial city. The
label: Paragraph

text: museum has continued to attract close to one million visitors per year, with typ-
label: Paragraph

text: ically more than 50% of these visitors being from abroad. The economic impact of
label: Paragraph

text: this influx to the city and region has been carefully calculated and often touted:
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Bilbao is a commercial colossus generating an estimated $150 m in
label: Paragraph

text: revenue from museum related visits and businesses in a typical year.
label: Paragraph

text: Granted, to celebrate its 700-year anniversary, Bilbao made other infrastructural,
label: Paragraph

text: public realm investments in which architecture also played a role, including a transpor-
label: Paragraph

text: tation hub by Michael Wilford and Associates, new Metro stations designed by Foster
label: Caption

text: and Associates, and an airport and footbridge by Santiago Calatrava. Nevertheless, peo-
label: Paragraph

text: ple do not travel to Bilbao to see the Metro stations. The prospect that a singularly
label: Paragraph

text: important work of public architecture, crafted by a visionary architect, could change
label: Paragraph

text: the fortunes of a city is now enshrined in the phrase “Bilbao Effect.” Reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: cathedral building during the medieval period, the desire to replicate the Bilbao effect
label: Paragraph

text: has influenced many municipalities and institutions to commission singular works of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture (often, but not always, art museums) by internationally renowned archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects in hopes of putting their own city or city district on a global map of cultural trade
label: Paragraph

text: and tourism. The Guggenheim Foundation has made several attempts, so far unsuc-
label: Paragraph

text: cessful, to spread the Bilbao effect, with major international design competitions, and
label: Paragraph

text: projects designed by Gehry and Rem Koolhaas/OMA, among others.’
label: Paragraph

text: Is Gehry’s achievement at Bilbao simply a matter of good timing, of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: giving institutional form to ideas propelled by vanguard art? Much has been made
label: Paragraph

text: about the closeness of Gehry’s architecture to the themes, techniques, and motiva-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of postwar art. That Thomas Krens sought to build a museum for the
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Foundation in Bilbao whose spirit, and permanent collections draw
label: Paragraph

text: on the avant-garde art of the 1960s and 1970s, and found an architect who has
label: Paragraph

text: explored similar territory was fortuitous. After the 1960s, a conceptual repositioning
label: Paragraph

text: of the sites and media through which art could be explored only further expanded the
label: Paragraph

text: avenues and areas of art’s influence, which could include, but was not limited to,
label: Paragraph

text: “everyday” experience. Architecture, on the other hand, by virtue of the expectation
label: Paragraph

text: that it should provide stable and accommodating shelter has always been bound up,
label: Paragraph

text: to some degree, in the everyday. The extents and limits of architecture’s environ-
label: Paragraph

text: mental effects and zones of influence cannot be conceptually or physically cireum-
label: Paragraph

text: scribed in the way the “art” can. This is why equating architecture with the everyday
label: Paragraph

text: does not provoke the shock achieved when art partakes in the same subversion: for
label: Paragraph

text: architecture there is always the risk ofa tautological bind, and with this a loss ofimag-
label: Paragraph

text: ination and a capitulation to the status quo. To both avoid this risk and overcome its
label: Paragraph

text: weakness as a profession, serious architecture has typically eschewed the ordinary,
label: Paragraph

text: and has instead striven to establish its autonomy as both an art form and a mode of
label: Paragraph

text: building. As an aesthetic and moral posture, high modernism had much to offer this
label: Paragraph

text: identity crisis. In particular, modernism’s assumptions of originality, internal consist-
label: Paragraph

text: ency and austerity of form and its concomitant rejection of the decorative, the con-
label: Paragraph

text: tingent, the discursive, and the hybrid helped create the illusion of a cultural power
label: Paragraph

text: that in fact continues to elude the architectural profession.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s singularity as an architect is not only in his formidable skill in composing
label: Paragraph

text: the very material of architecture, but also in his ability to opportunistically adopt,
label: Paragraph

text: when necessary, the political identity, modes of creative production, and ideolog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical independence of the artist, to the practice of architecture. If, with Gehry’s
label: Paragraph

text: house in Santa Monica we had a case where life masqueraded as art, with an insti-
label: Paragraph

text: tutional project such as Guggenheim Bilbao we may have returned to a more tra-
label: Paragraph

text: ditional arrangement where art imitates, or more optimistically, animates life. In
label: Paragraph

text: either case, the artist (as opposed to the architect) has the freedom to seduce by
label: Paragraph

text: eroticizing the everyday or mainstreaming the exotic — effecting through poetic
label: Paragraph

text: means a change in an audience’s conception of reality.
label: Paragraph

text: In venues provided by various institutions artists are involved in creating a spec-
label: Paragraph

text: ulative space, capable of capturing the multiple interests of prospective audiences.
label: Paragraph

text: The speculative space of art, wherever it sits on the spectrum between the com-
label: Paragraph

text: mercial and the sacred, is construed by desires and concepts, and may resemble
label: Paragraph

text: other “ordinary” spaces, but is decidedly not perceived through an ordinary lens.
label: Paragraph

text: This ambiguity of being rooted in the world, both geographically and culturally,
label: Paragraph

text: but at the same time establishing a quasi-art-religious space apart, is precisely what
label: Paragraph

text: gives Guggenheim Bilbao the power to inspire an unprecedented pilgrimage of
label: Paragraph

text: tourists seeking an authentic experience.
label: Paragraph

text: The seeking of a space apart is also what links Gehry and the Guggenheim
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao to Wright and the first Guggenheim in Manhattan. Architects and the
label: Paragraph

text: work they produce can never be fully extricated from their time, place and
label: Paragraph

text: the cultural forces that shape them. Yet, architectural projects take time to gestate
label: Paragraph

text: and build. Once built, they linger in time. A utopian reformer rooted in the nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth century, Wright wished to replace the existing city with an organic, prairie
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. A pragmatic liberal contending with the eclipse of progressive pol-
label: Paragraph

text: architecture’s ability to create value in cities built on speculation. Thus, Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim ignores the existing city and the Gehry’s props it up. Both created
label: Paragraph

text: an urban specter, and in that void conjured a compelling architectural vision of
label: Paragraph

text: engagement.
label: Paragraph
