text: THE FIFTH PLAN
label: Title

text: In recent architecture a new type of plan has been afoot. It has been stealing into
label: Paragraph

text: architecture for a decade or two, perhaps longer, alternately announcing and
label: Paragraph

text: obscuring its arrival via the paroxysms that come with a long gestation. Does this
label: Paragraph

text: plan signal a significant architectural turn? It is hard to say, for as yet it is more ofa
label: Paragraph

text: twinkle in its parents’ eye than an established progeny, insinuating its potential
label: Paragraph

text: without yet assuring us of its longevity, or even its vivacity. Nonetheless, this plan
label: Paragraph

text: has made it far enough along an accelerating arc to make it worth looking at its
label: Paragraph

text: origins, its manifestations, and (most importantly) its promises.
label: Paragraph

text: Arriving at the tail end of a century’s evolution, this new plan descends from
label: Paragraph

text: four antecedents: the premodern plan (through the nineteenth century: line-‘em-up-
label: Paragraph

text: just-so); the modern plan (early twentieth century: give-me-liberty-or-give-me-death);
label: Paragraph

text: the postmodern plan (1960s/1970s/1980s: we-used-to-do-it like-this-plus-je-ne-sais-
label: Paragraph

text: quoi); and the sequel-modern plan (from the 1980s through the turn of the twenty-first
label: Paragraph

text: century: modernity-non-chalant). On the heels of these four plan iterations, this new
label: Paragraph

text: plan arrives as a fifth generation — a fifth plan.
label: Paragraph

text: While each of the four preceding plan types had tendencies toward self-
label: Paragraph

text: definition — the architects of each self-consciously, and usually zealously, distin-
label: Paragraph

text: guished “their” particular plan predilections from any antecedents — the fifth plan
label: Paragraph

text: appears without Oedipal angst. It uses, discards, adapts, and mixes plan attributes
label: Paragraph

text: from the entire genome of the preceding century. It unflinchingly cross-fertilizes
label: Paragraph

text: “free,” “open,” “dense,” “axial,” “figured,” “serial,” “serendipitous,” “functional,”
label: Paragraph

text: or other techniques, employing the seemingly hardened ideologies of its ancestors
label: Paragraph

text: in surprisingly malleable ways. Free-plan spanning systems are filled with high-
label: Paragraph

text: density programs. Exuberant form runs alongside ultra-rational technological orga-
label: Paragraph

text: nizations. Volumes are surfaces and surfaces are volumes. The fifth plan is not only
label: Paragraph

text: comfortable in its skin, it revels in its mongrel lineage. Without looking like a mutt
label: Paragraph

text: (at least on its better days), the fifth plan is indebted to the full and ostensibly dis-
label: Paragraph

text: parate spectrum of its pedigree.
label: Paragraph

text: Where can this new plan be found? Differing strains of it appear in a range of
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary practices including those of Michael Maltzan (Pittman Dowell
label: Paragraph

text: House, Malibu Beach House), FANStudio (Fat Flat), Johnston Marklee (View
label: Caption

text: House), Mansilla & Tufién (MUSAC), Sou Fujimoto (Musashino Library, Chil-
label: Caption

text: dren’s Psychiatric Center), Natkevicius & Partners (Family House), Herzog &
label: Paragraph

text: de Meuron (Cottbus Library), SANAA (IT Student Center, Toledo Glass
label: Caption

text: Museum), OMA (Casa de Musica, Zeebrugge Ferry Terminal, National Art
label: Caption

text: Museum of China), and, of course, Toyo Ito (Sendai Mediatheque, U House).
label: Paragraph

text: No single practice lays claim (or, for that matter, is trying to lay claim) to this
label: Paragraph

text: new plan type, and none of them can be said to deploy it consistently. Still, when
label: Paragraph

text: scanning these projects an increasingly forceful exhibition of evolved plan thinking
label: Paragraph

text: comes into focus. The fifth plan’s presence might be found in a single building, in a
label: Paragraph

text: part of a building, across a string of projects produced by a particular practice, or in
label: Paragraph

text: a cross section of work by many architects. It may well be that this plan’s lack of
label: Paragraph

text: singular origin or ownership is what allows it to appear in so many different archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural contexts: across scales of work, types of programs, geographies, practices,
label: Paragraph

text: economies, and social worlds.
label: Paragraph

text: What Is The Fifth Plan?
label: Title

text: The fifth plan is compound, a fact that tints all other definitions that might be
label: Paragraph

text: ascribed to it. As will be elaborated below, the fifth plan’s propensity to combine
label: Paragraph

text: rather than distill is especially true regarding its tethering of program to form.
label: Paragraph

text: Without a doubt, the fifth plan’s breadth-mandate is at least in part an echo of
label: Paragraph

text: today’s de rigueur rejection of any form of cultural singularity. But the fifth plan
label: Paragraph

text: moves well beyond representing multiplicity. Already half a century ago, with
label: Paragraph

text: the introduction of collage, juxtaposition, and complexity, Venturi and others
label: Paragraph

text: let us know that modernism’s singular definitions of architecture had run their
label: Paragraph

text: course, opening the floodgates of architectural diversification. The fifth plan is only
label: Paragraph

text: that much more multiple. And yet its multiplicity is of a resolutely synthetic sort. It
label: Paragraph

text: is often impossible to discern where free-plan ends and figure begins in these new
label: Paragraph

text: plans, or what is primary and what is secondary, or even where they sit in relation
label: Paragraph

text: to commodity, firmness, and delight.
label: Paragraph

text: The fifth plan’s contribution to contemporary architecture lies not in its valida-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of ever more heterogeneity but rather in the unified condensate that emerges
label: Paragraph

text: when these several spatial states are brought together. In an almost alchemical
label: Paragraph

text: sleight of hand, the fifth plan’s mash-up of origins produces a coherent organization
label: Paragraph

text: of parts that sidesteps any indexing of difference without becoming singular.
label: Paragraph

text: With this alchemy of paradigms humming in the background, the fifth plan’s
label: Paragraph

text: parts and their interactions can be collected under a set of plan traits: viscosity,
label: Paragraph

text: cropping, and susceptibility. While these traits are broad and regularly overlap
label: Paragraph

text: one another, they are nonetheless a helpful set of lenses through which to look
label: Paragraph

text: at the contemporary plan.
label: Paragraph

text: In what follows, each of these fifth plan traits will be discussed across two
label: Paragraph

text: threads. The first will lay out kinships: what are the primary inheritances of the
label: Paragraph

text: fifth plan? The second will discuss new manifestations: where are particular tech-
label: Paragraph

text: niques present in the contemporary plan and what are the implications of these
label: Paragraph

text: techniques? This structure is meant to suggest that while the fifth plan is new,
label: Paragraph

text: its newness does not depend on distinguishing itself from what came before.
label: Paragraph

text: The fifth plan’s newness arises from the last century’s many sustenances now coa-
label: Paragraph

text: lescing into plan-based configurations that are, in toto, unfamiliar.
label: Paragraph

text: The examples below include, for the most part, versions of all of the traits above
label: Paragraph

text: (small scale work — houses — present these characteristics in a different way simply
label: Paragraph

text: because of their size). These traits are not yet capable of defining a fifth plan hand-
label: Paragraph

text: book, though they might be seen as a manual in the making. Together, they are
label: Paragraph

text: meant to identify organizational and formal strains circulating in plans today, to
label: Paragraph

text: highlight them at times and, more ambitiously, to advance their combined possi-
label: Paragraph

text: bilities for those interested in the contemporary plan. These labels are likely to
label: Paragraph

text: evolve and, in fact, should evolve ... their purpose here is more like that of iodine
label: Paragraph

text: in a CAT scan than pillar in a paradigm.
label: Paragraph

text: Viscosity
label: Title

text: Over the last hundred years, architecture has tended toward one or the other
label: Paragraph

text: extreme: plan openness or plan definition. In Houston, for example, this polariza-
label: Paragraph

text: tion plays out in two museum buildings across the street from one another: Mies
label: Paragraph

text: van der Rohe’s posthumously completed Brown Pavilion (1974) and Rafael Mon-
label: Paragraph

text: eo’s Beck Building (2000), both built for the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston
label: Caption

text: (MEFAH). In the former, walls, structure, circulation, and optical control all cede
label: Paragraph

text: to boundless openness and the immanent optimism attending its universalist ambi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions. In the latter, a matrix of rooms divides space into discreet bites of discernible
label: Paragraph

text: museum inventory, invoking the choreographed order of John Soane’s Bank of
label: Paragraph

text: England (1788-1827). Curiously, the MFAH buildings are both late versions of
label: Paragraph

text: their respective sensibilities. Mies’ building mirrors work that he had been doing
label: Paragraph

text: since at least the mid-1950s and Moneo’s emanates from discourses running
label: Paragraph

text: through architecture as early as the 1960s. The late appearance of exclusively open
label: Paragraph

text: or defined approaches in these projects exposes the tenaciousness of the debate.
label: Paragraph

text: Among architects, this debate has a tendency to be framed in unusually profound
label: Paragraph

text: (even moral} terms, obliging us to align our sympathies and leaving us with little
label: Paragraph

text: middle ground. There are those who side with flexibility, the virtues of technolo-
label: Paragraph

text: gies, and the seeming socio-political liberties of the free plan. And there are those
label: Paragraph

text: who align with functional discretion, the rhetorical value of rooms, and the stabi-
label: Paragraph

text: lizing role that knowing “this is a space in which X will happen” can bring to a social
label: Paragraph

text: organization. The gap between openness and definition disappears in the fifth plan.
label: Paragraph

text: That which had been open is less open, and that which had been defined is less
label: Paragraph

text: definitive, resulting in the delineations of openness and definition being pushed
label: Paragraph

text: toward one another.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the more extraordinary examples of this squeezing together of open and
label: Paragraph

text: defined occurs in Toyo Ito’s Sendai Mediatheque (2001), most obviously in the sev-
label: Paragraph

text: enth floor plan. There is no “free” space and there is no “determined” space in this
label: Paragraph

text: plan. The large figure of this plan’s central space — an undulating wall circumscrib-
label: Paragraph

text: ing a set of interior rooms and creating a ring of space at the plan’s edges — is large
label: Paragraph

text: and idiosyncratic enough to dissolve as it encounters the varied columns of the
label: Paragraph

text: plan. The columns are expanded across their diameters, enlarging their technical /
label: Paragraph

text: structural presence and, in so doing, biasing the space around them in ways that a
label: Paragraph

text: simple point column never could. The interaction of the large figure with the col-
label: Paragraph

text: ummns produces local relationships — program pockets that hover among the collu-
label: Paragraph

text: sions of the large figure, columns, furniture, and building perimeter.
label: Caption

text: At Sendai, there is only something akin to viscous space, thick with the interac-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of walls, structure, program, and circulation. Moving across the plan, these
label: Paragraph

text: viscosities are constantly changing; the central office area opens up and closes
label: Paragraph

text: down, but never in an entirely consummated way. The perimeter “doughnut”
label: Paragraph

text: of program narrows, widens, and re-narrows again, its dimensional heavings shap-
label: Paragraph

text: ing program into greater and lesser definitions. The line that expands and constricts
label: Paragraph

text: this doughnut is at times autonomous — defining the large figure — and at other
label: Paragraph

text: times deferential, entering a tighter orbit with the columns. This is a line, a single
label: Paragraph

text: line, with multiple loyalties: to its exterior and its interior, to its overall and local
label: Paragraph

text: organizational roles, and to its delineation of difference and connectedness. Many
label: Paragraph

text: of the spaces in this plan (especially those in the corners) are capable of changing
label: Paragraph

text: their own definition-states, pulsating between semi-open and semi-closed. The
label: Paragraph

text: Domino plan is alive and well in the Mediatheque, but it is now captured in a gelat-
label: Paragraph

text: inous spatial system that slows down the dynamics of its larger organizational
label: Paragraph

text: umbrella and increases the momentum of the subsets of space that live under that
label: Paragraph

text: umbrella.
label: Paragraph

text: A different version of the fifth plan’s viscosity occurs in Kazuyo Sejima’s entry
label: Paragraph

text: for the IIT Student Center competition. In this non-winning scheme, Sejima con-
label: Paragraph

text: fronted Miesian universal space by replicating that very space with her own big box
label: Paragraph

text: and then relentlessly over-packing that box with program. Imagine, for a moment,
label: Paragraph

text: Mies’ Neue Nationalgalerie filled to the brim with a mini-mall, albeit a mini-mall
label: Paragraph

text: saturated with the material /technological /aesthetic affections that an architect like
label: Paragraph

text: Sejima would of course lavish upon Mies. The project’s aformality no doubt halted
label: Paragraph

text: it at the starting gate vis-A-vis the competition (the scheme was presented in a set of
label: Paragraph

text: ink line drawings so delicate that it read as little more than a vaporous cloud of
label: Paragraph

text: hair-like marks hovering over paper). The Sejima IIT proposal is, nonetheless, a
label: Paragraph

text: radical repackaging of Mies’ universalism and Koolhaas’ congestion in a single
label: Paragraph

text: architectural prism, producing fifth plan viscosity through extreme functional
label: Paragraph

text: compactness.
label: Paragraph

text: New viscosities have risen out of our pursuit of closer program-form relation-
label: Paragraph

text: ships. With so much airtime given over to arguing the merits of program or form in
label: Paragraph

text: recent years, the mere fact of these two interests coinciding marks an evolution in
label: Paragraph

text: plan thinking. Beyond this realignment, however, the program-form merger has
label: Paragraph

text: given us a means of being unabashedly geometric and willfully programmatic,
label: Paragraph

text: which is to say these projects suggest a shift away from our recent (over)indul-
label: Paragraph

text: gences of indeterminacy and flexibility as architectural paradigms. The merger
label: Paragraph

text: of form and program leads directly to the thickening of relationships and, what
label: Paragraph

text: is more, directly to an explicit declaration of organizational subjectivity. New
label: Paragraph

text: viscosities are filled with programmatic densities and intensifications, common turf
label: Paragraph

text: over recent decades. But the fifth plan inscribes in this mix the force of deliberate-
label: Paragraph

text: ness, an open assertion concerning a plan’s artifice (its partiality) and a chance to say
label: Paragraph

text: “this isn’t all worlds; this is a world that I think is better.”
label: Paragraph

text: Cropping
label: Title

text: Over the last century, countless black lines have been laid down on countless sheets
label: Paragraph

text: of white paper with the sole purpose of laying claim to what an architectural perim-
label: Paragraph

text: eter should do. These lines at times focus on the relationship between interior and
label: Paragraph

text: exterior. At other times they articulate the form of a building or its functional ethos.
label: Paragraph

text: Regardless of what we intend when we draw them, these lines have been
label: Paragraph

text: enmeshed in our conception of the plan with one of two inevitable outcomes: a
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter that is definite (high contrast) or a perimeter that is indefinite dow
label: Paragraph

text: contrast).
label: Paragraph

text: As endgames, high and low contrast perimeters depend on how one chooses to
label: Paragraph

text: inscribe form and program relative to one another. This choice represents a fork in
label: Paragraph

text: the road for architects: either “architecture = stabilizing vis-a-vis life” or “architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture = vulnerable vis-a-vis life.” This choice is, to say the least, loaded. It is the
label: Paragraph

text: undercurrent running beneath many of our ideological directives and, as such,
label: Paragraph

text: is how we edit (bias) architecture’s otherwise too-expansive cultural resonances
label: Paragraph

text: in directions that we “believe in.” One might see form and program as concentric
label: Paragraph

text: (i.e. Frank Gehry’s shrink-wrapped EMR Communication and Technology Center)
label: Paragraph

text: or one might see them as cross-grained (i.e. Mies van der Rohe’s pin-wheeling Brick
label: Paragraph

text: Country House). Concentric sensibilities produce high contrast perimeters and
label: Paragraph

text: cross-grained sensibilities produce low contrast perimeters. Curiously, making this
label: Paragraph

text: decision has little to do with deciding to “be formalist” or “be functionalist” —
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s UTS Business School is cross-grained at times and Mies’ latter career work
label: Paragraph

text: (Farnsworth House, Crown Hall, etc.) is decidedly concentric. What this decision
label: Paragraph

text: does do is inscribe a reciprocal relationship between form and program in the way
label: Paragraph

text: that we access architecture. A concentric form/ program sensibility leads us to “see”
label: Paragraph

text: form and “intuit” program while a cross-grained form/program sensibility directs
label: Paragraph

text: us to “see” program and “intuit” form.
label: Paragraph

text: Our penchant for high or low contrast decisiveness along architecture’s outer
label: Paragraph

text: boundaries has disappeared. This change is not about indecisiveness. Neither is
label: Paragraph

text: it about one or the other boundary types having won the war. In fact, any number
label: Paragraph

text: of recent projects can be said to depend on a calculated cohabitation of these traits.
label: Paragraph

text: These projects include Herzog & de Meuron’s Cottbus Library, Michael Maltzan’s
label: Paragraph

text: unbuilt Malibu Beach House, Gintautas Natkevicius’ Family House in Birstonas,
label: Caption

text: SANAA’s Kanazawa Museum, and Toyo Ito’s Sendai Mediatheque as well as his
label: Paragraph

text: Tama Art University Library, among others.
label: Paragraph

text: Each of these projects crops plan relations into new sub-states, using the overlay
label: Paragraph

text: of a knife-like line to compress some proximities while atomizing others. Cropping
label: Paragraph

text: amplifies unevenness in these plans, which is to say cropping confronts head-on any
label: Paragraph

text: pretense of modern universality. This is particularly curious in Ito’s Mediatheque
label: Paragraph

text: as the building has an obvious debt to Corbusier’s Dom-ino system with its ground-
label: Paragraph

text: ing in the evenness of a colummn-field. As with the Dom-ino, and regardless of their
label: Paragraph

text: exaggerated size, the Mediatheque’s columns instill consistency across the build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing’s seven floors; their slight variations are alone unable to produce significant
label: Paragraph

text: affectations of each plate’s organization. But the lines that Ito introduces on each
label: Paragraph

text: level — the walls and scrims that slice across and lasso subsets of column-spotted
label: Paragraph

text: space — convert each floor into its own biased world. The ground floor’s “open
label: Paragraph

text: square” is formed with the sharpest of lines...one that is little more than a virtual
label: Paragraph

text: indicator of this space’s status as a programmatic no-man’s land. On the second
label: Paragraph

text: floor, an udder-shaped line — part solid wall, part low counter — extracts the
label: Paragraph

text: north-west corner of the building into its own state, bundling staff areas, service
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, a “talking room,” and the children’s reading area into an autonomous pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gram block. On the third floor, a lone linear stroke clips the library offices out of the
label: Paragraph

text: overall plate. On the seventh floor described above, a single meandering line
label: Caption

text: completes a solitary figure in the plate’s interior, bounding a dense programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: mass that hovers in the ether of the surrounding perimeter. On each floor, a seem-
label: Paragraph

text: ingly flippant line is etched among the columns so as to profoundly prejudice the
label: Paragraph

text: free-plan starting point of these plates.
label: Paragraph

text: Herzog & de Meuron’s Cottbus Library also depends on cropping, though here
label: Paragraph

text: the technique plays out primarily on the building’s perimeter in contrast to the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediatheque’s use of cropping as an exclusively interior technique. Cottbus holds
label: Paragraph

text: a serialized interior organization — a modernist organization based on repetition,
label: Paragraph

text: alignment with the structural grid, a field matrix — that is bluntly sheared by the
label: Paragraph

text: undulations of the building envelope. While different in other regards, the Kana-
label: Paragraph

text: zawa Museum by SANAA uses a similar perimeter-focused technique, its field of
label: Paragraph

text: cells and corridors clipped by its cylindrical face. The most visible transformation in
label: Paragraph

text: the edges of these plans is that of the change from an offset or indexed interior to a
label: Paragraph

text: shorn interior-envelope relationship.
label: Paragraph

text: If graphic shearing is the obvious delight of these plans (and is also what makes
label: Paragraph

text: them subject to too-facile critiques falling under the heading of “gratuitous geom-
label: Paragraph

text: etry damnation”), their organizational rewards are more nuanced. The incongru-
label: Paragraph

text: ous relationship of a perimeter to its interior catalyzes a minor wilderness at their
label: Paragraph

text: outer edges. “Minor” here is meant to differentiate these edges from the wholesale
label: Paragraph

text: (whole plan) wilderness of projects such as those of the Biirolandschaft species ...
label: Paragraph

text: minor means local, not total. Here, in fact, cropping depends on a systematic organ-
label: Paragraph

text: ization of interior space with enough momentum to let its truncation be legible.
label: Paragraph

text: Put another way, fifth plan cropping exploits the systematic to momentarily sus-
label: Paragraph

text: pend that same system’s certainties. On a particularly hubris-filled day, one could
label: Paragraph

text: make the case that cropping, with its interior efficiencies meeting minor wilder-
label: Paragraph

text: nesses, is a means by which architects can, at long last, stop the absurd swingings
label: Paragraph

text: of the rational/liberatory pendulum, swingings that have produced some of archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture’s most caricaturable Gf not always comic) moments over the last one
label: Paragraph

text: hundred years.
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture’s perimeter has long been a flashpoint for invention and
label: Paragraph

text: critique — think of the discourses surrounding architecture’s qualifiers:
label: Paragraph

text: object/anti-object, public/private, form/function, inside/ outside. The fifth plan
label: Caption

text: introduces cropping as a way of perching these pairings on the same, single, thin
label: Paragraph

text: line, invoking both, only to then flicker between them at breakneck speed. Is
label: Paragraph

text: Kanazawa an object? Of course it is — its circle is more perfect than anything
label: Paragraph

text: Ledoux could have imagined. Is Kanazawa an anti-object? Absolutely — its inner
label: Paragraph

text: workings are ruthlessly amputated by the blade of its outer edge. Cropping’s
label: Paragraph

text: shotgun wedding of form and program does nothing to soothe their irreconcil-
label: Paragraph

text: able differences; on the contrary, it bluntly exploits their agitating exchanges to
label: Paragraph

text: redefine architecture’s edge, opening up a new field of relations among architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture’s parts: its exterior receptions, its internal organizations, and its transitions
label: Paragraph

text: between the two.
label: Paragraph

text: Susceptibility
label: Title

text: t would be easy to write a history of architecture organized around plan modu-
label: Paragraph

text: ation types, with chapter headings including “axis,” “grid,” “symmetry,”
label: Paragraph

text: “repetition,” “field,” “figure,” “system,” “proportion,” seriality,” “centralization,”
label: Paragraph

text: “rhythm,” and so on. Perhaps a few recent experiments might make it in, at least
label: Paragraph

text: into the appendix: “collage,” “index,” “lattice”; there are no doubt others. Until per-
label: Paragraph

text: haps 50 years ago these were the spatial mechanisms for giving architecture
label: Paragraph

text: “order,” a way of organizing architecture’s parts and, more broadly, of civilizing
label: Paragraph

text: or at least explaining an unruly world. Order was our means of articulating and
label: Paragraph

text: projecting our ambitions: an axis will create importance; a field will be democratic;
label: Paragraph

text: a grid will contain the universe. Across the history of architecture, modulation (a
label: Paragraph

text: technique) and order (an idea) have had a remarkably intimate, quasi-synonymous
label: Paragraph

text: relationship, like twins with their own indecipherable language. And yet, the dis-
label: Paragraph

text: appearance of order from our lexicon already a half century ago has hardly dimin-
label: Paragraph

text: ished our use of modulation. How can this be? How can architecture’s “Dead
label: Paragraph

text: Ringers” — modulation and order — suddenly find themselves cut apart?
label: Paragraph

text: Once a twin, always a twin. Modulation and order have not now, and have not
label: Paragraph

text: ever, been cut apart. Transformations in architecture’s order-modulation relation-
label: Paragraph

text: ship can be placed into the five categories sketched out at the beginning of this
label: Paragraph

text: chapter: pre-modern: modulation supports order (Garnier’s Paris Opera); modern:
label: Paragraph

text: modulation establishes new order (Mies’ New National Gallery); postmodern:
label: Paragraph

text: modulation has a fistfight with order (Venturi’s Hanna Venturi House); sequel-
label: Paragraph

text: modern: modulation and order take a time-out (OMA’s Netherlands Architecture
label: Title

text: Institute); fifth plan: modulation makes order susceptible.
label: Paragraph

text: In short, modulation and order have never been far apart but they have regularly
label: Paragraph

text: changed their posture relative to each other. Their perceived estrangement appears
label: Paragraph

text: with postmodernism, when modulation and order take up adversarial positions,
label: Paragraph

text: producing a surfeit of anti-hegemony, anti-total, anti-object, anti-you-name-it archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectures. In fact, postmodernism’s adversarial repositioning of modulation and
label: Paragraph

text: order allowed us to conduct countless fruitful architectural experiments leading
label: Paragraph

text: to a plethora of alternative-orders in architecture, all the while requiring us to
label: Paragraph

text: mutter the second part of that hyphenated phrase — “orders” — under our breath
label: Paragraph

text: to avoid persecution.
label: Paragraph

text: The fifth plan establishes another new posture in the order-modulation sequence
label: Paragraph

text: of relationships: a modulated order whose aim is susceptibility, not firmness. This
label: Paragraph

text: posture amounts to, on the one hand, a resurrection of order as a positive attribute
label: Paragraph

text: and, on the other, a deployment of that order in a way that runs entirely contrary to
label: Paragraph

text: its legacy as a civilizing/ stabilizing agent. In the fifth plan, order is always there but
label: Paragraph

text: always volatile, unpredictable, and sometimes woolly. It is also legible, coherent,
label: Paragraph

text: and even reasonable.
label: Paragraph

text: The most important attribute of this new susceptibility is the ability of contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary modulating systems to generate relationships that exceed their systemic
label: Paragraph

text: terms (in contrast to modern or classical systems that work diligently to reinforce
label: Paragraph

text: their systemic underpinnings). The Mediatheque’s 13 columns are arrayed across a
label: Paragraph

text: four-by-three near-grid, with a single exceptional column intruding on its southern-
label: Paragraph

text: most near-grid column line. This grid’s wobbliness — it teeters it in the X, Y, and
label: Paragraph

text: Z directions — produces extreme polarizations in what we have come to expect
label: Paragraph

text: from modulation, with comparably extreme implications for what we intend as
label: Paragraph

text: order. Ona spatial level, the inebriations of these columns heighten their independ-
label: Paragraph

text: ence from one another, making each of them susceptible to absorption into local
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances. They are variously enmeshed in rooms (floors two, three, and
label: Paragraph

text: seven), border markers (floors one, three, five, and six), and free agents (floors
label: Paragraph

text: two, three, and four). As conduits of gravity, their intoxications are kept in check
label: Paragraph

text: by the physics of plate tectonics — the span of Matsuro Sasaki’s extraordinary
label: Paragraph

text: webbed floor system was constrained by a 40 cm depth requirement. Programmat-
label: Paragraph

text: ically, in other words, the soft modulation of these columns allows their systemic
label: Paragraph

text: role to entirely dissolve while technically these same modulations unload an almost
label: Paragraph

text: heroic structural obligation onto the spanning and design requirements of the
label: Paragraph

text: webbed floor system. The former is a system that produces its own disappearance
label: Paragraph

text: and the latter is a system that incites an extreme rationality elsewhere. And, almost
label: Paragraph

text: miystically, the two systems are one and the same, a single set of wobbly columns.
label: Paragraph

text: Mansilla & Tufién’s MUSAC building announces an alternate version of a
label: Paragraph

text: modulating system that consumes itself. MUSAC is astonishingly consistent in
label: Paragraph

text: its unit articulations, it is a thick-line plan, not field-of-dots plan, made up of either
label: Paragraph

text: four-sided or six-sided trapezoids, depending on how one chooses to read them.
label: Paragraph

text: The lucidity of the overall plan comes from the confidence with which these
label: Paragraph

text: trapezoids are arrayed. They are relentless and they are modern. Until: 1) one looks
label: Paragraph

text: at their effect on the overall perimeter, with its indiscernible profile; 2) each unit is
label: Paragraph

text: examined for consistency only to find that there is none; and 3) unit-to-unit (and, in
label: Paragraph

text: turn, room-to-room) aggregations are highlighted to expose a series of latent pro-
label: Paragraph

text: grammatic and circulation hierarchies superseding all of the democratizing rhetoric
label: Paragraph

text: that we expect to run alongside such unitary organizations (compare this to, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, the plan of Herman Hertzberger’s Office Beheer building, wherein the
label: Paragraph

text: gaps and the connector portals between cells assure that the primary reading of
label: Paragraph

text: these cells will always be individual, not aggregate). “Until” is a critique, a way
label: Paragraph

text: of Mansilla & Tufién declaring that theirs is not, in fact, a modern building.
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond critique, the conclusion of “until” in the MUSAC plan lies in its suspen-
label: Paragraph

text: sion, not negation, of modulation. In the abstract terms of geometry, every cell in
label: Paragraph

text: this plan remains a cell. In the application of walls, doors, and materials to those
label: Paragraph

text: geometries no two cells are alike. Walls stand alone, pair up into chevrons, or make
label: Paragraph

text: long strings of ziggy-zaggies; they construct perimeters in space or serve as islands
label: Paragraph

text: around which one moves; they change from solid to open; they aggregate into lar-
label: Paragraph

text: ger areas or subdivide into smaller rooms. At the same time, no matter what, all of
label: Paragraph

text: this difference is held in place by an uncompromising geometric system. The archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects’ affections appear to run in opposing directions at MUSAC: heterogeneity and
label: Paragraph

text: the disciplining of space. The turning point in this plan and others of its ilk is that
label: Paragraph

text: modulation and heterogeneity are not opposed, but in fact have a complementary
label: Paragraph

text: and catalytic relationship to one another. The success of the MUSAC plan is meas-
label: Paragraph

text: ured by the ease with which one can place a finger anywhere on its extents and ask
label: Paragraph

text: “field or cell?,” “unit or unique?,” “edge or center?,” and not be able to answer.
label: Paragraph

text: The fifth plan has removed the pejorative tone that has hung over order for
label: Paragraph

text: 50 years. It has done this not as a sentimental lamenting of order’s absence but
label: Paragraph

text: by rethinking order’s reason for being. Order, what we (as classicists or modernists)
label: Paragraph

text: used to depend on to get us through the day, and what we (during our after-
label: Paragraph

text: modern self-flagellations) then propped up as the straw man, has of late become
label: Paragraph

text: a means of designating where and how architecture can and cannot enforce its
label: Paragraph

text: rule-sets. Order has entered a new phase as the carrier of susceptibility, the bearer
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture’s openness and vulnerability.
label: Paragraph

text: Some Last Fifth Plan Thoughts
label: Title

text: We have been staring at architecture through our Rhino viewports for some time
label: Paragraph

text: now, beguiled by the ease with which we can whirl and twirl our way through and
label: Paragraph

text: among objects. After years of volumetric and surface-invested investigations, a
label: Paragraph

text: number of architects have turned their attention to the incisive conceptual role that
label: Paragraph

text: plans play in architecture’s evolution. This is not a move “away from the digital,” or
label: Paragraph

text: “toward a lost tradition.” It is the opening up of a new line of inquiry: important
label: Paragraph

text: transformations in our thinking about architecture are taking place and many of
label: Paragraph

text: those changes will find their greatest potential among the marks that make up
label: Paragraph

text: plans. Viscosities, croppings, and susceptibilities may or may not be the headers
label: Paragraph

text: under which the fifth plan will continue to evolve. Nonetheless, regardless of
label: Paragraph

text: how these labels might be applied, their net effect is to illuminate a series of recent
label: Paragraph

text: speculations leading to new conceptualizations of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Nothing is more evident in the fifth plan than the near total collapse of form and
label: Paragraph

text: program into one another. These new architectures suggest that architecture has
label: Paragraph

text: moved beyond arguments based on exclusive extractions from the Vitruvian triad:
label: Paragraph

text: “It’s about commodity!” “It’s about firmness!” “It’s about delight!” Form and pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gram are only slightly offset Venn-diagram zones in these experiments, with tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nology acting as a silent partner. Their nearly concentric state makes it essentially
label: Paragraph

text: impossible to discern formal acts/results and programmatic acts/results from one
label: Paragraph

text: another. And it gives the fifth plan a synthetic timbre long absent, even ideologi-
label: Paragraph

text: cally opposed, for a very long time. One might imagine that, some time from now,
label: Paragraph

text: the fifth plan may enable architecture to appear whole again, as a reverberating
label: Paragraph

text: semblance of singularity.

text: INTERNATIONAL PASSENGER TERMINAL
label: Title

text: Life is, more than anything else, a tendency to act on inert matter. The direction of
label: Paragraph

text: this action is not predetermined; hence the unforeseeable variety of forms which life,
label: Paragraph

text: in evolving, sows along is path. Henri Bergson’
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture is not a plastic art, but the engineering of material life. Farshid Moussavi
label: Paragraph

text: and Alejandro Zaero-Polo.*
label: Paragraph

text: When they left Rem Koolhaas’ Office of Metropolitan Architecture in 1992,
label: Paragraph

text: Farshid Moussavi and Alejandro Zaera-Polo started Foreign Office Architects
label: Paragraph

text: (FOA), moving the practice to London to teach at the Architectural Association
label: Paragraph

text: (AA). The AA in the 1990s, under Chairman Alan Balfour and Jeffery Kipnis, Direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tor of the Graduate Design Program, was a crucible for experimental practice and
label: Paragraph

text: design research. Zaera-Polo and Moussavi were commissioned to run a three-year
label: Paragraph

text: research studio using international competitions to provide content for AA Files, the
label: Paragraph

text: in-house scholarly journal. The Yokohama Ferry Terminal was the product of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1994-95 competition to rebuild the 1894 Osanbashi Pier in the Japanese port city of
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama as an international passenger terminal.’ With their 1995 winning
label: Paragraph

text: scheme, FOA and their students took a decisive lead in the shift toward digital
label: Paragraph

text: design that no longer distinguished between ground and building mass, or between
label: Paragraph

text: surface and depth, section and plan.‘
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama was one of a number of competitions that brought young innovators
label: Paragraph

text: to public attention: Jussieu Libraries (1992, won by OMA); Cardiff Bay Opera
label: Paragraph

text: House (1994, won by Zaha Hadid); IIT Student Center (1997, won by OMA, with
label: Paragraph

text: significant entries from Eisenman and Resier Umimoto); West Side Convergence
label: Paragraph

text: for IFCCA (1999, notable projects by UN Studio and Resier Umimoto); and Eye
label: Paragraph

text: Beam Museum of Art and Technology (2001, notable projects Greg Lynn Form’s
label: Paragraph

text: bleb facade, D + S’s continuous surface, and Scott Cohen’s tensegrity circulation).
label: Paragraph

text: Significant to Yokohama was not just the cultural shift FOA’s winning proposal
label: Paragraph

text: indicated, but the ways in which the competition’s theme — the sea, fluid dynamics,
label: Paragraph

text: transportation interchanges, circulation-as-program, temporal flux, transitional
label: Title

text: space, hybrid programming — prompted invention. Reiser Umimoto’s similar
label: Paragraph

text: scheme, which folded public park and interior circulation through each other,
label: Paragraph

text: and OMA’s diagram of program intensities varying over time, are stand-outs,
label: Paragraph

text: and the competition enabled exploration of what Stan Allen was later to call “land-
label: Paragraph

text: form building” as never before. The postwar mat building had grown up, improved
label: Paragraph

text: its ideas about circulation, and understood that it was fundamentally an urban for-
label: Paragraph

text: mation, not simply a “city-within-a-city.”
label: Paragraph

text: At Harvard’s GSD, Zaera-Polo and Moussavi were taught computation by Bill
label: Paragraph

text: Mitchell and Branco Kolarevic. But surprisingly little else marked this new terri-
label: Paragraph

text: tory. The “paperless studio” would not be introduced at Columbia’s GSAPP until
label: Paragraph

text: 1994. OMA’s Jussieu Libraries entry had manifested in the modest Rotterdam
label: Paragraph

text: Kunsthal (1992). UN Studio’s 1993 Mobius House, the only single-surface project
label: Paragraph

text: yet built, was important. Coop Himmelb()au had, since the early 1980s, begun to
label: Paragraph

text: think of form as ‘scape, in which ground plane, roof, walls, skin were no longer
label: Paragraph

text: discrete.? Himmelb(1)au’s 1980 manifesto, “Architecture Must Blaze,” was a call
label: Paragraph

text: for non-orthogonal, non-Cartesean design that, like their earlier experiments of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s, were affective and sensational environments. The accompanying
label: Paragraph

text: “Blazing Wing” installation, a tessellated structural skin “clad” in flames, rejected
label: Paragraph

text: modernism and postmodernism in favor of dynamic, non-normative form.
label: Paragraph

text: Influential were Frank Gehry’s iterations of the unbuilt Lewis House (1989-95),
label: Paragraph

text: his Bilbao Guggenheim (1991-97), and the fish sculpture for the 1992 Barcelona
label: Paragraph

text: Olympics that led to the horse heads roughly contemporary with Yokohama
label: Paragraph

text: (1995-98). However, Gehry’s approach to fabrication — structure as gantry-support
label: Paragraph

text: for non-standard skins — was not the structural surface of UN Studio and FOA.
label: Paragraph

text: Herzog de Meuron, much admired by Moussavi and Zaera-Polo, had built the first
label: Paragraph

text: of their iconic signal boxes and begun the second, but these breaks from normative
label: Paragraph

text: geometry were not close to the daring of Yokohama. Peter Eisenman had barely
label: Paragraph

text: begun to leave the world of the trace with designs for the Church of the Year 2000
label: Paragraph

text: and Bibliotéque de L’IUHEI in 1996. Zaha Hadid’s Monsoon Restaurant and the
label: Paragraph

text: Vitra Fire Station of 1994 were still planar compositions if the signature landform
label: Paragraph

text: massing of her mature work was already present; her interest in hybridizing
label: Paragraph

text: ground, envelope, circulation, and surface emerged in the projects of 1997-99,
label: Paragraph

text: and were fully realized by 2000.
label: Paragraph

text: At the time of its submission, FOA’s Yokohama was a pioneer for the potential of
label: Paragraph

text: emerging digital tools that enabled parametric modeling of dynamic surfaces,
label: Paragraph

text: where the form of circulation became the form of the building as a whole. Event
label: Paragraph

text: and organization replaced program, adaptive envelope replaced facade, and digit-
label: Paragraph

text: ally manipulated surfaces replaced composition. The project, completed in 2002,
label: Paragraph

text: marked a paradigm shift that would itself take more than a decade to come to full
label: Paragraph

text: fruition.
label: Paragraph

text: Form to Formation
label: Title

text: An important precursor for Yokohama, close to the AA’s Bedford Square home,
label: Paragraph

text: was The Imagination Group’s London headquarters, designed by Ron Herron
label: Paragraph

text: in 1987.° Member of the avant-garde practice Archigram, Herron died in 1994
label: Paragraph

text: but was teaching at the AA when Moussavi and Zaera-Polo arrived. The tensile
label: Paragraph

text: roofscape, stretching across two existing buildings and a decommissioned street,
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen from the terraces in the middle of the AA complex: an undulating min-
label: Paragraph

text: imal surface structure that glows at night.’ Homage to Cedric Price’s unbuilt Fun
label: Paragraph

text: Palace (1960-62), and an embodiment of Archigram’s interest in flexible event-
label: Paragraph

text: based spaces (“instant cities”), the new roof creates an urban landscape that verti-
label: Paragraph

text: cally connects two buildings across six floors, linked by scaffolding walkways that
label: Paragraph

text: cross at random angles, and culminating in a gallery and event space on the
label: Paragraph

text: original roofs.
label: Caption

text: In Herron’s Imagination building was the urban theater that Price and his col-
label: Paragraph

text: laborator on the Fun Palace, theater director Joan Littlewood, envisioned as social
label: Paragraph

text: catalyst.® For Price, architects were not in the business of providing meaning or
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetics, nor of constructing architecture as a visual symbol. Anticipating Bernard
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi’s late 1970s coinage of the term “event space,” Price believed adaptive
label: Paragraph

text: environments should enable a range of changing programmatic potentials.
label: Paragraph

text: Tschumi’s notion of urban theater, developed at the AA under Alan Boyarsky
label: Paragraph

text: and inscribed in Manhattan Transcripts (1981)° and Event Cities (1994),'° and other
label: Paragraph

text: essays published in the 1980s and early 1990s, was predicated on the argument that
label: Paragraph

text: “there is no space without event.”’’ Following landscape architect Lawrence
label: Paragraph

text: Halperin’s “urban scoring” of the 1960s and 70s, Tschumi sought to “choreograph”
label: Paragraph

text: space. Form could no longer “follow function,” but had to enable flux and dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: change, catalyzing event and social encounter, and mediating, by interconnecting
label: Paragraph

text: ith, exterior climates, circulation patterns, urban organizations, and cultural and
label: Paragraph

text: social formations.

label: Title

text: Central to this thinking was Sanford Kwinter, whose course on complexity at
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard’s GSD influenced Zaera-Polo and Moussavi as students. His 1992 “Land-
label: Paragraph

text: scapes of Change,” which discussed Conrad Waddington’s “epigenetic landscape,”
label: Paragraph

text: developed in the late 1950s to describe the genetic influence of environmental
label: Paragraph

text: changes on a population.’* Rene Thom’s idea of “fitness landscapes” followed
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1970s — developmental space, within which organisms evolve, as topological
label: Paragraph

text: and dynamical models, accounting for the potential combination of chance and pre-
label: Paragraph

text: diction. Kwinter enabled “typology” to become “topology,” and “form” to become
label: Paragraph

text: “formation,” adapting, mutating, and evolving. Yokohama understood the surface-
label: Paragraph

text: landscape not just as a material form, but also as a formation of matter — of potential
label: Paragraph

text: pathways of development:
label: Title

text: The radicalization of matter requires that matter is from the beginning irreducibly
label: Paragraph

text: sensate and responsive; that at every scale sensate, responsive matter organizes itself
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchically into discreet, irreproducible configurations with specific emergent
label: Paragraph

text: behaviors; and that all discreet material configurations at any and every moment
label: Paragraph

text: and any and every scale further arrange into complex ecologies.’
label: Paragraph

text: In Phylogenesis, Moussavi and Zaera-Polo classified the office’s work as a
label: Paragraph

text: “population” of projects, both the figure for the culture of FOA’s practice and
label: Paragraph

text: its protocols and techniques — what they call its “genetic potentials.”** The
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century biologist, Ernst Haekel, introduced the term “phylum” to
label: Paragraph

text: group organisms around a “body plan” or blueprint — families of morphological
label: Paragraph

text: and developmental similarity.’ Zaera-Polo and Moussavi described their practice
label: Paragraph

text: “as a lineage of ideas that evolve through time and across different environments,”
label: Paragraph

text: a “phylogenetic process” generating “differentiated yet consistent organisms,”
label: Paragraph

text: organized in the 1990s around the phylum “surface.”!°
label: Paragraph

text: Formative Processes
label: Title

text: Moussavi notes in The Function of Ornament, “Architecture needs mechanisms that
label: Paragraph

text: allow it to become connected to culture.”!” The concept of the phylum — the dia-
label: Paragraph

text: grammatic lineage that creates a “culture” of work — for both Moussavi and Zaera-
label: Paragraph

text: Polo must be dynamic, adaptive, and responsive to cultural change. In the 1970s,
label: Paragraph

text: Denise Scott Brown and Robert Venturi compared the “duck” — the building as sym-
label: Paragraph

text: bol — with their preferred typology, “the decorated shed,” or the building as sign.'*
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama was a direct response: Zaera-Polo and Moussavi were taught by Scott
label: Paragraph

text: Brown at the GSD. The decorated shed rethought as mat building was a hybrid
label: Paragraph

text: of shed, ground, and circulation. The mat building, a term developed by Alison
label: Paragraph

text: and Peter Smithson, was the direct precursor of Yokohama’s shed-ground-flow
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid. Zaera-Polo and Moussavi described the mat typology as the organization
label: Paragraph

text: of circulation, with architecture then “deployed on the circulation diagram”; Yoko-
label: Paragraph

text: hama was to become more consistent — “in which circulation can literally shape
label: Paragraph

text: space,” an expression of “landscape urbanism,” a preoccupation of the 1990s.’*
label: Paragraph

text: Stan Allen, proponent of landscape urbanism, begins his “thick 2-D” manifesto
label: Paragraph

text: with an appraisal of Yokohama.”° A “porous mat of movement and waiting spaces,”
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama is a continuous surface of “differing intensities of occupation”: “Con-

text: ceived as an artificial landscape, minimal sectional variation separates and

text: smoothes traffic at the same time that it activates complex programmatic varia-
label: Paragraph

text: 21 Yokohama proposed that the urban condition operate as a thickened sur-
label: Paragraph

text: face in which “program” equated to moments of intensity in the network of the
label: Paragraph

text: urban field. As such, it was heir to Koolhaas’ notion of the continuous surface, first
label: Paragraph

text: proposed in his analysis of New York, and developed in the Jussieu Libraries and
label: Paragraph

text: Kunsthal. The “synthetic carpet” of “programmatic lava” was “a single program-
label: Paragraph

text: matic composition” in which the city and building each flowed into the other,
label: Paragraph

text: and which, in turn, embraced a wide heterogeneity of program.” For Koolhaas,
label: Paragraph

text: the continuous surface was an urban condenser — “smooth congestion” — and an
label: Paragraph

text: urban intensifier — “engineered disorientation” and “enforced detours”: “an
label: Paragraph

text: unforseeable and unstable combination of simultaneous activities.””*
label: Paragraph

text: Eisenman identifies Le Corbusier’s unbuilt 1964 Palais des Congres Strasbourg
label: Paragraph

text: as the source for floor as a ramp, which joins the ground and the roof in a contin-
label: Paragraph

text: uum.”* The ground delaminates and rises up through the building, marked as a
label: Paragraph

text: continuous urban condition by sectional variation, and by “vertical voids,” forces
label: Paragraph

text: tion.
label: Paragraph

text: that push up and out of the envelope.”* Yokohama, though a horizontal organiza-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, follows Jussieu Libraries’ development: “Koolhaas uses the void, which is con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceived as an inversion of poché ... by conceptualizing it as a latent force contained
label: Paragraph

text: between layers of solid floors ... Conceptually the circulation and the floor levels
label: Paragraph

text: become a continuous surface.”’° The continuous surface as the diagram of pure
label: Paragraph

text: circulation was confirmed by Stan Allen’s focus on “field conditions,” leitmotif
label: Paragraph

text: for landscape urbanism.” Allen’s shift from points and lines to waves and fields
label: Paragraph

text: was also heavily influenced by Kwinter’s 1987 essay on the post-relativity universe
label: Paragraph

text: in Zone 1/2: “an open, far-from equilibrium system, responsive to and willing to
label: Paragraph

text: amplify every destabilizing fluctuation in the environment.””* Yokohama is a clear
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation of form understood as a plastic and dynamic field of events, devel-
label: Paragraph

text: oped out of rhythms, movements, pulses, and flows, and their effects on form.””
label: Paragraph
