text: Surface
label: Title

text: Bernard Tschumi, describing The Manhattan Transcripts project (1976-81), notes,
label: Paragraph

text: “Architecture is not simply about space and form, but also about event, action, and
label: Paragraph

text: what happens in space.”’’ Successful public spaces emerge, they are not prescribed.
label: Paragraph

text: Christopher Alexander’s 1965 “A City is Not a Tree” contrasted the sterile
label: Paragraph

text: institutionalized playground “asphalted and fenced in,” to spaces which would
label: Paragraph

text: enable play:
label: Title

text: Play itself, the play that children practice, goes on somewhere different every day.
label: Paragraph

text: One day it may be indoors, another day ina friendly gas station, another day down by
label: Paragraph

text: the river, another day in a derelict building, another day ona construction site, which
label: Paragraph

text: has been abandoned for the weekend. Each of these play activities, and the objects it
label: Paragraph

text: requires, forms a system... The different systems overlap one another, and they over-
label: Paragraph

text: lap many other systems besides. The units, the physical places recognized as play
label: Paragraph

text: places, must do the same. In a natural city this is what happens. Play takes place
label: Paragraph

text: in a thousand places — it fills the interstices of adult life. As they play, children become
label: Paragraph

text: full of their surroundings.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander was interested in the interdependency of urban contexts and events.”
label: Paragraph

text: Buildings were to be organized as large-scale self-similar organizations, locally
label: Paragraph

text: adaptable microenvironments responding to patterns of behavior, allowing for
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of second-order effects. With multi-dimensional problems and
label: Paragraph

text: unpredictable circumstances, performative design processes produced “generative
label: Paragraph

text: results”: form as a set of algorithms, anti-figural, anti-representational, anti-monu-
label: Paragraph

text: mental, anti-typological. For Alexander, the city was an open, self-regulating,
label: Paragraph

text: complex system, not a closed hierarchy of discrete elements: a space of pure
label: Paragraph

text: and infinite connection, of networks, flows, and ecologies.
label: Paragraph

text: By thinking of the ferry terminal as an urban formation in these terms, FOA was
label: Paragraph

text: able to challenge the normative linear organization of piers, creating circulation
label: Paragraph

text: around multiple interconnected loops. This aim required the building to be
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as a model of fluid dynamics: an interweaving of flows with different
label: Paragraph

text: speeds, orientations, interferences, and eddies. Directional flows connecting points
label: Paragraph

text: of departure, arrival, and transfer could be diverted, bifurcating to other pathways,
label: Paragraph

text: or slowed, pooling into eddies of programmatic interference. What they termed a
label: Paragraph

text: “no-return diagram” involved branched interchanges and nested circuits, such that
label: Paragraph

text: visitors to the pier could circulate in either direction along many differing routes:
label: Paragraph

text: “In whatever direction the pier is travelled, the experience will be of a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: forward movement.”**
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama’s concept is surface-as-ground, rather than surface-as-envelope.
label: Paragraph

text: Conceived as a surface that delaminates then (re-)enfolds, the surface-as-ground
label: Paragraph

text: is a continuous but layered organization. As a “loosely bounded aggregate,” the
label: Paragraph

text: terminal complex was characterized by “porosity and local interconnectivity,”
label: Paragraph

text: and by emergent behaviors that self-organized into a coherent, if complex, matrix,
label: Paragraph

text: defined by inter-relating, local constraint.” These localized moments could be
label: Paragraph

text: rippled, pinched, or perforated in turn, but were above all sectional. As Allen
label: Paragraph

text: has written, “In field configurations section is not the product of stacking (discrete
label: Paragraph

text: layers, as in a conventional building section) but of weaving, warping, folding,
label: Paragraph

text: oozing, interlacing or knotting together.”’®
label: Paragraph

text: To translate circulation and surface into a three-dimensional organization, each
label: Paragraph

text: segment of the no-return diagram was assigned a surface of specific size, while each
label: Paragraph

text: branching node within the circulation network was assigned a bifurcation geom-
label: Paragraph

text: etry. The no-return diagram had to be assimilated to the surface-ground: a
label: Paragraph

text: branched network overlaid on a field. Program was intensive rather than extensive:
label: Paragraph

text: Conventional programmatic distribution is fundamentally related to an extensive use
label: Paragraph

text: of space and time: programs are allocated in particular extensions of space and time
label: Paragraph

text: with well-defined limits...The potential of intensive space is to set up a degree of
label: Paragraph

text: specificity without delimiting extensions.’”
label: Paragraph

text: Intensive space as a defining concept was, for Zaera-Polo and Moussavi, better
label: Paragraph

text: able to negotiate shifting or time-based programmatic conditions, by creating a
label: Paragraph

text: continuous but differential variation, not tied to size or volume, nor to fixed
label: Paragraph

text: locations or configurations:
label: Title

text: Programs link the flows to the overall scheme, where they become like sediments in
label: Paragraph

text: the channels created by the folds on the surface, which in turn integrates the seg-
label: Paragraph

text: ments of the program through continuous variation of form. Varying degrees of
label: Paragraph

text: intensity diminish the rigid segmentation that social machines — especially those that
label: Paragraph

text: maintain borders — usually produce.**
label: Paragraph

text: Changing diurnal and seasonal demands could thus be seamlessly accommo-
label: Paragraph

text: dated. To achieve this, immigration control had to be mobile: the border was estab-
label: Paragraph

text: lished not as a fixed line, but as a series of strategic control points, along the axis of
label: Paragraph

text: the building. Program, both interior and on the exterior roof deck, was contingent
label: Paragraph

text: on the specificities of the surface — curvature, access, exposure or insulation, visual
label: Paragraph

text: connection, adjacencies, and proximity. But more importantly, it was determined
label: Paragraph

text: by speed. Program adheres to slowness, to the locations in which flow eddies or
label: Paragraph

text: stagnates, to moments where circulatory paths are momentarily held, redirected,
label: Paragraph

text: or detoured.
label: Paragraph

text: Smooth Spaces
label: Title

text: Yokohama is a smooth continuum of surface, infrastructure, structure, material,
label: Paragraph

text: and program. In this, it is indebted to two iconic works of the postwar period: Frei-
label: Paragraph

text: derick Kiesler’s 1959 Endless House, a continuum of life’s cyclicality and rhythms;
label: Paragraph

text: and Erwin Hauer’s topological sculpture and screens of the 1950s—1970s. But math-
label: Paragraph

text: ematics, geometry, and rules of ordering (algorithms) have always been central to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, and the experimental search for non-standard geometries has existed
label: Paragraph

text: since at least the baroque. We could think of the surging, undulating dynamics of
label: Paragraph

text: Francesco Borromini’s San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane, or the sensual curvatures of
label: Paragraph

text: Balthazar Neumann’s Vierzehnheiligen Church, whose non-focal transept crossing
label: Paragraph

text: requires a series of compound curves that could only be modeled in 3-D, long
label: Paragraph

text: before parametric software.
label: Paragraph

text: The baroque attempted to synthesize the modular Renaissance church into a
label: Paragraph

text: single spatial experience, one, moreover, that was expressly dynamic. Interpene-
label: Paragraph

text: trating forms, “smooth” geometries, and complex three-dimensional bodies char-
label: Paragraph

text: acterize the baroque, based in geometric calculus.” Plasticity replaces the planar,
label: Paragraph

text: becoming “free form”: restless jumping forms, vibrating or “swaying” forms, on
label: Paragraph

text: the cusp of deformation, a dynamic condition in which masses remain in tension,
label: Paragraph

text: ina state of unrest or transience.*® The baroque building is a complex system: com-
label: Paragraph

text: plex geometries in a continuum, forms within forms, fluid morphing from element
label: Paragraph

text: to element, and continuous variation. For Sergei Eisenstein, in his famous essay
label: Paragraph

text: comparing different iterations of Piranesi’s Carceri, the Renaissance state of repose
label: Paragraph

text: and equilibrium transformed into baroque “ecstasy,” a transformation from a pro-
label: Paragraph

text: totype to a dynamic system organized by an intensification of effects: montage.*?
label: Paragraph

text: FOA’s Yokohama follows this logic, space and form once again relational:
label: Paragraph

text: No longer are objects plugged into space but they become relational objects with
label: Paragraph

text: intrinsic spatial constructs: space is not just containing, it is a network of relations;
label: Paragraph

text: space is not invariant but dynamic; and shape is space (localized and transmutable).’*
label: Paragraph

text: Space itself becomes “a restless matrix affecting, and affected by, the behaviors to
label: Paragraph

text: , oa a AZ ee le 7 a
label: Paragraph

text: emerging out of the field: moments of intensity, peaks or valleys, vortexes pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced within a continuous field, “defined not by overarching geometrical schemas
label: Paragraph

text: but by intricate local connections”: “Form matters, but not so much the forms of
label: Paragraph

text: things as the forms between things.”** Model of an “emergent metropolis as a
label: Paragraph

text: thick, living mat of accumulated patches and layered systems, with no singular
label: Paragraph

text: authority or control,” Yokohama is the opposite of the iconic civic monument.”
label: Paragraph

text: Form-as-ground is the diagram of Deleuze and Guattari’s “smooth space,” a
label: Paragraph

text: space of pure connection, the space of journeys — trajectories, movements, and
label: Paragraph

text: speeds. It is intensive space — temporal, contingent, and dynamic. The ocean
label: Paragraph

text: and the boat are both examples. Its opposite is striation. Striated space is of the
label: Paragraph

text: old order of Cartesian space, of the modular, extensive, territorializing grid;
label: Paragraph

text: smooth space is topological, non-standard intensive, continuous, heterogeneous,
label: Paragraph

text: rhizomatic, non-linear, modulated haptic, deterritorializing:
label: Paragraph

text: Contrary to what is sometimes said, one never sees from a distance in a space of this
label: Paragraph

text: kind, nor does one see it from a distance; one is never “in front of,” any more than
label: Paragraph

text: one is “in” (one is “on”...).”“°
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama’s smooth deformation of surfaces is picturesque — undulating board-
label: Paragraph

text: walks spliced with grassy knolls, timber and steel grottos festooned with handrails
label: Paragraph

text: and fishing nets, craggy cliffs of structural glass. The warped surface geometry of
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama, mediating between sea, cruise liner, and city, operates as a space that,
label: Paragraph

text: like the active picturesque of William Gilpin and Richard Payne Knight, opposes
label: Paragraph

text: the pictorial framing of territory, and of one’s place in it: it has to be moved
label: Paragraph

text: through, traversed, in order to be understood. This desire, which fueled the
label: Paragraph

text: “occluded landscapes” and Romantic ruins of the early nineteenth century, equally
label: Paragraph

text: motivated architecture’s embrace of parametric design tools, taken from the movie
label: Paragraph

text: industry and engineering, in the 1990s.*”
label: Paragraph

text: But Yokohama’s smooth space is perforated and striated. This is significant. For
label: Paragraph

text: many of their peers, smooth space, so easily generated by Maya or 3D Studio Max,
label: Paragraph

text: became a holy grail. But, as Deleuze and Guattari have insisted, smooth space and
label: Paragraph

text: striated space exist only in mixture: “Smooth space is constantly being translated,
label: Paragraph

text: transversed into a striated space; striated space is constantly being reversed,
label: Paragraph

text: returned to a smooth space. In the first case, one organizes even the desert; in
label: Paragraph

text: the second, the desert gains and grows; and the two can happen simultaneously.””*
label: Paragraph

text: Great Waves
label: Title

text: Origami is the perfect example of smooth and striated mixtures. It is, of course, a
label: Paragraph

text: traditional element of Japanese culture, easily identifiable in the West. But to view
label: Paragraph

text: origami as a cliché would be to miss an important point: computational origami has
label: Paragraph

text: for some time been a branch of computational geometry, and thus of enormous
label: Paragraph

text: in surface-structures, that is, surfaces that are also structural, with structure an inte-
label: Paragraph

text: grated aspect of surface deformations. Mathematical origami was developed in the
label: Paragraph

text: mid-twentieth century, to tackle problems of geometry traditionally unsolvable
label: Paragraph

text: using compass and straightedge that could easily and simply be solved by folding
label: Paragraph

text: paper. The first International Meeting of Origami Science and Technology was
label: Paragraph

text: held in Italy in 1989. In 1991, Italian-Japanese mathematician Humaiki Huzita
label: Paragraph

text: developed a sequence of increasingly complex origami axioms. By the turn of
label: Paragraph

text: the twenty-first century, computational origami had exploded.
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Jackson, who lived in London and taught techniques of origami to designers
label: Paragraph

text: there in the 1980s and 1990s, has argued:
label: Paragraph

text: All designers fold. That is, all designers crease, pleat, bend, hem, gather, knot, hinge,
label: Paragraph

text: corrugate, drape, twist, furl, crumple, collapse, wrinkle, facet, curve, or wrap
label: Paragraph

text: two-dimensional sheets of material, and by these processes of folding, create
label: Paragraph

text: three-dimensional objects.”
label: Paragraph

text: The original concept models for FOA’s ferry terminal competition used origami
label: Paragraph

text: tessellation to develop both structural principals and their integration with surface
label: Paragraph

text: deformations and perforations. Structure was developed by adjusting the surface
label: Paragraph

text: geometries, creating a gradient that shifted from the soft undulations of surface-
label: Paragraph

text: ground to sharper v-pleats and x-pleats, creating v-fold and x-fold spans.
label: Paragraph

text: This relationship Moussavi and Zaera-Polo referred to as a “metamorphic”
label: Paragraph

text: assemblage, “a hollowed ground where loads are not distributed by gravitational
label: Paragraph

text: force through columns ... but rather by displacing stresses through the folded sur-
label: Paragraph

text: face of the shell.”*° These folded span geometries are robust, adjustable, and able to
label: Paragraph

text: create single span shell structures that accommodate complex compound curves.
label: Paragraph

text: The folded shells also provide seismic performance. They are readily “unfolded,”
label: Paragraph

text: that is, able to be documented in 2-D cut sheets. Scale creates differentiation: tigh-
label: Paragraph

text: ter pleating where more robust structural support was needed on the one hand; on
label: Paragraph

text: the other, looser folds that scaled up to become girders where extra stiffening was
label: Paragraph

text: needed, within which were housed ramps, forming sectional connectors between
label: Paragraph

text: the layers, and thus perforations in each layer that became folds that created a
label: Paragraph

text: topological seamlessness of levels, like a Klein Bottle.
label: Paragraph

text: The second significant Japanese reference is to Katsushika Hokusai, artist of the
label: Paragraph

text: Edo period. His best known image is The Great Wave off Kanagawa of 1831, part
label: Paragraph

text: of his Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji. Influential on the development of Jugenstil
label: Paragraph

text: and Impressionism in Europe, Hokusai produced a number of prints depicting
label: Paragraph

text: wave formations, including Big Wave, Ocean Waves, views of Homoku and
label: Paragraph

text: Kajikazawa, and Feminine Wave and Masculine Wave, both intense inhabitations
label: Paragraph

text: of the interior of a breaking wave. These images, part of the collection of cultural
label: Paragraph

text: artifacts used to spur invention during the competition phase, helped determine
label: Paragraph

text: many aspects of the design, from the general undulation and bifurcation of the
label: Paragraph

text: evels, to localized details: the interiorized ramps, overhangs of curving
label: Paragraph

text: cantilevered deck, or the valleys and rolling hills of the roof deck, circulation, and
label: Paragraph

text: park spaces respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: Hokusai’s waves are early examples of images that capture movement, holding
label: Paragraph

text: in dynamic tension dramatic experiences. Later in the nineteenth century, in 1882,
label: Paragraph

text: EtienneJules Marey developed his chronophotography gun, which could capture
label: Paragraph

text: movement at 12 frames per second. The image sets produced were less simulta-
label: Paragraph

text: neous moments than diagrams of movement as continuous vectors of curvilinear
label: Paragraph

text: flow, or “phase portraits.” In 1899-1902, Marey shifted attention to capturing the
label: Paragraph

text: effects of interference and turbulence in air movement using smoke arrays. These
label: Paragraph

text: photographs were also diagrams — the first notations of fluid dynamics and aero-
label: Paragraph

text: dynamics — that tackled a new problem, one that would become crucial to air
label: Paragraph

text: travel: the flow of air around a surface. Studying the way air reacted to certain
label: Paragraph

text: forms, he focused on curvatures, examining interference patterns such as eddying,
label: Paragraph

text: turbulence, updrafts, and drag, by taking images at a rate of 100 frames a second.
label: Paragraph

text: Marey’s “graphic method” pioneered the study of curvature as the notation of force
label: Paragraph

text: and time, a demonstration of the way topological entities incorporate time and
label: Paragraph

text: motion into their shape through inflection.
label: Paragraph

text: Yokohama had to develop its own graphical method, most significant of which
label: Paragraph

text: was the serial section, which is of the same family as Marey’s serial images of
label: Paragraph

text: humans walking or birds in flight. The section set was not descriptive but gener-
label: Paragraph

text: ative: the complex single surfaces of each level were originally produced by detail-
label: Paragraph

text: ing local conditions every 15 meters, as transverse sections, which were then
label: Paragraph

text: overlaid and morphed along the building’s longitudinal axis. The single surface
label: Paragraph

text: was produced out of control lines, cuts that in turn generated gradients of topolog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical change. From this point on, the project was led by the “resolution” of the trans-
label: Paragraph

text: verse sectioning, which shifted from 15-meter intervals, to 3.6-meter, to 1.8-meter.
label: Paragraph

text: This technique effectively “built” three-dimensional form by mapping different dia-
label: Paragraph

text: grams and distributions to each other: surface deformation geometries to no-return
label: Title

text: diagram segments, surface bifurcations to no-return diagram branchings, and
label: Paragraph

text: so on.
label: Paragraph

text: Using large numbers of two-dimensional sections to create a three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: form was very much of the moment, and not just as a consequence of documenting
label: Paragraph

text: complex topological geometries. In 1989, the US National Library of Medicine
label: Paragraph

text: began the Visible Human Project, which documented a male and female human
label: Paragraph

text: cadaver by taking cross-sectional photographs at small intervals. The male data set
label: Paragraph

text: was completed in 1994, with 1,871 transverse sections taken at 1-millimeter
label: Paragraph

text: intervals; the female set was completed in 1995, taken at a finer resolution of
label: Paragraph

text: 0.33-millimeter intervals. Coinciding with the duration of the Yokohama compe-
label: Paragraph

text: tition, the completion of these data sets, and the stunning high-resolution images
label: Paragraph

text: produced, caused a sensation. Within the field of architecture, these serial sections
label: Paragraph

text: moved notation from diagram to model: the image sets constructed a virtual vis-
label: Paragraph

text: ualization, which, if compounded together, reconstructed the three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: body. Yokohama became the architectural emblem of this new mode of
label: Paragraph

text: visualization: the serial transverse sections often appeared alongside their com-
label: Paragraph

text: pounding, showing the ways in which the form of the building was “built” out
label: Paragraph

text: of these sections. Eventually, the systems had to evolve, moving from “a ‘raster’
label: Paragraph

text: space, where each point is determined by local information, to a vectorial space,
label: Paragraph

text: where each point is determined by differentiated global orders.””*
label: Paragraph

text: Arrival-Departures
label: Title

text: FOA’s Yokohama International Ferry Terminal subverts the typology of the trans-
label: Paragraph

text: portation pier. In doing so, it works against the “super-modernity” of the type, or
label: Paragraph

text: what Marc Augé referred to as “non-places.””” An influence on Koolhaas’ definition
label: Paragraph

text: of junk space, Augé’s non-place identified typologies in which “place” is replaced by
label: Paragraph

text: “space” — depersonalized, homogenous, transitory spaces, regimes of transit and
label: Paragraph

text: travel, technologies of communication, spaces of control and detention. These
label: Paragraph

text: are also spaces of abstract unmediated commerce and leisure. In them, people
label: Paragraph

text: are atomized: “community” is broken down into discrete, anonymous individuals —
label: Paragraph

text: “customers, passengers, users, listeners” — with all references to the temporality of
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior world removed. The international terminal, at once a border zone and
label: Paragraph

text: a transit space, with its restaurants and shops, parking and transfer points, decks and
label: Paragraph

text: parks, is the epitome of the non-place. The challenge, then, was to find a way to
label: Paragraph

text: reintroduce place into the generic space of interval and transience.
label: Paragraph

text: How did FOA achieve this? Through “the expression of embedded forces
label: Paragraph

text: through processes of construction, assembly and growth.””’ By thinking of a built
label: Paragraph

text: ground that was shifting and unstable, but that was also a critical component of an
label: Paragraph

text: urban organization, linked to the intense activity of Yokohama Bay, and projected
label: Paragraph

text: back into the city proper. By extending the city into the sea, with the civic facilities
label: Paragraph

text: as far along the pier as possible. And by shifting the terminal from a gate and con-
label: Paragraph

text: duit to an interface, one that replaced a linear circulation structure with a looping,
label: Paragraph

text: networked organization: “The structure becomes a warp in urban space, breaking
label: Paragraph

text: the polarity between citizens and visitors.”**
label: Paragraph

text: By 1999, Lynn had coined the term “animate form” to describe this approach to
label: Paragraph

text: morphology.”” Static architectural form becomes a dynamic formation, a field of
label: Paragraph

text: force and interaction characterized by “smooth transformation involving the inten-
label: Paragraph

text: sive integration of differences within a continuous yet heterogeneous system.””°
label: Paragraph

text: No building is ever static; it is a complex interplay of energy transfers and multiple
label: Paragraph

text: microclimates, all constantly modulating. As a ferry terminal, Yokohama was the
label: Paragraph

text: perfect infrastructural program for this thinking: “the abstract space of design is
label: Paragraph

text: imbued with flow, turbulence, viscosity, drag so that the form of a hull can be con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceived in motion through water.””” It was not an autonomous entity but a hybrid
label: Paragraph

text: organization, meshed to its environment, in a constant flux of thermodynamic and
label: Paragraph

text: socio-political intensities; the coming together of ship, sea, pier, city, and different
label: Paragraph

text: modes and vectors of transportation.

text: Kanazawa proposes a new paradigm in museum conception and design. Inscribed
label: Paragraph

text: in SANAA’s trajectory, this structure manages to reposition the art museum in
label: Paragraph

text: architectural culture, as it redefines its sense of space and materiality, its relation-
label: Paragraph

text: ship to the phenomena of exhibition and display, and its role in today’s society.
label: Paragraph

text: In the modern era, the newly conceived institution of the museum offered a spe-
label: Paragraph

text: cial opportunity for architects and urban designers to shape the spaces containing
label: Paragraph

text: and representing art and history. Originating as public institutions during the years
label: Paragraph

text: of the French Revolution, modern museums started by collecting and displaying
label: Paragraph

text: past artifacts, and thus became a designed incarnation of history. In this role of
label: Paragraph

text: securing a space to facilitate the encounter between citizens, the arts, and the past,
label: Paragraph

text: the museum turned out to be a most essential public building in the new expansions
label: Paragraph

text: of Western capital cities during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Designs
label: Paragraph

text: like Karl Friedrich Schinkel’s Altes Museum in Berlin, completed in 1830, fully
label: Paragraph

text: expressed the monumental quality of these new, secular cathedrals of art. The mag-
label: Paragraph

text: nificence and grandiosity of museums grew over the decades, and even in the sec-
label: Paragraph

text: ond half of the twentieth century, museum designs such as Mies van der Rohe’s
label: Paragraph

text: National Gallery in Berlin, built in 1968, would redefine the overwhelmingly large,
label: Paragraph

text: empty hall as the main space for the museum, conferring a quasi-religious solemnity
label: Paragraph

text: toa program otherwise based in displaying small-sized artifacts. Later museum pro-
label: Paragraph

text: jects have tended to break from the grandiosity and monumentality of their prede-
label: Paragraph

text: cessors, seeking new references. A case in point is that of the Georges Pompidou
label: Paragraph

text: Center in Paris, designed by Renzo Piano and Richard Rogers in the 1970s, which
label: Paragraph

text: equates the space for art to industrial and temporary structures.
label: Paragraph

text: This progressive inquiry into museum designs that would relate to other, new
label: Paragraph

text: references cannot be dissociated from the exploration that contemporary art has
label: Paragraph

text: undertaken on the conditions of display and public presentation of the artwork.
label: Paragraph

text: The museum also embodies a model of civic membership, of social identification,
label: Paragraph

text: and engagement in the presentation of artifacts. In this sense, SANAA’s different
label: Paragraph

text: designs for museums during the past two decades significantly contribute to this
label: Paragraph

text: process undertaken since the mid-twentieth century. Their galleries and art centers
label: Paragraph

text: reduce their material presence to a complex interplay of containers, glass or reflect-
label: Paragraph

text: ing surfaces, and a pervasive use of light tectonics that let them substantially depart
label: Paragraph

text: from the monumental tradition in museography.
label: Paragraph

text: One could argue, with the museology scholar, Jean-Louis Déotte, that the phe-
label: Paragraph

text: nomenon of a universal process of “museification” ofall sorts of sites and artifacts in
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary culture detracts from the museum being the only repository of
label: Paragraph

text: meaningful objects. In this perspective, any object, built place, even natural envi-
label: Paragraph

text: ronment, or non-material cultural expression, may be “museified” — that is, virtu-
label: Paragraph

text: ally decontextualized to coincide with its own display.’ The former contents of the
label: Paragraph

text: museum, therefore, explode to take over a universal presence, and the museum-
label: Paragraph

text: container inevitably remains as a much more profane structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet museum programs posed the challenge of providing magnificence to a large
label: Paragraph

text: collection that may suggest a repetitive series of galleries, housing hundreds or
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of items. How architecture handles this programmatic need has consti-
label: Paragraph

text: tuted a key question in the evolution of museum design.
label: Paragraph

text: Glass
label: Title

text: Kazuyo Sejima and Ryue Nishizawa, founders and partners at SANAA, have
label: Paragraph

text: worked on a number of designs for museographic institutions for the past 20 years.
label: Paragraph

text: The most significant and realized designs include the N Museum in Wakayama,
label: Paragraph

text: Japan (1995-97), the Glass Pavilion at the Toledo Museum of Art, Ohio
label: Caption

text: (2001-06), the New Museum of Contemporary Art in New York (2003-07), the
label: Paragraph

text: Serpentine Gallery Pavilion in London (2009), the Teshima Art Museum in Japan,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Louvre-Lens in Lens, France, completed in 2012.
label: Paragraph

text: Among these designs, the Kanazawa museum may be considered their first
label: Paragraph

text: major realized commission, designed and built between 1999 and 2004. In this case,
label: Paragraph

text: there was a close collaboration between the architects and the art director of the
label: Paragraph

text: institution, Yuko Hasegawa. Hasegawa wanted the museum to showcase recent
label: Paragraph

text: art, from 1980 onward, and at the same time to reflect the local, Kanazawa tradition
label: Paragraph

text: of pottery and craftwork, which has a smaller presence in the museum’s collection.
label: Paragraph

text: She coined the term “new flexibility” to refer to the spatial quality of the museum
label: Paragraph

text: as articulated through a large number of spaces of different size, instead of a few
label: Paragraph

text: large areas that could be partitioned in temporary ways.
label: Paragraph

text: This is a fresh concept in museographic design, and one that framed the resulting
label: Paragraph

text: decision of conceiving Kanazawa as a dense cluster of rooms. Any exhibition or
label: Paragraph

text: display would therefore need to be adapted to the sequence of rooms, which pro-
label: Paragraph

text: vide different conditions of volume, height, light, and so on. SANAA expressed that
label: Paragraph

text: this engagement of the museum’s director was crucial to the design process, and
label: Paragraph

text: was much appreciated by the architects. Indeed, Kazuyo Sejima pointed out during
label: Paragraph

text: an interview that new museums are too often designed before a museographic
label: Paragraph

text: project is in place. This programmatic vacuum translates into a tendency to overly
label: Paragraph

text: emphasize the need for flexibility in the architectural result, so that when the cura-
label: Paragraph

text: torial team would later start working on their project, the building would also need
label: Paragraph

text: to adapt to its spatial requirements. In Sejima’s words:
label: Paragraph

text: In Japan, the client usually requires that the architect create big exhibition spaces that
label: Paragraph

text: use movable walls, so we [SANAA and Hasegawa] decided against making two or
label: Paragraph

text: three big spaces and designed eighteen smaller spaces. The circulation is flexible,
label: Paragraph

text: so that she can arrange the exhibition spaces in different ways, according to the needs
label: Paragraph

text: of each show... This allows them to run separate, smaller shows simultaneously, or to
label: Paragraph

text: use the whole museum. It’s very different from the usual way of operating.’
label: Paragraph

text: The design started as a grouping of rectangular spaces of different sizes and
label: Paragraph

text: shapes, tightly clustered and held together by a circle in plan, a low cylinder that
label: Paragraph

text: constitutes the limit and facade of the building. In volume, the 18 rooms emerge
label: Paragraph

text: over the level of the general rooftop with different heights, so that the complex
label: Paragraph

text: appears as a micro-city contained by a disc of glass.
label: Paragraph

text: SANAA’s other museum designs also conceive the entire building as a grouping
label: Paragraph

text: of independent volumes. The New Museum in New York City appears as an irreg-
label: Paragraph

text: ular stacking of containers that make the structure look like a casually piled-up
label: Paragraph

text: series of boxes. On the other hand, the Toledo Museum of Art Glass Pavilion fol-
label: Paragraph

text: lows a spatial organization similar to Kanazawa, with a floor plan that contains
label: Paragraph

text: within a square 18 different spatial units — thus making the floor plan resemble
label: Paragraph

text: a complex yet neatly organized food tray. As a reference to the glass objects being
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited, all volumes are shaped with rounded edges, and this geometry allows for
label: Paragraph

text: a more fluid connection between the units.
label: Paragraph

text: As Akos Moravanszky has noted, the frequent use by SANAA of curved glass
label: Paragraph

text: vertical surfaces, especially for display purposes, seems to refer back to Lilly Reich’s
label: Paragraph

text: designs in collaboration with Mies van der Rohe, especially for the 12 large curved
label: Paragraph

text: glass plates presented in the mining industry section for “Deutsches Volk, Deutsche
label: Caption

text: Arbeit,” the first propaganda exhibition after the Nazi takeover in Berlin, 1934.’
label: Paragraph

text: SANAA have used this way of display repeatedly, especially in the exhibit of their
label: Paragraph

text: own work in the Leon Museum of Art, as well as in their intervention in the Ger-
label: Paragraph

text: man Pavilion in Barcelona. Some existing techniques of ephemeral display, there-
label: Paragraph

text: fore, are incorporated into their permanent galleries. In this way, the museum
label: Paragraph

text: comes closer to the temporary condition of the display design and, architecturally
label: Paragraph

text: speaking, of the pavilion.
label: Paragraph

text: The “collection” of box-like volumes at Kazanawa results ina variety of naturally
label: Paragraph

text: lit spaces, ranging from the four open courtyards to the diverse galleries offering
label: Paragraph

text: different skylight solutions that combine with changing sizes and ceiling heights.
label: Paragraph

text: The repertoire of rooms should allow for any art exhibit to find the right space.
label: Paragraph

text: Photographs
label: Title

text: SANAA’s interest in reflecting surfaces is a constant design element throughout
label: Paragraph

text: their work. Their first art gallery, the N Museum in Wakayama, consists of a sus-
label: Paragraph

text: pended, horizontal prism of glass that acts as a large-scale mirror in front of the city
label: Paragraph

text: and surrounding landscape. So as not to break the continuous reflecting surface, the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design introduces a complex, rear ramp entrance that remains invis-
label: Paragraph

text: ible from the front of the building.
label: Caption

text: Sejima and Nishizawa pay a special attention to the photography of their archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture. Over time, they have selected a few photographers and have closely col-
label: Paragraph

text: laborated with them toward certain results. A common effect in the photography of
label: Paragraph

text: SANAA’s spaces is an intense white light that powerfully bleaches all interiors. The
label: Paragraph

text: qualities of their spaces reside in the transparency of surfaces, an augmented pres-
label: Paragraph

text: ence of natural light, and the ubiquitous location of white planes that maximize the
label: Paragraph

text: made invisible. An interesting precedent is their proposal for the new Campus Cen-
label: Paragraph

text: ter for the Illinois Institute of Technology (1997-98):
label: Paragraph

text: We selected a very small, thin column and very thick glass for the partitions. We
label: Paragraph

text: wanted to study an idea of reducing the usual hierarchy between structure and par-
label: Paragraph

text: tition, where the structure comes first and partitions are infill. So we tried to make
label: Paragraph

text: the structure disappear and the partitions very thick and heavy.’
label: Paragraph

text: In Kazanawa, SANAA chose to introduce a series of extremely slender columns
label: Paragraph

text: on the facade. The photographers selected to work on the Kazanawa museum were
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Niedermayr, Luisa Lambri, and Takashi Homma. Their work was dis-
label: Paragraph

text: played and published at the time of the opening of the museum. Niedermayr pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced interior and exterior images with a strong, bleached white light that lets
label: Paragraph

text: certain colored objects — furniture, visitors, some art work, greenery — stand out
label: Paragraph

text: in a white space with few references. Luisa Lambri focused on a few windows
label: Paragraph

text: and doors, where the images reflected on the glass surface translate into a different
label: Paragraph

text: color distortion that brings them close to the white of the building surfaces. With a
label: Paragraph

text: different approach, Takashi Homma focused on recording the construction proc-
label: Paragraph

text: ess, with images that show the snowed, white surface of the construction site
label: Paragraph

text: before it was broken in, then the layering of horizontal surfaces and materials, from
label: Paragraph

text: concrete to the layers of insulation and paving, to end with a snowed, white over-
label: Paragraph

text: view of the building that connects with the initial photograph of the site.
label: Caption

text: Pavilions
label: Title

text: In two recent temporary installations in London and Barcelona, SANAA designed
label: Paragraph

text: structures that were based on producing a reflecting effect on the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, echoing the previous experiences in Kanazawa and other art centers. These
label: Paragraph

text: two installations shared the common architectural theme of the pavilion, whether
label: Paragraph

text: it was about inscribing a temporary element in a temporary pavilion, or creating a
label: Paragraph

text: new one that would mirror the Serpentine Gallery as a pavilion-like structure in
label: Paragraph

text: Kensington Gardens.
label: Paragraph

text: The pavilion, with a name that derives from the Latin papilio, or butterfly, con-
label: Paragraph

text: tains the sense of ephemerality in space. Its originary use in landscape design cap-
label: Paragraph

text: tured the transitory character of its use, briefly along an itinerary. The pavilion is
label: Paragraph

text: based on lightness, as well as on an architecture conceived in visual terms, as con-
label: Paragraph

text: stituting part of a visual parallax, of offering and framing a point of vision, a per-
label: Paragraph

text: spective, in an open landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: At the German Pavilion in Barcelona, designed by Mies van der Rohe, SANAA
label: Paragraph

text: introduced a free-standing acrylic curtain spiraling and defining an interior space
label: Paragraph

text: within the glass volume of the pavilion itself. The transparent acrylic surface
label: Paragraph

text: was positioned facing the main glass facade of the building, thus engaging in a rich
label: Paragraph

text: as a mirror that reflected the already reflecting surfaces of glass, marble, and stain-
label: Paragraph

text: less steel.
label: Paragraph

text: The Serpentine Gallery Pavilion was a light, open structure that provided a
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting ceiling made of polished aluminum, a horizontal mirror suspended
label: Caption

text: above the heads of the visitors, reflecting the green surface of Kensington Gardens —
label: Paragraph

text: and the blue of the sky on its upper surface. One cannot avoid thinking of the hor-
label: Paragraph

text: izontal mirroring effects of Mies’ pavilion, with its still pools of water, and the many
label: Paragraph

text: symmetries between horizontal surfaces.”
label: Paragraph

text: Mirrors
label: Title

text: Returning to the museum designs, the Toledo Glass Pavilion creates a transparent
label: Paragraph

text: labyrinth made of rounded glass rooms wrapped in two separate layers of glass,
label: Paragraph

text: setting up a contrasting effect between the galleries and the fluid interstitial spaces
label: Paragraph

text: that separate them. Here, as in other SANAA designs for displays, the transparent
label: Paragraph

text: surface is acting as a curtain that sometimes wraps the visitors, sometimes the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited objects. In their own renderings of the architectural designs, SANAA
label: Paragraph

text: strongly emphasize the reflected images, which often tend to mirror the surround-
label: Paragraph

text: ing landscape. In the case of the Louvre-Lens, the exterior views strongly represent
label: Paragraph

text: the mirrored landscape, to the extent of making the building disappear. This is a
label: Paragraph

text: gesture that reminds us of Dan Graham’s series of pavilions, small-scale outdoor
label: Paragraph

text: constructions positioned in the middle of landscapes, mostly made of glass and one-
label: Paragraph

text: way mirror surfaces. Therefore, they dissolve in their environment, becoming mul-
label: Paragraph

text: tipliers of their context. Graham’s pavilions act as devices that visually interfere and
label: Paragraph

text: disappear in their locations. These pavilions provide a frame for their users to vis-
label: Paragraph

text: ualize the surrounding landscapes. This visualization takes place through a thin,
label: Paragraph

text: almost immaterial layer that defines an interior space from an exterior one — some-
label: Paragraph

text: times with degrees of ambiguity. Graham’s structures often may be termed as a
label: Paragraph

text: “minimal presence,” a purely visualizing device with an extremely light structure
label: Paragraph

text: that is sufficient to support it.
label: Paragraph

text: Dan Graham’s and Mies van der Rohe’s pavilions have a strong presence in
label: Paragraph

text: SANAA’s design through the use of reflecting surfaces, of mirroring volumes.
label: Paragraph

text: Regarding Kanazawa, Sejima stated that the choice of a circular plan and a circular
label: Paragraph

text: facade was a way to erase its monumental presence: “Avoiding a main entrance
label: Paragraph

text: makes it less monumental, less of a building. It can dissolve into the surround-
label: Paragraph

text: ings.”® Asked about the concept of pavilions, and how it exists in Japanese culture,
label: Paragraph

text: Kazuyo Sejima responded that “small kiosks within nature exist historically in
label: Paragraph

text: Japan, but also in Europe,” and that “dissolving the edge of interior space is some-
label: Paragraph

text: thing we are interested in, in our own work. It is easier to realize this in pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: design than in most other building types, so we really enjoy it.””
label: Paragraph

text: Museums tend to be structures highly charged with a public, representational
label: Paragraph

text: role. The cathedrals of the modern world, as they have been termed, museums
label: Paragraph

text: offer an opportunity to architecture to display its most symbolic and often monu-
label: Paragraph

text: mental face. SANAA, through their many museum designs, have avoided any form
label: Paragraph

text: of monumentality and have approximated their museum designs to the pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: type, which necessarily refers to concepts of ephemerality, visual and narrative
label: Paragraph

text: dependence on its surrounding landscapes, even a playful or recreational use. Pavi-
label: Paragraph

text: lions are not dwellings; they are just temporarily inhabited kiosks that punctuate a
label: Paragraph

text: much larger itinerary.
label: Paragraph

text: SANAA’s design decisions and their fortune in our society are also revealing
label: Paragraph

text: about the changing nature of museums, and by extension, of public structures.
label: Paragraph

text: As museographic institutions have become less the cenotaphs of massive archeo-
label: Paragraph

text: logical collections and more the transitional spaces where art is temporarily dis-
label: Paragraph

text: played, their architecture needs to express this change. An interesting reference
label: Paragraph

text: is Jean Nouvel’s design for an art center, the Foundation Cartier in Paris. One
label: Paragraph

text: of its main design decisions was to create a free-standing glass facade toward the
label: Paragraph

text: street, whereas the building stands at a distance behind this surface of glass. It evi-
label: Paragraph

text: denced that the logic of display as we know it through shop windows and art cases
label: Paragraph

text: was extended to the entire structure, similarly “displayed” to the whole city.
label: Paragraph

text: The pavilion may be seen emerging as the new type for public architecture, par-
label: Paragraph

text: ticularly for museums and exhibition centers. In Kanazawa, we do not find a highly
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchized architecture, but rather what seems to be a randomly put together
label: Paragraph

text: archipelago of box-like galleries — a perfect circle embraces and frames a clutter
label: Paragraph

text: of diverse, seemingly unrelated spaces. Its plan reminds us of a concentration of
label: Paragraph

text: different-sized paintings on a gallery wall, or an accumulation of items as shown
label: Paragraph

text: in collections, holdings, displays. From John Soane’s house-museum to Christian
label: Paragraph

text: Boltanski’s accumulations of portraits and historical evidences, collecting may
label: Paragraph

text: be portrayed in the sheer piling of materials. The Kanazawa museum similarly reg-
label: Paragraph

text: isters and articulates a resonance between its condition as a collection and its many
label: Paragraph

text: spaces as an accidental grouping of different galleries.
label: Paragraph

text: n Marshall McLuhan’s hands, the story of Echo and Narcissus is a cautionary tale. For
label: Paragraph

text: McLuhan, Narcissus’ inability to enter into genuine dialogue with Echo is the result of
label: Paragraph

text: a narcosis or numbness (the etymological root of his name) born of the experience
label: Paragraph

text: of gazing at a replicated image. McLuhan concludes: “He was numb. He had adapted
label: Paragraph

text: to his extension of himself and had become a closed system.” For McLuhan, this
label: Paragraph

text: closed system of the likeness, the copy, or the replication, is theorized as a form
label: Paragraph

text: of “autoamputation,” and he classifies all inventions and technologies as “self
label: Paragraph

text: amputations of our physical bodies.” McLuhan’s interpretation of the myth of Echo
label: Paragraph

text: and Narcissus begs the question of whether there are technologies and inventions
label: Paragraph

text: in Mackintosh’s oeuvre that constitute similar forms of autoamputation, facilitating
label: Paragraph

text: the experience of numbness in the presence of the replicated image. Like McLuhan,
label: Paragraph

text: scholars refer explicitly to the alphabet and to the practice of writing as technological
label: Paragraph

text: extensions of the self. See, Luther H. Martin, Huck Gutman, and Patrick H. Hutton,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: acoustic space and echo theory, a lone figure stands parallel to a long wall with five
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: amore, more, ove, re. Kircher’s diagram is not simply an illustration of the dissipation of
label: Paragraph

text: sound as it ricochets from one hard surface to another, but rather, it is a testament to
label: Paragraph

text: the re-presentation of sound that is latent within the echo. For each of the auditory
label: Paragraph

text: One way to situate Mackintosh’s white period, as it paralleled a similar tendency in
label: Paragraph

text: the Vienna Secession, is to examine it through the a posteriori historiography of the

text: Viennese architectural historian Emil Kaufmann and his 1933 publication of Von
label: Title

text: Ledoux bis Le Corbusier (From Ledoux to Le Corbusier). Kaufmann’s work in tracing
label: Paragraph

text: a continuous lineage from Ledoux to Le Corbusier is germane to this narrative as
label: Paragraph

text: he is the first to have coined the term “autonomen Architektur” (autonomous archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture); he described an architecture of isolation “isolierenden Architektur,” parallel-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the emergence of modern individualism; and though not an explicit argument of
label: Paragraph

text: his text, the implicit continuity of the architectural tradition extending from the neo-
label: Paragraph

text: classicism of Ledoux to the modernism of Le Corbusier, is the principle of mono-
label: Paragraph

text: chromy. In Kaufmann’s agile narrative, the abstraction of neoclassical form yields
label: Paragraph

text: to the whiteness of high modernism, as monochromy becomes the operative sub-
label: Paragraph

text: strate of formal abstraction, autonomy, individualism, de-contextualism, and pristine
label: Paragraph

text: anachronism. Though Kaufmann’s progressive narrative had many detractors, Meyer
label: Paragraph

text: Schapiro and Hans Sedlmayr among them, it positioned whiteness to become oper-
label: Paragraph

text: ative in modernist design and discourse: whiteness embodies principles of abstraction
label: Title

text: and autonomy; whiteness connotes novelty, newness or a pristine condition; white-
label: Paragraph

text: ness imbues an ensemble of elements with cohesion; and importantly for this narra-
label: Paragraph

text: tive, whiteness is a vehicle of displacement, rejecting mimetic tendencies, and
label: Paragraph

text: proffering an abstract moment of totalizing synthesis in its place. See Anthony Vidler,

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Like many earlier plans for Tokyo, the Capital Region Development Plan was not very
label: Paragraph

text: successful. Tokyo’s urban sprawl grew so quickly that many of the restrictions specified
label: Paragraph

text: in the plan soon became outdated and were abandoned. In 1965, a revised master plan
label: Paragraph

text: erased the greenbelt altogether and offered this zone for suburban growth. In the
label: Paragraph

text: meantime, the outer boundary of the capital region was substantially extended.

text: 8 The 1960s and 1970s
label: Title

text: found its most influential celebration. Among the 20 facades that were staged along
label: Paragraph

text: the interior street of the Corderie dell’ Arsenale, two contributions set themselves
label: Paragraph

text: apart: the installations of Rem Koolhaas and Frank Gehry. With their non-
label: Paragraph

text: conformity in mind, the 1960s and 1970s might best be understood as one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most contentious and, therefore, productive periods of the twentieth century.
label: Paragraph

text: For that reason alone these years might hold the key to many of today’s misunder-
label: Paragraph

text: standings, for going beyond the modern was then as much about a return to the past
label: Paragraph

text: as about a different conception of the future — the one that we have inherited.

text: recently revisited the park for the first time in 20 years. It was a cold gray December
label: Paragraph

text: day and I was struck by how little thought I gave to what the park has meant, what
label: Paragraph

text: sponsored its design, or the discourses it has participated in. During my visit and since,
label: Paragraph

text: am much more interested in what the park design has, and can, enable. | walked both
label: Paragraph

text: axial galleries that linked the park spaces and facilities. I followed the faded blue tile trail
label: Paragraph

text: through the thematic gardens, many of which have filled in nicely. The park’s meander
label: Paragraph

text: was not unlike Olmsted’s ramble in Central Park: sinuous, nested, apart from the city.
label: Paragraph

text: climbed in and out of the folies, despite the deterioration most have endured. As the
label: Paragraph

text: day unfolded I witnessed great diversity, from vast openness to sensual enclosure, intri-
label: Paragraph

text: cate detail to neutral expanses, groups of boisterous school children to lovers hidden in
label: Paragraph

text: the gardens. I also noted the park’s strong edges, reinforced by parking lots and service
label: Paragraph

text: acilities. It felt less an extension of the city than a city within the city — a microcosm,
label: Paragraph

text: really. Yet certain systems breach the park’s edges. The galleries extend to metro stops
label: Paragraph

text: in one direction, and, following the canal, to Ledoux’s tollhouse and the suburbs in the
label: Paragraph

text: other. Although the park is organized by superimposed systems, they are not experi-
label: Paragraph

text: enced as such. Indeed the collision of systems produces fragmentary places (the shape
label: Paragraph

text: ofa garden), odd moments (when a stair slams through a folie), and indexical conditions
label: Paragraph

text: (where paving patterns register the meeting of a grid and a sinuous line). Change is
label: Paragraph

text: evident. And slow. The Philharmonie de Paris by Jean Nouvel is taking over the park-
label: Paragraph

text: ing on the east side. The dragon garden is being redesigned. The folies are weathering,
label: Paragraph

text: and many are empty or, worse, cordoned off. | was unable to climb the belvedere, that
label: Paragraph
